Service was friendly and decently attentive, although the wait for our main courses was a tad longer than expected. There was also no tasting poured for the wine that I ordered; the full glass was simply plopped on the table, which was somewhat surprising. 

Overall, Boulevard pulls together a solid fine dining experience, and I wouldn't mind returning to try some of their other dishes.
author: Oliver L.

description:
Went there for dinner while visiting in town. Our party of five each had different entree and they were all good. The fishes were fine, but the lamb was really something to get. I'm not much of a lamb guy but the smell was tolerable for me and it was tender and juicy so I was impressed. Gotta love the atmosphere there, although the restrooms are a bit far away, but you can take the elevator down and take the stairs back so you can see their Michelin stars on the wall. 

Moving on to desserts, again, not much of a chocolate dessert guy here, but the Choco-Licious tasted really good, not overwhelming at all. The lemon tart thing was also recommended, the sourness was all I needed to freshen all the courses that I had that evening. 

Final tip, for those who weren't local. Use the restaurant valet instead of finding street parking (especially not the one next to the bridge). There were people smashing car windows on two sides of the street near by, leaving trails of shattered glasses, and people's stuffs got stolen and apparently it's common in SF!
author: Ian H.

description:
I come here quite frequently but wanted to update my review.

We had Jeff as a server, and he gets 5 stars.  What an awesome experience! He was super attentive, have great recommendations, and didn't rush us. He was really wonderful.

Also, I had the calamari & scallops appetizer. This must be new on the menu, and it's awesome! It's served under a bed of polenta. Mmmmmmmmmm yum! 

Bottom line is that you can never go wrong here. It's consistently one of the best restaurants in town.
author: Taylor L.

description:
I came here on my BF's company's dime for lunch last fall (Thanks!). The ambiance is what you would expect for a FIDI crowd: a lot of older men in suits. A bit stuffy and old fashioned for my liking, but understand the allure that other people might find in it.  

We had a reservation so we were seated immediately. We decided on splitting several appetizers and one main so that we could try as much as possible: 

Ahi Tuna Tartare Two Ways: This is one of the most beautifully presented dishes I've ever seen. However, the taste has much to be desired. The tuna was fresh enough, but the taro chips were a bit oily and the ingredients failed to add much flavor. 

Mixed Lettuce Salad with Poached Seckle Pear: I believe this is a seasonal item, but in my opinion is should be on their regular menu. The candied walnuts and persimmons elevated the salad. It's never a good thing when my favorite dish of the meal is the salad, but in the case, I'll forgive Boulevard because this salad was just so good!

Seared Day Boat Sea Scallops: This was served with a base of succotash of corn and beans and heirloom tomatoes. This dish was a bit heavy and nothing too special in my opinion. In my opinion, scallops are hard to mess up so if you're going to serve it, it should be accompanied with amazing flavors. This was not. 

Grilled Hawaiian Walu: For the main, we selected the fish garnished with roasted radicchio fennel, grapefruit, pomegranate relish, and crispy potatoes with creme fraiche. Everything about this dish was disappointing. I'm not too familiar with Walu, but I have had Roy's Misoyaki Butterfish several times and consider it far superior than Boulevard's fish course. This Walu did not melt in my mouth or have the same silky texture as Roy's. Nor did it make up for it in flavor. The grapefruit and radicchio were an odd combination and the creme fraiche was too heavy. The only thing I appreciated about the dish were pomegranate seeds, which I could purchase at a Safeway for $2. 

When it came time to order dessert, the waitress was nowhere to be found. I tried flagging one down several times, giving up to use the restroom and leaving my BF with instructions of what to order. When I came back, a waitress STILL had not stopped by. By that time, I was already late going back to the office, so we paid and left dessert-less. I was already disappointed in the meal, and the utter lack of service at the end confirmed my opinion: this place is way overpriced for what you are getting. Do yourself a favor and go to La Mar (one of my fave sit-down restaurants on the waterfront) instead.
author: Sophia V.

description:
Had such a late dinner for my sister's 21st birthday but totally worth it! It's quite casual in appearance but the food is quite the opposite! Well plated and thought out. 

---Dishes we ordered---
Appetizers: 
- Calamari stuffed with lobster & shiitake: interesting combination of different seafoods. My dad says its similar to a chinese dish that also stuffs various ingredients into calamari. I loved the chewiness of the calamari mixed with the tenderness of the stuffing. 
- wild boar & hand rolled pasta: so good! They cooked the pasta JUST right (al dente) and it was super chewy. The sauce was not overpowering but definitely enhanced the flavor of the pasta and wild boar. 
- Dungeness Crab Salad: sort of bland and nothing special. But if you love crab, not a bad choice
- Scallops & Dungeness Crab Panzanella: The scallops were cooked well so that they were tender but not overcooked. My sister LOVED the polenta and devoured the entire plate's worth.

Entrees: 
- Petrale Sole: so tender!! I LOVED this dish where it was slightly crunchy on the top but super soft and juicy when you take a bite of it. Too perfect!
- Sea bass: Actually thought this was swordfish because it was so chewy. But definitely had a good flavor to it that is unique to this type of sea bass. I would recommend this after the sole if you're looking for a fish.
- Pork Prime Rib Chop: One of their best dishes, my brother cleaned his plate up. The pork chop isn't over cooked at all. 
- Lamb T-bone: SO GOOD! If you're a lover of lamb, this is the dish for you. Cooked perfectly medium rare and full of juice!

Also, they have a $30 corkage fee if you want to bring your own wine. Definitely worth it in comparison to their prices on the wine list.
author: Chloe Y.

description: This was my first time back to Boulevard in over 4 years and it was still just as good as I remember. For an appetizer, I would suggest the beet, heirloom tomato and blue cheese salad. It was a light enough starter, but still hearty with the blue cheese. For a main dish, the salmon was a great option. It was cooked to perfection, as expected, and came with chanterelle mushrooms and a beetroot risotto. The group I was with also raved about the lamb, so if you are more of a meat eater, I don't suspect you could go wrong. I went with a bunch of industry people, so during out meal both the sommelier and chef came over to the table to talk about the food which was a nice touch. We opted out of dessert (their Patron cocktails were our dessert!) but still several showed up to the table and were enjoyed.
author: Hayley H.

description: The Boulevard is hands down the best restaurant in San Francisco. Their menu rotates often, but they always have unbelievable options. Save room for dessert and coffee because it's definitely someone you should try while you're there. They have an incredible pastry chef!
author: Kristin J.

description: We dined here for a special occasion. We arrived a little late for our reservation so we grabbed a drink at the bar. The gentleman who served us could not have been friendlier and I wish we would have just dined in the bar area. Upon seating our server greeted us and from that point forward the rest of our dinner just seemed very transactional. Our server asked if we would like another drink while our current drink was half full, when we didn't order any more alcoholic beverages it seemed as though our server could care less about us. The table behind us had four people ordering multiple expensive bottles of wine and it was very clear that she was very attentive to them, which is totally acceptable but I don't feel like she should have totally snubbed us. I have to say the abalone calamari was absolutely amazing.  My fiancé had the duck and really enjoyed it. I decided to order a starter as my entree as I typically do when we are out of town because entrees tend to be to large of servings. When I told her I would have the risotto, she definitely made it a point to say I was ordering an appetizer. Once we had our main course she asked again if we wanted wine or a half glass of wine, which just made us feel super awkward as this was the third time she asked to get us a drink. We ordered dessert which was ok, definitely not a wow factor for the price of dessert ($11 & $12). So I would say if you want to spend $500+ on dinner your experience will probably be top notch, but spending $200 is definitely not enough to get quality service. If we decide to go back we probably just sit at the bar as the bartender was a true gem, and genuine.
author: Steph L.

description:
We've been to the Boulevard many times!!  First of all, the ambience of this restaurant makes it remarkably charming.  Most of the tables are for small groups of 4 or less.  I wouldn't recommend for larger parties.  
This past time we were in, I had the flu and our waiter was so nice to find me a soup for dinner.  I wish I could remember his name...
Everyone else in the party had a wonderful dinner.  The presentation is always amazing.
I highly recommend this restaurant!!
author: Catherine C.

description:
Boulevard doesn't need another 5-star review but here it comes: beautiful, intimate, cozy with big town feel, the food and wines are home runs every single visit.  Why does it win Best Restaurant in SF (Best of the Bay, The Guardian) almost every single year?  Go there and you'll vote for it also, as the service is impeccable, the kitchen is like a Swiss clock with its pace of food service, and the food is fresh, creative, brilliantly simple but classic and comforting.  And the portions are nicely sized, not too big or too small!  

The envy of 99.9% of restauranteurs, Boulevard is what everyone else aspires to become, an almost-perfect restaurant every single meal and every day.  WOW is all I can say and I've been coming here for 15 years.  My colleague from San Diego was blown away by this place at a recent lunch and has sworn now to trust me with all things food whilst in the Bay area.  Five stars all day long....  my fave joint in SF, and 20 seconds off the Embarcadero, so walking off these awesome meals is a pleasure in itself.  You will see blue jeans and you'll also see Armani and Chanel in the same visit, so just sit back with a nice glass of wine and enjoy everything Boulevard!
author: David C.

description:
One of the most epic and San Francisco -esque dining experiences you could have. Located off the Embarcadero, this place offers the kind of dinner experience everyone should have. The views are stunning and the food and wine list are legit. Seasonal, very fresh flavor round out the food. The decor, food and the patrons are elegant and classy. I've been here on several occasions and service has ways been top notch. One time I sat at bar by the kitchen and watching the well oiled machine that is the kitchen was a neat experience. 

As far as the food, I usually get anything for the sea. The calamari, scallops and crab are all fantastic. You really can't go wrong with  anything on the menu, although I've never had any meat dishes. This is also a great place to take a date. Although it can get loud, it's very romantic and the decor is beautiful.
author: Sam W.

description: To be honest, I gotta say, good waiter service but the dishes arent the best in SF and if this were in LA. I wouldnt even went there except for the hot waitress. The the prime pork steak, has an taste of dry drenchness and not full of ap.
author: Jason X.

description: Three stars only because decor and service was great.  After reading reviews we thought food would be special but it was very average.  Appetizer was plain: avocado and crab nothing special.  Pork chop was dry and without much taste.  Splendid spot---tourist trap.
author: Carol S.

description:
So I can't really add anymore to the great reviews already on yelp...

Service was attentive and friendly.  No complaints!

Food was delicious.  The pork rib caps tasted better than the tartare, the tartare was not that  memorable. 

Wish I could afford to go back.
author: C L.

description:
A bastion of fine dining in The City for 20 years, Nancy Oakes' Boulevard continues to amaze.

The French Mansard style of the historic Audiffred Building where Boulevard is located sets the tone from the onset: diners are in for an awesome experience.  With dark wood, finely crafted iron work and mosaic floors, the dining room reinforces that idea.

The menu is a tribute to the bounty of fresh, local ingredients that the Bay Area has to offer.  Served with polenta al nero, uni and Mangalitsa lard, the Nantucket scallops and local dungeness crab, ($16.50) were sweet and succulent.  The creamy richness of the cheese was a wonderful foil for the tangy acidity of the blanco grapefruit in the burrata, roasted beet, and citrus salad ($14.25).  Roasted in the wood-fired oven, the Eden Valley Berkshire pork prime rib chop ($37) served with smoked pork belly and apple agrodolce and Yukon gold potatoes with mustard and Douglas fir sautéed erbette chard and Tokyo turnips was perfectly cooked, moist and juicy.  Served with Sicilian pistachios, roasted hamada grapes, cauliflower and lemon veloute, and Peruvian fingerling potatoes, the California lamb t-bone ($37) was presented off the bone perfectly medium rare.

The excellence does not stop after the main course; dessert is not an afterthought at Boulevard.  The flourless chocolate cake ($11) with olive oil ice cream, gummies, pistachio truffles, and caramel brown rice crisps was rich and decadent.  Served with creme fraiche ice cream, the warm Bartlett pear tatin ($10.50) was at once homey and elegant. 

Service is always spot-on.  From the hosts to the wait staff and bus people, everyone is friendly and attentive.  Drinks arrived promptly.  Water and wine glasses were never empty.  Courses were well paced.  Used dishes were promptly removed with no intrusion on the dinner conversation.

There is a reason Boulevard was nominated eight consecutive times for the James Beard Foundation Outstanding Restaurant Award before winning it in 2012:  everything at Boulevard is first-class.
author: CJ G.

description:
The Kobe Beef burger ($15.5) here is better than great, easily one of the top 3 burgers in the city. The light and airy house made bun let the Kobe beef be the star of the show. The beef was so flavorful and juicy, I had to hold it gently with my fingertips to ensure that no excess juices escaped. It was topped with award winning Cowgirl Creamery's latest cheese, wagon wheel. A nice compliment to the sweet heirloom tomato. Their fries are a little bit of awesome in a bronze tin. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tttm1r5Dw1sRMCfc3EQWPw?select=ttSYFde6vbFbEGnh81WkIQ)

As far as my experience. Let's just say my weekday lunch here was exhilarating! Sat at the chef's counter so had full view of the frenzied pace yet finely tuned precision of the chefs and restaurant staff. They chefs were churning out Italian burrata & assorted heirloom tomato salads left and right! They made an extra tamarind glazed scallop dish and they sent it our way, on the house! Love it. 

- Maine lobster risotto ($16) -  They put a generous amount of lobster knuckle and the risotto was everything you want it to be; rich, creamy, and buttery.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tttm1r5Dw1sRMCfc3EQWPw?select=CAtC7792jZe_vFJzu7AybQ)

Service here was very welcoming and top notch. Even though I was in Levi's and Van's they didn't treat me any different from the guys in black suits and earpieces. Yes, black suits and ear pieces as in Secret Service agents. Hilary Clinton was in town for APEC so there were several (I overheard the chefs talking) foreign diplomats dining here. 

Love the architecture of the space and bar. Might have to come back for a birthday or anniversary dinner. Valet is $12.
author: Earl G.

description:
As if this restaurant needs any help with ratings- I loved it! The atmosphere is charming, the location is perfect, the menu is fantastically diverse and the staff is so good at being there when you need something but not hovering.
We sat at the back of the restaurant with a window view of the embarcadero and the bridge. It was fun people watching out the window and still having a lovely view of the restaurants interior. We had the burratta appetizer and then calamari and the scallops with risotto. All were amazing!! The calamari was especially memorable, as it was the lightest breaded calamari I have ever had- perfect! Our waiter was lovely, poised, informed and so helpful.
Everything was just perfect! Will be back, again and again!! Can't wait!
author: Brandy R.

description: We had a much anticipated dinner at Boulevard last night and couldn't be more unimpressed with the food.  Our service was superb but the food was bland and the cut of meat I had was subpar.  My wife's gnocchi was dry and without flavor.  As I said, we were very much looking forward to our dinner last night so it was a shame to be let down.
author: Clark A.

description:
What can I say? When I saw the beautiful building and the private room we got seated in I couldn't wait for the rest of our celebration lunch to unfold.

Wine bottles lined one side of our private room and candles on the sides. The brick ceiling gave it a rustic look and the lighting was perfect.  Their menu has something for the herbivores and carnivores.  Of the variety of starters we ordered (see the photos posted) my favorite was the heirloom tomatoes and mozarella.  Honestly I never thought a simple appetizer like that could taste so good! My coworkers and I were in agreement.  The flavors were saturated in and it was absolutely delicious.  The tuna tartar was also wonderful. 

By now we were enjoying our champagne and our entrees arrived.  My salmon was buttery, soft and delicious. Noone at the table was dissapointed either. Our waiter was very attentive and even wiped down the champagne bottle for my Yelp pic :). Points! He was very sweet and had a smile on which made a difference in our experience.

For our dessert round I ordered the pink pearl apple cake.  The presentation was artistic and tasted heavenly. I didn't share this one and I have no regrets. Ha!  One of my coworkers absolutely recommends the butterscotch pudding so do think about that if you are looking for something sweet to finish your dining experience.

Overall, a very good experience. I would come back for another celebation.
author: Shell I.

description:
When I saw the 4 stars from 2800 reviewers, I made a reservation for my birthday.

First of all, when we got there on time, we had to wait for 10-15 minutes for our table. There were other people who were waiting to be seated. For a $$$$ restaurant, it was not a good start.

We had a perfect waiter. Absoluyely perfect. He was very helpful and nice. We ordered a great wine with his advice. He also brought a surprise small ice-cream with a candle. I guess the ice-cream, wine and the waiter were the bests of our night.

We ordered ravioli as an appetizer to share. 4 pieces for $18. The taste was ok but it was most like a sample of a tasting event.

We ordered swordfish and lamb as entree. 

Swordfish was ok, however I ate better ones in $ restaurants. The mussels were cooked perfectly. The octopus was tasty. The dish was ok but it was below my expectations except the mussels.

Lamb was small and it was perfect with the sides. The combination of the plate was amazing. However, the meat was just ok without the sides.

The ambiance, server and with a few more things it was a nice place. However, we had to eat more bread to feel full. The portions were very small and the appetizer was like a sample and not for sharing. I do not like feeling hungry after I leave the restaurant. Especially after paying $$$$.

Do I advise? Eh... You may go and try. It is a nice place and the taste of the food is really good.

Will I go again? No.
author: Tugce E.

description:
I have dined at Boulevard for years.  The food is consistently very good, cocktails are wonderful, and they have a great wine selection.  Boulevard has a great and versatile vibe - you can enjoy a romantic evening here or take part in a lively group celebration.  The place is fairly large, so it is a good place to score last minute dinner reservations on a Friday night.  And, if you cannot get a table for the time you want, there are seats at the bar and/or a chef's table where you can eat and watch them cook.

I have had the following dishes:
1. Calamari stuffed with lobster and shitake (very good)
2. Crocodile rolled pasta with rabbit meatballs (it does not contain crocodile - it was excellent)
3. California Lamb T-Bone (excellent)
4. Double cream French cheese (I forgot the name, but it is the first cheese on the menu - I asked them to include the fig compote - OMG, melt in your mouth excellent).

Hubby usually gets the filet mignon and enjoys it.  Filet mignon is not really my thing, but the meat looks very juicy and (based on the bites I stole) taste very good.

The prices are fairly high, but not outrageous.  We spend north of $100.00, but usually not over $200.00 for the two of us at dinner.  This includes drinks and at least a 20% tip.

My only minor complaint is that the menu for entrees is not as versatile as I would like.
author: Theresa C.

description:
My wife and I had our first date at Boulevard. Ben was our waiter. As we sat down for our dinner on that first date, I quickly recognized Ben as a server I had worked with at another restaurant twenty years prior. 

Last night, Christmas Eve, my wife and I returned to relive our first date memories. As luck would have it, Ben was there, and we had a chance to tell him how much we appreciated his great service those four years ago when we had that first date. 

Boulevard is not a great restaurant simply because of that experience. It's a great restaurant because it's a beautiful space, the food is tremendous, and the staff is highly professional and gracious. Nancy Oakes is a tremendous talent who knows how to get the best from her staff. They are loyal to her because of her great professionalism; case in point being Ben, who has worked there for more than twenty years. 

Restaurants who manage to hang onto great staff for that long are restaurants that do things right. Boulevard is a classic example of that.
author: Charles W.

description: Boulevard is one of the few restaurants where you could close your eyes and just point at the menu and be assured of a great meal.  Yes.  I have never had a bad meal or experience here; this is my "go to" for truly special events.  If you have an opportunity to host (or attend) a private dining even in the Wine Vault Room, you will not be disappointed.  It's an intimate space that holds 12 people; pricey but special.  It's hard for me not to order the scallop starter and pork chop, both are cooked to perfection.  Desserts are wonderful, too.  You owe it to yourself!
author: Donna G.

description:
The stuffed calamari appetizer had a lot of flavors. The sauce and the julienned vegetables added a nice crunch factor. I also liked the sauce of the short ribs dish served over crispy polenta. Although, the pieces of short ribs were a bit dry. 

My biggest disappointment was the waygu steak dish which we ordered medium rare but came out medium. The meat was a bit chewy. I expect any beef with a waygu label would be more tender, the kind that melts in your mouth.
author: Tina C.

description: I hope this place stays open forever. I remember going here with my parents when I was younger. I'd always order ravioli. There were like 5 on the plate and it probably cost $30 but they were the best damn ravioli EVER. Things haven't changed much. Except now I can legally drink and appreciate their classic cocktail list.
author: E D.

description: It bums me out that folks think Boulevard is 'too traditional'. Yes, it's an institution. But it's beautiful. The menu is incredible and the cocktails are about as good as you'll find without going to a dedicated cocktail spot (Devil's Acre, etc). Sitting at the bar near the open kitchen at Boulevard is an amazing experience.
author: Clutch R.

description:
Something savory - Angus Filet Mignon
Something sweet - Brown Sugar Angel Food Cake

It might be $$$$, but definitely worth it!

[TIP]  Make a reservation for dinner; otherwise, it'll be at least an hour wait.
author: Deana M.

description: I have not been to Boulevard since 2 years ago, with the valet parking service I remember that was so helpful for this nice venue located in the center of South of Market with almost no parking space near by.  Yesterday around 6pm with the heavy downtown traffic, took me 1 hour from the 101 exit to the restaurant and found out that they have no more valet parking service so it took me another 40 minutes to park at a lot 7 blocks away, and 30 late to my reservation of dinner with an important client.  The food was served and it's not as great as 2 years ago.  The service is still awesome!
author: Jason C.

description:
Wonderful destination restaurant. We decided to come here for dinner tonight despite not having a rsvp. We were able to snatch one of the tables in the bar area. Service is efficient, friendly, and knowledgeable of the wine list. Excellent food and reasonable price. We had 1 starter, 2 entrees, 2 wines for a total of $144 before tips. I do hate that they charge the SF health fee. 

Overall, we would recommend and return.
author: Tracy L.

description:
Great Location. Service Impeccable. Food Outstanding.

We got situated in a nice little nook at the corner of the restaurant. The restaurant expands a whole block and has great big windows showcasing the Embarcadero. The decor was cute and the venue was a lot bigger than I had expected. This place exudes a very comfortable vibe... we wanted to drink Pinots all night and people watch from our gorgeous view but we saved that for the after dinner festivities.

So out comes the Calamari appetizer that changed my life (not really, just being dramatic) but it was SO DARN DELICIOUS! I've never had calamari prepared like this before, it was barely-to-lightly battered and filled with some joy and served over this "dark" or sepia fried rice. Now that rice had some bang of flavor with it, almost seem like it was cooked in a seafood broth. 

The official appetizer description:
CALAMARI STUFFED with LOBSTER & SHITAKE
Sepia Fried Rice, Octopus & Meyer Lemon
Golden Enoki Mushrooms & Scallions

GET IT!!!

For entrees we both ordered different types of fish (Seabass & Halibut) which was soft and flavorful. We then ended with the delicious butterscotch pudding and red velvet bon-bons. The bon-bons were just ok to me but that pudding really took me by surprise... the texture and the presentation really did me in.

Highly Recommend!
author: Ryan E.

description:
The 5 star review is given solely because of their California T-bone Lamb entree. Just order it. It's amazing. My boyfriend and I each ordered it as we felt it looked like a stand out. Once we were done, we jokingly suggested ordering another to share for dessert. Can't get enough of it. All the flavours balanced beautifully. 

The appetizers were alright. I am not a huge fan of burrata but still ordered the heirloom tomatoes. I will say though is their balsamic vinegar is incredible. 

Service was ok. We were walk-ins on a Saturday night around 6.30pm but we got a table for 2 in the bar area (which is pretty much part of the main restaurant anyway).  

Meal for 2 including appetizers, a few beers, entrees and shared dessert came out to $200. Wanna go on a budget - just order the lamb. Seriously. It was insanely good.
author: Kirsty E.

description:
Service was a little bizarre at first, but the food made up for it and our waiter eventually got his act together and even seemed to warm up a bit by the end of the meal.

First, the weirdness -- our waiter seemed to be *really* preoccupied with the next table over, running over to them multiple times while pretty much ignoring us at first. He didn't offer to open up our wine until we asked, and when we did, he opened both, left them on the table, and immediately wandered off for about ten minutes. When he finally noticed that we'd been sitting around with empty glasses for kind of awhile, he just dumped the wine into everyone's glasses without doing the tasting or anything! Not what I would've expected from a 1-star. I decided the food would have to be amazing to justify the rating, and it actually did manage to meet my now-elevated expectations. 

Definitely order the crispy oysters with carpaccio and avocado and dungeness crab appetizers. The dungeness crab in particular surprised me -- so many bold flavors packed into a dish that also managed to be light, and they all worked so well together. For my main I did the petrale sole with clams, and again was surprised with how flavorful the dish was. I really liked the clams, which had a pesto-breadcrumb-like topping, and the brussels sprouts that came with the fish were really tasty. Overall, I was really impressed with the food, so I gave them the benefit of the doubt. Still, it would be nice if they worked out the service issues.
author: Shing H.

description:
I went there for dinner with my boyfriend and I really enjoyed it.
The staff is really nice, the location is really good and the food is great. The menu is really good and complete. I was in doubt of what to order among all the attractive options, at the end both of us had the lamb which was really tasty and well cooked. I really recommend that dish!!!
author: Victoria C.

description: Very nice and elegant place! However I wasn't to happy about the prices for what I got, Ordered an Angus file and it was good, but not for the price of $51. I loved the service and how they clean your table for you. Wish the seating was better. I had made the reservation a week in advanced and I had asked to get a seat as close to the window as possible (in order to see the bridge). However, they sat us at a table that was pretty far away and was placed in the wrong area, I had waiters keep walking by and hitting my chair because our table was sticking out into the walkway. They had told me that it was the closest they can put us because all of tables closer were for bigger groups, However, later on we clearly saw a couple sitting at one of the small tables next to the window. Overall, very good service but not a bang for your buck and seating for us was not adequate.
author: David C.

description:
4.5 

I had been dying to try Boulevard for over a year now and finally for my birthday we made reservations. We arrived early and waited for our party at the bar where we found seating right away. The ambiance is set with dim lighting, dark oak wood and classic mosaic tiling. Very elegant with French touches.  There were wine bottles scattered throughout the bar ordered by different parties starting off the night. The bottles made great décor for a first bar impression.

Our party arrived and we were seated. Our waitress was really nice but she seemed overworked. It's great that she was hustling but this isn't BJ's. At a restaurant like this, you want your server to be attentive and patient. It got better throughout the night... or maybe the booze kicked in and we no longer cared.

For dinner I had the pork prime rib chop with pears and candy yams. I think I need to say it again. Pork-Prime-Rib- with- PEARS- and -CANDY yams. It didn't even taste like a pork chop it tasted like heaven. And the pears complimented it perfect. My husband had the lamb and didn't care too much for it (but he's also not much of a lamb eater to begin with).  I'm sure he was wishing he ordered my plate. I gave him a little bite to try (nothing less and definitely nothing more! Too good to share).

In the end, I was really impressed with the ambiance, wine, and meal. I would definitely return to sit at the bar, order a bottle of wine and indulge on some pear induced pork prime rib.
author: Ava G.

description: Service was perfect, halibut ceviche was delicious as were the scallops. Great location. Nice staff. Interior feels old but with character. If you're looking for a reliable tasty meal, come here! Thank you!
author: Sarah D.

description:
My husband and I really just came here for the foie gras (while we could) but of course we had to share another starter.  The Burrata & Heirloom Tomato Salad was so fresh and light, which made us feel a bit better about indulging in the rich but oh so delicious foie gras.  This was one of the best foie dishes we've ever had - perfectly seared.  Too bad the portion size wasn't as generous as La Folie's...

But let's not forget about dessert.  I had the Turtle Sunda Pofiterole.  Every bit of it was just yummy!  I also wanted to try the Milk Chocolate Peanut Butter Ice Cream Bon Bon so I ordered just one.  Our server was nice enough to give us a 2nd one because she said they were hard to share.  I  had no intention of sharing with my husband but luckily I didn't have to since he got his own.  ; )
author: Rose A.

description:
Came here for my birthday dinner! 

It's right by embarcadero, so it's in a nice area and the restaurant itself was surprisingly spacious, clean, and romantic. 

The service was impeccable, of course, and our waitress was so patient with all our questions about the menu and giving us recommendations. 

As for the food, we ordered: 
-gnoccho carbonara with truffles: it was a really rich dish that had two pieces of "large gnocchis" (it looks like 2 long pieces of rice cake, but with gnocchi textures) with a small fried egg, pancetta (i think) and truffles on top. The dish was small, but more than enough to share 'cause I think after one piece of gnocchi, i probably couldn't have eaten more 'cause of the richness. 

-Scallops: We also got scallops as appetizers and the waitress was kind enough to add an additional one to our plate so that we didn't have to split the 3rd scallop. Nothing overly creative or unique about the dish, but the scallop was cooked and seasoned perfectly. 

-Lamb: The date ordered this one and he said he thoroughly enjoyed it. I usually don't order lamb 'cause I generally don't like the smell of it, though I did take a bite and it was pretty good. 

-Halibut: I ordered this as my entree, and I think the fish was a little more on the dry side than I had hoped for. Was a little disappointing, but nonetheless the overall dish was pretty good. 

I took a star off because I felt that even though the service was good, and most of the food we ordered were executed well, for a restaurant of this caliber and the amount of money we spent, we've had better food at better restaurants. Would come back on a special occasion if someone else really wanted to come.
author: Judy B.

description:
Really nice meal. 

To begin, it's got the feel of one of those classic spots. It's dark. It's got a fantastic bar with chilled bottles of champagne chilling in a sterling silver bowl on the bar top. There are servers seamlessly moving past each other without effort. And that's before you even sit down.

The wine list is outstanding. My appetizer included lightly cooked homemade pasta stuffed with a variety of delicate ingredients, served side by side with a few squash blossoms. Squash blossoms are one of my favorites. Easily a 4 star option. My main was likewise good. The meat was cooked just right - a perfect medium rare, which is really a difficulty in today's world. How many times do you order "medium rare" and get "well done plus?" Too often.

I cannot give it five stars because I didn't leave with the feeling of utter amazement, which is a prerequisite. But a very solid four star spot.
author: Ed W.

description:
Have heard so much about this restaurant so had to try it.  We went with another couple and were so looking forward to this dining experience.  I had a light meal at home that morning so that I would really enjoy my dinner.

Let me start with the ambience, the decor was ok but could use a refresh.  It was crowded and loud.  I could barely move in my chair as we were so squezzed in and could not converse with the other couple that well.  The womens' bathroom was downstairs and not convenient at all.

Our waiter was nice and had a good personality and offered suggestions on the menu, had a great sense of humor and had been there quite awhile so that was a plus.

Three of us ordered the salmon and one of us had the porkchop.  When we got our salmon, I was shocked at how small the portions were  -- almost appeared to be appetizer/tapas portion.  Mind you, I am a petite woman with a small appetite.  The desserts were boring.  My boyfriend ordered cheese at desert time.  He got a one-inch square of cheese that cost about $9.00.   We thought it was a joke.  We have had cheese for desert at other high-end restaurants and have been satisfied with the sampling of cheese portions.

Bottom line - the food was good but nothing what I would expect from a Michelin-rated restaurant. 

Needless to say, we left hungry and underwhelmed.  We do not mind spending $350 for dinner but let's be fair, give us what we pay for.  

Tip:  If you want to try this restaurant, eat first.  I only wish we had said something that night so that I could walk away feeling good about our dining experience.
author: Kathy S.

description:
This is my second time returning to The Boulevard.  The interior is amazing with a  tiled columns, blown glass lighting and a full bar.  They are Michelin rated, 1 star, to my pleasant surprise. The awards are posted down the stairwell to their private banquet room but I prefer the main dining area. The banquet room didn't do anything for me, at least what I could see. 

I started my dinner with a glass of champagne and foie gras.  It was nicely grilled and was paired with figs and grilled crostini, $35. This is not a terrine or torchon version.  This is the real deal.  

My main course, the lamb chop, medium rare, was wonderful as well.  My husband ordered the pork chop with a yellow and green bean pesto collage.  The veggies were killer!  I could have eaten those until the cows came home.

Unfortunately, the dulce de luche white chocolate bon bons were not as good as last time (they change them up) but my husband said I was wrong.  For the record, I lovvvvvveeee the dark chocolate ones.   

Overall, another amazing evening at The Boulevard!
author: Sylvia B.

description: Delicious food, great atmosphere, great service. Inhadvtoveat in the bar area but service was immaculate
author: Colleen P.

description: Came here because it is right across from work for lunch with two co-workers. We got seated immediately by the entrance. The table was a bit small, but it was fine because we didn't want to wait long for seats. We started with their soup of the day: crab bisque - rich in flavor and perfect amount for an appetizer. We also ordered the ahi tuna tartare to share and it surprised me with its ginger bits in the tartare - wasn't a fan of that, but my coworkers who liked ginger enjoyed it. I loved the taro chips and seaweed chips that were served with it. For the entree, I had the wagyu burger with fries and the coworkers had scallop risotto and wagyu bavette - all were delicious and the filling! My burger was too much for lunch that I couldn't finish it and took my fries to-go. The meal was super filling and service was great. Definitely want to return and try other dishes - the best entree I tasted was the scallop risotto though :)
author: Amanda C.

description:
I can't give a very accurate review since I was sick and all taste was off BUT I can say that I had an amazing experience. The waiter was so funny. He was selling the wagyu so hard and convinced 3 people to order it. Result: Dish wasn't like he described. But hey, them marketing skills tho.

My starter was the Sea Scallop Risotto. And my oh my that scallop was HUGE like it was on steroids. It was made to perfection. The scallop was very tender, wasn't chewy, and had a very nice sear. Soup of the day was Salmon chowder and my taste buds, it tasted so gooooooooood.

Main course was a oven roasted salmon and that SALMON was so tender. You just know when a salmon is perfect and when a salmon is overcooked. This was like nothing I have ever had! So yummy. The crispy kale was like eating potato chips.

Dessert = my most awaited course. I had the butterscotch pudding. To my taste, it was like coffee but again, I was sick so taste could have been off. Though the pudding was very soft and smooth. Everything was yummy about this. From the chantilly to the shortbread to the oats! I also tried the buffalo milk cheesecake. It tasted like any ordinary cheesecake...

I had an amazing experience despite the change in taste. Pricey place, small portions. The cooking was well done. The service was super. Can't wait to come back in the very distant future!
author: Benita M.

description: Dined here in 2007 and still dream about the quail. Amazing meals, always a delight. Pricey but well worth the experience and memories of exquisite food adventures.
author: Maria C.

description:
Came back here and I was impressed! I had the lobster bisque and pork prime rib & was very juicy & flavorful. The sauce on it was very tasty as well, and the fig on the plate was a nice touch. I was seated promptly and service was exceptional. Everyone in my party was very happy.

I look forward to my return.
author: Azizi A.

description:
We were just wandering the Embarcadero with no dinner plans, and then we stumbled upon the Boulevard, and walked in.... little did we know we would stumble into what I think is a treasure of San Francisco.

It was a cool Tuesday night, and the restaurant was packed. With no reservations, the host offered us bar seating right in front of their open kitchen. Being the foodies that we are, we decided to take her up on it and sat right in front of the action.

What an experience!!! We got to see the whole kitchen in motion, it was intense as their orders kept rolling in, and we saw how every dish was prepared. I ordered the halibut, and he ordered the lamb chops. My dish was perfectly seasoned atop a corn succotash, and I savored every bite of it as the smells of the kitchen filled my face.

I also saw their scallop appetizer roll out consistently. I'm definitely gonna have to come back and try that. 

AMAZING!
author: Natalie W.

description: Wow The Boulevard is one of the best restaurants I have ever been to in SF. The food is very delicious with perfect size portions. Everything is top notch including there awesome, compassionate service. Highly suggest you try this San Francisco gem if you haven't already!!
author: Travis T.

description:
Boulevard has been on my to-try list for such a long time and I'm so glad i was able to check this place out.  Very classy date spot, it's along the Embarcadero so if you request for a seat closer to the window you'll have an amazing view while you eat.

I came here for my birthday with 3 other friends. Our server was very friendly and did an extremely thorough explanation of the menu and popular wines. We ordered the Ahi tuni and scallops as appetizers, Filet mignon, quail and swordfish as mains, and some cake they brought out for dessert. No complaints about any of their dishes, everything was on par and perfectly cooked.

Can get pretty pricey but I think it's worth the dining experience. Prime location, great service, and even better food. Two thumbs up!
author: Angela K.

description:
We came here for lunch, and had:
- soup of the day: lobster bisque ($10)
- entree: soft shell crab gumbo ($21)
- entree: wood oven roasted american wagyu beef bavette ($28)

The soup had a great fragrance, and tasted great. The soft shell crab gumbo, well, it was gumbo, and not very special. The crab was tiny, not sure if it was even a full crab. The wagyu beef was less than memorable. Oh, and they served complimentary bread, which is just ok; it wasn't even warm, sigh.

The menu changes daily.

Given this is a Michelin starred restaurant, the food just did not stand out. Furthermore, when making the reservation, I had made a special note that we were celebrating our 10-year anniversary. Nothing was done to acknowledge the special occasion -- not a card, not a dessert.

The goods: (i) Reservation was easy to make. You can make a reservation on Open Table, and if Open Table doesn't have the times you want, you can call them, and they'll most likely be able to accommodate you (read: not very crowded). (ii) Valet ($15) was very convenient. You give your valet ticket to the waiter after you dine, ~15 minutes before you plan to leave, and your car will be outside waiting for you.
author: KP H.

description:
Took the hubby for dinner here for his birthday. 

Here is the good: Love the ambience, the convenient valet parking and outstanding service. 

The food on the other hand was very disappointing. We ordered the Scallops and the crab salad for apps and they were nothing to write home about We ordered California Lamb and Norwegian Cod for our main courses. Lamb was very rare when we asked for medium. The filet of sole was bland. The desserts were fine.

For us going to a Michelin star restaurant means a great experience with amazing food and this was a disappointed.
author: zika S.

description:
*IF YOU'RE GONNA DINE HERE JUST VALER INSTEAD OF LOOKING FOR PARKING* 
I was soooooo lucky being able to snatch a table for dinner on  Valentine's Day. Stuck in SF traffic I was an hr late for my dinner reservation in San Leandro so I was flipping around on yelp and realized that Boulevard was down the street from us so I placed a call at 630 to see if they had any dinner cancelations but instead the hostess informed me that they had an open bar area which was "first come first serve" so we headed there and right when we got in a couple stood up and we were seated right away, #winning!!!!! They didn't have a prefixed menus so I ordered the foie gras as an appetizer which was amazing in itself, not overly cooked and the tangerines server with them was very refreshing. For our entree it took about 45 mins for our meal to come out but our waitress came over and gave us some delicious chili cheese and crackers to snack on. My boyfriend ordered the Berkshire Kurobuta pork prime rib chop. When I think of fine dining, pork doesn't come to mind but this dish totally changed my view on that. It was a whole new experience, very flavorful and juicy. Definitely a must! I got the filet which was cooked perfectly! Every time I go to a place and order blue they always over cook it, but it was cooked to perfection here. The meat was juicy and tender. Next time I'll defiantly ask to be seated at the open kitchen bar area to see the chef at work.
author: Linda L.

description:
Great food and great view of the bridge. We started with the heirloom tomatoes and burratta as well as the squash ravioli. Both were good, but the squash was definitely the winner. I followed that with the pork chop, which was really incredible. Cooked perfectly. The maple pecan butter sauce really took it to another level. Finished with a Walnut and Apple Cake. The bourbon vanilla ice cream that came with it was delicious. Wish there would've been more of it. Flavor was great, but could have been a bit more moist. 

Overall this was a great meal. My only knock on it is that the atmosphere felt a bit stuffy, but our amazing server went a long way towards remedying that.
author: Ryan C.

description: Great food, short rubs excellent. BUT very short pour on the wine, and that is not good
author: Bob L.

description: Wonderful place for vegetarians and carnivores alike. A definitely serious restaurant that delivers.  Open efficient kitchen with staff who have excellent customer service. The server was engaging and always smiling. Amuse bouche (crispy ancient grains with cream and cucumber) was provided as a compliment. Vegetarian carrot soup with clamshell mushroom really rocked. Loved the beet salad with frisee. If you love deconstructing your food  and analyzing the tantalizing ingredients, this is it.  I was enthralled watching the dessert station where the staff masterfully concocted different mouth watering deserts - heavenly brownies with everything chocolate, milk cheesecake, strawberries galore, sorbet and ice cream and all the sweet goodness!!!!  Centrally located, waterfront, close to Bart and Ferry Building.
author: Kitty D.

description:
To me this place is like 3.5.
The food needs improvements. I had some kind of seared Halibut, and it was too bland. It had no taste at all. My wife had a steak, and it was a little bit too chewy and salty.

The chocolate bon bon dessert was off, and tasted like frozen snack.

Overall, I and my wife like the vibe and attentive service more than the food.
author: Bentley K.

description:
Outstanding. 

11:30 reservations on a Friday and was seated promptly upon arriving. The holiday decor was nice and everything felt luxurious but homey at the same time. 

Started off with the lobster and shrimp fritters and scallops. Both were amazing. I usually don't care for scallops but these were tender and definitely fresh as can be. The fritters were light and crispy. I wanted to try the tuna tartare but couldn't squeeze an extra appetizer for the three of us. Having seen it I would love to come back and try it   

I ordered the American wagyu burger and it came out perfectly medium rare as i ordered it. I think it needed to be a little more seasoned but other than that it was delicious. An extra $6 for fries seemed expensive but it was in line with Boulevard so can't complain. Crispy and potato-ey, everything you expect from some top end spuds. 

I also tried the pork loin cap and the risotto. The pork was some of the most tender meat I've ever had and the risotto and truffles you could smell from across the table. Both delicious. 

Dessert was the main complaint for me. After ordering a cappuccino and a butterscotch pudding the cappuccino took about 10 min to come and I was waiting for it before it came. After 10 min a small shot of espresso came out with no steamed milk. Because of the long wait I just drank it. The pudding was great, some granola and nuts really balanced it out and gave it a nice crunch. 


Highly recommend the pork loin and the burger if you want something simpler.
author: Eric R.

description: My friend Lisa recently reminded me that I had forgotten to write my review of Boulevard. Well, here it is! We were given a fantastic table by the front window. Our server was very good and took our drink order quickly. I had the sea scallop appetizer and the halibut entree. Both excellent!!  My guy had the heirloom tomato salad and the king salmon. Also great! Dessert was one to remember! It was a Carmel toffee popcorn bar and was absolutely phenomenal! The entrees were pricey and a little on the small side, hence the 1 star loss. Otherwise, a great evening with friends!
author: Sandra P.

description:
My overall rating of Boulevard is high because the food is great.  The service is a little lacking, especially for the reputation the restaurant has.  My husband & I came here for dinner for our 2nd wedding anniversary.  There's only street parking and or you can use their valet.  It was a Monday, and our reservations were at 6:30pm.  The placed was packed when we got there and we were seated right away

Our waiter took our drink orders soon after we were seated.  For appetizer, I ordered the sea scallops & my husband got the stuffed calamari.  The calamari is usually stuffed with lobster and shitake mushrooms, but my husbands just had mushrooms (no lobster but for the same price $).  My scallops were cooked perfectly and came with shaved asparagus and asparagus mousseline (you get two scallops).

Our dinner took a while to come out & the waiter came around twice letting us know it was coming out soon.  I ordered halibut and my husband ordered the pork chop.  My halibut came with caper spaetzle, sprouted lentils & quinoa with a fennel puree.  I loved the combination of all these ingredients & I would never think to pair them together.  My husband's pork chop was cooked medium and was juicy and tender.

On to dessert...I ordered the rocky road walnut brownie and cocoa nib ice cream & my husband got the buffalo milk cheesecake.  Our desserts had a "Congrats" and "Happy Anniversary" on it and that was a really nice touch.  My husband really liked his cheesecake.  my brownie was pretty dense and hard but was good when you ate the ice cream with it.  The peanut butter fudge didn't taste like peanut butter, but my husband ate all of mine.

I would have given 3 stars because I didn't think service was up to par, but the food made up for it.  You won't regret trying this place because the food is great, but there are better places to eat in SF.
author: Sara T.

description:
Yeah. If you feel like paying $50 for an OK filet, go for it. Myself, I was unamused. Not at the $50 piece of meat, seriously, if it's outstanding, $100 would be fine, but unamused with the food.

Boulevard feels like a dinosaur in the restaurant world. A relic. Something that in theory, should work, but in today's diverse culinary world, just feels flat. 

I WILL say that everything was technically well done (although my steak was more medium-well than how I ordered it: medium-rare). Shrug. It could be that modern American cuisine just doesn't have a place in my heart anymore? Eh. I've had better - but I've also had worse. 

The design inside is pretty darn charming, though.  My advice: Go for a cocktail and an appetizer. You'll get the gist, your wallet will be happy, and you won't be overwhelmed by the somewhat pedestrian "fancy" fare they offer.
author: Maggie V.

description: OUTSTANDING!  Sit at the bar and watch these chefs in action - the most entertaining and interesting place to be!  Starters:  Go easy -if at all- on the bread since portions are generous and you don't want to leave any morsels on the plates.  Sea scallops, soft shell crab:  YES.  Mains:  Kurobuta Pork Chop, Angus Filet:  ABSOLUTELY.  Dessert:  Strawberries-Sour Cream Brown Sugar Sundae:  INCREDIBLE!  Gotta be in my top 10 faves of all time!
author: Helen H.

description: Great food, ambiance, and service!! View from our table was of the bay bridge, it was beautiful! Food didn't take too long to come out and our waitress was very accommodating. Will be back!
author: Prabisha T.

description:
Boulevard provided an exceptional dining experience which left me more than satisfied. It is easy to distinguish the differences that make a fine dining restaurant such as Boulevard superior to the more typical "standard" ones. The classy decor sets the stage for what should be a pleasant meal. Still Boulevard does have its faults; the tables are very small and I often found that plates had to be rearranged and placed all the way to the edges to ensure that everything would fit. 

Our waitress met us with smiles and provided us with above-average service. Still at times I felt she was inattentive, definitely not the best service I've ever had, but no where near the worst.

As for the food itself; terrific! 
For me the appetizers were the star with the Fava Bean & Parmesan Raviolini standing out the most. When you first take a bite out of the raviolini the strenght of the cheese is pretty overwhelming, but after swallowing down this delicious treat you will be met with the most satiating after taste. If you're into rich cheese (like truffle cheese) this is a must.

For my entree I had the Pork Chop. The pork chop was cooked to perfection and tasted delicious however I felt it was missing something. The House in SF has a better pork chop in my opinion which is 100% attributed to the delicious sauce that goes over theirs. Still the pork chop was tasty and I definitely would recommend it.

Overall, Boulevard provided top-tier food in a very elegant environment. I would definitely come here again.
author: Eddie K.

description: I had a fantastic dinner here last night! I was really excited to try Boulevard and it did not disappoint. My friend and I started off with some drinks at the bar, which was cute, classy and the bartenders were friendly. When our reservation time came up, we were seated promptly and our waiter was informative. We enjoyed sharing the ahi tuna tartare, which was unique and tasty, and handkerchief pasta, which was not the greatest nor was it bad, it was just different for my tastebuds--perhaps a little too salty. I loved my medium rare filet mignon--some of the best I've had in the city and my friend was a fan of his pork prime rib. The dessert was delicious and my friend, who never bothers to order dessert, was over the moon for his! We had a great time. We will be back soon!
author: Jeanette Jane G.

description:
Fantastic dining experience! My friend and I got a table at the back of the restaurant next to the window. I had a direct view of the Bay Bridge, and it certainly made the dining experience so much better. 

The stained glass and dim interior of the restaurant transported me to a different era. You must ask for the table near the window. Luckily, we just got seated there without knowing better. 

I had a couple of favorite dishes. The calamari with lobster and shrimp stuffing was delicious. The stuffing just melted in my mouth and was very flavorful. The sea scallops were good, too, but not particularly memorable. The ahi tuna tartare was good and was a sizable portion. 

You must try the pork prime rib chop! It was the best pork chop I've ever tried. It was incredibly tender and juicy. The waiter said it's their best entree. 

Dessert was also amazing with the bittersweet chocolate brulee.  

This is a fancy restaurant that has great views, flavorful foods, and attentive service. I will definitely come back for special occasions.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I went to boulevard for a birthday and overall it was a great experience. I really have no complaints. we came about 15 minutes early for our reservation so we just waited by the bar. We got Moscow mule (delish!) and gin and tonic. They greeted him with a happy birthday as soon as we checked in.The service was top notch and the food lived up to the hype in my opinion. We started with foie gras and Octopus. The foie gras was perfect. Presentation wise I've never seen better foie gras. The octopus was really good although kinda spicy so if you can't do spicy foods stay away from the octopus. The main courses we ordered were the angus filet and kurobuta pork chop. The filet was super juicy and cooked to perfection. The pork chop was done really well also! The bits of bacon was also a nice add on to it! Our waiter recommended us some wine to go with our entrees which made the whole dining experience better. For dessert we got chocolate and butterscotch which our waiter said was the most popular desert. Since we were celebrating he's birthday they added a nice "happy birthday" sign on a white chocolate bar. So sweet! The dessert was  good but a little too rich for my taste. Despite that, boulevard was well worth the wait and money.
author: Jennifer P.

description: I was hoping to have a 4-5 star dining experience but they fell short. We had reservations came with a party of four and were sat promptly. I ordered the duck Medium Rare and it came out medium, still very moist but not quite up to my expectations. The butter was rock hard frozen and the bread was cold. The server reached across our table a couple of times to serve despite having enough space to serve from the side or back. I noticed some James Beard award and Michelin stars, this experience brought those into question.
author: Gabriel B.

description:
Came here for a private event, the service was phenomenal and the food was on point. We had an arranged menu to choose from but it was one I will not complain about. 

Starter: had the ahi tuna tartare. And it was amazeballs. Definitely one of the top 5 I've ever had in my life. Colleague ordered the beet salad with goat cheese and she was totally kicking herself in the butt. 

Main course: pork chop prime rib. OMG. Insanely cooked to perfection and savory and flavorful. Truly another all amazing dish to have.

Dessert: chocolate tart, sooooooo amazing!! Rich chocolate with the most crack addicting crispy crackle thing on top, not sure what it was and didn't catch it in the title. the waiter had cleared my plate before I could finish so was so disappointed I couldn't finish it, but maybe it's a good thing... To limit my overindulgent self.

Definitely one of my favorite meals ever. 

Coffee with dessert was also great!
author: Mandi L.

description:
1 michelin Star. Went for a birthday.

Nice atmosphere, pretty big restaurant and we were next to the main way, so not exactly intimate. Service really professional, good recommandations. 

Got the Matcha abalone, lamb, and "lolipop" as a dessert.
Love the abalone, especially the seaweed salad. Everything was really mastered, lamb was really tender. Didn't really see where the "squash baba ganoush" was though. Presentation could be better on the lamb.

Wife took the octopus and the pork. The octopus was really tender, and she said it was the best pork she ever had. 

Overall, a really good experience.
author: Lionel F.

description:
Haven't been here for a few years, so was eager to try Boulevard again.
Food was good: Octopus appetizer tasty, and my Pork Chop quite good. 
Martini was well-crafted, and Mocha coffee a good dessert choice. 
Service was cordial and attentive. 
Overall dining experience very good.
author: IQuack D.

description: Excellent food. Had the Mahi Mahi, great service, good beer selection. A bit noisey butt it was fine. Nice place on the harbor side. Party of 5 everyone enjoyed their meals
author: Pat A.

description: I came here with a group for a work dinner so we had a prix fixe menu. The tomato salad was melt in your mouth delicious. I don't even love tomatoes but this was amazing! I had the pork chop as my entree and everything was perfect. The flavored were so good and the meat was so tender. Large portion of meat too! Would definitely recommend as an entree. Dessert was chocolate and incredible as well. I would come back again!!  Hard to rate the atmosphere because we had a private room blocked off for us. Service was great and I hope to come back soon!
author: Emily F.

description:
Michelin Star eh? I rarely seem to agree with that rating scale so a 3 star review comes at no surprise to me.

3 stars for food, 2 stars for value, and 5 stars for ambiance and service.

Let's get serious though, you're all probably wondering how the food is. I spent quite awhile reading the reviews, figuring out what to order, and after thorough reading, I was not able to arrive at any conclusion except that the place was expensive. I decided to just play it by ear and ask for the server's recommendations when I arrived.

This is one of those places you go to for your 50th anniversary, or take clients to for business dinners. And clearly, based on the clientele, this rule seems to hold true. I was a fan of the cocktail list, but I felt that they needed to be more stiff. 

The appetizers were weak. The scallops were good but very expensive, and the calamari with stuffed lobster was decent at best. I didn't even finish it.

The lamb came out almost cold, but it was cooked perfectly. So tender you might mistake it for fillet mignon or something. Points docked here because I wasn't a fan of the sauce. It's thickened like 5a5's, and could have been tastier. I also split the porkchop, which again was perfectly cooked. This was definitely the winner between the two entrees, but didn't blow me away.

For dessert, I INHALED the chocolate mousse cake. Make sure you get dessert.

Overall, I was a bit unimpressed given Boulevard received 1 Michelin star, but I think it was still a good meal and a nice place to celebrate occasions. Unfortunately, the only thing that really wowed me was the price.
author: Jess C.

description:
Recent business lunch and won't return.  Small lunch menu, everything is overpriced.  

I ordered salad with chicken - it was not that large and the chicken was so overcooked (tough) I really regretted getting it.  I didn't speak up because it was a business lunch with a colleague.

I had soda water drink...and they won't refill for free!  Seriously?  It's WATER.  One of the few restaurants left that actually charges for soda refills. 

Waiter (Constance?  White older man, longer blond hair) was rather snooty and didn't smile.  Lunch took longer to arrive than average.
author: Brian U.

description: Just fab is all I have to say.. We got the risotto and the pork and it was great. Our server was very informative & we listened to his suggestions & all came out great. We also had couple of their mixed drinks at the bar which was very good as well. I will defiantly will go back and recommend it to my friends.
author: Howard W.

description:
Went to Boulevard for a birthday dinner. Chose it because a few people said although it was expensive, it's a solid meal for a special occasion. 

I was pretty underwhelmed to be honest. 

First, the waiter dropped a glass of water on myself and my brother. I get that it happens but disappointing service wise from what's supposed to be a nice restaurant. 

Second, portions are small, prices are high.

Which brings me to my last point, I would forgive all of the above if the food was amazing. But - it was mediocre through and through. Salmon was decent. Tried a bite of the steak, also alright. A bit dry. Nothing stood out, nothing was great. 

Having lived in the City for 3 years now, there's plenty of other places where you can get a meal that is truly incredible for that price. I won't be coming back.
author: Sarah L.

description: The Boulevard has become my go to business lunch place in San Francisco. The booths are comfy and semi discrete and allow for great informal business conversations. Nice variety of light to not too heavy lunch dishes. Setting is unashamedly rustic and the service is just right. Classy place
author: Ben V.

description:
I've wanted to go to Nancy Oakes' Boulevard for a long time, and I finally got my chance tonight. My table was ready when I arrived, and I was warmly greeted by the host as well as my server. The space is beautiful, older, dark and elegant -- a nice change from the other more industrial and trendy spaces in San Francisco. The mosaics on the floor alone are impressive.

The wine list is extensive. I enjoyed a glass of cab from Sonoma, and then devoured the grilled swordfish accompanied by a berry sauce, purple cabbage, and a prosciutto or jambon ($30). The fish was perfectly cooked, juicy and fresh. The sweet berry sauce was the perfect accompaniment. It is among my favorite fish dishes I've experienced. I had no appetizers or salads, as they seemed the most unreasonable to me at $10-14 per item.

My server was very friendly, but there were sometimes lengthy waits between visits. Most obvious to me was what seemed like a 10 minute or more wait for my wine after I had placed the order at the beginning of my visit. A 10-15 minute wait for a glass of wine seemed a bit excessive, and dinner took a while too. The restaurant was very busy and a lovely place to wait, but some attention should be paid to those initial few moments of the guest experience. 

The dessert menu looked incredible, especially the dulce leche. Unfortunately, I can't eat it. Next time, and there will be a next time.
author: Todd B.

description:
A temporary and self-induced increase in neurotransmitter activity has resurrected my trusty keyboard, despite it having been crucified eons ago by the pesky Romans. But never mind that, let's now discuss the who, what, when, where & why.

I used to count myself firmly in the camp that believed worthwhile artistic endeavors only had their origins in suffering, exhaustion, and hurt. It came from a place you sealed off from the rest of the world and seldom opened, and even then only for brief periods, lest it not be containable. And while that still holds true to some extent, I've also learned that it can come from other places as well, like forgiveness, in opening yourself up to becoming vulnerable, and food. Definitely food. And perhaps beverages. And also recreational sports.

A good case in point, Boulevard. Whenever I stumble into the city I more often than not end up doing something remarkable, but this place isn't just good, it's great. I could literally eat here every meal for the remainder of my days and yet be perfectly content. I really wish to bow deeply to the entire staff, especially to Nancy, Dana, Tim & Lisa for bringing to life such an utterly fantastic menu based on the principals of sustainability; each item is its own reward.  Every facet of the meal, from the courses, to drinks, to dessert, has been thought out in vivid detail.

Like any evolved human, I can certainly take enjoyment in the modern luxuries life in the present day has to offer, we truly do live in pretty exciting times, but a part of my soul yearns to be part of a simpler time, a time long gone by. The interior of the establishment takes one back to such a time. Warm and inviting, with just the right tinge of a modern touch, it sets an elegant backdrop perfectly. If you close your eyes, you can almost be transported to an era where people dressed to the nines, business was done outside the office, and fittingly, over a martini lunch.

Fortunate as I am to have worked through a good part of the menu, I've encountered nothing but hits, not yet a single miss. I'd highly recommend a show of appreciation to the staff of this restaurant (And any other for that matter) by bringing in for them a case of Modelo (Or similar) for the cooks. I've been spoiled in that I'll rarely order prime rib off any menu, I've had the good stuff and quite frankly most places will leave me afterward in a state of dejected disappointment. Boulevard will put on your plate a prime rib you will want to write about even weeks or months later.

A "Prime Rib Good" tip may have sufficed, however this is dedicated to a special someone who requested I write again, and inspiration is where you find it. If you don't like Boulevard, realize that you have bad taste in food and seek help immediately.

Soundtrack: Brian Jonestown Massacre - "Anemone"
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I6R9WSClRfE
author: Robert Z.

description:
Did i miss something?  We had read about the hamburger being one of the best in San Francisco.  Really?

Started with a crab salad that was pretty bland.

We both ordered the burgers, medium rare. only 1 was served that temperature.  The other was medium well.  The bun was dry.  Cheese over powered any flavor of the meat.  The 1/2 inch grilled red onion wasn't usable on the burger, so I have to wonder if the chef has actually ordered this item as served.  Where the potato chips served with the burger housemade? or Lay's?  There is nothing special about them, so I guessing they were Lay's.

They serve this dish with hotel room service size katsup, mustard and mayo.  Along with being difficult to open, you have to wonder why? Such an '80's gimmick.

Bathrooms while clean, are located in San Mateo.
author: EC N.

description:
I came here for lunch with a party of 5, and honestly I don't have one complaint. 

The service was friendly and sweet. Drinks came out a little slow but no real problems with that. 

All our food was delicious from the sole, chicken, to burger everything was so tasty. Seriously, those fries are amazing! We all practically ate every single thing on our plates. 

The interior and exterior of the building was really awesome and totally makes you feel like you're in the past. 

We all felt very lucky that we were able to walk in with no reservation and only had to wait about 10 minutes at the bar before getting our table. I would definitely come back to Boulevard any time!
author: Kelli H.

description: I've been going to Boulevard since they opened and I it took me some years to like it, but once I did I really did. The location and interior is one of the best in San Francisco. A few months ago I came just for drinks and appetizers and it was great, but a little pricey, which is to be expected. I do my most dining here for lunch and after many years I finally have to say it's slipped in my opinion. Let me begin with the name, atmosphere and concept, which is suppose to be French, but the menu is far from it and this is very disappointing. The hamachi crudo is really good, but seemed to belong in a Japanese restaurant rather then here. The burger used to be really good, but now the it's wagyu and I find it nearly tasteless and overwhelmed by the bun. Many have raved about the carrot cake but I find it way too busy with so much going on with a small dessert and I thought it was flavorless. Yeah, I'm being a Debbie Downer here and it's not a bad place at all, but things just don't seem right and it confuses me.
author: Raymond M.

description:
I was here hosting an event and the service was impeccable. 

Amazing filet mignon + to-die-for kale salad. 

I will definitely be back.
author: Jaime L.

description:
3.5 stars

Picking a place to celebrate a special occasion is hard when you live in a city with so many amazing restaurants.  It took me a while to make an effort to eat at Boulevard, but a friend of mine told me that he regularly eats here and with their 2012 James Beard award, I knew that I had to give it a shot. So, here is where we celebrated our five year anniversary.

First, this place was CROWDED on an early Wednesday night.  Make reservations or try to snag a seat at the bar overlooking the kitchen. The decor is more classic than contemporary, which makes sense as it's been around for something like twenty years. I liked the curved, brick ceiling and the velvet seats.

The tips and reviews led me to believe that I would be offered a foie gras special despite the CA ban, so I was so, so sad when the server said that there were no specials for the night.  I was even sadder when I saw that the scallop appetizer wasn't on the menu for the night, too! Oh well. 

I have pretty much the same thing to say about everything we ordered.  The ahi tuna starter, the lobster, and the filet were all good dishes, a bit on the small side, but nothing that made my eyes roll back.  Nothing really bad to say, but I'm not dying to come back here.  We split the baked Alaska for dessert, and we both thought that we could have done without it.  

The cost for one cocktail, one non-alcoholic mocktail, one starter, two entrees, and one dessert came out to $160 after tax and tip, which I think is standard for a restaurant with one Michelin star, but I think I enjoyed my meals at similarly regarded restaurants much more. 

Oh, and even though I specified that we were celebrating an anniversary in my reservation, it was not acknowledged by anyone. I was surprised.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I was having a chat with a friend of mine at the gym who mentioned that A-Rod eats at Blvd in the city when he is in town. Co-incidentally, I was in this neighborhood the very next day looking for a place to eat and decided on Blvd. If it is good enough for A-Rod...

We did not have reservations and we were seated in the bar area which was fine since they were full that night. This has more of an old school vibe as opposed to modern. It is more like a work dinner or older couple type of place as opposed to a first date type of place.  I did see some families there as well which was nice.  I had a salad and the steak There were good but not amazing which I was expecting especially given the reputation and prices. Dessert was the best part!

Service was impeccable and I loved how our waiter took his time to explain each of our dishes.
author: Sunil R.

description:
I had a business lunch at Boulevard and just lucked into the place.  My business partner and I were looking for a place to talk through some work and kill time ahead of our next meeting.  We went into Boulevard and ended up with a great experience.

I'm going to focus on one silly dish:  beet carpaccio

Yes, it's strange to think of, since it's not meat, but this was a great dish.  We see beet salads all over the place now, but this was fresh in presentation, which was not only artful but utilitarian as well.  

The beets are sliced very thin and then laid in circle covering the whole plate with thin layers of oil and balsamic.  Sprouts and radishes then grace the top.  Check out my uploaded photo.  This was unique and provided the perfect balance of flavor in the salad. I'd strongly recommend it.
author: Rich V.

description:
This is a solid business meeting lunch or dinner spot.  The food is great, the service is good, and the place looks great.  

I do have to say that i prefer the sister restaurant Prospect!
author: John F.

description:
I made reservations to come here on Saturday. We were running late about 10 minutes so we called to let them know. When we arrived, the restaurant was not even full so we didn't feel too bad. My friend had told me Boulevard isn't what it used to be and not as popular--I guess this experience aligned with that statement. Albeit, I had a pleasant experience here with tasty and food and very attentive service.

We ordered these items:
1) angus filet mignon - wood oven roasted - crisp spanish style potato & soft potato aioli bloomsdale spinach, confit shallots, aged manchego & parsley garlic vierge pine nuts, beef jus
2) sea scallops - a la plancha, garlic & thyme, black risotto with cloud ear mushrooms, bacon & leek brandade, crispy artichoke hearts, lobster & clamshell mushroom limonette
3) ahi tuna tartare - black sesame lavash, sweet potato & hodo soy tofu with misosudachi lime kosho, citron & ginger

Everything we got was tasty and I recommend these 3 items for table for 2 people with moderately hungry stomachs. You will spend a pretty penny so make it a special occasion and dress up so you don't feel underdressed in a nice French restaurant. Take BART and get off at Embarcadero to save yourself from  a potential difficult parking headache.

So, I don't really recommend coming more than once but if you're craving expensive French food, Boulevard is a good candidate for that.
author: Marlon T.

description:
What Happened  Boulevard !?!?!  Very disappointing dinner last night , cold food , intrusive service , a all-round poor experience   . Firstly Mr Waiter if the guests are having a conversation and enjoying themselves  please don't continuously  interrupt , your not the center of attention so please stop trying to be . Secondly four of the entrees were cold and returned . They reheated them and returned them but they are  still cold ( no manager checked with us to see if they were ok ).
