But  Guys , who reheats food in a fine dining restaurant ???? This is not Chilis , Its the Boulevard !

So now I ask to see the manager , between 5 n 10 minutes later a lady appears to 1/2 heartedly apologize ( Peter was off ) and explains that its policy to reheat food and that these things happen . We reorder , food arrives , its Ehh , Waiter interrupts again , no desert , no coffee , No real attempt to resolve a poor experience . 
Not your finest hour .
author: Dominic J.

description: I've been a fan of Nancy Oakes since L'Avenue days, and until my meal at Boulevard this week I knew I was in a world-class restaurant.  This last week, however, I was sorely disappointed.  The service was friendly and efficient, and I had but one complaint with it (more later).  With the exception of a fabulous salad and a stunning desert, the food was a failure on the part of the kitchen.  We had the lamb and the duck.  Both arrived at the table lukewarm to cold.  Lamb that is anything but hot is not fit to be served in a fine restaurant.  The duck, also on the cool side, was tough.  Neither dish had much flavor.  When the waiter came to ask how things were, we said not so good.  He offered to take them back for heating.  I declined, since I'd rather have succulent lamb that was lukewarm than hot but dry lamb.  A better offer, it seemed to me, was to start over with fresh entree's and get it right the second time.  In a first-rate restaurant, there is no excuse for any error in either service or in the food.  I am reluctant to spend the kind of money this kind of restaurant (rightly) charges for a second-rate offering.  I hope the kitchen hears this, and returns to their former relentlessness pursuit of perfection.
author: Jeff D.

description: I am not a very wealthy individual, so i NEVER get to eat at places like Boulevard. Fortunately, I am on a work trip and my awesome VP recommended this place and said it was on her! I had the crab and avocado and a California Red. It was THE BEST CRAB I HAVE EVER HAD. It was perfectly cooked, not too salty, and beautifully presented. The flavor of the crab was an explosion of decadence and it was without the "fishy" flavor that sometimes permeates fresh seafood. I'm aware that I'm probably not eating at the right places, but it didn't have that "imitation crab" rubbery feel that also accompanies supposedly fresh seafood. The avocado and additional veggies were great too-- perfectly seasoned, just crispy enough, and overall, wonderful. I don't have enough adjectives to describe how amazing this meal was-- just go check it out. The service was also wonderful. We went on a Thursday night after our conference adjourned and got right in-- a table near the bar! The waiter was attentive, gave good advice about the food, and was not pushy. Overall, a really great experience. I hope one day I can go back!!
author: Kait B.

description:
Le pere de Prospect? Peut-etre...

As the "father" of Prospect, Boulevard offers American fare with French influences in a classy and old-fashioned atmosphere that I can see why it's favored among the more mature crowd.

I've had Boulevard bookmarked for months because I heard such great things about it. Other than going as a basis for comparison of Prospect (Chef Nancy Oakes' New Infinity Restaurant), nothing really enticed me enough to put it on the top of my list. However, needing to put a dent on our Yelp bookmarks and with Boulevard both on our list, fellow Yelper and my friend, Heather C. and I decided to tackle this Michelin rated restaurant first. 

On Wednesday, 12/8/10, we arrived at 7 PM for our 6:30 PM reservations and were promptly seated. I called earlier to inform the hostess that we were running late because we were both stuck in rush hour traffic which she said would be fine. 

F O O D:
*FOIE GRAS w/ Yuzu Marmalade & Persimmons ($27): YUMMY! 

The generous slab of foie gras was perfectly seared w/ a caramelized crust. It was decadently rich, savory and melted on my tongue like a triple cream butter. The slightly tart and acidic yuzu help counterbalance some of the richness while the al-dente persimmons added a nice subtle sweetness. The bread, similar to a honey bran muffin was dry and dense and ruined the integrity of the entire dish. I'm not sure if they were trying to take a "healthy" approach to this dish, but if I'm going to clog my arteries with fattened liver, please bring on the toasted brioche please! 

*LAMB CHOP & LOIN w/ Artichoke Heart & Aioli and Sautéed Spinach ($36): GOOD, but not great.

Albeit a bit bland, both the lamb chop and loin were perfectly cooked to a medium rare with a soft pink center. While both tender and moist, the lamb chop was richer in flavor with a slight gaminess, while the loin was leaner and tasted similar to steak sirloin. The aioli filled artichoke heart added a creamy punch of flavor to under-seasoned lamb while the spinach added a fresh hint of bitterness tying the dish together.

*FROMAGE CHEESECAKE w/ a Pistachio Crust & Lemon Sherbet ($10.50): WHOA...can I kiss the pastry chef??? *wink wink* This dessert had a complexity of different flavors and textures that worked in perfect harmony together.

The pistachio crust was light, crisp and flakey and was the perfect texture contrast to the cheesecake that was velvety rich, fluffy and slightly sweet with a hint of tang. The subtle vanilla flavor from the Chantilly cream added a layer of decadence while the lemon sherbet gave it a citrus freshness that made you feel you weren't committing a "complete" sweet tooth sin. 

S E R V I C E:
Friendly and attentive but slow. Our 3-course menu lasted over 2.5 hours as it took over 25 minutes to get our app and over 40 minutes to get our entrée. If you're under a time constraint, you may want to go elsewhere. 

A M B I A N C E / D É C O R:
Situated in a French Colonial style building in front of the Embarcadero's waterfront, Boulevard exudes Old World Charm which attracts a refined and more mature crowd. Although stuffy, dark woods, amber lighting and an open kitchen created a warm and somewhat inviting environment.

While a nice date place, with seating for nearly 150 people and tables tightly situated together, it makes it difficult to carry an intimate conversation without having to raise your voice. 

The restrooms were difficult to find and it took a few wrong turns before I could find it. They also needed to be tended to because there were un-flushed toilets and seat covers hanging all over. 

P A R K I N G:
Semi-difficult street parking after 6 PM. Valet parking is available for $8 for dinner or there's a parking garage located 1.5 blocks away on Spear St between Mission and Market St. 

I enjoyed my dinner at Boulevard, however, for a restaurant of this caliber, it was lacking both an oomph factor in its food and time management in its service for it to be worthy of 5 Stars. 

I can now see why Michael Bauer coined Boulevard as the sire of Prospect, but with its classic fare and dated ambiance, I think "grandfather" is a more appropriate term...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Ate here last month with my boyfriend's family and it was definitely a meal to remember. Right off the bat, walking up to Boulevard, you can see the building it's in is quite charming, and then you enter the interior... and it's also really beautiful. Although Boulevard's ambiance is very upscale, it felt warm and inviting. I started with a Burrata salad and had salmon as my entree. Both dishes had amazing flavors paired together and the quality was excellent! The  menu options had a more European feel. This restaurant is great for a special occasion -- date, fancier dinner with the family, etc. If you're a foodie living in the Bay, definitely put Boulevard on your list.
author: Jean L.

description: Excellent food and staff! Haven't been in a few years and brought some business colleagues here the other night. Everyone raved about the food. I was please that it's still consistently delicious year after year. One of my favorite places to dine in San Francisco.
author: Linda K.

description: Brought my husband here for his birthday last night and was really impressed! The service was wonderful and the food was amazing! We ordered the crab ravioli to begin and had the lamb t-bone and filet as entrees. Both of which melted in our mouths....would for sure order both again. The wine recommendation by our waiter was fantastic and my husbands Moscow Mule was one of the best I'd ever tried. The dessert, chocolate cream puffs were enough alone to make us go back again. Although it's pricey ~$200 for both of us (we each had two drinks though) we will for sure be back soon!
author: Sommer A.

description:
***Boulevard is a nice, rustic and seasonal restaurant; there are parts of each course that are very impressive, but I do not think it is as good as my favorite rustic restaurants--Lucques, the now closed Campanile, The Village Pub, and The Farmhouse Inn & Restaurant***

Nancy Oakes' Boulevard is a very longstanding upscale San Francisco restaurant.  It recently won the James Beard award for best restaurant in the country and it remains popular today.  Despite the large size of the restaurant, it was quite busy for lunch on my visit.

The lunch menu at Boulevard is very seasonal from starters to desserts.  Their lunch menu includes a lot of lunch-type dishes like salad entrees, but you will find more dinner-esque items too like housemade pasta, scallop starters and ambitious desserts.

I started with their salad of mixed organic lettuces, poached Seckle pear, Hamada persimmons, Bayley Hazan blue cheese, and candied walnuts.  The salad immediately reminded me of a Waldorf Salad.  It was a great combination of flavors and contrasting textures.  The produce was fresh and vibrant.

While I felt the greens were kind of ordinary and the blue cheese did not have the uniqueness of great blue cheese I have had, I really liked the poached pear--lightly sweet and tender but not soggy or too soft.  The candied walnuts provided a good and sweet crunch.  I also liked the persimmons, which had a good flavor though Lucques' burrata and persimmon salad is superior to this one.

Next came the beet pyramid ravioli.  The ravioli was pretty good.  It had a good pasta thickness and the beet puree was very creamy though the beet flavor was not as strong as I was expecting.  The garnishes were great.  I really liked the crunch from the toasted almonds and rye berries.  The Cana 'd Cabra goat cheese was very creamy and had a more distinct flavor than the earlier blue cheese.

I then had the seared day boat sea scallops and they were nicely cooked--good outside sear (nicely golden and flavorful), soft and moist.  The base of succotash with yellow and white corn with heirloom beans was the kind of side you would just not find at a merely good restaurant.  The succotash was fresh and very evenly cooked.  The overall flavor combination was not as great as other scallops dishes I have had, but this was still a good dish.

I had the butternut squash cake next, which was garnished with creamy and sweet maple sugar creme, sage ice cream, a very tart brown butter hard sauce, and crunchy Piedmontese hazelnuts.  The cake was soft and not dry though the butternut squash flavor was not as strong as it should have been.  It was not a great dessert, but it showed that the kitchen might be able to put out some excellent desserts in the future.

Service was good.  The servers were pleasant but not as friendly as other places--mostly due to the brisk pace of the restaurant.  The service was attentive, efficient and quick.

Lunch prices are not too bad here.  Boulevard is definitely pricey, but it is an upscale place with high quality ingredients and strong talent in the kitchen.

The decor at Boulevard is okay.  It has an open kitchen, which is nice.  At first blush, the room feels out-of-fashion, but it has a decor that embraces its building's existing structure and design, which makes the decor feel right and not needing of a change.

Boulevard is a good and solid restaurant.  There is definitely strong technique in the kitchen and a very good attention to detail (down to the nicely plated desserts and good table bread with a great chew).  I like the seasonal approach and the freshness and flavor of the produce.  Boulevard is not as ambitious or creative as some of San Francisco's newer and more contemporary restaurants, but it remains a solid choice for a nice upscale lunch.

Valet parking is available.  You can also find metered street parking near the Ferry Building.
author: Anthony N.

description:
The first time I came here for dinner I was relatively unimpressed by the food here. I thought it was one of those overhyped, over priced type restaurants despite the awards it had received...had I reviewed it on Yelp then, I'd probably have only given it a 2 based on the food, service, and experience. But when the partner at my firm picked this place to come for lunch, who was I to say no?

We came here around 12:30 and were seated right away. There was quite a range of people here: corporate business types, the super casual start-up types the touristy types, etc etc..so it was already little different from my previous dinner experience.

The food this time was actually decent. Perhaps now that my expectations had been lowered, I wasn't expecting anything to blow my socks off.

I ordered:

1. Ahi Tuna Tartare - This was really good. The chips were a bit on the oily side, but I just ditched the chips and dived straight into the fish. It was fresh and well seasoned. I definitely enjoyed it.

2. The Salmon - This was ok. It definitely wasn't the best I'd ever had...and if I had to rate the salmon just on its own, i would probably only give it a 2. There were some bites that were delish..and some bites that were really bland. Meh.

3. Butterscotch pudding - this was pretty decent, but not my favorite.

4. Lemon Bar - YES. It was so good. I love lemon bars...so I'm definitely biased. It was still good though. yes. noms.

Overall elevated my experience here from a 2 to a 3, not a huge leap, but definitely somewhere I'd try again. :)
author: Jennifer S.

description: Clearly not a French restaurant. A Californian one with all the goodness and the limits. The produces are great but 4 lines to explain a dish are 3 too many. Starters come too fast. Simplify, simplify simplify.
author: MarcAntoine J.

description: This is the San Francisco stalwart. Whenever I am in town I go here. So many appealing dishes on the menu -- we're talking hard choices making a decision.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I think it's fitting for me to review this place as my 400th -- I've come a long way!

Anyway, my sis, the S.O. and I were out for a drive to get dinner and my sis decided to pull onto the valet of the Boulevard.

My reaction: "we're eating THE Boulevard dressed in jeans and our puffy jackets?!"

Sis: "yes, my Visa is as good as anybody's inside there."

Me: (gulp) "Ok."

Thus... the S.O. asked if we could get a table for three w/o any reservations and the host said yes...

Upon walking in... no one really gave us the look of death for looking the way we were... Then we sat down and our server was just extremely polite and on top of things... another good start.

I won't go into details with what the sis and the S.O. ordered since I didn't taste their food ... so here's what I got:

- Fresh Porcini Mushrooms & Cal Burrata Cheese (Champagne Risotto & Extra Virgin Olive Oil) ~ OMG! This was amazing! The portion wasn't too small or too big, it was perfect! The risotto was cooked to perfection! The burrata cheese and the mushroom tasted so fresh and the whole dish just blended all together. I was in love!

- Pan Roasted Sea Bass (Roasted Chestnuts, Chanterelle Mushrooms & Pancetta Sauteed Shaved Brussels Sprouts with Shallots & Herbs) ~ This was good... but not mind blowing good. The sea bass was tasty and it was cooked right... not dry at all. The side dishes that accompanied the fish tasted wonderful as well... the Pancetta was crispy!

For drinks... I started off with my Hanger One Kaffir Lime with 7-UP... then the sis ordered a bottle of the Chablis Grand Cru = my new fave white wine!

Overall, service was perfect. Food was excellent! My sis is right... good food needs to be enjoyed when your most comfy not decked out in suits and tight dress... I think even Anthony Bourdain said something similar at one of his shows. 

Thanks sis... again for an amazing dinner!
author: Cath M.

description:
Boulevard remains a wonderfully indulgent dining destination, delivering masterfully-prepared dishes without the pomp and circumstance of similarly-priced restaurants.

Even though we were seated on the opposite side of the restaurant this time (right by the entranceway), we had plenty of privacy and attention from the staff[1].

Our lobster tail l'amuse bouche was delightful, as was the Sonoma foie gras. The brown bread pairing threw us off, but the foie gras itself was marvelous, melting in our mouths. Also noteworthy was their scallops appetizer, a rich, tender treat. My entree, perfect cuts of Kobe beef, was tender and full-flavored, and reminded me why I'm happy to be a carnivore[2].

Several bottles of wine later, we found we had ordered more than we could comfortably finish. Not that that was an issue[3].


[1] Shout-out to server Alisha and bartender Patrick, and our busser, whose name I missed.
[2] Their menu has many meat options, but will be a challenge for vegetarians.
[3] Leftovers tasted just as good the next day.
author: Dave L.

description:
My experience here was mediocre at best. I had reservations at 6:15 on a Sunday, the hostess was pleasant and greeted us with a smile, and we were seated promptly. Our server came by, offered us some water and gave us a few moments to look over the menu. 

Starters:
We started off with the "smoked veal sweetheart sweetbreads and  "goat cheese, marcona almonds, & arugula". The sweetbreads came with two pieces on top of a thin sheet of mashed potatoes and were crispy on the outside and creamy on the inside. While it wasn't a bad dish, it didn't have a wow factor about it. The arugula salad however, was pretty good. I loved the marcona almonds it came with and the thick cut slices of goat cheese were delicious.

Bread:
We didn't receive our bread until after our starters came out. Oh well. The cold bread was served with room temperature butter with sea salt on top. The butter stole the show on this compliment. 

Entrees:
My bf ordered the pacific sea bass and he enjoyed his dish. The celery root purée it was served on top of was tasty and all of the components worked well together. I ordered the wood oven roasted pork prime rib chop and the meat was juicy and cooked perfectly. However, the yams that came with it were served cold! Yuck. It was as if my yams had been cooked first and left to sit on a cold plate while they started on the actual entree. While the maple bourbon sour cream sounded enticing, it didn't do much for the dish overall. 

Dessert: 
We decided to share the "holiday plate". It consisted of what looked and tasted like a sugar cookie wreath with red and green sprinkles that I could have bought a dozen of at the local grocery store for $3.99. A mini red velvet cupcake that tasted also store bought, a wrapped candy caramel, a piece of fudge, a nice attempt on a take of an ice cream sandwich, and a chocolate brownie tasting thing. In the words of Chef Ron Ben-Israel.... "In this test, you were no sweet genius." What this dessert plate really should have been named was "store bought dessert items that were on clearance" because that's what it tasted like. 

Service: 
For a restaurant to toot their horn on their food and service, our waiter failed to channel that on this particular night. We didn't get his name until our tab was presented to us and his name "Hunter" was printed on the receipt. I felt like we were shafted with the mute waiter that night. Maybe because we are younger than the crowd that they're usually accustomed to catering? Maybe he was having a bad night? Whatever the reason, the service wasn't warm and welcoming as I would have expected. 

The overall experience wasn't bad, wasn't as good as I had hope and expected, and wasn't memorable. I won't be back.
author: Victoria T.

description: Unless you're over 50, steer clear of this spot. The interior looks like an old vegas restaurant, with the crowd to match. Ordered the black truffle pasta starter for $37, but couldn't taste any truffle whatsoever. You could see the truffle, but couldn't taste it at all. So all I can think is that the truffle was very low quality. Had the pork chop entree  and while it was cooked very nicely, it had zero seasoning. Very disappointing experience overall. At 35 years old, I was the youngest person there. I would say the food very much matches the older crowd that is used to waiters wearing vests and ties, and boring hotel style food.  Giving two stars as the service was refined, albeit the server didn't know the menu as well as he should have. All in all, much better places to eat in SF you could find.
author: N T.

description:
RIP OFF

This place is way over priced for what you get.  We started with the octopus/calamari appetizer.  For $19 you get 2 little rings of calamari and 2 - 2 inch slivers of octopus.   For the entree...I had the halibut.  Tiny $39 piece of fish that was dry, flavorless and over cooked (you can get a much better halibut dinner at Tadich Grill for probably 2/3 the price).   My buddy had the lamb...very tasty but again for $39...you got 3 - 2 inch squares of meat about 1/2 inch thick.  Still hungry we went for dessert.  Ordered a scoop of ice cream for $5...I think they used a melon scoop to dish out the ice cream.  

Maybe this is a place to be "seen" in San Francisco...but the City has MUCH better restaurants.
author: Earl C.

description:
Interesting French food restaurant.
Skylark red belly is a nice Californian red wine.
I chose the grilled calamari as starters and lamb as main course. But the most delicious was dark chocolate tart. Good atmospheres and services.
author: Qingyi Z.

description:
Was just ok.  
Heard a lot about Boulevard and wanted to dine here for a long time.  
Service was great.  Attentive wait staff. 
Food was ok.  Nothing to write home about.  We had the halibut.  And the salmon.  

For dessert, we split the apple crisp with phyllo strings.  Meh.  

Been here.  Done that.  Next.
author: Paul C.

description:
Not A Cheap Date - But One You Won't Regret.....

Pros:     Great food.  Professional yet friendly service.  Warm ambiance.
Cons:    A tad (or 2 tads) expensive.  Bathroom is in a strange location.

Suggestion:  Request a table by the Embarcadero window.  Order the Chocolate Pot De Creme.

Star Ratings:
-   Overall:     4 1/2
-   Food Quality:   5
-   Food Quantity:   4
-   Menu:     5
-   Wine List:    5
-   Service:    5
-   Bathrooms:    3
-   Price:    4
-   Value:    5
-   Parking:     4
-   Ambiance:    5

It's been said there are more restaurants per person in SF than anywhere else in the US.  I believe it.  So when a couple of clients came to town at the beginning of a 4 day vacation in Napa Valley, my partner (in business) and I wanted to find something worthy of 2 very good people.  A place which looked and tasted fine without breaking the bank. 

-   Location:  Boulevard is in a beautifully restored building facing the Embarcadero at the end of Mission Street.  If you're lucky enough, you might get a spot with views from the Ferry Plaza to the Bay Bridge.  We did.  It was gorgeous.

-  Dining Room:  The room is much longer than it's wide with a good sized bar along one wall in the middle.  As befits a long-time establishment still in great demand, tables are spaced to almost maximize the number of patrons. However, you can get around without bumping the elbows of strangers and hold a conversation in a nearly normal tone of voice.  Ambiance is expensive yet warm and friendly.  Upper crust for everyday people.

-   Menu:   The menu is rather small, but as I said to a dinner companion, it doesn't need to be large if the selections are well chosen and executed.  Although the number and type can change on a daily basis, I counted 10 "starters", 7 entrees and 7 desserts.  The written descriptions were a bit high-fallutin' as if well versed prose counted toward more points, but I guess that goes with the territory.

-   Food:   Good looks will only take you so far.  Did the interesting menu translate to the plate?  It did.  Three of the 4 diners began with a "starter", including Pan Seared Scallops, Fairytale Pumpkin Soup and Beet Ravioli.  Portions were not huge, but everyone was happy.  The sauce with my ravioli was so good I needed extra slices of Boulevard's Acme sourdough to sop it up.  That sourdough was so tasty I could've had dinner with just bread, butter and wine.

Entrees were along that same vein...exotic sounding but with both feet close to the ground.  Everything earned a thumbs up.  My Alaskan Halibut sat on a bed of tomato risotto with small amounts of vegetables on the side.  The sauce draining through that risotto was so compelling I once again called upon the Acme bread to help clean my plate.  Good sourdough is as close to heaven as most people will get. 

My tablemates had Wild King Salmon...Lamb Prime T-Bone...and something called New England Lobster Clam Bake with a cornmeal clam fritter and steamed mussel.  Each was accompanied by vegetables.  Nary a complaint was voiced.

Dessert was unreal.  While our clients chose to close dinner with a drink, my partner and I each ordered the "Chocolate Pot De Creme".  It was ONE OF THE BEST EVER.  We each received a bowl with flourless chocolate cake topped with caramel malt syrup, Guinness meringue, milk chocolate lace and malted ice cream.  Just the right amount and combination of ingredients.  Holy moly.

-   Wine List:   As expected, the list was rather extensive.  However, it was well grouped and easy to understand. When we had a question, our server flagged the Sommelier who provided good advice without running up the tab. We each had a glass of chardonnay and shared a bottle of Fiddlesticks Pinot Noir from the Fiddlehead Winery near Lompoc.  A fine choice for $72.

-   Service:   Friendly, efficient and accommodating.  Our server, a youngish woman (aren't they all?), had an excellent understanding and perspective of the menu.  In particular, her patience to answer what some might consider "niggling" questions was quite admirable.

-   Price and Value:  Boulevard is not cheap.  $460 for 4 people is a bit steep to become a habit except for those with top tier jobs, a portfolio of lucky stocks with a low cost basis or an expense account.  Of course, value is something else.  It's not a cheap date, but one you won't regret.

-   Parking:  Valet parking at dinner is a reasonable $10.  Self parking is available a block away.  Parking on the street is chancy...especially at night.

-   Bathroom:  The bathroom was fine - when we found it.  You need to exit Boulevard through a seemingly innocuous door into the hallway of an adjacent building and walk down a flight of stairs.  At least it was good exercise.

For people living 50-60 miles away from San Francisco (such as me), Boulevard is almost a destination. Despite the hassles of driving through traffic on potholed streets, I must say the end justified the means.  I'll be back.
author: Richard N.

description: Came here twice. The first was for a dinner event and the service was terribly slow, like unbelievably slow. There was so much time spent waiting between each course. However, I came back for lunch and they made it up. Service was excellent! Despite the slow service during the first visit, their food was delicious, as it was during the second. My Dungeness crab salad, which I had both times was so so good, the steak bavette was cooked to a perfect medium, and the lemon ice box cake dessert was wonderful and not overly sweet. The recommended rose champagne was also a great suggestion and the blackberry peach lemonade was so tasty! I would definitely come back again.
author: Becky C.

description:
Brought my family here to celebrate my dad's birthday. Three stars because we only enjoyed 1/3 of the appetizers, entrees and desserts ordered. For a Michelin rated restaurant and for the $$$, we expected to enjoy more than a 1/3 of our meal. 

Appetizers Ordered: beef carpaccio, calamari and the scallops. This was my first time trying beef carpaccio and I felt that it was too raw for me. I love my steaks and prime rib medium rare so I'm biased on this one. Calamari wasn't the typical fried calamari you'd expect elsewhere which I was surprised by but definitely enjoyed. Scallops were fresh and tender but bland. I wouldn't order this again for $18 a dish. 

Entrees Ordered: filet mignon, lamb and the quail. Ordered the filet mignon medium rare just how I like it. Took one bite of this and knew it was the wrong choice. The steak was a bit tough and dry for my taste so I wouldn't recommend the steak. Lamb was tender and juicy. Good, but not memorable. It was served with deliciously cooked potatoes and pistachios that gave it a nice crunch. The quail was the best of the three entrees. The meat was tender and succulent. Skin was crunchy.

Desserts Ordered: dirty cowgirl, cheesecake, olive oil ice cream. Our waiter highly recommended the dirty cowgirl but we all found the dessert covered in strawberries to be mediocre. Cheesecake was my favorite. Loved the creamy texture of the cheesecake combined with the crunchiness of the crust. Highly recommend this! Was intrigued by the olive oil ice cream but found it to be light in flavor and unmemorable along with the flourless chocolate cake it was served with.
author: C Y.

description:
Best meal I've had in San Francisco. The quality of the food is beyond comparison.
We started with the scallops and puréed beets. It was INCREDIBLE.

I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Michelle H.

description: Not very impressed......the food was cold and the flavors were lacking in the Kurabuta park chop.  I celebrated my big bday there and they let me down.  :(
author: Kim D.

description: Boulevard is a restaurant whose food quality just doesn't just justify it's prices. Their food is good, it's just not "$300 per couple good". We started with the scallop appetizer, which was petite in portion and average in flavor. My wife had the pork loin and I had the lamb t-bone. Again, both were fine, but didn't distinguish themselves from food at half their price. The service was good and the setting is lovely. If the price was cut by half, I'd give it 4 Stars. But at the prices they charge, they don't warrant more than 2. In a city with thousands of options, you're better off going elsewhere.
author: Greg H.

description:
Boulevard is a great venue to take clients. We took a large group of clients here and had a relatively good experience. While the restaurant has great ambiance and is very clean, the food I would rate at a 3/5 stars. 

We ordered many items on the menu. Here is what I got:

- Crab soup (soup of the day) - $10 - very delicious, but the soup was a bit water-y. Also, there was barely any crab given.
- Kobe Steak $26 - I ordered medium rare, but it came pretty rare. It was so chewy that it was very difficult to swallow. I would not recommend getting it again. The potato and greens that came with it were much better.
- Sodas are not free refills (just FYI) - ended up paying $22 for about 6 sodas - they don't warn you of this either
- Scallops - very small portions unfortunately. We ordered one for everybody.

Overall, the experience was great, but the food was lacking, especially at over $40 a person. I would come back, but be hesitant to eat what I previously tried.
author: Albert K.

description:
My babe brought me here for my birthday.

Right next to the piers so we could take a nice walk before hand and after. Very classy atmosphere and the average age of the guests are at 40s.

Pork loin prime rib and Lamb t-bone both sound great, but we didn't want to order two meats so we went with 4 appetizer, 1 entree and dessert instead. The techniques and flavors are there. The chefs definitely deserve the recognition.  Improving the service and other peripherals like bread and butter can push this restaurant even higher, but that's really not necessary. For the quality of dishes you get, this place is well priced imo.

Calamari with lobster stuffing:
Although I like lobster, I didn't think lobster will show the skill of the chef very much so this might turn out boring, but babe wanted to try. Turns out, this is the best dish of the night. Very tender and well timed lobster in tender hotaru squid with herbal white sauce. Legs fried to perfection with clean batter that doesn't get in the way.

Quail:
very meaty and tender quail legs. Crispy, not over sweetened teriyaki glazing. Nicely done. 

Tuna tartar:
The tuna is very fresh and chunky. Although looked normal, I liked the cured kumquat and zesty sauce with hint of paprika or bell pepper making it interesting.

Sea scallop:
Very tender scallop. Nicely sauteed but not too surprising. What really hit me was the brandade croquette. Very nice texture and so clean that I cannot believe it's fried.

Lamb T-bone (entree):
Medium rare. Tender, not gamy. Delicious, but not exceptional.

Dirty Girl Alpine Strawberry:
I'm not a dessert person, but the strawberries were nicely cured. And not over sweeten.
author: Lance C.

description: Excellent food. Quail was the best thing in the table. The pork chop recommended by our waiter was great. Service couldn't have been better
author: Erick A.

description:
Wonderful dining experience. Although, I went here for a company dinner w/ preset menu to choose from...
Tuna tartar was exquisite, pork chop looked tender melt in your mouth and the brownie rocky road? Desert was simple yet delish! Wouldn't mind coming here on my own expense to try other dishes...
author: Frances D.

description:
Oh man, after seeing this place being raved about on Yelp, I decided I had to try it. Fortunately a friend and I were in the area one lovely Friday night and decided to head in. We didn't keep our hopes up though since I knew that this was a one Michelin star place and I assumed that we would probably need reservations. Well. FALSE. We didn't! Wow we got lucky enough to actually get a seat in about twenty minutes or so? They didn't have any tables so we got seated at the chef's bar which I honestly thought was an awesome place to sit because you got to watch the chef's prepare everything and that was a pretty sick experience if you ask me.

We ordered sea scallops, the halibut, quail, and and the meringue for dessert.

Sea scallops--great presentation but nothing special... we sat in front of the chefs that were preparing the appetizers so I really got to see the different types of presentations for the dishes. Sea scallops were good scallops but a bit on the flavorless side. 

The halibut--ugh. This was a disappointment. We had chosen the halibut because it was highly recommended but it ended up just being insanely dry. I didn't even finish my portion. 

Quail--this was exciting and so wonderful. Different parts of quail all fried and oh goodness oh so yummy. The peach fritters also complimented the dish very well.

Meringue--my friend and I are not extremely versed in the world of fine dining, so in all honesty, we were pretty confused as to what the meringue actually was. It honestly just looked and tasted like a giant marshmallow. Peaches were good, but I would have to say that the sorbet was the most redeeming part. Should probably just go with the sorbet in the future.

All in all, a really solid experience with great service. Despite the place being busy, the waiters were very accommodating and honestly I was just thrilled that we were able to get a seat for dinner on a Friday night. A solid 4-star restaurant. Not a 5 because I feel like a 5-star restaurant has to blow your mind. This place had decent food, but nothing extraordinary. It has great ambience though and is definitely worth a go at least once.


tldr; solid restaurant if you need to go somewhere a bit on the nicer side
author: Jasmine X.

description: Great service and excellent food.  Would highly recommend this to anyone who is willing to pay for a great meal, exquisite food and fantastic atmosphere.
author: Matt K.

description:
Just finished a meal here and I'm neither disappointed, nor on cloud 9, hence "a-ok" 3 stars. Service here is spot on, I am blanking on his name but we were taken care of by a bald man with glasses and a goatee who was very warm, funny, and easy-going.

We were a bit late, but seated promptly. We were seated in the back of the restaurant, at a table right in front of the ramp, most likely as a bit of the slap on the wrist for being late (there were plenty of other tables open). No matter, I took the seat closest to the ramp so that my parents could sit peacefully towards the inside of the dining area. As i predicted, one of the bussers with a goatee bumped into me almost every time he went down the ramp, knocking me with extra chairs, a tray, his arm, etc. He also bumped into my dad once. While the restaurant was busier than normal (Fleet Week, Giants Game, 49ers Game, Madonna concert, etc.) and I'm sure he was tired, it was kind of excessive. We ended up moving the table backwards towards the dining about half a foot, problem solved. They should considering just making that table a table for two, instead of three.

We had the heirloom tomato mozzarella salad, ravioli, and ahi tuna (in order of preference). Of these, the heirloom tomato salad was the winner by a long shot. The quinoa was phenomenal, and I've never had it prepared like that. The mozzarella was quite creamy and the tomatoes were very juicy and fresh! The ravioli was the next best thing, which usually comes with 1 rabbit piece and 2 wild greens and ricotta pieces, but since there were three of us and we were sharing, the waiter suggested we add an additional rabbit piece. The rabbit piece was very nice, much better than the greens/ricotta. Finally the ahi we could have (and should have!) done without, as the texture was just so strange. It looked (and tasted..?) like worms! We would have much preferred it to have been cubed or sliced.

For the mains, we had the halibut, lamb t-bone, and quail (in order of preference). My halibut was slightly overdone, but the white tomato risotto underneath was just right. It came with a single squash blossom stuffed with rock shrimp and fennel, I wish they could have given me another! The lamb usually comes medium rare but we were asked if this was okay, and we asked for it medium. It came out about half way in between both, and tasted a little gamy. The purple potatoes were very nice though. The quail was also very gamy, and overcooked. We were told this one comes at a specific temperature (which we were fine with), otherwise it tastes like liver. Well, it did end up tasting like liver, so if you are upset about the foie gras ban you should definitely come here, order the quail, and ask for it overcooked. 

At this point of the meal I was actually still hungry, because the portions were so small. I think I preferred the small portions because nothing was that amazing, but I would have otherwise been disappointed if it was much better and still small.

Finally for dessert, we had the chocolate marshmallow pie, the sticky toffee sundae, and the house sent us chocolate hazelnut bonbons as we were celebrating a birthday. The dessert was the best part of the meal, phenomenal! Don't let the medjool date cake turn you off, I like dates, but thought the cake would be some type of weird health freak thing, but it was delicious and didn't really taste like dates. We couldn't decide which dessert was better but they were both very good. Jessica Sullivan, you are an amazing pastry chef!

Weaver's decaf coffee was very smooth and the cappuccino also very nice.

All in all, I don't think that I would return or particularly recommend this place, but I don't regret coming here either.
author: Dahlia S.

description:
Since its beginning Boulevard has stuck with its original concept and it works!
Call me old fashioned but there's something to be said about no thrills, no frills and no bizarre presentation food and drinks.  
Good food and good service in my opinion is their recipe for success! 
 For starters we shared the goat cheese and medjool date salad along with the spicy sesame ahi tuna tartare and the seared sea scallops.  All three were great!  Again no thrills, no frills, no weird presentation, just good tasting food with fresh ingredients. 
For the entrees my wife had the salmon and I had the burger, both were perfectly cooked!
For dessert we shared the butter scotch pudding and it was fantastic!
We will most definitely return and recommend.
Service was polite and cordial without being obtrusive.
author: Alex N.

description:
Went here for a work lunch with my team.  It was a great treat for us.  Made reservations through Open Table.

There is valet so you don't have to worry too much about it, but it's $15 bucks, more than it is for dinner.  Cash only, pay in advance to the valet guy.

Once inside, it's amazing how it looks.  It definitely takes you to a different place.

Service was great.  Everyone was friendly and helpful.

None of us got any drinks other than water and coffee, but on with the food.

One of the girls ordered the beets ravioli.  I don't like beets, but for some reason the ravioli with goat cheese and the nuts - it was quite yummy.  Don't know if I'd order a plate, but did get to enjoy half of one.

I got the Kobe Bavette.  It's basically just slices of Kobe beef.  The crispy potato was essentially a twice baked potato.  It was just perfectly crispy on the outside, with the inside stuffed potato part nice and smooth.  Someone else ordered the scallops appetizer, but asked for a lunch size portion - which is something they can apparently do.  She always gets this item because she likes it so much.  There was also a swordfish and Ahi tuna ordered.  Everyone enjoyed their food.

We ordered a few desserts.  I ordered the Pecan cake because when I asked the server if I should get that or the pot de creme, she couldn't have said pecan cake fast enough.  Someone else ordered two bon bons.  For them each being $3.50, I don't know if it's worth that much because they were so small.   I mean, I guess that's what a bon bon is, but man, $3.50?

Overall, we enjoyed our time and the food.  I'm sure we'll be back.
author: Grace C.

description: Great service, excellent tasting food, valet parking and beautiful dining room. The only reason I can't give 5 stars is that none of the food was served hot (my husband had the same comment). When I asked our server about it, she said they let them meat "rest" before serving it. I get that, but that doesn't explain why the rest of the plate was also at room temperature. It was quite tasty, but just not at the right temp.
author: Nancy M.

description:
I am revising my earlier review (see below) from three stars to four based on a recent visit for lunch. The food was excellent and the server attentive and competent.
This time the problem was in the bar.
Perspective: last time (see earlier review) we arrived early before being joined by the couple we had invited, and sat in the bar, a few feet from the bartender, but he did not seem very interested in providing us with drinks after we ordered them. Lethargic bar service.
Fast forward to the recent lunch: again the bartender has no sense of service. We asked for two glasses of champagne to accompany our starters but the food arrived and had been consumed by the time the bartender could respond (the server saw the problem and apologized, but it was not her fault). Again, lethargic bar service.
It may be that the bar is understaffed and overwhelmed (this was a weekday and the place was busy but not too crowded). But the old saying applies: once is an accident, twice is coincidence. Three times? That should never happen in a Chronicle 100 restaurant.
Our meal was made less pleasant by the presence of a Very Important Person sitting behind me, who kept jolting his chair against mine, even after I moved the table and my wife's chair and my own further away. To make up for it, he left his crossed leg dangling in the serving aisle and made it difficult for servers to get around him. But he is Very Important and we should all be bowing, scraping and telling him how wonderful he is. I mentioned this to our server and told her that I understood her problem: one can't ask such a person to be more considerate of others. Consideration is for the little people. Very Important? Sure. If you don't believe me, ask him.

Most of us, unless we are wealthy, dine out only occasionally for a special event. We want a great experience at a great restaurant. We expect, above all, good value and we must necessarily consider the prices.
Having dined at Boulevard some years back, my wife and I, with guests, were looking forward to returning and were prepared for that great experience and good value once more.  We particularly liked the ambiance of the place, intact, though the brick ceiling added to the noise levels.
Service was rushed but competent. The wines we chose, by the glass and bottle, were excellent. My quail main course was exceptional--tender, moist and perfectly prepared. I had hoped for sides of some sort, but none were offered.
On the other hand . . .
At around $20 for starters and $30+ for main courses, this is an expensive restaurant. One offering was a three-ounce strip steak. Yes, just three ounces, prepared no doubt by scalpel. The tiny portions do not warrant these prices. It's not just a matter of value, it''s appetite too.
And . . .
The greatest disappointment was a detail, but an important one. I ordered the crab and artichoke bisque, and it was pleasant except for that detail. It came barely warm and was served in a cold bowl, so that it was tepid in seconds. After that, I touched the plates of all the other servings on the table as they came out: same thing, cold plates. No risk of our food remaining even warm, despite the few mouthfuls of food.
God and the devil, we have been told, are in the details.
author: John J.

description: Incredibly attentive staff, yummy food, and a place where I shall return! Sat and ate solo, the lovely woman who sat beside me returned for the 2nd night without her husband. Ordered the burata salad and the salmon. Didn't disappoint. Had fun watching the magic happen from the Chef's counter. Merci!
author: Davy M.

description:
Classic dinner spot. The filet mignon is perfection. If you are looking for a nice classic american dinner this is a great place. 

The downstairs is great to rent out for private parties
author: Korissa S.

description:
I had high expectations for this place, but it was just A-OK.
When I booked the reservations, the host asked for any sitting preference and I told her to put me where she would like to sit and she placed my table right in front of embarcadero facing the bay lights (Thanks you B). Service was attentive, but I based this review on the food itself.

We had the Ahi Tuna Tartare for appetizer as well as the soup of the day (lobster), main entree we had the Porkchop, dessert we had the Red Velvet Cake. All in all the food was good, but not a WOW factor for my palate.
author: Virginia L.

description: overpriced, bland food; mediocre service.  I do not understand why it is so popular.
author: Karen K.

description:
I have to give the servers a lot of credit for putting up with my co-workers shenanigans.  Some people just can't handle alcohol at lunch.

Bad behavior aside, our holiday lunch was glorious.  The restaurant is so beautifully decorated in art nouveau and was tricked out for the holidays in a spectacular fashion.

Given that we were such a large group, we managed to try everything on the menu, with the crab/grapefruit salad and the lobster bisque as standouts.  The bavette steak was the clear favorite of the entree choices but I stuck with the wonderful sole which was cooked perfectly and napped with a delicious sauce.  I loved the crumble dessert as well as the pot de creme.  

Thanks again to Boulevard for a wonderful event.  I've been eating Nancy Oake's food since the old days when she cooked at Pat 'O Shea's Mad Hatter and will always be a fan.

If you enjoy good food and wine, plus great service and fabulous surroundings, you owe it to yourself to come to Boulevard.
author: .Hon H.

description: My husband and I started off with the ahi tuna appetizer, delicious! Which was followed by the quail and filet mignon entree, so much flavor on one plate. The staff was really attentive and all very friendly.  This place lives up to its reputation for sure.
author: A M.

description:
4.5 Stars. I've been wanting to try Boulevard for a long time and I finally had a chance to do it. Overall, a fantastic meal, I thoroughly enjoyed every dish but some were clear favorites over others. One thing that I particularly noticed about Boulevard is that every dish was paired with just the right reduction, accompaniments, and sides. It is very clear that they've put a lot of thought and consideration into every dish and how the flavors really come together and what complements it.

AHI TUNA CRUDO - 5 stars, if you like raw fish, you'll love this dish. Fresh, flavored just right, absolutely perfect and I can't wait to come back to eat it again!

CRISPY KONA ABALONE & HAMACHI TARTARE - 3.5 stars, very delicious, albeit a tad spicy (which I did not expect), but I couldn't tell what I was eating (was that abalone or hamachi or something else?) except for a combination of flavors that worked well but did overpower the seafood just a tad bit.

SEA SCALLOPS - 5 stars, seared just right and paired nicely with a non-conventional "polenta" that works just right. Loved the scallops especially, fresh and delicious.

SEARED FOIE GRAS - 5 stars. FANTASTIC. I absolutely adored this dish SO much, especially after the long hiatus from foie gras due to the California ban. This was one of the main reasons I wanted to come here. They seared it just ever so lightly to perfection and everything alongside it was fabulous. 

BRENT WOLFE KING QUAIL - 5 stars. Wow, this is probably the best quail I've ever had. Extremely fresh and just beautifully flavored and done just right. This dish was recommended by our server and we were glad we went with her suggestion!

CALIFORNIA LAMB T-BONE - 5 stars. Again, extremely fresh meat, done just right, perfectly flavored. Another fantastic dish.

SEA BASS - 3 stars. I was actually really looking forward to this dish and whereas it was still a good dish, it just wasn't as strong as the other ones and felt more like a generic filet that I could've had at another restaurant. This is probably the sole reason why I didn't give Boulevard an overall 5 star rating. I think I was expecting something more special and it was more of a pleasant but generic dish in the end.

WINTER SYMPHONY CRISP - 4 stars. I'm not a fruit-dessert type of person but was pleasantly surprised by how much I actually liked this one.

CHERRY BROWNIE BON BON - 3.5 stars. Was also really looking forward to this one because I love chocolate and cherry. It was very good but I wish the cherry was a bit more pronounced rather than a subtle hint of it that left me looking for more.

DRINKS (non-alcoholic) - Special lemonade was very good, but my favorite was the one with ginger beer and some type of fruit but the name escapes me. Absolutely refreshing and delicious.

Overall, great dining experience. Service was impeccable. Food was fantastic. Had a great first time here and am looking forward to dining here again.
author: H I.

description:
This is definitely a beautiful place to go if you want an elegant atmosphere coupled with a stunning view of the bay bridge. Though if you come at night you will no longer see the bay lights, if you come on a nice sunny day you can see the behemoth of Yerba Buena island and the far off east-bay.

Have a hankering for seafood? Then you will definitely get your fill here. I hadn't had shellfish in quite a while so I decided on an under-the-sea themed binge. To start with, there was the creamy lobster bisque, not much in terms of texture but was amazingly flavorful.

The main course was the soft shell crab dish. The crab itself was lightly battered and cooked to a juicy, buttery perfection. Every bite an explosion of flavor. Surprisingly, there were also battered small green tomatoes that popped as they were bitten into and reminded me of just how much I loved tomatoes!
author: Nicole W.

description: Simply put: You don't survive the San Francisco's ultra competitive restaurant market that many years if you're not consistently solid. I hadn't been there in years and I just went there for back to back group lunches and it was as good as it was few years back. I have family that own few high end restaurants in town but I have to say this was very good. Salmon melted in our mouth and it was superb. The only slight miss was a chocolate dessert which had too much caramel, all else was good. Service strong downstairs
author: Eric G.

description: Food was delicious! Ordered sword fish with mussels and it was perfectly portioned! The service wasn't as great as I expected it to be. The waiter was slow and not too professional as you would expect from a fine dining restaurant! The wait staff need some fresh blood! :)
author: Vanessa N.

description: i visited here with my mom and brother for christmas dinner and very disappointed because of the service. The dinner was perfect but the waiter was very rude and unprofessional so I didnt even try to look at him or talk to him. I wish i could ask for different server or leave small tip but i didnt do it cause i was with my family. However i felt really uncomfortable and wont go to this place again.
author: Yuna L.

description:
Had dinner here with my boyfriend and his family last night, and the food was exceptional!

For appetizers, we ordered the Roasted Beet and Fourme D'ambert Salad, Italian White Truffles, and Heirloom Tomato with Buffalo Mozzarella and Burrata, which was my favorite! I'm a huge fan of tomatoes and mozzarella, so I might be biased-- but definitely order this one to start.

For my main entree, I ordered the Wild King Salmon. It was cooked so simply, and the lime and juniper beurre blanc provided the perfect amount of flavor. I'd rate this dish a 5/5 easily. 

I also had a taste of the Berkshire Kurobota Pork Prime Rib Chop and would give it a 6/5. I try to avoid pork as much as possible, but if I ever come back to Boulevard, I would order this dish for sure. :)

The reason I only gave 4 stars, however, was because the waiters weren't the most friendly or gracious. Still worth a visit though!
author: Kayla B.

description:
There isn't much more that can be said to this place other than, I loved it.  

Came here for a special anniversary dinner on a recent trip to San Francisco.  We made only a passing reference to it in a conversation with the waitress.  She was smart enough to make sure that when our desserts came out, there was a nice "Happy Anniversary" sign on a piece of white chocolate to accompany it.

It's that type of service that sets this place apart as one of the best.  

The menu is small but it focuses on quality.  You can clearly tell that a lot of preparation goes into each dish. My wife's fish came with a squash blossom stuffed with shrimp for example. That doesn't happen overnight and it makes great dishes into something terrific.  

I enjoyed the pork chop that was tender and cooked perfectly through.  Not an easy task with such a thick piece.  The portions were also reasonable too which made it easy to enjoy the meal without feeling like you've overindulged..  

The decor in this place is really something to see too. You can definitely understand how this place has won top honors.   

If I had a complaint, it's that its really at the high end of prices. This is a place for special occasions. But when the food is this good and service exemplary, it's a price worth paying.
author: Dan S.

description:
Another satisfying meal at Boulevard.  Corn and crab ravioli; cucumber, melon and kale salad; lamb; halibut were uniquely prepared and very flavorful.  

Our server really understood the menu and the wine list which is always a bonus.  The only bit of average was the desert and coffee.  The wonderful flavored that greeted us with the starters and enters were muted on the chocolate and butterscotch cake with accompanying ice creams and chocolate covered raisins.  The decaf coffee was also on the light (weak) side of nice bold flavor.

All-in-all, worth the price and a satisfying occasion.
author: John E.

description:
I suppose this place used to be good, but not anymore.

Food is ok.  There're many many many places in the city that serve better food than Blvd now, and the same goes for the service.

They need some work (food, service, interior design, staff's uniform to name many)
author: EriCardo F.

description:
I'm a big supporter of women owned restaurants, so I was excited to eat here.
It's in a nice location near the water, and the interior has a sort of old SF feel;  you can easily imagine the Big Four smoking cigars at the bar. Some patrons were dressed to the nines, and others pretty relaxed. I was really glad I could dress up jeans and be fine because I hate dry cleaning stuff and I hate being uncomfortable. I actually saw someone in cross trainers and yoga pants which made me giggle ( inside.) I basically think you could wear whatever you wanted to wear here and be welcomed with big smiles rather than condescending stares. 

Waitstaff was stellar. They gave us a lovely table, brought water and drinks right away, answered questions, and then disappeared except to bring our food exactly when they should have. There was no fussy rearranging of spoons, etc which can be a problem when eating someplace fancy.

Drinks: Yeah, absolutely get a cocktail.  I am generally not a cocktail kind of person, but they looked really interesting...and this is just sort of a cocktail place. Glad I did as they were unique and delicious. 

Appetizers: We had calamari and ahi tuna. The tuna was the winner. Wow. Husband is a sashimi purist, but he agreed that this was amazing. The calamari was good but not as memorable as the tuna.

Mains: I had swordfish, and he had pork. Both were well thought out (visually, texturally, flavors, etc., ) beautifully presented and perfectly cooked. 

Desserts: Get the butterscotch pudding. I didn't love the ginger cake. 

Was this the best meal Ive ever had in SF? No. That one was at Masa's back when Julian Serrano was there ( and that was a long time ago)  but it was definitely among the top 3. 

This is a really good choice for a special occasion.
author: El B.

description: Would definitely reccomend to people visiting SF! First time here for my Bf's birthday and loved all the food that we ordered! Everyone from the bar to the table and to the kitchen are AWESOME! Great service and we'll definitely come back for more when we visit the town again! Great Experience!
author: Stephanie D.

description: Boulevard is a sentimental favorite of mine when in San Francisco. I am always torn to dine here because of all the amazing choices in the unique city.  After all these years Boulevard is still one of the cities BEST places to eat!!  The food and service are 5 stars with consistent execution!
author: Gerald K.

description: Boulevards is one of my all time favorites.. Everything is great. What can I say, always great food.
author: Franklin L.

description: I only ordered a main course here. I ordered the California Lamb T-Bone Wood Oven Roasted. It was cooked perfectly and had a very nice balance of flavor. Maybe next time I will try the appetizers or the dessert.
author: Paul D.

description:
This place is great.  I came here for lunch with my Co-Workers for a celebration.  I got the Rib Cap and Gulf Prawns.  The pork just melted in my mouth like it had been slowly braised for several hours.  Well done Boulevard.

Other items on the menu for lunch were the Kobe burger, Atlantic Salmon, and Scallops.  All items were priced reasonably for a lunch at a Michelin Star restaurant.  Reservations were made a few days before for a Friday lunch.
author: Ben L.

description:
I am knocking one more star from my original review because I got a snarky reply from an "Antonio" who claims to be the owner, with "Thanks for the positive review!".

If you can't take the heat, get out of the (Boulevard) kitchen.
author: Jules L.

description: Great meal and beautiful presentation. I had the foie gras and pheasant. Both were excellent. My father had the soft shell crab and halibut and he was extremely pleased. Our server gave an excellent wine pairing recommendation and we could not have been more pleased.
author: John P.

description:
Butter. Poached. Quail.

I could eat this everyday. 

As you would expect from a Michelin rated resto, this place has impeccable service. All the food we ate was of a certain quality. But, the butter poached quail was clearly the star of the evening. 

I know the menu is seasonal, but here is the rundown on what was loved and super loved.

Asparagus ravioli with summer truffles - ok this dish had shaved truffles on top. TRUFFLES! thank goodness they haven't take that away from us (ahem, foie). The ravioli was melty-creamy in your mouth.

Burrata and tomato salad - huge fan of heirloom toms here. Especially when they taste like tomato candy. This dish was average, but super fresh. What more can you ask for from a salad like this.

Lamb - perfectly cooked and not overly gamey. a good dish.

Butter poached quail - Super love. Not usually a fan of breast meat, but this was tender and... buttery... and oh-so-fine.

A great place for loving looks across the table or just a tasty, albeit a tad pricey, meal.
author: Jess C.

description:
I love you, Boulevard. Marry me ;) 

Truly - want to impress a client or just treat yourself because you are awesome? Go to Boulevard. Stop reading ... go! go now!!
author: Carmellina E.

description:
Great ambience, dim lighting and romantic. Great view of the bay bridge if you come at night time and reserve a table by the large window in the back of the restaurant. Dressy place. 

We had the scallops, tartare, the lamb chops and the quail rolled in bacon. The scallops were amazing with the puréed beet - great pairing! The lamb chops were so juicy and I usually don't like lamb because of the smell, but this didn't smell at all. It melted in my mouth. The quail was also very tasty and a great combo with the bacon. We ordered two glasses of red wine to pair with the food. They give you free bread with sea salt butter - super yummy. The dessert menu didn't seem that interesting. 

Our waitress was very attentive and gave suggestions for food and wine pairing. Would visit again.
author: Mark T.

description: I will said that food is okay,  service is slow, taste is somehow  same thing,  not very unique I will come back to try something different maybe  it will changed my mind and my yelp review. 3 stars is  enough for now. Very price $$$$
author: Denish G.

description:
Ugh....had some old friends in town from Virginia and since they had never been to San Francisco before  they  booked a reservation at the famous Boulevard!

 

Julie & I tagged along to catch up and to celebrate one of my friends Birthday!

 

Neither Julie nor myself had been to Boulevard in years. I had always felt it was too stuffy, overworked and really just a place for tourists with more money than food sense.

 

Without giving it all away,  here is our night!

 

 We had 7:30 reservations, so of course we were seated not-so-promptly at 8:00pm. Once seated we were totally ignored. Even in jail they give you Bread & Water quicker than this! I also had brought a nice bottle of Cakebread Cab to celebrate the evening. When the server FINALLY worked his way to our table he was incredibly smug in the way he told me about the corkage fee (an obnoxious $35, but I knew that going in and was fine with it). One of us asked about a glass of Moscato, and the server said he would go check if they had it and bring the bottle back. Like a magicians rabbit, he disappeared....again! Oh, the bread finally came! Must say, they have awesome bread, too bad we had to wait 30 min for it!

Thank goodness we had a lot of catching up to do, because by the time "later-waiter" showed back up for our app order another 20 min had passed. Quick comment about the menu, PREDICTABLE! This menu is completely devoid of inspiration &  innovation. The Ahi Tuna Pokie looked like it came from the Bristol Farms Pokie Salad Bar-AFTER they dumped more dressing on it. The Carbonara pasta came all clumped together (way too starchy) and could easily pass for Olive garden fare. The Scallops were decent, but then again, can you really mess up scallops? I was shocked that they did not have a Beet Salad! bet they fix that soon...

 

I always feel a little strange pouring my own wine in a "fine dining " establishment, but the MIA Server was not gonna do it! So self serve it was!

 

The mains came out! Again, Chain Restaurant fare at Boulevard prices! Yum!  

I looked around, the place was packed! This place must have a shrine in the back to SFO international, because like lemmings, the tourists keep pouring in....Julie & I got dessert only because we decided we should go out in style since this will be our last visit EVER to Boulevard, the most pretentious, over-rated, over-worked, uninspired restaurant in all of San Francisco!

I wonder if people get extra frequent flyer miles for eating here?

 

 

 



--
author: glenn w.

description: Went here for my husband's bday and we both had a great experienced for the first time.  I had the Pork Chop and it was excellent.  My husband ordered lambs and it was delicious.  This order came with mashed potatoes and we both loved it.  As for the drink I had one of their specialty drink cocktails and it was okay.  He got the Fruity Tea drink and it was good.  As for dessert, we both shared the Cherry Buckle and one of the dessert port drink and loved it!  The service was friendly and helpful.
author: Food-Travel-Adventure A.

description: Boulevard really impressed us! Food was amazing, everything was fresh and well prepared..my wife's had a crab salad with avocado which was simple yet very tasty and fresh..I had scallops with mushrooms which was also cooked well and very flavorful..for our Mains we had the pork chop and halibut..again incredible flavor and well prepared! The staff was very attentive and for the most part left us alone but yet seemed to know when we needed a refill or when we were finished with a plate. All in all it was a wonderful experience and we definitely will return for a future date!
author: Bob W.

description:
Hyped up so much it's hard to meet expectations. Service was professional and very good. Food was good.

Here are 3 value seeking wine tips for now - to help navigate an expensive wine list:

2009 Domaine Zind Humbrecht, Alsace, Gewurztraminer @ $52 and is a wine spectator 92 

2009 Argyle, Nuthouse, Reserve Series, Willamette Valley, Pinot Noir - @ $78 is a good value and rated a wine spectator 91.

2007 Scherrer, Old & Mature Vines, Alexander Valley, Zinfandel @ $55 and rated a wine spectator 90.
author: JW U.

description:
We just enjoyed a wonderful lunch at a San Francisco icon.
 The service was spot on, all the items 3 apps, 3 entries and 3 deserts were wonderful. The wines were outstanding and our cocktails and after dinner drinks+expresso were excellent.  
 If you can't appreciate this, there is something seriously wrong with you.
This was a 5 star outing however; the proprietor has been so busy creating fabulous food that she has not heard about Obamacare and still pockets 4% of every check, ostencibly so that we can pay for her employees health care.
 That will cost you 1 star.
author: Richard L. D.

description:
Vegetarians should go only for wine. There is utter lack of creativity or sheer indifference for vegetarians. 
Have been there 4 times now of which I have been to the 'vault' three times. If I am rating only for wines, I would rate them 5. Cocktail selection is pretty good too and they make it nice. Their Manhattan and cucumber Gimlet were particularly great. All times, the waiters had good knowledge of wines and were right on the mark.

But they stumble once they hear the word vegetarian. On my lucky day they have a vegetarian soup and they will offer it immediately. They offer a lettuce  salad and that has appeared twice at my table with bacon, which needed to be sent back. The entree however, has been very very disappointing. All times, I was offered only one thing. A mix of mashed potatoes and a little amount of sautéd veggies. That's it??? First couple times I thought may be this is their vegetarian 'dish of the day'. But after having had the same thing a few times, decided it was the lack of imagination or indifference on the chef's part. Sigh....
author: S G.

description:
Considering the price, service and quality of food, Boulevard is a restaurant that I would go back often. The interior is on the traditional end, so it feels warm and homey. Our server gave us a big friendly welcome when we got seated and then introduced the menu to us. Boulevard doesn't give you the I'm-in-a-Michelin-star-restaurant feeling, but the atmosphere was very pleasant. 

We got the local Monterey abalone and beef carpaccio as appetizers. Both dishes were tasty, but the only down side was that the portions were very small. For entrée, I got the Angus Filet Mignon and it was prepared perfectly, it was very juicy and tender. However, I didn't quite like the onion ring on the dish, not because it wasn't tasty, it's just that I'm not a big onion ring fan and I think it made the dish a little bit too heavy. With that aside, the food was great. Totally a go-to place for a semi-formal dinner.

Expedition #2
Food: Great
Service: Great
Atmosphere: Great for family/friend gatherings
Average price per person: ~$75 (including tax & tips)
Parking: Street parking, not terribly hard to find around the area
Time spent for the meal: ~1.5hr.
author: Kat J.

description:
I gotta give BOULEVARD a perfect score. The food and service there is second to none. My wife and I met my mother and cousin there for dinner on Friday. My mother had a gift certificate there from a friend for her retirement - so we went to town there.

I ordered the House Special, Pork Prime Rib Chop. It was to die for! Easily the best pork chop that I've ever eaten. It was so flavorful and juicy, not tough or dry at all. My mom had the Lamb and my wife had the Filet Mignon. I had bites of each and they were all top notch.

We also each had a dessert - I had the Chocolate Ice Box Cake and it was delicious.

Probably not a restaurant that I can afford to eat at often, but if you get a chance to eat there. Enjoy!

5 stars
author: Joel V.

description:
Since I'm back in my country, I'm not able to have their food any more.
I miss their food and the staffs a lot.
The chefs are awesome and the servers are super friendly.
I know they always use the best and freshest ingredients.
They have been doing an amazing job.
I love everything about BLVD
author: Kristen K.

description: Went there for lunch. Had 'Ahi Tuna Tartar', 'Calamari' and 'Scallops'. Tuna was great, calamari was good (if light on actual calamari), and the scallops were okay. I wasn't impressed for their reputation and price. Perhaps I'll come back for dinner and reevaluate.
author: Seth C.

description:
I liked the place, but it's a lil artsy for my tastes.  Here, eat this sculpture of food I made!

Usually at French restaurants, portions of everything except dessert are a little skimpy.  Here, everything comes with a skimpy portion, even dessert.  

It's good, I'd come back, but there's another place I prefer.
author: Big Baby Jesus C.

description:
This review is long over do.
Thank you Boulevard for the most amazing serving experience I have ever witnessed. It was my Anniversary and Blvd went way beyond the call of duty. The food, service, hostess everything was perfect. Thank you again
author: Ann H.

description: The service was horrible! The pork was rare, the service was pathetic!!! Don't eat here!!!!
author: Colton R.

description:
Went on a foie rage to make up for lost time (thanks osama/sf), and had the Hudson valley pan seared Foie gras, fonduta ravioli & perigord winter truffles, Maine lobster porchetta Di testa & white asparagus, and Berkshire kurobuta pork prime rib chop wood oven roasted. Server was slightly snooty, perhaps cuz we didn't order 2 entrees, but meh. Food is on point and this place is definitely worth a visit.

My name is Boris Yelpsin, and i approve this message.
author: Daniel S.

description: Consistently one of the best restaurants in S.F.  A great place to go for those special occasions.  The food, drinks, service, and ambiance are all spot on.  Typically we're pretty laid back in S.F., but It's a nice change to see people actually dressed up for dinner.  There was maybe one couple wearing jeans where everyone else was dressed very well.  I remember when they opened, and happy to see they are still going strong.  They obviously take great pride in their restaurant, and it shows.
author: Sean M.

description:
YES! I got to try another michelin star restaurant! Boulevard location itself is great already. The view of the pier and the bay bridge made it a nice dinner spot. Their alcohol cocktail menu has some good choices along with their extensive wine menu. What caught my eyes was the NYOGT (not your ordinary gin & tonic). I love gin & tonic so I had to order this one. nonetheless, their bourbon cocktails are great as well.

The scallops for appetizer is a must order. I ordered fish for my entree and it was flavorful. I enjoyed every bite of it. The dessert menu looked really good as well.
author: Nancy N.

description:
Consistently a great meal with great service and an excellent wine selection. Try to request a table in front of the kitchen. All of our courses were amazing once again.

Drink:
I started with the Cucumber Gimlet

Appetizer:
Zabuton Beef Carpaccio with summer truffles was amazing. Perfect amount of beef vs truffle flavor.

Entrée 
Fava Bean & Parmesan Raviolini (this is an appetizer we had as an entrée) 
Pan Roasted California White Sea Bass was a nice thick cut piece cooked perfect with chanterelle mushroom risotto. 

 Wine: 
2011 Failla Pinot Noir from Sonoma Coast which paired well with the Sea Bass.

Dessert: 
Flourless Chocolate cake with Olive Oil Ice Cream & Gummies, Pistachio truffle, caramel brown rice crispies - Very interesting flavors, especially the olive oil ices cream.
author: Scott M.

description: We were 15 minutes late to our dinner reservation but we didn't have a problem at all, even though it was packed. Had an ahi tuna dish as an appetizer and it was delicious. Tried the berkshire pork and it equally as tasty. Portions are (arguably) small but I thought they were just right. The food is very high quality, as it should be for the price. Service was very professional. Well done, Boulevard, well done.
author: Steph D.

description:
Several Birthdays here. The place is really classy and in a safe neighborhood. I like tablecloths and fine dining. The service is excellent and the food top notch! The bread is nice and soft and the butter room temperature the way I like. The drinks and dessert are also bomb. What's kinda fun is grabbing a quick dessert at the bar too.
Love this place!
author: Cecilia D.

description:
Boulevard has long been my favorite restaurant in the city. It's a place I reserve for special occasions and important business meetings. 

Not any more.

If went for an anniversary lunch and it was one of the most disappointing dining experiences I've had.

The food is good, but not good enough to put up with horrible service.
author: S Y.

description:
The menu changes daily, but our app selections tonight were:  Fois Gras , scallops, Alaskan king crab, and ahi tuna.  For dinner, I had a lamb t-bone that was perfectly cooked, and my friends all had dishes that were to die for as well.  

I don't believe there was one mis-step the whole night.  Our waiter was incredibly knowledgable, and made some excellent recommendations.  

We took our clients here, and if I had to sum up their take, impressed would be an understatement. 

Do yourself a favor, and just come here....best money you'll ever spend.
author: Rene M.

description: Red abalone pasta. Enough said! This was a special when we went. Every menu recommendation made by our waiter was wonderful, but we dream about this one! What a great restaurant!
author: Mim D.

description: It was alright.  Went on a Thursday night, was sat without a reservation.  I had the scallops to start (which were really great and buttery) the pork chop (I've had better) and the chocolate honey mousse with rice Krispies, foam and pistachio-chocolate nougat for dessert (pretty tasty).  The service was great, but for how much I paid, I wasn't impressed by the overall experience.  Location is great: near the water downtown.  I didn't too much care for the decor inside.
author: Wouldn't You L.

description:
Just had an amazing birthday dinner at Boulevard!

My husband and I are budding foodies, so we're making the rounds of restauarants in the Bay Area with Michelin stars and started at Boulevard. I can see why it earned it's star!

We had reservations at 6:45. Due to a table of people who were slowly savoring their desserts (which I came to understand later), we actually weren't sat until 7:30. While we waited, the hostess comped us a round of drinks, and then comped appetizers for us as well. I have never experienced such amazing service! The entire staff was knowledgeable, friendly and gracious.

The atmosphere was upscale yet comfortable, very welcoming. And the good. So delicious. I had the lobster bisque and my husband had the squab for the appetizer round. The friends we were with had the tuna tartare. We were all impressed with our dishes (though the tuna tartare won for best appetizer I think- but it was a tough choice!)

For the entree I had the sole and my husband had the scallops. He said they were the best scallops he's ever had- perfectly cooked and seasoned. And the dessert (chocolate mousse and a tiramisu-like cake were truly decadent-- the perfect way to end an incredible meal. To top it off, I had the best wine I've ever tasted- if you're a red wine drinker, I can't recommend the Barolo highly enough.

All in all- a perfect evening- great ambiance, excellent service and delicious food and drinks. We will absolutely be coming back!
author: Amanda C.

description:
The decor and service was wonderful, and the food was exquisite! 

I got the Wild King Salmon, and it was perfectly cooked and the garnishes really complemented the flavor. Others in my party opted for the Sea Bass, and that was delicious as well. For dessert, I got the blueberry-nectarine crisp, which was a bit of a disappointment.
