I realize that this was a holiday weekend, but there is no excuse for this. Service was always a strong point at Boulevard. No longer.

Next, the food. While the appetizers were great, my lamb was not. Was that GRIT in my spinach? Why yes, it was! They didn't take the time to wash the spinach properly. I passed the first bite of my lamb T-bone to my wife. Her comment. "Wow. That's a lot of gristle!". The lamb was tough and gristly and hideously oversalted. The more I ate, the worse it got.  (My wife's filet was actually a quite nice piece of meat, although badly cooked). 

I complained to the manager. She looked bored, like she had heard it all before.

We went to Ducca for dessert.

In summary, Boulevard is no longer what it was. Five years ago, this was a great restaurant - perhaps one of the best in the country. Now it feels like they are just phoning it in.

 What rating would you give the meal if it wasn't for the magical "Boulevard" name on the front? I would probably give it two stars, except for the fact that they are charging $40 an entree. For that price, there are a lot of absolutely magical places to eat in San Francisco. Hence, one star for merely OK food and just plain bad service at top prices.
author: Joshua M.

description:
Time couldn't pass fast enough when I found out I'd be dining here. The night came and went and overall I had a fantastic experience.

This building is famous - read about its history on their website and it will make for a good story to share when you dine here.

Came on a Monday night with another couple and the place was buzzing. We had a reservation and had to wait a few minutes (no harm no foul) however the "waiting" area was the narrow space in between the already busy bar area and a row of tables.

Onward and upward though...our waiter nailed it. He was cheery, engaged, and gave great recommendations.

We started with a round of cocktails, I had the cucumber gimlet which was refreshing and light.  We brought a nice bottle of wine which elevated our meal. 

For apps we tried the avocado and crab salad and burrata dish.  These were good but left me a little underwhelmed (for the reputation that Blvd has established, you expect to be wowed by everything).

For entrees I had the pork chop (not my usual dinnertime go-to, but I was SO glad I took the plunge). It was delicious - juicy, perfectly cooked, and overall each accompanying ingredient delivered.  I also got to try the filet which was stellar.

Dessert was the apple cake, which was good but not the highlight of the meal. 

Overall, a great evening to be remembered thanks to the beautiful setting, great service, delicious food and above all else, perfect company. Should I get a second opportunity to dine at Blvd, I'll be twice as grateful!
author: Brianna M.

description:
OMG OMG. I went here for work because we won best team and our company took the time to treat us well. We had a choice of a drink and i had a diablo. We also had ordered delicious appetizers and i order the tomato mozarrela salad and it was delicious. We finally got to order our entree and i had the BLTA. OMG OMG if i could post the picture of this delicious plate that i posted on istagram it would make your tummy go round and round. 

By far an amazing experience with superb staff. Thank you guys for making our experience amazing.
author: Alex A.

description: What a disappointment!  We ate here recently with a large group because the reviews were very good.  The prices for an entree range from $39 to $51 plus more $ if you want a dinner salad.  I am fine with paying a higher price for an exceptional meal and experience but it was neither.  I ordered the wild king salmon and it was a tiny portion and pretty uninspired and bland.  I will give credit to the white bean artichoke side though.  My husband ordered the angus filet and was also underwhelmed.  One person ordered the quail and they did enjoy it very much.  For dessert we tried the summer berry tart and the chocolate butterscotch cake.  I will say that the berry tart was wonderful although teeny tiny and who can complain about chocolate and butterscotch!   You can find much better food at many different restaurants in the area.
author: D'Anne S.

description:
Came here on a Thursday at 630 pm and luckily we were able to get a table for four but it definitely felt like reservations would be hugely beneficial. Overall the food was great but the prices a bit steep, although it was free for me. 

For appetizers, we started with the Ravioli, which was fantastic in regards to the meat and texture of the pasta. We also had the Shrimp and Calamari, which was nothing special. Both portions were extremely small with four pieces of the Ravioli and 4 pieces of Shrimp and Calamari. 

Entrees were small portions relative to American portions but perfect sized for a normal meal. I had the Lamb T-Bone and it was the best lamb I have had in the recent past. My colleagues ordered the Pork Chop, which looked even better than the lamb, the Quail and the Halibut. Everyone enjoyed their dishes and had no complaints. 

The drinks were great as well. If you go into this restaurant looking for quality of food and not quantity, then you won't be disappointed. The value in terms of portion isn't there but the food was great and delicious.
author: Rick K.

description:
I never give reviews at all im in my mid 20's and my husband and i just got married yesterday, we had two guests with us. We booked in here for our wedding lunch, service was mediocre seeing as i was wearing a white dress, no congratulations or a complimentary glass of champagne (didn't expect it but would have been nice if they had to have acknowledged the fact that we just got married!!)

Lunch menu.. starters were nice apart from the caeser salad.. basically what he got was a lump of lettuce thrown on the plate with a sprinkle of dressing and parmesan cheese. I wouldn't have served this to anyone.

Main course.. 32 dollars for 6 scallops? Oh and they weren't cleaned properly?? My chicken dish it was fine but if you like your carbohydrates you will be disappoint none what so ever, no potatoes at all, no pasta and no veg.. just a leg of chicken?

Tuna and ribs were ok

Desserts were lovely. 

Overall very disappointed!!
author: Paula M.

description: The food is alright only worth 3.5 stars but I gave it for their excellent services!!! So my guest enjoyed his dinner and I was able to give him a surprise:)
author: Sally C.

description:
I'm glad I got to try this place once, but I'm not sure if it was good enough that I would be back. I was able to try the scallops, halibut, abalone, and lamb. 

My favorite dish was the scallops. 

Service is great, food is just mediocore for the prices.
author: Jennifer S.

description: We had a delightful evening at Boulevard ambiance and service wise.  The food, though,  was very disappointing.  We tried several dishes including the truffle ravioli,  the crab salad,  the pork chop and the swordfish.  Every dish was presented beautifully but all dishes lacked any interesting flavor.  I wanted to spice them up or spruce them up,  add a little of this or that to make them flavorful.  For the price of the dishes they all fell very flat.  They sound good, on the menu,  they look good, on the plate....but they are incredibly boring and lacking flavor.  Definitely not worth what I paid.  I have eaten here in the past and been very happy with the flavors.  I am not sure if they have a new chef?
author: mi m.

description:
Amazing dinner.  I have been here  a few times.  The last trip was the best.  I had the Wild Alaskan Salmon.  It was honestly the best salmon I have every had.  Soft and juicy, but not under cooked.  So good.

The bar service before the meal was top notch.  I had an excellent Manhattan and a nice Pinot Noir from Blue farms.  Wine list is of course excellent.

Parking tip: skip valet and head down the one way street towards the Bay bridge and you will find parking a few restaurants down on the left.  Head down into the garage.  It was $4 all evening with last out at 10:30pm.
author: Nathan T.

description:
Maybe it's the ambience, but I wasn't too thrilled about my experience today. My wife and I were celebrating our 9th wedding anniversary. This wasn't our first time here but it will be our last. 

We arrived on time for our reservations and were immediately sat down. For something intimate on our anniversary, it would've been nice if they sat us in the love seat booth than at a table. Reservations were full that night for a Saturday evening and attire was pretty casual inside. The decor reminded me of a steakhouse with everything dimly lit with candles at every table. It felt pretty humid inside.

Maybe it was just our luck, but our waitress wasn't attentive at all nor did we find many people walking around the area when we wanted something addressed. When waiting for our food, it took more than 1 hour to present our entrees to us. We even had to ask a couple of times if the food was ready. And when the food arrived, it wasn't hot because it was sitting on the counter waiting to be picked up. Since we sat in the middle of the entire restaurant, we saw everything that went around and knew when our orders were ready. But they just sat there.

Long story short, we won't be going back again and will not recommend any of our close friends to go either. What a horrible experience.
author: Hogan W.

description: Our dinner at Boulevard was amazing! Service and ambiance were great. The squid appetizer was delicious. Loved the creativity, flavor and presentation. The tuna in the tuna poke was so fresh and was prepared perfectly. The pork chop was one of the best pork dishes I've ever had. We wanted to lick the plate clean it was so good. The lamb entree was also delicious but got up staged by the pork.
author: Kyoko T.

description:
I can honestly say that I have dined here only once but it was a nice experience, reason for only 3-star vote.  My guy works in the area and occasionally treats himself to lunch or dinner- he raves about this place and likely would rate it a 5-star.

I won't go into food detail because I believe that one should have their own dining experience especially at a fine dining establishment.  What I wrote above should say enough.

I would advise anyone complaining/whining about the price at this place or anywhere for that matter, should just stay home and cook if they think it's too pricey.  Or, how about looking at the menu before entering any establishment.  My point, treat yourself once in a while, life is too short.
author: Sisi D.

description:
Maybe I ordered wrong but at the end of the day I think Boulevard is getting dinged because I am not a huge fan of French food and because I thought the prices were out of line with the food received.

Here is my take: Boulevard is a fine dining establishment that peddles upscale, undersized dishes.  Are they bad?  By no means, they are actually quite tasty.  Would I go back when in San Francisco (given all the other options) for the price point?  Absolutely not.

Not sure what to say, it wasn't bad, but it was highly forgettable, given its local competition.
author: Dean H.

description:
So we went to Boulevard for a birthday celebration. I had been dying to check this place out since they were a James Beard award winner for Outstanding Restaurant and what better way than for a birthday dinner.

So we walk over to the restaurant in high anticipation for an awesome meal. We walk through the revolving doors and the décor is very unique and pleasant. Definitely a nice cozy feel to it even though it does seat quite a few people. The ambiance is formal but not over the top stuffy which I appreciated and in the back the kitchen was open showing the Chef's working away which is something I always enjoy watching.  Just as a note, this place does get fairly loud and this was on a Wednesday night so I can only imagine how loud it would get on a weekend night.

We were promptly seated at the restaurant and immediately a waiter comes over and offers us menu with a smile. I peruse the vino list and ask the server for recommendations and he was able to direct me to the perfect vino. We then look through the dinner menu and I decide to try the Tuna and the California Lamb T Bone. The tuna comes out and the presentation is very nice. The mushrooms on the dish were tasty but I was a bit disappointed with the tuna itself because it did seem a bit bland and not as fresh as I was hoping for. Shaking off the confusion I get pumped for the Lamb T bone. Now just so everyone knows, I am actually not a huge lamb person because it could taste "gamey." The lamb comes out and again the presentation is solid and it comes with delicious potatoes. I take my first bite and the potatoes are delicious and the lamb to my surprise is not "gamey" at all. Solid but not anything that blows me away. I was a bit disappointed and maybe because I had high expectations so that is the fault.

Overall I think Boulevard is a solid restaurant but maybe a bit over hyped. The food was just OK in my opinion. I don't think I would particularly recommend this place as the most amazing restaurant but I would not mind coming back for another meal.
author: Dan M.

description: Terrible Service, Awful drinks, stay away!  I would not recommend this to anyone. They should be ashamed to call themselves.
author: Joseph H.

description:
I have been here several times now so this is a group review.

-Last night I called to order a bottle of champagne for a friend who was having her birthday there. They really found no way to accommodate me, and although not rude, were certainly not helpful. 

-Menu lacks luster

-Drinks from the bar are slow (Despite us saying we were trying to catch a flight) and not very good. All three drinks I have had (Bloody Mary, Manhattan and Salty Dog) were not special, interesting or delicious.
author: Danielle V.

description: I come here for work every so often. I'd say the food is hit or miss. When you consider the price and reputation - I felt compelled to give a quick review.  Overall food was ok. Decent flavor - nothing to exotic on the menu. So when I ordered the filet I guess I had higher expectations. My order was med rare but I kid you not the steak was cooked medium well to well.  That on its own was enough for me to give 3 stars.  But when the waitress didn't show up my entire meal to ask how the food was dropped it down to 2 stars. I ended up saving half the well done steak on my plate to show the waitress - but it got picked up by a bus person well before she showed up. Overall food is avg at best - and when your talking $$$$ it's not remotely worth it. There are so many better options nearby in the city.
author: Jared T.

description:
A took me to Boulevard to celebrate my birthday last weekend.  We had 5:45pm reservations on a Saturday.  It was a little cold and the chance of rain was extremely likely.  I'd never been to Boulevard, but I'd heard it's quite the fancy restaurant and since we were celebrating my birthday, I used it as an excuse to get dressed up!  Boulevard is not the kind of restaurant where you feel out of place if you're dressed up.

We were seated at a little booth by a window where we sat next to each other on a cushy bench seat.  It was very cozy and romantic.  Perfect table for us.

Our server was extremely helpful and I like how they have coat hooks by all the tables to hang up your jackets.  Nice!

For our appetizers, we shared the Pan Roasted California Squab with
Potato Gnocchi, Roasted Brussel Sprouts & Chestnuts, Shaved Fresh Oregon White Truffles & Truffled Jus.  It was sooo good!  The squab was really tender and flavorful and the gnocchi was yum.  I love potatoes, so I love gnocchis.  I normally don't eat squab because I used to have pet parakeets and don't like the thought of eating little birds.  We also shared the Ahi Tuna Tartare with Grilled Black Sesame Cracker, Wasabi Tobiko, Preserved Citrus & Black Radish Vinaigrette, Pickled Shiitake Mushrooms, and Shishito Pepper Oil.  The tuna was super fresh and the mix of flavors was amazing.

As for the entrees, I got the Maine Lobster & Royal Sweet Sea Scallop with Meyer Lemon & Limoncello Risotto, Crispy Sunchokes & Black Trumpet Mushroom.  Don't worry, you don't need to dirty your hands on this one.  The lobster is peeled and everything is really neat and tidy.  I liked the lemony flavor of this dish.  It was so good that I licked the plate clean.  Literally.  

A ordered the Wood Oven Roasted Lamb Prime Rib Chops with Sauteed Red & Green Spinach, Potato Fritters with Bearnaise Sauce, Red Wine & Tarragon Lamb Jus, and White Mint Sauce.  I tried a little bit of the lamb and it was super yum!  The spinach though, wow, sooo flavorful!

For dessert, I ordered the Chocolate Macaron with Roasted White Chocolate with Chocolate Mirror Glaze & Chocolate Curls, Truffles, Pressed Pear & Pistachio Tuile, and Pistachio Ice Cream.  They don't skimp on this one.  It's a huge dessert.  It was good and it was chocolatey.  They even put a candle in it and a separate piece of chocolate that said Happy Birthday on it.  So cool!  A ordered the Clementine Cake with Frozen Blood Orange Souffle, Huckleberries, Mosaic of Winter Citrus, and Meyer Lemon Meringue.  His was super light and very citrusy.  I liked it.

Awesome restaurant, great service, delicioso food.  I'd go again if I could afford it.  Two yums up!
author: Kris L.

description:
Me and my friends are on a "mission" to try out most of the Michelin starred restaurants and Boulevard was lucky to be selected for our first try out!

After our dinner, the comment on the food is "very delicious"; however, I have actually forgot that I had such good food after a few days later....I guess Boulevard didn't "wow-ed" me that's why 1 star is missing on my rating~

Anyways, back to the food. We had four people so each one of us ordered one appetizer and one main course so all of us get to try out all of them. This is what we ordered for appetizer:

1. SONOMA FOIE GRAS - very nicely cooked! This is one of the best foie gras that I've ever had. It melted in my mouth....la la la la la~~~~
2. MONTEREY RED ABALONE - the abalone was very tender, and the fried green tomatoes were awesome (now i realized it's green tomato....we thought it was some kind of melon at first haha~)!!
3. CRISPY MARYLAND SOFT SHELL CRAB - first impression was "is this a thai dish?" the shell soft shell crab was on the hard side....but the chili noodle was pretty good~
4. FRESH HERB ROASTED PORCINI & RICOTTA STUFFED SQUASH BLOSSOM - i like this dish, but i think it's a bit too pricy....the fried ricotta cheese ball was a surprise~

As for the main, I ordered the WOOD OVEN ROASTED CALIFORNIA LAMB PRIME T-BONE - i love lamb so everywhere i go i usually ordered lamb. The meat was sooooo tender and juicy even thou i had it cooked medium rare~ the only complain was foraged greens....they took me a while to chew them down...

my friends had ordered the duck breast, pork prime rib chop and filet mignon. I had a piece of each meat and they were all tender and juicy inside and crispily roasted outside. Overall they were all pretty good.

We didn't get to ordered desserts but the TIRAMISU ICE CREAM CAKE
did catch my eye.....if i ever go back again i think i will get that for sure!

After tax and tips the bill came out to be around $300. Service was okay, food is great~ Portion is decent in a girl's point of view...I don't know about the guy's~ Overall it's a nice experience!
author: Louisa L.

description:
The food here is generally outstanding and it is my favorite restaurant in SF and I have been to most of the good ones.

Had dinner there tonight and I would recommend the following:

Appetizer: Shrimp and calamari  - Excellent
Dinner:  Filet Mignon with potato and mushrooms on the side  - Excellent
Dessert - Butterscotch pudding with chocolate on the side - Very good to Excellent

Décor is great as well.    I have been here maybe 5 or 5 times and always great!
author: Mark M.

description:
The James beard award put Boulevard back on the map this year - it's definitely a San Francisco classic, with dark wood decor, revolving doors, classic and strong cocktails like the Moscow Mule and the Cucumber Gimlet, while adapting its menu a little more for local ingredients.  

The space is actually long and narrow, and it's pretty lively inside, so it's definitely not one of those stuffy fancy places.  It's not cramped, per se, but there's not a lot of room to maneuver.  Service is prompt but not hasty, and drinks are refilled quickly.

For drinks, don't be fooled by the fruity sounding peach cocktail because it's pretty strong and not too sweet.

They didn't have a tasting menu, but my friend and I kind of created our own... we started with the beet salad, with roasted red beets, lemon cucumber, champagne grapes, and a good amount of goat cheese - you can't really go wrong with that combination.

Next, we had the seared scallops, which were complemented nicely by the artichoke, and it came with three perfectly seared pieces.  The lobster dish was buttery and tender, with smokiness and richness from bacon and melted leeks, but I wasn't as big a fan of the risotto al nero, which was more like purple rice (I was expecting more like a squid ink risotto).

For the main we had the bone in Kurobuta pork chop, which was tender and cooked just right.  I'm a big fan of fruit with my pork chop, so I would have liked more cherries with it, but it had enough flavor in itself to stand alone.  The greens underneath were drenched in pork jus and lardo, making it a very enjoyable vegetable accompaniment. 

For dessert, we had the chocolate marquis, which wasn't too sweet but was definitely rich and satisfying.  I like the crunch of the hazelnut wafer and the slight kick from the coffee flavor.

I appreciate that a classic restaurant can stick to its roots while maintaining a very well rounded experience.  I'm glad that after multiple nominations, they finally got the Outstanding Restaurant recognition.
author: Marilyn H.

description: Don't believe the hype!  Now, the service was stupendous and the food was very fresh, however the portions did not match the price points for me.  I know that's the foo foo, shee shee thing; small portions at high prices.  I get it, you're paying for fresh, seasonal food.  But, I like to eat!  I'm an eater, ok.  If you like to eat the way I do, eat a small meal  before you go, and you will be alright.
author: Chira E.

description:
We went here after a ridiculous amount of research, getting recommendations from the concierge., looking at overall city rankings, etc.  We wanted someplace special to celebrate our College graduate!  Yeehaw!  No more tuition!!!   I'm glad I don't own or operate a restaurant, because even some of the best places had just brutal reviews!  Boulevard was no exception.  We found it to be completely worth the effort of the quest.  We all had different salads and entrees, and when coerced shared bites.  I frankly don't like to share so giving up even small nibbles of my King Crab salad and entree of wild caught King Salmon was difficult.  Our daughter didn't/wouldn't share because she enjoyed her fried squash blossoms over a sweet corn risotto too much to let any of it go.  I'm not a beef eater but our daughter's boyfriend is, and he said the big chunk of steak thing he had was delicious as well.  Rich had a halibut served over a bed of tobouli - his only complaint, in fact the only complaint between all of us that evening where the entrees were concerned was that the tobouli was cold and the fish was hot.  He knew that it would be served that way however, when he ordered it because our server, who I loved, had warned him.  The desserts were amazing.  (One, that was supposed to be butterscotch had a little too much of a delicious chocolate swirled through the dessert and it overpowered the butterscotch). Our cab driver told us on the way there in fact,  that we had to have dessert.  She and her friends head there at the end of their shifts and splurge before heading home for the night - again, we each had different desserts and this time we all agreed to take a bite and pass the plate to the right so we could try all of them.  This is when it gets tricky, one man's bite is another one's scarf! as in don't eat all my chocolate thing or I'll kill you.  The graduate I think ended up with the best dessert, not the one she originally ordered.  It was a tart cherry crumble and it was delicious!  As it was her night, we decided it only fair to let her have the last say.  The portions overall were perfect.

Boulevard has a full bar, and a really nice wine list.  I loved the ambiance - many reviews said it was fancy, I found it more casual fancy at most.  Lots of jeans and hip looks, but not many groups looking intimidatingly "fancy".  I highly recommend it for the delicious food and the overall experience.  Take a walk out on to the pier after dinner, great view of the city, and don't forget a slicker like I did, oh well. . .
author: Myrna S.

description:
This review is a long time coming as I haven't dined here since my BY (Before Yelp) period in life. Nancy Oakes is one of the local pioneers in the San Francisco dining scene, starting with L'Avenue on Geary, Boulevard, and the newly opened Prospect. 
Here's what we ate: 
Appetizers (shared) 
1) Big Island Abalone - Two tender pieces in a creamy bean sauce. The sauce made for a great bread soaker. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tttm1r5Dw1sRMCfc3EQWPw?select=OWOaiduW8Bwg8PkNWlxGCw) 
2) Tuna Poke and Sashimi - Served with rice puffs and fried seaweed, the sashimi was mouth melting tender while the poke was creamy and topped with Wasabi tobiko. Refreshing starter. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tttm1r5Dw1sRMCfc3EQWPw?select=55vQ8swirwFxxNW1_gOoXA) 
3) Fried Soft Shell Crab - Cut into two halves, the crab was crispy good. Accompanied by an Asian flavored slaw and pickled radish strips. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tttm1r5Dw1sRMCfc3EQWPw?select=kaE2AhAANwV6cxWNrADeCw) 
4) Dayboat Scallops - Three medium large scallops seared well and topped with a spicy red sauce. Potato cubes mixed well with the sauce. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tttm1r5Dw1sRMCfc3EQWPw?select=jGVeUqYzXCwQjYm1x1dvZQ) 
Entree 
5) Grilled Pork Prime Rib Chop - One of their classic dishes, the meat was a bit more well done than I like, but still tasty. The garnishes provided a carousel of flavors with spinach with garlic, baby carrots on a small mound of mashed yam, four interestingly flavored croutons (crunchy yet soft centered), and fresh Bing cherries. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tttm1r5Dw1sRMCfc3EQWPw?select=cnMHLvH4lzVMXvwurUKyug) 
Dessert (shared) 
6) Chocolate Cherry S'mores - Chocolate Devil's Cake topped with melted marshmallow sauce with a scoop of Cherry Ice Cream. A shortbread cookie came with this dish. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tttm1r5Dw1sRMCfc3EQWPw?select=h50IGBOqLhMIspOhvTnyWg) 

My friends were kind to give me bites of their entrees, roasted lamb (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tttm1r5Dw1sRMCfc3EQWPw?select=1AIwgMyisOgfQdbYPTEsWg_ and roasted white sea bass (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Tttm1r5Dw1sRMCfc3EQWPw?select=QmxkSEF7xpyHy-1awihRLQ). 
The restaurant hasn't changed much over the years. On a holiday weekend Friday night, it was busy, but not packed, with mostly out-of-towners and older local couples. Wait... think I'm one of those older customers there. Our waiter, also local, was surprised that we were locals and joked with us about other fine dining restaurants in the city.  Besides the comforting atmosphere, I always remember their blue glassware (water glasses),a rarity in restaurants these days (The Restaurant - Ritz). The food is comforting and uses local, seasonal ingredients. My friends hosted the dinner which came to just around $85.00 per person (no wine or alcohol). Definitely not an everyday dining spot, this restaurant is a nice destination for those special occasions.  Nice to see things haven't changed much over the years.   Happy 4th of July!
author: Mike C.

description:
In my reviews, service/cleanliness is two stars and food is 3 stars. Food was perfect but service was soooooo bad it deserved a -2.

The food here was as good as people had told me.  Absolutely delicious and worth every penny.
The Good: Pork Chop (Crispy on the outside and OHH so TENDER on the inside), Scallops (OMG SO DEeEEELiCIOUS), Lobster (YUM.)
The Okay/Bad: Nothing..maybe the complimentary bread was meh but hey its comp

The service...wow..just wow..  We came in early and got a seat at the bar and our server had started off really nice with a smile and warm welcome.  Then as time went on, I don't know if he was having a bad day or whatever, but he seriously gave us the stink eye, slammed my tea pot, not giving me any acknowledgement when I ask for anything, and pretty much doing everything a server shouldn't.  We wanted to leave so many times throughout the night but it was our mini vacay to SF and heard so many good things about the food that we ended up staying.  Seriously, for the amount of money we payed, the service was RIDIC..  

Will I come back?
HECK NO, the food was AWESOME and forever in my food memory, but the service left me with bad memories and gives me nightmares of servers slamming tea pots in my face.  K bye boulevard.
author: John K.

description:
My beloved and I celebrated our fourth anniversery with dinner here.  She is the queen hell goddess of parking karma, so we found a spot on the street right in front of the door.  I can't help the rest of you with that aspect, sorry.

We're not big alcohol drinkers so we always appreciate when a restaurant has specialty non-alcoholic drinks.  I had the Elderflower Syrup drink and my wife had the Arnold Palmer.  Our charmingly dorky waiter said he liked my choice better and he was right.  The elderflower was so flavorful I ordered a second one.  The Arnold Palmer was okay, but I make a better one at home with fresh-squeezed lemon and Earl Grey tea.

Appetizers: Scallops, mouthwatering, though I thought only three scallops for two people was a bit chintzy.  Fig Prosciutto and Carmelized Pecan salad also first class.  Entrees: we both had lamb T-bone cooked to perfection.  It came with a juicy spinach sautee and fingerling potatoes.  The potatoes were a bit dry, though they tasted good.  I was too busy "mmmmmmm"ing over the lamb to notice.  Dessert: she had one of the home-made ice creams and I had a couple of chocolate coated peanutbutter ice cream bonbons.  Bonbons tasted heavenly but were partially melted inside, should have been solid ice cream.

I notice I had three reservations about food items, but I'll still give Boulevard a five star rating for the beauty of the interior, the smartness of the service and the general excellence of the food.  And be sure to check out the bathrooms: nicer than some houses I've lived in.
author: Michael L.

description:
I have been here for dinner, and it was one of the best experiences I have ever had. That's what is keeping this at  4 stars.

Recently, I went here for drinks. All were over $10 each - that's fine...I expect it in the city. However, I expect my martini glass to be filled more than halfway for a $13 drink. It was smooth and tasted great, but was under-served by just giving me a few sips. My mom's margarita, same thing...all ice, hardly anything to drink and $12.
author: Amy O.

description: Went to the restaurant alone tonight and felt at ease. Liked the ambience. It was neither too posh and stuffy nor overly loud. Plenty of couples and families celebrating their special occasions.  Loved the kurobuta pork chops, but loved all the interesting  accompanying sides even more. For a lady, the pork chop was perhaps too large a portion. It was very thick and generous. I had the black and tan for dessert. The flourless dark chocolate and butterscotch cream layer cake was moist and not too sweet. I didn't care too much for the chocolate and marshmallow ice cream that came with it as it was too sweet. Overall, a very enjoyable meal!
author: Li L.

description:
My boyfriend and I visited Boulevard after finding it in the SF Chronicle's top 100 Bay Area Restaurants for 2011.  I AM SO GLAD THAT WE DID.

Our server was fantastic -- I only wish I remembered his name to be able to give him credit.  He was knowledgeable about the food and the wine that we ordered.  He helped me pick from 3 things for dinner that I was interested in, as well as suggested an order to the apps that we ordered to build into our main courses.  

The food was fresh and delicious.  Soft crab.  Pea ravioli.  Woodroasted tenderloin and root vegetables and fish with lobster-stuffed squid and roasted tomatoes.  Each bite better than the last.  

The atmosphere was cozy, with a little funky mixed in.  The tables were close to each other, without feeling crowded.  I loved the long banquette that was near our table.  

It was a special meal, on a special vacation that I will remember for a long time.  Not sure if  I will make it back since I live on the East Coast....
author: Becky M.

description: Consistently good food, great service, lively and warm atmosphere. Why does Yelp care that my review is too short? I'm not a fan of musing.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Dined at Boulevard with my wife on the Saturday before July 4.  I had the lobster stuffed morels as an appetizer. Exquisite!  This unlikely combination brought out the best of both ingredients.  Paired with a Talley Reserve chard.  The pork chop entrée  was also over the top. Service was first rate.  Every restaurant employee is looking out for their guests.  Pricey, but worth every penny.
author: Nerbie E.

description:
yes another michelin star knocked off the list!

i came here for lunch w a coworker so last min reservations during prime rush hr was easy.

ordered:
-spicy sesame ahi tuna tartare: miso cucumbers, charred shishito peppers, lime aioli, chrysanthemum tempura, nori & taro chips.. the tartare was a little bland, wished it was spicier

-sea scallops and summer truffles: on a bed of risotto and corn.. so good, i cleaned my plate.. my coworker on the other hand, did not finish the risotto and *gasp* truffles!  

-petrale sole a la plancha: roasted fresh hearts of palm, golden chanterelles & cape gooseberries, fingerling potatoes & sweet white corn beurre fondu.. the fish was cooked perfectly and the meaty chanterelles went well w the fish

-berkshire pork prime rib cap: figs & red onions, shelling beans, crostada de romanesco, squash, balsamic vinegar & pork jus..the pork was nice and tender but after a while it got too salty 

sadly, had no time for dessert.. my usual .5 hr lunch at work turned into 2.5hr here


notes:
-me and my coworker were the only non-caucasian people
-we were also the only people under 30
-bc of the above factors, we were treated somewhat badly in terms of service.. yes, we can afford this place for being young, thank you very much! 
-to go to the bathroom, you have to exit the dining area and go down an elevator.. what a mission!

despite the slow and semi bad service, i'd come back to try dinner and dessert
author: Raquel T.

description:
The hubby and I went to my birthday dinner here.  At first when entering the place seemed larger and louder than I expected, I had my heard set on a romantic dinner without the noise, but the hostess told us our table was by the window with a great view and we settled at the bar for a drink.  

A few sips into my martini the table was ready and we were stead with great, attentive service, our waiter was knowledgeable but not overwhelming or stuffy, just professional.  

We had the ravioli and foi gras to start.  Amazing dishes, everything about them was yummy.  The foi gras was cooked to perfection the strawberries and bread that came with it balanced out the flavor and brought out nice nodes.  The ravioli were good too.  

For the entrees we had the lamb and duck and both were good, nicely paired and cooked very well with complex yet unpretentious flavors.  

We had some chocolate dessert which I could have skipped but since it was my bday had to get for the candle.
author: Inga W.

description: I think this restaurant just gets a lot of attention becasue of its location but it's nothing special given the myriad of exceptional restaurants in the city. I ordered their "seasonal chicken salad" for lunch and it was hands down the worst lunch salad I have ever had in a restaurant. No flavor, no thought went into it, no richness or complexity. Just a bunch of random ingredients that don't make sense together thrown on a plate.....second time eating here and I don't think I'll be back.
author: VKiss B.

description: Wow...lunch at Boulevard. Outstanding food and service. Great people. Really great food.
author: Michael S.

description: Food and atmosphere is elegant and awesome at the same time. This stuff is what you see on Food network and always wanted to try out.
author: Erik D.

description:
A celebration dinner at Boulevard... what a night! Great service, even for such a large party. Wine selection was incredible, vegetarian menu options were divine. The favors were fantastic, service was incredible... everything about this restaurant was amazing! 

Atmosphere is elegant in an old school way- definitely not a super modern SF dining experience, and the elders in our party felt quite at home. That said, I also loved it and will definitely be going back! It is a visit to another era- where cell phones don't ring off the hook, chivalrous men hold doors and pull chairs, and the servers treat the patrons with dignity and deference.
author: Kate B.

description: Have dined at The Boulevard about five times over a span of 20 years. The restaurant continues to deliver delectable dishes with flair! You won't be disappointed if you're looking for French cuisine with an American touch. The roasted morels with lobster were simply divine as was the fig salad. The halibut with risotto was delicious (though we did add a touch of salt) as was the wagyu bavette. This restaurant is the real deal.
author: Joy O.

description: I've been coming here for years. My recent visit was simply outstanding. The filet was cooked to perfection. The drinks were just right.
author: Wolf H.

description:
I made a reservation for lunch with my associate and showed up right on time. Our table wasn't ready so we were invited by the hostess to hover around the bar and wait. 

We stood there jumping out of the way of the wait staff as they rushed by us every 20 seconds interrupting our conversation. After 15 minutes of jumping around, the bartender managed to pour us a beer and glass of wine. As soon as we were served, our table was ready. So then I had to wait around to pay the bartender before I could proceed to the table. I really can't remember what I ordered, usually I order some kind of seafood, so that must have been it. 

Even though it was a miserable experience, I'm giving Boulevard 2 stars because everyone tells me its great.
author: Bill B.

description:
Took 10 years to finally try this place out, but it was well worth the visit.
Service was not quite 5-star, but pleasant and attentive enough to not annoy.

The food was amazing. realistic portions kept me from stuffing myself and left room for desert and I left feeling satisfied but not in need of  a stretcher to get back to my car.
You're going to drop a pretty penny here ($170 for two of us with no alcohol), but it was well worth it for a special night!
author: Brian T.

description:
Had heard about this place for years and finally had the opportunity to go for a dinner party.  We had a bit of a rough start since we couldn't get seated even with a reservation, but that was mainly do the the vast number of people that were sticking around for after dinner drinks (I'm guessing in part because the venue is so enjoyable).  After a bit of frustration from the seating fiasco, the manager stepped in and took control and really turned things around for us.   She tried to comfort us and and offered to buy us a drink or call our mobile when our booth was ready.. she really seemed quite sincere committed to helping us and she really saved the day!  Once we were seated the service was exceptional.  Food came out quite quickly for a party of 6, although maybe that was in part to us being seated so late.  The seafood was fresh and the drinks were poured with a strong hand.  

Tip:  If you can be seated in the rear of the restaurant (especially in the evenings) you have  beautiful backdrop of the  SF Bay and the light on the New Bay Bridge... The view alone is memorable.

Best Dishes:

Appetizer: Tuna Tartar & Beef Carpaccio
Main Dishes: Halibut & Lamb T-Bone
Desert: Flowerless Chocolate cake & Alpine Strawberry
author: Honeya O.

description:
The contrarian instinct to criticize the most elite restaurants seems strong in user review communities. I understand--I sometimes feel cynicism hood my eyes and tastebuds the moment I sit down in the most hyped, trendy San Francisco establishments. Maybe it's the same instinct that has us call size 4 actresses "fat" and Miss America runners-up "hideous." 

After reading a chain of yelp reviews bashing Boulevard, I wasn't sure what to expect. In the end, I'm siding with Michelin. Boulevard earned that star. Our meals were some of the best we have had.  The Heirloom tomatoes and buffalo mozzarella starter may have been the most pedestrian listing on the menu, but by no means was it dull. The tomatoes looked and tasted like they had just fallen off the vine, the mozzarella tasted more like burratta, and the sprinkling of toasted spring onions were like teeny-tiny onion rings, taking the dish out of the realm of caprese salad. My quail was perfectly cooked and I can't praise the farro enough. The filet mignon was just as good. 

The dessert was a highlight (but then, that's always my favorite part of a meal). We split a deconstructed s'mores: a buttery homemade cookie-like graham cracker, a square of devil's food cake with a thick layer of ganache, topped with a layer of bruleed homemade marshmallow, a scoop of homemade cherry ice cream, and a sprinkling of cherries. I could have eaten ten of them. Oh, and you might have sensed the theme--yes, every dessert, including ice cream, is homemade. 

The service is top-notch. I've read other reviews that complained that service was too attentive. Really? Personally, I like a full water glass. And I won't chide anyone for being too good at a job. That's like when a peer tutor came into my class and told my students that they were "over-prepared." 

Yes, the prices are high. And the portions are small, which is good for the American waistline, although I do prefer being fuller after an expensive meal . . .
author: Susan S.

description: Make reservation and always get dessert. this is one of the most consistent restaurants in the city. fine service and a reasonable price for the high end side of cuisine.
author: Ronald F.

description:
I was terrible and waited until literally the morning of my boyfriend's birthday to make reservations (hey, in my defense, he wouldn't tell me what kind of food he wanted to eat, and his favorite food is RAMEN.  Not happening).  We spent the day tromping around SF and came to Boulevard for an early dinner, and were pleasantly surprised by the ambiance.

Said ambiance quickly faded; this place gets crowded and LOUD.  The food was really great, but so rich that I had trouble eating it all.  The most memorable part of this place was the service; our waitress was just such a joy!  She helped me out when I excused myself to use the restroom and tracked her down to tell her, in a panic, that it was my man's birthday and if she could do anything special, it'd be really nice.  She really came through and brought us an amazing blueberry crisp dessert that I wish we could have every day!

Just a heads up, the noise level of this place during busy dinner rush really takes away any "romantic" atmosphere you might be looking for.  It's not awful, but it's not for everyone either.
author: Addi M.

description:
The service was second to none. When our server Keith asked us what drinks we wanted he overheard us mention that my mom wasn't feeling well and brought over some tonic water and bitters to help her feel better! 

Everything from the decor, the sea salt sprinkled on the butter, the french bread that was better even than the acme bread I love in the city. It all combines with delicious ingredients and incredible desserts.

The lunch menu seemed to have few items but everything we had was the best we've ever tasted. They found a way to elevate a cesar salad, to make a believer of scallops out of someone who can only have them bacon wrapped and sold my mom on the bass. Try new things here because even if it's something you may be unsure about it is going to be cooked so well you'll be glad you did.

I can't rave enough about this place, so looking forward to going to the bar or trying the dinner menu. For the quality, service (every server was focused on the tables...even the cooks!), and ambiance this place is a steal.

A little about me: I've been to Mortons, Bradley Ogden and Alexanders and this place is tip toing to the top of my list of place to eat!
author: Zaviera R.

description:
I was disappointed.   The food seemed to be made of high quality ingredients and reasonably well prepared.  However, I just wasn't very impressed with my meal.  Gristly lamb aside, it was a fair meal, but at the prices charged, I was completely underwhelmed.  Moreover, the arrogant bartender and distracted waitress that served us did nothing to make us feel welcome.  

It may be the kind of "safe" restaurant to take older, banker type clients, but if you are looking for something alive, where people have passion for what they do, go somewhere else.
author: Jason R.

description: The hostess was completely pretentious and beyond rude. The only reservations available when we booked on open table were at 10pm. Due to the late reservation we decided we would do dessert/coffee/cocktails. As we mentioned this to the hostess she laughed, crossed out out reservation and told us we could try and grab a seat the bar. In a snooty tone she said tables are for full dinner menu only. Well gladly take my reservation then, with this attitude towards your customers I have no desire to spend my money in your establishment.
author: Whitney F.

description:
I came to Boulevard to celebrate my sister's birthday (it is her favorite restaurant in SF) and I was very impressed.  We got one of the best tables in the house, right in front of the window in the corner. Fantastic view overlooking the Bay Bridge.

I ordered the Sonoma foie gras (by far my favorite dish) and the lamb T-bone.  My sister and her boyfriend ordered the potato gnocchi with rabbit porcini bolognese and the pork prime rib chop.  For dessert, we ordered the strawberry tart and hummingbird cake.  All of the food tasted fresh and amazing, the portions were actually quite filling (I had three beautiful, juicy cuts of the lamb T-bone), and I left feeling fully satisfied.

The service and quality of food are top notch- and expected, for what you are paying.  Our bill plus the corkage fee plus the freaking 10% SF sales tax plus the freaking 10% healthy kids whatever tax came out to be $100 per person...with about 20% of the bill going to taxes.  I think the dining experience is definitely worth it, just a little bitter about all of the tax-piling.

Everything on the menu tastes amazing, so you can't really go wrong.  I definitely recommend Boulevard for dinner.
author: Amanda N.

description:
I was there with my family for lunch because they didn't have a table in the evening, and we only had few days in SF.
The restaurant location is perfect, right on the ferry where many other restaurants, shops and market are. 
We ordered the salmon, sole, steak, beet salad, potato cream and Caesar salad. Everything was great! 
The dishes were bit small but we enjoyed everything and were not hungry after.
I gave only 4 stars because I think overall it's a little expensive for the food we got. (Comparing to other restaurants in the area).
I highly recommend this place, and probably dinner is even better. Enjoy!
author: Dana E.

description:
Food and service was amazing. The food was beautifully plated and the quality was superb. The service was wonderful. I was most pleased when our waiter came over and asked "do you have any questions?" I asked him if he could tell me what was on the dish. He was so nice and explained all the components of the dish and thereafter, made the detailed effort to come back and explain everything else on the other dishes. I really appreciated his thoroughness and patience in explaining all the dishes. When you are not looking at the menu, it is hard to remember what you ordered and it made the experience a lot better when the waiter explained what you were about to eat. All the little details from the food and service, really gave this place a special sparkle. Boulevard is very well deserving of the James Beard 2012 award (http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/SF-Boulevard-restaurant-wins-James-Beard-award-3541335.php).

For our dinner for two in June (before Foie Gras was banned in SF), we ordered: 

* Monterey Red Abalone $22 (5 of 5) Delta Asparagus, Crisp Abalone Mushrooms, Green Goddess, Borage & Tarragon. The dish only serves two slices of abalone, but it is of fabulous texture - soft and delicate. And well paired with its vegetarian equivalent abalone mushrooms.  This is a fun dish; I just wish I got some more pieces of abalone. But at last, I had to save room for my other dishes.

* Hudson Valley Foie Gras $29 (5 of 5) Huckleberry "Shrub" & Pickled Rhubarb, Caramel Rice & Lake County Walnuts, Wild Rice Toast. The foie gras was delicious and nicely paired with the huckleberry. I didn't favor the wild rice toast too much, because it tasted like rice cake, but it was made in-house and I thought it was a clever new take on the bread paired with foie gras. 

* Foie Gras Custard $19 (5 of 5) Fresh Porcini Mushrooms & Foie Gras "Custard", Grilled Hearts of Palm, Smoked Mushrooom Coulis, Maderia Jus. This dish was refreshing and an explosion of taste. Imagine eating Yoplait Custard but with the flavor of foie gras. It was creamy and all foie gras. Absolutely delightful to taste. The side components were also fresh and paired very nicely with the Foie Gras. I never had grilled hearts of palm and I rather liked it. It was mellow tasting and texture a little like fresh bamboo. It was tasty and paired very well with the strong flavors of the foie gras custard.

* Crispy Maryland Soft Shell Crab $17.50 (4.5 of 5) Golden Carolina Rice Grits with celery and Jalapeno Pickled kale, Sea Island Peas & Sorghum. This dish was wonderful, but just not as amazing as the foie gras or abalone dishes. Because this dish was fried, it seemed a little heavier than the other dishes. Don't get me wrong, this is still absolutely fabulous dish, but the other three were just more fabulous. Probably because this dish was fried and the others were not, that's why this dish was heavier in taste.

* Berkshire (Kurobuta) Pork Prime Rib Chop Wood Oven Roasted $37 (5.5 of 5) Roasted Chanterelle Mushrooms & Anson Mills Polenta with Herb Butter & Parmesan, Broccoli di Ciccio with Our Pancetta, Garlic & Chili Flake, Blueberry, Pickled Shallot & Sage Relish, Roasted Pork Jus & Aged Balsamic. Oh my goodness. Probably one of the best pork chops ever. It was so juicy and tender, I couldn't even believe it was pork chop when I ate it. Delicious! 

* Angus Filet Mignon Wood Oven Roasted $42 (5.5 of 5) Fondant French Fingerling Potatoes & Smoked Red Onion Marmalade, Broccoli di Ciccio, Onion Rings & Sherry Caramelizd Cipollini, Sauce Vert, Green Peppercorn Beef Jus, V.S.O.P. Butter with Foie Gras. Oh my goodness twice. Boulevard's filet mignon is probably one of the best ever. The quality of meat is top notch. The way they cooked it was perfect. It was so soft; you didn't even need a steak knife. The cut was so thick (at least 2.5 inches high), but when you cut it in half, it was perfectly cook to medium rare. No blood drippings and perfect brown rim around the perimeter of the meat. It was amazing. I definitely recommend this dish. However, I didn't feel like this dish needed the onion rings. It was fine without it. And I didn't really taste the foie gras butter on the beef. Maybe it merged into the filet. None the less, the filet mignon could hold on its own just by itself.   

* Dessert "Black Forest" Ice Box Cake $11 (4 of 5) Layers of Devil's Food Cake, Chocolate Mousse, Cherry Glee, Espresso Caramel, Cherry Chocolate Chip Ice Cream. This was a beautifully layered devil's cake with alternating layers of cake and mousse. Delicious, but if you are full, you can pass on the dessert.   

* Dessert milk chocolate peanut butter bon bon $3.50 each (4 of 5) Good, but I think I can pass on the bon bon next time. 

Boulevard was fabulous in food and service. It is definitely worth going for special occasions. Don't forget to use open table to make reservations.
author: Janice T.

description:
Service: 5 Stars
Food: 4.7 Stars (damn close to 5 stars!)
Ambiance: 5 Stars.

Definitely one of the, if not the, best dining experiences I've had in San Francisco.
author: Emma A.

description:
Generally an outstanding meal, although the desserts were a disappointment.

The day boat sea scallops were amazing; the accompanying garlic, tomato, and chive relish packed a punch of flavor.  The foie gras was very good, and the sweetbreads were excellent; better, I think, than ones I had at Jean Georges.

For our mains, we had the squab and quail and the pork prime rib chop.  The pork dish was outstanding; I've never had such flavorful pork.  The quail tasted better than the squab, but the dish overall was still very good.  The figs on the dish were delicious.

The only disappointing part of the meal was the desserts.  We had the doughnut and the strawberry tarte tatin; I found the tarte tatin to be overly sweet, while the doughnut was a bit dry and not terribly special.  

Our server was extremely knowledgeable about the menu and gave us great recommendations.  The dining room is very comfortable and offers a great look into the kitchen.  When I come back, I may just skip the dessert and indulge in the rest of the meal.
author: T T.

description:
Finally. A Michelin star worth of every $$$$.
Gary Danko and Fleur de Lys were good, but Boulevard just blew me away.

Starters:
Scallops- Incredibly tender and seared to perfection.
Tomatoes & Mozzarella- Simple, but oh so good. Excellent cheese.

Mains:
Seabass- Well-cooked. Amazing potato gratin.
Filet mignon- Great marinade. Loved the king trumpet mushrooms. 

Desserts:
Berry Pudding and Chocolate Cherry S'More- Heavenly.

No recommendations. All dishes were delicious and well-executed.
author: Sophia B.

description:
I received a gift card from my boss to go here. When I finally went, I decided to go with my family...and we're not the fancy type. When we went of course my sister and brother thought the portions were small for the price we paid, but I ordered the pork chop and it was huge. 

Overall, the food was amazing. My family would most likely not come back because of the price, but if I had the money, I'd get the pork chop again.
author: Christina L.

description:
This visit I was much more disappointed in Boulevard.
We spent $260 for two people. For those prices, you would expect a wonderful experience.
To make a long story short, the service was brusque and curt, the food was overseasoned and sweet, and drinks were overpriced.
The server talked really fast. Instead of telling us details to try to help, he just listened for a half-second and would interrupt and say, you should go with ---. I definitely got the feeling he was trying to move us quickly so he could get a second sitting e.g. second tip for the night. Also he sold me on a wine which was nothing like what I had asked for, didn't let me taste it first, then never said anything despite the glass sitting there completely unconsumed (at most really nice restaurants, the server would have offered a different wine or comp'd the obviously disliked wine). Generally he didn't seem happy to have us there; he seemed to be going through the motions as efficiently as possible. It felt like a business transaction.
I was disappointed in the abalone. Smothered in rich sweet sauce so that you could barely taste the abalone. Likewise the pork chop entreee was smothered in sweet cherry sauce. The best things all night were probably the bread because the butter came with sprinkled sea salt which was tasty and the ahi tuna was which very fresh. The filet mignon was pretty good although not outstanding. Generally speaking, the food was all decent but not memorable or inventive or unusual in any way.
The drinks were all slightly upcharged such that the alcohol bill came in pretty hefty.
I have to say, this place isn't worth the prices. The food is decent but there are much more interesting places to eat in San Francisco. And the servers, while not unfriendly, are not warm or personable or cheerful. The atmophere is cold.
author: p v.

description:
Lovely solid good restaurant!  It was a work group dinner for 8 people, and Boulevard was very accommodating and kept the red/white wine coming while we ordered our appetizers and mains.  

I had the lovely scallops appetizers (gone in seconds, tasty!) and had the filet mignon with greens and potatoes (cooked just right, yummm!).  And I had a nice, smooth cup of decaf afterwards.  

We all enjoyed ourselves immensely, fresh tasty food, great company, and our out-of-town visitors enjoyed the dungeness crab and halibut as they cannot get enough of California cuisine and seafood.  

Nice historic decor and really nice, relaxed ambiance.  I would definitely recommend this restaurant for a dinner for 2 all the way up to a group work dinner - pleasant & wonderful food.
author: Maile N.

description: Highly overrated. It's definitely good food but certainly not the best I ever had. I got the Dungeness crab to start, lamb chop and lobster ravioli. Lobster ravioli was too small and just OK. Lamb chops were good but not as good as the other reviewers have said. Dungeness crab was whatever. Atmosphere is kind of.. Tavern-y. Service was very good. I would probably recommend going elsewhere though.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
Still my Number One place to go for a great dinner in San Francisco.  And, hey, I get out a lot.  Went to Boulevard this past Saturday and had an overall great experience. Made reservations and promptly seated upon arrival.  Got seated in the back 1/3 of th place which is my favorite for nice conversation among diners. The central area is abuzz with the cook staff and open kitchen moving swiftly and the front part is with the bar. Each area has its own unique style and can suite to taste. 

Our server was very professional (Jay) and was very smooth throughout the entire meal.  Not too obtrusive, but not too distant when we needed her.  Service of plates is done team style so everyone gets their plate at the same time.  Great busboy service for refills and clearing of the plates. 

The food is just the best tasting. Dinner menu has about 10 entries in the appetizer/salad section, and there were 7 main courses. Our foursome had the heirloom tomatoes, the beet salad and the sliced beef with lobster plate.  All were absolutely wonderful.  Sauces and dressings just superb!

Our main courses were the halibut, sea bass, filet and pork chop.  Boulevard is so good because it is a great American Grill.  The meats were cooked to perfection and every so yummy. The mix on the plates was just wonderful also. 

Desserts were the home made ice cream, chocolate torte, and profiterole.  So good. 

The location and the old San Francisco building ambiance, the great all around food and the superb service makes Boulevard the place to go. 

After all these years, it still has the magic touch. 

Highly recommended!
author: John G.

description:
Reservations are a must.

Sat at the bar and had the grilled pork chop and gnocchi.  Pork chop was excellent and portion was enough for two.  Watching the line cooks were very entertaining.  Provided a greater appreciation of the meal consumed!

Drinks are a must and very good pour.

Ethan the server was excellent - very attentive, chatty, and frank.

I'd say the attire is business casual to dressy.  Ambiance is very steakhouse and loud.  Crowd on this Saturday night was mid-30's and up.  

A definite return spot!
author: Sandy M.

description: I have the privilege of eating at some exceptional restaurants. Boulevard is one of the finest places I have dined at. The food is outstanding, highly locally sourced, creative and well-executed. The service was top- notch. Our waiter made excellent suggestions, was appropriately attentive and engaging. I highly recommend Boulevard.
author: Chris B.

description:
I ate here for my birthday dinner and have been raving about it ever since. It's a lovely restaurant with impeccable service. 

For my appetizer, I had the beet salad with goat cheese. It was elegant and delicious. For my entree, I ordered the filet mignon, and it was one of the best steaks I've ever eaten. The fava beans complemented the dish well. I also had the birthday chocolate cake, on which they wrote Happy Birthday. It was beautiful and I really appreciated it. 

My date asked the waiter for a whiskey drink recommendation and got a whiskey smash. He loved it and had 2 more! It was delicious. 

Highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Annie C.

description:
I would classify Boulevard as more traditional than contemporary American Cuisine. I mean, they've been around the block for over a decade. So the dishes here are more dated than what Yelp has led me to believe. So many 5 stars review, I really do feel bad giving this place a 3 stars. But then again James Beard disagrees with me for 2012 so I can get over it. 

Why was it just A-OK for me, because I can barely remember my meal here. I know I had the Berkshire Pork Chop, and I told my self, Nopa's Pork Chop was way better. In fact, every memory of Pork Chop to me points to Nopa. So lesson to self, never order the Pork Chop anywhere else. As for the seasonal duo of lamb, well I tried to look it up and I couldn't find it. So even the internet thought it was forgettable.

Anyhow, 7 years ago, I would've agreed with James Beard. Now the standards have been raised by the likes of Nopa.
author: My T.

description:
I have been to this The iconic SF restaurant for a while so I decided on visiting it again and I got the same results as last time i was hear the food was average, great service, good atmosphere to have a date or a meeting and convenient location.
I have the WOOD OVEN ROASTED KOBE BAVETTE which was a disappointment. my friends had the sole and salmon which both were average. the final bill for 3 people was $194 without any alcohol.
author: Arash H.

description:
Review 400.  Glad it's for an excellent place such as Boulevard.

I'll just put it simply, Boulevard is f'n amazing.

I don't consider myself a foodie either, so I tend to get finicky about portion sizes, selection, etc.

The tuna tartar app was great.  The tuna was done in strips and it was stupid good, like to the point where we were even gobbling the lettuce garnish.  For a main course I had the lamb, which comes off the bone but praise PETA, that had to have been one of the best pieces of meat I've had in my life.  The lamb was incredibly tender, succulent and juicy.  It was almost melt in your mouth good but with enough texture for a decent chew.  The salmon was also masterfully done.

Surprisingly, I found the food to be enough to be filling.  Two appetizers and two entrees shared with my dining partner were more than enough to have us not even able to look at a dessert menu.  Of course the service is top notch and the wait staff seemed very knowledgeable about the food preparation and quality.
author: Steven R.

description:
Food:  We started with the scallops app and the asparagus with egg app.  Scallops were fresh and cooked to perfection.  Asparagus was good but ridiculously undersized for the price.  Seriously one piece of asparagus and egg for $17.  Really people?  Wanna wanna upcharge?  Geez.  For entrees, we ordered the halibut and swordfish.  These dishes also could have been slightly lower priced but this didn't bug me as much as the appetizer issue.  Great ingredients, great flavors.  So so fresh.  For dessert, we ordered the sorbets.  Once again, great flavors and drool worthy.  Overall, an absolutely fabulous meal.     

Drinks:  Cocktails were a little pricey ($13 gin gimlet?) and a little lacking on the liquor.  As for the wine, the bottles are extremely extremely overpriced.  Here is a tip:  bring your own bottle (its cool) and pay the $30 corkage fee.  That way you can go out and buy a nice bottle for $45 that the restaurant would charge you $135 for.  Add the corkage fee and it is still cheaper to BYOB!

Service:  Service was stellar.  Our waitress was friendly and attentive.  She let us take our time throughout the meal and didn't push us.  Water was always refilled.  The staff that brought out our dishes didn't even ask to ask whose was whose.  It was all in the details.  Really great. 

Ambience:  Classy but not as fancy as I thought it would be.  I was worried about what to wear but you could totally get away with dark jeans, fancy top, and nice shoes.      

This is a great place that knows what it is doing.  Service is impeccable and dishes so delicious.  My only qualm is the way overpriced wine list and appetizers.
author: A. M.

description: I enjoyed the meal here, the service was impeccable, came here because of the James Beard Award. But the food is OK for a top notch restaurant. I would come back but there seems to be lots of great restaurants in the city, I'd chosen AQ over Boulevard. Good for business dinners and dates. So all in all, it's not a bad restaurant. But I'd venture out to others before returned.
author: Victoria E.

description: One of my go to restaurants in SF. Go here for the dinner menu, the lunch offerings aren't as good. I've gotten the filet mignon every single time, and it never disappoints. The quality of the beef is on point, and the flavor is amazing. Cocktails are especially good here, although they are quite pricey. It's hard to get reservations, so you either have to plan in advance or get bar seating.
author: Jerry K.

description:
We ate here several months ago for lunch. Despite being well-dressed and well-mannered we were treated snobbishly at the host stand, as in, more snobbishly than I can recall being treated anywhere, but we brush off that kind of thing and I wasn't particularly worried about it at the time. We had our small son with us, so I thought maybe they just don't like kids, but was not worried because he's very well-behaved.

We waited much longer than I would have expected for our server. Again, not great but no big deal. Then we ordered and explained our son has serious food allergies. We asked whether a particular item, which seemed like a pretty good fit, would be safe for him to eat. The server seemed completely unwilling to help us determine whether it would be okay for him. After several exchanges, all perfectly cordial on our end, she said, "Well I COULD go and ask, but..." as though her having to do so was clearly unreasonable. (Even at low-end places, servers often go ask so they can be sure what they're talking about.) 

I was surprised that she didn't know the ingredients better, which might have allowed her to make suggestions as often happens in this situation; didn't care when it was a serious matter; and didn't even want to try to find out. I actually felt kind of intimidated given that this is a safety issue. I said nicely, "Could you?" And she seemed taken aback that I was actually asking. I was deeply surprised that she didn't seem remotely invested in us and our son having a decent, non-emergency room experience, which should have been easily achievable. (Of course we would tip extra for her trouble.) Finally she did go ask -- I think it required two trips since her first trip did not actually resolve the issue -- and we figured out something for him to eat. She then left us alone for a very long time. If she was angry that we'd taken extra time, well, it would have taken far less time if she'd been helpful from the outset instead of basically making us force her. I was seriously unsettled by her indifference and not exactly set up to enjoy a nice meal. 

Whatever I ordered was unmemorable which is a shame given the price. My husband had an okay entree and a delicious soup -- definitely, memorably good -- that was not warm enough by a wide margin. He pointed it out to the server in his extremely nice, low-key way. She said it had just cooled in the wide, shallow bowl. He again said very nicely that it just didn't seem hot enough to eat. It truly didn't, and my husband won't complain about things that seem marginal. She dithered again. Finally she took the soup away, reluctantly. When she came back she explained that the pepper was still in there, but no longer on top, since the soup had been taken out of the bowl, reheated and put back in. Since when is the health department okay with that? If the soup is too cold, it may be growing bacteria and needs to be completely replaced and put in a new, clean bowl. I couldn't believe that she was actually telling us they'd handled it that way, let alone the fact that they'd ACTUALLY HANDLED IT THAT WAY. Ugh. 

We didn't say anything further but finished up as soon as we could. We will certainly not be going back. My husband had had this restaurant on his list for a long time and it was a disappointment that it turned out to be the least enjoyable meal of our weekend in the city.

The check took a very long time and I took my son outside for a little walk, mostly because I couldn't wait to leave. Going out and coming back in I smiled nicely at the hostesses and they stared at us like bugs. I usually think people are just hypersensitive on Yelp when they say the hostesses or whomever were snotty but this was truly extreme, complete with looking us up and down appraisingly, which had also happened when we first arrived. It didn't seem they recognized that we were customers even though they'd been the ones to seat us in the first place.

Two stars for potential: the flavor, if not the temperature and service of, the soup, and the truly awesome nonalcoholic drinks -- best I've ever had.
author: Megan M.

description:
This place is the business.  Like literally.  There's just business happening everywhere here.

I think 50% of the customers were wearing light blue polo shirts with black slacks.  You know, that typical business attire.  There was drinking, fake laughing, ass kissing, and business talk all around.  It was tremendous.

But on to the food...  It was delicious.  The Filet Mignon was absolutely exquisite.

One thing though that I didn't like was the fact that you have to travel 2 hours just to get to the bathroom under a million flights of stairs.  Obviously not, but it was pretty far.  It made it quite difficult to both hold my urine and run down the stairs at the same time.  Great place though.  Will definitely be back to hopefully dine in the midst of talking great business.

the Great,
GumZ
author: David C.

description:
It's not often that all the hype you hear about a restaurant is warranted. I try to keep my expectations moderated in such situations. But, it was hard not to like Boulevard from the start.

The first thing I noticed was the great mix of patrons.....tourists in jeans and shorts, old money San Fran, young couples, new money San Fran.....all cohabitating nicely in this fairly fancy setting. Didn't see any kids but mine (which always worries me a bit) but they were well-behaved and blended in too.

Servers were great. Pace was not too slow or fast. Wife got a Ketel Cosmo and I got a drink off the menu that had about 40 ingredients in it (the only ingredients I remember were cognac and orgeat syrup). Cosmo was reported to be excellent and mine was good but a bit tart overall. Moved on to sauv blanc for dinner. Thing 1 and Thing 2 got house made sodas which were pretty tasty and refreshing and not too sweet. They liked them but it may have been because they only get soda once a year.

I had the calamari stuffed with rock shrimp and the filet as a main course. Wife had scallops app and the sea bass. Thing 1 and Thing 2 split the quail and the tomato mozzarella app. 

The standouts. First of all, presentation really means something here so it goes without saying that each plate was a mini work of art. For the food....Tomato mozzarella salad was really good. I know it's so simple to make but the tomatoes were perfect and they were served with the best and creamiest mozzarella I've ever tasted. Oh yeah, the pesto drizzle was pretty exceptional as well. Calamari and scallop apps were outstanding, too. My filet was cooked perfectly and served with a roasted tomato confit on top. On the side there was a really tantalizing bean stir-fry and some really rich (whipping cream?) and savory (bacon fat?) mashed potatoes. One of the best parts of the filet main course were these little crisps scattered amongst the vegetables. They may have been parmesan crisps or something like that. I found a way to get a little piece of crisp into every bite.

Dessert? Of course. Pastry chef is no slacker here.....turtle sundae profiterole was excellent as was the blueberry-nectarine crisp. 

Wow. Everything was so good. Will definitely be back. Make reservations well in advance.
author: Robert W.

description:
A culmination of perfect service, creative and expertly crafted cocktails, and flavorful sumptuous fare.

We came without reservations (whoops) so spent a while enjoying dirty martinis and dark n stormys at the bar. The bar staff was welcoming and knocked us off our stools with delicious drinks.

After seating, we were welcomed by an extremely attentive waiter and bus staff, who have nailed the balance between present and pestering, and friendly and professional. 

The food delivered exactly what the experience had built up to- richly flavorful thick seared pork chops with chorizo stuffed peppers, roasted beans and nicely complementary sauce plated underneath.

Absolutely a great place, good for friends (as our visit) but also seemed like a dazzling date spot.
author: Joel U.

description:
The simple dishes we ordered, the goat cheese and beet salad, salmon, and pork chop were exceptionally prepared. Boulevard is an example of how classic dishes never grow tired when made with fine ingredients and good technique. Nancy Oaks, awarded best chef in California by the James Beard foundation in 2001, did not disappoint. In all areas the service was first rate. (A warning to the gentlemen, the staff wear a blue shirt, tie, and dark vest. If you are considering wearing these clothing options at Boulevard, don't.) 
The wine list is reads more like a tome. The warm lighting and tiled walls cast a rose golden hue. On the bay side, there is a view of the Bay Bridge. It's a sexy restaurant, but the noise level prevents it from being an intimate space.
author: Nicole S.

description:
3.5 Stars

Overall, a quality meal that awakens your palate and mind to great flavors with outstanding presentation that is appealing to the eye.  I would come back here again.

I was a bit disappointed with our service as there were overwhelming raves about the service here.  For example, our table was full of crumbs after consuming the bread (see pic with caption "Crumb-y table."  I ended up cleaning the table. Not a big deal, but you know, if an organization thrives itself on service, it better deliver to every single table.  Second, the time that elapsed between appetizer and entree was 30 minutes.  Ugh.  I know, it's not a fast food chinese restaurant, but just a bit too long to stand.  Especially if it's Sunday at 10 pm, you know? 

Besdies that, you'll enjoy the food.

Try the cocktails, like the la reina.  Cool, minty, and citrus.  

Our appetizers were sea scallops and maine lobster. Beautifully executed.  Both were perfectly cooked and i really enjoyed the flavors on both dishes. 

Our entrees: Lamb chops - medium rare - perfect.  The potatoes and sour cream on the side were great. Just like a baked potato only better.
Pork Chop - perfect, moist, nice crust on the outside. 

Dessert - chocolate mud cake.  can't go wrong with chocolate. 

Price isn't too bad, under 200 bucks for 2 people, and def worth it for the quality of food.   I hope next time i go back, i get the service i've been reading about.
author: Diana L.

description: Expensive good food and friendly staff, but overcrowded and very noisy. Not a true French bistro or a restaurant for relaxed dining. Typical Pat Kuleto decor.
author: Pam J.

description:
Boulevard offers one of the best dining experiences in San Francisco with food that's perfectly prepared, inventive and very, very memorable. I love the Art Nouveau dining room (or is it Art Deco? Or maybe neither?) At any rate, the dining room is sumptuous without being stuffy and the service is attentive without being hovering.

You may have to call 2 months in advance to get a table at a prime dining hour - but it's worth it. Pricey - and worth every dollar.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Excellent tasting food, very well prepared.  Portions a bit small for me but excellent flavor. One gripe is we brought our own wine and despite the $30/bottle corkage (read = free money), they would only let us open 2. Lame.
author: Josh B.

description:
My wife and I came here 10 years ago to celebrate our anniversary.  10  years later the food is still wonderful and the place is still packed with people.  It just shows that new is not always better. Now for the food:  Italian Burrata and Heirloom tomatoes was a perfect salad for a  summer night . Alaskan Halibut and Sea Scallops-Beautifully prepared and cooked perfect. We ended the evening with a 'ball park' Bon Bon-  

The only negative ...the waiter was aloof but on the positive side the bus person works non stop.
author: James P.

description: wonderful, consistently top notch food & service.  I've dined here many times over the years and I'm always very pleased with everything!
author: Cathy C.

description: Brought my mom here for her birthday, l. Great atmosphere, Ok food, and Excellent service which made up for the small bon bon lollipop  I got for like 17 bucks as dessert. LOL!!  The man who took care of us was extremely nice. loved their late harvest reisling, and risotto, The pork chop was so soft and tasty, I almost finished it off my mom's plate..  A bit pricey but so worth it.
author: Claudia E.

description: Such a beautiful restaurant, and the food is excellent. My friend and I sat at the counter and watched dinner being prepared; the staff are so talented. The halibut was amazing and I could have eaten five of the butterscotch pudding. So good.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Man, this place is great!  

Bartender took great care with our drinks.

Servers were prompt, always around, but never around.
