Food was fantastic!!   

-Salmon (hers)
-California sea bass (mine)
-Heirloom tomato & mozzarella salad
-Crab-stuffed calamari

It's just how you want it to be.  Comfortable, classy, delicious, special.

Weekday reservations don't seem to be too challenging, but book early on the weekends! 

Challenging to get a great bridge view when there are only 2 of you.  The "2" tables are midway through the restaurant with larger group settings near the front / window / bay view.

Can't wait to come back!
author: Todd A.

description:
The best Valentine's Day dinner I've had in SF.  

We started with the abalone and pan seared foie gras.  I literally melted in my seat as the foie gras melted off the fork in my mouth.  It's the guilty pleasure I love to indulge. Thank you little bloated duck for sacrificing your liver for my delectable meal!

For my main course I had the duck breast and the ravioli filled with shaved truffles.  I'm surprised that some say the duck here is tough or bland.  Maybe it was because it was Valentine's Day weekend, but the duck was so tender I could have cut it neatly with a fork.  The ravioli was a miniature package of different flavors.  My boyfriend also seemed to enjoy the wood grilled walu.
author: Gail S.

description: Always a great meal at this place. It's fun to sit at the bar or grab a table with a group. Don't forget to to have dessert. Great vibe and service.
author: Vicki L.

description: Came back for dinner last night at this SF institution.  I had the local calamari with lobster and shrimp stuffing for the appetizer and it was wonderful.  For entree, I had the guinea hen butter - poached roasted breast and pancetta wrapped leg.  Both pieces of the hen were super moist and delicious.  I loved the beautiful presentation and all the other elements of the dish (for example, the hen was was paired with braised red cabbage and red beet gnocchi).  The service was also excellent.  I called ahead and they were super nice and able to provide a nice Happy Mother's Day presentation with the desserts we ordered (even though it was 1 day ahead).  So while there are always new and trendy places to eat in SF, I continue to love Boulevard for its consistent excellent food and service!
author: Tim L.

description:
Along time ago, a great restaurant opened in San Francisco on 1 Mission Street called The Boulevard. Years later it's still here in the city and like a vintage Napa Valley wine, keeps on getting better and better with age!

If you're flying into San Francisco for business or if you're a leisure traveler who appreciates the markets finest cooking, make sure the boulevard is on your calendar. If you're a European traveler, your best bet for an enjoyable evening is to go to The Boulevard as I've dined at some of the best restaurants in Germany, France, Switzerland, and the Netherlands, of which great chefs come from.

I've been dining in San Francisco since 1979 and The Boulevard is on top of my list.  Here's Why:

Food:  

- In order to produce a great dish, you need top quality ingredients and you need to know what you're doing. Believe me, The Boulevard knows what they are doing! When the server placed my dinner on my table , I knew everything was a 10 before I even took a bite.  My last dish was the ANGUS FILET MIGNON , which was WOOD OVEN ROASTED.  The quality of the meat was sensational and nice and tender.  The YUKON GOLD POTATOES were fantastic,  The SPINACH was cooked perfectly and was so good I could have easily finished 3 or 4 side orders of it.  For desert, the DARK CHOCOLATE TART was absolutely delicious as the pastry team here sets the bar for deserts in the city.

Service 

- The servers at the Boulevard move quickly into and out of their customers table areas but when they come to your table, they make you feel like you're the most important person in the world.  They can describe every item on the menu in more detail than a dictionary and seem quite happy to be working in the best dining room in San Francisco!

Atmosphere

- The atmosphere is so good in here that you're not going to want to leave. The lighting is perfect with an opulent feel throughout the room. Part of the kitchen is open but you hear little noise so can easily carry on a conversation.  There is a charming feel to the place that I have not experienced anywhere else and you can tell from the expressions on the diners as you walk through the restaurant
author: Gregg M.

description: I would give this place a solid 4.5. The service is attentive yet unobstrusive. The location is perfect and the food is really good just a tad pricey. Took a client here for dinner. We had a rather large party and the food came out timely for the most part. I ordered the winter kale salad and it was delish. There were pieces of kale chips added which gave it great texture and a nice flavor. My main dish was the lamb which was cooked to perfection. The sides of potato and cauliflower were just ok. Nicely cooked but it seemed more attention was paid to the presentation of them than the flavor. Next to the lamb they were an after thought rather than an accompanyment. I would return here as long as someone else picks up the tab.
author: Shariyah M.

description:
My second time here, this time with my wife.  Before I begin however, I would say that the first time I was here a couple of months ago, I would have given this place 4 stars.  But the second experience was much different.  The ratings are all based on food quality.  

Tonight, we had scallops for appetizers and for entrees, we had the halibut and the filet mignon.  As a whole, everything was very salty.  It was like the Chef's idea of flavor is sea salt.  I'm not sure if they had a change in cooks or what but it was overkill.

I asked for my steak to be medium and it was spot on.  But it was really, really, really dry.  And really, what's up with two onion rings on top of a filet mignon??  For that price, at least give me two pieces of shrimp.

We ordered the "black forest" dessert as well -- meh...

My two star rating basically means we won't be coming back -- and not just because there is way better restaurants in SF, but because the food was just darn right bad tonight.

Spend your money wisely my friends...
author: Mr. E.

description:
It's been some time since I've gone to a fancy restaurant, so this was a nice treat.  I heard this place gets pretty busy so make sure you make reservations at least a week in advance, otherwise you'll eat dinner at 10 pm.

We had the pancetta wrapped rabbit and foie gras for appetizers.  The rabbit was very tasty.  It was cooked to a medium rare so I thought it was slightly chewy.  I think had it been cooked a little more, it would've tasted like chicken.  The foie gras was good but not extraordinary.

I had the halibut.  I thought it was slightly overcooked.  It was seasoned well.  I'm usually pretty hesitant when it comes to ordering fish at an American restaurant because usually it comes out bland.  I thought the sea bass was better.  It had a better consistency, light and buttery.  

My choice of drink was a limone fizz.  This was delicious and very refreshing!  It's like an alcoholic bubbly lemonade.  

For dessert, we had the strawberry tart.  This was pretty good.  It was a bunch of strawberries on a flaky pastry.  Think of a round croissant topped with strawberries and a piece of white chocolate.

The ambiance is warm and dimly lit.  

The bathroom was a little confusing to get to. You have to go out of the restaurant, pass through a hallway to another door and go downstairs.  Once you're downstairs, you'll have to look around because there are several doors.

Overall it was a nice restaurant with good food, great service, and good ambiance.  The damage for 2 appetizers, 3 glasses of wine, a cocktail, a glass of port, 2 entrees, and a dessert was just over $200.  It's a bit pricey so I would save this place for a special occasion.
author: Laina T.

description:
This place is worth it's hype. We started off with the scallops and the foie gras. 
The scallops were prepared perfectly. The were slightly crisp on the outside, buttery on the inside! They paired well with the split pea accompaniment. 
The foie gras was everything that you would want out of this dish: rich, buttery, decadent heaven. The dish was decadent. For the main course I indulged in the filet. I cannot write it justice, only salivate as I imagine it. 
The finishing was their house carrot cake. Epic. The frosting was light and well paired. The cake itself was moist. The hazelnut ice cream was a nice touch. 
Boulevard- you are right up my pallet alley!
author: Bindi D.

description:
Came here several times and each time the service was great, the food was good and the drinks kept coming! This is the place where I fell in love with Saint Germane (the cocktail, not just the liqueur). I wouldn't recommend their special seasonal drinks, they did not taste good at all!! However, if you don't like the drink you ordered, you can just tell the server and she can put in a new order for no charge! SWEET!

The last time I went I ordered the following:

Soup of the day (Lobster bisque) $10: Nice rich creamy soup and you can definitely taste the lobster. I wish I could ask for more, but I had to try something else.

We had various types of appetizers, but we ordered so many that I do not remember what I ate, but all was pretty good as well. 

WOOD OVEN ROASTED KOBE BAVETTE
Creamed Bloomsdale Spinach with Smoked Bacon
Smoked Trumpet Mushrooms, Roasted Fingerling Potato, Beef Jus $23: The meat was cooked right, I asked for medium rare, and that is what I got.... but it didn't melt in my mouth like other meats I have had... maybe it is the type of meat and how it was cooked?

Dessert: We ordered various types of desserts and shared. Nothing spectacular stood out that I should rave about. 

The place is really expensive, I went during lunch.. and it still cost us a lot of money (with all the alcohol that we had... it made sense LOL).

If I am ever in the area and want to spend the $$$ on food and great service, I would come back. 

FYI, parking sucks and seating arrangement was weird. Our party of 10, 4 of us had to sit on this long one armed suede couch, another sat at the head of the table with a chair that was made for a queen and the rest of the party sat in regular chairs. I was sitting on the couch and i just felt like I was sinking and couldn't speak to them at eye level... just weird.
author: Erica T.

description: This is truly a wonderful restaurant. The cuisine is excellent, the drinks stellar, the service really top notch. Only thing I found wild was how people dressed here? I mean this is an expensive place, it's beautiful, elegant décor. Someone went to great lengths to create a beautiful space. BUT...there are those handful of SF ding dong's who dress like they are going to a Keg party. Dear god. Some tech brat in a t shirt and shorts with dirty grubby sneakers. Hipster? If you can afford dinner there you can afford a pair of dockers and a dress shirt. Can these people understand that one pair of jeans and a tshirt isn't appropriate for every, every occasion. Work, funerals, first dates, interviews...that indeed, sorry ...you have to change. Everywhere I looked there was one guy dressed like he was working on his car. It takes away from the elegance of the décor.
author: Armando Z.

description:
I've been to Boulevard a couple times over the course of several years and happy to say that it's still a solid fine dining restaurant destination. I think now with the bridge lighting, the dining experience can get that much better especially as night time rolls by. Most recently, I came here with my family for Easter dinner and we were seated near the back windows so we can have a view of the bay bridge light show. 

The food was great as usual and service was fine. I ordered the sea scallops as my appetizer, which was very good. I then ordered the pork chop for my entree which was mouth wateringly satisfying, probably one of the best pork chops around, with Nopa trailing a short second. Desserts were also very good and nicely done. Also not to mention they got a pretty decent wine list at pretty reasonable markup as well!

My best tip is to request the back seating so you can get the awesome view of the bay bridge light show. Overall solid restaurant that never disappoints.
author: Justin L.

description:
Always a pleasure to dine here at this lovely, La Belle Epoque-styled restaurant.  The servers have always been correct, well-informed and know how to present food and drink properly.  This past week, my husband and I stopped by for our eighth visit at this perfect eatery.  Greeted without snobbery and seated quickly, we were welcomed by a short menu of perfect food pairings and options.

The lamb was like butter and the fish was flawless.  We had some Kistler Pinot Noir and one could not ask for a better meal.  I would say in my visits past here, the appetizers have been somewhat unfocused or not quite perfect; however, the main courses/entree dishes have been without fault.

Take your time here--they want to present perfect food, so give them time to do just that!
author: Elle W.

description: Everything was truly special - the ambience in our private room for our party of eight, the friendliness and hospitality, the beautiful presentation of the food, and most of all, the delicious meal. My filet was prepared perfectly. The dark chocolate sorbet was rich and perfectly sweet. Our party ordered almost all items on the menu and everyone was delighted.
author: Adam R.

description:
So many reviewers found Boulevard to exceed their expectations.  I would have been thrilled if my experience came anywhere near my expectations.

Strike One: Making us wait 25 minutes for our reserved table.

This is a large restaurant, which would be full most nights, even if they didn't take reservations.  They should have enough space to buffer no-shows and late arrivals with walk-ins.  But for such a  large restaurant, to make those who DO HAVE reservations wait so long is inexcusable.


Strike Two: My wine was corked.  OK, the only time I'm truly disappointed by a corked bottle is when it's one of my own.  However, when the so-called sommelier came over to my table and began to ARGUE WITH ME about whether the wine was corked, I was downright shocked.  Alright, I *am* extra-sensitive to TCA (the chemical residue created by the bacterium responsible for "corked" wine) ... but the sommelier should know that whether you can sense the TCA or not, the first thing it does is dull the enjoyable aspects of wine.  I made him bring over a new bottle, at which occasion, I demonstrated definitively to him the tremendous difference between a good wine and a corked example of the same wine.

Strike Three:  My food was cold.  At this point, Boulevard's redemption was impossible.  Interestingly, they didn't even try.....


At least my date's food was good.
author: Droo G.

description: Overpriced ... tasting menus at many other high end SF restaurants offer better value and more compelling choices.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
I always wanted to try Boulevard. I might have expected too much... It was good but I'm not sure if I want to go back, unless somebody is paying for me...

The condition:
Anniversary dinner, early Sunday night with a reservation for 2. $130  (tax and tip included) for 2 main, 1 dessert, 1 coffee, and 1 tea.

8)
- very professional service
- beautiful decor, just like a real classy restaurants in Paris.  (Even the bathrooms are very ncie.)
- daily updated menu
- big selection of drink menu
- great place for a special occasion

8(
- pretty pricey (I think most of the price goes to well-stuffed members and its prime location.)
- small portion for the price
- when it gets crowded, the service gets little slow and pretty noisy 
- no free parking around the area
author: Mariko H.

description:
Everything was absolutely superb. The atmosphere in the building is excellent - I love the brick ceiling!

I have rarely had such a thick filet mignon cooked to absolute perfection throughout the cut. Perfection. Presentation of the dishes was very classy. Every dish at the table looked excellent. Food prices were on the high side but not outrageous considering the quality and the area.

Wine lovers rejoice! The wine list is extensive and we had some great wine. But I found the wine prices to be exorbitant, which was the only low spot.
author: Cameron T.

description:
After years of hearing about Boulevard, I finally made the trek for a birthday dinner. Bottom line, we had 4 diners, and everyone was happy with their meals and appetizers/starters.  I had the ahi tuna, burrata salad and filet mignon. The filet was so good with the perfect crust and buttery consistency with mashed potatoes and onion rings. Clever and yummy, with just the right portion size. The wine list is outstanding, there is a Sommelier, and they waive corkage for each bottle purchased. 
Conveniently close to BART in SF near the Embarcadero waterfront. Great for tourists and locals alike. Beautiful historic location. The seating in some areas can be a little close, but no worse than a European restaurant. Reserve at least a few weeks in advance if possible. It books up. They comped my birthday dessert.
author: C H.

description: An incredible evening. Love a place where the locals go for a five star meal.
author: Dallas F.

description: Requested a rare burger, and got a freaking awesome burger that was perfectly cooked rare.
author: Danny L.

description:
3.5 stars.
It's not the 5 star restaurant it used to be.  There was once a dress code and difficult to get reservations.  Now, people come there in jeans and there are tourists, etc.  But that's OK with me if at least the food is great.  Well, food good but not great.  The menu was kinda boring... salmon, fish, lamp, pork chop, filet mignon.  Typical variety that every decent restaurant has on their menu.  I really wanted the quail, but it was not on the menu.  I had the pork chop.  Good but not the best I've had and though well cooked, it was not juicy.  I've had better.  The appetizers were good (ahi and scallops) but small.  I did not like the rhubarb dessert I ordered and had the waiter stopped in to check on us, I would have sent it back and ordered the red velvet cake.  The cocktail I had, the gimlet, was not good either.  Both the cocktail and dessert were simply too tart.

Service is good and we were seated in an area with views of the Bay Bridge.  One nice touch... I let them know this was a client celebration dinner so they brought out white chocolate with the desserts with "Congratulations" written in dark chocolate. Nice decor inside.  Overall, good restaurant.  A bit pricey for the food, this is more like a $25-$30/dish place, not $37/dish.
author: Angelique B.

description:
There was a protest regarding foie gras when we dined there...which personally I totally supported because eating the liver of a goose or duck that is force fed seems barbaric at best. However clearly some other guests were visibly uncomfortable. They are quickly with there bodies turned to avoid the protest signs in the window. Okay; about the meal- pretty good , nothing shockingly new or great. I had the salmon and my husband had the sole. Kale salad to start which was good but again not exactly spectacular. Atmosphere seems pretty dated- the cooking area almost so dated it's steam punk cool- but not exactly. Tons of tourist or people who think wearing white sneakers ( not ironically ) and baggy ( not saggy, edgy just comfy casual) is acceptable . The bathroom is located downstairs which means you get to touch a myriad of doorknobs before returning to your meal - sort of defeats the purpose of washing them. The best thing about boulevard I think is the font on the signage. 
If you are in your mid- fifties or older it could be your scene.
author: elizabeth m.

description: Huge disappointment. Friend and I were in town for the weekend and wanted to have a splurge meal. This place was definitely expensive, but the food and service were totally not worth the money. Portions were ridiculously small (even the apps are too small to share) and I've had better sea bass at a wedding. Worse, the service was rushed and she seemed inconvenienced at having to split the check two ways. Overall, the whole experience had me wishing we had gone to Gary Danko's instead.
author: Ann B.

description:
It started well.  The gentleman who showed  me to the table offered my girlfriend a black tablecloth after noticing she was wearing a black dress.  Plus one for attention to detail!

Unfortunately, the rest of the night was a disappointment.  The food was mediocre, but that doesn't top my complaint list.

This was by far the worst service I have received from a Michelin rated restaurant.  The server seemed to be allergic to smiling and went about the entire night in a cold/standoffish manner.  This also is the only Michelin restaurant I've been to that simply dumped the dishes on the table once they came out.  No explanations or anything--the waitress and her busboy just came dropped the dishes in front of us and left.  I don't mind this kind of service if I'm eating at, say Olive Garden or a cheap Chinese restaurant, but Boulevard should do better.  

Other complaints include cold bread (yes, I'm a snob when it comes to cold bread) and the fact that the tables were squished together.  It was difficult to enjoy the meal when I could overhear conversations of the tables surrounding us. 

Sigh*  After such a promising start, bitter disappointment. No idea how this place gets the acclaim and media it does.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I have been going to Boulevard since it opened. I worked across the street at One Market Plaza and dined here many many times through the years.

When I think of Boulevard, what comes to mind? Nancy Oakes, mashed potatoes, amazing sauces and creativity. Our dinner this past week was really not up to par with what I've come to expect from Boulevard.

Let me start with what was GREAT: The service, the valet and the cocktails. Any restaurant charging these prices for a meal need to have those items covered.

Here is what we ordered. The starters were FAR tastier and creative than the entrees.

Starters:
- Ahi Tuna Tartare (quite good, but pretty safe)

- Seared dayboat scallops (same as above)

- Monterey Red Abalone (very tasty & creative, but for 20.00, you barely get 2 bites of the abalone. It's about the size of a silver dollar)

Dinner/Entrees:

- Wood Grilles Walu (very tasty, but not very filling)

- Sonoma Duck Breast, pan roasted (tough, chewy & low on flavor)

- Angus Filet Mingnon (quite good, but pretty safe)

Dessert:
- We tried 3 or 4 at the table & they were al pretty forgettable.

I'm not sure what I expected. But their menu used to be so inspired. They had many options for vegetarians. My duck was a TOTAL miss. It was just a chewy mess, and I love duck. If their menu doesn't get an upgrade, I'll be surprised. I'll certainly head back when it does.

On another note, I was also disappointed that the server was hawking the current cook book. Really? Shall I purchase some girl scout cookies while I'm there too? Come on Boulevard - you can do better.
author: Maureen B.

description: Wonderful atmosphere. Loved sitting at the chefs bar. Scallops were a hit as well as their wine selection. Service was quirky and knowledgable. Would certainly return!
author: Laurie S.

description:
"And tonight, as always, we'll be serving overcooked entrees in minuscule portion sizes with a palate cleansing bank account reduction."
"Oh, that sounds lovely, we'll take two!"
"But no more than two, we'd like to go home famished if you don't mind."
author: Michael D.

description: Absolutely delightful and the scallops are the best I've ever had.
author: Johnny W.

description: Always a dining experience!  Crowded and bustling on a Tues evening.  Had the Tuna Tartare to start, and it was a generous portion of very fresh shredded tuna with a light dressing.  Main course was lamb, perfectly prepared and well presented.  Only minor complaint was the two very tiny vegetables on the plate, which are more of a garnish than a side dish.  Service was pleasant and gracious.
author: Howard G.

description:
Boulevard is one of our favorite places in Frisco! 

The service is always perfect. Their bartenders always have the best seasonal cocktails. My favorites are the ones made with Hangar One! The wine selection is sublime! 

The food here is impressive and the presentation is artistic. Even the bread is to die for. 

BEST APPETIZER'S_____________________ 
- MARIN SUN FARMS GOAT "BORSETTA" RAVIOLI 
- AHI TUNA TARTARE 
- FRESH MONTEREY CALAMARI FILLED with HOUSE CURED SALT COD 
- DAY BOAT SEA SCALLOPS 
- MARIQUITA FARM BEETS & ORGANIC MIXED GREENS is my favorite salad. 

BEST ENTREES___________________________ 
- LAMB T-BONE WOOD OVEN ROASTED, BRIOCHE & LEEK STUFFING. Seriously amazing!! 

BEST DESSERT'S_______________________ 
- All of them! Go in a group so you can get one of each and share because these are all worth trying. 

WARNING! On my Man's B-Day I brought a custom made gelato cake and we were charged $12 a slice cutting fee. This seems steep even for Boulevard. OUCH! But hey it was his birthday.
author: Caro S.

description: This is a San Francisco classic. Everything here is good, reasonable size dishes so you don't feel really full. The building is really old but well preserved and nice; You don't find places like this in US. Be prepare for expending big bucks. Good for small customer parties (more than 14 don't fit)
author: Eduardo S.

description:
What a fantastic restaurant!!!  The reviews are spot on.  We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.  We dined at the chef's table, and had a most memorable experience.  These chefs are pros, and it was helpful to see what we wanted to order.

Scallops as a starter was great.  The seabass was great.  The halibut was great.  Should I go on?  Bottle of New Zealand Ata Rangi Pinot Noir was as excellent as I knew it would be, and a steal at only $36.

Very good service finished the evening.
author: Lawrence C.

description: Omg - way overrated! Nothing special here at all. I regretted having dined here. Fish was ok, but nothing special. Salmon with a red wine risotto?  No.  Michael Bauer was way off on this one.
author: Jean P.

description:
It's hard not to compare our dinner here with the dinner that we had at Zuni a few nights before.  Boulevard has a better wine list, better food, better service, better -- pretty much everything.  Zuni is cooler (the servers don't term the dishes "awesome" here) and a bit more fun because it's looser.  But Boulevard wins hands down in terms of what you get.  As for the quality/price ratio, that's a tougher one, but it does so happen that I was a guest at both dinners.

My abalone appetizer was superb, and I liked the lamb that was thrust on me as the main dish.  (The server didn't call it "awesome," but he did push it pretty hard.)  We had a Bordeaux blanc, which was OK but sort of boring, and then moved on to a Chinon, which I loved.

Great special occasion place!
author: Kenneth R.

description:
We have been to Boulevard several times.  We go after ACT matinees so we open the restaurant at 5:30 PM.  The restaurant filled up with loud tables of businessmen
And the noise level was so high that I had to turn off my hearing aids.  The appetizers of stuffed calamari were goof.  The soft shell crab was prepared tempura style and was ok.  The tuna was fussy and we all had quail which was prepared two ways with the legs sauteed in batter and the breast roasted.  The waiter said it would be medium which he said was pink.  All were overcooked.  Too fussy and reduced to multiple parts.  Same  for the dessert of ginger cake.  Multiple small pieces scattered on a plate.  Wine was good.  Service was correct.  $100 each.  We asked for Embarcadero view seats in the back but you couldn't talk when the place was full.  It is always full so "buyer beware."
author: David J.

description: Fresh and delicious and local. From the peacock floor mosaic upon arrival to the outstanding desserts, this is a classic SF dining experience. The affogato with cherries and assorted crunchies was a fine dessert.
author: Nancy M.

description: My first disappointment at Boulevard. Menu was not very exciting. Service was less then adequate and no  acknowledgement of my wife's birthday other then a note when my family was seated. I would have paid for something special. Even a cupcake with a candle would have been nice. The table behind us celebrated a birthday and a birthday desert was delivered. We waited for at least fifteen minutes looking at each other while waiting for a check thinking that perhaps they were preparing a birthday desert. I was reluctant to leave a decent tip but l did knowing that it would be quite some time before I darkened that door again.
author: Bernie V.

description: I had a lunch meeting at Boulevard SF.  I rated this restaurant 2/5.  I had toast salad 4/5, salmon asparagus 2/5 and Halo Halo 4/5.  The servers were inflexible, not accommodating and very slow.
author: Lily Y.

description:
Since I've been working in the food industry, I've been a much tougher critic when I dine at fine dining establishments. So, with that said, my review is a review of the establishment as a whole, not just the food. When I pay a good amount of money for a meal, I'm expecting not only a lot out of it, but a flawless meal. 

Made a reservation, and when we got there, we were seated right away. The service is very good. We order our meal and got our drinks. Service was not great but it wasn't so slow that I got impatient. I wasn't in a hurry to go anywhere do whatever.

Their dishes are composed with many elements and multidimensional. The appetizers were great. We ordered a ravioli with a cheese inside that I thought was great, very flavorful and creamy but I feel the other flavors were lost in it. 

The main courses were very disappointing. We ordered everything to share. With that said, we split it in half, and we both came to the conclusion that parts of the dish was very salty. The fish and the sides on the plate was unevenly salted and over salted. Very disappointed, especially for a fish dish that should never be over salted. The vegetables were also very salty. We also ordered a quail to share and to be honest, there was nothing special about it. There were some raviolis that I couldn't figure out what was in it and it was dense. The bird was slightly overdone and tough.

Dessert we ordered a butternut squash cake and that was really good. A combination of hot and cold, soft and crunchy. The flavors were good. A little salty, sweet, with a subtle buttery flavor but not too much. 

Overall, dessert was my favorite part of the meal but there was nothing else about the meal that made me want to scream for seconds. At an establishment as this place, and the price tag, there are much better places to spend my money on. I will sadly not be coming back.
author: Stephy Y.

description:
4.75 - Pretty pretty good - food was delicious and prepared with care, service was subtly attentive and professional, and the atmosphere was bistro french with authentic touches from color to materials used.

Let's start with the important stuff - the food. So while the food wasn't crazy unique in terms of ingredients or flavors, what Blvd did well was that all dishes were executed with precision and taste.

I started with the Maine Scallops ($16.75)  served with some cream potatoes and heirloom tomatoes. The scallops were seared just perfectly and presented with care and made the hero of the dish as they should be.

For my main I had the Californian Sea Bass ($34), pan fried with fava beans and potato gratin. As I mentioned earlier, it wasn't anything different in terms of flavor combination but the preparation was perfect. My fillet was seared beautifully golden brown with a touch of crispness, and when you fork through the layers of the fish, it breaks nicely and is tender to the taste. Presentation was impeccable.

Dessert was actually my favorite. I couldn't resist the Hummingbird Cake ($10.50). I've personally made this Southern cake but their interpretation took it a bit further with layers of honey & banana cake, spread with hazelnut & pineapple jam, topped with banana mousse frosting, coconut meringue, and paired with pineapple sorbet. I was in heaven.

I'd definitely accept an invitation to dine at Boulevard again.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Yelped around and found that this would be a great place to take the gf for a celebration dinner. We made our reservation on Open Table and were able to walk right when once we had arrived.

The service here is excellent and we were seated right by the open kitchen so we got to see the chefs at work. It kinda felt like the show "Hell's Kitchen" without Gordan Ramsey cussing everyone out, very cool. The first thing the waiter asked us was if we needed to make it to a show or had any time constraints on the meal that he needed to know about. When we were asked that I was surprised that a restaurant would even ask and try to work with MY schedule. +1 to service

We ordered:

Appetizer: Lobster Ravioli
Main Course: Filet Mignon
Main Course: Lamb
Drinks: Malbec, and Winter Bliss

The appetizer only came with 3 pieces however the waiter said that since there were two of us, he would gladly add on another piece so that we could each have 2 at no additional cost! 

The ravioli was perfect! The lobster taste was there and it wasn't mushy or left you wondering if you just ate lobster or crab. This was a delish appetizer that I think all should try!

The Malbec I ordered with my lamb complimented it well and the Winter Bliss (mixed drink) was not over powering and my extremely light-weight girlfriend who hates the taste of alcohol was able to drink the whole thing!

The filet and lamb were both cooked perfectly to our liking and I could not have asked for any better service! The atmosphere was perfect as well, with tons of christmas decorations and lighting, really set the mood!

If you are looking for a celebration dinner or one to take a girl out to, this would be the place!
author: Steven C.

description:
Chose Boulevard for our own "au revoir fois gras" dinner last night and we were not disappointed. We ordered both the traditional fois gras (seared and on a lightly cinnamon scented toast point) as well as the fois gras custard. Very interesting take as it was almost like a fois gras brulee. Very rich but oh so yummy, esp the mushroom coulis (which could be a good stand in for vegetarian fois gras). 

I chose the quail entree and absolutely fell in love with the preparation. The apricots were dressed with an elderflower vinaigrette which toned down the acidity of the fruit perfectly and gave them a lovely floral note. 

And our waiter Jeff was absolutely wonderful - attentive without being overly obstrusive. He made perfect drink recommendations which paired wonderfully with each dish. He definitely enhanced and completed our dinner experience. We're definitely asking to be seated in his section again.

PS Try the Pomegranite/Ginger Beer cocktail. Mmmm...perfect!
author: Noriko W.

description: The whole experience here was fantastic.  We got there super early for a 9pm res so we sat at the bar and had a couple drinks (the bees knees - whoa! and some good pinot).  We were seated near the back of the restaurant with a nice view of the lighted bay bridge.  Service was excellent the whole time - we didn't feel bothered, but never waited for anything we needed.  Now I can't remember what we had (squab, I think, and maybe lamb) and apps... whatever it was, it was delicious, all of it.  We'll definitely be back here!
author: Kristen B.

description: I just had one of the best meals I've ever had in my life.  Never thought anyone could reach Reatta status but this place has.  The halibut and lamb were awesome.  Sides were great.  I usually don't do dessert but everything was so good I did.  It was redonkulous.  The chef here is an artist.
author: slapnuts m.

description: Usually when I go to a "fancy" restaurant I order the steak.  But for some reason, I can't remember if the waiter suggested it or not, both my friend and I ordered the pork chop.  Kind of a weird thing to order, right?  It was transcendental.
author: Mitori H.

description:
I visited Boulevard on Friday night with two friends that live in the city. I have to say I was little skeptical at first because I had read recent mixed reviews of a lot of "hype" with under delivery, but ultimately was convinced by all of the positive recommendations I had received from friends and fellow Yelpers (thanks guys!). Man am I glad we decided to go! When we arrived through the rotating front door we were immediately captivated by the trendy decor, such as the brick style ceiling and stylish lights. It reminded me of a trendy New York restaurant, like something you would see in SOHO. We were seated promptly and greeted by our friendly server who took our drink order. However, when we had questions about some of the wines on the menu, she answered with non-informative, lukewarm, descriptions. Kind of a disappointing start to the evening, but at least it was only the wine list and the only isolated complaint I can offer. She gave us a few minutes to mull over our decision, and we decided on a California red (Prelude Pinot Noir - very good). When it was time to order appetizers, she instantly transformed into a knowledgable foodie who was able to break down all of the dishes! Thank goodness for the transformation, as all of her recommendations that we ended up ordering were great. She had explained that the appetizer selections were on the smaller side, and they were designed to be ordered "one per person" to accompany each meal. We opted to order 3 appetizers and share them so we could all try a little sample of each. The first appetizer was the Spicy Sesame Ahi Tuna Tartare. It was very high grade tuna, and it was prepared and tasted exceptional. Next was the Porcini appetizer which was well prepared and tasted good. Finally, we split the Veal Sweetbreads. Wow, these things were good! If you have never had sweetbreads before, or are hesitant on ordering them because of where they come from (animal thymus), put all of that behind you and try them. By far the best appetizer we ordered. For the main course I ordered the Eden Valley Berkshire (Kurobuta) Pork Prime Rib Chop. It was very tender and juicy, and the flavors were perfectly balanced. I also tried a taste of my friend's Pan Roasted Local Wild Salmon. I like fish but I'm not a big fan of Salmon, but this dish was cooked to perfection and tasted fantastic. Finally, I had a small taste of my friend's Wood Oven Roasted Angus Filet Mignon. I wish I would have ordered this one for myself because it was one of the most tender, flavorful, and best prepared filets I have ever tried! You will not regret ordering this one! We decided to skip dessert as it was late and we figured we would end up having a night cap at a local bar in the Mission. 

In conclusion, this was one of the best dining experiences that I have ever had. I would definitely consider myself a foodie, and I enjoy fine cuisine at new restaurants. Expect to pay about $80+ per person, but remember that you get what you pay for. If I could rate this place more than 5 stars I would. This place is definitely worthy of the Michelin rating...

One last word of advice: Good luck finding the bathrooms! They seem to be a mile away from the dining room and they are not labeled clearly. I thought at one point I had walked through a different restaurant to get to it! Maybe it was just me or maybe that was an intentional part of the "mystique", but nonetheless you may want to hold it if you want to get back to your table before dinner arrives!
author: Andrew C.

description: Fantastic meal! Softshell an Sweetbreads to start, then on to Quail and Prime Pork Chop.  All were just outstanding! The lone stumbling block continues to be the quest to the bathroom.
author: Jack J.

description: The servers and hostess were all incredibly rude. The food was mediocre at best. Don't waste your time.
author: Kate A.

description: The food is okay.. not worth it for the really expensive price, in my opinion. Really intimate setting, service is nice.
author: Carmen T.

description: I have come many many times over the years and Boulevard is simply my favorite place in the world to have lunch.  If you have an important meeting, bring them here.
author: Gage H.

description:
On their menu right now is this:
Washington Steelhead Salmon

This does not exist. It is either a steelhead or salmon.
Whats next ? Flounder Tilapia ???
If it is steelhead it cannot be wild caught unless bought from the Indians. Must be farm raised. But maybe it is Salmon. They say they did it because Steelhead was not selling so they choose to mis-label it. Which BTW is illegal because both steelhead and salmon are game species. How could they let this happen ? Misrepresentation.

Looks like Marketing faux pas ? What is the head chef saying...??

They mislabeled this for themselves, screw the customer. I have no trust in this place.

Everything way overpriced. Wonder what else is deceiving on their menu.

California Fish and Wildlife could shut this down. Think I will call them.
author: Smith S.

description: Love! One of my new favorites! They change the menu daily, however everything  from the appetizers, main course and dessert were divine. I highly highly recommend. The ambience is wonderful and makes for a great place to celebrate birthdays and anniversaries.
author: Zainab B.

description:
My wife and I eat here once per year for one of our numerous anniversaries.  My recent dining experience in September 2011 was no different than the last 3 years.  

Lobster raviolis were INSANE! My wife and I ordered a few starters to share and a main dish. I do not think you can do wrong with any dish as they are executed to perfection. The service is on par with any high end restaurant in SF. Great selection of wines. Dessert was least impressive, but decent. I would highly recommend for special occasions.

Expect to pay over $100 per person but very worth the experience.
author: Tony O.

description: Don't try to go there without having reserved a table! This is an in-place in a bustling city where I anyway had the feeling every evening while we were in town that the whole population was out to grab a bite. We had a reservation, still had to wait a few minutes to get our table, but it was worth the wait. Service was friendly and accomodating, although a bit at the limits. The food was just great! Ahi tuna and sea scallops, amongst others, for starters. My main course was a pan roasted king salmon on pinot noir risotto, which sounds like an odd combination, but actually tasted delicious, the two aromas blending quite favorably. We also had a lamb t-bone, swordfish and halibut, which I was told tasted equally well. The wine list is large. We found a wonderful Napa petit verdot. The name is Snowden, so the wine became a conversation piece as well, but actually was a very fine wine. If the restaurant is full, it can get a bit noisy. The part towards Embarcadero where we sat has carpet, so the noise level was much better than around the bar.
author: Michael P.

description:
This is one of those restaurants where your food is super fancy and expensive but you don't get much. To me it was perfect portion though because I generally don't eat a lot. I had lamb for the first time (yes first time ever because my best friend never lets me eat lamb) but it was beyond delicious. I felt like it was cooked perfectly and seasoned perfectly. The place is very fancy and classy so dress well. 

The service isn't the best though and is a bit slow but I can live with it.
author: Jenny N.

description: Been here twice for a work lunch. I thought it was over-priced despite the fact that I didnt even have to pay the bill. The food is good, but not $30 dollar per entree good. The service is very acceptable. The ambiance is very classic, old san francisco wealth. It looks like a place you'd dine at with your private wealth banker, whip out a cigar, and eat a $20 dollar burger.
author: Phantom Of Yel P.

description: This was the second time I tried boulevard restaurant. The first time we were seated at the bar and had an amazing experience. The bartender made us divine cocktails and the small dishes including the gnocchi specially stood out.  Unfortunately they did not have the same selection and no gnocchi the second time. The diablo margarita had a kick because of the jalapeño agave but it was not special. The squab risotto starter was mediocre. The squash soup was not impressive and the ravioli di mar was ok and the bites were bland. The experience made us not want to try out any deserts. I guess because of the first experience our taste buds were craving more of a unique feel. For the prices I feel that there are other restaurants that may give you a classy and better food experience.
author: Tulip M.

description: Never disappoints. Low key elegance, beautiful service, great food. Pricey for sure, but just a lovely experience. And the Negroni is in a proper Martini glass filled to within a ¼" of top, unlike every other Negroni we've had in this town. Totally reversing the norm of the higher end the restaurant the stingier the drinks, here they just do it right. Because that's what they do.....
author: Harley M.

description:
Took my boyfriend here last month for his birthday.  I was a fan of the valet, but not of the decor (a bit kitschy and old) and most of the diners were coming from work and older.  With all that aside, the service was great and the food was delicious!  They cleared our plates after each course, and our bus boy joked with us each time.  We shared and demolished:

*red abalone with grilled octopus, black ink pasta - I liked the pasta's texture and loved the grilled octopus!  I was expecting more from the red abalone as it sounded exotic, but I was slightly disappointed.  

*dungeness crab salad with grapefruit, blood orange and fennel salad - I loved every delicate bite!  This appetizer is bursting with flavor and so refreshingly cool

*king swordfish with beet risotto and cashews - the fish was perfectly cooked and the texture was so buttery and dense.  They did not skimp on the fish, which I appreciated given the price!

*hen wrapped in prosciutto with gnocchi - this was a very rich and savory entree and slightly over-seasoned

*banana cream pie with dark chocolate eclairs - I was not a fan

*chocolate "candy bar" with toasted marshmallows, vanilla ice cream and caramel rice krispy - I couldn't stop eating this and loved the medley of textures and flavors, particularly the well-balanced pairing of salty with sweet, fresh and burnt.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Came here for lunch... We got the pork belly and oyster starter. The pork belly was cooked perfectly and the oyster was good as well, the only problem was that we wanted more of it! I was thinking that the portion would be a little bigger for my entree (I got the sole), but it really wasn't.... I was not expecting large portions by any means knowing what kind of restaurant Boulevard is, but these were still small. 

I do like that they had some creative and original starters on the menu. I wasn't very impressed with my entree, and my friend wasn't impressed with hers either. Overall, it's a good place but nothing spectacular, nothing happened there that makes me want to go back there. Service was alright, kind of snobby. I miight go back again, I have heard from people that Boulevard is sometimes amazing and sometimes OK (I guess I went on an "OK" day...), however I will probably wait to go back until someone else is paying the bill because I don't want to pay that much money with the chance of getting another OK meal.
author: Alison B.

description: My boyfriend took me here for my 25th birthday dinner & I'm so glad he chose it :) we had a table with a nice view of the bay bridge all lit up. Our server was fabulous and so attentive ... The instant a plate was finished he was there to take it off our table. They have a nice wine selection and my bf got this jalapeño cocktail that was so tasty. Nancy Oakes really knows what she's doing with that menu, everything sounded incredible! For appetizers we went with the ahi tuna tartare & the beet salad. They were both perfect! I got the sea scallops a la plancha ... They were cooked to perfection and were the most delicate scallops I've ever had. The purple potatoes were so simple but they way they were cooked was incredible. My bf got the swordfish and it was light and just melted in your mouth. Since we were celebrating my birthday the server brought me a scoop of coffee ice cream with a candle in it, which was the perfect ending to the night. We left so satisfied & our tummys felt good ... We were happy to leave dinner not feeling overly full. 5 stars all around, I can't wait to go back :)
author: danielle a.

description: Be prepared to wait. This place is short on hospitality and long on wait! When we finally were seated 30 or so minutes after our reservation time, the table was so squeezed in that the servers threw my bag on the floor and mussed the top of my hair brushing by. Food tasted bland and what wasn't bland was unbelievably salty.(calamari and sole) desserts were good but it's not a dessert place! Save your money and go somewhere where the star rating lives up to its name!
author: Rhonda H.

description:
I'm torn between four and five stars, but I think it's close.  

It's been quite some time since I've been to Boulevard, and yet I still remember how much I enjoyed the experience in the few times I managed to visit.  The food was absolutely delish. I have a soft spot for inventive, fresh American cuisine. I've had the filet mignon, which was tender and juicy.  The salmon was soft and flaky.  The wait staff goes above and beyond to make customers happy, which always add to the overall dining experience.  The prices are standard for this type of establishment.  

Personally, I'm not a fan of the set up, location, and decor.  It can get pretty loud and very packed.  I call these minor inconveniences, considering the consistent quality of their food.
author: Angel S.

description:
I loved my Boulevard experience. We went there to celebrate the bf's bday after reading great reviews. It was worth it. I emailed ahead and got a nice table, but was surprised by the lay out of the "nice table". But it's a great people watching area in the restaurant.
The food was good, very tasty. The waitress was pleasant, she was willing to answer our questions and take back my bf's drink to the bar when he decided it was too strong :p
For a special occasion or just a good date night, I think boulevard is ideal. Great location, so on a nice summer night you can go walking along the embarcadero afterwards.
author: francis c.

description:
This place is fancy and makes me feel like I'm in a scene from the great gatsby. The kitchen/huge stone wood oven is situated right next to the tables. The open kitchen gives it a homey/cabin feel with is nice if you are on a business lunch because it encourages conversation but don't like that it leaves my clothes smelling like food afterwards. 

I don't eat lamb but everytime I go the waitress recommends that. My friends have gotten it before and it looks grilled to perfection. I wish I like lamb so I can try it. 

I've had the hanger steak with fries here. Really tasty and it comes out exactly as i ordered it (medium rare). 

I love bread and judge a place by the bread. This place has pretty warm, fresh, amazing bread. Comes with butter and sea salt.
author: Keara C.

description:
This place is a joke.

You spend alot of money for very, very little.

I was very disapointed in what I received on my plate.

I ordered Lobster and it was a complete joke.

Total rip off.

I would never, ever, go to this place again in my entire life.
author: Neal C.

description:
Would give this 3 1/2 stars ( if yelp let us do half stars)  The food was very good, the service was just, in a word, weird. 

We had the abalone and black risotto which was the best ever dish.  The lobster and beef carpaccio  and soft shell crab appetizers were good.

The pork chop was the best main course, but the lamb rib and filet mignon were also very good

The angel food cake dessert was a highlight

The portions are very small.  Despite three appetizers, the main dishes,  dessert and cocktails no one was really full, and we are not big eaters

We probably will never go back due to high prices and small portions, as well as the off waitress that served us last night.
author: Foodlover B.

description: We had a family birthday dinner here.  There were so many delicious options to choose from, it was hard to decide.  We opted for the heirloom tomato salad with burrata, and then most of us had the pork chop and the risotto.  All meals were perfectly prepared, presented beautifully, and the flavor blend was fresh and delicious.  The risotto came with a stuffed squash blossom which was delicate and perfect.  We highly recommend Boulevard.
author: Marion P.

description: I haven't eaten here in 3 years but I still think about it... i think that says something. It is still one of my favorite restaurants in sf - I wish it was easier to get a reservation!
author: Jessie L.

description:
Big flavors...big main portions...big space footprint.  The first not a surprise -- San Francisco's food scene attracts talent and creativity...wonderful food is expected to result.  The portions were a little of a surprise -- with a nod to French cuisine, I wasn't sure if this was their way of infusing an "American" flair to the menu.  And the footprint was definitely a surprise...it's been a few years since my last visit to SF but I feel like many of my previous experiences were in much smaller more intimate spaces.  

The good news is the expanse of space becomes much more intimate and charming as you settle into a table with a view of the bridge...at the bar for a cocktail...or seated at the chef's bar watching the controlled chaos of the kitchen as they cook and plate starters, mains, and desserts for you.  With mains looking too overwhelming for me, I chose two items from the starter menu for my meal.  The beet salad with ricotta and hearts of palm was a lovely balance of earthy, smooth creaminess, and a touch of acid at just the right moments to make it all work.  That was followed by a small treat from the kitchen:  a savory cracker with a caviar spread ... delicious!  My "main" was the warm lobster starter  -- lobster was sweet and perfectly cooked and framed by a thin slice of panchetta as a base.  Thankfully my "lighter" meal allowed for a cheese course -- a cow triple cream, cow and goat blend, and a tangy bleu.  A beautiful finish to a nice meal.

Sitting at the chef's bar provided terrific foodie entertainment and a chance to make new friends at the bar.  Don't be intimidated by the menu, space, or dynamic of Boulevard.  The staff is warm...service professional...and you're in for a delightful time.  But if you plan to take full advantage of the experience, come hungry or at least bring friends you can share the large portions with.  Bon appetit!
author: Mylene B.

description:
Consistent. 
A favorite for lunch.
One of the best restaurants in San Fransisco.
One that I recommend with out any hesitation. 

Today: 
- Appetizer:  Tangerines and Medjool Dates with cacao nibs, pistachio, tangerine syrup... AMAZING combination; I'm still thinking about the hints of chocolate from the cacao. 

- Entree: Kobe Bavette Steak with smashed potatoes, spicy broccoli rabe, onion rings... Everything was perfect. The spice in the broccoli rabe really stood out.

Tips: 
- Even on the busiest nights it is not impossible to get a table at the bar.
- Suggest a table rather than a booth
author: Evan F.

description:
Wow,

Is all I can say. It has been some 15 years since I ate here last (sorry pat and Nancy) and I was so blown away by the great food, wonderful atmosphere and stellar service....that I truly should have come many more times since than.

This restaurant is the paragon of consistency, The food is still amazing, the restaurant is still beautiful, and the service is still impeccable.

I had the pork chop which was amazing (great pork cheek too), unlike Spruce, the food was cooked to perfection with amazing touches added to enhance the flavors. The fillet Mignon was so tender it was decadent. The lamb t bone was some of the best lamb ever!.

The tuna tartar was really really good.

Finally the deserts were very nice. The chocolate peanut butter bon bons were fun. The baked Alaska was great. The Banana  butterscotch pie was rocking.

I really liked this place as did everyone else (no wonder it gets such amazing yelp reviews). I will come back much quicker this time.

thanks for the great meal Boulevard!
author: David G.

description:
Well... there is a reason why restaurants get stars from Michelin... and well.. also from me :)

It is probably the most expensive place I had been in the city but it is totally worth.

The reception is very gentle and the bar for your wait has all the classic drinks and more.

Once sit, you are served the old style, with class and knowledge. Starter of AHI TUNA TARTARE .. DELISH!!

SCOTTISH SALMON (SUTHERLAND COAST) as main course.. WOW.. how can they cook salmon that good.. never managed that at home!! It was presented greatly and the taste was superb!!

The sommellier gave great advices on a superb white Nora Albarino whine..... WOW!!

Desserts were to pair with the rest...GREAT!!! Served with the proper sweet wine... YUUUUUUUUUUUUUMMMMMM!!!

Remember to dress up a bit... it is kind of a formal place :)
author: Gianguido G.

description:
I've probably eaten here 6 times.  Wait staff is always top noch and the food is very good.

Always go with the steak, you won't be disappointed.

I've had one sub par dish here, it was the halibut.
author: John D.

description:
3.5 stars

I was born "thirty-something" years ago (well, now that and 6 days ago, to be accurate).  Last week, a slew of birthday dinners began.  

Birthday dinner #1 was with a bunch of friends who took me out to dinner.  My food friend, Mike, is someone who believes I do not eat anything but pricey food - which is so not true, and Boulevard became the venue.  

I had been hearing all week long, "YOU have not eaten at Boulevard?  How is that possible?  YOU?"

Yes, me.  In all of these years, I had never dined at this San Francisco icon of a restaurant.  As we discussed this - Rob reminded me that he did make reservations here last year for Valentine's Day, but then ended up taking me to Paris instead.  Yeah - no matter how nice a restaurant may be - Paris wins.

That said, I was excited to try Boulevard, and our party of 10 sat down at 8:30 PM, after a 30 minute Happy Hour across the street at Americano.

Photos uploaded.

First off - it was a very warm evening in San Francisco - - and the restaurant was downright HOT.  Being sensitive to temperature - I asked everyone at the table and all agreed, it was steaming hot in this restaurant.  The booth we were seated in was roomy and had a nice curved table and bench seat with huge chairs surrounding the table.  

Considering this dinner was being bought for me, and given what I had heard time and again regarding Boulevard's pricing, I brought two bottles of wine to save a bit on costs - one bottle of a great Chianti, and ol' faithful, a 2004 Joseph Phelps Cabernet.  Saving those for the entrees, we decided to order some bottles of white wine to begin the dinner - and perusing the menu, I noticed the wine prices were decent, as was the selection.

On the menu was a "fried abalone" appetizer, and I knew I'd be opting for that.  Others ordered salads, or scallops, mostly.  Mine was interesting - I have never seen it offered before, but the concept was more interesting than that taste.  The portion was ridiculously small, too.  The scallops were very good, but my take is that the only way to make scallops bad is to overcook them.  They were nicely done at Boulevard.

For the entree, I opted for the lamb - which was very flavorful, lacking any gaminess, and presented nicely.  Great choice - and several of us had picked this dish.   I did try everyone's else's entrees - including the halibut, filet mignon, and pork.  I was generally  unimpressed with all three - -  the halibut was plain as day, the filet mignon was boring and overcooked by about 45 seconds, and the pork was entirely too salty for my taste, though some disagreed.  They were all "pretty good" - but nothing stood out except the lamb.  This is where Boulevard lost the half-star in my book - - you can't be a four-star restaurant without impressive entrees.

The service was good, but nothing notable.  A restaurant of this caliber has to offer service at least this good - - but there was nothing personal, fun, or unique about it.  Everyone was polite, and our server made recommendations.  We never needed for wine or water refills either.  All in all - a strong 4 stars for the service.

We then opted to order desserts.
It's been a little over a week since I went to Boulevard, and the only dessert I can remember is the chocolate mousse my friend ordered.  That was not just delicious, it was heavenly.  Other than that dessert, the rest faded into the background, though the "Happy Birthday" candle and chocolate was appreciated.  The Cafe Americano I ordered was extremely tasty -  great coffee!

Now, having been to Boulevard, I can honestly say that this is a good expense account location.  The restaurant is large, with an excellent location that looks out at the Bay Bridge, that provides "pretty good" food with good service.  It makes my date list solely because the ambiance is nice and in spite of being large, it feels intimate.  That said - there was nothing "special" about Boulevard.  My tastebuds were ready and excited to get knocked out of this world for the evening, but that failed to happen.

To be clear, one friend of mine replied to the invite that was sent out with, "I hate this place but for Grace, I'll be there."  On the contrary, another friend who LOVES Boulevard, knowing I had been terribly sick all week long, wrote on the night before to the whole list, "Um... so Grace has been ill all week.  If she can't go tomorrow night, will the rest of us still be going to Boulevard?"  (Alright, we know why HE came....ha!)

I should note that despite what I am writing about the food, it is totally appreciated that my friends took me to dinner here.  I am truly glad I tried it, and had a wonderful time.  What they lacked in culinary delights, we made up for in good conversation, excellent wines and lots of laughter.

A good life begins with good friends.
And that, if nothing else, I seem to have.

Thanks, guys, for a great evening!  (sniffle sniffle)
author: Grace K.

description:
Boulevard was very good, just not great and not worth the price.

Food:  I started with the English pea soup with squash blossom.  The soup was flavorful and well-balanced, but darker in color and didn't quite have the fine texture as I enjoyed recently at another restaurant (name withheld!).  The squash blossom was deep fried and stuffed with ricotta = yummy.  For the main I had the pork chop:  a very thick cut cooked evenly and with a nice crisp on the outside.  Served with a tiny bit of polenta and some greens tossed to the side.  My partner started with the foie gras and had the California white sea bass -- both of which were very good but below knockouts.  For dessert we had the meyer lemon custard tart.  Very tangy with nice berries.  I quite enjoyed it.  Coffee was ok, nothing to write home about.  

Service:  Very attentive and a little general when it comes to recommendations.  I got generic answers when it came to wine and dessert recommendations.  Maybe the wait staff wants to remain neutral?  Guess that's ok.  

Ambiance & Decor:  Lively, with good attention to detail and "Pat Kuleto's timeless Belle Epoque" design.  A table for 2 will make it seem more like you're at a Paris streetcorner cafe than a 4-star restaurant.  

Overall:  An enjoyable experience all around, but not the best food or price in town when it comes to high-end restaurants.  I will come here again when I'm on an expense account!
author: Larry R.

description: Overpriced , bland/ average food- not worth $100/ person (w/ a glass of wine and dessert). Service is average
author: Romita J.

description:
This place is fantastic, the pork chop and the halibut  were out of this world.  The presentation is spot on and the service was above par.  Looking at the plates around us no one seemed to be anything but overly happy with their food.  I saw the filet mignon, the crab salad and the sea bass and I can't wait to go again.  This is a food lovers heaven.

The chef owner was nice enough to come to our table and ask us how everything was topped off out night.
author: Shirley W.

description: If Michelin was just about the service and decor, Boulevard deserves its star, easily. Unfortunately, that's not how it works. That is not to say the food does not taste good. It does, but it's no better than any of their Bib Gourmand restaurants, and for $80+/person, it should be more memorable. The fig prosciutto salad came with an extraordinary mascarpone crema and was the best thing we had, but the scallops, halibut and pork chop, while all perfectly cooked, were pedestrian. We wanted to end on a high note with dessert, but the sticky toffee was bland, not sticky and just had a few chunks of toffee, didn't even finish it. *Frowny face*
author: Snuffles B.

description:
I've been wanting to try Boulevard for quite some time- as the boyfriend has been here on more than one occasion for work functions. Thus, we made (and by we, I mean I) a reservation for last night to celebrate my 25th birthday. (Hey, I got what I wanted, and he didn't have to put the thought into deciding where to take me! It was a win-win situation!) 

Boulevard is lovely. Really and truly lovely. The decor and ambiance throws me back to "the old days." When men still wore suspenders, and ladies rocked the fancy, frilly hats. When sitting around the radio for the broadcast was a form of entertainment, and milk cost 25 cents a gallon. I almost felt like I stepped into an old-school news room meets hotel meets swanky speakeasy. Yes, dear Yelper, I challenge you to formulate that image in your head.  

Although our reservation wasn't until 6:30, we arrived at 6:05 and were promptly seated. Please note: We made this reservation AT LEAST 3 weeks in advance. This place books up fast! 

Our server was friendly, attentive, and oh-so-polite. Definitely some of the best service I have ever encountered! I'm not sure what his name was, but I was impressed!

We ordered:

Whiskey Smash (Can't comment on this- I'm not the whiskey drinker of the two of us!)

Lemon Drop (Probably one of the best Lemon Drops I've ever had. A perfect balance of sweet meets sour.)

Calamari (Prepared two ways, both fried and not- the top portion is stuffed with goodness- including shrimp and something spicy. The bottoms were like normal calamari. It was a good dish, but I'm not a huge Calamari fan to begin with.)

Swordfish (This was delectable! I had them cook it all the way through- I'm not a huge fan of raw. I finished my plate. I could have eaten the potato accompaniment, again, and again, and again.)

Squab (The boyfriend ordered this- and on the rarer side. I liked it, and the risotto, but was much happier with my own dish)

Peanut Butter & Chocolate Marquis (OH MY GOD. I could eat this a thousand times and never grow sick of it! It was absolutely incredible! Forget the  ice cream and fudgesicle accompaniment, and go STRAIGHT To the whipped peanut butter brownie with the hard chocolate shell. We seriously considered ordering another.)

Boulevard was an absolutely wonderful time, and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to anyone else!
author: Annalise F.

description: Went on a trip with my girlfriend awhile back (a few years if we are being honest) and Boulevard was our "big dinner" for the trip, and it did not disappoint!!! Great service, excellent food, and amazing atmosphere! The only small downside was the dessert we ordered (if I remember correctly it was some sort of "deconstructed strawberry shortcake"), it wasn't terrible but after the delicious appetizers and entrees it was a little lackluster. But overall a great experience
author: Austin P.

description:
Lucky enough to have our boss take our group here for lunch as a holiday treat!
Yay for corporate cards! Since we went during the holiday season, the entire dining area was so well decorated! I loved the holiday spirit the restaurant conveyed - it gave it a very homey feeling even though you were in an upper scale restaurant.

Appetizers:
* Ahi Tuna Tartare - served with crispy nori chips.
* Seared Sea Scallops
* Beef Carpaccio
* Anchovy/Heirloom Tomato mixed green salad

To feed all 11 of us, we ordered 2 of each appetizer. All were very good, especially the tuna tartare. The nori chips made all the difference in the world.

We each ordered the Soup of the Day, which happened to be a lobster bisque. The only comment I have is that I wish there were some pieces of lobster in it. However it was still rich and we were definitely given a good amount. 

For the entree, I ordered the wood oven roasted Kobe Bavette. What is a bavette, you may wonder - because I wondered the exact same thing. I asked our server and he described it so well that I just had to order it. Turned out to be sliced medallions of tender Kobe Beef. It cut like butter and melted in my mouth like butter. Absolutely delicious. 

For dessert, I ordered the chocolate Buche de Noel in celebration to the holiday. Very sweet, very rich, and very chocolatey. Everything I expected :)

Boulevard had great service and great food. Will definitely be back if I need to celebrate anything important!
author: Julia K.

description: The first time I went here was many years ago for a Birthday party. It was very loud and noisy and the service and food was spotty. Since then I have gone back a few times because friends invited me there for dinner. The experience was not much better. sigh..... Well, I have been asked to go back and I refused, because I think there are so many other places here that I know I would enjoy so much better.
author: JA M.

description: Spendy but you have to treat yourself once in a while, right?  I consider Blvd one of my oldest friends in SF because it opened up right about the time I got here and is still going strong!  Don't overthink it with a resv.  Walk in whenever the mood hits and grab a seat at the chef's counter where you can watch the ballet of all the various dishes be meticulously prepared and come out to the tables warm and perfect. And you might learn a thing or two too!
author: e w.

description:
There are very few restaurants or meals where every single dish was delicious, but Boulevard delivered on my most recent dinner for my birthday. My experience here has been one of the best dining experiences I have had to date. 
Boulevard's ambiance is seemingly on the more casual side for fine dining, as there was loud conversation as noise. 
The biggest downside was that our reservation was for 8pm, but we ended up having to wait until nearly 8:45. Despite that, service was great and once we sat down, the rest of the night went off without a hitch.
Again, everything we ordered from appetizer to dessert was amazing. However, of all the dishes we tried, my favorite by far was the Kurobata Rib Pork Chop. UGH, do not miss this. Perfectly cooked with even a small piece of smoked pork belly on top. I wondered if it was unclassy to pick up the rib bone to pick the meat off of it, but I did it anyway because the pork chop was THAT good. 
It's great to see a restaurant with women at the helm (the owner and chef de cuisine). I believe their Michelin Star is well-deserved. Boulevard is definitely one of the best meals I've had in the City, and I will be back!
author: Jen T.

description:
Was taken here by a vendor a few weeks ago, fantastic time. Started at the bar, enjoyed a few wonderfully made cocktails while we waited for our reservation time. I love the atmosphere in this place, it's bustling and energetic with a polished charm.

Wine selection was great, and the wait staff was very knowledgeable in helping us choose a good pairing. The oyster & abalone appetizers where amazing, and everyone enjoyed their main courses.

I always have coffee for desert, but everyone else enjoyed their desserts. We stayed for 3 hours, and never felt rushed. A fantastic evening out!
author: Eric V.

description:
Okay..so it's 2 years later, i'm 2 years older, my ex and I are no longer together (hence the ex status) but I wound up here again for my birthday.

my dear dear friend took me here for a belated birthday dinner. i am not spoiled - just well taken care of okay? 

Head Chef Nancy Oates? HATS OFF TO YOU HONEY. This restaurant does meat well, EXTREMELY well. I had the lamb rack and boy.. Upon my first bite, it was pure bliss! I could hear angels singing.. 
It was accompanied with Half Moon Bay brussel sprouts. I LOVE BRUSSEL SPROUTS!
leiflet had filet mignon, and it was quite good but I still think my lamb rack was better ;) 

the foie gras appetizer?! DELISH. you can't go wrong

Also, head pastry chef Jessica Sullivan? You have made me a believer in the power of pie. Your huckleberry pie w/ fleur del sel caramel ice cream... HEAVEN.
author: Susy C.

description:
I've been hangin' in SFa few days a week for over a month now on business, and The Boulevard's just become my favorite restaurant on this painfully extended trip.  

I knew I was in for a treat when the relatively simple salad made with arugula, candied walnuts, pink lady apple, blue cheese and endive totally hit it outta the park. Who'd a thought that a salad of greens and garnishes could be so good; so intensely flavored; so perfectly dressed. 

The American "Kobe" beef  (from a hybrid breed of Kobe and Angus) hangar steak served with fingerling potatos was amazingly tasty.  My lawyer (gee I hope she wasn't charging me for the time it took her to eat;), loved her duck lasagna and asparagus appetizer, served with a gently deep fried egg (never seen one of those before). 

No time for dessert, but gotta give it to them; one of the best lunches I've had in  a long long time.  Check them out for sure. The Boulevard's stylish and pricey, but if you wanna find a special place for an "important lunch meeting" you couldn't do better than there.
author: David M.

description: Nice restaurant with great food and atmosphere.  I'd eat here more often I lived in SF.  We had lunch and had a beef dish and the salmon.  Both entrees were very good.  Service was on point as well. I'd love to try this restaurant for dinner.
author: David M.

description: Solid, perhaps even very solid. But not spectacular. Everything we ate was good, but nothing was great. Our server was efficient and attentive but indifferent. It was still a positive experience, but with everything I had heard/been told/read about the place, I just expected more. When I see a Michelin star and numerous James Beard awards,I expect to be wowed. And in that context, our meal was kind of disappointing.
author: Doctor S.
Manda Bear B.

description:
My boyfriend took me here for a romantic "belated anniversary" dinner and we both had an amazing time! We had some sort of abalone/octopus appetizer which I was a bit skeptical to try (my boyfriend loves seafood) but in the end I was so happy we ordered it because it was delicious! I ordered the filet mignon (medium rare) and my boyfriend ordered the lamb t-bone (medium) and they were both perfect and paired perfectly with a bottle of red wine that was recommended by our waiter! My mouth is watering as I type this just thinking about it!! Aside from the delicious food, the service was fantastic as well. Very attentive, friendly, and helpful. We weren't on any type of time schedule so I honestly didn't notice if the service was quick, but I didn't care! 

It is pricey, but it's the city. If you have some $$$ to spend or want to celebrate a special occasion definitely come here! They will make your dining experience so special and one to remember! :)
author: Hannah K.

description:
Wow--the service is amazing.  I just wish I remembered our server's name for this review.  He was a perfect fit--not intrusive yet always there with a watchful eye.  

The food-- as noted so many times-- is really very good.  Love this restaurant!

The only thing that irked me a bit was when I questioned the color/taste of the wine we ordered.  It was a $68.00 half bottle of 1993 Calera Pinot Noir.
The cork broke off in the bottle not because of the corkage effort, but rather because the inside end just crumbled away with wine saturation.  I thought the color was off right away and the sommelier's advice was, "What do you expect?  It's a 17 year old wine".

He never came back to check on our table to see if the taste got any better after breathing for a while.
Our server came back and told us that every once in a while, he has seen people get a bad bottle of this wine.
We felt better for at least being checked on by our server.
author: Thomas D.

description:
Perfect place to celebrate an intimate or family occasion. Lovely and sophisticated decor-- love the mosaic marble details; beautiful platings, exceptionally-prepared dishes, excellent wine selection. Our waitstaff was attentive and our glasses were filled every time it was half full. 

I thought my food was good, but when I had to really pay attention to every detail and taste, it was a tad salty for me; however, I still enjoyed my experience there overall. Boulevard is a lovely place that I'd sure be happy to come back to.
author: Thea T.

description:
Boulevard is an excellent restaurant and the best meal we had on our trip. The gorgeous dining room was deservedly packed and we settled in at a cozy little table by the open kitchen. My ADD was in full effect as I took random glances at Pat Kuleto's impeccable design, Blvd's impressive menu, the bustling kitchen and the beautiful people of San Fran. Our waiter was great and his service for the evening was spot on. He also seemed completely sincere and grateful in accepting the praise of the delectable meal he laid before us. Our dining tour began with Dungeness Crab Salad with Ruby Red Grapefruit, Avocado, Belgian Endive, Kaffir Lime and Poppy Seed Vinaigrette and Italian Buffalo Mozzarella with Marinated Baby Artichokes, Crispy Truffled Fennel Shaved Black & White Truffles, and Wild Arugula. Both were delicious and nice starts to our meal. Every single ingredient was fresh and bursting with flavor. The truffles were amazing and we spent the rest of the meal passing forkfuls of tasty little bites to each other. Oh, you've got to try this!
