description: Food and service was great!  We were lucky to get a table by the window facing the bay where we got a great view of the Bay Bridge.  The soft shell crab appetizer special was amazing!
author: Randy F.

description:
Popped in for drinks and small plates the other night with a group of friends.  They lived up to their reputation.  This is a confidant restaurant that is very sure of its self and its vision.  Trendy but not pretentious; hip but comfortable;  knowledgeable but not snotty.  As this wasn't the first stop of our night, details of what exactly I ate and drank were washed away in the fantastic company and atmosphere of Boulevard.   There were sweetbreads and artichokes, and goat cheese, and salad, and pork belly.... An awesome place to hang with friends and eat and drink the night away.

4 stars for doing everything right, no 5th star because of the limited food and wine experience for the night (I am sure that a return visit for dinner would earn the 5th star)
author: Rich T.

description:
You can't go wrong by eating here.
The fresh local ingredients and cooked well.
Scallops, delicous.
Candied walnuts salad, very refreshing.
Pork chops are difficult to get right, and they hit the mark.
Sea bass was good with a nice crispy skin.
Macaroon dessert, I would order this again.
Mint ice cream cake, was so so.
Service was excellent.
author: Po L.

description:
Every time we go to SF, we dine at Boulevard. Every time, over the years, is worse and worse. Made a reservation days in advance, but had to wait. This happens EVERY SINGLE TIME. Of course you are "invited" to spend some money at the crowded, two row-deep bar. We said no. This did not please the snooty hostess, which then proceeded to ignore us. After seated the waiter was ok, but not, again, what we used to experience in other times. AND the food was definitely very low level. ALL dishes (3 people) were heavy, unremarkable and NOT AT ALL what you may expect from a restaurant that USED TO BE GOOD.
When you seat 180, things go bad quickly at the kitchen, and they just keep going on the past shine of a gone glory.
Bye-bye, Boulevard, you were a nice place years ago; too many good choices in SF to endure your now stale, ill-prepared food and hostesses' attitude.
author: Gabriel S.

description:
I expected and received EXCELLENCE here. This was one of my best restaurant experiences in San Francisco, which was great seeing as how I brought my parents when they were visiting!!

The food was stellar. I had the foie gras starter and then filet mignon as my main. Both were perfectly presented, seasoned and accompanied. Though I don't remember what my parents had, nobody was disappointed.

Our waiter was top notch and, along the the sommelier, provided good recommendations for all of us. We sat in one of the window-lined booths which was spacious and allowed us to experience the great vibe in the restaurant without being overwhelmed by noise. 

My wino/foodie father was impressed so that's as good as it gets, for sure!
author: Kelsey P.

description:
Great location, great service and pretty romantic atmosphere.

Started off with the foie gras (best starter we had), lobster w/egg and dungeoness crab salad. 

Had the duck over risotto which was so so... the mushrooms were definitely the best item on the plate. Also had the salmon, which was about as good as the duck.

Desert was a chocolate layered ice cream cake which was IMO forgettable.

+1 star for having Epoisses on the cheese menu!

Definitely a great place to go on a date. Worth the price? Probably would lean towards no.
author: Marty G.

description: I may be just starved for good food, having lived in Boston for too long. But this was one of the best meals I can recall eating. Usually, I get an entree, and feel bored after about five bites. At Boulevard, I cleared my plate before I even noticed I was eating. It was that good.
author: Morris R.

description:
Boulevard is located just off the Embarcadero only a few steps from the water. The Ferry Building as well as a few other great restaurants are nearby so parking in the area is nothing short of impossible. Thankfully I know my way around the Muni tracks so my friend and I only had to walk a couple blocks from the nearest stop. 

I'm from the Bay Area but I've lived in LA for a while now (same goes for my friend). We're used to sunny days all year so we're both extremely thin blooded. The short walk to Boulevard's entrance made us shiver and shake uncontrollably (it was about 50 degrees). Brrrr. After going through the revolving door we instantly warmed up due to the cozy atmosphere and obviously because the heat was on, thank god. We then began the timely task of peeling off our fifty million layers before we got heat stroke. 

We didn't have a reservation so we were given the choice between sitting at the chef's table or on the bar side. We chose the bar side which didn't have anything wrong with it. The only thing that separated us from the reserved tables was a waist-high wall. Who cares. We enjoyed our table. Plus we got to watch the bartenders furiously mix drinks and poor wines. Neat. 

We had reservations for an early dinner so we were planning on eating a light lunch. I asked our server what he would recommend and he said splitting a soup or salad and splitting an entree would be perfect for us. We ordered the Lobster bisque and the American Kobe beef burger (with heirloom tomato, house made bun, little gem lettuce, Cowgirl Creamery's wagon wheel cheese, and French fries) to split. The lobster bisque was extremely heavy so the small serving size was perfect. Also, dipping the table bread (San Francisco sourdough) in the soup was to die for. The burger was a smaller size too, but because it was Kobe beef it was very filling. The patty was mouthwateringly juicy. When I cut the burger in half the juices came out and soaked the bottom of the bun. Delicious, but gross. Gross because I absolutely hate getting my hands dirty. Even when eating a burger I usually only use my pointers and thumbs to hold it. Delicious because... well juicy burgers are just plain awesome. The fries were also great. The were crunchy on the outside with a warm, soft inside. The ketchup (which I'm guessing was made in house) complimented the fries perfectly. 

On the way out of the restaurant there's a perfect view of the Bay Bridge along with the Ferry Building and the piers. The Embarcadero is a nice walk, especially if you don't live in the city. Just be sure to bring plenty of layers and a couple hand warmers so you don't lose a finger to frost bite.
author: Kevin R.

description: I know it's on Embarcadero so it's one of those "expense account" restaurants for all the financial district businesses, but it seriously is an awesome restaurant. All the appetizers and entrees were perfectly cooked --- beef, lobster, fish. I had a vegetarian friend with me and they specially made appetizers and dishes for her to cater to her diet. Great service, food and ambiance = 5 stars!
author: Shivani S.

description:
Truly enjoyed our evening at Boulevard!  My husband and I were there for our anniversary and both had the Filet Mignon.  It was cooked perfectly and the flavor was exceptional.

The service was really, really great!  Our server was friendly and made us feel welcome.  The restaurant is beautiful and the ambiance was perfect.

Only one tiny complaint:  there was a VERY loud party going on and a few inebriated guests screeching kind of killed the atmosphere, but this is not the fault of the proprietors.
author: Laura C.

description: I have been dine at Boulevard in past 10+ years, never disappointed me for any occasion.  Love the food and service.
author: Lyn L.

description:
So couple nights ago I cruised down the Boulevard... and here's the summary:

Food: 4/5
Ambiance: 3/5
Service: 2/5

So the food was great. For appetizer, me and companion shared a foie gras and tuna tartare which were both excellent. Then main course, we had oven roasted lamb and pork both medium rare. I liked the pork better. Presentation is simple and pretty. 

Dessert was not impressive. The bon-bons are like ice cream lollipop dipped in chocolate. We also had the black forest cake and raspberry rhubarb. I found them either too sweet or too sour, there was a lack of balance in dessert plates. 

I think the dress code for this place is more like a business casual. It's like a place where you bring your guests for dinner after long day of work at financial district. Not the kind of place to bring date, I think. So you can expect something professionally prepared and flawless from Boulevard. But definitely not going to be a memorable night.

Service was the least impressive part.... enough said.
author: Marlis T.

description:
Yay birthday dinners!

Very slow start... took 45 minutes to get our appetizers. I was in great company though, so 3 rounds of Kir Royale's and I nearly forgot about the fact that  we had order copious amounts of food.  Our waitress was incredibly gracious amidst our starving pleas for food and discounted a hefty portion of our bill. Win!

Apps
Monterey Red Abalone - SO GOOD. we had to order since you don't really see abalone on menus that often. And the sauce with the fava beans was incredible!
Royal Sweet Scallops - YUM
Italian Burrata and Assorted Heirloom Tomato salad - the cheese was so creamy and the tomatoes were perfectly peppered. 

Mains
Pork Prime Rib chop
Filet Mignon 
-we are shameless carnivores. both were delicious.

Desserts
Strawberry Watermelon Ice Cream cake - we got this for the 'WTF is that' factor. unique flavors and texture. not a huge fruity dessert kinda gal, but i'm up for trying something new!
Chocolate Flourless cake - i mean, I basically drop my panties for anything involving chocolate (did i just reveal too much?). this did not disappoint.
Mint Chip ice cream bon bons - SO gourmet. These were not your ordinary Dreyers ice cream filled bon bons. 100% fresh mint sorbet surrounded by a decadent chocolate shell... I could eat a carton full.
author: Laura C.

description:
There are good reasons why we keep returning to Boulevard.  We are comfortable there and always pleased with the food.  It's beautiful and it's fun.

If the lamb burger is on the menu go for it.
author: Clarke H.

description:
I had high expectations, and Boulevard met them all.  Service was attentive, with the nice touches of black napkins to match dark clothing and clearing crumbs between courses, yet still personable and friendly.

Food offerings were creative, delicious, and presented nicely.  Minus one star for not having a standing vegetarian entree on the menu, but my "dietary constraint" was handled gracefully.  My salad was pleasant but not so memorable, but the ravioli with golden beets and goat cheese?  Divine.  Very nice dessert options -- we each had one and all but licked the plates clean.
author: Andi T.

description:
LOVED BOULEVARD!! The best meal I have ever had as a whole because I loved everything I ordered (when usually I feel part of the meal I love and other parts I think are just meeh). The tuna tartare was very tasty and a decent portion. The foie gras was AMAAZZINNGGG. Yes, that good. The filet was cooked to perfection, just the right amount of seasoning/sauce and just the right amount of rareness. For dessert I had the strawberry/watermelon ice cream cake. It sounds simple, but it wasn't. There were many layers to the cake, and I loved how all the flavors of the different layers tasted together. I left super happy, and ready to go back again. I'm already planning my next meal there! 

One thing to watch out for - if your server asks you if you want a bottle of water, they mean the fancy bottled water that will cost you $8 a bottle, not that they will bring you a bottle with water in it. We had just sat down when she asked us and we didn't think about it til it was too late. We felt a little tricked, but admitedly it was our fault we should have said we wanted tap water. I guess fancy water with a fancy meal is fitting anyways, maybe it made our meal a better experience overall.
author: Julie Y.

description:
My wife and I went to Boulevard last night, loved it!  It took a while to park the car, we had to call the restaurant to find out that the valet is actually on Stuert.  Keep that in mind if you're driving there.

We ate at Fleur de Lys last week so it was nice to have good food that didn't break the bank.  Boulevard proves that you can have a nice filling meal that tastes great without being too chi-chi.  It's a bit dressy, but I didn't have to wear a jacket.

The food, oh the food,

Apps:  The wife ordered the calamari stuffed with rock shrimp, servered with fingerling potatoes and chorizo.  I had the dungeness crab salad with avocado and blood oranges.  The apps arrived very quickly, 5-10 minutes after we ordered, which was nice since I was starving.  Both dishes were delicious.  Be warned, the appetizers are big, the neighboring table ordered lobster ravioli and got 4 huge lobster filled pasta pockets.

Mains:  Sea bass with chanterelle mushrooms and mashed potatoes for the wife, pork chop with potatoes and swiss chard for me.  I preferred the pork, it was sweet and a little tangy.  Each thing on my plate tasted so great that I ate them individually, I didn't want to mix the flavors.  The sea bass was good too, but the pork....

Dessert:  By now I'm completely stuffed, ready to skip dessert.  The server brought dessert menus and in a moment that can only be described as pure gluttony we ordered the greek yogurt cheesecake.  It came with a gingerbread ice cream sandwich.  Tasted as good as it looked.  

I will return to Boulevard, but for now I'm off to the gym for 3 hours to work off dessert.
author: Shen J.

description: Went to Boulevard with a friend for lunch.   Have not been here in a decade and yet the food is just as good as when I left.   It's  superb.   Especially the lobster bisque, scallops and Kobe burger.
author: Stevie A.

description: This place was great. We came for my mom's birthday and it was the perfect amount of fancy, but still laid back and fun. My filet minon was really delicious, though my mom and husband noticed that theirs were overcooked. I wasn't too impressed with the drinks or the menu, since choices were pretty limited, but overall I loved the experience and will probably come back one day.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
Still not feeling it. 

Service and presentation are both good. However dishes don't seem to have that wow factor of other top venues. For me it all comes down to the music that the flavors play: do they sound alone or (more thrillingly) do they create a symphony. My last experience was more of the solo variety, not bad but not magical. 

I did appreciate their ability to accommodate us without a reservation, though this was a combination of luck and late dining (9pm-ish), you should seek out reservations here it's typically booked up. 

The dining room is attractive, not trendy but not quite Grandma either. It's a more formal atmosphere than typical, but I take back my stuffy comment. Diners do tend to be mid 30s and up, similar crowd to Myth, Spruce, etc.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Great - went here for my birthday dinner and it was much more modern (dishes were much more eclectic than I had thought they'd be) and of course, delicious. Great service, wonderful experience.
author: Victoria K.

description:
The Dish: We ate here for our anniversary dinner. We ordered the local calamari stuffed with lobster for appetizer. It's absolutely delicious, and though we were hesitant at first to order a dish we could get at any other restaurant, it was the best decision. It's grilled instead of fried and all the flavors combined was just perfect. For entrees, I had the Pacific Swordfish and he ordered the Alaskan Halibut. I'd strongly recommend you to order seafood at Boulevard - they make some damn good seafood. I actually liked the Halibut a lot better (we traded mid-meal) because it melts in your mouth and is grilled perfectly. The Pacific Swordfish comes with potatoes & dip, which was incredible. The Swordfish, according to my boyfriend, was really good as well. I think it just didn't suit me. We finished off the dinner with chocolate brulee and white-peach sorbet, both of which were good. Typically not a chocolate lover, I still ate a good portion of the 3 mini brulees. 

Ambiance: The service honestly was a bit slow. We had a dessert menu for a good 15 minutes even though we decided after 2. Though slow on the service side, the food makes up for it. Amazing place and experience for an anniversary dinner!
author: Gina T.

description: Sheena wasn't a punk rocker, but she definitely rocks.  The recommendation on the pork chop was legit.  Wouldn't have thought the risotto would have gone together so well.  Great food, great service, chill people. Everything I love about good restaurants in the City.  Was as good or better than I remember. Bummed it has taken so long to make it back.
author: Anthony D.

description:
Man, I've been waiting to come here forever now. Finally got to come here for dinner.  This place was packed... even at 9!! Hostess was extremely nice and let us know that our table will be ready in a couple minutes... even though it's more like 15-20, it was OK cuz I got to see what everyone was having.. and you know if you want good things, you gotta be patient and wait.. Finally got out table near the back where you could see the Bay Bridge.. Awesome view..

We started with:
*Ahi Tuna Tartare: Wasabi Tobiko, Miso Mayo, Cocktail Grapefruit with Lotus Root Chips and Crispy Nori ($17)
   There were three small portion squares with all three toppings on each one. My favorite? the Miso Mayo.. Not a strong miso smell/flavor but enough to taste it.. If you could get the whole thing to yourself, I highly suggest you do.. 
*Local Calamari Stuffed with Crab ($16.50)
  It came with a little side of fried stuff but wasn't sure what,, I know there were fries rosemary and I was hesitating if I should eat that but I did and it was really good.. Th calamari stuffed with crab was awesome.. No skimping on crab. I only wished that there were more then two so instead of getting one small bite, we get one whole thing for $16.50..

For my entree, I had the Angus Filet Mignon ($39.75)
  It was served with sauteed spinach, crispy fingerling potatoes, and red wine beef jus. The steak itself was a little more cooked then I wanted it to be so it was a little too dry. I mostly fed my BF the meet so I filled up more on the spinach and potatoes.. 

Dessert time is here!
*Almond Butter Cake: Extra Dark "Hot Cocoa" Ice Cream with House made Toasted Marshmallow Marcona Almond Araguani Chocolates
Blood Orange Sorbet ($10.75) 
  Great plating! It looked good even when I didn't take a bite of it yet. The almond cake was moist and had a good almond flavor. I loved the marshmallow. Makes me want to make some myself right now, The extra dark "Hot Cocoa" ice cream was too dark. Flavor wise.. I'm not a big fan of dark chocolate.. 
*Sticky Toffee Pudding with a Caramel Custard Top
  Earl Grey Tea Ice CreamCandied Kumquats, Almond Biscotti ($10.75)
  Almond biscotti was DELICIOUS.. Probably one of the best I've tried so far.. I liked this dessert more the the Almond cake one.. The taste was just better.. Caramel Custard top was smooth and creamy... 
*Fleur de Sel Caramel Bon Bon ($3.50)
  I should of saved the $3.50 cuz I could of made it myself. =)

The bill was expensive! 3 shots of Remy was fucken $67!!!!! My fucken goodness, I could of just bought a bottle for myself! With tips, it came to about $102 each! The portions are definitely on the small side and expensive! Thanks to my future brother in law, I didn't have to pay.. =) I love him..!
author: Juliane N.

description: Frankly, I don't know why anyone would waste $400 per person at the "French Laundry."
author: Anthony W.

description:
So with the Michelin guide coming out this last Tuesday, I decided that I was going to eat at every Michelin starred restaurant in California to see if Michelin actually knows what they are talking about.  My first restaurant to review is Boulevard.

It's funny because most dining experiences for me come on a whim.  We were in the city, watching the world series, my friend had just been jumped by scalpers and we were in desperate need for some truly delicious food.  We got there at 9:00 o'clock and Boulevard was completely full, which is to be expected.  We sat in the bar until 9:30 (our reservation was at 9:15, no big deal) and were escorted to the table.  One of the first things that I noticed about this place was that some of the hostesses never smile.  The wait staff was very pleasant but there was something completely off-putting about the hostesses.  

We decided on on doing 5 course, gluttonous to say the very least, but we hadn't eaten all day and we're starving.  The food here is classic Michelin star food, if that makes any sense.   There are no frills, no attempts to exceed what have been doing for years, and I guess that's OK with me.  There's something to be said about maximizing your strengths, over coming your weaknesses and producing good, but not great food. Let's do a breakdown of what I had.

Heirloom salad with mozzarella: Sadly, one of the best, if the not best dish of the evening.  Seasoned to perfection, there's something truly magical about the acidity of tomatoes and how it interacts with mozzarella.

Abalone: Proclaimed to be one of the signature dishes.  Was just OK for me.  The accoutrement's were too plentiful and overshadowed the beautifully cooked Abalone.  There was a tangy flavor to the dish which was slightly odd, and it lacked a distinct bite (acid) which was needed to make this dish memorable.

Dungeoness Crab Salad: - Nothing special, again lacked acid.

Potato Gnocchi and Lobster:  The lobster was fantastic, cooked beautifully, the gnocchi was masterfully prepared, soft and delicate. The tomato on the dish, to me wasn't needed.  This dish really hit the spot and whoever cooked it probably deserves a raise

Polenta, White Truffle, Slow Cooked Egg:  I wanted this dish to be amazing, it was just OK  for me.  The temperature was off, it was luke warm which is a HUGE problem.  The texture of the polenta lacked viscosity, and when served with the slow cooked egg, it made it mushy as if I was supposed to drink it with a straw.  The white truffles were fragrant, fresh, and are always reliable.  

Alaskan Halibut with Squash Risotto:  The risotto, unlike the polenta was cooked beautifully, was seasoned very well and complemented the tempura squash blossom exceptionally.  The halibut was a little overcooked, but it was still, in my opinion delicious.

Lamb with potatoes:  The lamb was the shining star on the menu.  I hate lamb, I really do, but they cooked it perfectly.  It had tremendous flavor and showed some beautiful skill.  The potatoes were definitely inconsistent.  There were three fingerling potatoes on the dish, all three had different flavors and were cooked unevenly.  It was very strange.

Bon-Bons with Banana Ice Cream and Butterscotch: I am not a dessert person.  It was OK.  Nothing special.

Overall the service was solid, they described the menu well.  They marked the tables.  They did clear plates while people were sill eating, which I thought was really odd and a faux pas to say the very least.  I kind of got the feeling that if I were there at 7pm instead of 9:30pm the quality of the food would have been better.  You know they always say, "FINISH STRONG" and that truly describes what did not happen here at Boulevard.

Party of 2 = $500 with tip.

Michelin Star deserved: YES

I guess the guide got it right on this one..One down 43 to go...
author: Shaun C.

description: Good Food but a bit pricey. The good was pretty good, but I could have gone elsewhere for a similar but cheaper meal. The place is really nice though. The service was great. Our waiter checked on us several times and was very polite.
author: Kevin K.

description: I was taken to Boulevard for our anniversary and our experience was unforgettable. We both ordered the filet mignon and it was absolutely incredible. We both ordered them to be prepared medium. Mine did come out a bit overdone and Jeff our server was quick and happy to take both of our plates back so we could enjoy our meals together. My boyfriend was already halfway done with his filet and Jeff brought us both back BRAND NEW FILETS to make up for their error. Talk about amazing service. Everything was unforgettable. Definitely one of the BEST filet mignons I have ever had in my whole 27 years on this earth. The service was on point. Jeff our server was very helpful with the menu and happy to make sure we were taken care of. And to top it off when we ordered our dessert, they brought us out a second surprise dessert plate. Everything was amazing. I will definitely be back to Boulevard!
author: Lindsey N.

description:
I forgot this on my previous review when I wrote about our un-enjoyable experience at Boulevard.  The restaurant brought a dessert for my mom whose birthday we were celebrating, which was nice.  However, they then charged us for the dessert which was tacky - and it wasn't even a dessert we would have chosen!

Pass on Boulevard.
author: Josephina F.

description:
After arriving early for our Open Table reservation, we were promptly seated in the middle of the restaurant, alongside the open kitchen.  It's a little noisy but in the pleasant sense of an efficient operation.  It's a great location near the ferry building and convenient to Muni.  

Service was outstanding throughout. Our server Janelle was very attentive; her timing was perfect in taking orders and clearing the table.

We very much enjoyed our meal and are ready for another visit.  We started with glasses of Prosecco to go with a shared starter of ahi tuna.  For mains I had the roasted lamb with stuffed squash blossoms, prepared medium rare, with a glass of zinfandel.  My wife had the Alaskan halibut served with fingerling potatoes, green beans, garlic and lemon aioli, along with a glass of pinot gris.  For dessert we shared the butterscotch pudding with pecan shortbread strips, pecan granola and chocolate Bavarian cream.
author: David E.

description:
Nice restaurant.  Very lively, friendly service, and good food but not great food.  I had some high hopes for my first meal at this restaurant.  It fell a bit short of my expectations.  3.5 stars.

We started out with the appetizer special, a risotto with burrata cheese and a generous amount of white truffles shaved on top.  This dish was quite good and very flavorful.  Our other appetizer was the day boat scallops with roasted cauliflower which was a colorfully presented dish with great quality scallops and vegetables used in the dish.  My entree was the pork prime rib chop topped with pomegranate seeds, super thinly sliced grapes, diced celery and with a side of a sweet apple-like sauce and a side of perfectly roasted and seasoned fingerling potatoes -- it was good.  I also had a healthy portion of the sea bass entree that sat on a bed of shaved brussel sprouts and shallots -- this entree was probably a little better than the one I ordered.  For desserts it was the alpaco chocolate cake and the key lime pie with strawberry sorbet and margarita granita (tangy and salty margarita flavored crushed ice) and topped with fresh strawberries.  The desserts were pretty good overall, not especially sweet and not exactly satisfying that sweet tooth hankering I had after my meal.

Fresh ingredients and good food, but not very imaginative dishes and nothing that would have broadened the horizons of your palate.  I suppose I just expected more from a restaurant that is one of the most popular in SF and has kept its Michelin star for a number of years.  I've been to a number of Michelin starred restaurants in the Bay Area, across the U.S., and even foreign countries and the food here just didn't match up.
author: Erich D.

description: Boulevard is definitely one of my FAVORITE restaurants!! The servers were very friendly, accommodating, and helpful. My hubby and I dined here over the weekend for my birthday. It was my first time at this establishment. Our waiter was super friendly and recommended the pork chop dish, scallops, pasta with truffle oil. All the dishes were cooked to perfection!! He also suggested the ice box cake. I was a little hesitant at first because he mentioned the cake has bananas. I am not a fan of bananas; however, the dessert was definitely a nice, sweet surprise. I loved it and they even decorated it with a happy birthday sign and candle! I will definite come back!
author: Alyssa B.

description:
have you ever eaten dinner seated at a table perched on the median of a busy street? well i have. more on this in a second...

we arrived on time for a 6:30 reservation on a tuesday night. the restaurant was about  80% full and we were seated right away. we were lead to a table that was located opposite the kitchen. to help you visualize the location: there is an open kitchen, a counter for diners facing the kitchen, a lane for traffic, a railing, our table, another lane for traffic and finally, tables lining a wall. so all night servers and customers were zooming by on our right, on our left, on our left and right... add to that the loud din coming from the kitchen making having a conversation impossible: AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

i could see seating someone at this table that was a walk-in but i had made my reservation a month in advance. i could also see that there were other two tops available. bad form boulevard. if they try seating you here: refuse. i'll walk out next time.

as for the food, i had:

ravioli di mare- the trick to making the cappelletti is to cook the pasta consistently because of the varying thicknesses. unfortunately the pasta wasn't cooked through where it was folded over so it was underdone. the sauce was ok. when the server put the dish down, he warned that the plate was hot and it was. i love that. when your food is served right away from the kitchen, still alive and vibrant.

alaskan halibut- slightly overcooked and needing some salt. this time when the server presented the plate he still held it with a towel implying it was hot but when i checked, it was not. all the items were tepid, as was my wife's pork chop. the spinach was good.

soft french meringue- totally forgettable. save the calories. with dessert i had the "jack rose" cocktail. what intrigued me was that it was made with house-made grenadine. the cocktail was over-the-top sweet, like a shirley temple.

we did a byob for the wine, a '11 williams-selyem "terra de promissio". w-s is one of my favorite producers. bob cabral is a master winemaker. to have so many single vineyard offerings, each unique and different, is quite an accomplishment. '11 was the first time that w-s sourced terra de promissio fruit and i'm sure it won't be the last. the wine was incredibly fragrant, balanced with a long finish. terra de promissio is located in the petaluma gap, not that far from the city. it's the home of some incredible vineyards. if you want to give a p-gap pinot a try, check out clary ranch's website. corkage was $30.

service was the absolute minimum to get us through the meal. order, bring food to the table, "how is everything?", check. 

now for the ambiance. the customers are a mix of business types, tourists and locals. attire ranges from sharp to people who looked like they just got done mowing their lawn. there were two guys sitting at the end of the kitchen counter wearing white tee shirts with corporate "advertising". the one with his back to me was in my line of sight every time i looked over my wife's left shoulder. so all night long i read "what do you know about your competition?" over and over. kind of how you re-read a ketchup bottle label when you're at a diner. at least the tee shirts looked pretty clean.

rather than leaving with a memorable experience i left, i don't know, kind of, sort of, let me think, angry. i've been to boulevard before so i know what they're capable of, hence the three stars.
author: Sanil S.

description:
Went to Boulevard on a lark to take my niece out to dinner while she visits SF for a convention.

Pro:  The place is wonderful and the atmosphere is awesome.  Worked well for a bigger party, but also is great for two people.  Has a nice view if you sit by the windows at the end of the room.  Food was excellent, service was very nice, and for the most part properly timed.

Con:  A bit $$$, and the service started to falter towards the end.  Coffee did not come out with dessert.  Not much offered if you have a teen or pre-teen with you (although they did a good job coming up with something that worked).  Best bet is leave kids at home if you can. :)
author: Jim M.

description:
I ate here for my Dad's 70th birthday and I must say this was one of the best meals of my life!  The menu is filled with so many yummy choices.  I'm a person that likes to order steak wherever I go so that I can compare, but our knowledgeable waiter talked me out of it and I ended up ordering a salmon dish.  It....was....divine!  The food is super rich and top notch.  Presentation is fantastic, especially with the appetizers.  The service was a tad slow, but the food definitely made up for it.  if you have the chance to eat here I say run, don't walk to Boulevard!

There is valet parking for $10.  I wish I'd known this before I spent 15 minutes driving around for a spot and settling in the Rincon garage for $8...then I had to move my car out of the garage mid-meal because it closes at 11pm!
author: Sonya T.

description:
***Good***
Amazing food. Great Service. Good wine list. 

***Bad***
Portions are a little small. Pricey, but is to be expected given the quality. 

***Recommendation***
Burger. Sounds lame, but its amazing.
author: Nick K.

description:
I was taken here by a colleague today for lunch to celebrate the end of a very insane project. The food and service were both fantastic!

For starters I got the ahi tartare and my coworker got the crab cake. The crab cake was good (no filler!) but nothing extra ordinary. The ahi, though, was excellent quality and had an excellent flavor. And the nori "chips" that came with it? So inventive! I had high expectations for my main dish and it didn't disappoint. My main course was the  Waku with Italian butter beans. It was fantastic. Perfectly cooked and seasoned.

The service was great as well. That's an area in which I usually have complaints and here I had none. The service was attentive but not overly so, friendly without seeming too casual, and gracious and classy without seeming snooty.

There's a reason this place has enjoyed success in SF for 15+ years! Will definitely be going back.
author: Sydney L.

description:
.My girlriend and I 

ate here before the Billy Joel Concert. Food was great. Would have liked a bigger portion of the appetizer, but still was yummy. Our was was great. We told him we were attending the concert so he made sure our order was process quickly. Had the lamb. Good portion size. My girl had filet mignon. Perfectly prepared. We arrived 30 mins before our reservation. They sat us 20 minutes before our 6:00 reservation. We want to go back so we can sit at the counter so we can watch them prpare the food.  It was a terrific night in the city.
author: Ronald M.

description: Waiting 25 minutes for a 9pm reservations, after a long day at work and on my birthday... Yes totally ki$$ my @$$
author: Steph Q.

description: Beautiful location and a great place for a special occasion. Highly recommend the pork chops which is the speciality dish. Service very good and made a special night unforgettable.
author: Sunny G.

description:
I've been here too many time to count and each time its a treat.  

The service is great.  They have a great selection of wines.  The food is always prepared right and in the right portion. 

Nothing bad i can say about this place other than the fact that you have to go out of the restaurant and take the elevator down to use the restroom.
author: Steve N.

description:
Boulevard's food will surprise you by barely reaching the state of mediocre, usually evident in every restaurant resting on its laurels and focusing on volume, revenue per table, and margin controls instead of creating customers who return for a culinary experience again and again. 

My wife and I came for lunch.  Potato gnocchi appetizer would be rejected by even the biggest fans of anything cream-based.  All flavors were overwhelmed by cream.  Even trumpet mushrooms could not make their rightful contribution to the flavor of this dish.   

Ahi tuna was slightly overcooked and had too much salt.  

Bread was served cold and developed a soggy texture despite being delivered in the morning.  A few minutes in the oven would be a nice touch before bringing the bread to dining customers. 

Unlikely to return.
author: Leon K.

description:
Man, I want to give Boulevard 5 stars. I really, really want to. But it just doesn't deserve it. At this price and at this rating, you really have to own at your game, and Boulevard doesn't.

I know part of it is luck and timing, and I certainly don't seem to have either of those. The food has always been impeccable, which is what is earning this place its 3 stars and no less from me (but really deserves 5). But the service on the other hand, something that you expect to get at this high price point, is quite lackluster.

I have been here several times, and each time some serious problem will happen. I keep going back due to such favorable reviews from Yelp and close friends, hoping that management has nicked the problems in the butt, but alas, no shift.

Let me give you an example. I will preface this to say that we know quite a bit about wine. We have had wine from all price ranges, and we go to wineries several times a month and wine bars all the time. I'm savvy to the attributes used to describe wine, and while I'm super adventurous and will try anything, I also know what I like and I can describe it well.

This one time we sat in the bar area for a dinner since we had no reservations (no prob, this place is hot, I don't mind at all), and our waitress was excited that we wanted to order a bottle of wine and there was only 2 of us (it was a date night on the weekend). We were unfamiliar with some areas of the wine menu, and since there was no sommelier in sight, she offered us some of her own suggestions. Fantastic! I love hearing what people at an establishment like. She said "I don't know if you like barnyard, but this has a hint of it." Having had wines that tasted of a farm before, we were adventurous and willing to try it. She said over and over and over again (almost in an annoying way too) that if we didn't like it, there would be no harm done and she'd take the bottle back.

HOLY BAT SHIT BATMAN! Did they let the cow drop his turds in with the grapes during crush? Did they use a special dung yeast during fermentation? This thing was like drinking filtered and pasteurized goat poop. I'm not exaggerating one bit.

Thus, we returned the only bottle we've ever returned in our lives, and profusely apologized for doing so as we were embarrassed that it was so bad that we actually had to return it. The waitress looked shocked, as if we committed a crime in their establishment, and even though she was the one who kept pushing that we could return it, she seem flustered and bothered that we actually took her up on it.

The remainder of the night was quite ruined. We hadn't even received appetizers, dinner, or desert yet, but as they came out one by one, everyone began to treat us unkindly. No one was more rude than our waitress though, as it was made incredibly clear that we were making her night uncomfortable. Maybe she had to pay for the bottle out of her tips, but that seems unlikely, and frankly far from our fault.

I will not give up entirely, as I'll eventually succumb to social pressures to revisit, but it won't be without hesitation and a bit of residual anger due to how we were treated.
author: Kevin E.

description:
Really good wine list, really good food, really great service.

Food portions are kind of small, but very, very good. Had a wonderful time here. Though I'd say dessert isn't worth the extra calories. 

I had the tuna tartar and the filet. The filet was a good size, but my dining companions had fish which were on the smaller side, and another friend had the pork loin which was pretty good and pretty decent size.

The tuna was fresh, good, but not the best I've ever had. Could have used a little more kick. My filet was a wonderful piece of meat, but a little cool. I know I ordered medium rare so I expected the center to be cool, but the outside wasn't even warm/hot. What was hot was my plate, because it had been sitting under a heat lamp.

Over all I had a good experience and the Tattinger was delicious. Forgo dessert, drink more champagne.
author: christine c.

description:
It seems that high end restaurants fall into one of two categories--unbearably pretentious, or, so comfortable in their own skin that they lack any sign of pretentiousness. I love that Boulevard seems to be in the latter category.

I went here for lunch yesterday and had their roast chicken dish. Succulent, yet crispy, the chicken was tasty and substantial, and the spaetzle, mushrooms, and sauce all combined perfectly. I had a less than stellar smoked duck salad as well, but I'm not going to ding them for duck given that I'm not a huge fan of duck to begin with. The ambiance is lovely, and the service excellent.
author: Darjeeling T.

description:
Best restaurant in San Francisco? Psssshaw. It seems to win that award a lot, but I don't see why.

Granted I only went here once, but the food was totally unmemorable. I got a dish that I thought was going to be a chicken breast, but the menu was unclear and it was chicken salad.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
One of the best dining experiences one will ever had...enough said; go and try it.

The dungeness crab salad was on the salty side, but I was able to put up with that.  My lamb t-bone was excellently done; rare on the inside and crusty on the outside.  For dessert, I just had to go over the edge and get the triple goat cheese cream pie, accompanied by a scoop of strawberry ice cream - now what a combination!!??

Take your expense account dinner here for an unforgettable meal.
author: Ron L.

description:
Typically, I am underwhelmed when going to these higher priced, highly rated restaurants. It seems my taste buds can't help convince my brains that paying $80/head for a good meal (sans alcohol) is a good value. Boulevard easily broke this convention. From the inventive appetizer salad of roasted beets and figs paired nicely with a spicy arugula to the perfectly cooked halibut steak with asparagus as thick as your thumb to the silky blackberry ice cream, everything was meticulously plated and prepared. 

Boulevard also emanated the vibe of a great happy hour or after hours restaurant -- lots of energy and bustle. Not the stuffy, harp-playing (no offense to harp players or their fans) that you usually get in nicer restaurants.

Plus, the location is just off the Embarcadero, so it's easy to get to and located conveniently for anyone who would like to walk-off their meal before retiring for the night.
author: Randy M.

description:
Freaking delicious here.

At first i was turned off about the menu because there was no veggie option but they have a veggie option available but just not on the menu.

I am glad i stayed to eat at the place because the meal was delicious. All the desserts looked amazing too so we ordered 4-5 of them. I cant say enough good things about them. 

The flavors and service were extraordinary. 
My friend from out of town was thoroughly impressed.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
We flew into SF for a weekend wedding and decided to try Boulevard who was nominated for the 2011 James Beard outstanding restaurant.  

Service was good.  Food was just okay.  Decor was nice and comfy.  We ordered the ravalini and seafood salad for appetizers.  The ravalini was amazing.  The ravalini had great flavor without being too over powering with the bits of bacon and mushroom on the side. I would highly recommend this dish to others.  The seafood salad was good nothing really memorable.

We ordered the filet mignon and the pork prime rib for our entrees.  The pork prime rib chop was very good.  It was very flavorful and juicy from the pork jus. I liked the potatoes with the potato chip flakes over the German potatoes.  We asked for the filet to be cooked medium and was  well done.  The filet was bland and we weren't happy since they overcooked the filet.  They did give us another properly cooked filet.

At the end of the day when we got our bill nothing was done for us for the mistake.  We are not asking for the filet to be comped but at least do something to make us happy like comping the dessert or a small discount.  We shouldn't have to request this.  I truly believe what makes a okay/good restaurant from a great restaurant  are the little things that are done beyond just great food and great service.  The meal did not have a wow factor.  I wouldn't come back here.
author: Kenway N.

description:
The boyfriend and I came on a recommendation that Boulevard was the *must visit* place in San Fran. We enjoyed our meal, but probably wouldn't come back. 

We had to wait in the bar for about 10 minutes before our table was ready, which was fine (especially as we had been a few minutes late for our reservation) and it gave us a chance to grab a drink while we waited. The bartender was friendly, and drinks were well-made and quasi-reasonably priced (around $10 for a vodka soda). 

I ordered a fish entree (listed on the online menu as the California swordfish, although they actually served it with a different fish the night we visited). The fish and the accompaniments were flavorful, but there was nothing particularly interesting or surprising about the meal.  The boyfriend had the duck, which was good but not as tender as we had hoped. At dessert, the chocolate bon bon stood out for its taste and presentation. The wine list was comprehensive, but the wines tended to be priced in accordance with the rest of Boulevard's menu (read: a little too expensive).

In the end, we left feeling like we'd had a nice meal, but not as delicious, memorable, or interesting as we had hoped. If I were to do it again, I'd pick somewhere known for its food, not for its fame.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Okay, there are a lot of over-hyped places in San Francisco but from the opening salvo Boulevard brought the goods. The service throughout the meal was attentive and thoughtful and perfect, the glasses were kept full, and when our entrees were a bit late, we were constantly updated. (We were dining at the busiest evening hour). Top-notch and plentiful crew. 

We had an appetizer that was the most expensive one I have ever purchased besides seafood (I think) at around $17, a mushroom ricotta cheese combo. It was absolutely some of the best stuff I have ever tasted. A wonderful starter. Small, just enough for two people to get one of everything, but really something special. (It was actually a special for the evening.)

We ordered the duck and lamb, both were cooked perfectly, plated perfectly, and matched with just the right sauces and sides. Along with a great wine pairing suggestion, the meal was one of the best I have ever had. 

I took my date there for her birthday, and she felt the same way about Boulevard. 

Worth every star.
author: Jj S.

description:
So maybe a $50 lunch isn't normally justified but isn't that the beauty of business dining? This place is pricey but worth it. And i've been told dinner is even better. If only I could afford to eat here more often.
I had the kobe beef and what really rocked my socks off was the little shortrib on the side. It sent me into a shortrib ordering spree that sadly, ended because nowhere else could I find such amazing short ribs. My friend had his favorite, the roasted chicken. My appetizer was not as memorable but the ginger cake I had for dessert was freaking good. 

The service was a little snooty but attentive. It's definitely a top choice for power dining.
author: Lainy C.

description:
A fantastic dinner. 
The atmosphere and ambiance were great and the restaurant's physical plant itself is neat, complete with a peacock mosaic on the floor when you walk in. Our party of three were seated in the back corner, along the windows looking out onto the Embarcadero; whether it was because we were dressed nicely (shirts and dark slacks) or whether that was the only table open, I can't say.
We started with a cocktail - I had the cucumber gimlet, which was amazingly refreshing and very tasty. The vodka martinis ordered by the rest of my party were apparently also good.

The menu appears to change every night and there are no specials, so what I ordered may not be on the menu, but to start I had the sweet sea scallops, which were fabulous. They were topped with jalapeno or some sort of spicy pepper and the dish was great - the scallops were perfectly cooked, not over or underdone. I cannot remember what my fellow diners had, but they were pleased. We paired our first course with a very nice gruner veltliner - the sommelier was very knowledgeable and pleasant.

For my main course I had the filet mignon, cooked perfectly to medium rare, exactly what I was looking for. Our entrees were paired with an outstanding Turley zinfandel.

I finally ended the night by ordering a single malted dulce de leche ice cream bon bon. If you're interested in something sweet to end the night, but don't want a huge dessert, I would highly recommend it.
And the final order was a 20 year-old armagnac, which, along with everything else that evening, was great.

Lastly, service was terrific. Our server was very attentive without being pushy, knew the menu inside and out, and, to my delightful surprise, dishes were not cleared until all the parties at the table had finished their plates (which is rare to find these days).
author: Bryce K.

description:
Looking for a place to take you date? Then look no further.

The ambiance, crowd and service were top notch.

We had reservations but were told it would take about 10 minutes before we were seated. I actually didn't mind because it gave us time to go to the bar, grab a drink and relax a bit. Once our table was ready our server gathered our drinks and placed them on a tray as she lead us to our table.

The filet mingon, halibut and t-bone lamb are good choices. For dessert we had a port wine and a chocolate mousse cake.

The place was crowded and everyone was chatting it up but despite that you can still have a sense of intimacy at your table.

Aside from the food, service and ambiance of the place what got me was the bathrooms (yes, the bathrooms). It's located on the lower level of the restaurant, but to even get there you have to enter a door covered by red velvet curtains. Once you get there you can either take the stairs or ride the elevator to get to the bathrooms.

My suggestion? If you and your date/friend(s) are up for it get dropped off, take the BART or leave your car along Pier 39 and walk to Boulevard (or closer if heels are involved). It'll build up your appetite and give you a chance to talk it up before the big meal. Afterwards you can walk off all you've ate and drank in the city (which is beautiful I might add).
author: John G.

description:
I had the best service here that I have ever had in my life. (Charles: mad props. You were truly the man of the (3) hour(s))

Nothing vegan on the menu, and no vegetarian entrees, either. Normally, huge boo from me. But of course, like at all restos of this caliber, they were delighted (it seemed) to make me a vegan appetizer and entree.

The appetizer, a salad, was made up of lovely mixed greens with the sweetest yellow tomatoes known to humankind, slivered hearts of palm, and just the right amount of a delicate vinegarette. The entree was a sample platter of veggies cooked a variety of ways, and served so elegantly you would swear it was off the menu. I ate both with the freshest rustic sourdough and marvellous olive oil. (The olive oil was brought specially for me. Would I care for some olive oil for my bread? Why yes Charles, how considerate of you. Will the finest olive oil this side of the Atlantic do? Why yes, Charles, how thoughtful of you.) Vegans: you will be taken care of here. Taken care of like a little baby rabbit that needs to be wrapped up ever-so-delicately in the softest of blankets and cradled ever-so sweetly while being hand-fed the tastiest of clean spring carrot greens. Yes, it's that good.

You really can't ask for a more pleasant dining experience than you get at Boulevard. Full disclosure: I didn't even see, let alone pick up the bill, so I can't speak to value for your money. But if you need an impeccable dinner no matter what the cost, or are being tapped for dining suggestions by your rich uncle who's only in town for one night and who is just dying to catch up, or if money, simply, is no object: go to Boulevard. It's what fine dining should be.
author: Devin F.

description:
I wanna say the service was fantastic. ABSOLUTELY FANTASTIC. Service definitely would get 5 stars from me. From start to finish our server was polite and our busser was very quick.

When it comes to the food, i'd have to only give it 4 stars. While it was delicious (don't get me wrong), everything was over-salted and for the price I would have expected better.

Would I go again? Yes, but i would hope that the food was a little more even with the price.
author: Austin O.

description: Dinner was fantastic. Every dish I tasted was great, but portions are a little small. You'll need an appetizer and probably dessert... I had the coco nib brulee, which was the one thing I was underwhelmed by. I would be tempted to order 2 appetizers or 1 plus a cocktail next time. Atmosphere was a little loud as well, but service was top notch, and my guests seemed to enjoy the meal as well. I will be back!
author: Matthew H.

description:
truly a 4.5 (because the dessert was such a dud)

Boulevard gave me multiple food orgasms... yeap, one after another, after another, after another... he sure knows what he's doing ;)  

What was ordered:

Gnocchi with Maine Lobster:  Perfectly cooked lobster!  The sauce that accompanied it was the perfect combination of tangy/sweet and brought out the sweetness of the lobster.  The gnocchi's were unlike gnocchi's I had ever had before.  This dish was so simple, yet the perfect execution made it so delightful to eat.

Rabbit ravioli:  Tasty, but nothing spectacular; especially when having it AFTER the Maine lobster appetizer.  It paled in comparison.  Also, i was thrown off by the name.  I was under the impression that they were rabbit-STUFFED ravioli.  But no, they were marinara-ish stuffed ravioli with the tiniest, albeit tasty, morsel of rabbit on the side.  This is the one dish I would not reorder.

Wagyu Beef: perfectly marbled.  With every bite, the juiciness came oozing and coated every corner of my mouth (get your mind out of the gutter).  Thinking about it makes my mouth water.  This is as flavorful a piece of meat is going to get.

Lamb T-bone: lamb is definitely one of my favorite proteins.  This is THE best lamb, I've ever had, hands down.  I enjoy the taste of game meat, but i know a lot of people don't.  this lamb had NO hint of gamy-ness whatsoever. Ahh, perfectly cooked.  the outside was perfectly grilled to give it a slight crisp, and the inside was perfectly moist and tender.

WARM Valrhona Alpaco Chocolate Cake:  This was a buzz-kill. First of all, the cake did not arrive to us warm.  The edges were hardened, the inside dry.  I had a couple of bites and was over it.  My date and I didn't finish it and we ALWAYS finish our desserts.

Drinks: Chateauneuf du Pape, Zinfandel/Malbec Blend, Pellegrino, Weaver's coffee.  I was thrilled with our wine choices; they complimented our meats very well.  I had never heard of Weaver's, but it was excellent and I drank mine black.  And the Pellegrino, well, it tasted like Pellegrino :P

Conclusion: This is the best food experience in the city I've had so far.  The decor, ambiance, and atmosphere of Boulevard is relaxed yet retains a certain elegance.  Service was excellent--the dishes never came too fast or too slow and our waitress was chill and down to earth.  She gave us generous wine pours, practically giving us one glass for free and comped our dessert because she could tell we weren't thrilled with it.  

I love Boulevard!  Thanks for the multiple (food) orgasms!
author: Allie L.

description:
I've been here several times because the food is amazing especially the appetizers and most fish dishes. 

There is one consistent problem. The arrangement of the furniture is uncomfortably situated. When you walk in there is nowhere to wait for the hostess without being in the way of people coming in or leaving. The bar area "waiting area" is narrow and crowded with tables of people trying to talk over the noise and eat and drink with people standing over them. 

If I do not get seated in my favorite corner booth I will most likely leave. I put up with the bar area to eat once without a reservation and I was miserable. The experience was poor. If I didn't know about my one spot that I am comfortable sitting I would have probably never come back.
author: Dee C.

description:
The service here is great. I was going to dinner with a group and my friend and I arrived thirty minutes early. There weren't any bar stools where we could sit and wait, but they kindly pulled two seats for us to use. On top of that they ended up seating us early and we were able to wait for the rest of our party at our table. Our waiter, Ethan, was wonderful as well.

The food was very good. I got the Ahi tuna and scallops, which were enough for me for dinner. Our dinner companion ordered a bottle of Neal Cabernet 2002, which was excellent also. I had a delicious ice cream dessert.

The restaurant overall is pretty big, though the booths are a little tight. It was also inconvenient that the bathroom was downstairs. But overall, a great experience with excellent food and service.
author: Keiko O.

description:
Oh Boulevard,
It's sad to see,
that you are now a solid "3"

Enough said.
author: Tom E.

description:
Three generations of our family came on a Monday night (ages 10,55,85).   We were seated immediately for our 6pm reservation (no tables available 7pm).  The waiters and bus people were nice and gave us help deciding what to eat.  The food came fairly quickly.  

Our appetizer, crab, avocado and melon salad, was very nicely seasoned.  The pork was a little plain but was good for children.  It came with wonderful mushrooms,spinach, and gnocchi.  The halibut was perfectly cooked and came again with nice sauces and sides.  The lamb was delicious and came with a mysterious but tasty sauce (gooseberries? capers?).  We would have enjoyed more veggies.  

We got both cheese and dessert.  The cheese was disappointing, hard and undistinguished, when we were expecting soft and gooey; but perhaps it was our ignorance in ordering.  We got a dessert involving several forms of both apricot and chocolate .  It was beautifully decorated with chocolate lace, had a crunchy chocolate cylinder around the mousse, sorbet, fruit, jellies, sauce...really nice. 

Some people think this place is very overpriced, we thought differently.  We spent 65$ per. person (with tip).  For a fancy restaurant like this one its not too bad.  

We liked this place overall!!
author: Nina A.

description:
Took the bf here for his birthday and Boulevard did not fail.

Parking can be rough, but hey, it's the city.

Service was excellent.  Waiter was attentive enough and helpful with suggestions.  Added a nice chocolate piece to our dessert to say "happy birthday". 

We ordered the foie gras for app, sea bass entree for him and duck breast for me. Foie gras ($29) was perfect, and the piece of toast it came with was even better (I'm a sucker for carbs).  Sea bass ($34) was moist and tender but didn't quite stand out to me. I was extremely satisfied with the duck breast entree ($33), as the meat was cooked perfectly to my liking and it was flavorful. 

I ordered a Whiskey Smash cocktail ($12) which I didn't think was so fantastic that it should be worth $12.  

Dessert was the brown butter financier cake w/vanilla ice cream and raspberry sorbet. It was delicious and buttery. 

$180 worth of damage done.  Well worth the experience.
author: Michelle W.

description:
A group of us went here for a friend's birthday and had their private wine room dining area. The dinner was long and leisurely but I am going to make this short and sweet. 

The waiter was an interesting character, old school service, but a little overbearing with his recommendations- I'll get to this in more detail.

I think we tried every appetizer/small plate and they were all very small but outstanding. Flavors blended seamlessly and were delicious. This definitely turned out to be the strong point of the entire meal.

We moved on to our entrees. I am a mostly vegetarian who just recently began eating meat when it is of very high quality (local, sustainable farm, grass fed, etc). I was excited to get the Filet Mignon. There were few meats I missed while being vegetarian for almost 10 years and steak was one of them. I like my steak pretty medium rare and a little bloody. The waiter insisted that all of their meats are basically cooked a level under what you order. He said medium rare is "medium" there and said if I ordered it medium rare, it would come practically raw. He really made it sound drastic and as if I would be disappointed, yet if I just order "medium" it would be perfectly how I wanted it. It was so simple... There's nothing worse than an overcooked steak so I was very hesitant but he finally convinced me to order it medium (it was also feeling like it would have been rude to go against his expertise and still order it medium rare). Well, needless to say, my steak came out and it was cooked medium. I was so disappointed. It was barely even pink and only in certain parts. It was a true medium, with no rare to be found. Not exactly what I had dreamed of in my $50 steak. We've cooked ourselves better steaks at home from Bi-Rite.

Desserts were good and the appetizers out-shined the entrees. I would recommend coming here for drinks and apps but don't bother with the main course.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Sad to see this restaurant decline since my last visit. We ate here last night and it was nothing like I remembered. Our filet mignons were cooked to the right temperature, but the taste left a lot to be desired. Neither my wife nor I (who both love and eat a lot of filets) really liked it. For the price (it's expensive!) I expected a lot better. 

What really sealed the deal for me and ensured I'll never go back was the extra charge on the bill titled "SF Mandate". When I asked the waitress what that was for I was told it was an extra charge to help pay for their employees health insurance. WTF? Doesn't me just eating there do that? I mean, that's the cost of doing business. 

No one helps me pay for my insurance and because they forced me to pay for theirs I will never be back.
author: Mark S.

description: My husband and I ate there for the first time Saturday night. Everything was perfect. I had King Salmon and he ordered the filet mignon. Perfect, perfect. For dessert we shared the red velvet cake. Super exceeded expectations. It wasn't cakey full of icing like other restaurants. We will definitely return.
author: Ngan L.

description:
OOOOOOH YES! Spectacular place to dine. Impressive, classy, tasty and memorable. Perfect for Valentine's Day, special date night or any other grand occasion, unless you are rich FiDi businessperson or a BALLERBALLERSHOTCALLER. If so, call me! ;)

Open-ish kitchen, spectacular service, creative menu, cool location almost on the water, and huge windows that peep the Bay Bridge. Dim and romantic, lively but intimate.

It's been almost a year since I've dined here, so I'm gonna try to convince my boy or mom and dad to take me here again. I remember this fantastic gumbo appetizer which was like a concentrated reduced sauce with a biscuit. The serving was small and served in an enormous bowl, but the taste was INCREDIBLE! It was rich, buttery, spicy and smoky. Rack of lamb was superb too, which is always my dish of choice, but the gumbo really took the cake. When you see "gumbo" next to items on the menu containing more exotic words and ingredients like pomegranates, fennel, arugula, creme fraiche, celery root, it's hard to order something as ordinary-sounding as "gumbo", but I doubt this place makes any dish boring.
author: Chelsea P.

description: Came here for a late night dinner, I can't remember what I had except for the scallops. Mouth watering scallops! This place served the best scallops I have ever tasted. It was fresh, juicy, and cooked to perfection. Other wise, the service was great.
author: Carrie Y.

description: I chose this restaurant to celebrate my husband's birthday this past Sunday, because it's still considered one of the best in SF.  I'm very pleased to say, that it's worth every penny of its' reputation.  The environment remains welcoming, elegant, & lively, & our entrees were excellent. I had the Quail & my husband, the Pork Chop.  Our dinners were beautifully presented,  juicy, & tasty.  Thank you, Boulevard, for an enjoyable dining experience.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I recently organized a private dinner event for 30 of our firm partners and clients. The Banquet Manager, Pamela and her team, help me put together a successful and memorable end-of-summer evening. The banquet menu choices reflects favorites on their dinning room menu. 

At our little, intimate soiree, we started off with their California Hass Avocado and Hearts of Palm salad which was made of organic little gem & mixed lettuces, toasted chopped hazelnuts & a wonderful herb pesto. Thin slivers of shaved summer truffles lay on to of the hearts of palms which some guests mistook for cheese and was pleasantly surprised at the combination of the two. 

I selected the following two dishes as our entree choices: 

- I had the wild caught California White Sea Bass (not Chilean and fully sustainable!) It was perfectly cooked and sat atop a bed of risotto made with tomatillo water. I particularly enjoyed the side of fried squash blossom Filled with halibut brandade tomato relish with some EVOO and Basil lovingly drizzled on top 

- The client next to me had the other choice of wood-roasted California angus filet mignon topped with french beans, bacon and cipollinis with a warm vinaigrette. The sides looked like a chunky bit sunshine - yellow and white Corn and fingerling yukon gold potatoes.

They were generous enough to allow another two choices for dessert: 
- Half of our table opted for devilish chocolate brownie sundae with hot fudge, vanilla bean ice cream and chantilly cream. 

- Not to be outdone, the angel food cake proved to be just as rich as a brownie. (Pamela warned me that the angel food cake is dipped in butter and brown sugar - that sort of sealed the deal with me) it came with a rich mascarpone ice cream, blackberries and peach sorbet. This dish was the beginning of my food coma that night. 

Thank you Boulevard for great service, cool ambiance and excellent food! 

By the way Richard, Hugh Jackman has nothing on you!! Thx - J
author: Jenny D.

description: I had their burger again today.  I just want to say that Australian Beef sucks, they have no friggin flavor and is POS.  I said that at lunch today and some idiotic Aussie had issue with that.  Let me repeat that, Australian beef is the worst beef in the world and if you like it that's fine.  Thank God Boulevard does not serve POS Australian Beef which sucks big time.  IMHO you might as well take some card board grind it up saturated it with water and serve it and it would taste exactly like Australian Beef! I HATE AUSTRALIAN BEEF.  I LOVE AMERICAN BEEF!
author: Jim J.

description: of course one of the fancy places to play dress-up.  We had corporate annual dinner there and it was a great experience in their private room. You get what you pay for, excellent!
author: Shell J.

description:
Michelin Star...no doubt.

I was in SF for a week for work and had the pleasure of dining here, last night. I was expecting great things and I was not let down. It has a feeling of swanky-ness, but is totally approchable.

Food is pricey but worth it.

Starters:
1.BRUIN FARMS TOMATO SALAD
   Buffalo Mozzarella, Shaved Market Squash & Parmesan Colatura Tuile
   Pine Nuts, Arbequina Extra Virgin Olive Oil 
(just returned from Rome and this Caprese was just as good!)
2.BABY ICEBERG 
   Green Goddess Dressing, Brokaw Avocado & Roasted Hazelnuts, 
   Boucheron Goat Cheese, Watercress & Chervil 
(very good, not spectacular)

Main course:
1. WOOD OVEN ROASTED FILET MIGNON 
    Dwelley Farms Haricots Verts, Baby Mushrooms & Fried Shallots
    Banana Fingerling Potatoes with Mountain Gorgonzola Sauce
    Roast Beef Jus & Barolo Vinaigrette
(perfection when it comes to steak and potatoes! melt in your mouth good!!!)

Awesome wine list - pricey, but excellent wines. 

Was too full for dessert.

I hope I can come back!
author: Caleb Y.

description: One of the most solid restaurants in the city.  It's been great for over a decade.  The food and service has been great each time I've been.
author: Brandon L.

description: Blah at best.. My husband and I were so looking forward to our dinner here. This has got to be the most overated place in SF. Rude hostess and wait staff. Hugely disappointed. The menu was late 90's and tired.. the only thing that saved the meal was the beautiful space.
author: Kim P.

description:
We live in Los Angeles, and on a whim (and a lot of frequent flyer miles!) decided to have a bit of fun and go to San Francisco for lunch on Tuesday.

We booked at Boulevard based on the menu and wine list on their website, neither of us had been there before.

Awesome. The food was great, the wine list was amazing (plenty of glasses and half-bottles too), service was wonderful.

I won't go into detail with what we ate and drank, but martinis, appetizers, entrees, wine, dessert, dessert wine, cheese and port made for one heck of a nice lunch. 

We walked it off strolling down the Embarcadero, got a cable car back to downtown from Fisherman's Wharf, took a picture of the bay and got back to the airport in time for a 5pm flight back.

Fantastic restaurant, really, really great people working there. Made our day.
author: Steve M.

description:
let me Usher you in with a song:

Waiter:  You see you searching for restaurant that'll 
take you out and do you right. 
Well come to Boulevard baby and let the Flank Steak
show you what it feel like. ahhh yea

Sommelier: You know all you gotta do is 
tell me what your sippin' on. 
And I promise that ima keep it commin' all night long. 

Me: Lookin' in your eyes (mr. abalone)
While you walk the other side, 
(and I think that Braised Shorty Ribs I've got a thing for you) 
Doin' it on purpose, winding and workin' it. 
I can tell by the way you lookin' at me yeaaaa

All together now: I wanna make love to this grub to this grub to this grub to this grub, I wanna make love to this grub, to this grub to this grub, to this grub

(!!!) yum
author: Joanna M.

description: I ate here last night, was recommended by a friend. Sat at the bar and asked what to get, the bartender suggested the pork chop which I would normally order. I was so glad I did though, this thing was soooo good. The only reason I'm not giving the place 5 stars is the drinks were a little on the small side. Other than that though, the restaurant itself is really nice inside, cool ambience and the food was great. Also, they have an old espresso machine there that made some excellent espresso and cappuccino, got a lot of workout while I was there.
author: Chris D.

description: Husband took several business partners for dinner. Everything was very good, Problem...he ordered a very large steak (porterhouse or something) he was only able to eat a quarter of it and asked that it be boxed. Is that such a no no in this fancy restaurant? Well lo and behold when he got home he went to give our labrador a treat, unfortunately all the meat had been cut off the bone and he was sent home with just a bone. Pathetic.
author: Ronda F.

description:
Flew out here from LA after I was able to get a reservation......absolutely amazing food.  Started off with Foie Gras.....and my main course was Suckling Pig, 3 ways.......
wow........
This is definitely another stop in my book!
Service was amazing, and I love watching the chefs prepare straight in the dining area.
author: MeikaiLani K.

description:
I went here recently, and I think I was the only one in the restaurant on Thursday night under 45 years old. It was very boring and lame, frankly. This place used to be trendy and the place to be, but it is no longer the same restaurant it once was. The food was mediocre at best, but still very expensive. The menu selection is very limited, and it is clear the restaurant isn't doing very well based on some obvious indicators. I would be surprised if this place is still here in the next few years.

Somehow these guys got my prior review taken down even though it was honest and straightforward. I would therefore suspect their other high reviews of being inauthentic.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
Have visited this restaurant many times over the years both for dinner and for lunch and, especially after my last visit, I believe the quality of food and service has declined. Its always been a very noisy room but the previous quality of food, from menu selection, product quality and preparation has meant it was worth shouting to converse with dining companions. The main selection our table had for dinner recently(Lamb, Pork and Quail) was ok, but both the lamb and pork were tough. The vegetable selection was so-so. The attention to detail is slipping. For example, the waiter forgot we had ordered a bottile of wine, the restrooms seemed to be ignored and the mens restroom had no towels(hope the kitchen staff use another restroom to wash their hands) maybe they need a sign in sheet for staff to ensure they check regularly.
So I guess the value equation has slipped negative and I doubt if I will be dining here in the future.
author: Charles S.

description:
Dined here last fall for dinner.  I won't mention what I ate because I believe their menu has changed since then.  However, the food and service were excellent.  Our waitress was especially patient during our wine selection.  

The decor makes this seem like the kind of establishment I would visit on a business meeting.
author: Lesli C.

description:
It has been over a year since I began boycotting Yelp (when I get mad, I stay mad), but I am finally back! What has thawed my heart slightly and calmed my anger? Boulevard. 

A group of 6 of us came in one Sunday evening to share some dishes and a couple bottles of wine. For appetizers, we ordered the soft shell crab, pan seared scallops, and ahi tuna. All items were good but not great. Except for the scallops - I freaking loved those little things. As for the main dishes, we ordered the lamb, pork, and one fish dish. The lamb wasn't tender enough, which makes the entire dish unappealing. The pork was dry...really dry. The fish - I can't even tell you which fish dish we ordered because it was that unmemorable. 

As you can see, Boulevard, in fact, is really not that amazing and is very much over-hyped (my personal opinion). However, I really must admit that they do have one dish that they have truly perfected. Boulevard's scallops are hands down the best scallops I have ever had. Given that I am a seafood fanatic and order scallops whenever they are on the menu, you can count on me for this one. I will even pay for your scallops if you don't like them - that's how much I mean it.

As happy as can be with the scallops, though, there was one quite important aspect of my dining experience that I really couldn't shake. Our waitress was so great in helping us choose our dishes, but everything else about her was just so...annoying, rude, and a number of other negative adjectives. Not only did she hover a whole lot, but she also thinks it's appropriate to tell us how much we owed her for her services. When the check had returned back to us after our cards had gone through, we realized we hadn't tipped her enough. While we were all reaching for our wallets to put in extra money, the hovering waitress had remained hovering without us noticing until she so rudely quipped, "No, you didn't tip enough. I tried to give you a great experience, but I guess I did not do well enough." AWKWARD. She is lucky my friends are far nicer and more polite than I am as I would have totally walked out without putting another dollar on the table for her. 

SO - 
Pros: scallops, ambiance (sophisticated but not snooty), free corkage on second bottle, which was awesome as I happened to have some wine in my car.
Cons: Waitress, over hyped food (not really their fault, I guess)

3.5. 
Yes, I fucking hate bad customer service.
author: Ha V.

description: I came here for dinner this weekend and it was so great. I haven't been in so long and it was way better then I remember. We started at the bar with a cocktail, I had a Paloma and it hit the spot.  I had the tuna appetizer that was super fresh and exactly how I like it. I also ordered the sourdough pasta with rabbit meatballs. The pasta was so different and the meatballs had pistachio in them, very interesting dish. so good. I want to keep Boulevard on a more permanent spot on the rotation!
author: ashley m.

description:
So looking forward to dinner at Boulevard but it turned out to be the worst experience in a 5-star restaurant ever. A 20 minute wait for the appetizers we ordered, then 1 in 4 of the appetizers was cold. We sent it back.  Later, 2 of the 4 entrees were cold to the point you could see the sauce congealed on the fish dish. We sent them back. In the meantime, our dining companions finished their meals. For the second attempt, husband's pork chop came back perfect but my fish was very obviously just reheated.  The fish was way overcooked.  I did not return it only because I was so hungry by that time and the sad meal was dragging on.

Wait person was friendly but not attentive. We had to flag down others to get our dishes returned.

Manager gave perfunctory apologies with no explanation even though he did discount the total bill for us and gave us free dessert.  Still not enough for me to recommend this restaurant--especially at its high prices. Is Boulevard sitting on its laurels?  

So disappointed that I am writing a letter to the chef/owner--first time I've taken the time to do that.

P/S Soup course, dessert and the pork chop were very good.  Everything else was "just OK," hot or cold.
author: Cathy Q.

description:
