You know those restaurants with a lot of good talk, but the restaurant actually stinks? Well, this is NOT the case!

They treat each and every customer with utmost respect, friendliness, and attentiveness.  Upscale service, without the snootiness.  

Each time, I savor the food, the experience, and enjoy the pictures, until my next 'annual' trip here.  

I only go here once a year (sometimes twice) for very special occasions only.  Why?  Because the food, drinks and service here is wonderful, but really, really above and beyond my financial means!  (I'm being honest here...it's worth it, but let's not go overboard.)

Foie gras is to die for. I have tried a different entree each time I've been here, so I can't really name any specific entrees currently, but I do love it all. Seriously!!

The view = spectacular view of Bay Bridge and the water, especially if you're lucky enough to get a window seat. 

I love Boulevard.  And if marrying the chef of Boulevard was legal in San Francisco, I'd try to do that.   :-)
author: Fannie S.

description:
Had to wait 15 minutes even though we had a reservation and they gave us seared scallops as an apology! Went for holiday lunch and the place was busy. Gold stars dangled from the concave brick ceiling. FOH staff was made up of young girls - not the most professional or friendly group of girls, but I'm sure that's why they work the lunch shift. On to the food!

Lobster Bisque - small serving, rich and delicious but don't expect to find any lobster pieces in there.

Goose ravioli appetizer - 2 tiny homemade raviolis that are tasty, but I have had better for a portion of the price. Perbacco anyone?

Petrole Sole - slightly boring, just because I wanted to go healthy did I have to go boring? Overcooked fish and sad bed of beans & greens.

Flourless Buche de Noel - Delicious rich chocolate spin on a traditional German cake
author: Sabrina S.

description:
Good service, good food, good location. 

A little on the loud side as far as the noise level, but that did not spoil it for us.
author: Laurent C.

description:
One of my favorite places for a nice dinner.  The decor is not my style, but the food is excellent.  The day boat scallops, Gnocchi with Maine Lobster and Waygu Zabuton were perfectly prepared.  I am consistently impressed.

The last time I was there, I lost a bet to a random guy.  I don't even think he was a patron.  If you need to use the restrooms, you need to head to the back and go down an elevator through a different lobby.  As I was waiting for the elevator, there was this guy hitting on this girl, but she wasn't having any of it.  I told him that he didn't have a prayer and if he could get her number I'd buy him a drink.  I head to the restroom (wash my hands), come back up the elevator, and as the doors are opening I see the two of them making out.  He raises his head and smiles

When I returned to my table, I asked our waitress to send two gin and tonics to the madly-in-love couple near the back lobby.
author: E L.

description: Came here for a special birthday lunch.  Ordered the soft shell crab sandwich.  It was a good size.  The service was good but kinda slow even though the restaurant wasn't even busy.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Lots of great memories, but probably time to move on... When I went with a work group earlier last year, our waitress seemed frazzled and impatient with our animated, yet polite and sober group of four. The questions and our discussion  about wine selection seemed to throw her off and she abruptly walked away and sent the sommelier. Unfortunately,  I had seen her reaction and that set an uncomfortable tone for the whole meal - especially because I recommended the restaurant. She probably isn't even there anymore (hope not.) I went again over the summer for a birthday. The gentleman who served us was a true professional. I thought the food was good, but not out of this world. The birthday girl loved it though. When I went again for work in October (this time a lunch) the woman who served us was pushing additional dishes and trying to talk us into getting wine with lunch. The food didn't taste as good to me. Maybe it was the tartar sauce taste with the fish (good fish but hate tartar sauce.) Anyway, when I'm being up-sold at a fine restaurant, it is annoying and uncomfortable. It really put me off. Hope they can make some tweaks and come back strong.
author: Win S.

description: Although its a seasonal dish, Boulevard has the BEST beets, watermelon and goat cheese salad I've had in my life - and I've ate lots. The food was delicious and perfectly prepared. Also they have a nice wine list and the bartender that served us made perfect cocktails. Usually crowded and sometimes hard to get reservations, but overall the food and wine was great
author: Shari S.

description: Delicious and a great date location. The food was definitely a highlight and the waiter staff was very attentive.
author: Ben T.

description: This place was great. Good wine list. Good atmosphere. Menu is reprinted daily to reflect fresh specials.
author: Robert C.

description: Came here for lunch after a long morning of sightseeing in SF. Food and service are impeccable. Probably one of the best burgers (American Wagyu) I've ever had. Pork Shortrib was very tasty too, but the bacon in the marmalade sauce was a bit overcooked. Dover sole is very hard to cook, but this one was spot on. Appetizers of mozzarella salad and calamari were good starters, both with great dressings. I wish there was a bigger or more diverse beer selection, but even O'Doul's would go great with that burger!
author: Tony L.

description:
This is my sister's and my go-to place for top-notch food and pampering, when we can afford it! Be prepared to spend at least $100/person for dinner, but it's worth every penny. Warm and friendly atmosphere, perfect service. Food spectacular. 

Especially important for us middle-aged women was being treated like visiting royalty - that's what we really don't mind paying the big bucks for. Middle-aged women get tired of being shunted to the kitchen-area or next to the bathrooms and then ignored for the duration of the meal. 

It's the service at Boulevard, coupled with the spectacular food, that brings my sister and myself here for special celebrations. (If I can figure out how to win the lottery without actually buying a ticket, I'm eating here every month!)
author: Jane M.

description:
Went here for a work lunch. VERY crowded. So crowded that people who had reservations and were waiting to be seated were getting hit in the back and shoulders by the revolving doors each time new people walked in. 

Love the interior design; tons of old school character. I ordered lobster bisque and then some sort of chicken dish. Everything was excellent. I'd order it again, and take people there I want to impress. Willie Brown was sitting at the table next to us. 

The only thing I disliked about the experience was that at our table of six, the waiter kept reaching in front and across me to serve the person to my left, instead of going around my back (there was space). I'll go back anyway.
author: Green Y.

description: Honestly, I was underwhelmed.  I had heard such great things and my meal was only ok.  The carpaccio appetizer was good, and they let us try a few wines before we picked a bottle which was nice, but my main course, the sea bass, was overcooked and very dry.  For how much we were paying, I expected it to be perfect.
author: Julie T.

description:
I'd give the food four stars if the prices were cheaper, but for the quality/price ratio I'm calling this a three.

The decor is gorgeous and full of character, and the service is first class.   Good bread and good wine by the glass. But the food? is oversalted. I had salmon on a bed of corn and wild rice, with a spinach salad.  My other half had steak.  All of the dishes were prepared very well, and the ingredients were great, but the saltiness of the food gets in the way of fully appreciating it.  Even without the salt, for the prices Boulevard charges I expect a certain zip to the food, some alchemy of flavor, and -- though the menu is interesting and the cooking is skillful -- that extra magic just isn't there.  I don't think we'll be back.
author: Julia S.

description:
My best friend flew up to the city from San Diego to spend Labor Day weekend with me. It has always been one of our dreams to eat at a Michelin rated restaurant. Instead of going to a play like we originally planned, we decided on a fancy restaurant.

After flipping through the SF Michelin guide (deciding we could only afford one star) and talking to one of my dad's best friends, we decided on Boulevard. 

The decor is beautiful and classy. I felt like I was in a lovely French brasserie. You cannot beat the view from the dining room of the Bay Bridge and the Ferry Building. The view is particularly beautiful at twilight, when we were there, due to the lights on the bridge being turned on. I had reservations, which is obviously the way to go. When we arrived, we half expected not to be taken seriously due to our age (we are both eighteen) but were treated absolutely wonderfully. The wait staff was more than attentive and helpful. Although, one patron in her fifties did give me a confused/bitchy look in the bathroom. But my friend did try to assure me it was just because of my age (we were certainly the youngest by at least seven years).

I had the squab and quail with wild rice and seared foie gras. It quite seriously was one of the best meals of my life. My best friend had the white sea bass with a squash blossom fritter stuffed with Dungeness crab. For dessert, he had the raspberry-lemonade sorbet and I the Mascarpone cheese ice cream. Loved it.

Since we were unable to order drinks (although I have heard their Cucumber Gimlet is fantastic), our bill came to $97 without the tip. He thought it would amount to more, so we were both happy. 

I love this place and I will go back again as soon as I can find a fellow foodie from the city to accompany me and make some more money.
author: Emily M.

description: Yes!  Excellent, friendly service.  Consistently fantastic.  They do a great job for special occasions.
author: Ottis M.

description:
What an amazing experience, especially when someone else is paying.  Been there for drinks but only was recently lucky enough to experience dining there.

We had the most divine wine here, it was a California Zin, by a small winery named Carlisle.  They don't make many bottles and things seem to sell out immediately (nothing available on their site).  I hope I will have the opportunity to try their wines again.

I had the beef carpaccio with fried oysters for my appetizer... The waiter said they were scrumptuous, and they were.  For the entree I tried the lamb 3 ways.  I definitely liked the appetizer better than my entree, but they were both well presented and totally perfectly done.  We ran out of room for dessert though.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Our whole party thought that Boulevard was incredible.

The evening started off on a good note - delicious, well-made cocktails - and kept getting better.

The scallops appetizer was decadent and delicious. The king salmon entree was cooked perfectly and I loved the accompanying Farro Perlato and beets. My husband's guinea hen was also done perfectly, and we were very impressed by the accompanying Truffled Mushroom Dumplings. The Warm Vanilla Crepes capped off a great meal. Yum. 

Service was great and we liked the open-kitchen concept. We'll be back.
author: C M.

description:
I would go here again because my wife enjoyed it.  And if you have never been, it is worth checking out.  The environment is romantic, customer service is top notch, and the food is good.  Not spectacular but good.

I had extremely high expectations for the food.  I was not disappointed, I just expected to be blown away.  I have been to cheaper places with better food.  However, if you are looking for a place that has the entire package, romantic, customer service and decent food, this is the place to go.  You can even go on a walk afterwards by the water because it is on the embarcadero by the Bay Bridge.
author: Jo H.

description:
My wife and I had a wonderful meal here. The drinks - I had a Wimbledon - a nice Pimm's based concoction - and she had a "special tea" which was a delicious non-alcoholic drink chosen from a pageful of really exotic alcohol free drinks.  

The appetizers were excellent, the main courses were good but not as good as the apps. For dessert we let the pastry chef pick and we were pleasantly surprised, or rather stunned by the deliciousness of every bite of the dessert. 

I don't think we could have failed here. This might be my wife's new favorite.
author: Jon B.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend for my birthday! The atmosphere was amazing! Beautiful place with a great location! We arrived a little early for our reservation so we went to the bar. The female bartender seemed to be in a foul mood. She barely uttered a word to me and quickly mixed my midouri sour and went back being pouty-mcpout-a-lot. A few minutes later she heard me talking about a fabulous Chanel quilted handbag. All of a sudden her mood changed, she was smiling and started chatting it up with me. :) 
Once we were seated I looked over the menu, everything sounded SOOOO appetizing.
I ended up ordering the 
Wood Over Roasted Angus Filet Mignon W/
French Onion Fingerling Potatoes & Sauteed Rainbow Chard, Crilled Maitake Mushrooms & Beed Jus 42. 
Can I just say YUMMM!!!
OHM NOM NOM

My Boyfriend ordered the:
Grilled & Wood Oven Roasted Lamb Rack Chop & Loin
Artichoke Heart & Aioli, Roated Early Girl Tomato & Sauteed Spinach
Fingerling Potatoes with Chervil-Pesto & Pine Nuts, Olive Salad & Roasted Lamb Jus 36. 
He LOVED IT!!!!

The service was great, our waitress was very friendly and attentive!
The only negative was the portion size, which I was anticipating...I'm not a big fan of "little food" for a large price. But the taste was definitely worth it!!! Hoping to go back someday for a splurge!!
author: Niki G.

description:
I was visiting SF for a conference and only had a short amount of time to squeeze in lunch. I was hoping to use my time in the city wisely, and Boulevard was definitely the right place to do that!
Because I was eating by myself, the hostess suggested I sit at the chef's table - a bar overlooking the cook's line. The wait staff was very friendly and attentive, and it was very enjoyable to watch the other diners' food go out. 
I enjoyed a fritter appetizer that was making it's debut on the menu. I hope they keep it, because it was delicious and flavorful. I had the rabbit ravioli for an entree. The portion was small - perfect for lunch with an appetizer, but if you are coming for dinner or only ordering an entree, this might be too light. I also tried a taste of the butternut squash soup, which was quickly selling out - for good reason! 
Service was wonderful - friendly and attentive, both my waitress and the hostess were happy to talk to me about San Francisco and offer suggestions for the rest of my stay. As a solo diner, the chef's table provided a very welcoming place to sit, and entertainment with my meal! The food is very well-done - innovative and delicious. It is not an inexpensive place to eat, but is worth the splurge.
author: Laura S.

description:
hmmm, Itsa well thought out restaurant with good food. We had ok, (actually odd) service, maybe the waiter had a hang-over or the "hey I work at Boulevard and I am great ... syndrome ". Bad service is  probably an exception to the restaurant machine that Boulevard is.

While maybe not such as fan as the many 4 & 5 star reviews, raving about this and that. Well, however conflicted I rate it 4 stars.

For the bite by bite, Mojito by Mojito, napkin commentary...see the other 100's of comments.

I continue to LOL at other reviews....like (paraphrasing)...... "the necterines in the salad made me cry with delight" or "the waitress was nice to me" or "IMA foodie and ate at Boulevard when I was 3 years old ...when they opened and I still love it" 

Itsa SF icon. Not just according to those from Walnut Creek.

Polished, experienced, balanced dishes. Worth the price.
author: Matsuo U.

description: In San Francisco for the week and wanted to go somewhere memorable with my wife and Boulevard was absolutely amazing.  This place far exceeded my expectations.  It's really all in the details and from the decor, architecture, furniture, food, menu and service everything was top notch. The fact that my ice tea came with a cool extra bottle on hand made it seem so special. The blue colored water glasses, the revolving doors, leather menus, brick ceiling, tiled floor, wall decor, table settings and lighting just made the experience great. For our meal we had the pork chop and sea bass and both had such amazing flavors you want to savor every bite. We also had the butterscotch pudding for dessert and that was amazing. The service was run like a military operation with classy waiters everywhere that all paid us so much attention at the right times I was barely sure who our main server was? I see why this is the best in SF and if you go to the restroom you will see wall to wall awards. Overall an amazing, flawless , and delicious experience and I will come here whenever I'm in SF and my even take my friends again before I leave.
author: Jim M.

description:
After all these years Boulevard still remains a required stop on a culinary tour of San Francisco. Last night was my first visit in over 5 years and Boulevard was just as good as I remembered. 

Yes it's expensive, but the food and service are both equally really great. I had the Ahi Tuna appetizer which was an excellent cut of fish, and the fillet was perfectly cooked. Both my friends raved about the sweet breads, and one is a professional cook, so they must have been divine. Her baby squab and quail main looked very tasty as well!

Excellent wine selection. We all loved the Madeira as a post-dinner drink.
author: Dave S.

description:
Average food in a pleasant setting.  

The best course was the crab appetizer.  Mozzarella cheese was bland, popcorn desert was too sweet, lamb dish was fine but small and overpriced at $37.

Maybe this was once a culinary stop, now it seems to be more a pleasant restaurant with good services.
author: Greta S.

description: This review is based on the reservation process for booking a private room- The Wine Vault. First off the process is arduous and unnecessarily complicated. You have to call to the day, 6 weeks before your planned date at 1:00P exactly. The reservation team specifically- Becca, is rude, curt and incredibly unprofessional. After trying to book the room over 3 months checking in by email, I called at 1:05P and was told "sorry, the reservation had been taken. That's why we asked that you call at 1P." Did I mention that I drove in the day earlier and sent repeat emails trying to secure this reservation? No semblance of understanding was given by this woman. In response to asking if our group could be seated in the main dining room, her response, " I don't think we can accommodate a group your size (8), I'll have to ask our GM." When asked when she might expect a response? She replied, "when he gets back to me." Really? Wow!! So rude. In desperation I accepted the only available 9:15P booking and was told I would receive a confirmation email. None was ever sent, even after a follow up email. 2 days later I cancelled the reservation and sent the reservation staff an email of dissatisfaction. Crickets... I see why this establishment has lost it's Mitchelin star. The dining experience is so much more than a good meal. For the amount you pay to eat at Boulevard you should rightfully expect a modicum of respect and a good customer experience.  Need a private room for a special occasion? I highly recommend Aquerello. Excellent customer service, they don't make you jump through any hoops and are supportive through the whole process
author: Halima T.

description: Beautiful ambiance, fantastic food, great service ;) we will go back there for sure !
author: Nellie S.

description: Great! Great! Great place to spend Valentine's Day with the one you love. Great Food! Great Wine! Great Conversation!!!
author: Susan S.

description:
I had lunch a Boulevard about 5 years ago at the height of Boulevard Zagat frenzy. I was completely unimpressed with the dry chicken I had and vowed never to go back and to ditch Zagat. Sure it is a gorgeous interior in a classic building but the food is what I'm there for. 

Recently, I went on a dinner date there and was pleasantly surprised by the food. I was expecting overcooked stringy scallops but I got perfectly seared tender morsels.  The Sonoma duck was unbelievably delicious.  The entree portion was ginormous.  

My view of Boulevard has been completely altered.  I'll be happy to dine there again.
author: Monica L.

description:
We had an outstanding meal last night (recommend the lamb) with great service.  I could see them pulling a fresh loaf of bread and slicing for our table (sourdough with a great crust)...just great for my dad who loves bread (I think he had 7 slices!).  Our waiter was helpful, attentive without hovering and helped accommodate the changes my step mom asked for (lamb on the bone, without sauce) without a hitch.
Our booth table was quiet enough for a conversation yet within a lively restaurant setting with a view of the Bay Bridge at sunset.  
I had been at Boulevard a couple of weeks earlier for a dinner meeting and also had a great meal so would recommend it as well for meetings and private parties.
author: Rochelle S.

description:
We booked a last minute reservation for Boulevard, score! I've been to Prospect, but not Boulevard so I was excited to try its older sister. 

We walk in and we're immediately sat. Not a window seat, darn, but our table had a neat vintage, totally comfortable love seat. ;)

I order a martini and damn its delicious. Good start. 

We all decide we're ordering our own starter and main (so glad we did this!). 

I ordered the foie gras to start and the lobster and sea scallops for my main course. 

Granted, we were just in Paris and I had foie gras like it was going out of style. I expected it to be good, but to be underwhelmed. Wrong! Wow, this may have been the best foie gras to date. It was perfectly made, melted in mouth, it was utterly mouth watering. The marmalade/brown bread that was served with it: divine! Wow, wow, wow. So delicious. 

Meanwhile I tried Kevin's Ahi Tuna (score), Leigh's Ravioli ('cot damn), Melinda's Beet Salad (um, speechless). They were all terrific. So, I'm freaking excited about what's next. 

My lobster and sea scallop dish with risotto and tempura mushrooms were absolutely delectable. Leigh ordered the same amazing dish. Melinda was very happy with her fish and Kevin's lamb was eye popping frighteningly delicious. The sauce, the texture, the smell, the everything. 

We decided to call it quits after all that tasty food and opted out of desert. I'm betting on Boulevard that they're sweet treats were equally impressive. 

I've definitely been missing out. A-mazing!
author: Art A.

description:
My friend and I stumbled in here, this was our backup after we couldn't find the place we originally intended. Not a bad mistake to make. At the end of my meal when I went down the stairs to the restrooms I discovered their gauntlet of Michelin and beard plaques. I wasn't surprised at all.

I had some appetizer that was delicious, but I can't remember what it was, because the lamb T-bone that came after it was fan-freaking-tastic. Like out of this world. So glad my dining companion talked it up.

The orange creme brûlée was also above par.

Service was timely, polite, unobtrusive and professional. I was particularly impressed when I collared some server standing at the window waiting to get a pickup and asked for restroom directions. She snapped to without hesitation and guided me expertly. A little thing, but she clearly believed that helping me was the utmost priority at that very moment. Rare and special to see that level of excellence,
author: Paul N.

description:
A beautiful restaurant with good food and adequate service at extremely high prices.  

Expect a good (but not outstanding) meal to be served very late, with minimal service.  If you've only allowed 1 1/2 to 1 3/4 hours for dinner, to get to a performance, plan on needing to skip dessert and rush off to barely make curtain-time.  And to pay a very high price for the experience.  I've had several experiences, all the same.
author: Local R.

description: This place already has great reviews....and I now know why. Enjoyed the ambiance and food. Perfect dinner date. BF brought me here and I look forward to returning again. I had the halibut (and loved it). He ordered the filet mingon and enjoyed it...but he liked mine more.
author: Logan N.

description:
J'ADOREEEEEEE!

Went for a date night. The setting is perfect! Romantic and Classy.

The food is spectacular. The tasty, sweet fois gras, the warm and soothing lobster bisque, and the delicious lamb were all gorgeously displayed and cooked to perfection. 

The service is outstanding! Our waitress overheard my date mention that a basic salad would be great to start the meal off and balance out the calories of the dishes. Five minutes later we had just that on our plates. 

The wine, well it's a French restaurant, they know what they are doing ;) 

I am looking forward to a return visit very soon!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This is a mash note to the folks at this lovely San Francisco treasure.

I LOVE YOUR CUISINE!

Each and every time I come here, alone or with others, the welcome is real and if they're not too busy, warm and friendly. The swarm of folks waiting for a table always made me glad I've got a reservation.
author: William M.

description: Snob stop... GOOD FOOD, but, good lawd its wahay overpriced- ladybird can't pay that kind of $$ for the amount of food you get. lil too fruu fruu for me. Besides, the tables to are too close and Its really loud so it just got weird....I mean look at me.
author: Ladybird G.

description: Wonderful ambiance and food.  Filet was wonderfully cooked and husband's quail was amazing.  Sea scallop app also great.  Top notch service and all around wonderful dining experience.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Fine dining while maintaining a warm neighborhood feel to it.  Seems like a place where you would have regulars going there for years, because it has that kind of an old time atmosphere to it, i.e. classic, not trendy.  Even w/ 9:45 dinner reservations, the place was still crowded and loud when we got there.
The entrees weren't too interesting and didn't see a prie fixe menu, so we just went w/ appetizers to get a better tasting.
Standouts: 
The ricotta and also the foie.  Ricotta was a special for the day and the foie was the largest hunk of foie I've had, which was seared perfectly.  You can ask them to separate the foie appetizer and they'll give u a little more.  We didn't ask for this but they did it for us.  
I wanted to like the lobster gnocchi since I was drooling when I saw that on the menu, but the gnocchi consistency wasn't there...a bit dry and pasty.  
So six apps and drinks came out to a bit over $200 for two, probably could of did fine w/ five though.  Service and presentation were stellar.  Valet out front for $10 will save you a lot of time circling around...which we did for a while and gave up.
author: Glen G.

description:
Top 5 favorite meals in the city:

LOCAL BURRATA, FRESH TRUFFLES & PINE NUTS
WOOD OVEN ROASTED ANGUS FILET MIGNON
FOXWHELP FARM PEARS & SPANISH GOAT CHEESE SALAD
WARM DEVOTO GARDENS APPLE TART
author: P K.

description:
We celebrated a special occasion here and even though we had reservations there was a bit of a wait...20 minutes. Maybe it was the champagne we inhaled while we waited but time flew by.

The restaurant was extremely busy but service was still very good. The menu has a larger variety of entrees and we were all salivating after the waitress told us about the evening specials.

I had the salmon and my friends had the Filet Mignon. The salmon was melt in your mouth delicious goodness and the perfect size leaving room for dessert. :) We shared the Seascape Strawberry Sorbet & Key Lime Pie and wow! Probably one of the best dessert I've ever had aside from my moms Key Lime pie of course...sorry mom.  

Boulevard came highly recommended by SF friends and it delivered!
author: Leanne S.

description:
Boulevard came highly recommended by friends, two who are chefs, one a restaurant owner in Phoenix. With those credentials we had to check it out. My friend and I stopped in for lunch around 12:30 on a Thursday and the place was full with lots of tables with people on power lunches and lots of tables with people drinking wine and enjoying a long lunch in the city.

We were told to sit at the counter, which is essentially a bar giving a great view into the open kitchen. This was a great tip just for the fact that the couple behind us was told they may have a 20 minute wait for a table and we were seated right away (there was only one other fellow at the counter). Our server arrived for drink orders about 30 seconds after we'd been handed menus, so he said he'd be right back to see what we wanted. It was quite awhile before he arrived to ask what we'd like to drink, so by then we had our food orders in mind. I don't mind waiting for food, but don't make me wait for a drink while I also wait for food. We chose a couple drinks off the specialty menu, mine was the saffron gin martini, which was excellent, but it showed up about 2 minutes before my food, with which I would have preferred a glass of wine. 

The guys working this kitchen have the assembly process down. The special of the day was a Kobe burger, and they would have at least 5 plates lined up with fries as they toasted buns, made the burgers to order and put them together with sauce and toppings. We also watched them put together the Day Boat Scallops in the same manor. It was pretty easy to pick out the house favorites. 

I had the soft shell crab and my friend ordered the Kobe burger. Both were quite good and cooked perfectly. The burger was huge and flavorful and $16, which is completely reasonable for what we received. Outside of timing issues this was a great dining experience and I would also suggest the counter seating for the experience, and if you don't have a reservation.
author: Heather D.

description: I'm afraid that this place has seen better days.  The physical space needs to be refurbished.  The food is just okay.  I would skip it.
author: Orlando C.

description: Had a great Birthday dinner with the Family at Boulevard. Service was outstanding and the food was amazing. Extra Bonus points since we got to watch the Bay Bridge light show while eating diner. The Lamb T-Bone, Pork Prime Rib, Quail, and Salmon were all perfectly prepared and made for an outstanding experience. I was a little disappointed that the Sweetbread appetizer only came with two little medallions of Sweetbread; wish it came with a couple more, it was that good.
author: Marco M.

description: Best meal I've had in a long while. My tastebuds have been transformed. Service was also lovely.
author: Tasheenah B.

description:
I really enjoyed this. It wasn't too pricey, a little higher than a good dining restaurant, but I didn't break the bank eating here with my husband. 

We started with sharing the tuna tartar, better than most I've had, and that's one of my favorite apps. For the main course, I ate the lamb prime rib, cooked medium rare. The only reason I give this less than five stars was that it wasn't quite medium-rare, but more medium. However, the treat for this dish must have been the Potato "Risotto" with English Peas. What a creative and delicious way to serve a potato side. I had to say that was one of my favorite parts of the meal. 

My husband had the Pork prime rib chop, and lets just say, even in a finer dining establishment, he knows that sucking the meat off the bone is considered a faux pas, but he had to stop himself from even doing that. Overall, the kitchen seemed in top order, we watched as they ran food back and forth, cooked, prepped and sent out food, and the chef knew how to keep her staff in order.

Highly recommended, even if not for a special night, but for a weekend evening where you just want to go eat good food and be in a beautiful room and be satisfied when you leave.
author: Brenda C.

description: The best filet mignon ever!!!!!!!!! Nice vine selection as well. Make sure to make a reservation as they are always full.
author: J M.

description: I guess I didn't know what I thought Abalone was when I ordered it but for a brief second I was worried I'd made a mistake. Then I tasted it and was relieved that it was in fact the best thing I'd eaten all year.
author: Jessica B.

description:
It's really 3.5 stars. 

Pros: The service is excellent.  Definitely an awesome spot for a special 
occasion restaurant.  Popular. Incredible wine list.

Cons: Pricey, small portions (a little larger than tasting menu), loud and dated interior.

Unlike most people I probably wouldn't make it an effort to return but I wouldn't decline an invitation.
author: Roger H.

description:
The service was top notch, definitely one of the highlights of the experience and ambiance is cozy and romantic.

Apps were all wonderfully delicious, mains were good...not great and desserts perked us back up. I don't remember the apps but for the main dishes we had the filet, halibut and seabass and for dessert we got the chocolate cake and strawberry/watermelon cake to share.

I know the menu changes so I would definitely come back if someone suggested to come to Boulevard.
author: Wendy L.

description: Very nice service and atmosphere.  Food was pretty good-- not outstanding.  Pork chop was delicious.  Will go back.  My only negative is the noise level can be a bit deafening
author: Michael C.

description: My favorite part about this place is the ambiance. The old SF vibe feels good and not too snobby. The food was excellent with not much too complain about. The only thing I would say is, do not order the carmel popcorn dessert. I was surprised because their dessert chef was a known name. The soft shell crab was delicious and the ravioli was just as yummy. I'd say go check it out, it's an awesome space.
author: Mandee J.

description: $307...$307... For this?  I was expecting to get some action tonight, but not like this!  I wanted to  try  this place for a while.  Got the chance, went here for my anniversary.  My wife ordered the filet and I ordered the lamb.  But, let me back it up.  We ordered one appetizer, two tomato wedges, some arugula and mozzarella.  It was sparse, but tasted ok, not shocking or great, just ok.  I could have made this in 5 minutes after a stop at Safeway.  We ordered a cocktail, nothing unusual or extraordinary at all.  I ordered a $100 bottle of wine.  Wine list wasn't great, had about 18 Bordeaux to chose from, that's not a lot.  We ordered our entrées.  The filet, not prime.  It was choice Angus.  Well, that's ok, it was under $50. The filet had no flavor, washed out.  It had been pan seared, but no crust, just bland and totally ordinary.  My lamb..I got three chucks of lamb for $40. These are chunks I may have thrown into a sandwich as leftovers had I been at home.  These chunks should not have had the starring role in any entrée.  Tried to skip the dessert but the nice waiter brought us a complimentary scoop of ice cream so at least this screwing had a happy ending.  Completely underwhelmed.  This place did not wow me.  I came home and made some pasta.  For special occasion night out, look at other options.
author: Tim K.

description:
Great dinner. Probably the best I've had in SF so far.
The place is crowded and noisy. Real "Brasserie". Great service.
I am giving 4 stars rather than 5 because :
- the wine waiter's behavior was not the one expected in such a place.
- the restrooms were as clean as the BK ones at 11pm.
author: Georges L.

description: In short, a little underwhelmed by Boulevard.   My faith in both the James Beard Foundation and the Michellin Guide has definitely been affected. To be clear, the service was great. Our server was spectacular and handled everything perfectly (although I'm not sure one should have to wait to sit for a reservation made a month in advance) and for a time slot after peak seating. The food we had was good, but not great. It was well prepared but not spectacular. The noise level made it very difficult to talk. I've definitely had far better meals for far less money.
author: Kent D.

description: We dined at this restaurant last week. The service was rushed for a restaurant of this caliber. Portions were small for the price charged. However, the food was very good.
author: Juliette R.

description: My fiance and I went here for our anniversary dinner. Food was very creative and delicious. Service? Immpecable. Ethan was our server and while some of the patrons here seemed stuffy, our server was very down to earth and funny. We also loved two of the busers. Our drinks were never low, our food courses spaced out perfectly. I had the scallops- delicious. Fiance had the swordfish which was killer! We both had the cheddar apple salad- A real winner. We shared the Ahi Tuna Tartare- that was the only disappointing dish of the night. Not much flavor for the price. It's the only reason they do not get a 5. I will close by also saying they have one hell of a wine list!
author: Jenn L.

description:
i was totally disappointed with my lunch here.. the food was not seasoned.. and the meat products were overcooked... 

my wife's scallop appetizer was cooked well.. but my trout salad with beets was pretty flavorless... 

my roast pork was dry as was my wife's lamb... 

the only redeeming part of the meal was dessert (brown sugar tart)
author: Stan L.

description: Great place, up-scale, classy and pricey, but worth it!
author: R J.

description:
A lovely meal to celebrate some milestones that a friend had reached...great appetizers, primo mojito to start.  I had lamb that was served in medallions, and my friend had scallops.  Both were beautifully done.  We ended by splitting an order of the icebox cake, which really was perfect since we were quite full by that time.  Our waiter was top-notch, and seemed able to appear out of nowhere (despite the fact that he was at least 6').  Additionally, we had a generously sized round table toward the back, elevated a few inches in a nice spot.  

Lastly, I should mention the Alderwood Creek Pinot Noir, of which I ordered a glass.  It was a very tasty wine, and went beautifully with the lamb.  

Thank you, Boulevard, for a really pleasant dining experience.
author: Germaine J.

description: My favorite restaurant of all time. Everything from food, to ambiance, to service, quality, EVERYTHING blows every single one of my expectations out of the water EVERY single time I dine there. I recommend it to every single one of my friends and family. Their filet mignon is the best I have ever had, and none other can even compare. Really amazing restaurant.
author: Ally M.

description:
Foodie heaven.  Open kitchen, nice bar area, brick ceiling, view of Bay Bridge.  Service was attentive.  We were promptly seated, and never felt neglected or rushed.  They have a gat wine selection, but also a nice group of sans alcohol drinks.  if alcohol is not your thing, try the elderflower press. My wife had the goat cheese and roasted veggie salad and I started with the sea scallop and artichoke bisque.  Both were great.  For the main course, I had the pork chop, which was succulent and served with some nice semolina gnocchi and kale.  I do not like pork not well cooked, but I realize that is just me.  I do wish they would inform you that the intend to serve it with a pink cool center near the none.  I would have elected to cook it a bit more.  My wife had the filet mignonette, which was very tender, and came with some wonderful potatoes.  For dessert, I had the pecan cake, and my wife the dulce de leche, and both were also fine.  Portion sizes were good, presentation nice, and all in all a very pleasant evening.

I can't take off a star for my preference for fully cooked pork, but I had to mention it.
author: Gene B.

description: If you're hungry when you come in you'll probably be hungry when you leave, too, but your wallet will be a lot lighter.  I couldn't believe how much they were charging for tiny servings.  The restaurant is gorgeous to look at, but while waiting in the crowded bar for a table one of the wait staff nearly knocked me over.  Dude, lose 10 or 50 pounds or learn to say "excuse me".   When the food came it was, like the restaurant, lovely to look at, very artfully arranged.  The flavors were nice but nothing that knocked me off my feet.  And, honestly, if two people spend over $300 for dinner I don't think I should be looking for In and Out burger an hour later.
author: Kevin T.

description: Boulevard is a San Francisco staple.  Located in a beautiful historic building, this is a popular restaurant for SF residents and out of towners.  The food is fantastic and the extensive seasonal menu offers a range of delicious dishes.  Love the quail entree. Won the James Beard award for Outstanding Restaurant 2012 and definitely deserving.  If you want to have a nice upscale meal without a stuffy environment, Boulevard is your best bet.
author: Shelley W.

description: Boulevard is an upscale elegant dining experience. The food was delicious however the service was not very good. It took a long time for our entree to come out and we were beginning to wonder if he forgot to put it in.  Boulevard is a great place for a special event.
author: S And B D.

description:
I love the Ambiance of Boulevard!!!  As one would say, this is truly a date place.

I chose to try Boulevard because of the reviews it got from articles that I have read.  It seemed that most say it is one of the best dining places in SF.  So that sparked some curiosity in me.  And I wanted to spoil my friend a little.

It was a Friday night and we had reservations at 9:15.  First impression, I loved the coziness it gave off.  The mood of the restaurant was dimly lit and intimate.  But there was a good buzz from all the people.  It was very full which is always a good sign.

After checking in, the host had told us our table was going to be ready shortly and to enjoy the bar as we wait.  At first I felt somewhat disappointed asking myself what the purpose of having a reservation.  So we went and had a drink at the bar and had a seat at one of the small tables.  And no more than 10 minutes, another hostess came up to us, addressing us by our party name, holding the menus and taking our drinks and putting it on a tray that she had, and asked us to follow her to our table.  At that moment, I took back the negative feeling that I had initially, and appreciated that service of actually being more personal with the guests and making them feel that they are being serviced.

Our server was awesome.  She knew her stuff and was attentive to our needs.  I ordered the T-bone Lamb and she knew that it was not a typical order and I might not know how to properly cut into it and gave me tips on how to get the best experience with eating a bone in tenderloin of lamb.  That was absolutely a treat.  Rack of Lamb is so common, so being able to try the Tenderloin of Lamb bone in was exactly what I was looking for when looking for something out of the box cousine.

My friend ordered the halibut which she loved!  I got to try some and the combination of the perfectly cooked halibut with the toppings was definitely a treat.

One of the things that noticed... the location of the restrooms.  This might sound weird, but the restrooms was through a door marked by a curtain and you have to go downstairs where it is located.  I don't know if its the design of the building, or done on purpose, but I love how its not part of the restaurant.  Gave a sense of class in my opinion.

Definitely worth giving a try once and its a nice treat on special occasions.
author: Japen G.

description:
I looove Boulevard.  The food is soo good there.  Also love the Belle Epoque design.  

Boulevard is considered a splurge restaurant so I don't go there often but when I'm there, I've never left disappointed!
author: Wendy H.

description: Were in town for our wedding anniversary. Special dinner and could not eat here the last time we were in town for NYE. We got in at 6:15 pm. and when we walked in it was packed. We had a nice little table. The service was first class, the food was fantastic and the ambiance was nice. I wouldn't return the next time we are in SF.
author: m w.

description: Boulevard is one of the best restaurants i have been to in san francisco. And I have been2many fine dining restaurants.Waiter was super friendly, and the food is top notch. I'm a Samoan, and I eat a lot. This is NOT a place for heavy eaters. But for some reason, It was just right for my tummy. $433.18 for 5 people W/Starter, Main course and Dessert, wine not included. I would definitely come here again and again. Nice place to bring a date.
author: Sal T.

description:
When my boss said "I'm taking the team to lunch" I got excited. I didn't realize lunch would be a 3.5 hour affair. And when I'm doing 12-16 hour shifts, 3.5 hours is a big deal.  But, we won a Burden of Proof Motion in one case, and completed openings and closing in another.   No deadlines today, time to take a break.

I started with the tuna tar tare, good, but not outstanding. Pretty plating. I moved on to the Alaskan cod-- ok, not outstanding. From what I've heard about this place, I expected outstanding. 

I could've done without the pounding of the bread dough at the bar (?) during lunch - completely distracting. Service seemed slow. My boss ate four plates of bread by hisself as we waited for our apps. That's a lot of bread. The wait between dinner and dessert seemed even longer. 

My cod came with spinach, of which a small bit lodged itself between two of my teeth. Not one of my seven Team Members had bothered to point this out to me. Yay.  Fuck sake.
author: Meg W.

description:
I had been looking forward to my first Boulevard experience, taking the wife there for her birthday treat. I'm going to split my review into two sections, 1. The Food, 2. The Service.

1. The Food, as I had anticipated the quality of the food was outstanding, the flavors electrifying and the presentation inspired. Nuf said.

2. The Service, I had to call back to confirm my reservation and was kept holding the line for an unacceptably long time, then spoken to like I was interrupting something important, that pissed me off. On the night we were greeted and seated. Our waiter was OK, but watching the action on the floor I could see other waiters that were far more pleasant and entertaining, he wasn't rude and he knew his stuff, he just seemed a little boring compared to the other animated characters. Sounds over critical? Not when I'm paying top $ for my dining experience, and service is just as much a part of the experience as the food. 

Overall: This place really does impress, the building itself is sublimely beautiful, the food worldclass. Just hope you don't get Mr. Boring as your waiter.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I do not write many reviews, I do not believe in reviewing all the places you go to, just for a this or that..
We were a party of 12, company Christmas party on Thursday January 3rd at night, I am writing this as I would love to let the server know ( sorry did not get the name) that the service was excellent, such a good team work with the bussers and the food runners, I personnaly never asked for anything, got my drink, bread, wine, food in perfect seat without asking, The server was very pleasant, very attentive and had a great attitude. Food was really great, thanks Chef. Decor is really nice. Nothing to say...It was a Great memorable night, thanks to you Boulevard !! I did not put five stars because I do not believe in perfect places. But I have been working in restaurant for now 30 years, and I can say that this one is on my great list...Thank you....I definitely recommand..
author: Wilson D.

description:
I had been to Boulevard when I was like 10, which was 15 years ago and I didn't remember a thing about it. Thanks mom and dad, that money was obviously well spent! :) (sidenote: that was also the age when I claimed my favorite restaurant was Taco Bell just to make my mom mad)

Anyway, one would think that after 15 years a restaurant would feel outdated and the food would have lost its novelty. WRONG! The decor looked like it could have just been built, brick ceiling with metal beams and French looking flower glass lamps. The restaurant is very upscale yet cozy, a little French, pretty modern, very friendly servers, comfortable booths and cool glassware and dishes.

Unfortunately we came for a quick team lunch during work and we only had time to order main courses.

The Walu was served with a horseradish creme fraiche was served on a bed of lentils. I loved everything about this dish, it was absolutely fantastic!

I need to come back for a full meal or at least drinks and dessert (the desserts looked amazing).
author: Elaine S.

description: I had THEE BEST lamb I have EVER had at this restaurant. (and I have eaten at some pretty amazing places...) The atmosphere is noisy and fun, but don't let the causal environment fool you, this is a FINE dining establishment. The food is top notch and our service was on point. I have recommended this place to a number of my friends and every single one has thanked me for the reco.
author: Angela L.

description: Foodie friends of mine anticipated this dinner like the second coming.  It was awesome, no doubt. The staff was everywhere and the experience was fantabulouso.
author: Chris B.

description:
After seven consecutive years of nominations. Congratulations to Chef/Owner Nancy Oakes and Pat Kuleto on their recent 2012 James Beard award. Often dubbed the "OSCARS" of the Culinary industry.  Established in 1990, the James Beard Foundation Awards recognize culinary professionals for excellence and achievement in their fields and continue to emphasize the Foundation's mission: to celebrate, preserve, and nurture America's culinary heritage and diversity. 

BOULEVARD is nestled in the historic Audiffred Building.  In the Embarcadero Waterfront with views of the Bay Bridge, The historical building that is home to BOULEVARD is the only local structure to have survived the 1906 earthquake and the fire that destroyed major portions of San Francisco.  The building was to finally suffer from a fire in 1978 that destroyed the interior completely, but that left the brick and stone facade intact.  On May 10, 1981 was designated Landmark No. 7 of the City of San Francisco. The exterior of the building, with the exception of the atrium style top floor that was added, is identical to what would have been seen by passersby in 1889.  As you enter BOULEVARD via revolving doors it is not difficult to imagine the interior being a part of that bygone era, with beautifully crafted wood, fixtures, iron and mosaic work that graces each element of the detailed design. A fitting home for what has become one of San Francisco's landmark restaurants. Reason for mentioning the history of the Audiffred building is because the bathroom is quite far away depending on where your seated which is due to the fact that the Audiffred Building is a San Francisco historical landmark and to relocate the restrooms would be quite the arduous task. 

After quick valet and prompt seating I had a chance to just enjoy the ambiance of BOULEVARD. Very bustling downtown San Francisco business vibe. Businessman checking their stocks on their phones or talking with their colleagues about the next proposed deal was nothing but typical Downtown San Francisco. The age range I noticed was mid 30's to upper 50's. 

Starter: Local Calamari. (Stuffed with 'Nduja & Shrimp Panzanella Calabrian Chili Aioli, Artichoke Hearts, Pickled Kale & Crispy Calamari). Very tasty but not your usual Calamari you would find in bulk. Each Calamari were individually wrapped and stuffed while giving you the more traditional option of a crispy Calamari.  Artichoke Hearts with the Calabrian Chili Aioli were incredible paired with Calamari.

Salad: Bruno Del Rosso Tomato & Burrata Salad ( Star Route Organic Lettuces with Fines Herbes, Lemon, Anchovy, Caper & Chili Flake Relish, Toasted Levain Croutons & Taggiasca Olives). Very Nice Salad. 

Main: Berkshire (Kurobuta) Pork Prime Rib Chop.  Wood Oven Roasted Crispy Bacon & Sauerkraut Dumplings, Cider Glazed Turnips, Apple Creme Fraiche
Sauteed Red & Green Spinach, Caraway & Apple Balsamic Vinaigrette Roasted Pork Jus with Sage. lol.... WOW this dish was amazing. From the tender pork to the perfect compliments of bacon & Sauerkraut Dumplings this dish was out of this world. One of the best Pork Chops I've ever had without a doubt. The sauteed Red & Green Spinach were just right on and complimented the dumplings well. 

While others in my party opted for more of a chocolate dessert I decided to go with the more subtle approach. A scoop of strawberry ice cream with a simple oatmeal cookie. Strawberry Ice Cream was heavenly and the Oatmeal Cookie was once again "the perfect compliment". I can not remember the exact ingredients to the drinks I had but I can tell you what they were. If you want a mans man drink. Seriously a grown man strong drink then order "The Boulevardier" which  consists of bourbon and other tasty ingredients. I had to scale it back a bit so I went with the "Jack Rose" which consists of Apple Brandy, Grenadine, Simple Syrup, and other ingredients. Very strong and beautifully constructed cocktails. Well worth the money you are paying. 

In conclusion BOULEVARD restaurant truly deserves the James Beard Award, for I'm surprised BOULEVARD has not won the award previously. Being that a restaurant can only win the award once, BOULEVARD joins The French Laundry in Yountville as James Beard Award winners. BOULEVARD exemplifies outstanding service. With attentive and knowledgeable waitstaff, top notch bartenders, and delicious food you can not go wrong dining at BOULEVARD.

F.Y.I. - All chocolate is made from scratch in house, as well as the Grenadine for their liquors which is made from fresh Pomegranate.
author: Alastair G.

description:
I think nancy oaks is great and she gives so much to meals on wheels.  

also her husband must be amazing because I can't live without the chicken and apple adell's sausages. 

but:  maybe it's just the times I came?  Nothing had a complex subtlety nor amazing strong flavors.  Have come here only once, so maybe next time it'll be better.  I can't even remember what I ate aside from feeling like the foie was a bit overcooked. 

good service, fine vibe.
author: Hannah W.

description: Very good and tasty food. I'd give it 5 stars as the service and food is great and some of the best you will find in the city. But it is way overpriced. It's one of THOSE places that you pay $35-45 per entree and you say, "that's it?". I say go here for sure if you just wanna show everyone how much you are rollin' in the scrill, or if someone is gonna foot the check for you. If you want amazing food and you also plan to stuff yourself I say go to Tadich or House of Prime Rib.
author: Ryan E.

description:
YUMS! The appetizers were scrumptious! Best crab salad I've ever had. And dayboat sea scallops to die for. 
I couldn't help but taste across the table because everything was presented so nicely. 
I had the quail and squab with figs etc and the flavors were so deliciously combined and everything cooked perfectly. 
Everyone's plate was delicious and though my bf thought the portions were too small for his liking, I thought the quality and originality of the food definitely made up for this.
Dessert sucked but its ok because the meal was outstanding.
author: Spring L.

description:
Before reading this, note that my point of view is not that of a foodie or anything gourmet.  No doubt I'm picky ( raised vegetarian turned moody carnivore), but I'm fairly simple in my tastes - food ought to be prepared with care, taste good, and not make me sick. 
 
Alas, having now dined at Boulevard, I fear I'm losing my simplicity, my "girl next door" attitude of food...   I have interfaced with a sommelier (I think).  I have been delighted with old-vine zinfandels.  I ate a steak that would never, ever need steak sauce.  I actually have an appreciation for American food... and watch out, because now I have standards for it. 

Boulevard ups the ante with a lively atmosphere, attentive staff, and carefully thought-out plates.  The open kitchen  atmosphere shows that they are confident in their process.  The buzz of energy reminds me of nice train stations and the vibe of people being excited to mingle.   Great place for clients and business meetings, or for meeting folks visiting from out of town.
author: Maulie D.

description: We have been here twice and it hasn't disappointed.  Easily one of our favorite restaurants in the city.
author: Shellynnie W.

description:
This is a great restaurant--one of the best in the city.

Went on Sunday night at 9:30, and it was still packed. I was worried that we might be there very late because some previous Yelp reviewers mentioned that the service was on the slower side. However, our food was prompt and I never felt like we were waiting for too long.

For a starter, get the Tuna Tartare. It was outstanding.
author: Sam K.

description:
I can't say anything new here other than I really regret not going here for my birthday dinner this year!
Everything is amazing and consistent. The best deserts also. I just wish I could enjoy it more often.
author: Linda V.

description:
OK. So, I'll just get to the point. I wasn't impressed with the fancy-schmanciness. I walked into this place and the average age was 45 and I was asked if I was over the age of 21. We waited 15 minutes for a table when we had a reservation. I liked the interior design- dark wood antiquey french inspired and dim lighting. 

Now the food. My glass of wine was more like a wine-tasting. We pretty much ordered what our server recommended. Starters: Sea scallops- pretty good but there were only 2. Rabbit ravioli: a little dry, small, and only 2 again. Foie gras: kinda loved it. Entrees: I ordered the Alaskan Halibut: very dry and bland but was good when I took a bite of it with the fried squash. My friend ordered the Alaskan Salmon: also dry and bland and better when eating it with the truffle. Her husband ordered the Lamb: the best of the three, very tender and flavorful. For dessert, we had the Pumpkin cake which tasted like the bread that was served with the foie fras with the earl grey tea ice cream which I loved. 

Our bill came out to $100 a piece and our dinner lasted almost 2 1/2 hours (keep in mind, there were 3 of us).  I wouldn't come here again, but I'm glad I tried it... just to ya know, try it.  After eating here, I realized I have more of an affinity towards Asian cuisine. Well duh, I am Asian. 
-
author: Melissa V.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I am a fan of Nancy Oakes. I have been coming to Boulevard since the late 90's and have always had great meals there and have met some really interesting people as well. 

It was a Saturday night, May 31, 2014 and we had a reservation for 7:45pm. When we checked in at the front desk the hostess told us to have a seat at the bar and that they would be coming to get us shortly. After 45 minutes passed I went over to the front desk and asked why we were still waiting at the bar for a 7:45pm reservation at 8:30pm? The front desk hostess looked at our reservation and realized that the previous hostess had not checked us in. Big no no in the restaurant business like missing a wake-up call at a hotel. We then waited another 5 minutes and were seated.

Ethan was our waiter and he is a Boulevard historian and great waiter and I have been served by him various times over the nearly 15+ years that I have been coming to this restaurant. Within our party we all ordered the fish dishes and three of us thought the meals which came about 45 minutes later to the table were lukewarm and just OK. The other person in our party was just enamored by the overall experience of Boulevard and thought his salmon dish was prepared to perfection. I have had several friends from New York, Chicago and other major dining cities tell me that they did not know what all the fuss was about and thought the restaurant was good but not exceptional. I can tell you that after coming here for 15+ years my last few visits to Boulevard makes me start to see the decline that I experienced years ago at One Market Street restaurant. Taking your loyal customers for granted and losing your edge of what it takes to stay on top of the restaurant scene in a City like San Francisco. We should have been offered a free dessert or had a meal written off the bill for the various inconveniences we experienced throughout the evening. But that is not how restaurants operate when the economy is good within the City...they do not have to according to their assessment.

We all understand that the City has changed and Boulevard is a dinosaur from a business model perspective due to the changing dynamics and increased hipsters into the City but that is why you opened up Prospect right to cater to the new technology elite that have no taste they just want to be seen and fed mediocre food in a more hip environment for higher prices. 

I am sorry Boulevard but this Saturday night you missed on several fronts.
author: Reynold B.

description:
This was my first Michelin star rated restaurant experience. As such I had very high expectations of what a Michelin star rated restaurant is. I ended up going here with my girlfriend for lunch instead of dinner.
That may have been my mistake. Lunch was less than stellar and also may be due to the fact that my fiancée and I both got the burgers. We are huge fans of burgers and I base the quality of the food at the restaurant based on their burgers. Generally burgers are usually the best sellers at restaurants if available so believe this is a fair assessment to make. 
And just as I thought, most of the dishes being served were the burgers. 

The burger itself wasn't bad but definitely is not memorable. it did not have much flavor and was very simple. I like simplicity in dishes but it must be packed with flavor. However, this burger was not. Maybe it's my fault for getting the burger but as popular as it is, it should be good as any other dish on the menu. Perhaps dinner will be better. 
The service was great, attentive, without being intrusive. And their drinks are great. I had the Moscow mule and it was delicious, served in a copper mug of course. 
I'd like to come back to try out their dinner menu to get a better assessment of this restaurant. 

The takeaway is, if you're getting lunch at the boulevard, don't get the burger but try some of their other dishes.
author: Barnabas H.

description: Great restaurant and fantastic place.  The decore was cool and the service very attentive.  I keeper, for sure.
author: K H.

description:
This is a solid 3 star place, in my book.  With high per-plate prices and a michelin star come great expectations, and as much as I wanted Boulevard to meet them, they just didn't - at least in the food department.  Everything else? Fantastic.

The staff is above and beyond awesome.  Everyone was friendly, helpful, prompt, professional, and courteous - they were truly the highlight of the experience.

The interior was beautiful, with warm brick, inset lighting, and stained glass over the bar.  It was packed with people, but there wasn't really any issue with volume or atmosphere (except for the insanely loud guy behind me, but that's not the restaurant's fault!).

The food was good.  It tasted okay-to-pretty-good, depending on the dish, was beautifully plated, and served at an appropriate time.  Everything was well-cooked.  (To preface this next bit, I'm NOT a picky eater at all, and I was really looking forward to trying a michelin star restaurant.)

My real disappointment was with the duck wrapped in pancetta, served over a bed of wild rice with roasted cherries.  (There were spinach and onions involved as well.)  It sounded SO GOOD on the menu, but in reality, there wasn't a lot of flavor.  It could have been a matter of using a sauce with more punch (or more of what existed), but when I was done with the dish I was thinking of ways it could have been improved, not sitting back and thinking "yum, that's orgasmic."   

In comparison, I had some of my boyfriend's hawaiian walu with lobster-stuffed calamari - that was MUCH better.  He even liked the fried cauliflower they served, which is quite an accomplishment for him.   (He did NOT like my duck dish.)

Dessert was good - we had the chocolate cherry marquis.

So, maybe Nancy Oakes' vision doesn't jibe with mine, maybe that dish was just a fluke, or maybe my expectations were too high.  Totally possible.  But when you're charging $30-40/plate, I think you should be wowed.  I loved the location, the staff, and the experience of trying Boulevard, but I don't know that I'd go out of my way to try it again.
author: Jennie K.

description:
I have to say, I was very disappointed with this restaurant.  I was expecting great food, they do have a Michelin star after all!  This restaurant is supposed to be in the same class as Gary Danko and La Folie and it was not even close.  

It started with us arriving, 3 of us with coats, and no one asking if they could check them for us.  Then we had an 8 p.m. reservation, and had to wait 15 minutes to be seated.  Then we had to send the first round of martinis back because they tasted like water and had several large pieces of ice floating around in them. 

I started with the soft shell crab as an appetizer, thinking it would be pan fried, but it arrived battered and deep fried, so much so, that I couldn't even taste the crab.  My mother had the same thing.  My father tried the ravioli with morels which was good, but nothing too outstanding.  My aunt had the roasted beet salad, which she claimed was good, but I didn't try, so I cannot comment.

For dinner I had the sole with lobster fritters. The sole was alright, but a tad bit overcooked, and one side was fried.  It was an unusual flavor combination and I was not impressed.  My father had the lamb T-bone, which I tried, and it was delicious.  It did not, however, make up for the overwhelming lousy food that everyone else was served.  

Bottom line, if I'm even back in San Francisco, I will NOT be returning to Boulevard.
author: Courtney S.

description: Wow, exquisite food. Painfully expensive but actually felt worth it, the dishes were well thought out and all had really interesting flavor combinations. Our waiter was a little creepy/odd but didnt ruin the evening. A good choice for a treat.
author: F S.

description: I came here for a work dinner. They provided us with a very nice private room for our party along with our own bar. It was a very intimate and warm setting. Because of our size we had a set menu that night so we had a crab salad and then our choice of fish or beef. The crab salad was really delicious! It had a good amount of lump crab with a nice balance of citrus. I also loved that it came with chunks of avocado. For my main I chose the beef which was filet mignon. It was cooked well. It was tender and came with potatoes and king trumpet mushrooms.
author: Alice J.

description:
I'm definitely a blessed woman! :-)

Incredible friend treated me for lunch at Boulevard, which is just a block from my office. I was in for a FABULOUS experience!

The atmosphere is elegant, yet warm. Impeccable service. 

We started with the fresh Monterey Bay calamari. Crispy and absolutely wonderful! He ordered the dungeness crab linguine as an entree, while I went with the natural pork tenderloin. We both were astounded by the richness of flavors. Everything about the dishes was just really right and we left feeling absolutely satisfied.

I am definitely coming back - hopefully for dinner next time!
author: Simone W.

description: Excellent food and service. The halibut was perfect and the Strawberries and Cream were delicious.
author: Francisco E.

description:
I feared that I may write up too many positive superlatives married with expletives when reviewing this restaurant, but now decided that I will abstain from doing so and just tell you to GO.  GO GO GO GO.

Yes, Boulevard is not new and revolutionary if you're the easily bored hipster foodie type looking for the fresh hot young thing in which to enjoy your proverbial culinary 'romp in the hay" and then report to your friends about the morning after.  Oh no.

But if you're looking for that gorgeous, classy creature who consistently leaves you satisfied and tingling, then give Boulevard your card.

The design of the building and ambience alone was a feast for the senses.  I'm not even going to get into the service (both with our waiter and the sommelier), nor the drink, nor the food, for fear that this review will become a very bad novel peppered with aforementioned positive superlatives laced with expletives accented with numerous horrible metaphors. (it's already starting to get there) 

I will leave it at this: 'Tis beautiful.  Just... go. (buries face in hands.)
author: Mo R.

description: Loved the place, I had the Filet and it was cooked to perfection, for the dessert I went with the Vanilla Creme Brûlée it was awesome.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Went there for lunch during the week.   Even though the food was ok, the serivce needs improvement as follows:

1.  Even though we had a reservation, they seated us 15 minutes late
2.  It took them about 40 minutes to bring our food once we ordered it.
3.  The car valet took about 20 minutes to bring our car

All of these issues let us to waste over an hour just waiting which is not acceptable and makes the whole experience not worth it.   I believe that their name is carrying them for now but the service issue will catch up with them soon.   Would I recommend this place or would I go there again - no!
author: JP M.

description: Boulevard is one of those old reliable restaurants. As far as I can remember being into fine dining, they've been able to manage a consistently high bar of diverse food. Admittedly it's been a while since I've been back and I now question myself why that is. Every time I've been has been highly enjoyable. Any of the steaks (which are menu regulars), the rib eye or filet mignon is always superbly cooked, and when available the duck breast wrapped in bacon is also wonderful. Service is always solid and the ambiance makes for great leisurely meals. The caveats? If you want to eat on a Fri or Sat night you'd best be making reservations at least a week ahead of time (still true in the bad econmony). Even if you have reservations, you might still have to wait. Not that it's a bad thing (unless you're dying of hunger) as you can get to know your company over at the bar (which can also be crowded). 4.5 stars.
author: Kim N.

description: My first time in San Francisco and everything was spot on. The service, food and atmosphere were amazing. Great wine and cocktails.... and Michael Jordan was at the table next to us! It's pricey, but well worth it. I'd recommend this place to anyone for any occasion!
author: Sherry K.

description:
I loved this review:

"Love the food.
Love the service.
Love the dessert.
Love the view.

Hate the bill."

... on the other hand, for the four of us it was new years eve...  Of the wine service, the presentation, selection assistance, timeliness, and service for our four wines (two we brought in, only charged corkage on one) was extraordinarily good.  The food was of high quality and great presentation throughout.  Not a huge fan of the stuffed squid amuse buche and I thought the deserts lacked appeal (at least for me), but that is part of the dining experience to try new things.  Left completely satieated.
author: Mark V.

description:
First off I have never reviewed but I have relied on yelp for many of my positive dining experiences, so thank you fellow yelpers. However today I felt somewhat cheated out of what should have been a lovely time. 

Positives:
+ GREAT Lobster Bisque
+ Unique and classy atmosphere with an open kitchen. 
+ Good cocktail program. 
+ The rest the staff looked sharp 
+ Squash Blossom Salad was nice. 

Negatives: 
-  AWEFUL, unknowledgeable server (Chris B.) 
- He didn't seem like he wanted to be there, (I have been bartending for 5 years so I understand that sometimes you aren't too happy to be there but at least put on an act for your customers.)
- When asked about the process for their in house aged Buffalo Trace Bourbon he admitted "I have no idea". Which is fine, but I would expect him to at the least go find out from the bartender, which he never did. Was just kind of odd.  
- Sub-par burger. I've had much better at Super Duper Burger for half the price. It was  overcooked and dry even when I ordered medium rare.
-THE FRIES, where do I start... When I go to a $$$$ establishment I expect hand cut fries or at least good ones. They were frozen and out of a bag I can assure you. 
- Fries were also cold, not as big of a deal.
- When I told the waiter the fries weren't the best and clearly out of bag. He did not deny it and instead replied: "Oh I love the fries and I don't even like fries". Then maybe you are not the best critic for the subject...

In a city with such amazing food I always feel somewhat cheated when I do not have the best possible meal given the cuisine. Perhaps it was the fact that it was a lunch on a Tuesday, but still a place of this caliber should always live up to expectation. 

Cheers!
author: Cash S.

description:
My husband and I went o celebrate a big birthday with 4 couples. Everyone was very disappointed in our meal and service.
Our drinks came immediately but there was a very long wait until our appetizers were brought to the table.
2 people returned their  soup,which was cold..One person asked for a different dish, the other person waited 10 minutes for the soup to be returned.Another long wait for the main course. The flavors were just OK.No one had a great meal and one person's pork chop was tough and tasteless.
Portions were small, service unfriendly and a very disappointing experience.
We are all locals and none of us would rush back
author: Kathryn E.

description:
The food here is excellent!  We had the Monterey Red Abalone, Sonoma Foie Gras, and the Bruin Farms Tomato Salad for our appetizers.  All of the appetizers were really flavorful and in perfect portions to compliment the entrees.  I definitely recommend the Foie Gras, which was a perfect grade and richness, served with a log of toast.  

For our entrees we had the Alaskan Halibut and the Pork Prime Rib Chop.  Both were delicious and all the ingredients in each dish worked great with each other.  I will admit that the Halibut could have used a bit more acidity, but other than that it was great!  The sear on the Pork Chop was perfect and the Chop was surprisingly very moist for a pork chop.  I strongly recommend that everyone try this restaurant at least once.  The food is most definitely exquisite.
author: Brett F.

description:
BF's birthday so I decided that I ought to take him out to his favourite restaurant and it was quite the treat for both of us. 

With a bottle of wine, we started with the Ahi Tuna Tartare which is very simple and yet very refreshing. I can't think of anyway to truly describe the appetizer but it was the perfect way to begin. I had the Filet Mignon which was just cooked to perfection and the potatoes with the bacon was scrumptious. 

The BF has the lobster with prawns and I tasted a bit of the lobster which was also incredible. The meals we had were simply perfect  and the service was spectacular. I had booked through OpenTable and they immediately called to verify -- really everything was absolutely excellent.
author: Shauna S.

description:
So.... I ate there Sunday night and was having a fine enough time.  It was a nice meal.  Then the bill came, and a bunch of factors sort of aligned and I realized that I wasn't having enough fun for the money.

Everyone got one single drink, one salad, one entree, and one scoop of their homemade ice cream.  $290+ for three people including 20% tip.

That's when my focus shifted: the night before I had eaten at Jon's Street Eats with my husband.  Three courses for 2 people and that was $22 including 20% tip. YES I KNOW IT's not the same thing.  Just please bear with me: yes Boulevard's decor is sublime, the lighting, the nouveau decor, the ambience is incredible.  It's just a gorgeous space.  And like a previous reviewer states - sometimes when you're with a parent you'd pay any price to take them somewhere they can't complain about for 2 hours (i.e. the "nice" versus "fancy" thing). 

But I felt great value for money at the street cart (see my review).  Was I getting $290 worth of experience at Boulevard?  

After the check, my feelings about the experience started to unravel.  I mean, that's a **car payment**!  I'm doing halfway OK in this recession but I'm so much more aware of my money now.  

Here's what when through my mind as we paid the bill: 

1. Was the pork ribeye **that** good?

2. Is a beet salad worth $16?  Why are they pairing beets with bleu cheese?  Does that taste right?  Didn't I have a salad at Dopo the other evening that was better?  

3.  Could I make mashed potatoes as good as that?  Are whipped potatoes a new thing that everyone's doing now?  Is there something about these whipped potatoes that sets them apart from say, the food court at Whole Foods?

4. Why is my husband's filet dry?  How do you dry out a filet??

5.  I can't buy that shirt I wanted anymore.  

6. If you balance a filet on three fingerling potatoes, is it now worth 42 dollars?  

7. Why is his broccoli rabe so salty?  

8.  Can't I just buy all these ingredients and make them pretty well myself??

9.  Haven't I had a better homemade ice cream at Bi-Rite Creamery or Lush?  

10.  Where is my waitress? 

11.  I wanted those new curtains this month but now I guess I can wait until next month.    I wonder if they'll sell out by the time I can afford them...




A few months ago, I dropped the same amount of money per-person at The Bazaar in Los Angeles - maybe a little more.  Unlike here, I walked away feeling like I just got away with stealing something - food was so bright and interesting and weird and magnificently tasty and balanced.  I drank 2 glasses of the most salacious wine ever.  I ate almost every tapa on the menu. The servers were incredible.  I got tipsy and started texting and MMSing pictures of each course.  I'm still talking about that place.
