The point:  I felt like Bazaar was a wonderful way to hemorrhage some of my hard earned money and I would do it again with no problem.  I would give up things to go back to The Bazaar. I did not feel the same about Boulevard.

So have a drink at their beautiful bar and maybe get some food, take the out-of-town family there for a very special occasion.  But beware:  I think this place has passed the point of value for money.
author: Alli D.

description: So happy with this experience. Celebrated a birthday and service was great. Food was tasty and creative. We started with the ahi tuna tartare and the gnocchi and they were incredible. Then we had the quail and scallops and they were exquisite. Tables were a little crowded and noise level was higher than I anticipated. Overall would go here again. Received complimentary ice cream with a candle...that was so sweet!
author: Antonette B.

description: If you like cooking at sit at the chef's counter than this is a solid 4. Its a to of fu  to see the line chefs fire and plate the wide variety of dishes. If  not - then it's a 3.  Clean food, new American, great service, seasonal - but no real wow factor.
author: Michael S.

description: Worth the hype.  Amazing, dynamic flavor profiles on every dish, excellent service, great wine list
author: Ryan W.

description: Very good food and fantastic service.  Company was superb!  Great pit stop in San Francisco.
author: Virginia C.

description: Melt in your mouth sea bass and a wonderful wine list-- visit now.
author: Amanda H.

description: Stuffy, snooty, under seasoned, underwhelming. This place is not only forgettable but way way way too much hype has been given.
author: Justin M.

description:
This is the only review I have ever written here that basically says, "This restaurant is excellent in every single way without any flaws."

Everything, and I mean everything, about this restaurant is excellent. All food I've had is perfectly cooked, perfectly spiced, plated, presented, everything is great.   The service has always been awesome.  There when you want them, otherwise invisible.  The wine list has just about anything you'd want.

The open kitchen lets you watch the show if you eat at the bar.

For at least the last decade or more, these guys have been the #1 or one of the top few restaurants in the city, as voted by most foody places and that placement is well deserved.
author: David L.

description:
One will always enjoy a solid meal at Boulevard. In fact, for those prices a good (or great) meal is a given. What should distinguish the best from the average is the service, and my last experience at Boulevard fell far short of my expectations.

It was the night of our 5-year wedding anniversary. We started out with a crab appetizer - good. My husband had the filet mignon - again, good. I had the squab and quail duo - great. What was missing was a knowledgeable server who knew wines and cheeses (since we got the cheese course instead of a dessert). I asked about the different French wines by the glass - varietals I had not heard of and wanted a good recommendation but our server clearly did not know about the wines nor tasted them. So I pretty much got a textbook description of a few which frankly did not help so I ended up with the Patricia Green Pinot which I was told was a light Pinot which it was not. 

Then for the cheese course, I asked what the difference was between the two goat cheeses listed. Again, the server seemed unsure which made me unsure of what I was going to get. She recommended the Italian goat cheese because it's "creamier" - aren't all goat cheeses creamy by definition? I was not happy with the recommendation. I would have appreciated the server telling me that this one was a strong, pungent goat cheese in which case I may not have ordered it. In fact my husband hated it and didn't eat it.

I look forward to a better experience at Boulevard next time.
author: Miki C.

description: Came here twice- both work lunches. Professional, good service and good food, pricey , a little old timey...
author: C A.

description:
Woohoo!  As good as it gets is RIGHT!

Boulevard never disappoints.  This was my second time dining there, my first visit was years ago shortly after they first opened.  I must say years and years later, it still is as remarkable as I remember.
author: Linda A.

description:
Boulevard is an upscale eclectic eatery on the edge of the Embarcadero.  Its so stylish its unreal.  With beautiful handblown light fixtures, tripped out tile, all sorts of ironwork designs and funky funtiture, a beautiful bar complete with stained glass, and open kitcken with friendly cooks, its hard to focus your eyes on the menu.  

But once you do my friends, you will be excited, I mean real excited.   With menu items such a day boat scallops, crab salad, foie gras, sweat breads there was a lot to drool about.  But take a deep breathe, dont blow your culinary load just yet. We havent even gotten to the entrees yet.  Fish options ranged from Salmon, to Halibut, to Sea Bass all tempted my taste buds.  Being from Massachusetts, it was clear that i had to opt for the Alaskan Salmon.  And boy was it worth it.  
The wild caught Sockeye Salmon (TAKU RIVER, AK) was fire grilled and served with fried green heirloom tomatoes with aioli, pickled spring onions, and a sauteed sweet white & yellow corn with a side of shaved breakfast radish salad & green tomato salsa verde.

I remember the cocktails being delicious but after a few of them I've lost all recollection.  Just take that as a sign that they were strong.     

It's clear that the staff here puts a lot of pride into their food, drink and service.  I'm eager for my next trip to SF to try some new menu items at Boulevard.  

(A special thanks to the Tunnicliffe's for sharing this gem of an establishment with me.)
author: Ben G.

description:
Note food alone for me was only 3 stars, but the service was so fabulous that I bumped up my rating to 4 stars.

A friend had dined here earlier, and said the appetizers were out of this world, while the entrees were just plain good.  So my friend and i decided to make it a night of appetizers.  7 appetizers and a split of Crocker brought us to a grand total of $176.88 (without the hefty tip I left for our wonderful waiter).

Here's a quick run down of my thoughts about the appetizers we had:

Ahi Tuna Tartare - A simple ahi tuna tartare.  Nothing extraordinary about it, but delicious because ahi tuna tartare is always yummy unless the fish isn't fresh.

Crab Salad - Huge disappointment.  Looked and tasted like a glorified tuna salad.  Actually, it tasted worse than the tuna salads that I make for my sloppy Tuesday lunch.  Tasteless and bland.  Skip it!

Scallops - The scallops were definitely out of this world.  Cooked to perfection, melt in your mouth goodness!  Sadly, someone thought it was a good idea to include these disgusting tunips/radishes with them.  Bad idea!  I had to rinse my mouth out with wine to get rid of that turnipy taste to enjoy the other scallops!

Foie Gras - My friend loved it.  I didn't enjoy it that much, but I admit my bias:  I'm not a foie gras fan.  Never quite developed the taste for it.

The gnocchi and cheese ravioli were towards the end, so I was stuffed and couldn't really enjoy eating as much.  All I remember is the ravioli wasn't as good as the gnocchi.

Overall, I thought the ingredients were fresh and delicious, but some food combinations were not well thought out.  Probably wouldn't go here again when there are so many good eats that are nicer to my wallet.
author: Christina L.

description: Food was ok. If you want to share a plate beware of the $5 scam (per plate) for splitting that will show up on your bill. They do not tell you about the charge. $3 for a glass of club soda.
author: Ryan K.

description:
With all the raving reviews about Boulevard I had really high expectations but was sorely disappointed by the food and the service. 

The food was nothing spectacular. It was just my luck that I ordered an appetizer and main entree with very similar sauces.  I thought this was my mistake so I was pretty conscious to avoid making the same mistake when I went to Gary Danko. However, the waitress at Gary Danko assured me that the variety of flavors in their dishes would avoid any overlap. Gary Danko +1, Boulevard 0.  You'd think that the chefs at Boulevard would realize the overlap and recommend another  dish but they didn't. Strike 1.

Now, not only were my appetizer and entree similar, but the flavor of the sauce and the texture of the quail was something that didn't dazzle my tastebuds.  The sauce was all to familiar and perhaps I even had a similar dish at a less expensive restaurant.  What a disappointment. Strike 2. 

The service was okay, nothing spectacular.  The waitress came by once to see if the food was okay then never returned.  She also seemed in a rush and preoccupied.   When our dishes arrived at Boulevard, no one took the time to explain our food.  For a restaurant rated for high customer service, I would expect quality service regardless of how busy the night is.  The reason why I have this expectation is because Gary Danko was just as packed the service was impeccable.  (Gary Danko +2, Boulevard 0).

Also in regards to the seating, if you're lucky enough to snag a seat at the 6 or so tables at far end of the restaurant, you'll get a spectacular view of the Bay Bridge.  However if you're no where near there, the seating is okay. 

When we arrived early to our reservation at Boulevard, we simply stood in front of the revolving door entrance.  It was a bit awkward but we were seated maybe 10 minutes later.  However at Gary Danko, there is a bar for you to wait while you're table is being prepared (Gary Danko +3, Boulevard 0).

I was really hoping for a great time at Boulevard but was very disappointed.  I'd rather save my money and make a trip to Gary Danko. Boulevard does not even come close to Gary Danko in quality of food and service.
author: Shirley W.

description: I love their appetizers.  The main dishes were awesome too.  The desserts were beautifully decorated and delicious.  Our server was super nice and attentive.  He kept checking on us.  I made a reservation but yet still had to wait for another 30 minutes.  It bugged me but other than that this is one of my favorite restaurants.
author: Hanny H.

description:
I'd give the food 3.5 stars, but the fact that this place has good food and excellent service without being pretentious is enough to bump it to 4.

We came here for dinner around 8:45 and started with the Day Boat Sea Scallops, which were seared to perfection.

For the main course, we had the California White Seabass, which was moist and flavorful, and the California Squab & Tolenas Farms Quail.  I wasn't too crazy about the squab, but the figs on the plate were absolutely divine.  We washed it all down with a Limone Fizz and Cucumber Gimlet.

If the weather permits, definitely take a walk by the pier post-dinner to take advantage of the gorgeous view of the Bay Bridge, which I actually think is more beautiful than the Golden Gate Bridge at night (sorry if it's blasphemous of me to say so) for a picture perfect evening with delicious food as the tastetrack.
author: Jen L.

description:
I finally decided to stop into Boulevard for dinner. I wanted to preface my review by noting that I only had the appetizers and dessert. I wasn't very hungry, but I wanted to treat myself tonight to a nice small dinner that would fill me up without overdoing it. And I have been thinking about Boulevard lately, since it was so close to the office. I walked in, and the room was this beautiful Art Nouveau/Belle Epoque design: the fantastic bricked ceilings gave the room a very old, but beatiful feel. The light fixtures throughout were very serenely classic, giving the whole atmosphere a very elegant feel. I was very impressed. The waitstaff couldn't be more helpful and up to par with the best restaurants in the City-my waiter was friendly enough. 

Now comes the important part: the food. As I mentioned earlier: I only had two appetizers: I ordered the Moterey Red Abalone with Spanish Octopus: that arrived in a small boat-shaped bowl. For $22.00, I could not believe what I got: a very petite piece of octopus, which was a little unrecognizable, a few small shell beans, and I think abalone, but I wasn't sure. The problem here is that the restaurant had the nerve to charge me $22.00 for such a puny little portion. I know this is considered a high end restaurant, and I suppose one expects such small portions, but for $22.00??? Really? Then I went on to my ravioli appetizer: it was supposed to be a porcini butter confit rabbit-I got THREE SMALL raviolis-SMALL! I mean I have never ever had three small small small puny raviolis for $16.00. $16.00!!!! For THREE SMALL RAVIOLIS. And then the description said that it came with wild greens. What? Was it some sort of a mirage-themed appetizer where you have three little pieces of greens in the midst of three tiny little raviolis? And the mushrooms looked like tiny little...well...nevermind. I could barely even pick them up with my fork they were so small. And I am a mushroom fanatic! I almost asked the very nice waiter for a magnifying glass! I had the entire side of bread to try and compensate for the lack of food on my table. I would have been hungry at the end of my meal (not to mention sick at the thought of spending $38.00 for those two plates) had I not had three Amaretto Sours. I am willing to pay the price for a good meal, but come on people! Really! However, all is not lost:  the saving grace came at the end: the Chocolate Marshmallow Pie. THAT was worth the having to sit through those Barbie-doll sized appetizers. The Milk Chocolate Mouse sitting on top of the Chocolate Streusel Crust,topped sooooo beautifully with the mouth-seducing burnt marshmallow, and the two delicious chocolate chip cookies with the chocolate ice cream in the middle was the perfect way to finish my day. I basically forgot about the meal before that (until I sat down tonight to write this review). It is worth it to just go back ONLY for this dessert, and I haven't had a dessert that good since the Ile Flottant at this restaurant in Paris! I may even try the other dessert offerings at Boulevard, visiting only for those desserts. The Pastry Chef is a Goddess. I would kneel before her if I could.
author: Julien N.

description:
I don't remember much since I came here more than a year ago with three girlfriends. All I can say is that the filet mignon was DIVINE. 

Also, we were the standout minority table in the sea of whites.
author: Lin H.

description:
Food and service great as usual and great value for the quality.
Don't sit near the host station if the girl with the squeaky voice is present as she has a very loud laugh which went on throughout our entire meal.
author: Bernard O.

description:
I'm unlikely to dole out five stars, but this place is well deserving. I was recently in San Francisco on business travel, and my boss mentioned that she had made reservations for a little group to have dinner here one night. It was also conveniently located 400 yards from our hotel.

It was Monday night and the place was packed, and apparent it wasn't going to slow down. As I always do before going to a new place, I perused the online menu beforehand and already determined I was going to have the duck, wild rice with spring fennel, sauteed red & green spinach, roasted yellow chanterelle mushrooms, melted celery root, pine nuts & rainbow carrot confit. Probably the best duck I have ever had - cooked to perfection and the plating was simply divine. Oh, and you'd be foolish to skip dessert. Chocolate angel pie for me.

This place is solid; everything you want in a great restaurant - great ambiance, great food, great service. Great logo, too. The font is reminiscent of that used in the Paris subway.

Be back soon, Boulevard!
author: ellen e.

description:
Super delicious! Came here with a group of 4, and we were seated in a booth.

We ordered one appetizer, four entrees, and two desserts. The ahi tuna tartare was normal to me. My friends and I, for the entrees, either had the salmon, cod, lamb, or steak. I loved my salmon, and I believed my friends enjoyed their dishes too, especially the lamb!

However, the dessert definitely sealed the deal for me! It's been half a year since I went so I don't remember, but we had an angel food cake, and a chocolate cake, and they were HEAVEN. The chocolate was really rich, so I was glad we had the fluffy angel cake to compliment one another.

The bill was pretty big, but we expected that. I wished the bathroom wasn't so far and downstairs, but that's okay. Other than that, it was really scrumptious and I can't wait to come back for another round!
author: Evelyn S.

description: Great atmosphere in a charming setting. I have enjoyed Boulevard before. On our recent visit our seasoned server was rude and pretentious and probably should retire. The food is beautifully crafted but very skimpy in portion for the price point. It took over an hour for our meal to arrive. I am worried that Boulevard has developed attitude since their recent "best in the country" award, it's a shame.
author: Kim D.

description:
Michelin Star Restaurant: 

Went here for lunch during the week and did not need to make reservations.  The restaurant was quickly occupied by patrons during lunch hour and most were business lunches and guest in their business attire.  We were seating in a cramped little table for two.

Had the black current french soda, one lobster bisque, the crab cake appetizer, the seared scallops entree, and the oven roasted sirloin steak.  

I think the lobster bisque was good, but the salt started to over power my tastebuds.  By the time I moved onto my steak, I couldn't taste much of the steak. 

The soup and appetizer was good, maybe it was just my error on the combination chosen. 

Valet parking available which is a good idea when parking is difficult in the area. 

The lunch was about $100 for two.
author: W. L.

description:
On a Sunday evening my hubby and I walked into Boulevard with no reservations.  Lucky us, we got in. With an excellent wine and cocktail list,  I had a very good glass of cab at the bar.  The wait was not long. We got a table by the window and the place was very full.  From visitors in their athletic shoes and frumpy outfits, to gorgeous young hipsters in their finest, this is a great place to people watch.

This popular restaurant is very noisy and full of action.  We could see the chefs busily preparing food from our table.  The service is professional and our server did a very good job. ACME sourdough bread and butter arrived and  I started with a green salad: lettuces, beets, nuts, cheese, figs, and champagne grapes...excellent.  Hubby thought the lamb t-bone steak was  delicious and cooked perfectly.  I had the salmon with spinich, mushrooms, and hazelnuts...very good, but a bit salty.

Oh, but the dessert!  Excellent!  We shared a seven layer chocolate cake and cherry gallette and had to admit it was the best dessert we've had in awhile.

Enjoy this restaurant for a special event.  It is pricey.
author: Rose J.

description: I gave this place 2 stars for the wine, as the food and place was average at best. We had the swordfish, and pork, but both meals were boring, unimaginative, and lacking accompaniments to make them stand out.  The place is loud, and crowded, when the waiter asked me how the meal was, and I explained the above, he advised that due to being so busy, they have to make the meals with Subtle  tastes.  Very disappointed in this place after reading the reviews on here.
author: Craig A.

description:
I should start this review with the fact that were it not for the pastry chef this place would be receiving 3 stars, and that compared to some of the other high class, business lunch places I ate at in San Francisco they have a long way to go to catch up. What they lack in the food service department they fortunately make up for in a refined, elegant dining space, with some quaint hints of a more rustic San Francisco era, especially at the bars. If you sit towards the back of the restaurant you can also get a nice elevated view, above everyone else, of the Bay Bridge.

Maybe it was the fact that I came in alone, or that I was carrying a camera bag, or that I was wearing a cable-knit fisherman's sweater and not a suit, but for some reason I was ignored pretty heavily here by my server, who seemed to have very little interest in catering to me at all, despite how empty the restaurant was at the time. I had to stop another waiter server several times, to ask for water refills and some bread, which honestly wasn't that good anyway, although it looked great. Perhaps that is part of the reason I was a little more harsh on the food critique than I would have been otherwise, but whatever the case I expect good service, especially in this city.

I will give them credit for having a substantially diverse menu, and I wanted to try just about everything on it, so narrowing down to a reasonable selection for lunch was pretty difficult. In the end I decided to start with the spicy ahi tuna tartar with cucumber-miso vinaigrette, cilantro, and wasabi potato chips. The flavor combination was good, and you could tell the quality of the fish was top notch, but I really wanted more from the wasabi chips. I was expecting a nice, bold kick from them, but instead they were kind of flat, and not all that crunchy either. I think if they had been a little more powerful and the sauce holding the tartar had been a bit stronger this dish would have been excellent.

Having a bit of lamb envy from Nicole's dish at Fleur De Lys the previous night, I decided to go for the lamb loin medallions with yukon gold mashed potatoes, creamed wild nettles, chanterelle mushrooms, and lamb jus. Much like its predecessor, this dish lacked flavor in several areas I expected to find it. The nettles had virtually no flavor, and served little purpose in the dish other than color, and the potatoes were just bland, no hint of garlic, pepper, or even salt. The mushrooms were a nice companion to the lamb, which was thankfully cooked wonderfully, and really saved this dish.

I was so bummed by the first two courses that I had pretty much written off any chance of trying dessert, and was ready to pack my stuff up and head out to Dolores Park to take some photos of hippies. By stroke of pure luck, I happened to glance at the dessert menu anyway, saw something that really intrigued me, and wound up having what turned out to be my favorite dessert of the entire trip. The gingersnap ice cream sandwiches with pumpkin spice ice cream, Mexican chocolate sauce, and Chantilly cream I'm assuming are a seasonal dessert, so hopefully you get the opportunity to try this before they swap it out for something. Although, considering how expertly crafted this dessert was, I have the utmost confidence that Boulevard's pastry chef will deliver another knockout in its place. The flavors that were so desperately wanting in the first two courses were very much abundant in this final one, and at the end you wish you had another 2 cookies (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=hpw7UrWf51aaWKbaGGJ2hA&select=5crpl87eKBN0Q9ZnVD_tdA) on the way. Even without the chocolate and the cream, the ice cream sandwiches are simply delightful, but those 2 elements push them over the edge into the realm of magical.
author: Justin C.

description:
Service was delayed.  Ahi Tuna was savory with texture. ( this dish reminded me of Alan Wong in Hawaii).
I enjoyed the Lamb T-bone....but something was missing (including our Sommelier)
The Sommelier had no personality, he did not even bother to greet us or look us in the eye.  I would have had better wine service from a robot!  I don't know if I'll return.  The warmth and sincerity of the staff is lacking.
author: Robert L.

description:
The adjectives "amazing" and "incredible" appear so many times in the reviews for this place that I think I was just expecting too much.  

The food was quite good although the portions were tiny.  I guess I shouldn't expect any less (or more?) at a high end restaurant but I've dined at other Michelin starred restaurants and been completely satisfied with the portions.  If it wasn't for the bread I think I would have left hungry.  

I think the food & experience are worthy of 4 stars but when you factor in the prices, I have to give Boulevard a solid 3.
author: Bob C.

description: I'm quite a foodie but still hadn't tried out Boulevard.  We decided to wrangle our close friends and do a group dinner of 10 people there.  We made a reservation about 1.5 months ahead, and they booked the wine vault room for us.  The room itself is pretty cool - it's separate from the rest of the restaurant and it houses all the wine.  The one weird thing about that room is because it houses all the wine, the waiters come in every few minutes to retrieve bottles of wine, so it definitely gets distracting.  I got the crispy abalone & hamachi tartare appetizer - the abalone was good but the hamachi tartare was just okay.  The tartare wasn't super flavorful and nothing special.  For my entree, I got the quail.  It was very rich, but super good.  The quail itself was cooked really well and was really moist.  It also comes with pancetta wrapped quail leg - this was good but pretty fatty.  My friend couldn't finish her portion since it was so rich.  My husband got the kurobuta pork chop.  This was amazingly good.  Another friend of mine got the sole, and found the pasta part of it very salty.  For dessert, I got one cherry fudge bon bon.  Definitely very small for the price, but it was good.  My friend got the meyer lemon icebox cake.  The strawberry sorbet was REALLY good - great flavor and not too sweet.  Overall, the meal was good, but not as amazing as I had hoped it would be.
author: Steph H.

description:
This is a very fine restaurant with lots of hype so I was ready to get mesmerized. This place looked very classic and felt like a San Francisco  staple near the Embarcadero. I love the atmosphere and the discrete upscale feeling it emanates. The open working kitchen adds a nice social aspect to encourage conversation and provide a sideshow.  

The food is a little hit or miss. They have some staple dishes like the steak and pork chops that are excellent, cooked perfectly and sauced well. Then there are the other dishes like fish dishes that were not up to par for a restaurant of this caliber. This was bland and overcooked while the vegetables that came under the fish tasted better than the main protein itself. Service is very good and prompt to keep you feeling comfortable and intimate in the moment. A solid restaurant if you go with its trademarks.
author: Ed L.

description:
Been here three times, and I have to say, every time I've come here, I've always thought: the food is good, but it is always a bit too rich for me, and the flavors tend to fall a bit flat after a few bites.  I am not sure what it is, but it's never been a homerun for me here.  Don't get me wrong, the food is excellent, as is the service, but something is just always a bit off for me in terms of taste.  

I have to say though that everything here with chocolate is executed perfectly.  Not just good, but very good.  

Definitely come here at least one time.
author: Mark M.

description: I was really disappointed in the vegan options. not a very veggie friendly place. I'm sure that it's different if you eat meat though...so I can't really comment on that.
author: Sky B.

description: Came here w/ my boyfriend for dinner to celebrate his promotion. Yay! We arrived early for our reservation and they were able to seat us right then and there as it doesn't seem to get busy until around 6:45ish (we got there around 6). We ordered the foie gras, the soup with a fried zucchini flower, the pork entree, and the lamb entree. The foie gras was one of the best renditions I've had in awhile (glad I was able to get in before the July 1st ban) and the pea soup was very good as well. The lamb my boyfriend got was super delicious and tender but my pork was a bit on the dryer side for me personally but it was flavored really well. All in all, a good solid restaurant for a nice celebration. We'll be back next time!
author: Jennifer W.

description: What a superb restaurant!  Wonderfully spectacular (but crowded) dining atmosphere, friendly (slightly spotty) service and mouthwatering food!  While they do not have tons of options for vegetarians (which, sadly, for our server was our whole table!) they do occasionally have options, depending on the ever changing menu.  Never-the-less they were very accommodating about finding a way to please vegetarians.  I opted for the BUFFALO MOZZARELLA salad as an entree which was amazing, especially the Winter Chicory "Chopped" Salad accompaniment, and a small side of nettle- herb crushed potatoes, which was as good as it sounds!  For dessert we shared the RED VELVET CAKE which was a little dry but still amazing!
author: Pb J.

description: Once again, Boulevard proved to be one of the finest restaurants in San Francisco. For lunch today, we enjoyed three appetizers with fresh summer produce, tuna tartar, porcini mushrooms & asparagus. All were delicious & sophisticated. The two gentleman had hamburgers for entrees, I had a chicken breast salad. A nice glass of Sancerre went nicely. The waitstaff is efficient, unobtrusive, pleasant & professional. If you haven't been, you are missing out!
author: Mary D.

description: Great ambiance and service, Great food. I wish they had some more options on the menu though
author: Shirin E.

description:
Our dinner at Boulevard rounded out our wonderful trip to San Francisco. We were staying at a hotel only a few doors down and he knew this was where we would have our last dinner in our city of love. 

There is something magical (for me) being in this City. Boulevard embodied everything I find dear in San Francisco. The actual restaurant is architectually beautiful. When we first walked by the restaurant on our first day in the city, I realized that the outside of the restaurant was featured in a car commercial a couple of years ago.

I don't have refined tastes or am experienced in fine dining. I don't even drink wine. However he has traveled the world and has eaten in places from Dubai to Tokyo. We both agreed the food was amazing. We had the foie gras, calamari, swordfish, lamb, chocolate cake and a selection of cheeses. The food was beautifully plated. Our server was an older gentleman that was friendly, funny, and very attentive. Wonderful service. 

-I would definitely return over and over again. 
-It was not difficult getting a reservation. We walked by that afternoon on our way back from the Ferry Building and made a reservation for the same night. 
-Great service.
-Beautiful restaurant.
-Food was like nothing I have ever had before.
author: Miss S.

description: I've been going to Boulevard since 1999 and the food and service are consistently good. I usually order the fish of the day or filet mignon and the warm chocolate cake.
author: Konnie X.

description: My go-to spot for a dirty martini, and the food ain't bad either.  Came here to celebrate an engagement of friends and it did not disappoint.  We started off with the sweetbread appetizer and it set the tone for the evenings meal.  Between the salmon, pork and filet we all couldn't stop raving about how delicious it all was.  Don't skimp on dessert because the cheese selections and berry dessert left little fairies dancing on your tongue.  Yes, it was that good.  Can say without a doubt this place is a staple for a wonderful meal in my fav city of SF.
author: Evie B.

description: If you're visiting San Francisco this restaurant is a "MUST". Menu changes daily, food is fabulous.
author: Yun P.

description:
Ah Boulevard...you are between 2 and 3 stars for me. On my quest to complete the 2010 Michelin list of dining experiences, I made a reservation at Boulevard last night. Everything sounded wonderful and would have been if.... 

My first course, the foie gras was beautifully present but was cold in the middle and bloody! I have never had to send a dish back, this was a first for me. At $27 it really did need to be cooked properly. My dining partner continued with his abalone first course which he said was good, but not accurately described as it has a dairy based sauce (he is lactose intolerant) but was not described this way on the menu. When the foie finally returned they had simply reheated it instead of replacing it! I was very surprised that a restaurant of this caliber would do that. At the end of the meal they did remove it from the bill but I would have preferred a properly prepared foie in the first place. 

Second course for my friend was the pork ribeye/cheek and the lamb chop T-Bone for me (as recommended by the server as the best dish they had to offer). Once again they both were presented beautifully if they had been properly prepared. Both were over salted and uncomfortable to eat. The interior of both of the meat dishes was somewhat better and cooked well but could not overcome the saltiness overall. We decided to skip dessert based on the first 2 courses. 

Charming and warm decor that was drowned out by the noise level. My friend had 2 Manhattans to the bar that were inconsistent in how they were prepared. Overall 3 stars (would have been 2.5 had they not removed the foie) but it isn't likely that I would return with so many other options.
author: B J.

description:
Very disappointing considering the price and the hype
The food is just ok overall
My salmon was actually spoiled
It smelled weird and the waiter returned it himself and apologized profusely
They comped part of the meal for that reason
I don t think we will ever go back there
author: FOO D.

description: We were in San Francisco/ Napa for 5 days eating at some of the best restaurants around and kept coming back saying that this was the best meal we had.  The decor is fun and classy at the same time.  I will say when reading the reviews it appears to be ether people loved it or thought it was OK.  We loved it!  We started off with Roasted Beet & Spanish Sheep's Milk Cheese Salad.  It was very good.  My wife then ordered the Filet Mignon and I had the Salmon special that evening.  We both really enjoyed our meals.  But you cannot leave without trying there wonderful deserts.  I had the Butterscotch Pudding that put me in a coma while my wife had the Cherrie Buckle.  The cocktails were wonderful and they have a great wine list.  The place is loud which we enjoyed and service was fantastic.
author: Mickey M.

description:
I'm a line cook for Bix restaurant. I know food.

Boulevard is AMAZING.



The End
author: mel l.

description: Came here three Sundays ago to celebrate a belated valentines day with my girlfriend.  It was an extremely pleasant evening, with a great ambiance and service.  The food wasn't bad, but for the price I paid for it, it really wasn't all too inspiring.  It may help to know that I'm currently a culinary student attending CCA in SF, and I really take every opportunity I eat at fine dining establishments to glean whatever I can learn.  The plates (kurobuta pork chops and sea bass) were classically prepared without anything that stood out.  If anything, the pork chops my girlfriend ordered was a bit overseasoned.
author: Michael L.

description:
I took my daughter here for her 21st birthday last night and I wantedit to be a memorable experience; it was PERFECT.
Quality service at a restaurant like this is so important, and we were delighted from the time we checked in until we left!
I had mentioned it was my daughters 21st birthday when I made the reservation weeks ago, it seemed like the whole wait staff was aware, everyone that waited on us gave her birthday wishes!
Of course, the food was great, the abalone appetizers were exquisite.
I had the Sockeye salmon and she had a filet mignon, both were excellent.
Drinks, wine, and dessert were the best. Can't wait to return!
author: Dave T.

description: For those of you visiting SF - Boulevard is a hot restaurant and you'll definitely want to plan a special dinner here if you enjoy French-American cusine. If you decide to go, do it big or just don't. Service and food are excellent, 100%. Highly recommend the sea scallops, roasted beet & goat cheese salad, halibut and pork t-bone. There's a reason why this is one of the most popular restaurants since 1993. Boulevard exudes class and culinary talent. Have a fabulous dinner!
author: Beeta O.

description: This restaurant came highly recommended and I will say the food was amazing.  The only thing that was lacking was the service.  We waited about an hour to get our food and my friend didn't care for the dish the waiter recommended.  Not only that but our waiter was MIA most of the time.  Not what I expected.
author: Lily R.

description: So underwhelmed by my experience here, to the point of bewilderment. The price was okay but gosh everything was just so BLAH. Tuna tartare was so dull, king salmon entree was unimpressive, some of the vegetable sides were extremely bitter, and dessert...I don't even remember it because it was so forgettable. The flavors all fell flat. Our waiter was not knowledgeable about the food. I cannot conceive of this food being considered fine dining, let alone exciting.
author: Sandy B.

description: Perfect place for a beautiful night with the wife and father inlaw.  I had the Alaskan king crab pasta with the Sole...wife had the ahi tuna tar tar with salmon and dad had the ravioli with pork chop.  Food, drinks, company everything a smash hit, id love to go again!!
author: Not A Disgruntled W.

description: In early October I took my husband to Boulevard for a belated birthday dinner. It was the most wonderful experience we have ever had in a restaurant. We were seated in a private window seat. Our waiter, Hunter, D. treated us like royalty. You could taste the passion in the food. Appetizers, amazing. Our entrees, porkchop and lamb were prepared perfectly. And then...the desert... Butterscotch pudding and creamy cheesecake with corn cookie crust...intoxicating! The ambiance in the restaurant was stunning. Whenever we visit San Francisco again, Boulevard will be tops on our list.
author: Joanie f.

description:
Finally made it here after so many raving reviews!

Colleague was able to get reservations for 6 for lunch on a Friday.

Appetizers:

- lobster bisque - very creamy. Creme Fraiche was fun to swirl around. You can really taste the lobster and the portion was just right for a soup appetizer. Good consistency and good flavor. Lobster was not too over powering.

- tuna tartare - nothing to really rave about. Good but not exceptional.

- seared sea scallops w/ squid - super yummy. I liked this dish better than the soup and tuna tartare. The scallops were seared perfectly.


Entree:

- house made pasta (fettucine) w/ mediterranean (sp?) flavored shrimp & mussels - i have no idea why i ordered pasta but it was just one of those days where carbs just looked the most comforting for my stomach. I should have ordered the Kobe Bavette because looking over at my colleague's dish i almost drooled.  Anyways my dish was good, not spectacular. It was odd not to have mussels with the shell in my pasta. Maybe cause my plate was really small? Portions are on the smaller side but that's a good thing because it's lunch!


Dessert:

- chocolate macaron with dallop of pistachio ice cream on top a fudgy brownie/cake. Really good but too big for one person. 

- coffee creme brulee - decent

Cocktail:

- cucumber gimlet - more on the tart side but not overly sweet and you can really taste the cucumber. Luckily it was not really strong so it was still ok for lunch :)

Service: 

- not bad but they did not re-fold my napkin when i left to use the ladies room.  Other than that everyone was really nice. It wasn't quick but wasn't really slow either. 

I would definitely want to come back for dinner.
author: Terry D.

description:
Can't think of a single bad thing to say. 

Our server and the bartender were professional but not stuffy. Everything I ate was just delicious. And I ate nearly everything on the menu.

One of my dining companions was a little disappointed in his meal (he had the steak--I tried it and thought it was good), but said it was probably because he had such high expectations anything less than transcendent would have been a let down.

Go. You will like it.
author: Sid N.

description:
Outstanding. Boulevard a gorgeous space that felt very 1920's and French. Great ambiance. The scallops and the quail were both excellent. The steak was good, but ordering it was probably a mistake with all of the other interesting entrees. Excellent cocktails. The only slightly off note was desert, we tried the chocolate option and the apple cake. Neither lived up fully to the rest of the meal.

Boulevard's price point is a notch above other restaurants in the area but the value is definitely there. Reservations are necessary and can be challenging.
author: Robert J.

description: One of my favorite places in San Francisco.  Traditional yet relaxed.  Lively, yet romantic.  I've never had anything to eat here that didn't hit the spot, a perfect blend of flavor and presentation.  I only wish it were closer to my house so that I could go more often.
author: H. H.

description: Very friendly yet non-intrusive service, great food, great atmosphere. Highly recommended!
author: Jeff K.

description:
Came here to celebrate an anniversary.

Was very excited....but.....
Lack of service..service was really slow..It was a lot of sitting and waiting. Sitting and waiting ....waiting to order, waiting for food, waiting to pay the bill, my goodness!

APPETIZER:  Scallops which was cooked perfectly. 
MAIN: walu fish and BBQ pork ribeye both full of flavor.

RESTROOM: was like a scavenger hunt. Went thru a door which led me to an elevator. Had to turn right and go down down down these steep steps. I noticed that other people were confused about to where the restroom was because I saw them headed in the wrong direction too. That made me laugh in my head because they did what I did just 10 second later.
author: Omi Y.

description:
Food was good but not great.   

We ordered two fish dishes and both came out a bit oily and over cooked.   Either they were expecting us to finish our starter sooner and let our mains sit in the warmer too long or they just overcooked them.

The service was top-notch.   we did feel a bit rushed; maybe that's because the service was on top of you at times; i.e. starters removed and immediately, within 10 secs, the mains arrived. 

I would only recommend this place if corporate or someone else is picking up the bill; the quality did not match the price.
author: Aus B.

description: Interesting place. Great reviews, beautiful interior and very good service. Everyone I speak with seems to love the place. Me not so much. Food was good but quite pricing. There was a partron at the next table that was distressingly loud. When my dinner arrived there was something on my plate that was completely unrecognizable. I placed it to the side, under the edge of the plate and forgot about it. The Alaskan Halibut was delicious. At the end of the meal when the waitress came to clear the table she saw the item and thought I was "...playing some sort of joke." She saw the thing and thought it was a small dog turd. We talked about it for a bit and it took some convincing that it came with the meal. I don't think she ever comletely believed that the item came on the plate. I won't go back.
author: Bryan B.

description: Boulevard continues to be our goto place for a romantic dinner or where we take family members for a special dinner.  Their service is top notch and is unsurpassable as seen when the servers continually, without being annoying, asked us if we needed anything and even went so far as sticking something under our table leg when from afar they noticed that out table was a bit wobbly.  The food is memorable, savory, and the portions are appropriate.  The crab cakes were to die for and were the best we ever had, as they were cooked to perfection, made from quality meat (not just a bunch of claw meat or breading) and our main meals were beyond delicious.  As my husband and I work so hard we occasionally need a special night out and Boulevard continues to be the restaurant we visit for special occasions or when we feel we need to treat ourselves to the best food and service.
author: T J.

description: Came here with my in-laws to celebrate my husband's birthday. From the service to the food, everything was excellent. The waiter was knowledgeable and enthusiastic. I decided to become adventurous and tried the foie gras - best thing ever! Especially with the toast. The lamb, pork chop, and fillet mignon entree's were all cooked with great flavor and perfection. Good times!
author: Jenn G.

description:
The view is amazing! If you want to have a nice romantic dinner and just gaze into each others eyes all night and don't really care what the food taste like, this is the place for you. 

It was girls night out for us. I ordered the halibut and I felt it was over cooked and lacked flavor. I also tried the dishes my girlfriends order and felt everything was kind of flavor less. With so many restaurants to choose from in San Francisco, I would have to go elsewhere.
author: Nicole C.

description:
My husband and I were given a gift card of $200 to spend at the Boulevard--our first time.  The first thing I noticed on entering was how many white shirts+black tie and/or vest are working there, moving about in seemingly huge numbers, giving it a very busy, darkly lit, dressed-up banquet but near-taverny type-of-atmosphere.  It felt like a lot of fun to be here.  Thankfully the carpet helped to dim the noise.  
     The waiter was very cordial, always looking after us.  At times, near the dinner end, I thought he was putting an oddly-timed self-interest first to butt-into our intense conversation to ask how the dinner was going.  Ok that was forgiven, but not for half the food we selected. 
   We ordered 2 Starters: Dungeness Crab salad and the Calamari.   The crab salad had 3 slivers of crab about 2.5 inches long x 1 inch wide and 1/3 to 1/2 inch thick, laid naked atop 3 thick pieces of avocado, with a melon dressing and sprigs of greens here and there.  I have seen more crab meat in 1 joint of a crab that I had cracked myself at Fisherman's Wharf than I saw in this dish.  What a joke.  For $18, that was the dullest, most unimaginative salad with not enough crab to make up for the lack in ingenuity.  Before ordering, I actually had considered the salad would be sufficient for me without ordering an entree. That much avocado on anyone's plate is an appetite killer and who wants to waste the entire dinner experience on something I can eat at home for 50 cents?  Ha.  
    The Calamari was rubbery with a flavor nothing to write home about, my husband reports, costing a whopping $17.  I'd say these starters should not have been on the menu.  Someone in the kitchen needs help with salad making.  Even the rich and famous deserve better salads/appetizers.
    On to the dinner.  I was plenty hungry after the slivers of crab so I ordered the prime Pork Chop with fig dressing and spaetzle dotted with lentils, with cooked spinach for $38.  The last time I spent that much was nearly the cost of our entire dinner in the East Bay.  The chop was done perfectly at slightly pink, the dressing was a nice fruit-sweet balance to the salted seasonings on the chop and spinach.  There were only 4 spaetzle pieces on this nearly empty plate so I immediately asked for more and a side dish of spaetzle was supplied right away.  Ok things were looking up.
      The Filet was great tasting but paying $48 seems way too excessive.  At these prices, I began to think about the giant payroll of this place.   My husband had asked to replace the mashed potatoes with spaetzle - he also got only a few curls  of spaetzle next to his filet so he asked for more.  What's up with meager amounts of spaezle on a plate that already looks empty (like mine did) save the dot of meat at the center?   The young broccoli stems were impossible to chew so he asked for spinach since mine seemed passable.  He got the side of spaetzle OK; however they charged him another $7 for the additional spaetzle.  Ballsy !! -- given the price of the filet dinner, wouldn't it just be decent to include it?   Is this how the 1% make it to the top?
    Nothing on the desert menu looked interesting so my husband settled for a tiny scoop of OK Chocolate sorbet....($5.00) in a huge bowl.  I was so fat-satiated from the 6 oz pork chop I couldn't consider another thing.  Wise decision on my part not to eat the avacado before dinner.
   Next time I will definitely look for somewhere else to eat in SF....the meager value of a $153 meal plus tip and SF taxes topping $200 doesn't ring true for me.  No wine included and one drink.  I don't spend that much on groceries for the week.  Have the rich lost their minds and put up with poor starters and punny spaetzle portions?
author: Kate S.

description: Avoid it!!!  Food poisoning.  I had dinner there last night: Ahi Tuna salad to start with an halibut as main menu.  The Ahi tasted ok, not great.  The halibut was dry and tasteless.  The real problems started when I got home.  Total food poisoning - pain, cramps, diarrhea - the works...  It's 15 hours later. I didn't sleep all night and am only now starting to feel a bit better.
author: Elazar H.

description:
Thanks Nishy! Excellent suggestion for my stop over in San Francisco the other day! Loved the Tuna Tartare, my salad was "so-so," the orange infused sea bass with veggies was unreal, and my friend's veal shank looked rather tasty.

Four stars because they were completely out of anything with the word "ravioli" in it... which would have been excusable but the waiter later informed us that anything with "chocolate" in it was also not available. 
 
So... with that said I guess it's safe to assume that a lot of people are quite fond of Boulevard's raviolis and who could turn down chocolate cake!?

Date Rating: 9
Pick up Scale: 4

Strong Suggestions: If you have dinner sooner than later then they won't run out of something you might want to have for dinner.
author: Megan C.

description:
It's so @#$#@ good I have to write a review even though there are 12 bilion reviews already.  First course:  buffalo mozzarella/heirloo tomato trio and the daily special deep fried soft shell crab with fried beans and pickle.  Loved the crab.  Filet mignon was extremely tender and as tasty as American beef can be.  Halibut was perfectly cooked but order it only if you like a very strong, smoky mushroom flavor.  Dessert:  key lime tart with blueberry granita and ice cream.  Good service from waiter who gave honest, educated suggestions.  $25 corkage fee.

Where they can do better:  Better eye contact, maitre d says thank you for coming while staring into lala land.  Same thing with waterboy.  Waiter rushes a bit but the food sure makes up for all the minor details.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
This is one  of the best meals I have had all year. Definitely on a par with my much loved and exalted Saddle Peak Lodge Mother's Day dinner.  Mom got trashed that night and this was nowhere near that entertaining. However, the food was amazing, the service was far superior to Saddle Peak Lodge and the whole experience was wonderful.

I started with squid stuffed with bacon, potato and onions swimming in a tomato broth.  Delicious.  I wonder if I could ever replicate this?

D had summer truffle shaving covered tortellini stuffed with ricotta cheese and braised mushrooms.  It was delicious but not my favorite dish.

For a main course I had halibut served over a summer squash risotto, with brandade (a tuna mixture) stuffed squash blossoms, lightly fried.  I ate every morsel even though I was getting full.

For a main course, D ate black cod over yellow corn nage with a lush foam...very flavorful and even though the ubiquitous foam is a little gratuitous for his liking, the flavors were delicious.

We had a great evening, and I will be going back the very next time I am in the neighborhood.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
So Disappointed!

My husband and I  were taking visitors from Manhattan, well-travelled, well-heeled, out to dinner. Though we hadn't been to Boulevard for several years, we didn't hesitate when it came to choosing a restaurant: we both had magical memories of the food and the service at this place, & felt sure we'd all enjoy the experience. Sorry to sound a discordant note in the chorus of praise from recent guests, but we were startled by the evening's events. Our wait person had manners appropriate to an Applebee's . She was obviously both bored and overworked, & rattled off the evening's specials as quickly as possible. We waited a long time before the starters arrived. One of us had something he described as "2 fried eggs & some polenta," described by the server as one of the stars on the menu. The rest of us had heirloom tomatoes with burrata, pretty but totally tasteless---what on an ordinary menu would be called "caprese" & contained more basil. Two of us then had lamb, which was acceptable; one had soft-shell crab which he obviously found quite ordinary (leaving half a small portion); another some kind of salmon sushi, and I a broiled calamari, the latter 2 from the starter menu. My calamari was truly awful---strangely seasoned, oddly plated, with a texture somewhere between denim and horsehair. Desserts were sorbets for a couple of us; one cheese (straight out of the fridge). No one offered us coffee; during the meal, we ran out of bread, which was not replenished, and there were long hiatuses between courses which was OK because we had lots to talk about, but they WERE inordinately l-o-n g. 
We went on Aug.31st. The place was crammed with what appeared to be tourists---lots of shorts, ripped jeans, T-shirts, baseball caps. 
We concluded that a) Boulevard must be coasting on its reputation; b) its summer crowd must be composed mainly of out-of-towners drawn by said reputation, who know little about food or drink, and c) to be on the safe side, we will henceforth go to Zuni, even if it's not tourist season!
author: Helen P.

description: Best restaurant in SF hands down! Never had a bad experience at Boulevard year after year. Excellent menu that caters to everyone. Superb meal served by an impeccable staff.
author: S F.

description:
best for special occasions.

the food and service is fine and all, but the portions are not for adults. my favorite thing here has been the pork chop, but i probably won't be back for some time. the snoot factor is pretty high, perhaps the usual ratio with portion size.
author: Mr G.

description:
Boulevard has been  one of my go-to restaurants for special occasions, but after my last visit, I don't think that I'll be back.

From the moment we walked in the door, we were off to a bad start. The hostess was busy trying to accommodate a couple without reservations and spent several minutes looking at her records, scanning the restaurant and consulting with another employee. The entire time my boyfriend and I stood there waiting without ever being acknowledged. I wasn't hoping to cut the line, but even at most cheap joints you are welcomed and told that you will be attended to soon. When the hostess did finally address us, she did so with zero personality (our server had a similar disposition).

When we were seated the hostess asked if we needed anything. I mentioned the I had a headache and would appreciate a glass of water. She said that she would ask our server to bring a glass right away. Well, we waited about 5 minutes for a server to appear and when she did, she was either unaware of my request or had forgotten about it. She asked us if we would like any water while we looked over our menus. I said, "Yes" and then waited for another 5 minutes for the water to arrive. (So, I'm not obsessed with water or anything, but I also want to mention that, once we had it, the busboy that was refilling our glasses kept doing so with such speed that water sloshed out onto the table every time. That didn't really bother me, but it did seem sort of haphazard for an upscale restaurant).

Now on to the actual food, we ordered scallops for a starter and the first one was TO DIE FOR! It was so delicious that I was starting to remember why I had so loved Boulevard in the past. Then we moved onto the remaining two...both my boyfriend and I agreed that they were the sandiest scallops we had ever tasted. I don't cook seafood (who am I kidding, I don't cook anything), so I am not sure if a cook has anyway of weeding out a sandy scallop. It doesn't change the fact that the texture made eating the last two totally disappointing.

As entrees, I ordered the filet mignon and my boyfriend had the lobster with spätzle. I thought that his meal was quite good, but he didn't love it. Neither of us were very impressed with my filet. Also, I asked for a substitution (I prefer mashed potatoes to the fingerling potatoes that the filet was paired with) and it came out with fingerling potatoes instead. 

Since we both love sweets, my boyfriend and I ordered two desserts to share. The cinnamon ice cream that came with one of them was excellent. Other than that, both were average. 

Finally, when the bill came, we noticed that we had been charged an extra dollar for my boyfriend's entree. Given the $150+ total, we didn't even bother to mention it, but it was just one more small disappointment on an underwhelming dining experience.

Overall, the service was below average and the food was OK. At a neighborhood restaurant I would have given a similar experience two, maybe even three, stars, but a restaurant like Boulevard doesn't get the same level of leniency. If it wants to attract the prices of a restaurant that specializes in fine dining, it needs to perform like one.
author: Nata B.

description:
Boulevard is the absolute PERFECT date night and/or special occasion restaurant...so of course I haaaaddd to go there in celebration of my 25th birthday!!!

The service was impeccable.  We were greeted immediately and taken quickly to our table which was situated right in front of the kitchen (so much fun watching everyone cook!).  Since we were celebrating a milestone birthday, we dressed to the nines but the atmosphere---while posh---was very relaxed and I would have felt comfortable even if I wasn't wearing a cocktail dress, heels, and a vintage cardigan.

Our server was very attentive, enthusiastic, and helpful.  I got the special lemonade and it was amazing.  For dinner I had the mozzarella salad and the raviolis.  I've never liked truffle oil, but lemme tell ya, REAL truffles are out-of-this-world delicious.  I practically licked my plate clean!

The sweetest part of the night is when our server brought dessert they had put a piece of chocolate on the plate that said "Happy Birthday!" and he lit a candle for me when he placed it on the table!  It was the perfect ending to a very wonderful meal.

Even their website is overflowing with elegance and charm.  I can't wait to have another reason to celebrate, because off to Boulevard it will be!
author: Bunny R.

description:
no matter what ppl say, I love their food !!!!!! 
I had a great experience!!!
author: lily y.

description: This was my second time here and I have to say I was truly disappointed. I remember it being so much better before. The food was still pricey but the flavor was just not there anymore. I had the filet mignon and the pear salad. The filet mignon just had way too much going on. They even put bacon bits on top. It just killed and overdid the dish for me. The salad was all over the place with not enough flavor for it all to come together. I also ordered the brownie and ice cream dessert and was even disappointed with that! Not sure if they changed chefs since the last time I was here a few years ago, but I have to sadly say I will never come back. Should've gone out for pizza instead. Truly disappointed.
author: Food L.

description:
I really want to give this place a 4 1/2 with a 1/2 deduction for the cost - over $500 for four adults and one 9yo. The food, service and ambiance were all top draw. My order was stuffed calamari (starter) and the highly praised pork chop both were excellent tho' the pork could have been a tiny bit moister. My wife had the ahi tartar and guinea hen and she loved them both. My grandson had two starters, the calamari and quail and he said the were of the highest quality (Note: His dad is a professional chef and he is used to eating gourmet stuff and has developed a very sophisticated palate already.) My son had the lamb and couldn't stop praising it. My d-I-l is a vegan so they whipped up a nice couple of concoctions  but nothing spectacular. The wines - an Ancien Pinot Gris from Sonoma and a Zin from Carnerous - were superb. Finally, the three desserts - almond ice cream, mixed berries, dark choc with crumbles - could all win prizes. 
All in all, a great time was had by all.
author: Victor G E.

description: We went here for my birthday dinner. I learned how to decorate, garnish food on the plate from this restaurant, which is good. But for me, kind of heavy taste and over priced.
author: A J.

description: This was our 4th (5th?) visit to Boulevard, which is pretty good for a visiting couple. For the first time, we were somewhat disappointed with both the food and the service. We tried a pork dish, which had a marvelous flavor, but was w-a-y overcooked. They replaced it with a properly cooked dish, but overcooked food at a Zagat 27 restaurant is not acceptable. Sorry to be a pain, but we all know that's true. The waitress was pleasant enough, but in a very robotic, plastic way. We've had much warmer service at Boulevard in the past. All in all, I'm used to better from Boulevard. We'll certainly go back (I guess everyone's entitled to an off day) and hope for a better outcome.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Anyone who's read some of my earlier posts (hi, Mom!) knows that I often struggle to find places to take my parents for meals.  It's not that they're shut-ins or suffer from any kind of dietary restrictions.  Rather, they have a pronounced aversion to anything that is "fancy".  The meaning of "fancy" according to my parents is a moving target: an expensive restaurant that serves steak and french fries would not be "fancy," whereas a hole in the wall with exotic-sounding entrees would undoubtedly be too fancy for their tastes.  I guess you just know it when you see it.  Long story short, while I am always excited to get a visit from my folks, finding the right dinner spot is nearly impossible.

Boulevard, however, got the job done in spades.  I've always been a fan of the inventive, yet consistent, American cuisine, and thankfully, my parents were too.  While I almost lost them when I ordered the tuna tartare (which is pretty much ubiquitous at this point), the steak (which my mom said was the best she had ever had) and pork chop (which my dad devoured in approximately 90 seconds) were big crowd pleasers.  Boulvard is loud, and always packed, but you know that you're going to get a good meal every time.  It may not be my absolute favorite restaurant in SF, but it's always a great option, especially with guests from out of town.
author: Ty D.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in the city.  The food is always excellent, the service is friendly, and it's the only place I know of where you can find Castalia pinot noir.

Their short ribs rank among my most memorable meals.  Unfortunately it's been a couple years since I last caught them on the menu, which changes based on the quality of ingredients available to them.  They also offer a vegetarian option (you have to ask about it) which consists of most of the vegetable components in the menu items.  I've ordered it at lunch before and it was just as good as I'd expect.  The presentation was thoughtful and it felt like more than just a bunch of side dishes arranged on a plate.

The desserts here are consistently delicious and beautiful.  I've sat at the bar and only ordered dessert on more than one occasion.  The bartenders are friendly and accommodating, so I never mind eating dinner at the bar if the wait for a table is long.

A while back I splurged on dinner at Gary Danko, and it was great, but when the check came all I could think about was that I could have eaten at Boulevard twice for the same amount of money.  Boulevard is a little pricey, but worth every penny.
author: J W.

description:
For the money that you're spending here, you would expect a lot more. 
I had the ahi tuna tartare, which was pretty good but the lamb t- bone was a disappointment. It came out really bloody and soggy looking, and tasted bland. Service was fine, nothing spectacular so obviously i would just tip the normal 18%. However after my bill was taken away, I saw our server take a look at our bill and tip and shook her head exasperatedly. She seriously did a double take. I mean, what did you expect?
author: Heidi T.

description:
Okay, this review is based on my not-refined palate.

All the stars go to the service.  EXCELLENT SERVICE!!!  Amazing waitstaff!!

I ordered a dinner-sized portion of scallops because I didn't order an appetizer.  Scallops are only on the appetizer menu, but since I didn't order an appetizer, one of our fantastic waiters asked if I wanted my dinner to be scallops & I said yes, please.  Most of the time you have to worry about overcooking scallops; don't want 'em rubbery.  Mine, however, were almost sushi-like, pretty soft & gooey.  

The s'mores dessert was, believe it or not (I have a sweet tooth), was WAY TOO RICH for me that I couldn't finish it, and it wasn't a big serving.  

If good service is high on your list, you will not be disappointed at all here.
author: Pineapple C.

description:
This is a very nice restaurant near the Bay Bridge in San Francisco.  We dined here for a friends birthday.   Would really like to rate this place 5 Star, but just cannot.  
Pros:  This place is very nice, white tablecloths.  Excellent service..truly GREAT service  The sommalier is very helpful and they have a very, VERY nice wine list.  They offer great wines at all price points.  The appetizers are really good, though small in portion.  
Cons:  The steak was really not that great for the price, the salmon was over done.  And again, for the prices..the portions are really under sized.  I am not saying we were looking for the all you can eat...just really small portions.
Overall:  I recommend this place if in San Francisco.  Dont forget the view of the bridge, ask for a table with a view.
author: Christopher C.

description: The one star and not zero is for the server. He was decent. The lobster soufflé was ice cold (confirmed that was not how it was supposed to be served). The crab was entombed in a greasy cocoon.  My wife's saltimbocca had a thick layer of (not very good) cheese, which should have been a bechamel. Disappointed.
author: workingstiff f.

description: With its ambiance, great location on the Embarcadero, and amazing menu, my dinner at the Boulevard was simply one of the best I've ever had.
author: Ammar A.

description: Aces across the board. I've been there 4 times and have never been disappointed. $$$ I know, but this place is one of the few that actually delivers product worthy of the price, and they have an open kitchen with counter seating :)  So I believe you can rely on them if you're chasing tail or simply looking for creative, well-prepared food. Oh, and don't forget dessert. Whoever works pastry is a mad genius.
author: John H.

description:
Amazing restaurant and dining experience.

I went here with family to celebrate and the restaurant met our high expectations both with the delicious food and spot-on service.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
I had one of the best dinners by far on Sat night. 

It first starts with the excellent wait staff. Our waitress was friendly, non pretentious and helpful.

Second was the food. The Hardy pinot recommendation was excellent and perfect blend for the food. Appetizers of ravioli and scallops were perfectly prepared, tasty and delicate. 

The main courses were again prepared with care. I had a rib eye pork chop. Never heard of it but I was blown away by the texture and flavors. It was cooked medium to perfection. Soft, buttery texture with a light crust. Wow. Our other diners had similar successes.

Finally be prepared to be amazed by the desserts. We shared creme brulee, eclaire and banana creme pie. Light and not heavy. Not overpowering to keep the meal in balance. 

We left the restaurant very satisfied but not bloated. This is dining at it's finest. 

Oh, food excellence ain't cheap. Be prepared to tack on the SF 4% food tax to an already expensive meal.
author: mike l.

description:
Thank you to my old boss for inviting me to her team dinner at Boulevard. 

It's been years since I've been.. literally YEARS.. Wow I don't remember it being this yummy. 

The service was fantastic.. The ambiance, very lush.. 

I started with the Lobster bisque.. I enjoyed the presentation and the flavors were delish.. 

My main course was the scallops with cauliflower. it was pretty good.. 
I recommend these two if you're not starved but want a tasty meal.. 

I'll come back again, SOON..
author: Monica S.

description:
Boulevard is AMAZING!  Granted, it is quite expensive but its definitely the place to go if you want the best meal of your life.  

I went with a party of 7, ranging from 25 to 58 years old.  We ordered the Ahi Tuna Tartare, Scallops, Calamari, and Tortelli as appetizers.  For entries, we ordered the Sea Bass, Pork Prime Rib Chop, and Filet Mignon.  Everyone insisted that their dish was the best sea bass, pork chop, or filet mignon they had ever had.  

No complaints whatesoever - I only wish I could afford to go here more often!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Boulevard is perfectly located-- right in the Financial District for the perfect after work dinner with an excellent view of the newly lit Bay Bridge.  It has a great lively atmosphere, and the food is superb.  I had the fava agnolotti and crispy sweetbreads as a starter-- loved the sweetbreads.  Perfect texture and a fantastic start to the meal.  For my main, I had the angus filet mignon medium rare-- well seasoned and just the right amount of chewiness.  For dessert, I had the rhubarb apple crisp.  It wasn't bad but nothing extraordinary.  The dark chocolate mousse, however, seemed to be a hit at the table.  

Service was mediocre-- definitely something for their staff to improve.  We had to call for our waiter's attention multiple times, and one staff member definitely knew nothing about the cheese plate (calling cheeses the wrong names).  Also, if you're looking for a place for intimate conversation, go elsewhere.  It can get noisy, which is a pro or a con depending.  

Aside from the service, an all in all good experience.
author: Alice Y.

description:
Amazing food. 
Amazing wine.
Amazing service.
Amazing location.

This was one of the best meals I've had. Despite my super sourface during Valentine's Day. P & I got dressed up and had a great time here. 

P tried foie gras here for the first time which he thought was delicious. 

We had a bottle of great veltliner, lobster, and sea bass. All fantastic. And then moscato and scotch for dessert. 

Very classy but not a snobby joint.
author: Candice L.

description:
Both times we've been to Boulevard, the food has a disappointment.  The dining room is beautiful (best lighting in town) but it's not enough to make up for their generic, overpriced cuisine.

Boulevard's menu could charitably be described as "traditional."  It's pedestrian fancy-restaurant fare-- filet mignon, fois gras-- executed without style or subtlety.  Their cooking lacks zest-- drab flavors and unimaginative ingredients prevail.  This is not a meal you're going to write home about.  

Tonight we got squab (gross, over rare, left a weird aftertaste)  lobster (bland, forgettable) ravioli and salad.  With some drinks and desert, almost $200 with tip!

Crowd: biz cas, of a certain age

Suitable for: your grandma from Kansas
author: Amar P.

description:
What an amazing place. The ambiance is great and the building has a lot of history. We had a late evening reservation and when we came in the hosts were great. They sat us immediately, took our jackets, etc. etc. (we felt welcomed). Not only that but we had the best view in the house. We were right at the Embarcadero and Mission corner with a great view of the Ferry Building and Bay Bridge (ask to be sat here if at all possible). 

Our server was Ken. He was very attentive and gave great recommendations throughout our meal. He helped make my wife's birthday dinner a true success.
author: Josh J.

description: We had 2 seats at the Chefs counter.  The seats are not the most comfortable... but the food, smells, and watching the kitchen in action makes the dining a fun event.  We came home with a mental notebook of recipies and presentation tips for our next dinner party.  Ahi tuna, beet salad, swordfish, pork loin... oh my!  Great, attentive service, wine list, and menu choices.  A must if in S.F.
author: Chloe C.

description: The atmosphere and the restaurant design itself was beautiful. As the for came, my thoughts changed. The service was poor and unresponsive. They wouldn't poor the champagne. The burrata was average. The filet mignon was average as well. Dessert was quite boring. Not a great experience. Not worth the price and one michelin star.
author: Max V.

description:
This place is a scam.

If I were to offer you the following deal:
1. Pay a little over $200 for two.
2. Wait 25 minutes for your table which you ordered 2 weeks in advance, while crowded near the bar with 20 other people who are also waiting for their table.
3. Find no decently priced wine on the menu.
4. "Enjoy" mediocre, outdated "french" food arriving in small portions: Calamari starter had ok calamari but came with a bland crab bisque; Beet ravioli was decent, no more; Lamb rack was overcooked; Lobster was rather good, not great though.
5. Top it off with the worst desserts I tasted in a while - we did not finish more than a quarter of them, and we are usually (especially GF) big dessert fans. 
6. Receive little attention from server, including no question or inquiries after leaving 2 desserts almost untouched.

would you take the deal? I vote no way.

Don't get me wrong, I'm happy to pay a decent sum for a classy restaurant with good food. However, paying that much for mediocre food and bad service is not so appealing.

Unfortunately, Taylor's Automatic Refresher was closed by the time we finished dinner, so we couldn't console ourselves with milkshakes.
author: Yair L.

description:
Came here last week as a surprise from my husband! Delicious! We had a great table, excellent service (Thank you Danielle! She was very knowledgable, honest and gave great rec's!) and of course, amazing food. I can't say anything new - I mean what else could I possibly add that hasn't been said!? The tuna tartar was amazing. This is a great special occasion spot - along the lines of Spruce, etc.

My only complaint is that the bathroom is FAR away - but if that's my only complaint - eh, not really a big deal!
author: Isabel M. L.

description:
Never Again. Sorry no way! Not sure why and what makes this restaurant so special. I went there last night and was greeted by a hostess who said that we "should entertain ourselves at the bar". After about five minutes of standing staring at bar tender we were approached us and told that "I will be right with you" at which point he disappeared to the back of house. 
Still waiting at the bar which is really just more seats and nowhere but the sever station to stand we were cut off physically by a female server who never even made eye contact and as we backed up now having decided we had had enough "entertainment" a younger male waiter pushed his way between us and walked ahead.
Really this place can take its star and place it somewhere.
We left called the concierge at the St Regis who directed us to Water Bar where we received attention and care as well as any amazing meal without the noise the bad smells and the attitude of complete disinterest from Boulevard staff. In addition we sat and looked at the light installation on the Bay Bridge and it is worth seeing alone.
It is rare to see a restaurant try and jam as as many people like sardines but every walkway id narrow, every area at the bar is for seating and there is nowhere to go should you arrive 5 mins early for a reservation.
author: mark S.

description: We had dinner in this restaurant tonight. The food is terrible. The reason I still give one star is the waiter is very nice do good services. We ordered quail and pork chop well done but all came with pink red. The  mushroom all disappeared after pork chop reheat and never eat such terrible pork chop before. My niece ordered filet mignon medium but came with well done. We were in Benu last week had quail and little steak.  Boulevard is not anywhere close to Benu. I think many restaurants could do much better than Boulevard.
author: Janet L.

description:
My boyfriend and I went here last night for a late valentines night out. Honestly, the food here was just okay, but not what i would have expected from a $140 dinner. I have definitely had better food elsewhere, and for less money. We were both dressed pretty casually, but he was treated rudely when he asked to use the bathroom, seemingly because they assumed he was some sort of riff-raff? He had to explain to the staff that he had a table. Also when I ordered my wine they just slapped a full glass down on the table. I think the only time I've never been presented with the actual bottle and allowed to taste was at the Olive Garden or something like that where you're either ordering just red or white.

The kicker is the horribly violent food poisoning that has had him throwing up and shaking in bed all day today. For how hoity-toity this place was and how raved about it was i have to say it was a massive disappointment. 



 I'd say that was a pretty terrible deal.
author: Martha K.

description:
Overrated.  Service good. Interior nice. Food OK.

I'd give more details but yelp will just filter this review anyways just like all my other ones.  

Spend your money at another fine dining establishment.
author: Ben A.

description:
We celebrated BF's 50th birthday with dinner at Boulevard... two nights in a row.  We originally made a reservation for his birthday dinner, but we were walking past the restaurant the night before & we couldn't resist going in.  We thought we'd change our reservations for the following night, but the food & experience were so wonderful we decided to come back.
