Tim was our server for both evenings.  He was so amazing the first night we requested his section for the second.  He managed to surpass our already high expectations.  He spent the perfect amount of time with us, gave us fabulous recommendations & made BF's birthday really special.

The menu changes frequently, but we enjoyed the stuffed calamari appetizer so much we had it both nights.  I had fish both nights.  I can't remember which one I had the first night, but I had the salmon the second night.  It was served with the most delicious crispy egg I've ever had.  BF enjoyed the lamb & steak entrees.

Boulevard is one of our favorites & we're so happy they came through for a fabulous birthday weekend.
author: Cecily J.

description: The food is wonderful - to taste and to behold. I really appreciated the special attention to texture in each dish. I highly recommend the crab salad. I had the quail which was cut perfectly so there was no struggling with tiny bones. Cocktails were fine, but next time I would just stick to the wine list. I had baked Alaska for dessert, which was delivered with a candle and a tiny chocolate banner that read "Happy Birthday".  A happy birthday indeed!
author: Kate M.

description:
We celebrated my sister's 50th here on Saturday.  This is our special place that we've been to a few times. 

Nearly every thing we tried this evening was excellent:

 - Foie gras and persimmon appetizer
 - Seared day boat scallops with cauliflower
 - Salad with warren pears and cheese
 - Filet Mignon
 - Pork (rave reviews on this)
 - Lamb 

The things that weren't quite up to expectations:

 - My entree was Roast Sea bass with shaved brussels sprouts and crispy pancetta.  This dish was spa size portion and the brussels sprouts tasted like they were shaved with out any seasonings. Rather bland and disappointing dish.

- After we were done with our main course, we saw another table get amuse-bouche before their appetizers.  Our server didn't provide us with the chef's taste, makes me wonder if our server forgot this!!

- We asked the sommolier for a wine recommendation. He took a long time to come to our table, and when he did, his communication skills were like a neanderthal: more grunting and pointing rather than speaking.  We did, however like the wine that we chose.
author: Karrot L.

description:
Considering how high-end this restaurant is, it's refreshing that they have a chef's counter where you see the line chefs put together the main courses.  

The prices are high --- a full course meal for one -- starter, main, dessert, coffee, drink --- ran me about $75 not including tip.  Everything, however, was flawlessly executed.  Portions run a little small but to really appreciate the skills in the kitchen, you really should order a 3 course meal.

I started with the dungeness crab salad which was a deconstructed salad.  All the elements of the salad --- the crab, the lettuce, the melon, the citrus --- were separately placed across a long plate.  The crab salad tasted just a tad salty for my taste but all the elements together did make up an impressive dungeness crab salad which was light and refreshing.

For my main, my waiter recommended the pork chop, which was brined in cider and topped with a dash of pesto.  The chop was perfectly cooked and tender.  I didn't care for the sides except for the greens though.  If I come again, I'll probably try the salmon.

Before coming to the restaurant, I had made up my mind on having a cheese plate for dessert.  With an impressive selection of cheeses (mostly goat milk cheeses from Italy, France and California), I was served up a small but incredibly tasty wedge of Riobola goat cheese accompanied by several slices of thin baguette, some champagne grapes to cleanse the palette, a small chunk of wild honey and some warm, roasted almonds.  That cheese plate surpisingly turned out to be the highlight of my meal.  It doesn't take a lot of cheese to satisfy the palette and with the compliments of bread, dates and honey with periodic cleansing of the palette with the grapes.

My other dessert was a flawless cappucino.  A woman at a table nearby ordered a cup of tea and she was brought an iron Japanese tea pot with beautiful ceramic tea accessories.  It's nice to know that when you are paying $5 for a cup of coffee or a cup of tea, all the trappings of luxury are included with that cup of coffee or tea.

Never missing a beat, every component of my meal was made with quality ingredients and flawlessly executed.  In spite of the high-end food, service is refreshingly down-to-earth and unsnobby.  

I'll admit --- there's nothing startingly original on the menu (fish, lamb, pork and a variety of seafood appetizers) but you can taste the freshness of the ingredients.  Come here for the best experience in farm to table California fresh cooking with unpretentious service a nice romantic atmosphere.  

Definitely make reservations like I did.  I came 15 minutes early but they seated me right away.  A few people at the chef's counter got a little drunk and started jumping up and down (I could feel the vibrations) and earned dirty looks from the waitstaff --- but normally, it's mostly couples out for a romantic dinner.
author: Audrey Y.

description:
I recently dined here with my girlfriend on a recommendation from a trusted foodie friend, and Boulevard did not disappoint.

First things first--the wine list.  I am not a wine expert by any means, but neither am I a wine dummy, but the Boulevard list is extremely extensive, and our waiter was very patient in helping us pick out a bottle of German white wine that was both reasonably priced and, more importantly, tasted excellent!

I ordered the tuna tartare and sashimi as an appetizer and the squab and quail as my main course.  Compared to the tuna tartare I've had at other fine dining restaurants (such as Aqua), Boulevard's lagged slightly behind in portion and taste, but it was still good.  The quail, however, was truly excellent, and I highly recommend it--lots of flavor, very filling, and the thyme on it was a great complement to the dish.  

The food itself weighs in at between 4 and 4.5 stars, but I'm giving Boulevard a full 5 because we received such excellent service.  It's a pricey night out, to be sure, but worth every penny.
author: Eric A.

description:
So... finally we were able to snag reservations here with their link to open table - I guess we finally planned enough ahead of time. We were seated right away and had a nice view of the cooking area. 

What we enjoyed - 

- first, the apertif - French 1215 I think it was called. We both had it and it's a girly drink but delicious! It has Elderflower liquier in it but it was very subtle. 
- we shared the Monterey Red Abalone and the Sonoma Foie Gras. The abalone with sauteed mushrooms were tasty but the Foie was a bit too juicy for us. I know, others may wonder what's wrong with that, but it left a bit of a gamey taste in our mouth. 
- for the main course, we both ended up ordering the Lobster and Prawns with fava bean risotto. The risotto was just heavenly - you'll find yourself scraping it off the plate and the seafood was perfectly cooked. Just a tad disappointed with the portion size compared to another diner who had the filet which was nice and sizable for the price paid since they were the same price. Next time!
- for dessert - we had the carrot cake which was fantastic. 

Decor and atmosphere was romantic. 
Service was impeccable. You know, the kind of place, they fold your napkin when you're off to the loo.  ;)

We'll be back ... for the filet!
author: Kuishingal F.

description: I came here for lunch with the team during one of our off sites. The food was SO good. I had the meatball sandwich (I am sure the name was fancier on the menu). The staff is attentive and took all our coats, talk about fancy! My coworker had chocolate cake for dessert and we all ate from it. This place is upscale, so would be a good place to take a special date. The only thing that turned me off was when I ordered my white wine with my meatball sandwich, the waiter looked at me like a pooped my pants. YES, please give me WHITE wine with my RED meat. I do what I want. Other than that, I enjoyed it a lot.
author: Melanie S.

description: I went here to celebrate my Mom's birthday and it was fantastic. I was a little nervous about the cost but I think it was well worth the money. I had their salmon and my mom had the filet mignon and they were both amazing. Our waiter Tim was so helpful and nice. He not only brought my mom their irish coffee bon-bon's (So Good!) as a birthday dessert but he gave us a whole list of things we should see while in San Francisco and a list of brunch places he recommended.
author: Jacqualynn G.

description:
I'm baffled.  I really don't understand the hype surrounding this restaurant.  The food is passable but the service was terrible.  the Sommelier was fully incompetent and our waiter acted very much like his family was behind held hostage in lieu of his service.  The restaurant was very loud, but this would have been passable had the overall experience been better.

A forgettable experience that I won't be returning for more of.
author: David G.

description:
My husband and I were lucky enough to receive a gift certificate to Boulevard and we decided to use it to celebrate our 8 year anniversary of being together.  I was a bit worried after reading some of the reviews on here, but we had a fantastic time.

First, the ambiance of this place is so wonderful.  I loved the intimate, classy feel that this place gives off.  Take a look up too! The ceiling is so beautiful.  It did get a bit loud, but it's hard to find a truly quiet restaurant nowadays.  The decor is really lovely, and fits the restaurant really well.  

Second, the service was great.  Our waiter was very attentive and helpful.  He was in general really nice to deal with.  He wasn't over the top nice and didn't bother us too often, but we never really felt like we were trying to flag him down.  The pace of the meal was not too fast or too slow.

Third, the food was awesome, though I felt that the portion sizes were on the small side.  I was very happy with everything we ate (beet salad, tuna tartare, lamb t-bone, filet mignon, chocolate brulee, flourless chocolate cake), though not too long after I felt kind of hungry.  And I don't really have a huge appetite, so this was sort of disappointing.   All the dishes were seemingly simple, but had little touches on them that really made them taste great.  Lamb can be a miss sometimes, but in this case my lamb had none of the weird musty gamey flavor it can get and was perfectly cooked and tender.  

Overall, we were very pleased with our experience and Boulevard and look forward to dining there again.
author: Marissa M.

description:
I think this place gets over-hyped.

The service was off the charts. The food, stayed on my plate......
author: A. B.

description:
We went to Boulevard for my birthday last week. I was dying to try this place since I have heard so many great things. I would give this place 4 stars for the overall dining experience but 3.0 stars for the food. 

We started off with the scallops and potato leek soup which were amazing. My husband ordered the lamb dish and really liked it. I ordered the filet which was okay. The meat had a strange stringy texture to it and it was a bit overcooked. The side dishes were basic and nothing exciting. The portion were perfect.

As a chocolate fanatic we ordered to chocolate cake/ice cream dish off the desert menu which was not exciting and had a strange dry taste to it.

Our waiter was amazing and provided excellent service. The ambiance is beautiful and makes you feel you are not in SF.

Overall great dining experience but food is nothing exciting.
author: muneet g.

description: This is a review just for the bar service.  I ordered a martini with a twist and the bartender showed up with a martini with olives.  No problem, I understand that that happens once in a while, and that the drink just needs to be remade as ordered.  So the bartender apologizes and takes it back, but then I see him go back to the bar, pluck out the olives and replace it with a twist!  I can see how you can get away with maybe replacing a twist with olives, but a martini with olives in it will definitely retain the olive taste even after you remove the olives.  Anyway we spoke to the manager about it and he was very apologetic and brought us a dessert on the house, which is the reason for the three star vs. two star bar review.
author: melita s.

description: Impeccable! Food, ambiance, service, everything is wonderful. Last night's selections included the guinea hen and halibut. Both perfectly cooked and beautiful to look at. Chocolate mousse for dessert was barely recognizable as a mousse; instead we got a very interesting and complex creation. Wonderful...
author: George Y.

description: This restaurant has been around for a long time (as SF restaurants go) and has been reviewed as one of the top five restaurants in SF anytime it has been reviewed.  The proof is in the pudding.  Go.  There is precision at work here with texture and flavor, like nothing else I have ever experienced.
author: Jenn D.

description:
This is my favorite place to go for very special occasions when I want to celebrate.  

I took my Dad here after I got my first bonus at a new job as a thank you for being an awesome Dad and for all the money he spent educating me (especially college!) :).  A friend who knows good food & wine (and is herself half French) recommended Boulevard as the perfect place.  It feels very nice, but not pretentious.  My family doesn't go to many fancy dinners, so I wanted someplace where we would feel welcome and not intimidated.  After I went with my Dad the first time, I've been back twice since. 

Excellent food, wine, and service.
author: Suzanne A.

description:
Went to Boulevard for my birthday last month and...WOW. Fantastic food, great service, and a nice view of the bridge from our table. I definitely enjoyed our appetizers and dessert a bit more than the entrees, but that's only saying that the entrees were amazing as compared to the others being out of this world. 

Scallops: Delicious, and I'm very picky about how my scallops are cooked.

Squab: My boyfriend gave me most of this dish because he so enjoyed the noises of pleasure/ecstasy I made every time I took a bite...

Wreckfish: Very good! But hard to match the squab I had just finished.

Filet: Probably my least favorite of the meal but that's also because I've been less and less fond of heavy red meat dishes lately. Nothing at all wrong with the preparation at this restaurant. Boyfriend loved it.

Profiteroles: Fantastic dessert but very rich, so be prepared.

Pear and fig pie: Holy crap, heaven.

The only slight downside to the meal was the attitude of the bartender while we were waiting and I ordered a drink - she seemed very preoccupied and wasn't helpful answering wine questions. However, our actual server was beyond attentive and more than made up for the first.
author: Amy F.

description: This place is phenomenal. The service was attentive but unobtrusive. The food was to die for. They have a cucumber gimlet made of Hendricks like they knew I was coming because that's my favorite gin.  You will drop some coin here, but it's totally worth it. I made a reservation a month in advance for a Friday night, but it looked like you could walk in after 9-930 and get a table.
author: Eric N.

description:
We had a 8pm reservation and when we arrived the place is packed, but we were seated very promptly and were given a table in the back near the window as requested. Service is good but slow; there was a long wait between appetizer and the main entree. Food is excellent and of course very pricy. 

When we left the restaurant, the front desk told us that the valet will help us get a taxi. Well, valet was no where to be seen.
author: Sharon P.

description:
Wanted to try this restaurant for a while now, and two days ago being in the neighborhood we decided to give it a try.  We called to make a reservation but were told that there is nothing available, however we could try to stop by and sign up before restaurant opens.  We did just that and where able to get in!  
Atmosphere - we didn't know what to expect but the whole restaurant's setup, brick sealing, decorations on the walls, view of the Bay Bridge seemed to match well with it's name and reminded us of some european boulevards, so I guess 5 stars for that. 
The waiter service was ok, just that, ok. The waiter didn't seem to be very professional, motivated or helpful.  Can't give more then 3 stars for the service which we really did not expect for a restaurant in this class. 
Food: Bread wasn't warm but fresh and tasty.  Roasted Beet Salad was very good. 
For our entrees my husband ordered fillet mignon and I ordered a local petrale sole. 
Fillet itself tasted good but was lukewarm.  Sole was over salted and tasted fishy. It came on a bed of what seemed to be corn, completely tasteless.  Both dishes had to go back to the kitchen.  Our waiter apologized and asked what would we like to have instead.  My husband had no problem with fillet, except that it was cold, so he reordered it again.  I ordered quail.  This time our dishes came a lot quicker and Fillet Mignon was at the right temperature, however there was a lot more butter in the dish this time, which you could taste, and the cut of meat itself wasn't tasty at all.  My husband left half of his steak untouched - not so great for a $50 dish.  My quail was very tender and tasty.  Overall for basically 1 good entree out of 4, just can't give it more then 3 stars. 
I'm glad this wasn't a special occasion dinner, since it would be even more disappointing.  There are tons of excellent dining places in SF.  I don't think we are coming back.
author: T S.

description:
O My God!  This is one of the best places ever!  I took my brother in law and I was not let down at all!  Better than Gary Dankos by a long shot and on par with Masa's and the Ritz for less money.  The service is impeccable and the ambiance can't be beat.

I wanted a ressie around 7pm but only 8:30 was available.  I was told we could come early in case something opened up earlier (they do take walk-ins).  We showed up at 7pm and headed to the bar.  Not only is the architecture amazing but the bartender knew how to make a Pimms Cup!!!!  Awesome!  To make things better, we only waited 10 minutes before being seated.

Both my brother and I had the same thing, fois gras and filet.  FINALLY, a perfect fois experience!  I haven't had fois cooked this well since 2007!  So many people overcook fois and it dries out.  This was plump, juicy and just amazingly yummy!  Hey Hippies!  Don't fuck with my fois!  If you don't like it, you don't have to eat it and I'll keep my nose out of your vegan sprout treats.  Deal?

The bread was soooo tender, chewy, soft and sour like real sourdough should be that I could have eaten so much of it I would have been as fat as Aunt Pitty!

The filet was cooked to a perfect medium rare and the fingerling potatoes with a slightly spicy sauce were the perfect complement.  

I brought my own wine, Alexander Valley Silver Oak, with a corkage of only $25.  Considering the only Silver Oak they had on the menu was $135 a bottle and my bottle was 3 years older - score!  I gave the waitress a glass for her to enjoy as is customary.  She so loved us!

The food here was so good it made me cry tears of pure joy!  This is a must do again for sure!
author: Deirdre S.

description: It was a special birthday for my partner, and Boulevard did not fail. Food was incredible - perfect portions. Quail was the best I'd ever had, and the lamb my partner got was also fantastic. Love the nettle gnocchi, and other interesting things that came on the plate! Thanks again - we will def return again in the future!
author: Modern L.

description: Just spent a foodie & wine weekend in SFO.  Had a blast.  This will be one of six reviews I am writing.  Don't waste your time or money eating at Boulevard.  Ambience sucked, service was a bit slow, food was certainly sub-par.  If you like to eat what the server told us was basically their 'house specials' - expect nothing, at least, while cooked perfectly absolutely no flavor or seasoning.  I am speaking of the salmon and the beef wellington- which were both highly recommended.  Also, starters EXTREMELY small portions, if sharing, you get one-half a bite to one bite each.  Totally not worth it.  Find a good yelped Little Italy restaurant, and go there.  Probably cost 75% less than we wasted at Boulevard. I could go on, but I'm sure you all get my drift. HORRIBLE waste of a perfectly good evening in SFO.
author: Tina M.

description:
Excellent.  We went to Boulevard for a special date night.  We'd never been because of the difficulty of getting a reservation at prime time, and the cost was a little scary.  But it is certainly worth the wait and worth the hassle.

Everything that they served us was amazing.  We had the calamari appetizer (which is very easy to screw up if you don't fry it) and that was succulent and delicious.  Even the table bread was amazing.  The cocktail menu was fun and all very interesting.  The entrees were all wonderful too.  I had the lamb, which was good if you like lamb.  My wife ordered the pork, which blew my already very good lamb dish out of the water.

Service is incredible, without being uppity or snotty.  It's just an all around fabulous dining experience.
author: Jon S.

description: Worth all of the approx. 10,000 pennies I spent here! Our server was fantastic - warm and personable, not stuffy in the least, and attentive without being overbearing. We had the scallops (delish!) and a fig/marscapone/prosciutto salad to start, and I think my friend and I were both tempted to pick up the dish and lick off every last bit of the marscapone! The entrees were equally good - we had the quail and the halibut. The chocolate dessert went a little overboard with both a rich cake and a little gelato-filled cookie, but I'm not complaining! The only thing I didn't like was my margarita - the salt and pepper on the rim was a little too much for me. Overall, a great experience!
author: Stacey P.

description: On Christmas Eve I had a glass of Chardonnay that tasted of butterscotch at the crowded, charming bar with the barrel vault ceiling of such excellent design and quality it's only second to the ceilings at the Oyster Bar in Grand Central Station.
author: Tina T.

description:
Blvd. deserves five stars.  It fully lived up to its reviews.  The food is fantastic.  We had a table for four.  I had the halibut, guest 1  had salmon, Guest 2 had lamb chops and guest 3 had the chicken.  Each and everybody's meals were fantastic.  We are all still raving about it almost a week later. A fudge cake was served for the birthday person which we all agreed was amazing. 
Cannot go without mentioning the exceptional service provided by Jay our service.  She has such a wonderful personality  and style.  A real asset to this fine establishment.  I will return on my next visit to San Francisco, which I hope will be soon.
John McDonald
author: John M.

description: Boulevard is our go to restaurant in San Francisco. It serves consistently great food in an upscale, but not stuffy and pretentious, environment. Unlike many other "top rated" restaurants its not style or substance, and is the perfect blend of style and substance.
author: Elle T.

description: The sommelier, Rob, is awesome, and so is the rest of the waitstaff. There's not a single bad thing I can say about this restaurant. Put this on your bucket list.
author: Tyler C.

description: I usually go for lunch and sit at the counter in the back that overlooks the outer kitchen.  I love it.  This week, I had the tartare, paella and panna cotta.  All delicious.  I took my mom, who was in from out of town.  Among other things, she had a cheese course.  The accoutrements were very generous.  It is not an inexpensive lunch, but I am never disappointed.  Valet at lunch is $12.
author: Amber B.

description:
Atmosphere/Decor is great.  
Location is nice too.

Food was tasty but pricey for the portion size.  I don't mind smaller portions but do think the price could be dropped a bit.  

The service was rather slow although our waitress was great.  Everyone at our table was served dessert with the exception of one person.  We waited and I finally flagged down our server.  Somehow they forgot to bring it out.  By then our coffee was cold.

I'd go back for a special occasion but there are other restaurants I'd try first.
author: Keneke K.

description: This had been on the top of my list for place to eat in SF for a long time.  Im happy to say I can finally cross it off, but now its top on place to go back! The food was great, service was great and atmosphere was great.  I took my girlfriend for her birthday and it was worth every penny.  I wouldn't go unless it was a special night because of the cost.  I had the pork chop that was the best I have had (even better then nopa)
author: Vince C.

description: have you ever walked into a restaurant and felt like your youth was pretty evident? upon entry through the revolving doors of Boulevard, i was met with a sea of shimmering white hair reflecting the lighting coming from above. the clientele at Boulevard clearly isn't your average 20something. you're guaranteed to see older white couples and a bunch of yuppies with overly gelled hair. the food matches the needs of the clientele accurately. i imagine the older crowd just wants good solid food. they're not looking for any fusion or gastronomy, so this is a great fit for that generation. while everything we had at Boulevard was prepared very well and each dish balanced nicely with flavors and textures, there wasn't anything very different or special about each dish.  still, it was a very good dinner and i would come back (but probably not until i grow some grays).
author: Regina C.

description:
I hadn't eaten at Boulevard's in what seems like 10 years, well since the dot.com era so I know it dates back. I work by here and walk by all the time and for some reason I felt like it was a crazy expensive place, I guess 10 years ago I wasn't use to the prices or they have lowered their prices or something...

We were able to walk right in without a reservation which shocked me to start things off. The crowd is a bit hob nob drinking champagne for lunch and most of the people are dressed in business attire while I am in casual biz attire. 

Our waiters was decent, nothing to write home to ma and pa about though... I ordered the crab linguine and my co-worker ordered the burger and asked for it to be cooked well done. We also had a special red tea which was pretty damn yummy as far as tea goes. 

When the food came out I had a few bites of my pasta which was good, however my buddy was not happy with how his burger was cooked so we swapped food since I was fine with it being more on the medium side. Bot the pasta and burger where good, not out of this world good but good food. 

What did surprise me was that it was under $50 for lunch even with the special tea drinks! This isn't cheap however we are talking about one of the top rated restaurants in San Francisco and a local legend as far as restaurants go so I was pleasantly surprise to not drop 3 digits for lunch.
author: Bobby B.

description:
I'm really not sure what to say about Boulevard because it didn't make a huge impression, good or bad. I looked forward to having dinner there for a couple of weeks prior to our visit and was careful to mind the "expectation gap" that can sometimes result in disappointment with a fine dining experience. The service was adequate but not what I would call attentive or friendly. The scallops were good, but not great. The pork prime rib chop was ok but a bit shy on flavor. Dessert was ok, but there was no ooh-ing or ah-ing. The wine list is a distinct bright spot in the experience. There are many good selections spanning a wide price range.

My wife and I left the restaurant in agreement that we wouldn't turn down a convenient opportunity to go back, but we have no desire to proactively pursue a return trip. We walked by Boulevard a hundred times before we finally decided to give it a try.We may walk by more than a hundred times before we return.
author: Eric E.

description: Best dining experience I have had in the US. Perhaps because it didn't feel like I was in the US? No, it has to do with the food, the service and the ambiance. We started with the Ahi Tuna Ito-Zukuri. It was light and fresh. I had the Halibut and my date had the filet. Everything about my fish was perfect. It was flaky and moist. My date's filet was cooked to perfection; medium rare just the way a fine piece of meat should be! We shared a nice bottle of red and split the chocolate pot de creme. Magnifique! Such a romantic restaurant but I had been here once before with my cousin and had an equally enjoyable dining experience! Well maybe not equally... ;)
author: Courtney K.

description:
food: two stars (* *)
My date and I started off with the ahi tuna tartare.  It was put on the plate in a clump on which sat a quail's egg.  There were some nicoise olives strewn about as well.  It tasted good, but at around $17 was vastly overpriced considering the portion.  I thought the concept was lacking too.  Why not have a nicoise tapenade?  We then split the filet mignon and halibut.  The steak was excellent and accompanied by some fingerling potatoes with cheese on top.  It was very tasty, but I felt like the concept was lacking for a restaurant of this culinary caliber.  Why not accompany it with a spinach risotto?  Meat and potatoes are just so basic.  The halibut was evenly cooked, but lacked any definitive flavor.  It, and its accompaniments, were forgettable.

environment/service: five stars (* * * * *)
Without a doubt the best service I have ever received in San Francisco, anywhere.  Attentive but not overbearing.  Knowledgeable without being pretentious.  I started making it a habit to call out the names of poor waiters in my reviews, and I feel it only fair to highlight the good ones as well--ours was Alisha.  Along with her, the rest of the wait staff were extraordinarily attentive.  Empty glasses and plates did not sit on the table for more than 10 seconds before someone came around to check on us or remove them.

value: three stars (* * *)
Even with this being a high-end restaurant, I still found prices to be slightly higher than they should have been.  $17 for perhaps 2oz of sushi-grade ahi tuna is steep, and while expensive steaks are no strangers in this town, $40 for around 6oz just seemed a bit higher than it should have been.  I also dislike being slapped with a 4% "SF Health Plan" surcharge at the end.  That, just like any other administrative/employee-related expense, needs to be included in the prices on the menu.

average of
food: two stars
environment/service: five stars
value: three stars
================
averaged grand total: three stars

estimated price per person (excluding drink):
$35-70

would i recommend it to others?
Probably not.  It was good, and a very lovely evening, but not superb like I had been told.

would i return?
Probably not.  I would like to try one of the many other high-end restaurants in this city next.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
To be completely honest, Twin and I had so much wine here, it's kind of a blur. However, I know one thing for sure - we had a fabulous time. 

The building is historic and beautiful, and the interiors are traditional and classic. Some might think it is a bit stuffy, but I really loved it. The menu offers more traditional fare, all beautifully prepared with fresh ingredients in a lovely presentation. 

Boys, this is a great date spot. Tables are well spaced out, and there is definitely some "mood lighting" going on in the later evening hours.

We started with the Royal Sweet Scallops, which were buttery and perfect. We both had the Wood Oven Roasted Filet Mignon, with haricot verts, toasted hazelnuts and fried shallots. It was served with banana fingerling potatoes with gorgonzola sauce, roast beef jus and Barolo vinaigrette. The beef was super tender and flavorful, and you really can't go wrong with fingerling potatoes + gorgonzola!  I'm pretty sure we both finished our dish. :) 

We were a bit overserved when we left Boulevard... but full, happy and giggly as usual!
author: Caroline A.

description: went there on Saturday and place was packed. Food was delicious and i liked wine menu, it had everything!  liked they view to the bridge. hard to find parking
author: Veronika G.

description:
even though this place gets criticized a lot, I still think it puts out a reliably tasty meal.
Italian Burrata & Assorted Heirloom Tomato Salad
--Costada Romanesco Panzanella with Pine Nuts, Parmesan, Lemon & Herbs.  so this is a classic pairing but the panzanella took it to another level.  like tiny little crispy crouton bread salad, just tasted very good with nice additional texture.
Northern Halibut
--Black Risotto with Shellfish Broth, Saffron Aioli, Roasted & Clarified Tomato Relish with Lemon Olive OIl.  another solid dish with the interested jelly like clarified tomato relish.
Wood Oven Roasted Kobe Bavette
--Dwelley Farm Haricot Verts, Toasted Hazelnuts & Fried Shallots, Banana Fingerling Potatoes with Mountain Gorgonzola Sauce
Roast Bef Juse & Barolo Vinaigrette.  perfect salted bavette.
Flourless Chocolate Cake
--Dark Chocolate Cream Filling, Caramelia Chocolate Ganache, Malted Cocoa Nib Ice Cream, Fudge Sauce.  love nibs.
overall a great meal with standard ingredients, but strength is good food foundation and execution.
still doing well-- descriptions a little wordy
--Fairytale Pumpkin Soup with Jonathan Apples, Braised Benton's Bacon, Fresh Los Banos Telleme Cheese, Nettles, and Sage
--Alaskan Halibut with Hay Smoked Chanterelle Mushrooms, Sauteed Bloomsdale Spinach, Black Rice, Quinoa and Anson Mills Farro Picolo with Parsnips and Butternut Squash and Crispy Quinoa and Butternut Squash Puree over fish
only problem was fish was dry otherwise flavors good
--pear crisp with salted caramel ice cream: great
another awesome dinner meal:
--Sea Scallops with Petite Shiitake & Clamshell Mushrooms, Job''s Tears, Miso, Lemon & Hon Wasabi: excellent use of wasabi kick, just perfect
--Wild King Salmon Grilled with Lacinato Kale with Soft Potato Cavolo Nero Crisps, Porcini Butter Wild Texas Pecans, Blueberries & Lemon: again can't go wrong, perfectly cooked
American Kobe Bavette with Roasted Tomato -- also was salted and cooked well.
--Soft French Meringue with White Peach Sorbet, Nectarines, Moscato d'Asti Baked Peaches, Creme Anglaise
vs. Flourless Chocolate Cake with Olive Oil Ice Cream & Gummies, Sicilian Pistachio Truffles, Caramel Brown Rice Crispies: both desserts with complex ingredients, inviting presentation, various textures but not mixing too much -- delightful
they still got it
--alaskan halibut with Caper Spaetzle with Sprouted Lentils & Quinoa, Coal Roasted Fennel Puree & Bloomsdale Spinach, Baby Zucchini A La Plancha Buerre Vert with Pickled Mustard Seeds = little dry this time
--D'Anjou Pear & fourme D'Ambert Blue Cheese Salad with Oregon Hazelnuts, Capers & Dried Cherries, Pear Kefir Creme Fraiche = good
--chocolate pot de creme: French Oak Panna Cotta, Frozen Bittersweet Chocolate Foam, Zinfandel Gelee, Chocolate Wafer Crunch = excellent
author: Rob C.

description:
Sprawling and elegant, almost too nice for the likes of me. I found it almost suspicious that they welcomed us so graciously, in a Groucho Marx, "I wouldn't belong to any club that would have me as a member" sense. Top drawer all the way.

I think the Wednesday-night packed house speaks volumes to the quality of the experience, as it is a very large restaurant and is dearly expensive. Like, pawn-your-girlfriend's-laptop-while-she's-in-the-shower expensive. The pro maneuver is to manufacture an occasion "special" enough to get your parents to take you here. (My suggestions include proposing to your significant other in order to receive the congratulatory dinner on the folks, and then breaking off the engagement on the cab ride home.) If your parents are absent/dead/out of town/cheap, you should kidnap the well-to-do couple of your choice, at knifepoint if necessary, and force them to bring you here and foot the bill. The lenient sentence you will receive as a first-time offender will be well worth your trouble, especially if they spring for dessert. The filet mignon might be worth a third strike.

Our waiter killed it; impressively professional while still very friendly. I forget his name but he kind of looked like a taller, thinner version of the gaysian secretary on "Entourage". 

Bonus Review: One star for that show and anyone who thinks it's still good.
author: Trav W.

description: I still have the taste of the vintage wines and the tender steak in my mouth that we had after a loonnngggg dinner which took almost 4 hours. It's a bit prices but worths it!
author: Beril Y.

description: So we were deciding between olive garden and boulevard for my birthday.  Boy am i glad we picked boulevard.  The service was extremely friendly and attentive.  I had the scallops with prosciutto, the lamb, and the angel food cake.  All of it was great!  Especially the lamb.  My friends had the tomato salad which was so so, and the filet which was awesome.  The calamari was a little "intestinal." You can have as much bread as you want if you ask for it.  And the harmony non-alcoholic beverage is awesome.  I highly recommend this place for your birthday (there were 3 others) but i think everyone left feeling special.
author: Norman P.

description: So consistent, with unparalleled service. Informed and engaging waiters offering perfectly prepared food, not to mention out of this world wine selections.
author: Bryce F.

description:
OK, so I came here for free. It cost us about 1,100 for 8 guys, yeah we pigged out. I tried the bass and it was good, the calamari is not the fried type that everyone is used to, I liked it. 

The warm brownie with ice cream was really good, had different wines and tried the dolci dessert wine for the first time, liked it too. I did notice that there was a sculpture made of iron on the roof. 

What I did notice is that not too many people walk around unless they're tourists in the area. I'm trying to eat as much sea food while in the west coast, Its hard to find a good place in NYC which serves fish fresh.

It was a trip going to the restroom, you had to go through some outside door to an elevator shaft that takes you down one floor and walk through another lounge area before you hit the restroom, yeah I'd probably go back here once I hit the mega lotto
author: Edward I.

description:
We came for lunch with great anticipation. They had called me a couple hours earlier confirming the reservation, which was good. And, we were seated professionally and calmly. The wait staff manners and service overall was excellent.

I hadn't seen other reviews comment on the noise level; it was about 12:15, and the financial district was out in force. Good taste, but noisy, noisy!! Very! We waited a few minutes to look through the menu, which may have been a mistake, that they thought we were "ladies lunchers" (I wasn't). I had a lovely mushroom soup appetizer, my friend a salad; both came promptly. We both then ordered the Scallops with mussels, over saffron risotto; those did NOT come promptly, unfortunately. It must have been a 45 minute wait for the main course. The scallops were just "ok", a bit tough, the mussels miniature; risotto was very nice. We ultimately had a cup of coffee and left, haven taken almost two hours to get our food and eat. Paris, that's expected, but SF? And, most of the financiers had eaten and gone. Priority to them? All of this plus one glass of wine cost $93. Had the scallops been to die for, it would have been better. So, in summary the kitchen staff must have been challenged; whether that was abnormal for lunch, at least, one has to give them a small benefit of the doubt. 

Sadly, not sure I'll give them a try again any time soon. For the supposed calibre of food and status of the restaurant, I expected better. Fun to try, but it "missed" on a few cylinders.
author: J D.

description:
I like food...I don't like spending  a ton of money for it, but when I go out to a nice restaurant, I want something fulfilling, unique and just plain tasty.  Last night, my fiance took me to Boulevard for my birthday.  Everything about this place kicked some serious butt.  The waiter was prompt, responsive and attentive to our needs.  The atmosphere was elegant, yet casual and cozy.  The food from the bread and butter to the dessert was a complete treat, even the specialty cocktails were tasty.  I had my first sidecar and it was fantastic.  If I didn't have to work the next morning I could have sat there an enjoyed about six of those.  

For the meal, we had the venison carpaccio with fried oysters, the duck entree with a bittersweet chocolate ravioli, and I had the lobster entree with scallops and saffon potato cake.  Each bite was fantastic on all of the dishes, the food fresh and prepared wonderfully.  We thought it couldn't get any better but we took down two desserts including the apple terrine dish w profiterole and the chocolate brulee which almost made by fiance pass out from pure excitement.  Overall a fantastic meal.

Will we go back?? Definitely! for another special time.  It's pricey but well worth it.
author: Ken P.

description: This has to be my favorite restaurant in the City.  The service, food and location cannot be beat!  I try to come here a few times each year, and each time it is the same:  Great service.  Great food.  What else could you ask for?
author: Marcus L.

description: Could have been an off night although I was really disappointed in my meal here.  Appetizer was very average.  Seared scallops with pork belly.  How can you not nail that?  Main was the signature pork chop.  It was good but I expect more if this is your signature dish that never leaves the menu.  Service was a bit distant.  Not a cheap place either.
author: John O.

description:
I spent the 4th of July weekend in San Francisco and was looking for a upscale dinner with nice atmosphere. This place was GREAT.

I originally was going elsewhere but decided to try Boulevard last minute. To my surprise they were able to a accommodate us with no drama or problems. The service was excellent. Our server was beyond helpful and very knowledgeable. The food was flavorful and surpassed our expectations. 

Boulevard turned out to be a highlight of our trip. I will definitely recommend friends.
author: Henry R.

description:
On a recent trip to San Francisco, Boulevard was one of many restaurants my boyfriend and I visited. I can't begin to explain how fantastic the food, service, and drinks were at Boulevard. 
We made reservations for a Saturday night. When we walked in it was slightly busy, we checked in and were led to the bar. My boyfriend ordered his normal scotch, while I went ahead and ordered a cosmopolitan. i like them light pink so I made sure to tell the bartender. Well, let me tell you this guy knew what he was doing. I never had a more perfect cosmo. He actually squeezed lime juice right from the lime into the shaker, which really made the drink.
Were were notified that our table was ready. It was a great window table with a view. There were great menu choices. We started off with the tartare which was quite good. I went with the salmon for dinner and it was so fresh, cooked perfectly and delicious with just the right amount of sauce on it. My boyfriend opted for the pork chop which was a recommendation from the waiter. I have never seen him enjoy a meal as much as he did that night. This trip was in October and he still mentions the pork chop from there. I'm not a huge fan of pork but I tried it anyway and I could see why he still rants about it. The waiter was animated and attentive, which is always a plus in my book. All together it was a great experience, and if I ever visit SF again I will ensure Boulevard gets a visit from me.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
Fancy American fare
3.75 stars actually

FOOD:
CRISPY STUFFED SQUASH BLOSSOM
"Stuffed with Dungeness Crab. Mixed Frying Peppers, Harissa Yogurt, Romesco & Cilantro-Chili Sauce"
$13.50
So amazing! One of my favorite appetizers. Fresh crab not hidden in sauce. The crispiness was light and perfect.

Salmon
$24
The salmon was ok, nothing amazing.

Pork shortribs with paella
$17.50
The dish was too salty for me and very hearty. The shortribs were reasonably tender. The paella was quite wet.

DESSERT:
STICKY TOFFEE SUNDAE
"Medjool Date Cake, English Toffee. Toasted Almond Ice Cream, Hot Fudge.Buttered Pecans"
$10
A tad bit too sweet, perhaps because it has toffee. The cake was alright - slightly hard and light on the date taste. Ice cream was just alright in taste. Overall, the dish didn't seem refined on my tongue.

AMBIANCE: Classic art nouveau wood look

SERVICE: Wonderful! Loved our waiter! Very attentive, good at water refills.

VISIT DETAILS: Relaxing lunch with a good friend
author: C L.

description: Boulevard is still amazing and still arguably making my favorite food in the city. I love the ambiance and service as well. Last weekend for the first time we went with the intentions of sitting and eating at the bar. They offered us a spot along the open kitchen where you can watch the cooks work their magic instead of the regular bar. It was great! I would request this spot in the future and highly recommend it if you like to see how hard the cooks work. It's a little more casual than the fine dining tables as well. It was fun to see the cooks make our food, then be served it. I loved the beet salad with buffalo mozzarella. It was so delicious. I also had the quail entree with apricot and it was very good as well. 5 stars!
author: Natalie N.

description: The dinner was delicious.  Scallops were delicious.  My husband made reservations here because he had heard good things about it.  We all enjoyed the dinner.
author: Colette E.

description:
I had a 2-hour, 3-course lunch here today and it was fantastic. Less face time with statutes and cases, more face time with fine albeit microscopic food... YES!

I began with the lobster bisque, which while devoid of lobster meat, was potent with lobster flavor. It was red instead of white and thin instead of thick, but a solid starter. I really wanted the ahi tuna tartar, but I didn't want to be the fat summer associate known for ordering the most expensive item on the menu either. My life is full of hard decisions.

Next I had the wild caught and pan seared day boat sea scallops. I may be a drama mama, but I'm not exaggerating when I say these were the most delicious scallops ever. They were incredibly huge, slightly crisp outside, perfectly cooked inside, and in this beautiful sauce--my only gripe was that portion size. How does an entree consist of two scallops?

I was still famished and too lazy to return to work, so I decided to get the Valrhona chocolate truffle cake. It was more mousse than cake, but it satiated my appetite until 3p or so. Overall it was one of the best working lunches I've had, but only four stars because our server was missing half of the time.
author: Liz T.

description:
The food and service are pretty solid, albeit on the pricey side.  But if you come here, just remember 2 words:
Foie gras.

I'm a nice girl, but I'd bitch slap your mother in church for some foie gras a la Boulevard.
author: Cindy W.

description: Disappointing. I found the food lack flavor and creativity, leaving me bored and unimpressed. Having heard so many good things, I have been looking forward to dining at Blvd and had high expectations. However, having dined at nearly every other coveted five star restaurant in the city, I know that for a bill of $250 for two, food and service should be impeccable, and unfortunately that was not the case at Blvd. My filet mignon was cooked well, but the flavors and the side to compliment were bland, uninspired, and cold. I'd consider going back (if someone else was paying), but I'd rather dine at another top-tier restaurant, because there are just too many to choose from in SF.
author: Matt D.

description: This place was one of the top end places but recently lost its respect from food critics I guess. This place was good to me and I enjoyed it but probably not as much as other people. I do like this place a lot though and I would definitely come back for the food. Located in a good location near the ball park and right along embarcadero.
author: Tim M.

description:
i. loved. it. 

my foodie uncle was in town for a conference in japantown and asked if i'd like to meet him for lunch in the city. i asked some co-workers for a spot in SF that was BART-able so i could jet in from berkeley, and i am so glad they recommended this place! i loved every minute of my experience here; from the second i walked in and spied the gorgeous tiled floors made to look like peacock feathers, to the time the cheerful host bid me goodbye and offered me a bookmark with nancy oakes' cookbook information on it. the service was perfectly friendly and accommodating, but the food was the star of the show. 

i wanted one of everything on their frequently-changing menu, but finally settled on the pacific walu, a firm-fleshed white fish from hawaii. it was luscious yet delicate, and beautifully presented atop a bed of sauteed wild arugula with kalamata olives and artichokes. accompanying it was a "crushed yukon gold potato cake," a cake of buttery, creamy mashed potatoes seared to a crisp crust. as he was likely to eat japanese food for the rest of his stay, my uncle opted for the kobe burger, with golden french fries served in a paper cone inside a tiny copper pot. boulevard grinds their own meat, so you can order it medium-rare without hesitation. even a burger here is extra special: made of kobe beef, served with asiago cheese, little gem lettuce and heirloom tomato. we both loved our food, and my uncle even complimented me on choice of restaurants. 

some of the other yelpers who've reviewed this place have mentioned that boulevard is expensive, and while it certainly wasn't the cheapest meal i've ever had ($20 for the walu and $15.75 for the burger), i thought the quality of the food was certainly deserving of the price. it was a fantastic meal, and i can't wait to go back!
author: Kris G.

description: Everything was just perfect. The service, the ambiance, and the food. A lovely perk is that valet parking is only $10 in the evening. Even with a $5 tip, it was a bargain.
author: Penny C.

description:
Sad to say it, but truly one of the worst dining experiences I've ever had. Truly disappointing.

Let's start with the appetizers. Gritty sandy scallops?!? And not just one... all of them. Don't care to try that again. And the "meyer lemon air" on my dungeness crab salad added nothing except made me think "Oh... they use foam... must be because the chef is trying to mask some bad creation underneath". The flavor was nice on the salad, though. 

And then on to the entree. We both had filet, and both asked for medium rare. What arrived was a disaster and poorly cooked. Not sure how you can destroy a nice piece of meat, but the cook certainly did so last night. My first bite was well done (not even medium). And the whole piece was unevenly cooked. The top of my meat was medium-well while the bottom was raw. Looks like someone left it on the grill and forgot about it for a while. And the flavor? There was none... no seasoning at all. Thank god there were salt and pepper shakers on the table, because this was the first time I've ever had to season my own food at a restaurant of this "caliber". One of the sides was a fingerling potato dish cooked in duck fat. It is difficult to imagine, but they actually tasted like what happens when you get french fries as take out and leave them too long in the bag before eating them. Soggy and greasy and a bit cold.

We were hoping that the dessert would at least partially redeem the evening, but we were once again disappointed. It the third (and thankfully) final stop on our culinary adventure. The butterscotch banana cream pie was interesting in concept, but the phillo pastry shell was too dry and couldn't hold up (both flavorwise and structurally) to the goopy filling inside. The balance of whipped cream was way off too. And then there was the "White Coffee Cream Eclair with Chocolate Glaze, Vietnamese Coffee Ice Cream, Chocolate Pot de Creme, and Chinese Five Spice Shortbread". Seme like a lot? Yes, it was. A whole lot of bleh... (In truth however the ice cream was actually the best part of the meal.)

If were just up to the food, I would rate this a one star experience, but I'll give a little credit for the attentive and friendly staff, nice atmosphere, and great wine line list.

But when you're spending $300 for two for dinner, wouldn't you expect the food to be outstanding?
author: Chris C.

description: Had a small business lunch here today. The menu was over priced and quite limited. They did not have a single meal sized salad. The salmon was tasty but the asparagus soup was boring. The server was obnoxiously attentive and oddly got my order wrong. The booths were really  tight and uncomfortable and I am a small person. I won't be back.
author: j t.

description: We had a reservation for 6:30, arrived at 6:25 - we were seated as soon as we walking in the door. The tables for two are a little small - but the ambiance is really nice. Great food, great location. Valet was easy and quick.
author: Melissa W.

description:
Sunday had my first experience at boulevard. just one word WOW.......

I was feeling a little under the weather but man this was still a great meal!

We started with the: 

AHI TUNA TARTARE 
Nori Wonton Cracker, Radish & Cucumber Salad 
Asian Pears, Ginger, White Sesame Vinaigrette, Yuzu Salt 

nice fresh ahi that was just soooooooo sweet.


ITALIAN BUFFALO MOZZARELLA
Marinated Baby Artichokes, Crispy Truffled Fennel
Shaved Burgundian Truffles, Wild Arugula

mmmmm little bit of mozzarella, some artichokes and truffles !


then were the entrees:

the couple i was with had the 
MAINE LOBSTER 
BUTTER POACHED
Lobster Spaetzle, Clamshell Mushrooms, Cauliflower & Bacon
Blood Orange, Pine Nuts, Lobster Nage

ANGUS FILET MIGNON (CALIFORNIA)
WOOD OVEN ROASTED
Fondant Fingerling Potatoes with Sauce Bearnaise & Crispy Shallots
Wood Grilled Maitake Mushrooms, Sauteed Bloomsdale Spinach
Red Wine Beef Jus 

both look amazing!

I had the 
BERKSHIRE PORK RIB EYE & DUROC PORK CHEEK (IOWA)
WOOD OVEN ROASTED & SLOW BRAISED 
Yukon Gold Mashed Potatoes, Spiced Quince
Creamed Star Route Farms Nettles, Roast Pork & Braising Jus

WOW..... man the pork rib eye was tender, juicy and flavorful! Then underneath this massive pork chop there was the pork cheek . At first i realize what the pork cheek was and then i tasted it.mmmmmmm mmmm tender and just ripped apart!

then finally the desert:


i couldnt eat any more but..... 

Hazelnut Chocolate Daquoise
Hazelnut Cocoa Nib Meringue, Chocolate Truffle Cake
Hazelnut Praline Ganache, Blood Orange Marmalade Ice Cream
Burnt Orange Caramel 

WARNING: Very rich. Very Very rich. mmmmmmmmmmmmm

service was great and couldnt believe how busy it was on a Sunday night!

Treat yourself, its well worth it!
author: Roy K.

description: Great restaurant. Here with a large group and they treated us very well.  The menu is very good and the location is great. Just wish it had better views of the Bay.
author: Patrick B.

description:
I was introduced to Boulevard by my bud Teresa, as it is her favorite American restaurant. That says alot, considering how much she likes to eat.  Boulevard captures the essence of California cuisine: fresh, seasonal, locally grown produce, and locally farm raised meats. The menu is printed daily, and as the server will mention, "We consider all our dishes to be daily specials."  

I've dined here 3 times in less than 2 months, every experience wonderful and memorable. From the moment you walk through the old wooden revolving door, to the time you savor that last bite of decadent dessert, Boulevard is a classic dining experience that will keep your coming back with locals, as well as the out of towners.

Dishes I've had, and loved:

Seared fois gras (Perfect balance of flavors and textures)

Seared scallops (PERFECTION)

Arugula with goat cheese, walnuts

Lamb (You've never had lamb like this before. Flavorful and perfectly cooked. A masterpiece)

Pork Chop (Only 1 of 2 restaurants I'd order pork chops from, the other being The House in SF)

Chicken (If you like chicken, its done very well here. Crisp skin, moist chicken breast, very good in flavor)

Go, you won't be dissappointed!
author: Titi N.

description: The food here is outstanding. I could spend all day tasting different items on their menu. The staff is very attentive and friendly. You will see why this place is well known and frequented.
author: Shana K.

description:
Here's the problem I have with expensive restaurants: if I'm going to be paying a lot more for my food, it better not just taste better, it needs to taste proportionally better.  For example, a meal that costs me $40 should taste 4x better than a meal that costs $10.

Unfortunately for Boulevard, there are some amazing $10 meals to be had out there.  So before I even went to Boulevard, it already had some almost unreachable standards to live up to.

The service was excellent and the food is definitely very tasty, don't get me wrong.  But it's just tough to justify the price.

Oh, also, minus one star for not giving free refills on cokes.  You're charging me $35 for an entree and can't give me a free refill?  Lame!

If you want a fancy meal in the bay, head over to Skates in Berkeley.  Better food, better atmosphere, better view, better value (and free refills).
author: Chad H.

description:
I walked in and the first person I saw was Willie Brown, that's how good this place is!

Beyond the good food and ambiance, the wait staff was amazing!  Very nice, on top of their game the entire meal and not too in your face so you could enjoy the meal.

I had the Duck, which was good, not great, but I was able to try the Pork Prime Rib which was amazing!  When I go back, that is what I will be eating!
author: Ken V.

description: Damn I just wanted to eat here not buy the place. Ok, seriously the missus and I came here for our anniversary dinner. I had he heirloom tomatoes with bufala mozarella to start, sea bass entre, and almond rocha ice cream cake for dessert. The missus had the scallops, pork chop and the cheese plate. With all the recommendations from friends I guess I went in with overly heightened expectations.  The food was good but just didn't knock my socks off, a feat near physically impossible. It was good just not like Gary Danko good. The service was outstanding. Very knowledgeable and attentive waitstaff.
author: Michael L.

description:
My husband took me to SF for my 30th birthday. We were both so excited to go to Boulevard as we've heard so many good things about the restaurant. 

We were seated quickly bc we had a reservation and NO SERVER came over to us, looked at us, took a drink order, etc. for 20 MINUTES! Finally  my husband called over the bus boy who got a manager.  

The manager apologized and took our order. Finally a server (we didn't even know if he was our server because he didn't say hello or tell us  his name) plopped our food down in front of us. 

We enjoyed the food but since the service was SOOO bad we won't go back there anytime soon or recommend Boulevard to anyone. 

They should have given us a free dessert or glass of wine. Whatever it makes me so mad to think about it!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Lindsay S.

description:
Boulevard is a really fun neat little restaurant nestled in the Financial district of SF. Their appetizers and their desserts stole most of the show. The mains were good - but not as exciting.  
 
Rabbit bolognese ravioli with rabbit wrapped in pancetta was delish! I didn't care for the one side of the ravioli with the green stuff in it, but the bolognese was so good! Good presentation points on the ahi tuna tartare appi. 

No amuse bouche. =( 

Their cherry s'more deconstructed was very unique! Bravo for the fresh cherry ice cream and the marshmallow fluff aka meringue. 

Good decor and the service is immaculate. I love the old rustic feel. The new restaurant should not disappoint. 

Make sure to get a seat at the very back of the restaurant facing the bay bridge. That's where the best views of the city are!
author: Joyce T.

description: Boulevard is an excellent restaurant which has been consistently good for many years.  The location is by the Embarcadero and the beautiful Bay Bridge with oscillating lights and the dishes are creative and generally excellent as well as the desserts.
author: Ashley A.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in the city. It's not cheap to eat here, but it 's worth it. Chef Nancy Oakes has crafted an establishment which treats every diner to an amazing culinary and social experience.

From the moment I walked in to when our dessert plates got taken away, Boulevard was truly an enjoyable experience. 

The food (try the Walu!), the drinks, the ambience, the service, the staff -- simply outstanding.

I had dinner with my friend from NYC, and he said "this is truly a San Francisco restaurant, you can't find this in Manhattan." Even though the prices are up there -- and some of the clientele sport Birkins and Breitlings -- Boulevard is not stuffy, and has a very inviting atmosphere. 

The portions aren't heaping, but you leave very satisfied.
author: May C.

description:
I had the privilege of coming here for one of my best friends Hilary's 24th birthday. It was our roommates and Hilary's family together in the private wine cellar room and boy, we were doted upon. Let me first say that probably the single best concoction of the night was their Par Avion cocktail (prosecco, pisco, honey and a lemon twist). I had about 5 of them and tried my best not to act a fool in front of Hilary's parents.

I got the quail (as a recently defected vegetarian, I wasn't too into the quail's skin, but I ate it anyway because I didn't want to be fussy), and it was great. I sucked their little bones dry. Appetizers like the pan seared foie gras, lobster ravioli and scallops were delectable, although the foie gras was a little rich for my taste (again, newbie carnivore). I tried the pineapple panna cotta and the only thing that sucked about it was that I had to share. Everything about the meal and experience was so divine, I wish I could live in that world of decadence whenever I wanted. The bill was over $700. Impressive, huh?
author: Laura M.

description:
I've been here twice, and had a great experience both times.  I don't remember the food being all that interesting or adventurous, but it was excellently executed.  The service was impeccable for both visits.

If you're an out of towner, consider staying at the Hotel Vitale -- right across the street from Boulevard.
author: Teague A.

description: The service was great! This is a awesome place to relax and unwind after a long day. My stay was short but I'm going back hehe
author: Delroy H.

description: Great selection of tasteful food.  Good wine list, and also has a full bar.  Service is great.  Ambience is historically classy, and could be somewhat loud. Good lunch and dinner menu for intimate occassions or business.  I've had a wide selection of food from appetizers to dessert and enjoyed them all  The portions are good too!  Overall great place to go with a nice location and view too...
author: Jane E.

description: Years ago hubby & I ate at Boulevard several times. I recall it was delicious, the wait service spot on & from the 1st experience to the last time we ate there, we were never disappointed. We haven't returned only because we try to keep our $$ on the peninsula & south bay restaurants. If we really wanted a special occasion, Boulevard would be a consideration on our list of many outstanding SF restaurants. So many restaurants, so little time, $$$$ & appetite!
author: Kathi H.

description:
Boulevard is an amazing restaurant, you have to give this place the credit it deserves. The food is always what you expect, and the chefs offerings are always fun to try, the specials are always a great way to see what the chef is thinking of. I've been her a couple times and I always try something new, and the wine selection is excellent. 
You must try this restaurant, it's worth every dollar you spend, service is great, Ambience is great. 

Try everything on the menu and don't forget dessert, you will not be disappointed.
author: Benjamin B.

description: I'm not sure I've had anything that's less than delicious. Foie Gras melts in your mouth + filet mignon is cooked perfectly at medium rare + an extensive wine list to compliment any dish = complete satisfying meal
author: Jennifer C.

description:
YUM. A few things: the food is delicious here and the portions are surprisingly large for such an upscale restaurant. Bring your friends who love American (or specifically California) cuisine because Boulevard turns. it. out. when it comes to traditional items like filet mignon, sea bass, and pork chops. In a word: execution. Boulevard isn't cooking things with liquid nitrogen -- they're classic and what they do, they do very well.

Service is friendly, professional, and attentive but very low-key. They are not all over you or bringing you black napkins to match your dress/pants - so if you're looking for a place where you drop your fork and 10 people scramble to pick it up, then Boulevard is probably not the place for you. Pretty much everything we ordered was out of this world delicious, but from a conceptual standpoint certainly not awe-inspiring.

The decor and atmosphere is on the casual side given the price of the food and drinks, which some will love and others will dislike. There were women in nice dresses and also people in jeans - and a bar area where folks can sit and have a more casual nosh/drink. Don't get me wrong, it's lovely inside - but it doesn't quite say "special night out" or "fancy restaurant" the way some of the other restaurants in Boulevard's same price range would. 

The perfect place to bring your in-laws or relatives from out of town or get consistently good food and cocktails.
author: Britt M.

description:
As another reviewer said, this place is perfect for any occasion.

Originally intended to sit at the bar and dine somewhere else but the dishes looked sooooo good coming out, we got a table. 

Excellent service, excellent food AND drinks!
Clean and great interior! Just beautiful.

Definately will go back.
author: Ann F.

description:
Enjoyed a delicious goodbye dinner with a great friend here.  The food was all delicious.  Perfectly cooked lamb, duck and foie-gras ooh-la-la.  The table service was very good.  Attentive without being too stuffy although they did lean toward stuffy a bit.  All in all the evening left us smiling and elegantly sated.  

My only complaint was the wait.  We were on time for our reservation. When restaurants are picky-pants and give away reservations after 15 minutes (as they do here) the customer should be able to expect prompt service.  We waited 40 minutes huddled as close as we could to the crowded bar trying to stay out of way of the busy waitstaff.  The hostess, while very polite was unapologetic and treated the matter more as a matter of course than an exception, which tells me this is a common practice here.  A more refined welcome to an otherwise delightful experience would have been greatly appreciated.  First impressions are important.
author: Russell D.

description:
Usually wouldn't add my praise to a place with nearly 1000 accolades, but this was one of the best meals I've had this decade, and I just had to gush.

Decided to roll the dice for a last-minute business dinner here. Showed up early at the bar, asked if we could squeeze in a 5:30 walk-in (when they open for dinner), they put us on the list, and we got in!

Since getting a table here can be an event in itself, my host suggested we try a sample of their appetizers as I'd never been here before. The tuna and the scallops were only very good, but the soft shell crab and the fois gras were absolutely amazing. Highly recommended.

We both had the pork chop as an entree, the best pork chop I've ever eaten. It melted in your mouth, and was full of flavor, without being overpowering in any way. There were some other things garnishing the plate, but they were insignificant in comparison.

Had an amazing chocolate torte for desert. A total over-the-top finale.

Service was friendly, funny, and unhurried. The wine menu was small, but adequate, with a mix of wines for having a down-to-earth dinner, or an event. Prices, as per the area, are a bit on the high side, but the food and service definitely don't disappoint.
author: Ken W.

description: This the the best restaurant I have ever been to, and is certainly one of my favorites of all time. The food was prepared impeccably with incredible skill, the wait service was extremely knowledgable and polite, the formal atmosphere was flawless and incredible, and my experience was all around wonderful. Thanks Boulevard. :)
author: Lindsay R.

description: So disappointed to say we went  for a family birthday made a reservation and were seated promptly after ordering we waited at least 25 min. for our starters to arrive they were tasty,pear salad and soft shell crab...then we waited for another 30 min. in the middle of a very noisy dinning room for our entrees our server was nice but that did not make up for the wait...our entree all diff. finally arrived basically a properly cooked protein with almost invisible accompaniments, all except my daughters sole that tasted as thought the salt shaker had spilled on it!.  We left the restaurant hungry and to add insult to injury after paying an incredibly large bill my daughter aoke with a touch of gastric distress apparently from her poorly cooked sole entree. I can honestly say I would not only not recommend this restaurant but would talk anyone out of trying it..
author: L V.

description:
Good, not great, for lunch at a Michelin-star restaurant downtown.

My friend and I came here for lunch on one of our weekly Michelin star lunches in SF. The atmosphere, service, and food were all good, but not spectacular. I had lamb and my friend had a burger, neither of which were exceptional for the price. Little details, like lighting, butter temperature (for the complimentary bread), and general visual presentation of the dishes, were lacking, compared to similarly-priced restaurants. 

Would not eat here again, given the other high-end options in the downtown area.
author: Paul K.

description:
I can tell the ingredients they use are good, but all the dishes we ordered were really bland. My fish (wild pacific sea bass) on their special menu was bland (it wasn't quite seared), the t-bone lamb was gamey and bland. Only one of our friend who ordered the pork chop, that was surprisingly good.
DO NOT order their MARIN SUN FARMS GOAT "BORSETTA" RAVIOLI.  
they came out dry, gummy and super bland. THere was nothing good about this dish. IT really lack sauce and salt (but who am I kidding everything we ordered here needed some kinda seasoning).
Also we came here with two babies in tow and requested them to set up high chair...they sat two babies next to each other....which of course didn't work at all for us...since when do babies feed themselves?
If i have to come here again...I'd probably only order the pork chop and steer clear of everything else
author: Jill L.

description:
I just got back from eating lunch here, and the food was so yummy I had to write a review right away.  

I had a salad, which was good, but really...who raves about a salad.  

I am most pleased with the entree and dessert I had.  I chose the Maine crab cake sliders.  You get two sliders on a grill toasted homemade buns, topped with little bacon strips, heirloom tomatoes, and a bit of magical tartar sauce.  When I think of sliders, I think mini hamburgers.  Seeing it as a crab cake sandwich was new to me.  The crab cakes were really, crabby, too!  It had a good amount of crab meat.  My mouth was happy, happy, happy!

As for dessert. Mmmm...I wish I remembered what it was called on the menu, but it was a brioche soaked with berry sauce topped with good creme fresh and fresh berries all around.  There was a dollop of ice cream on the side with some chocolate shavings underneath.  

Boulevard really knows how to serve good, well thought out food.
author: Rowena B.

description:
Overall experience was quite delightful. 
We started with:
1.  The foie gra - the pumpkin bread pairing was delicious
      Beet & goat cheese ravioli- very bland, I would not recommend
For entrees we had:
2.  Filet Mignon- Always a pleasure 
     Roast pork- Really tough to find lions this tender
Dessert:
3.  Huckleberry treat- awful, the peanut brittle tasted burnt & wheres the cinnamon
     Doughnut cheesecake- I thought it was amazing but my gf didn't

Service:  They were really busy so I had to pour my own wine.  Other than that, service was stellar

Atmosphere:  Big winner here with all the festive decorations.
author: LIVE to E.

description: Beautiful restaurant and ambiance, great service and delicious food. It is pricey, but a great place for a special evening. The lobster ravioli is amazing
author: Nicole L.

description: Very classy place, great ambiance, even better location.  Top notch service.  Delicious sourdough bread.  We ordered the scallops appetizer and really enjoyed.  The ahi tuna entree was to die for and had some sort of pumpkin on the side.
author: V. H.

description:
This is one of the best all around restaurants in San Francisco. Greats, views, excellent service. beautiful decor and phenomenal food. I have been a bunch of times and have not been disappointed yet.

I usually order the same thing thing (surprise, surprise) and it is excellent. The nectarines in the salad I get are the best ever. It's like you are eating candy instead of fruit. I really wish I knew where I could get these. Also their fillet is spot on. Nice and tender and always cooked to order.
author: Jeff P.

description: My husband and I chose Boulevard to celebrate a very special occasion - finding out the gender of our baby!  They sat us in a nice booth and made the whole night very special.  We brought in a cake from a nearby bakery which had the color of the gender of the baby hidden inside.  The waiter was so accommodating - he even served as our official photographer!  The entire wait staff came by to check on us and see what the gender was.  They were all so friendly and sweet!  It was a great and memorable night thanks to the staff at Boulevard!
author: Hayley D.

description:
As a tradition, our family of four has a special dinner three days before Christmas. This year we chose Boulevard.  Without a doubt this is one of the most beautiful restaurants in the City during the holidays. My wife and I have eaten here once or twice a year for the past ten years.

That said, we're unlikely to return and will simply try new places instead.  The combination of the slow service, minuscule portions, prices ($10+ over similar), dreary offerings and "unspecialness" (over-hyped, out-of-towners) make it a has-been in my book.

As far as the food goes my adult sons were really disappointed by the small sizes and unimaginative preparation. I was particularly disappointed with the fois gras; it was a demi-cut at best, overcooked and the little holiday touches (sugared nuts and pumpkin bar) did nothing but make it look lonely on the plate. It looked comical.

Wine selection is average and reasonably priced considering the cost of the entrees.
author: Richard G.

description:
We hit Boulevard by chance - Tuesday night in San Francisco without reservations, and a last-minute call confirmed a table for 3. We were seated quickly and graciously in the otherwise packed room, which was dressed up for the holidays with some extra glitter and frills. It's a busy space, visually compressed by the low, barrel vaulted ceilings, but still very attractive.

My feelings about my meal were mixed. The tuna crudo appetizer was skilfully prepared and attractively presented. Small chunks of grapefruit and mango, paper-thin jalapeno and fennel slices and a grassy EVOO added an interesting mix of flavors; I couldn't help but notice that their presence forced the very slightly-flavored tuna to serve more as a platform than a presence of its own. 

My entree was just the opposite. Wayu - a white-fleshed, buttery Hawaiian fish - was cooked perfectly and nestled among black & gold chanterelles, roasted butternut squash, farro, fregola & black barley with arugula, hearts of palm and violin squash, whatever that is. The flavors were fabulous... one offsetting the other with  contrasting and complimentary notes. (The only less-than perfect note was the less-than inspiring hearts of palm, and it may be that there were just a few too many on the plate.) While the first dish had technique but lacked balance in flavor, the entree had it all. The knifework, cooking and assembly of the entire dish were truly impressive, but never tricky or showy. Everything was done, seemingly, for a reason - strength of flavor of each ingredient determined the size of dice and slice, all to good effect.

In a sense, that's how I felt about the entire experience at Boulevard. Service was for the most part excellent; helpful and knowledgable without showing off or calling attention to itself. The sommelier was extremely knowledgable yet utterly un-intimidating. The one small hitch we found in the service - twice - was some small lack of coordination in timing. We ordered our meals, and wine from the sommelier - and the meals arrived before he was back with the wine. I admit my appetizer sat for a minute while I waited for him to pour the wine. 

I decided to go with a glass of Ramey Chardonnay with my entree, rather than the excellent tinta de toro;  again, my entree arrived before the wine. I would have preferred to have the wine first, of course, but hardly a fatal flaw.

We split one huckleberry tart three ways, and while the filling and accompanying fluer de sel ice cream were delicious, the crust was - not sure how to put this - highly competent but uninspired. Perhaps the dough lacked a touch of salt, but it just was uninspiring after the care lavished on all the individual ingredients in the preceding dishes.

I'd go back, and probably will.
author: Robert D.

description: Boulevard nailed it! Excellent cuisine: Pistachio, Pear, and Goat Cheese Salad was divine; dessert exceeded any and all of the sugar fantasies my limited mind could conjure up.. we sampled the Caramel/Chocolate/Rootbeer/Honeycomb delight, the Dark Chocolate Pretzel Bon-Bons, Cinnamon Chocoates, and two of the sorbets.
