Mmmmmmm! The staff was polite, friendly, and helpfuI. They made us feel so special! I have to give them well-deserved props for being so accommodating to the vegetarian diet. While there are a couple of meatless dishes on the starters list, there is actually a vegetarian main course not listed, so just ask! It's a creative palette packed with a variety of tastes! Enjoy, and have fun on the way to the bathroom. It's an adventure in itself!
author: sydney h.

description:
Nearly everything that needs to be said about this restaurant has already been said - it's stunning, you are treated like royalty, the food is incredible. 

The only thing I need to add is that this *is* a place for vegetarians. You just wouldn't know it from the menu. Currently there are just three vegetarian starters, 2 salads and a pasta appetizer. All are excellent. 

The entree side of the menu shows no vegetarian options. BUT, everyday they create a vegetarian entree special, and I've been able to enjoy two of them so far. The veggie entree isn't an afterthought, it's a selection from all the different sides off the meat-based entrees, but done beautifully. When I get my special platter with 10+ different items (seriously), I feel like the lucky one at the table. 

Some of the items from Friday night's platter: asparagus, fava beans and english peas, braised spinach, cauliflower with mimolette fonduta, herb roasted artichoke heart, brie, *three* different preparations of potatoes, wine-soaked cherries, trumpet mushrooms, Crispy Cippolini Onion Stuffed with Gruyere, and one or two more things. 

For the vegetarians that have complained that this isn't the place for them... I'm not sure if things have changed or what. But I called the restaurant and confirmed they do a veggie special everyday. And by the way, it's only $25. For some of the best food I've ever had, and the most variety, it's a steal at what is arguably the best restaurant in the city.
author: Jen L.

description: It was good, not spectacular.  We had a similar meal at Insalata's later on in the week, and it was equally as good (saying this because the items we ordered were very similar).  I really do wish I could give it more starts, but it was just A-OK as yelp says 3 stars indicates.
author: Nicole S.

description:
We have lived in the SF Bay area for many years, and have continued to return to Boulevard for its beautiful setting, excellent food and service.  We even hosted a significant birthday party for my husband in their private room a few years back.

Unfortunately, last weekend we were quite disappointed.   We went on Saturday to celebrate Valentines Day, so really wanted to have a special and great meal.   We were considering Masa or Gary Danko, but opted for Boulevard because it had been a while since we had been there.

To me, a 3 star review is a serious criticism for a place of this calibre.   We were hoping for some advice from the sommelier about a particular wine.  Our waiter indicated he would have him sent over.  After about 15 minutes of waiting with no word, we received help from another waiter who was quite knowledgeable.    Strike 1.   My husband ordered a filet mignon cooked "medium."   Well, it came quite rare.  Pretty surprising for a restaurant of this caliber.   They redid both of our meals, but that was it.    When I have to send back my meal because it isn't -objectively- properly cooked I expect at least an apology or some kind of gesture to make up for the meal.   Most high calibre restaurants would remove the charge for part a meal that they botched.   Nothing of the sort at Boulevard that night, which left me really annoyed.  It will be a while before we return, if ever.
author: Jennifer M.

description: I don't often enjoy eating lamb out but the lamb at Boulevard is perfection.  The fig, prociutto salad dreamy, and I tried a bite or two of the quail with peaches, etc.  Everything was sooooooo delicious.  But mostly I give it 5 stars because I had so much fun watching my date enjoy all the food.  :)  We both remembered why it's his favorite restaurant.
author: Set S.

description: Went a couple weeks ago on a date!!! Awesome Lamb!!! Yum!!
author: Domina V.

description:
i've been to Boulevard many times and they never disappoint...

don't:
be in a hurry

do:
get a cocktail and sit at the counter.
order at least 2 appetizers (more if you can fit it in) and go somewhere else for dessert.
ask the waiter for suggestions, but never get the special 
order a bottle of wine and enjoy your meal.  even if it's just you.

love this place, maybe as much as Tadich Grill...
author: Greg L.

description: I went here for a birthday dinner and was definitely impressed; there was "Alaskan salmon" on the menu at the time, and since I am from Alaska, I thought I would give the waiter a challenge and ask what watershed the salmon was from. While he didn't know off the top of his head, he researched and returned promptly with the response Copper River. Aside from the obviously fabulous service, the food was phenomenal and gourmet. I would absolutely return.
author: Ella A.

description:
The fine, fine best friend birthday tradition continues:

His 29th: Bobo's
My 30th: Quince
His 30th: Gary Danko
My 31st: Chez Spencer
His 31st: Boulevard

We started with a list of appetizers that we both agreed was one of the most difficult to choose from. We wanted them all. We settled on the japanese hamachi, featuring a fantastic orange carpaccio, as well as the foie gras. Don't get me wrong yelpers, I'm normally anti. I hope the city passes the ordinance to ban it. But when the birthday boy wants it, I'm off my soapbox. And this foie gras, with toasted acme whole grain bread, vanilla cherries, root beer jelly and beer nut bon nons was superb. Make sure you scoop all those flavors together at once.

On to the main course.

I went with the salmon, deliciously surrounded by risotto, fava beans and peas. He had the quail breast, which was complemented by one of the best ravioli I've ever had. How do I know this? Because both dishes were so appealing we shared.

We debated dessert for a minute, decide to go for it, and ended with one of those how can something taste this good layered chocolate and peanut butter ice cream cake.

Service was exceptionally attentive. Everyone on the wait staff exuded that confidence that only comes at a place where they know what they are serving up is good. Atmosphere was lively, perfect for a celebration.

I cannot wait to see where we go next.
author: Jason B.

description:
Boulevard is undoubtedly a fine dining establishment. The menu is classic American cuisine--great, fresh produce, traditional combinations, an older crowd, an exquisite wine list, and cocktails that Mad Men's Don Draper would aptly describe as "simple and significant." 

I dined at Boulevard last week with my sister and her husband. The bufala mozzarella in the caprese appetizer was the best bufala I have ever had. The tomatoes were succulent, and the basil was fresh. To be honest, the rest of the meal was sort of a blur. I'm not sure if that was a product of the great conversation and company, or if it was because the food was great, but not  as mind-blowing as I expected. I ordered the lamb t-bone which was delicious, but not memorable. The best dish of the table, however, was the wood-oven roasted angus filet mignon that my sister ordered. This steak was to die for--perfectly cooked, juicy, excellent! The crisp fingerling potatoes that came with it were equally tasty. 

All in all, this was a lovely place to dine, but not "the best" culinary experience I have had to date.
author: Vassi I.

description:
As you walk through the revolving door, you can see straight to the back of the restaurant.  The kitchen is open and the tables that are parallel to the kitchen can see the chefs running back and forth.  The bar is fully stocked and it was empty the night we went.  This reminds me of a place straight out of Gotham.  It doesn't seem like the sort of establishment you can stumble into while strolling down the street.

They seated us at a small table that was pushed up against a metal gate near the bar.  To my immediate left was a group of 4 people speak Japanese the entire time, so it wasn't too hard to tune them out.  It wasn't the best seating in the world, I felt hidden off to the side.  As we got situated I noticed they left me a black napkin.  YES!!!!  I finally found a place that hands out black napkins if you're wearing black.  I almost thought that the black napkin thing was a myth...so many lint filled days.  Anyway, back to the review.

We started with the Maine lobster and shrimp ravioli and it was delicious!  We also ordered the Neal Cab, which was nice but I thought I was being smart by ordering a bottle...turned out to be an $80 bottle....yes, that was a bad idea.   Brett our server, was nice and he kept coming back to refill our glasses, but we still didn't finish the bottle that night.

For dinner I had the fillet mignon and my husband had the Scottish salmon.  I think he got the better dish that evening.  After dinner we ordered dessert.  I ordered the white coffee cream eclair with a white chocolate glaze and he ordered the butterscotch banana cream pie.  

The service was impeccable and the atmosphere was not stiff.  I think this is a very charming place and I wouldn't mind coming back if they change the menu, I'd love to try something new.
author: Ash P.

description: Excellent service...our waiter gave excellent recommendations for food. Great food. We had a couple starters and entree that were too die for. Lovely time and will visit again when I'm visiting the area! Next time I'll try to go for the bar area where you can watch the chefs cook.
author: Amanda C.

description:
I will never go back to a place that treats minorities different from whites.
I felt like I went back in time 40 years.
author: roy t.

description:
My wife and I had been meaning to eat at Boulevard for over a year, but had never managed to make a reservation (partly because they apparently block reservations from OpenTable during prime hours, so it doesn't show up when we are looking for a place to eat).  Finally managed to get there back in June.

We had an excellent meal here.  For appetizers I had the scallops and my wife had the abalone, both of which were very good.  I had the pork chop for dinner and my wife tried the quail.  We really enjoyed them both.  Managed to have a bit of room for desert, so I had some of the vanilla ice cream (fine, but not as good as the appetizers and entrees).

The service and ambiance at Boulevard were great.   It was a pricey meal, but we really enjoyed it (once we finally got around to going!).
author: Richard M.

description: Nice enough, kinda loud, food wasn't bad. The restaurant staff took themselves VERY seriously, to distraction. Wish they gave the same amount of attention to food and service.
author: Flynn L.

description: Some restaurants just don't need to be on yelp.  This is one of them. Excellent from top to bottom. Over 1400 reviews so I'm sure I don't have to say another great thing.  Our waiter did slack on getting us water and getting our togo bag.  He spend most of his free time chatting with other servers while they were getting their customers orders.  Aside from our service everything was top notch.  I just want to know where to get one of those cool BLVD ball caps the chefs were wearing.
author: Joco F.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF.

Sure, you gotta book like 5 bajillion years in advance at some random date and time to get a table... but if you actually get one, you are going to be in for a treat!

Everything I tried was unbelievably awesome. 

My recommendation: the Foie Gras was amazing...

The service was some of the best I've ever experienced in a restaurant. They really know how to run that operation.

Yeah, you're going to pay a lot...but if you're into food, you will definitely enjoy it. If you're a cheapskate, or rate a restaurant based on how much food they pile on your plate...don't even bother.
author: AC M.

description:
I've been here twice. Once for just drinks, and the last time was when I treated my fabulous flatmate to a dinner. She would give this place 5 stars.

Drinks: They are pretty stiff, and that alone justifies the price. I had a Manhattan and it was solid.

Food: The most memorable thing about my meal were the seared scallops. They were a bit dry, but the seasoning and lemon saved them. I know mistakes happen, and what came next more than made up for it. I had the rib chop and my flatmate had to squab. Both were cooked and seasoned perfectly.

Service: The service was excellent. I felt that the server went out of his way to make me and my flatmate feel at home.

I would definitely go back here again with a date or some really important business clients.
author: Jim B.

description:
Went here to celebrate our engagement with my fiancée  as this is one of her favorite places to eat!

I had never been to Boulevard before this. We had 2 courses each and a bottle of red wine the total come to about $150 with tip.

one really nice thing they did when the waitress found out why we were they they wrote congratulations in chocolate in our desert! sometimes it is the little things that you take note of the most.

being a michelin rated place it had all you would expect.

It is well worth it.
author: Mark H.

description: Went here for my birthday dinner and exceptional food and service. The price tag was higher than comparable places in nyc but having tried other places in sf - it's on par with price. Notable wine list and knowledgeable servers with pairings.
author: Soniya V.

description:
A few years ago Boulevard was a destination.  If you wanted to let people know that you have finally arrived, Boulevard was it.  We used to take our important clients here for lunch in the late 1990s and our important new hires - in the early 2000s.

Fast forward to 2009, and a lot has changed.  Gary Danko, Michael Mina and Aqua made Boulevard slightly less relevant, but it's still a great spot for a business lunch. Instead of celebrating new hires, we said farewell to two of our employees who were leaving the company.  Whatever the reason for dining here, I still adore Boulevard for the atmosphere, ambiance and consistency. 

We made reservations for a group of 10.  They asked us for a credit card, which would be charged a $100 cancellation fee should we fail to show up.  I thought it was an unnecessarily strict policy, until I realized that they set up a private room for us.  The room, located to the right of the main dining room, is a small wine cellar with a table big enough for 10-12 people.  The room had stone walls, a monastery-like ceiling and wine racks filled with bottles.  It was like dining in a grotto - a bit creepy yet secluded and beautiful.  I am not sure whether they put us in that room to keep us away from the rest of the customers, but it worked.

For my first course, I went with Ahi Tuna Tartar.  It was served on a long, thin plate along with mushroom tempura.  The tuna was very good, although the tiny Japanese cucumber cubes sprinkled all over seemed to overwhelm the tender taste of tuna.  The miatake mushroom tempura was served with some sauce that tasted like wasabi mayo.  A bit too strong for my taste.  The tuna tartar itself was great, almost as good as Aqua's.

For my main course, I went with the Kobe Bavette steak, medium rare.  The steak (about 6 oz) was tender and flavorful.  It's a shame there wasn't more of it.  I wish it'd come on a bed of another steak, not on a bed of spinach . . . I left the spinach on the plate, and I cannot speak to its quality.  The steak was served with potatoes, crushed with shallots and bacon.  Dee-licious.  All this was served with a dollop of creme fraiche, which had a unique sweet taste, making it more suitable for a dessert course.

Speaking of dessert, I went with a Banana Dulce De Leche Truffle cake.  Caramelized banana was slightly overcooked, making caramel taste slightly burnt.  I enjoyed the dulce de leche sauce which went well with my vanilla ice cream (I asked them to substitute chocolate for vanilla).

Our waitress was extremely professional and handled our 10-person party with ease.  I was surprised how polished the service was, and how proper the table setting was.  The knives, the plates, the iced tea in a glass decanter - all pointed to a high class establishment.  Boulevard also did NOT add the tip to the bill, even for a party of 10.  It actually worked out in the waitress' favor, but she really did deserve that 19% tip.  A 3-course meal for 10 + a few drinks + a bottle of wine for the table + tip = $800.  Ouch.

Great restaurant, great service.  I'll be back as soon as I am allowed to use the company credit card at lunch again.
author: Yan G.

description:
This place was delicious. The service was EXCELLENT (5*) and the ambiance was nice as well :) 
I felt like the appetizers didn't live up to the expectations (we had the roasted pear, ahi tuna, calamari) and then for the entrees we had the quail, salmon, steak, & sea bass. The food was good but nothing I would scream pay $$$$$ for this! I felt like I could've found something similar but for a little less. 

However, at the end of the day, I will say, you won't get service like this just anywhere in the city, it's worth the $ for the service & the food is good. Worth at least 1 visit :)
author: linda t.

description: This restaurant delivers both service that is educated and friendly backed by solid food and wine.     Since this visit did not afford a trip to Napa,  out waiter Jeff paired our wines with each appetizer we ate (there were 6 for 2 people) and then the meal.  Each wine he gave a visual definition of the winery, history and set an expectation and was capable to deliver a real experience.    Thank you!
author: Marcus A.

description:
Consistently one of the best restaurants in the city. I've never had a disappointing dish or glass of wine here. The atmosphere is comfortable and the service is always on point. Big plus for having Paul Hobbs on the menu. 

Last week while there, I had my normal (personal Boulevard favorite) foie gras starter that can never disappoint even with this have been the umpteenth time I ordered it.  While taking a few clandestine stabs at my dinner buddy's plate of a delicious roasted beet salad while he wasn't looking. We then moved onto our mains - mine being the lamb, his being the ribeye. 

I highly recommend you trying out the lamb, it's not your average chop for sure. Accompanied by a savory mash, it was tender enough to cut with a fork alone. 

We split a scrumptious chocolate torte with house made espresso ice cream to end the night and both of us were satiated and so happy with the choices. Boulevard, you continue to be my no hassle guarantee to a great meal.

Also try out their cocktail, the San Francisco Sensation. It's a sort of lighter tastier and more fantastic rendition of a lemon drop.
author: Anthony B.

description:
We showed up on time for our reservation and had to wait 25 minutes to be seated.  So one star off for that. 

Everything picked up from there. Food was delicious (I had foie gras and lamb, he had "bouillabaisse" and pork) and service was great. Jeff was full of good recommendations, they were super patient with my slow eating, and recommended great wine to accompany. 

I might avoid this place on nights when the giants are in town, (we think this explains the table wait as the place cleared out right after we were seated) but otherwise a great spot for a date night. Will definitely be going back!
author: Allison M.

description:
This was an A-OK dinner! We had a great table, and I bonded with coat guy who moved too fast to get a tip :(
The star was the foie gras! 
We split the gnocchi, crab salad and I had the scallops as an entree. All three of those were good, but not mind blowing. Even the desserts didn't look appealing- not sure what was going on. 
Our server was fabulous, we loved our wines- minus one selection from another server, but we returned it and got what we had originally wanted but were talked out of.
Makes me sad to say cuz I had an amazing time right down to the after dinner Calvados when I was last here a few years ago.
author: Catherine R.

description:
...originally from los angeles, we were spoiled by the best of what was offered here...so we brought our palate-talents to norcal. making last minute reservations on the drive up, boulevard (which was recommended by a cousin) was accommodating over the phone and we hoped this would transcend upon our arrival- and it was. 

beautiful decor, a fusion of classy and spunk, everyone from the wait staff to the chefs (and even the patrons) livened up the atmosphere. we were situated in the small area near the kitchen where we witnessed chefs concoct their masterpieces. outside the window, you can see san fran at its finest like in our experience, the national pillow fight day lol it was entertaining to watch the fight while taking a bite into the tartare. (after the pillow fights by the 1000s and 1000s there, the city was covered in feathers)

for dinner we had the pork shoulder and filet mignon, starting off with ahi tuna tartare and the scallops. pairings were a house cab. for dessert we went with the chocolate flourless cake and chewy caramello bar. amazing thru and thru from presentation to execution, we couldnt rave enough about this place and would definitely come back...
author: rocky a.

description:
Really solid restaurant.  

I went with a friend.  We split an appetizer of a octopus and calamari soup.  It wasn't all that memorable.  

For dinner I had the Farewell to Foie Gras.  This was a decadent main course.  But what do you expect with a giant hunk of foie gras on top of a wagyu steak.  Probably the best foie gras I've had, but other than that the dish wasn't all that memorable.  

Final Rating:
Very nice dinner, but a place that I won't necessarily go out of my way to visit again.  Definitely got out shined by Frances the following night.  

Greg
author: Greg V.

description:
I took my kids here a few times and I absolutely love this place. Everything on the menu is great and I would recommend that whichever you decide, it will be good, guaranteed! The atmosphere is very welcoming and the staff are very friendly! 
Sure the prices are a little expensive, but worth it! For me its the quality of the food and not the quantity and although the portions aren't "big" they are enough to fill a person and delicious!
Can't wait to come here again soon!
author: Danny C.

description:
This place is solid but there are definitely better places for the money.  I wasn't blown away by anything.  We ended up here after looking for a beef brisket sandwich (don't ask), instead we filled out bellies with foie gras, abalone and filet.  Service is good and the prices weren't crazy, but, again, for the reputation this place enjoys I expected more.  

We did walk right in, though, and one of us *ahem* even had flip flops on.  In this economy they'll seat anyone!
author: Matt S.

description:
Came here with a lot of expectations after reading all the great reviews about The Boulevard.  Started with a whisky drink while waiting to be seated.  I can't remember the exact name of the drink...Square something, something Square.  Anyhow, it was a good drink.  Good flavor with a nice kick.  

Got seated and ordered three starters and an entree serving two people.  The sashimi was fresh and excellent, the lobster chowder was nothing I've ever tasted (amazing!), fried soft shell crab was so good it made me hungrier, and finished off with pork chop for the entree.  The meal was most excellent.  I would definitely recommend The Boulevard to friends.  It lived up to its expectations.
A very good one. we are so lucky to got a table via walk in last night! They are very friendly and my son is the only one child in the restaurant in a raining day. A big thanks to them! :)
author: Sherry C.

description: I have been to Boulevard a number of times.  I can say, without hesitation, that it's one of the very best... right up there with The French Laundry IMHO, with less snootiness.  I went recently with friends from London and they were god-smacked and wouldn't stop talking about it until I put them on the plane home.  Wonderful!
author: Warwick M.

description:
You know, I have been here for lunch many times and the food was good, service was good, but definitely over priced

A very near and dear friend of mine loved this place. Every time he and his wife visited SF,  they always went to this restaurant. So when we knew our friend had limited time left, we wanted to have a special experience at their favorite restaurant for him.

We called a month in advance to set up the reservation. I specifically asked for a table for six, upstairs with a view. I explained the circumstances of our friend and his illness. I then checked to confirm this reservation two weeks ahead, and finally the day of. We all wanted this evening to be special.

So we all arrive at the Boulevard, convening in the bar for pre-dinner cocktails. We arrived 30 minutes early and were told our table was not ready. We had a second round. Then when we checked in to the hostess stand, we were told our table had been given away and it would be 90 minutes before another table upstairs was opened. After all the pre-planning we had done, communicating to the restaurant, we were so disappointed. We were seated in the middle of the downstairs area. So basically every time someone opened the door to go to the bathrooms you got a breeze. The noise was insane, we could hardly hear each other. It just got worse from here.

Our server was not friendly at all. She did not have anything favorite to recommend nor did she encourage trying an appetizer. She went out of her way to act like it was not her choice to wait on us at all. The ticket times on everything were horrible. We received our appetizers, then about 4 minutes later our salads, and then not 5 minutes after that our entrees. This is really confusing for me because the coho and the pork chop were both way over cooked. At this point, most of us are feeling really uncomfortable because of how obvious it was the server did not want to wait on us. We asked for a manager twice. The manager came out, gave a semi - believable apology and offered us each a free dessert. We picked two desserts which were decent. Then the server charged us for them. At this point we were so exasperated. I waited around to get the ticket fixed. I asked the server what her problem was after my party had left. She did not think anything was out of order or wrong with anything she did at all. 

So my dear friend's last experience at the Boulevard was a disaster. It has taken me a long time to put this in writing but it was such a shame it had to turn out this way. I will never visit this restaurant again.
author: Jason K.

description:
Have an immensely enjoyable dinner last night at Boulevard.  

Starters included the deviled crab bisque and dungeness crab salad.  The bisque was incredible and the crab salad was very good.  

Main courses were the swordfish and the lobster/mussel beignets.  The swordfish was very good and the lobster/mussel beignets were out of this world.

For dessert, we had the asian pear sorbet, the orange/vanilla sorbet and the bon bons.  All very good and a perfect complement to the meal.

We had not had dinner here in quite some time, though we have lunched here frequently.  We will definitely return soon.
author: David F.

description:
My experience with Boulevard, bar its very beginning, was spectacular. The beginning? When we entered (no posted hours, by the way), the petite manager/hostess gave us her best Minnie Mouse impression and said, "I'm sorry, we stop serving at 2:15." 
"Well what time is it?" I asked, pulling out my phone. I looked at it and turned to my friend. "It's 2:20." Minnie just smiled. The restaurant was full of people. Minnie rattled off the names of some other area restaurants she thought might still be serving. I was less than thrilled so I said, "By five minutes, really? We made a special trip to come here and had trouble parking..." She just smiled and said nothing. I looked around at the full restaurant and gave her my best "bitch are you for real" face. [At this point my friend said she wanted to say, "Yeah I'm black and my friend has blue hair but this is San Francisco, don't make us get all Seven on Your Side."] Minnie squeaked that she'd go ask her kitchen. She returned and patronizingly said, "You can eat but you have to pick something RIGHT AWAY." Um, okay. 
But, once we were seated? The service was spectacular. We were not rushed and when I made some mention to our waitress of how I knew we had to order quickly she just waved her hand dismissively. She was great. 
Now on to the food!!! Oh, man, it was fantastic. They do not miss a trick. My favorite was the lobster bisque soup. Paired with their amazing, crusty, spongy bread and butter I wanted it to last forever. I also enjoyed the beet and goat cheese salad and my friend's shrimp salad looked as divine as little lobsters. We both had the scallop entrée and they were impeccable. I'm not a big risotto fan but it was well-cooked and savory. We also enjoyed a few different options from the drink menu. If you don't drink you should still check out their cocktail menu as they have the best non-alcoholic listings I've seen in any San Francisco restaurant. I had an Arnold Palmer with fresh lemonade, but they had other more amazing-sounding beverages with muddled mint, etc. For lunch, with both of us having soup, a starter, an entrée and an [albeit nonalcoholic] drink from the bar, we spent about $50 each before tip. Considering it would be easy to spend twice that much on their dinner menu I'd recommend lunch as a great way to try this amazing restaurant and not break the bank. Just make sure to get there by 2:15 because Minnie Mouse shuts that place down like it's a McDonald's.
author: Jane P.

description:
My husband and I went to Boulevard for our Anniversary the other day. Let me start by saying that we eat out quite a bit and have had some amazing meals. We have also previously eaten at Bouelvards sister restaurant, Prospect, which was amazing and a 5-star experience all around. Based on that, I was looking forward to Boulevard. Boy are they completely different!  

Service at both restaurants were amazing so I am surprised that Boulevard was knocked on their service in prior reviews. Our waiter was prompt, knew the menu, offered his opinion (this is huge in my book, I hate when a waiter tells me that eveything is amazing and has no opinion), offered suggestions (I told him what type of wine I was looking to start with before we opened the bottle we brought and he made the perfect suggestion based on what I was looking for) and made us aware of the wine policy (corkage is waived on the bottle we brought if we buy a bottle from them, even if it's a half bottle). I will say that the gentleman that was our bus boy was extremely sub-par not refilling water, bread or removing the empty plates which the waiter compensated for. The waiter did pretty much everything on his own and did it extremely promt and attentive. 5 Stars for our waiter. 

Ambience was nice but Prospect felt a lot more upscale, private and quiet. Prospect felt like a restaurant worthy of over $100 per person while I felt Boulevard felt like an upscale bar that people working in the area would frequent for Happy Hour. Not a Michelin Star rated restaurant. 

The food was the biggest disappointment of all. It was just ok. We had 2 app's (Ravioli's & Scallops), 2 salads (Heirloom Tomato & Fig) and 2 entree's (Quail & Pork Chop) we both shared and nothing stood out. Nothing was worthy of the Michelin Star. As a matter of fact, the ravioli's were down right gross. It said they were filled with Duck or something or the other. 3 ravioli's came and 1 was the meat filled and the other 2 were filled with a bitter spinach, not cheese and spinach, just bitter spinach. Every store bought ravioli I have ever had bet the pants off of these. We decided to cut our losses and go elsewhere for dessert it was such a disappointment. The entire meal we compared the food to other restaurants and their sister restaurant. Even the bread at Prospect feels more like a Michelin rated restaurant than Boulevard. At Propect they have people delivering a piece of fresh baked bread that is amazing hot out of the oven as it comes out. It sucked having to wait for your next piece as they made their was around the dining room but it was amazing and felt like a high end restaurant whereas as Boulevard, they drop off a plate of cold sourdough that is very run of the mill. To me it's little stuff like that, that makes an experience. 

Needless to say, we won't go back to Boulevard but we will be going back to their sister restaurant Prospect. Based on my experience I can't understand the Michelin rating and the "Best Restaurant" award.
author: Christina F.

description: My wife and I have been to this restaurant numerous times and loved it.  However on a recent trip there we were shocked.  I had a pork chop that was so tough that I had to saw through it with a steak knife.  My wife had lamb and found it tasteless.  When a meal with wine is over $200. you expect much better.
author: John S.

description:
Quick reservations were made here at the last min. Arrived and had a great time. Now, I know I look a lot younger than I really am, but omg I was pretty much the youngest one in here. O well. Hahaha.

Great place to grab drinks. But dinner was definitely right on. I forget our waiter's name, but he was such a sweetheart! 

Scallops
Swordfish-i loved this dish. not too tough or tender
Halibut-seasoned and tasty

and of course lillet blanc!
author: Lola D.

description:
Just say you pay what you get!!! Services and food were excellent, and yes it's very pricey!!!

Ordered:
Seared Dayboat Sea Scallops
Japanese Hamachi
Atlantic Sea Bass

Overall it was all excellent, can't remember what else was ordered.
author: Nhung T.

description: I was going to place a reservation for more than 10 folks. You would think that they would put people that represented their restaurant well. Instead, I spoke to someone cold, not interested & snooty.
author: Spooky E.

description:
Dined on a Saturday, party of 9 and we all had an appetizer and entree,  the awards this restaurant had is now a mystery to me. Half of the dishes were good and the other half just not. The building is beautiful, the staff is not. If it weren't for our wonderful server Ethan the rating would be a 2. The hostess staff and bartender were unfriendly and seemed annoyed to be there. 
The kitchen in the middle of the restaurant needs better ventilation, my cloths still smell like beef! Honestly if you are a vegetarian I don't think you would enjoy dining here.
I hate leaving a place that is so highly rated thinking we way over paid for the experience.
If you go.....we all loved the Filet, Scallops and Salmon (although the salmon dinner was so small in portion it looked like an appetizer). Avoid the Lamb, under cooked ( and I love rare), over salted (and I love salt). 
Lesson here don't assume Awards = excellence.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Excellent, creative, comfortable restaurant.
Staff is very professional and courteous. Excellent wine list, meats and desserts - butterscotch pudding is one of my favorites.
Smart spot for business dinners, as it has a very good menu for a broad set of tastes and staff is very discreet.
In the last few years it has lost a bit of it's thunder to Water Bar and other newer places downtown as a "place to be seen", but it's still always a good choice.
author: Michael B.

description:
A perpetual reminder that San Francisco has some of the finest restaurants in the country and this is one of finest in the City. 

Go here as soon as you can, you will be delighted. 

No more need be said.
author: Nicolas E.

description: Wonderful fine dining with great food and beautiful plating.  The pork chop was the best I've ever eaten--tender and flavored perfectly. Finest and freshest ingredients as well.  Service was very attentive and low-key.  For a crowded and busy place, the noise level was acceptable.  It's a friendly and non-intimidating restaurant and deserving of its past acclaim.
author: John K.

description: Got this recommendation from a local SF foodie, and he was right on target. Food was delicious, service was fantastic, beverages were tasty and prices were fair. Convenient location, and not too loud even though restaurant was full.
author: John A.

description: Excellent experience. Great food. My husband had the steak which was cooked to perfection. Our waiter, Ethan, took FANTASTIC care of us. Great food, great service, great ambiance. I will go back next time I'm in SF
author: Nilo K.

description:
The Boulevard is in a great location, a "vintage" building, right downtown, and easy to get to. You do need to make a reservation if you are going for dinner-- it was really busy, even at 8PM on a Wednesday night. 

There was a "businessy" feel to the crowd-- a lot of men in suits. It is also very pricey, so if someone didn't have a job, I don't think they'd be going there in the first place (which might explain the clientele, at least in part). I wouldn't say the atmosphere was "hip" or "trendy". "Sophisticated" might be a good descriptor. 

The service was excellent. The server we had was friendly, attentive, and cared about us and our experience (at least she made us feel like she did). Now...about the food. The best part was the chocolate mocha cake. It was about $14, but served two for sure, and was delicious. The rest of the meal wasn't so great. We had to send our halibut back because it was undercooked, The flavour was good-- but it should have been cooked. The calamari starter was also "ok". It had a pretty fishy taste.

Overall, I thought it was just "ok". I might go back if it were for a business dinner type event, but I wouldn't want to go there with friends or on date night.
author: Kristn K.

description: I have been going here around Christmas for over 10 years and I love it more and more every time! Amazing place, the decorations are awesome around Christmas time and the food is bangin!!!! Portions look small but really fills you up and the staff is amazing. Once asked for creme brûlée for my brothers GF and I to share and the waiter brought us two with no charge on the second. They really go above and beyond and really make the experience something to remember. Going for my birthday in a couple weeks because I can't wait until Christmas time to experience it again.
author: Natalie C.

description: Despite 8 or 9 years passing since I'd dined here last, my mind was still fresh with the fond memory of my "lamb three ways" and "1000 layer carrot cake" I had been served here that evening long ago, and I was curious to see if time had been kind to this longstanding San Francisco favorite. Time had been kind after all - It could have shown it's face as worn, jaded and stale, but instead Boulevard has evolved and progressed into a well respected and matured old steadfast that keeps patrons coming back to time and time again. The crowd here seems to be just as "mature" as it's beloved establishment, so as a thirty something four top we were the minority.  But the food was fresh and fun (like our four top I like to think) and I have to be honest when I say I was looking for things to tear apart about the food -  but I just could not find anything. Starting with the bread that was warm, sour and chewy (but that's easy, this is The City) followed by my beet carpacio that stood out from those I've had before. This one had whispers of mint and pistachio and the beets were paper thin and required little effort in chewing. I then had the halibut which was seared perfectly on the exterior and contained a succulent, moist and completely seasoned interior. It was accompanied by green, young chickpeas which were creamy and earthy. I choose, without a second thought, the lemon tart. So unassuming and humble, yet so easy to get wrong. To my unexpected surprise, this was, by and large, the most excellent lemon dessert of it's kind I've ever had before or since. The crust was all at once rich, buttery, tender and light, and the lemon filling was sweet and zingy and bursting with lemon flavor. I can never find a lemon bar, tart or pie that is lemony enough for me with the correct balance of sweetness, but this one left nothing to want for. It was topped with an ethereal, marshmallow-like, toasted swiss meringue. It was thick and rich and clung to the plate. My fork kept scraping at the remnants that were the only evidence remaining of the sublime dessert. I was so completely full before the dessert even arrived, and yet it was beyond my self control or better judgment to finish the entire thing, it was so delicious. The service was fine, it wasn't some of the warmest I've had but also not the most aloof or pretentious I've had. Not memorable either way. But what was memorable was the food. And isn't that why we go out? To eat? We don't go out to get served, we go out to eat. And so it remains that Boulevard holds a special place in my memory for the spectacular food, and I pray that 8 or 9 years won't pass again before a new memory is made.
author: Veronica E.

description:
Went for lunch. Food was great, slow though.
Waitress is a bit of an airhead, messed up cocktail order & gave us wrong checks, etc...

Cocktail during lunch time was not that great, the mojito was way too sweet and the mint were not muddled enough.

Overall, they did have great food, services would've been great if our waitress were not having one of her bad day.
author: I G.

description:
I had a fantastic experience at Boulevard. I chose the lamb as an entree (thank you Yelp commenters for the suggestion) and it was amazing. Crispy, tasty, juicy... Ahhh... The thinly-sliced carrots where also really good. 

Being alone on that night, I was offered a seat at the bar, so I had a view on the kitchen which was highly entertaining.

The bread was very good, served with better that had a pinch of salt on it. 

Instead of dessert, I had a Chartreuse V.E.P, which is quite an unusual drink, even in France, where I live. 

In short, I'll be back, I loved the dinner!
author: Tristan N.

description:
Killer from start to finish. My bro from LA. ate here 2 nights before we did, and he suggested it. Had 8 pm resos on a Sunday. We arrived and where immediately seated. Awesome Service!!! The server was flawless from start to finish. 

The Lady had scallops with risotto to start, I had the fois gras. Both came out hot and perfectly cooked. Lady had the fillet for entree, I had the lamb t-bone. Again, both where cooked to perfection!! We had some Peli and a bottle of Pinot Noir, wine service was outstanding!!! 
Great berry tart as well as the chocolate tart!! 

Very memorable experience!!
author: Andrew B.

description:
I took my family to Boulevard for my birthday.  The appetizers were very good but the entrees and desserts were disappointing.  After much fuss about how they like to cook their fish moist and not over cooked, that's exactly how our fish (salmon and halibut ) came out. The desserts were
dry and tasteless.  For the very high cost of the dinner for 4, I would not return.
author: Agnes K.

description:
Boulevard is one of my top picks for standard gourmet 'American' fare with phenomenal ingredients and very classy decor.  The crowd mostly fit either 'older with their grown children' or 'couples on a nice date' (I was in former category).

We arrived a little early, so took a seat at their bar for some apertifs -- classic Dubonney Red on the rocks -- restaurant bars that have it are usually pretty well stocked.  After running into some friends (in the latter 'nice date' category), we were seated in the back on a raised area.  The menu is printed daily, so no specials (or I guess they all are). Wine list is medium and the staff was helpful in navigating it.

We started with the heirloom tomatoes and ceviche tacos.  The tomatoes, while the simplest dish and hard to justify for $16, were delicious, amazing what good ingredients can do.  Ceviche was good.  Next were the heavier starters -- scallops and the seared foie gras -- both were phenomenal and rich, exactly as expected.

For our entres, two of us had lamb t-bone.  Not only was it filling (I was a little concerned after our miniscule appetizers), but simply delicious medium rare with braised greens, very happy with the choice.  Another was the squab, which was equally flavorful.  The last entre was the halibut, seasoned well but a little dry

We closed with a bowl of summer berries and Greek yogurt, a perfect sharable dessert after a big meal.

I wanted to give five stars for the dishes that were phenomenal, but chose four based on the few that weren't perfect and the price.  App and entree per person (four total), two bottles of wine, one dessert all in about $600.
author: Aki N.

description: really don't get what is so special about this place. Overpriced mediocre at best food with poor service. Definitely will not be coming back.
author: Olga B.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF! Very classy environment with great service and food.  Simple looking dishes but plated beautifully. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I'm not sure if I've already reviewed Boulevard, but I think it's time to revisit as I simply love this restaurant.  I got married this past weekend, and hosted the reception dinner in their private room downstairs.  

Planning:  One person - Pam - worked with me throughout the entire planning process.  She was nice, professional, easy to deal with and very clear.  Everything she said, she did; when we arrived everything was as we expected.

The Room:  The main dining room is classic SF with postcard views of the bay bridge.  The private room is downstairs, but very well appointed, as you would expect

Service:  Impeccable.  Brian was the head waiter and the entire operation ran smoothly, like a well oiled machine.  Timing was perfect, food was hot and every order was correct.  Changes and other special needs were handled quickly and easily.  Not a single guest complained...and these were not shy people.

The food: 
App: Dungeness Crab Salad w/ crème fraiche dressing, served over tomatoes and topped w/ white asparagus.  Delicious, well balanced and hit all the right notes.

Main: Choice of Halibut or Pork Chop.  Their pork order was low that week, and they volunteered to add filet mignon to the menu at no step up charge.  Flavors were on point, setups matched perfectly, everything cooked as ordered.  Smiles all around.

Dessert: choice of crème brulee or butterscotch pudding with chocolate ganache cookie.  I opted for the latter and was smitten.  The crème brulee was delicious, but standard--as it should be.  

Most people can only hope for a perfect wedding day, I got lucky and lived it.  I attribute that mostly to my bride, but that would be an entirely different review.  If you can bare cutting back your party from the typical 150+, this is your best shot at that dream  If you have another event or dinner to plan, this could work equally well.  

I could review upstairs as well, but suffice to say that it's pretty damn good.  Food is superb, but never fancy for the sake of being fancy.  Dishes are well thought, ingredients fresh and it never disappoints.  If you're looking for a good meal, at this price range, you're not going to find many better choices in the city.  

Easy 5 out of 5 stars.
author: Chad K.

description: Went here for my wife's birthday.  It was really good but nothing stood out.  For the price there are a couple of other places in SF that I prefer.
author: Robby W.

description: Generally...just OK.  For the price, I was disappointed with the quality of the food. Appetizers were so-so and the portions small for the cost. Nothing special about the the entrees.  The restaurant has become too big and busy and has not maintained the quality and flavors it once produced. Service was good although our server had no personality. Wine list is way overpriced. I saw mark ups of three times + over cost. I always feel ripped off when restaurants mark up their wines that much.  I have a feeling that this restaurant is resting on its laurels.  Doubt that I would return; and I am a local.
author: Steve H.

description:
Alright. All the 3-star reviews have kicked my butt into gear.

I ate here last March and it was phenomenal (I chose "phenomenal" because "nom" is nicely tucked in the middle. nom, nom, nom). It was everything I hoped it would be. I had the lamb chop, medium rare, it was cooked perfectly and was the best piece of meat I've ever had. Ever. 

I also had a beet salad and strawberry shortcake for dessert. Both phenomenal. I asked the waiter to suggest wines for each course and (wait for it...) he did a phenomenal job. 

I spent $130 on dinner for one and it was worth every penny.
author: Kim B.

description: good service, nothign special.
author: Ashwin G.

description: Great food, matched only by the even greater interior design!  Such a beautiful, historic building.  The best calamari app I've ever had... not the kind of calamari you'll expect, but so good.
author: Tom W.

description:
I think I just spent the most money I've ever spent on dinner, for the least amount of food. Boulevard was definitely a one time experience. 
My two friends and I shared 2 appetizers-the scallops and the ravioli. Each dish came with three of each (coincidence?), and they were both around $16. They were both well prepared, though the ravioli was on the cold side, it was covered in truffles, which I discovered taste nothing like truffle oil, nice surprise. We then split two entrees suggested by the waitress, the sole which came with shrimp (2) and scallops (1), and the fillet. I am not a beef eater, but for the money I was contributing to a $39 piece of meat (which was very small), you better believe I ate it. Add in a few cocktails, a few glasses of wine (3 of each), and you've got yourself a $212 tab. Like I said, one time experience.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Boulevard is one of my favorite restaurants in the city for a special occasion dinner.  It's in a great location along the Embarcadero and has a sort of French bistro type vibe. The service is good, and the food (overall) is amazing!  My husband and I took our families here for a graduation celebration, and it didn't disappoint. I would highly recommend the lamb. If you don't order it, you'll be oggling the plate of any friend that did. It's an enormous cut of meat that looks and tastes outstanding!  Most of the menu items are good. The only dish I have had that wasn't "amazing" was a ceviche appetizer, but it looks like they may have taken that off the menu now...

For the price point, I would go to Boulevard any day over other fine dining places such as Quince and Gary Danko.
author: Alison J.

description: I went to Boulevard with some friends and we had a wonderful time. We started off with a special pasta dish to share with white truffles, which was absolutely fabulous. I recommend not sharing it, and getting it as your starter. For main dishes I would highly recommend the Kurabuta Pork or the Filet of beef. Both were excellent dishes. We passed on the dessert and went with a cheese plate. The cheese plate is good, but not great. Nobody beats Garyo Danko for cheeses. The restaurant was packed like always, even 5 years ago during the recession. The service was pretty good, and I recommend getting the table in the back of the restaurant so you can enjoy the views of the Bay Bridge both for dinner and lunch. Overall, a great place to come enjoy a fine meal with friends or on date night. A little tweaks here and there and this place will be 5 stars on my list. Boulevard isn't going anywhere for years to come during good times and even the bad times of the economy. This place is here to stay and great location as well.
author: Mark L.

description: Boulevard is absolutely wonderful. In particular, their manager, Jen, was so helpful when we needed the restaurant opened a bit earlier for a photo shoot for our engagement. She poured two glasses of champagne for us, stayed throughout the shoot to make sure we had everything we needed, and secured a reservation for us later that evening. We returned for a delicious dinner at one of our favorite establishments. The view is to die for, the abalone is yummy, and the steak was delicious. Great ambiance and wonderful location.
author: Anisha D.

description: Highly recommend the scallops.  Need to make a reservation, but if you do, you will have a wonderful table, complete with a no wait experience.  I tried several of the food options, and all were very nicely positioned on the plate, excellent tastes, and superior proportions.  If you want a wonderful place to entertain your guests, celebrate a birthday, or just get together with a special friend, or girl friend, or wife, this is definitely a place to consider.
author: Justin O.

description:
This place actually made it on the Michelin Guide?

My coworker raved about this place. Said it was her favorite restaurant. So my friends and I decided to go. 

My fish was bland....and the service was slow. I guess the only good thing is that it was located near the ferry building and if you were lucky to get a window seat, you'd have a great view.
author: Kelly V.

description:
My girlfriend and I went for dinner a few nights ago for our anniversary. While we were there, we really enjoyed the restaurant. I wasn't terribly impressed by the appetizers but the mains were pretty delicious. I had filet mignon and mygirlfriend has quail. The desserts were some of our favorite things. I personally really enjoyed the brown sugar angel food cake and we also had another but I can't remember the name. Anyway, overall it was a good experience and, aside from not refilling our drinks often enough, the service was well handled.

Then we went home. It started slowly but proceeded to creep up on both my girlfriend and I. We both got rather sick pretty quickly and it certainly left a negative impression on my experience. I won't be tempted to go back. I will still give it two starts but it definitely was disappointing to spend 150$ on dinner and then have it make both of us sick on a special night for us. We probably aren't the norm, but there was something funky going on in the kitchen.
author: Michael P.

description: Good food, terrible service. Took out-of-town friends there for dinner last night. Appetizers arrived quickly but then there was a L-O-N-G wait (1 hour 15 minutes+) for entrees.  Waitress conveniently disappeared for that entire time, and when we were able to flag her down (at the one-hour-plus mark) to ask what was going on (our guests were getting annoyed), she advised us that our food was "being plated."  It arrived after another ~ 15 minutes.  Food here is good, but for what this place charges I expect better service.
author: Joe C.

description:
Keeping with this years buzz word: STIMULUS I decided to stimulate myself and skipped on down Mission Street...oh wait look over there it is the Yelp headquarters...stop..hello Jessica, Jeremy, Nish and all you behind the scenes Yelp people...I digress...off to see Nancy Oakes. 

Yes people it was time I poured some money into this economy one meal at a time. It only seemed fitting...Obama signed a package and Arnie was just finished putting pen to paper for California. 

A fine hello to my lovely hostess who had me escorted to the Chefs Bar. The only place to sit in the restaurant to enjoy the show. Why I sit there is because there are so many things on the menu I want to try but don't. At least this way I taste each and every dish with my eyes. Today I went for a MANLY MEAL. 

Warm bacon salad with lots of bacon and soft boiled eggs and just the right amount of acid from the pickled red onion and earthiness from the button mushrooms. Sprinkle on salt to my taste and lots of pepper and it was the perfect way to start my MANLY MEAL. What next? Well beef of course. Since it was lunch I did it in the form of a KOBE beef burger medium rare of course. It was served on a house made bun with rosso bruno tomatoes and little gem lettuce all served alongside the perfectly presented fries. 

As if this wasn't enough I needed a BIG red so had an amazing glass of Barolo....she I have to go back to work! 

No dessert but cheese was tempting. 

Roll out back onto Mission Street feeling proud that I did my part to stimulate the economy and myself at the same time.
author: Scott P.

description: I may get some crap but honestly I can only give it 3 stars.  I have visited twice and while some of the dishes soar like the lobster I had last week, it just does not do it for me.  The lamb was okay.  One dessert was great, the other sub par.  Wonderful wine list, service is outstanding, great location, but something I can not put my finger on is missing.  Maybe real passion about the food.  I could ramble on but will end with expect some great dishes and some disappointing ones.
author: Celeste B.

description: Came here for lunch a couple times when it was on a partner's dime.  Can't remember what I ate but it was pretty damn good.  Kind of a stuffy atmosphere though, a bunch of dudes in suits.
author: David Y.

description: I was given a $300 gift certificate for Boulevard. I was over the moon not only with the attentive service, but the perfectly balanced flavors of our courses.
author: Desiree P.

description: The ambiance was beautiful but the food portion was small for the price you paid. The staff was excellent and the service was per-fit iw ould give it a 5 star but the portion of the food iam not impress.
author: Thomas T.

description: Visited San Francisco for 4 days. I went with local friends to Boulevard. The ambience is very nice, and the food is just okay and definitely overpriced. After paying in the restaurant, I had forgotten my wallet and had realized it the day after. I then called... They told me that they would look for it and call me back. After an hour, they called to let me know that they hadn't found it. My flight back was scheduled the day after and without my ID, which was in my wallet, it would have impossible to fly. I spent all day juggling a police report and phone calls to the airline in order to arrange some sort of identification (no money, no credit cards, and no ID). At 6 PM, I received a phone call from the restaurant, informing me that after a cleaning, they found the wallet (I had a feeling they hadn't looked the first time that I called). I rushed to the restaurant, grabbed my wallet (and thanked them of course) only to get back to the hotel to realize that I was missing $180. Very kind of them to not take all $190... So, I called the restaurant and they said they would check. I never heard from them again. Didn't expect that from a restaurant this level ...
author: Bilha K.

description:
My husband and I came here for our anniversary.  
The food was phenomenal, absolutely one of the best filet mignons we've ever had.  My husband ordered it medium rare, and it was tender and perfectly seasoned.  It was spot on.  The scallops I ordered was nice and delicate.  I'm a big fan of scallops so I can always appreciate them when it's well executed and Boulevard did just that.  The duck breast was divine and I enjoyed every last bite of it. 
The wines on the other hand was not as good as I expected.  I ordered a glass of beaujolais to start off with but it tasted as if it had been opened for more than 3 days.  The smell was a good indication that the wine was old so it was not a good start for me.  My second glass was the Morgan pinot noir but I regret ordering it because it tasted young and not quite ready to drink.  I would've loved to order a bottle of wine that I was familiar with but my husband doesn't drink.  My wine choices were limited to wines by the glass or half bottles which none appealed to me.  I find it strange that the restaurant served their wines by the glass in a different glass from those who ordered wines by the bottle.  My two glasses were served in a glass that was slightly bigger than the white wine glassware.  I expected the pinot noir to be served in a burgundy glassware so I felt a slight isolation from those who purchased a bottle and received the appropriate glassware.  Another thing I found odd was how the table was set.  The silverware were all turned over facing down, but I digress.
I gave them four stars because of their service and wine.  The server did his job but was not very engaging with our table.  I was bummed that they didn't put a candle or special message on our dessert for our anniversary.  I was hoping for a special experience with my husband because I expected more from a  restaurant of this caliber.  Overall the food was great and would recommend their food to any foodie.  I wish I can say the same for their wines and service but perhaps it was one of those off nights  for their wine and service department.
author: Vaun H.

description:
I cannot praise Boulevard enough.  This is the only restaurant I booked in San Francisco solely based on reviews instead of recommendations from friends and I'm really glad I did.  

The restaurant is adorable and we were seated in one of their cute loveseats against a window.  We were immediately brought out sourdough bread, which they promptly replaced everytime we finished it.  We finally had to ask them to stop bringing us bread!   

The appetizers we had were fantastic.  We ordered the abalone, which we had also had the night before at Michael Mina and I have to say, the abalone at Boulevard was much better.  We also ordered the local calamari with dungeness crab which was great.  I am normally not a fan of grilled octopus but this was delicious.  

For main courses, my boyfriend had the quail which he cannot stop talking about.  He said it was the best bird he's every eaten.  I ordered the california sea bass which was very good but I had heard their seafood is not as good as their meat.  My only complaint is that the asparagus they served with it didn't go well with the other flavors and were too big and meaty.  I think they served it to keep with the green theme on the plate. 

I do have to ask why in San Francisco are the restrooms in another building?  Wish they were closer - and this was one of the many restaurants we encountered this in.  Guess I'm used to NY where a restroom is required in each restaurant!  

Overall, we very much enjoyed our experience at Boulevard and will be back.
author: Heather B.

description:
After wanting to eat here for many years, I finally got the chance, and it did not disappoint.  It was also the first place I had been since I was a kid that has a Michelin star.  I was excited!  We were in a group of 8-9 so I kind of assumed the service would suffer, but it was great.  Almost as great as the food that is...

I followed the waitors suggestions and got the scallops appetizer and the duck w/ ravioli for my meal.  The scallops were awesome and i could've eaten about ten orders if they had kept bringing them.  I haven't had duck very many times and have found it to be very hit or miss.  This was by far the best I have ever had and it would be hard for me to order anything else next time.  I tried a bite of the lamb as well and it was tasty and looked amazing.  The table split a bunch of deserts and they were all good too, just like everything else here!!!
author: Josh S.

description:
I do agree this place is over rated. Don't get me wrong. The food was good but I wouldn't say, "GREAT, I can't wait to come back for ...". We ordered the:
foie gras - Good. Nothing special though. They serve seared foie gras anywhere. You don't need to pay 20+ bucks for it here.
scallops - seared. Same comment as above. 
rib eye pork chop - rib eye? It looks like a regular pork chop with the bone to me. They didn't need to make it sound fancy by added "rib eye". This was good but no pork chop can ever beat The House. Best pork chops EVER! and about 30% cheaper!
***OH WAIT! Almost forgot. The description also said black truffle shavings. I DID NOT see any black truffle shavings nor did I taste it. Cheap move Boulevard. I was really disappointed but I'm not the type that complains. (I will just Yelp it ;p)
lobster - My bf ordered this. I'm not a huge fan of lobster but it was good. 
choc. mousse something - Good but I didn't go gaga.

I've always wanted to try Boulevard and I'm glad I did. It was a nice experience but there wasn't anything that stood out. Ummm.... would I go back?.... Prob not. It's not my cup of tea. It's over priced for food that is just OK. I kept thinking about other restaurants that were better as I was eating the different dishes. If you like the food here or this type of style I suggest Alexander's or The House. I think the prices are more reasonable and the food has more WOW Factor.

Oh, btw... I don't like drinking alcohol when I dine so I ordered coke (tased like pepsi) but most restaurants that I've been to refill your soda without charging. This is prob. up to the server but we were charged for 3 sodas. Maybe it's just me but I find that kinda tacky....
author: Karen L.

description:
I had dine at Boulevard twice and it will probably be the last of it.  This place did not exactly left me in awe, but ehh.

Service was not exceptionally the best( they never came back to ask us about the food and how we were doing).  

We ordered the lobster bisque and I gotta admit it was to die for.  Super tasty....

BUT....

the seabass, it was way too dry. I literally had to add a bit of some pressure towards my fork just to actually cut a piece to my friend. Yes, it was that dry for me to actually add force to my utensils, so I can try to enjoy it by pieces. 

My friend ordered the free range chicken and his dish was definitely better than mine. Presentation was presented nicely and tasted just as great.

I'll give them a break about the service since it was friday, but I definitely expected better especially when you are paying that much for dinner.
author: Sophia S.

description:
Holy crap get the lamb!!!!! A-M-A-Z-I-N-G!!!

Wine selection is pretty good.... Prices are usual a place like this (yes that means expensive).  Bar is pretty good and ambiance is nice.

Pssssttt...try the lamb.....
author: Chris B.

description: This was my first and last time dining at the Boulevard. The food was good, a little salty, but still good, very pricey small portions.  The biggest turn off was the service.  We were a party of four and were there to enjoy great bottles of wine and a meal.  We requested waters for the table and our waitress turned and said "I heard you, I'm on my break and I'm doing you a favor". I kid you not, this is what she said.  Luckily we got a new waiter who tried to save the night but we were all appalled.  Never again!,
author: Debbie B.

description: I took my husband here for his birthday. The meal was great and the service was impeccable. Our seat wasn't great I felt too close to the other tables (it would be totally ok if we were in a cheaper restaurant, but I had higher expectations for the Boulevard)  and we didn't have a view. Some tables have a fantastic view of the bridge but all of those are for 4 people and more. Next time I will come back with friends and reserve a table near the large window.
author: Xinwei L.

description: My first time at boulevard today was okay. The service was amazing, but the food was extremely salty! The butter that came with our bread was coated with SEA SALT. Bread was cold but still soft and tasty. I ordered the sea scallops(very good), and my boyfriend ordered the raviolis which lacked flavor. For our main I had the California lamb t-bone(tasty, but salty from the bacon bits) and my boyfriend had the quail which was very tender and fatty. Uggghhh. Overall it was ok but not for how much we paid. There is a possibility of us going again if they change their menu or come up with More of a selection.
author: Chelsea Z.

description:
I can see why Boulevard has one Michelin star, but I can also see why it has only one. The service was pleasant, gracious, and unpretentious, but our food did take a very long time to arrive. The decor is attractive, but the lighting is a little dated -- and those antiqued posters are only cool if they're originals. The wine list is solid, but not terribly exciting. 

For appetizers, we tried the calamari, the abalone, and the heirloom tomato and bufala mozzarella salad. The calamari was fine, but not quite as good as a similar dish I've had many times at Divino in Belmont. The abalone was well-cooked, and the abalone mushrooms were fine, but not thrilling. The heirloom tomato salad was ok, but not great; only the purple cherokee tomato in the salad was as good as the ones I've bought at the farmer's market, and the mozzarella di bufala was not as good as some I've bought at the grocery store, as it was a little on the bland side.

For an entree, I tried the California sea bass, and this was where I really started to get impressed: this is a fish I don't think I've tried before, and as the server mentioned to me when I ordered it, it has a very firm texture, almost like chicken. It was well-seasoned and well-cooked, with a lovely golden crispy tinge. The beans served alongside were lovely, and the dish as a whole was well-composed. My husband's quail and squab was good, but not thrilling; a very solid, competent dish, but not a knockout. 

The most compelling reason to go back to Boulevard, for me, is the dessert. We shared the cake donut with buttermilk ice cream, and it was absolutely fantastic. Normally I'm not a fan of cake donuts, but this one was glorious -- luxuriously cakey without being too rich, infused with a rich citrusy flavor, and lightly coated with sugar for a perfect amount of crunch. The buttermilk ice cream was beautifully light on the palate, with a tart, acidic bite. It was the perfect foil for the cake donut. There was also a dollop of raspberry sorbet on the plate, which added a nice splash of color.

Although Boulevard won't deeply excite the most adventurous foodies, the dishes are well-executed. The views are good, the service is good, it's a pretty, pleasant place to have a meal, and it's not hard to get a reservation. The Michelin star is deserved -- especially if you order dessert.
author: Sarah F.

description: 3 of us had dinner and each one of us raved. Great appetizers (lobster ravioli, ahi tuna tartar, artichoke salad) followed by great mains, finishing with awesome deserts.  Superb service. Yahtzee!
author: Mike s.

description: Food is fantastic. Service Great. Atmosphere elegant. Had the Lamb and it was delicious. The place for a special occasion.
author: Les W.

description:
"Fuck my liiife," uttered the pantry cook after seeing my order for beef carpaccio come in. "Time to get a new job."

I was one of the first customers of the day and it was the first carpaccio of the day, and the beef hadn't been sliced yet. Did he not see the table number and realize I was sitting at the open kitchen's counter directly in front of him as he grumbled, or did he say it hoping to make me feel bad for causing him such stress so early in the service? 

Either way, I didn't really care - it's the life of a cook, with which I am very familiar. Restaurants are always putting items on the menu that require a few steps too many to make, thus decreasing enjoyment of preparation for their maker. There may not have been love in the dish, but precision and quality certainly were, and this helped to brighten what was the only dark point in my two-hour lunch. I waited 15 minutes - while sipping a perfect fresh blood orange martini - for the carpaccio to arrive, but that was understandable, and absolutely worth it.

The paper-thin, grass-fed Angus beef, lubricated with a drizzle of extra virgin olive oil, nearly disintegrated upon contact with my tongue. Its delicacy tempered the accompanying roasted chanterelles, which were too salty on their own but made beautiful love to the meat and my palate. Flavorwise, I would say the scattering of tempura-fried green beans did little, as their gently sweet beany-ness was overshadowed by a peppery tangle of baby arugula that also shared the plate, but their perfectly (PERFECTly) done batter lent a needed light crispness. As an ensemble, with a tiny bit of each component on every forkful, this was one of the best appetizers I have ever eaten.

Endorphins continued to flood my body for the rest of the meal, which may be due partly to that very strong martini earlier but probably because everything else also exceeded expectations. The wood-oven-roasted pork flat iron (a cut from the tender shoulder) boasted a deep, beautiful char and scrumptiously juicy, flavorful meat, all thanks to brining - always a smart move with today's lean pigs. The pork stood on its own, but so did its sides: pancetta-sautéed Brussels sprouts, grilled Mission figs, and a chestnut puree that could have been served in a bowl as cream of chestnut soup. This dish in particular was fun to eat; I felt like I was playing with food in an acceptable adult manner. So I began to tinker. To the pork, the cabbage-ettes and pancetta respectively offered a slight chlorophyllic bitterness and a chewy, salty-spicy porkiness. The figs, chestnut puree and pancetta together made for a delicious threesome. But my favorite was the pork with a cut of fig and a schmear of chestnut: a match made in hog heaven.

Although I was nearly full to bursting, I couldn't pass up a taste of Boulevard's house-made frozen treats. The sarsaparilla ice cream was American childhood nostalgia set into a sphere of goodness, and coupled with a little snickerdoodle it nearly made me giggle like a kid. I thought of lazy Sundays in Hale'iwa as I spooned my way through a pineapple sorbet. But the real kicker was a dark chocolate-covered salted-caramel ice cream bonbon, a perfect sweet ending to a fantastic meal, well-attended to throughout by my gracious, engaging server.

If you know how professional kitchens operate, you'll love sitting in front of the kitchen as I did. Boulevard's involved, multifaceted dishes can only be pulled off with the kind of seamless teamwork I observed. The cooks, who are constantly exchanging the typical X-rated kitchen banter in Spanish ("This fucking whore" to a special order, "I'll bang your grandma on the pastry counter," for instance), don't waste a movement and will jump in to help he who may be falling behind.

Hopefully the grumpy pantry cook doesn't quit, since he seems to be especially good buds with his side-by-side co-worker who prepares the hot items for appetizers. Breaking brotherhood in the kitchen could lead to a temporary falter in Boulevard's high standards, and I'd hate to see that happen.
author: Tadd T.

description: One of many dinners with different groups and group sizes.  Have never been disappointed with service, ambiance, food or drink.  It feels luxurious to be seated in this wonderful restaurant and be treated like royalty for a while.
author: Ash A.

description: Fancy food.  Good presentation. Small portions.  Average taste. Average service.  Quality not proportional to price.  Interesting ambiance, but noisy.
author: Greg C.

description:
First, the two appetizers we had: 
AHI TUNA ITO-ZUKURI Hand Line Caught, "Ribbon-Cut" Ahi Tuna Padron Pepper Tempura, White Sesame Aioli, Togarashi-Shoyu Vinaigrette Rossa Bianca Eggplant with Wasabi Shinku Pear Dressing & Shiso  It was a whole lot of ribbon cut Ahi tuna  with a single tempura pepper and a suggestion there were other elements on the plate.  Overall, it was bland, bland, and bland.  I would never order it again.

RAVIOLI ,PORCINI BUTTER CONFIT RABBIT & A PAIR OF WILD GREENS with RICOTTA Bellwether Basket Ricotta with Borage, Nettles & Lamb's Quarters, De Bruin Rabbit Hon Shemeji Mushrooms.  Three raviolis arrived the two outside one were filled wild greens, shoes bitterness masked the Ricotta cheese. The center ravioli was the rabbit filled one.  It was a decent couple of bites.  The mushrooms were excellent.  Overall I'd rate the dish as fair to good.  I would not order it again.
The only saving grace of the early part of our meal was some excellent bread, and a great wine recommendation of  a 2010 Hermitage.   

Second the mains:
ALASKAN HALIBUTALA PLANCHASquash Blossom Stuffed with Rock Shrimp & FennelWhite Tomato Risotto Vialone Nano with Hearts of PalmOlive Oil Slow Roasted Baia Nicchia Miniature TomatoesTomato "Pate", Laudemio Extra Virgin Olive Oil & Genovese Basil.  
This dish made the whole trip worthwhile.  Everything about it was outstanding.  It will the benchmark that every halibut dish I eat will be judged by. My wife loved it as well, labeling it the best halibut dish she had ever eaten.

ANGUS FILET MIGNONWood Oven RoastedDwelley Farms Romano Beans & French Fingerling PotatoesConfit of Roasted Tomatoes with Capers & GarlicCaesar Fava Bean Relish, Basil & Roasted Beef Jus.  The meat was perfectly cooked, but was not memorable.  The roasted tomatoes were very good, as were the fingerling potatoes. It was a good, but not great dish. 

 CHOCOLATE MARSHMALLOW PIE Chocolate Streusel Crust, Manjari Chocolate Ganache
Milk Chocolate Mousse, Burnt Marshmallow Chocolate Chip Cookies, Chocolate Ice Cream.
I loved the pie itself, and the presentation. I was not that wild about the cookie ice-cream sandwich.

Our service was attentive.  The wine, halibut dish, and pie made for a memorable evening.  I disagree with the reviewers who thought the portions were small.  Apparently, they have never had 'really small ' portions.  I would return to Boulevard and choose two different appetizers.
author: Joel R.

description: I had dinner here last week with 2 other colleagues.  The restaurant has a warm ambiance and the food is good but not exceptional.  The service was professional.  I will definitely return for a business dinner, but probably won't for any special occasion or if I'm looking for an exceptional dining experience.
author: Max R.

description:
Boulevard used to be one of the top restaurants in the city, but it seems like it hasn't gotten any better and all other restaurants have improved a lot, because after coming back 4 years later to this restaurant I don't understand how I liked it so much before? This place has really gone down in quality. For the price you pay, you can get way better food in various restaurants in SF. The food wasn't bad, it wasn't the quality and taste you expect for the price you pay. 

What did I get?
1) Appetizers
   a) Buffalo Mozzarella (very bland tasting)
   b) Squab Breast (This was delicious, I would come back just for this)
   c) Pyramid Ravioli (good, but nothing amazing)
2) Main Courses
   a) Risotto (was good, but nothing amazing)
   b) Lamb Rack (good, but I have had better, just go to Kokkari or Evvia)
3) Desserts
    a) Doughnuts (Really good, the cream caramel that came with it was outstanding)
