So, overall I had 1 good appetizer and 1 good dessert and the rest was mediocre for the price. There are so many great restaurants in SF and this used to be one of them, but has been dropped off my list.
author: Ahmed H.

description:
Food was superb but three stars for the lack of service and friendliness.
A busy restaurant does not always equate to mediocre/ poor service.
Made reservations but still tried to stiff us in the corner.  
Good wine selection.
Give it a try.
author: ki k.

description: The food here was amazing, the service was just OK. The server seemed like she wanted to get off work (we came in toward the end of the night) but the kitchen was still open for another 30 minutes. Regardless, I recommend, the sea bass and squab. My friend and I shared these dishes and both were really good. The setting is romantic and it's very close to the water. I recommend coming early to find parking.
author: Kristin H.

description:
For as much hype as this joint generates, I allowed myself to get all worked up about the dinning experience I was surely going to enjoy... 

And then I ate here. 

I don't get it. 

It wasn't great. I mean, I'll give it good...but great? Hardly. 

I dined here with two colleagues and we kind of all felt the same...it could have been better. 

For example, when we went they didn't have a regular "starter" salad on the menu. Which isn't a huge deal, but I asked the waitress if they could do a small green salad, and she said, "yes." 

No big deal, right? 

I mean if she had said, "no," I would have shrugged and ordered the soup. 

My colleagues also ordered the offered side salad. 

When they came, I was a surprised. The waitress literally set down 3 small plates of lettuce in front of us. Nary a cherry tomato or carrot slice in sight. 

I repeat - LETTUCE. 

If you don't have a green salad (salad defined as lettuce AND assorted accouterments) then just say, "no, we aren't offering one today." 

End of story. 

Very strange. 

The rest of the meal was decent, yet forgettable, for the price. 

Too bad...
author: Becky M.

description:
A few years ago I would have given this place 3 stars. I worked in the financial district and this restaurant is a default restaurant for business dinners. I alway told myself I will never go unless someone else will pay for it. Recently someone gave me a gift certificate to Boulevard. I was a little dissppointed because I've been here a lot before. I haven't been here lately though so I took the gift certificate, brought a friend and went. 

First of all, this place was packed on a Thursday night. Lots of people compared to neighboring restaurants. When I used to come here it has this weird smell... not anymore. The food was exceptionally good. I had the foie and the steak. My friend had the lobster bisque and the lamb. I will go back soon.
author: Sheila D.

description:
I try to only review places I've been to recently, but I really don't see a trip to Boulevard as being within my budget anytime soon, and I've got to add my praise for this place.  This is for a meal I had there in Oct 2008.  Absolutely, hands-down, the second best meal I've had in San Francisco.  Maybe anywhere.  (The first was by way of knowing the sommelier at Jardinière, so I'm not sure that's fair).

Some college friends were coming into town and as is our tradition, I wanted to do some destination dining.  On the advice of a friend, decided to try Boulevard.  Amazingly, I was able to get a reservation about a week in advance and they were extremely accommodating with me as our party kept growing in size, from 4 to eventually 7.

For whatever reason, they were able to open up the private room for us (I guess it wasn't booked on that particular Saturday.  Score!)  They said it could have seated 10.  It was the wine cellar, although I'm not sure it's the main wine cellar as I only saw the sommelier come through once to take a bottle off the wall.  Maybe I was having too good a time to notice.  This was one of the few times in my life I've enjoyed a meal away from the hoi polloi and my simpleton heart was sent aflutter.  The details are a little hazy now, but I enjoyed every moment of the experience.  Good food and good friends are always a good time, but I'm sure Boulevard had a great deal to do with it.

We split a few appetizers.  I recall the foie gras being a particular standout.  Upon the recommendation of some kind of framed posting in the men's restroom, my friend noted that the sweetbreads were to be tried, and despite the less than appealing location of the inspiration, it was spot on.

The sommelier was extremely helpful in recommending some wine pairings for our meal, and knowledgeable too when we pointed out some types and regions we had tried before.  Our food came at perfect intervals and the wait staff was almost invisible, but always seemed to anticipate our needs, down to the letter.  I remember at one point I dropped a fork and before I had time to ask for another, a new one was there waiting for me.

As I remember, if it weren't for the upscale decor and me being dressed up for the occasion, I would have licked the plate my lamb entree came on.

Desserts?  We were awash in warm chocolate cake and creme brulee to write home about.  I think I had some scotch as well, which blended the night together perfectly.  I know I'm making this sound like some kind of dining nirvana, and perhaps the spirit of that night and the time since have worn away any rough edges on those memories, but I can't help myself.  It was just that good.

The drinks from the bar was quite good as well.

In total, the bill for 7 people, with split appetizers, entrees, desserts, 3 bottles of decent wine, and some after dinner drinks came out to be less than $800.  it was worth every penny.

I would definitely go back.  I'm just looking for the right occasion.  It would be perfect for a special occasion with family.  If I'm ever in the position to get the private room, I would take it in a heartbeat.  Great location too.
author: Zhi Q.

description: As good as it gets! I love this place. It's walking distance from my home and always a pleasant experience.
author: Ann L.

description:
Great dining experience.  Fantastic food. 

My husband and I went on a Saturday night. It was busy, yet quaint. The appetizer, main course and dessert were fantastic. Their turtle profiteroles were unbelievably delicious. I can't wait to come back and try out new dishes.
author: Jane S.

description:
Boulevard is wonderful for its comfort and consistency. I travel often  to SF often on business and eating at the bar overlooking the kitchen is warm and welcoming, and it is great fun to watch a world class kitchen in action' service also is fantastic.ssq  The food and ingredients are A+, and the staff is warm and welcoming.   I love this place!  (also eat at tables w/ friends and equally nice--but tend to go w/ friends to more trendy spots and eat here in lieu of room service).    

Only reason not 5 stars is that ironically the place is too consistent!
author: Leslie C.

description: James beard awardee. Michelin star? Food is good but not unbelievable. Pricey. Waitstaff good. Great area. Nothing to brag about. It beat out nyc restos for the jb award. Kudos.
author: Jorydude r.

description: Had a good birthday dinner here, service and food was great. Unfortunately, an elderly couple actually got up and shushed us during dinner. And not even politely requested, but fully demanded, which unfortunately kind of ruined the entire birthday dining experience. Being that this is one of the trendier restaurants in SF, considering their recent accolades, this was pretty surprising, and unfortunate, that this was my experience with the restaurant, especially on a birthday occasion. Hope I can return one day when the rest of the restaurant clientele is OK with other patrons speaking above a whisper, especially on their birthdays.
author: Erin C.

description:
Exceptionally crappy.

Never again. 

My husband was SO looking forward to trying Boulevard, after having heard so much about it. Three years ago, we finally had the chance and excuse, with out-of-town foodie guests visiting. 

What a nightmare. 

Shortly after we placed our orders, the restaurant (and surrounding neighborhood) lost power. Okay, that's a PG&E issue, not a Boulevard issue... Except, from that point on (about 9:00 ish), they kept us hostage waiting for our food and PROMISING that we'd still be able to be fed because they still had the wood fire stove going and the power would be back up, surely.

After 45 minutes of waiting for the appetizers, we suggested that perhaps we should leave and come back some other time. "No, no, no!!! Don't be silly! We'll have your food RIGHT out!!!" were the assurances of the staff. 

After waiting for TWO HOURS to get our appetizers, they finally conceded that they would not be able to provide dinner. Great... This is San Francisco, not New York, and restaurants (besides Mel's, In & Out or Tommy's Joynt) tend to shut down by 10:00, and we're VERY HUNGRY at this point. 

Just to really finish the evening, they charged us full price for everything we'd ordered, including coffee, if you can believe it. We put up a minor stink, but were fed the argument that the business had lost money that night because of the lack of power and, ergo, we, the few remaining suckers who'd stuck it out, needed to pay up.

Bullshit. That's what insurance is for. 

We were so incensed, it took two weeks to simmer down before my husband could craft a letter to the management. Surely, at least an apology would be in order. We honestly thought we were doing the restaurant a favor by informing the management of what a deplorable experience we'd had. 

BIG MISTAKE!!! The return letter followed the same argument as that which we'd heard from the staff on the evening in question... that the restaurant had lost money that night, etc, etc. No apology, no request that we come back and try it again, nothing. 

I don't care how good the food is. With an attitude like that, they will NEVER get my business again, and HELL YES I'm gonna YELP about it. 
Do yourself and SF a favor and BOYCOTT BOULEVARD ON PRINCIPLE.
author: Hannah Q.

description:
Food is excellent but they have gone the way of big prices and small servings.  It is noisey and they jam customers into  small spaces, often into booths that force the table into your stomach.  They move people in and out at the speed of lightening.  

And you have to climb down to the bathroom. Only to find that it has not been serviced lately.  Messy and missing towels and papers. Plezzzz.  Get your act together.

Not sure that great food and professional service offsets  small servings, prices and congested atsmosphere.
author: Barbara W.

description:
I want to enter you through your sexy revolving door and feel your presence envelop me.  I want to caress your beautiful, smooth, globe-like chandeliers. I want to sink deeply in to the curves of your beautiful hand-carved wooden chairs. I want to feel the warmth of your amazing and oh-so-unique brick ceiling.  

But most of all, I want to gaze upon your menu, speak softly to you and then, when the time is right, I want to slowly nibble on your succulent Dayboat Scallops and eat your juicy Fillet.
author: Jay Z.

description: Been here before and it has been always very good.  No wonder that they are so busy even on a Thursday night.  The place was crowded and nosey, but we were greeted with a smile and took us to our table right away.  The food was great.  We had the crab salad, lamb chops and pork shank.  All delicious.  Will certainly be back again and again.
author: Colin W.

description:
4.5 stars. People here know what they're doing!

Came here for an anniversary date and it was the perfect venue and restaurant choice. It was a cold and rainy night so it was an automatic haven right when we stepped in. The atmosphere was warm and elegant and instantly put me in a great mood. I was super excited to start eating!

We ordered hot apple cider (spiked, of course) with Riesling to start, and munched on some sourdough while we waited for our appetizer. We ordered the scallops with pork belly and persimmons which was AMAZING. I really enjoyed every delectable bite of the scallops which paired perfectly with the persimmons. For mains, I got the Wood Grilled Walu and Pork a white-fleshed, buttery Hawaiian fish, which was cooked to juicy/tender perfection. Every bite was better than the last - I couldn't stop eating! It came with black & gold chanterelles, roasted butternut squash, fregola & black barley, and hearts of palm - creating a mouthwatering combination of complementary flavors. He got the Berkshire Pork Rib Eye & Duroc Pork Cheek which was gobbled up in a heartbeat. My fave part of that was the parsnip mash w/ pomegranate avils and the brussel sprouts - yum!

We both ordered our own desserts b/c no one wanted to share - he got the Hazelnut Chocolate Daquoise and I got the Profiterole & Apple Terrine. My apple terrine was a bit jelly-ish and clunky, so I didn't touch it but the cinnamon ice cream it came with was unique and good. And you can never go wrong with hazelnut or chocolate.

I was surprisingly full afterward and would love to come back to sample some other dishes. The menu offered way more items that we had time (or room in our tummies) for, so next time! We'll be back.
author: Natalie W.

description: If I could give half stars, I'd give Boulevard a 4.5.  I ordered the Wood Oven Roasted California Lamb Prime T-Bone for my entree and the Chocolate Mocha Bomb for dessert.  The medium cooked lambed mixed well with the creamy shallots and mushrooms. Thought the dish was good, but not amazing. The Chocolate Mocha Bomb on the other hand was AMAZING.  I have a huge sweet tooth, and this decandent trio of a desserts was pure heaven. Creamy espresso mousse drenched with a layor of melted chocolate, cherry ice cream with little bits of crunch from the chesnuts, and flourless chocolate cake.  Great ending to a delicious meal.  As with most fine dining experiences, expect a fair wait between courses, but great service with a smile. =)
author: Michelle C.

description:
Well liked by all, Boulevard is consistently among the top two most popular restaurants in Zagat, which I consider to be a reliable restaurant review service.  What I enjoyed most about my meal there was the moistness of my fillet.  It was perfectly bloody and served at the appropriate temperature.  I paired the meal with an excellent '96 Chataneuf de Pape and the combined effect was a touch spiritual, a touch exhilarating.  

I'm intrigued by the private room they have downstairs that I peeked into when using the men's room.  Perhaps I'll pony up the bucks to throw a private event there one day.  In the meantime I'll save Boulevard for special occasions or impromptu splurges.
author: John M.

description: Not really happy with this restaurant. The food was not great. We werent feeling comfortable with the service. And the value for the money was poor. I am really surprised with the excellent reviews..
author: Irma M.

description:
What does a girl do when her husband's a terrible planner and she's pressed to pick the restaurant for her birthday every year?  Embrace it and learn to love the creative control.  I thought I was set with Acquerello this year - but you know you've been together too long when you encounter silence when describing the place as quiet and romantic, followed by "it's your birthday so if that's where you really wanna go..."   

That's how I decided on Boulevard.  But it was an easy decision because it's one of my favorites -- just haven't been in years and always thoroughly enjoyed it in the past from business lunch to dinners with friends.  It's alive with hustle bustle of mature patrons, professional staff and an open kitchen which you can get a birds eye view of at the counter seats -- perfect for solo diners.  Beautiful warm space w/ views of the Bay Bridge. 

For starters my b/f chose the sea scallops which were great.  I got the pyramid ravioli trying somewhat to makeup for the pasta I was missing at Acquerello and it was ok but didn't quite hit the mark -- but their forte is grilled meats and fish.  As expected the Hawaiian Walu was spot on and his filet was cooked perfectly.

Service is always friendly and professional and desserts are great.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
Atmosphere : pretty, cozy, warm, fancy, bistro
Food: steak delicious, cant go wrong.
Crowd: chic, business on weekdays
author: Shadi N.

description: I went here for dessert, got the chocolate cake and it was ok.  The inside seems nice and swanky, but really pricey.  It's very old styled, but I feel the more airy look of Scomas.  I do like the view of the kitchen staff preparing the food and I would like to come back to have an appetizer so that I could watch the chefs at their art.
author: Lisa H.

description:
My last meal at SF was enjoyed at Boulevard, which was so close from my apartment but I'd never come around to try it until the final evening.

Confidently I say that their appetizers are better than their entrees in terms of novelty and presentation.  And their dishes change frequently as none of ours looked like those photos uploaded on Yelp. 

Must tries are their buffalo carpaccio (the new addition to their menu, and I don't think it's reflected on their website yet) and dungess crab salad.  And I was rather disappointed by the quality of sashimi used for their tuna tartar.

Now that I have left Bay Area for close to two weeks, I do sincerely miss its restaurants.  Right now if I were to dine at Boulevard I'd probably give full 5 stars, but that's now how I felt back then....
author: Mami T.

description: Wonderful ambiance and outstanding food. Great for a special occasion and good value for a Michelin starred restaurant.
author: Evan H.

description:
I'll start out by saying that this was the best restaurant experience that I have ever had!

Boulevard is one of those special occasion type of places as it can be pricey, but WELL worth it.  The second you walk through the door you realize that you are about to have one of the best meals in your life.  I was impressed by the beautiful decor and the view of the Ferry Building from our table.

My fiance' and I went here on a rainy Tuesday night and the place was packed, but not in a loud type of way.  Staff was friendly all around from the parking attendant, to the host, to the wait staff.

I never imagined that the salad of greens could be as tasty as it was for an appetizer.  I ordered the filet mignon and my fiance' ordered the pork rib eye.  Both dishes were spectacular and unforgettable.

For anyone that wants to splurge on a special occasion this is as good as it gets!
author: david j.

description:
Boulevard was pretty good.  The dishes were mostly standard fare, meaning, nothing too ambitious.  Some were strangely bland while others were really flavorful.

Scallops and tuna tartare were flavorless, chicken breast was amazing and flavorful, ravioli not so much, steak was okay, and the doughnut was delicious.

Service was fantastic -- all around from start to finish.  No hiccups at all.

Would I go back?  Tough question.  Because of the price, I'd probably try some other 'nice' restaurants first before venturing back here.
author: Ankur P.

description:
Those not born to greatness can assuage themselves by snuggling up close to power, in the hopes of gathering small crumbs of significance.  In other words, if you want to be hired by my firm, you have to get through me first.  My role as gatekeeper and chief interrogator also involves some social planning.  Meaning, I stick my head out of my office and say to my secretary "I need a table for 7 at Boulevard."  And he makes it happen, because he's fabulous that way (and a lot of other ways, too).

My iced tea was wonderful.  Be a purist: skip the flavor of the day iced tea and just have the regular stuff.  I didn't even need to sweeten it, it was that good.

The baby gem lettuce salad was bacon-bit-rific, but too heavy on the dressing.  If you have faith in the quality of your ingredients, it's not necessary to smother everything in a bath of blue cheese dressing, tasty though it may be.  The avocado slices were too much, and were set aside.  The heirloom tomatoes were tomatoes, and were set aside.

The bavette steak was done properly (medium-well means little pink), but was strangely only luke-warm when it arrived at the table.  What's the story with that??  Still, very tender and flavorful.  The tater tots that accompanied it were decent, but uninspired.  The chef knows this, because they came sitting in a pond of blue cheese dressing.  Blue cheese is the duct tape of cooking: if you know you can't get it right, just cover it in blue cheese.

The kobe burger of one of my compatriots came with excellent french fries, very crispy and delicious, and not oil-soaked.  His diver scallops appetizer was positively Lilliputian, so don't expect it to make much of a dent in your appetite.

Lunch: decent.  We'll probably do Aqua next time.
Interview: decent.  I would still rather hire me, but that's not an option.  Plus, two of me in the same firm would be critical mass.
author: Ben P.

description: Loved the crepe suzette. Right balance of sweet & sour plus a wonderful fresh finish
author: Leonardo L.

description: Classy, outstanding place. Was here last for my Birthday, and had a fantastic time sipping Veuve Clicquot and chowing down on some appetizers. Wish She'd open a restaurant here in Scottsdale. Is it me, or is this place kind of loud?
author: Eric E.

description:
I came here for a special dining evening.  Our group occupied the private downstairs dining room and had a wonderful 5-course meal with wine flight.

Our course started with the Ahi Tuna Carpaccio.  The Ahi was sliced so thin that I swear you could see through it.  The flavors were wonderful, just a hint of olive oil and spices to compliment the natural taste of the fish.  Perfection.

We then had a pan seared Monterey calamari stuffed with roasted pork belly.  This dish was so unique and flavorful.  Served atop butter beans and a salametti picante, the textures and flavors combined to give quite a pleasant treat.  I wanted more!  This was served with a wonderful Zinfandel.

We were then treated to a dish of squab breast with porcini mushrooms and potato raviolis.  The sangiovese they paired with this dish was superb!  A true genius chose this combo.  The squab breast was quite tender and just melted in my mouth.

After the squab, we were presended with a very different and unique dish - Elk tenderloin.  I'm not a huge fan of meat, but let me tell you, this dish was divine.  Served along side was a small piece of foie grois.  The combination was to die for.  To finish the perfection of this dish was a beautiful red meritage wine - Omaggio from Seghesio Vineyards.  Delicious.

Finally, to close this fabulous meal, we were served a slice of mirror glaze sacher torte.  Decadent and beautiful.  

Such a wonderful experience with exceptional service.  This is a dining experience that I won't soon forget!  The chef is a true artist and the location is superb for a romantic evening out.
author: Christy L.

description:
Many new, pricey places in town could quickly outshadow a decade-old resto if it doesn't continue to perform. But Boulevard matches the newbies well.

The menu changes daily and apparently so does the clientele. Some Yelpers mentioned a tacky crowd armed with bags of schwag from Pier 39. There were some odd birds in there last night, but it was much closer to Foreign Cinema than Rainforest Cafe.

Intimate, Frenchie and very, very cozy. Large, but manageable space. The friendliest waitress and sommelier I've seen at fancy-pants places - it was actually ok to throw your head back and laugh in here.

Everything I ate blew me away. Shaken daiquiri with honest-to-goodness West Indies' white rum. Appetizer with tempura-fried garlic-something and summer squash was springtimey and a great start. My Angus short rib entree with green mashed potatoes was heavenly, as was his filet mignon. I didn't even specify how I wanted my beef prepared, but it came out perfectly anyway. Dulce de leche sundae was perfect, as was the Langue-dac wine I had to wash it all down.

Lick-the-plate urges got really bad, but I prevailed.
author: Tara R.

description:
After much anticipation and hearing all the hype I was looking forward to dining here. The food was delicious except for dessert. The duck was cooked perfectly, soft-shell crab was crispy and flavorful. However, the rhubarb dessert was mediocre and poorly executed and I'm being generous.

What was most disappointing was the ambiance and the service. We waited about 25 minutes before anyone even acknowledged us. Quite simply that is unacceptable. And the tables are packed in like sardines. No sense of intimacy here and people strain to eavesdrop into your conversation which is rude. 

This place did not make me feel like I was experiencing something special. This is no Coi, La Folie, Quince, or any other number of truly deserving Michelin star recipients.
author: BB H.

description:
Ok, I was all down with writing a mediocre review for this place because of the high-end pricing and the high-end snobbery goin' on here.  

We received our meal(s) and it was still "... ummmmm ... the portions are kinda skimpy ..." 

... and then we ate.  ... and there was complete silence between us.

We are totally screwed for a bad or even mediocre review on this place.  It ROCKS!

We had the crab salad "starter", the entree of salmon and the entree of pork chop.

OMG!  Several glasses of wine and an awesome dinner ... for $150 overall ... 

Larry's gettin' some tonight!


HE FELL ASLEEP!!!!!!
author: Michael O.

description:
What can I say about Boulevard that hasn't already been said?

This is one of the best restaurants here in San Francisco. It's where all yer high-powered finance guys and VCs love to lunch. We sat toward the front and I swear to god every time a group of guys got up to leave I was positively raked over on their way out the door. And so it goes in the testosterone-charged world of money making.  But it's not just the elite with their highly evolved wine list analysis skills who dine here. Admins and lowly office assistants come here as well, dressed in Banana Republic sweaters and pants, and order their bowl of soup, hoping to be noticed by the big shot male clientele. It's an interesting study in San Francisco culture and sexuality, lunch time at Boulevard is.

My friend was able to get reservations for 1pm as it was already 11:30 by the time he called. We valeted and were seated immediately upon arrival. The hostesses are very pleasant and there isn't a hint of attitude here.

Our waiter was the consummate professional - knowledgeable about the menu and alert to our needs without being obtrusive. And you have to love a fine restaurant  where the waiter gives you a choice of tap water and doesn't wince if you choose that over bottled.

I had the lobster bisque for starters and it's perfection. My friend had the pancetta stuffed ravioli. 

For my main course I decided on the Kobe Bavette with baked fingerling potatoes with crme fraiche, smoked Bacon & chives, sauteed spinach in a gorgeous and flavorful reduction sauce. What is a bavette you ask? I have no idea. But I do know it's a tasty hunk of meat. Because it was a very warm day today the meal was a bit heavy but delicious. Listen, I'm not going to say don't eat at Boulevard on a hot day. But there's not much in the way of light fare on the menu. My friend had the halibut. We both enjoyed our dishes very much.

Pricey? But of course! This is Boulevard!

After a delicious latte we had to skedaddle. It was a nice treat to start the week : )
author: Alison P.

description:
'Tude

That's what this place has. Took a client here, but he was running late.  I was starving so wanted to sit down and order an appetizer and a glass of wine.  Took 20 minutes to sit me.  (Wha'?)

Ordered scallopS and a phenomenal zinfandel.  Finally my client arrived and ordered a drink.  When his drink arrived the waiter took the menus (we hadn't ordered entrees yet!).  (Wha'?)

When he walked past, I told him I'd like to have the menus back so we could see what we wanted.  He said the scallopS were coming and they "didn't allow" menus on the table with food because they wanted the presentation to be "unfettered."  (Wha'?)

Bear in mind there was no food in sight (took 10 more minutes to arrive).  We were both starving, so I pressed him and he said, well, he could leave ONE menu.  (Wha'?)

My client and II were incredulous.

When the scallopS arrived there were two (2) of the smallest scallopS I've seen.  (Wha'?)

(Two sets of eyebrows raise).

We gobble these down (very tasty) and devour 3 baskets of bread over 45 minutes (wha'?) 'till the lamb chops, which were delicious and cost $44 each (wha'?), came.  I guess "unfettered" was a theme, 'cause the lamb was pretty unfettered on the plate, and for $44 I'd expect a little potato fetter or green bean fetter or bell pepper fetter.

When I read other reviews about the small portions, I wasn't put off 'cause I kinda like to eat light most of the time.  But, baby, this was  l i i i i i g h t.

All in all, the food we had was great.  But it was insulting to be told when we could (not) have a menu, to be served two tiny scallopS, and to be charged $44 for a small bit of lamb.

The food's great, but with 'tude... 'eh.
author: Scott W.

description:
Came here for J's birthday. I've been dying to come here for ages, so I was pretty happy that J's brother suggested it as the birthday dinner locale.

Too bad it didn't live up to my expectations. It was entirely unmemorable. Case and point: I can't remember what we ordered, what kind of wine we drank (I only remember that it was white), and if the food was good or not. At least I don't remember the food being bad. I didn't pick up the tab, but I remember thinking after finishing the meal that it wasn't worth whatever was paid (very overpriced).

There are better restaurants in the city. Of course if you're coming here on other people's tabs, by all means enjoy yourself. Otherwise, I'd skip it.
author: Susanna W.

description:
Wow. Boulevard now ranks in my top five restaurants in the city. I've been here several times for lunch previously and thought the food was good, but never been blown away. Just got back from one of the best dinners I've had in the city.

Seared fois gras. GET IT. Soooooo good. I can't even begin to describe how delicious it was. A very generous portion, perfectly seared, is served with 3 cubes of toasted chocolate bread and cooked apple pieces. Fois gras and chocolate? Sounds weird. Tastes fan-freaking-tastic. Many apologies to the duck whose life was sacrificed for me to enjoy this amazing dish.

Roasted lamb chops - perfectly cooked to medium rare, on the bone, with a seared, almost crispy skin. Served with farro cooked with chanterelle mushrooms, artichoke hearts and haricot verts. Upscale comfort food that warms the soul and delights the palate.

Dessert was three different sorbets: grapefruit, grape and Greek yogurt. The grape fell a little flat (more like a foam than a sorbet), but the grapefruit was perfectly tart and sweet and the Greek yogurt was creamy and slightly tangy.

We also ordered a lovely bottle of rioja that was rich and velvety on the tongue. Wish I could remember the name of the label.

Yuuuuuuuummmmmmmm.
author: Deb I.

description:
I was urged to try The Boulevard restaurant in San Francisco by a colleague of mine. Not knowing anything about the restaurant I researched it on Yelp, and was impress by the menu and the reviews. So off to the restaurant we went.
Like the ignorant pagans we were, the four of us showed up with no reservations, hoping to get a seat at the bar or a table. The hostess, upon hearing we were a four top without a reservation look at us like we clearly did not know where were at all. The quoted wait of two and hours barely crossed her lips when she pointed to a small round table tuck away in the alcove in the bar and told us to grab it now.
As luck would have it, the waiter turned that table into a four top complete with all the linens and tableware needed. This is where one of the best Epicurean experiences of my life was about to take place. Let me tell I have been cooking professionally for 30 plus years and have experienced restaurants on every continent on this earth save one, it was too cold and the dining options were only mess halls.
After perusing the wine list I settled on a Pinot Noir from the Frances Thompson Vineyard by Flowers. Good Juice when you can get it. We looked at the menu and selected five appetizers to sample. Four of the five appetizers ransacked my taste buds with such imagination and superior flavor marriages that they were clearly illegal in at least 49 states. The Foie gras, Scallops with black truffles, Calamari and Abalone, and the heirloom tomato salad with Burata, were clearly champions of the appetizer page. There is no reason to go into detail on each one of these at all. There is no way anyone should ever take the ranting of a crazed chef as a testament to their creative prowess. One just needs to go online and make a reservation and get educated. The fifth appetizer was good, a cheese raviolini with eggplant, flavorful but truly pedestrian sitting on the same table with the app gods.
The entrees where excellent and were well thought out in appearance and flavor. I had the salmon, to my right was the duck breast wrapped in pancetta, and other two positions on the table due to any  lack of sear imagination and understanding of the ingredients that been paraded on the table for the last hour, each choose the Halibut. The duck clearly was hands winner of the three.
We opted for a second bottle of Flowers and passed on dessert. I clearly set myself up for the sequel.
You know I recently dined with a genius of flavor and had an experience in a restaurant that startled me. The ingredients that the chef choose, the preparations he executed, all were just awe inspiring. My partner in the meal, had spent time reading the menu on line and came to the table with a lot of pre conceived notions and opinions. I implore come to this restaurant and any restaurant with an open mind and look upon each dish as a painting or any other art median you want to. Experience it for what is and try not to figure it out for any reason. A perfectly grown tomato, picked at the right moment, let to ripen in a sunny window until perfection, sliced and seasoned salt and pepper is heaven.
author: David S.

description:
My review on Boulevard is a little biased due to the fact that my lunch experience was a company expense to entertain a client. So when you don't have to look at price to analyze your choice the experience is much more enjoyable. Boulevard is not for the price conscience diner.

The Christmas decor is beautiful.  They did a wonderful job making the space warm and festive. The service is impeccable, very attentive and friendly! 

I started with the scallop starter dish.  The scallops are on the small side but were perfectly cooked and very tasty.  The 3 small scallops comes served over risotto.  I did not have the risotto because I wanted to save room but to be overly critical because I have to be I mean this is one of the best restaurants in SF, the risotto looked a bit oily.  The scallops were tasty but for the $15 plus price tag I don't know if I would be as satisfied if I paid out of pocket. 

For lunch I had the Organic Chicken Cobb Salad.  The presentation was unusual but coming from a picky eater I enjoyed how all the ingredients came separated on one plate.  If you've eaten out with me you know there are certain foods I don't like touching each other. So to get a salad of all meals being served with ingredients separated I was pleasantly surprised. You can spice up chicken all you want but you can tell good fresh meat when you taste it, Boulevard made something as plain as a chicken breast succulent and satisfying.

Overall my meal was very good.  I enjoyed my entire lunch experience at Boulevard and I think I closed the deal!
author: Frankie F.

description: This place is as good as it gets! My daughter and I had dinner there on Friday night and our meal was unforgetable. Will definitely return!
author: J F.

description:
Boulevard is arguably the most popular restaurant in San Francisco, thanks to the amazing food, waterfront location, and proximity to the financial district.    

Food:  5 stars.   Come here for the extravagant food above everything else.  Everything we had was par excellence.  For starters, the dayboat sea scallops were perfectly cooked and delicious and the seared sonoma foie gras formed a perfect combo with strawberries and balsamic vinegar.  For entrees, the oven roasted suckling pig is phenomenal in its three variations, especially the sausage, and the BBQ Angus short rib is tender and succulent.  Both desserts we tried, the vanilla crepes and strawberry rhubarb trio, were heavenly.

Service:  4 stars.  Service, although smooth, could use a bit more polish for a restaurant of this caliber and the price you pay.  We had to wait a few extra minutes past our reservation to be seated and the wines by the glass took a little longer than expected to reach our table.  Otherwise, the server was friendly, professional, and knowledgeable about the menu, including being spot on with his food recommendations and wine pairings.

Atmosphere:  5 stars.   The restaurant is remniscient of a high end French brasserie, especially the exterior.  The interior adds a touch of whimsicality (look for the peacocks) to remove any hint of stuffiness.  Although the crowd exudes age, power and money, younger people will not feel out of place.  

Hits:   Seared sonoma foie gras, seared day boat scallops, oven roasted suckling pig.

Misses:   Expensive prices, no tasting menu.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:   Bix, Cosmopolitan Cafe, Myth, Redd, Spruce
author: Keith C.

description:
Mediocre.

Unless your age matches their deliberate decor (circa late 1800's, early 1900's), you will feel slightly like a fish out of water.  But, at least the tables are spread quite apart from each other, unlike other restaurants of this "caliber."  I liked my prosciutto and mozzarella salad.  However, my main of butterfish was overcooked AND fishy.  Is that even possible?  I hear the meat is supposed to just flake off...but mine had to be yanked off.  I also hear that butterfish prepared properly elsewhere does not taste so fishy.  The palm hearts and trumpet mushrooms underneath the fish, however, were to die for!  Unfortunately, that was the only thing that really awed me about this whole Boulevard experience.

Shame.
author: Liz C.

description:
For awhile, I have heard that Boulevard is one of San Francisco's swankiest restaurants from my foodie friends. That's why, when my employer gave me a gift certificate for excellence with a big work project, I was thrilled!:) I waited for my sister to fly in from out of state, and we went out for our birthday. 

From the moment we walked in the door, we were treated like royalty. The host ushered us to the bar and we ordered cocktails until our reservation was ready, which didn't take long. The meal was incredible (I had filet mignon), but the best part was dessert. There's really no way to adequately describe the chocolate/fruit/icecream fusion that I still think about sometimes. 

Go here with someone you really care about. Or just someone you really want to care about you. They'll be impressed.
author: Jaynel G.

description: The Best food in San Francisco - at least this week. Tough market to stay on top. King Salmon and the Pork Chop were both beyond excellent. Loud room was offset by the fact that so many happy customers were enjoying themselves. Over the years, this place continues to improve. Amazing!
author: Dave H.

description:
I'm sure Boulevard deserves more than 3 stars, but because I came in with such high expectations, I really can't say I'm fully satisfied with my experience. 

I had the winter salad and veal for lunch. Both dishes were so-so. The lemonade of the day was too tart and had to be diluted with water before it tasted okay. The dessert was excellent, though. Service was slightly on the slow side. 

But hey, I sat next to Willie Brown and observed that his service was amazing ;)

3 stars.
author: Han C.

description: I really enjoyed this restaurant. The decor was a lovely french style throughout. The ceiling was laid in small bricks, which was beautiful. The front entrance was a mosaic pattern. There were lovely fixtures and we got to sit in the front by the window. The food was also very good and worth trying.
author: Felecia W.

description:
Mom and I decided to take ourselves to a lovely dinner the day after Christmas. Thankfully, we made reservations -- the place was packed, especially for a Wednesday!

I had the *special* vegetarian platter. They take bits and pieces from all over the menu and put together a sweet platter full of delicious goodies (you just have to ask since everything on the menu is meaty). My mom had the salmon on the bed of pesto risotto. She said it was the best salmon she thinks she has ever had.

The waiter was very nice and we had a great little table in the middle of the restaurant, so we got to see everything that was going on. Unfortunately, he guy at the table behind us had a voice like a muppet, which made my mom cringe every time he spoke. And, of course, he was a storyteller -- you know the type: never shuts up and expects laughter after each breath taken.

Other than the nearby muppet, everything was perfect. Boulevard is such a classy place with a really pleasant ambiance. After dinner strolls on the Embarcadero are my favorite thing in the winter, so the location is perfect.

Everything went as expected: quality food and a splendid evening.
author: Syd V.

description:
My first review centered on our waiter and the excellent service and wine selections.  Well, we returned after 2 years and guess what- same waiter.  Service was again excellent and we enjoyed every bite.

Highlights included the Foie Gras and quail, but the abalone was over the top.  Wine picks were again excellent with a Blue Farm pinot that was the best in my opinion.

For me - in the top of the food chain category, Boulevard is a winner.
author: g p.

description:
I can't believe I've never been here before. Dined last night with two other couples. Loved the decor. Arrived and were greeted nicely and shown to a table at the bar while we waited for the first seating to start.  Nice by the glass wine list and, as you would find in any worthwhile SF standout, Anchor Steam beer. A couple of nice cocktails and we were off to the table. Our server, Jeff, was knowledgeable and pleasant. He was around but not hovering. The food was marvelous. Scallops for a starter. They were a joy. Of course, I had the rack of lamb. I don't really like lamb but I do love saying 'nice rack'. Just kidding. Love the lamb. Oh, and I do love saying 'nice rack' as well. I thought it was odd that this was the first place I'd had a rack of lamb where I wasn't asked how I wanted it prepared. But it was rare and perfect. The risotto under it was perfect too.  We ordered a plethora of desserts and shared. They were all fabulous.

Pricey but well worth it in my book. Some say it's gone downhill but I can't compare. Highly recommended.
author: Brian B.

description: The foie gras, and the lamb steak were delicious. It was a lively french bistro style atmosphere, with a diverse wine list. It was expensive, but not as bad as some places i've been to in nyc. Service was excellent.
author: Ojas V.

description:
I don't want to bog you down with wordy-ness, so let's keep this short. 



Whoa. Whoa. Whoa.
author: Jill R.

description:
I have dined at Boulevard three times and have always been pleased.  It is a bit on the stuffy side, however it's nowhere near as stuffy as a lot of other fine dining establishments.  I went once during truffle season and could have died happy in my seat.  Mmmm, truffles....

Minus 1 star for being kind of stuffy and also slightly overrated; plus 1 star for giving my lousy, cheating, lying ex-boyfriend the worst food poisoning of his life (he he).  Boulevard--you read my mind!
author: vicarious c.

description:
I profess to be a foodie.  I've lived in San Francisco for three years.  And yet I'd never been to Boulevard.  My friend Fredi said this was unacceptable, so we went there on Friday night.  I have to agree with Jean K.  The food was excellent -- the experience not so much so.

The crowd is a strange mix of blue-hairs, tourists, and obnoxious FiDi people on expense accounts.  The latter two groups are incapable of keeping their voices down or adhering to most rules of common decency, and the restaurant was LOUD.  Tables are a little close together, not to mention fairly small.  However, despite the questionable crowd, I was really impressed by the service.  Our waiter was extremely knowledgeable and unafraid to make a recommendation.  This is the only time I've been in a "touristy" restaurant and been impressed by the service.

On the advice of pretty much everyone, I started with the tuna.  The tuna was excellent.  However, they put foam on it.  Look, it's not 1986 anymore.  Was Marcel back in the kitchen???  The escolar was recommended by the waiter and was perfectly cooked.  The dessert blew me away.  Figs surrounding ice cream that had baklava IN IT?  Brilliant. 

So, yes, it's expensive.  Yes, it's touristy.  But there's a reason this place is generally in the top five SF restaurants: The food is impeccable.  But if you're looking for something quiet or romantic, this isn't the place.
author: Geoff K.

description:
Eating a meal at Boulevard may make one feel like they've "arrived" because it truly is an institution in SF, it's expensive, and it's worth every dollar.  

Immediately when you walk in, you notice the old French-style Brasserie ambiance and it's lovely!  While waiting for our table, we sat at the bar and ordered some cocktails.  They make them strong at the Boulevard Bar - definitely 5 stars for that alone =D  And I love the little touches they put into everything - they even give you a tiny bowl in which to discard your olive pits from your martini.  Love that!

As we were being brought to our table, we were greeted by a quirky, albeit very nice, waiter who was a lean Mr. Clean's doppelganger, and who was on the ball and had great recommendations.  I took to him immediately because he told us right off the bat that the food is pretty rich, so one starter would be fine for the two of us in our party if we were going to get an entree each.  

He did not mislead us.  We ordered the foie gras to start and it was so delicious that my bf said that this was a dish you "had to eat with your eyes closed; it's so good!"  For entrees, we were not disappointed with the Alaskan Halibut and the Hawaiian Walu.  We were in a seafood mood after the rich foie gras, and it really was all cooked to perfection - flaky and moist, and served with great vegetables.  

Tips: 1) Try the "Salty Poodle" - it's a cocktail that tastes like a grown-up margarita, i.e., a little more refined; 2) Don't drink too many cocktails that you don't save enough room for dessert (a very unfortunate lesson we learned...); 3) Don't be intimidated by the more mature, i.e., 40 years old +, crowd.  The experience is what you make of it, and we definitely had a great one, even though we were by far the youngest patrons there that night...

Oh, and because of Tip #2, I will definitely have to come back and try the desserts which look scrumptious!
author: Kira K.

description:
Welcoming.  Quality.   Ambrosial.

Boulevard was my first experience dining in an upper echelon restaurant - and boy, did it do me right.

It's been quite a while, but I still remember my scrumptious lamb like it was yesterday.  The true quality of the beautiful, tender meat really shined through as the seasonings were subtle and sparse.  The pool of au jus from the lamb fortuitously seeped into my roasted veggies, giving them more flavor than they already had.

Rewind to the beginning of the experience.  The server kindly apologized for the potential hour wait and offered us a seat at the bar where my date and I enjoyed perfectly seared scallops in a divinely toasty and creamy chestnut puree accented with a sprinkling of truffle oil.  The bartender wasn't very talkative, but got the job done.  Our wait ended up being more like 30 minutes.

The table service was flawless - my date and I always had what we needed, but never really noticed who our server was until we asked for her assistance with our dessert dilemma.  Dessert was nothing creative and pretty run of the mill - a trio of sorbet of sorts with meringue cookies - don't really remember to be honest.

$$$ Not cheap, but definitely not the worst in the city and a very, very good deal for what you get!  $130 plus glass of wine, incl. tip for $130.

Know Before You Go:
1. Going solo (or with a friend?) - sit at the counter and watch the line do their thang.  It's beautiful.
author: Jane L.

description: Completely packed on a Tuesday night.  I had another excellent meal.  Risotto with truffles, an abalone dish, seared foie gras, and rack of lamb all were delicious.
author: Laurel B.

description: I love it here. Every time I go, the food is outstanding. You cannot go wrong with any choice. I love that they have a great champagne by the glass selection. The ambiance and decor is beautiful and the location is wonderful. I am running out of super adjectives. It's all love here.
author: S. P.

description:
We rolled in around 5:45pm last Tuesday.  They opened the kitchen at 6:00pm so they said we could sit at the bar and have a few drinks.  I ordered a Mojito and my Wife had a Cosmo.  The drinks were tasty and very heavy in alcohol (the way I like it).  Right at 6:00pm they picked up our drinks and walked us to our table.  

We were there for my wife's new job promotion so money was no concern for us that night.  We just wanted to relax and enjoy a nice dinner together.  

Our server was amazing!  Nice, funny and very attentive.  There was no pressure to buy a starter and they did not make you feel like you weren't supposed to be there.  He brought us bread promptly and of course it was as fresh as you could get.  My wife and I are conscious about what we eat so our first concern was how healthy the food was, but with an array of great fish and meats our options were pleantiful.  The main course did not have an abundance of food to where you feel obligated to eat everything and feel like shit afterwords.  They gave just the right amount of food.  

Everything was perfect, the atmosphere, the server, the food all perfect.  If you are looking for a wonderful dinner where price is no concern but definetely not over the top then you should go to this place.
author: Nick C.

description:
Review # 444 is really going to make or break this place, let me tell ya. I kid of course, because the name Boulevard speaks for itself! I came here for lunch with several work colleagues and found it very telling that former Mayor Willie Brown was right outside waiting to inherit our cab. 

The decor is impeccable. The service - probably the best I've seen, well... ever. They were so attentive I wondered if they had other tables to wait on? The food was divine from start to finish and after all was said and done, wasn't as expensive as I thought it would be! 

Whether you're local or a tourist, this is a restaurant worth visiting and spending $$$ in. You won't regret it!
author: Julia N.

description:
We scored a table at the far end of the restaurant with a spectacular view of the Bay Bridge, Ferry Building and Embarcadero.  The service was spectacular and our server had a great command of the wine list as well and was able to recommend a good pinot from the Santa Barbara area.

I had the foie gras with a sampling of grapefruit. The presentation is very well done and I think I enjoyed the appetizers more than the main.  I haven't had foie gras for awhile, but it was cook to perfection and tasted so delicious.  I had the sea bass for the main and it was well cooked. For dessert I had the raspberry lychee and pineapple sorbet. I couldn't really taste the lychee in the rasberry lychee. The pineapple was delicious. 

The only thing is that the bathrooms seem sooo far away from the dining room as you have to go through two doors, down the stairs and down a hallway.
author: Natalie S.

description:
I am happy to report to my fellow Yelpers, that I had another great dining experience! 

A good friend took me out for my (belated) birthday lunch to Boulevard. I had heard mixed reviews about the spot, and was not quite sure what to expect. Of course walking into a nice dining establishment wearing some jeans and a pair of Hi-Top Vans (albeit paired with a nice button down shirt) you kind of almost expect to not get great treatment, but it was quite the contrary.

Started off with the seared calamari and artichokes, which was quite honestly, perfectly cooked. I think the sauce was a *wee bit* on the heavy side, but the flavors were amazing.  (and bear in mind, I have had a massive allergy attack all week and can barely breathe through my nose, so to still taste everything means it's good!) Had a nice white burgundy with it, which, although a bit overpriced, was MOST excellent. 

Moved on to a Rioja tasting to see if it might pair well with my main course...tasty wine, but not quite right with the Cod dish I picked. 

The main...seared Cod with white shrimp and Italian beans with a local Farmani chorizo and a buerre blanc. Holy SH*T this was AMAZING!!!! I find that sometimes it's hard to get a perfectly cooked piece of fish, let alone pair it with another seafood AND a "land meat", but this was the perfect combo. Fish was done to perfection, chorizo "strips" were the perfect accent to the shrimp and the sauce....I coulda eaten double the portion...well, my mouth could have anyway - I am actually quite stuffed while typing this.

Finished off with a light pistachio ice cream bonbon, which...was accented with the cutest little piece of chocolate that said "happy birthday" on it. The absolutely ADORABLE waitress we had (Desiree - you deserve a raise !!!) remembered that when we 1st arrived that this was a belated birthday meal for me, and remembered to add that little tidbit (alongside her excellent service and assistance with wine pairing, etc.). You know when you get the personal touch that you're at a great dining spot, and we definitely got that. 

(and did I mention how CUTE she was? SO CUTE!!!) 

At any rate...the staff seemed very friendly, the courses were served at appropriate times, and the food was delicious. 

My only (minor) complaint was, the wines were a bit on the higher priced side for what they were...comparable East Bay spots would charge less for the same wines, but for the total experience, I feel that Boulevard hit the mark. 

Since I work all of 3 blocks away, I will DEFINITELY be back. (and will most likely be asking for the lovely Desiree to be my waitress - she was honestly delightful!)

If you want a fine dining experience without the obnoxious prices (the rates were quite reasonable considering) then Boulevard is a great spot to check out.

Happy birthday to me!
author: Marco M.

description: Private room for holiday party was cool but I wasn't a mind blowing meal.  I know this is a local fave, so maybe I ordered the wrong thing?  Service is excellent and the wine selection is on point.  I'll be back when I have money to blow.
author: Rayna A.

description:
I'm somewhat conflicted about Boulevard.  Sure, it's one of those quintessential SF restaurants, it's always on Zagat's top 50 most popular restaurants in SF, and people gush over it like vodka on Britney Spears.  I tried to like this place, I really did, but it just didn't float my boat.

Other than the nice view of the bay bridge, I didn't get that special "razzle-dazzle" feeling in my loins that really special restraunts (and cheap underwear) provide.  Make no mistake, the food is well prepared and tastes fine, but I was not impressed by the complexity of the dishes or the level of service... especially at this price point.  Boulevard's a busy place and I felt like a leper during most of my visit as waitstaff seemed too preoccupied catering to the older gentlemen in suits or to the private dining room.  Well dammit!  Lepers have feelings too!!!  To be fair, one of the kindly busboys took pity on me and offered me bread and water... 

Anyway, I left Boulevard somewhat disappointed and insecure.  I kept thinking, "What on earth are others seeing in this place that I'm obviously missing??"

I may never know as my leprous brain may not be capable of understanding such abstract ideas.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
If I understand Boulevard, it is what people from Iowa think a French resturant should look like if it were located in San Francisco?

Why can't I rate 0 stars?
author: Ron O.

description: Very nice restaurant and made a great ending to my last night in California. The foie gras is the second to the best i had since having it at the Ivy in London. The wines list was a great selection of the best. The food was savory, delivered fast and high quality. Wait staff was very professional. Great light setting. Defintly worth coming to if you like proper fine dining
author: Brandy Z.

description: I was taken here by a friend. When we walked in, the place was packed. I mean REALLY PACKED. I got a seat at the bar while we waited for our table. After some cocktails, we were taken to a crappy table (ok it was packed but we had reservations) and I could tell my friend was pissed but did not want to make an issue so we sat by the door (which was not the best spot since it was cold that night and tons of people = crappy table) and started to check out the menu. Since he had been here before, I decided to ask what was good. I tried the Ahi Tuna Tartare followed by the  Kobe beef (which it looks like they no longer list on their menu). It was a nice dinner but would have been better with a table not so close to the door.
author: Bella B.

description:
I went to Boulevard with a date for a late dinner, around 9. The place was still packed and we had to wait in the bar about 15 minutes after our reservation time to be seated.

After that, though, the service was excellent. I never had to fill my wine glass, empty dishes never sat on the table for more than a few minutes, used silverware was immediately replenished, and crumbs were swept away promptly. I don't generally eat anywhere where anybody does any of those things.

The atmosphere was fairly crowded and bustling, but not unpleasant. The ceilings are crazy arched brick vaults, the floor in the bar is a mosaic of tiny tile pieces with a large peacock at the front, a motif that is repeated throughout the restaurant. The front side of the restaurant faces Mission, but the back side looks out over the Bay Bridge across the Embarcadero. The wall columns were riveted plate steel painted white, and all in all the decor was really beautiful.

The bathroom is a trek, but is stylish and well-maintained.

I had the squab breast with a couple of sweetbreads, four small, square potato gnocchi, and a pair of chantrelle mushrooms. A small appetizer, but delicious.

For the main course, I had the braised duck breast, which was a little less cooked than I expected and which was served with a single pyramid-shaped ravioli filled with all manner of things, from black truffle and bittersweet chocolate to braised duck and hazelnut. The ravioli was not large, but was a little bag of goodness.

My date had the filet mignon, which was served with a large hunk of russet potato topped with sour cream and truffle. She ordered it well done and it was perfect.

For dessert, I had the butternut banana cream pie, a tart served in a very fine, filo-like dough, with butterfly wings made of white chocolate flying from the top and a hard dark chocolate ganache on top.

I'm sure the wine list was great, but I'm no wine connoisseur. I picked a reasonably priced bottle of the right general type for the food, and was not disappointed.

The pictures on the web site are representative of the presentation and portions--beautiful and small. Nevertheless, I did not leave hungry.

I like the place, and would consider going again, but if I were going to spend the same amount of money again in the city, I'd probably try a few more places before returning.
author: Kelly J.

description:
If you are anything of a foodie, you have to go to Boulevard at least once.
If you've heard anything about the reputation, beleive it.

The food, the service, the cocktails, the view, the ambiance, it's all there.
Had the Tuna tartare, Swordfish, American Kobe Burger.  Everything was cooked to perfection.
The food was just as tasty as it was described on the menu!
The cocktails were strong and exotic.  I don't think I've ever had a cocktail that had Gin AND tequila and tasted good.  
I would recommend this place for a romantic dinner-at night it's extra sexy.
author: Natalie R.

description:
Boulevard is located conveniently down at the Embarcadero is the type of restaurant to go out for a casual evening, but expecting good service and excellent food. 

Boulevard is sure to turn into a personal favorite due to the friendly people watching and desirable eats. I personally recommend the crab salad and the filet. And. don't forget to share desert and coffee. I have every intention of taking my family and friends here to catch up, chat, reconnect, eat, and whatever. Boulevard is not the special occasion restaurant in my opinion because there are more intimate and finer dinning in the bay. Again, Boulevard is the type of restaurant where you go because you always know what you are going to get and that is good food and good service.
author: Leslie C.

description: I've loved this restaurant for years and just had a wonderful dinner yet again.  I love the twinkly atmosphere, it's so charming.  We had a great server the other evening and the food was fantastic, my husband is still talking about his tomato salad.  Delicious desert as well it's always a pleasure to come to Boulevard, it has never let me down.
author: Nana S.

description: Consistent on excellent food, creative dishes and superior service.  I have been here for work events for the past 10 years and it has always been a great experience.  It is a great place for a special occasion although the main dining room can get loud.
author: Lisa V.

description:
Bring your mom here.  It's a classy restaurant without the stuffy feeling (there were several young people).  The decor is 1930s SF and the menu is very contemporary.  Possibly the best service I've ever received was here!

I should disclose not that this service and the half a bottle of wine that I had buttered me up quite well for this review...

My sea bass was tender and salad was crispy and refreshing.  The shrimp on top of the fish were a little surprising to me.  I really didn't think it would work well, but I was wrong.  they were extremely tender, not tough or boring as shrimp can be and they were topped with a green herb.  This green herb, whose name I don't know, was the perfect topping.

I have a couple of suggestions for improvement though.  First, I wouldn't put so many peas on the plate.  I can see the chef's vision to use a fresh green color to pretty-up the plate, but the peas are just not that posh on such an elegant dish.  Also the other greens on the plate were all there for green's sake, not adding a compliment to the fish.  I noticed a different fish dish, which had a variety of carrots prepared differently; so what I think is going on is color themes.  It's ok if not everything on the plate is green, or orange.  The other note I had was for the salad appretizer.  The asparagus was unnecessary and even detrimental to the dish, I think it should've been steamed, salted and needed more acidity.  The dressing had hints of lemon, but the asparagus demanded more.
author: Aristocles P.

description: Getting ready for the experience.. Bartender is expertly explaining the menu.. To be continued.... Tuna tartars- rediculously awesome.. Seared foie.. Just ok. Pork chop medium.. Awesome .. Goat cheese was super high quality.   Line was humming..   Love this place.
author: Robert F.

description:
A very tasty lunch spot that is many times more tasty when your firm is picking up the tab.

I love the black napkins.  No lint.

And soft old-school porn in the bathroom.  who doesn't like that?!?
author: Matthew R.

description:
I had a wonderful time at Boulevard.

My Dad and I decided on a whim to go and try to catch a table. We showed up around 9 PM and was told we could hang out at the bar for a while and see if anything opened up.

After a couple glasses of wine we were seated. Everything was great!

The atmosphere was cozy, but wasn't anything special and the staff was accommodating but brief.

All in all if you want good food you'll find it here, but it isn't an overall mind blowing experience for how hyped up it is.
author: rachel c.

description:
Boulevard has been around for a while, and that you can see by the quality of food and service.  I have heard it has gone a little downhill recently, but if this is downhill, I sure missed out on the hayday.

The Angus filet I had there was amazing.  I rarely order steak, because, well, there are other things that can be more interesting.  Here, this was amazing.  In fact, I really can't remember anything else besides the steak, the wonderfully complimenting sides, and the amazing wine list...except maybe that I will never order the chocolate torte here again, even with 10 people, because it is just too rich.  

I really have to go back, because I can't remember anything besides the steak....and that it is amazing (said third time).  On second thought, maybe that says something.
author: Kapeli M.

description: This was my third visit but first as a vegetarian.  I would not recommend it if you are a vegetarian the choices are very limited.  The ambiance and service are great.  The starters are excellent but not even one entrée choice for vegetarians.  Very disappointed.
author: Kathy R.

description: A bit pricey but EXCELLENT all around.  I highly recommend it for an elegant night in SF.
author: Anthony D.

description:
Boulevard is a staple for business lunches and dinners in the financial district. You won't see groups of young people going there to have a good time, but it's more likely you'll see a room full of middle-aged white collar suits discussing business over a fancy meal, and dropping the corporate card when the check arrives. 

The chef at Boulevard is well known in the Bay (chef Nancy) and has received a handful of awards from what I hear. 

Now, on to the food. I've had both lunch and dinner here. The menu changes between both meals...I'd recommend lunch over dinner since I like the items on the daytime menu more (i.e. tuna tartare, crab cakes, lobster bisque, etc). 

Quick Highlights/Lowlights:

- Ahi Tuna Tartare: This is excellent. Extremely fresh, probably one of the best tuna tartares I've had. 
- Roman Punterelle Salad with Arugula & Castelfranco: This salad was surprisingly delicious. All ingredients were very fresh and complimented each other well. Small portion. 
- Pan Roasted California Sea Bass: I was warned by the waiter that this fish is a bit different than the typical Sea Bass. I still ordered it, and I'm glad I did. It was cooked very well - golden crust, but soft and moist on the inside. Came with a side of delicious fingerling potatoes that have a butter sauce on the side, and tasty crispy brussel sprouts. 
- German Chocolate Cake Bon Bon: I wanted a small dessert...and this is JUST that. It's like a miniature cake pop, with chocolate on the inside. Although tiny, the bite of chocolate/ice cream/nuts was delicious. 
- Cappuccino: Not sure what kind of coffee beans/espresso they use, but I enjoyed the cappuccino, served with coffee leaf art. 

Overall, Boulevard is a nice fidi restaurant with a business-chic ambiance. The food is good, but portions are small and it might dent the wallet a tad. I'd give it 3.5 stars.
author: Sabeen c.

description: A friend recommended this place so we were excited but sadly it didnt live up to expectations especially when its such a pricy establishment. We dined here for holidays with the in laws. For apps we ordered the ahi tuna, the scallops and the foie gras which were all pretty good. My father in law had the sole which he said was pretty good. My mother in law had the lamb and she said was quite tasty, but everyone else around us was also ordering the lamb so its gotta be good right lol i had the filet mignon and it was quite good but all the plates portion were on the tiny side. unfortunately i couldnt remember what we had for dessert but the hubby was still hungry after his entree so he ordered the red albalone. my father in law did get the coffee andd he loved it. bill for four people $450 including tip.
author: Gina H.

description:
Boulevard is the doppelganger-equivalent (to me, at least) of my beloved No. 9 Park. Its long-lost west-coast twin. A mirror in service, food and atmosphere.

Unlike  No.9 (which I sought out specifically on the advice of my mixologist friend) I stumbled quite by accident upon Boulevard, walking along the water my last night in San Francisco. My tummy was of course grumbling and I had passed nearly a dozen restaurants that surely could have been acceptable.

I was not looking for acceptable, I was looking for something amazing. I was hankering for No. 9...the familiarity, the food, the service and the cocktails. I happened upon a, well, happening place and peered inside. The menu struck a cord that just felt right....Berkshire pork, sweetbreads, shaved summer truffles. But I was wearing jeans and flips...and a gray driving cap embroidered with a giant flower. It looked a bit too fancy for me. But when I saw some out-of-towners (hey - takes one to know one) sauntering in wearing jeans and sneakers, I deemed myself appropriate.

A seat at the bar there was not, but Boulevard's glorious open kitchen features a marble (or granite?) topped counter where you can enjoy your meal. Wait, you mean I can watch them cook and plate all the food from like, a few inches away? SOLD. Sign me up. 

The sommelier was very gracious in suggesting a wine for me after talking to him about what I like. I ended up loving his suggestions...a 2006 Moscato Giallo from Trentino...the aromatics of a spatlese yet bone dry in finish. The by-the-glass list is impressive and diverse as well!

After enjoying an amuse of pureed peaches, lobster, cilantro and cauliflower, I moved onto the Sweet Breads and for dinner, the Alaskan King Salmon. Halfway through the sweetbreads the sommelier brings over a taste of a rose from Pink Belly, a wine he makes himself. Perfect for the spices of the dish. At this moment, a very handsome chef leans over and inquires, in a charming french accent, as to how I am enjoying the sweetbreads. With the Salmon, the sommelier kindly brought over a taste of a crisp refreshing Godello. 

Dessert was the most amazing thing I have ever had. I know that sounds general and sends up some exaggeration flags, but it was really spectacular. Peaches and Butterscotch it was called. A meringue drizzled with butterscotch, a roasted half of a peach, a scoop of peach sorbet, and buttermilk pannacotta. I was going to order a second one (okay, maybe here I am exaggerating) until the waiter comes waltzing over to me with another dessert! "From us," he said, placing in front of me a small dish with a truffle and a mint chocolate bonbon. I don't even know where I put it, but it was delicious.

Sitting at the bar, taking notes on my food and experience (I often do this when I dine alone) the waiter offered to give me a copy of the menu to take with me. Not only did he do this, but the sommelier wrote down all of the wine for me that I tried, along with is card, and placed it all in an envelope for me to take along.

These people really take care of you. 

On some interesting atmosphere notes: The chefs all say hello to you and make conversation with you when you sit at the counter. They laugh and joke with one another on the line (one chef telling another chef to, "keep it gangster") and they even let out a few muffled cheers as the chef de cuisine calls "last fire," indicating the last dinner order of the night. They compliment the waitstaff ( i heard one cook tell a server, "you guys are kicking ass tonight,") At one point, one of the chefs leans over and asks about my salmon and I reply, "it's so unusual having the chef ask me about my dinner, " and she humbly replies, "I am not the chef, I just cook." 

It's a good thing this restaurant does not exist anywhere near where I live, because between this and No. 9, I would go broke!
author: Leighann F.

description: Skip the starters they are overpriced and just not that awesome. Especially for the price and they are hard to share. Swordfish, quail and lamb all excellent entrees. Our server was ok. He was slightly pushy on selling us more. For example, three people two starters he indicated were not enough. Same with desert. Desert is a definite do! The first of the season strawberries wonderful as was the rocky road walnut brownie. For an upscale place dress code was completely casual. Prices were on the high side for the quality of the food. For example the swordfish comes with potatoes they were very tiny which was fine but they were not cooked through. The swordfish was cooked perfectly.
author: myra f.

description:
This is the last of the Zagat/SF Top 100 Restaurants that we'll be able to try while in San Fran...sniff, sniff, sniff.

Boulevard does not disappoint.  The service is excellent--we had a very friendly, personable server.  The food is very good & the entree size is large.

We tried the dunganess crab salad & the pear salad as our starters.  You really do need to get your own starter because they aren't that large to share.  The dunganess crab was excellent while the pear salad is comparable to Myth's simple green salad, except Myth's salad is twice as big & half as expensive.  For entrees, we tried the Hawaiian escolar & the pork chop.  Both were very tasty.  The pork chop was very dense & a tad bit overcooked, but the flavors were good.  To wrap up the evening, we shared the lemon merengue pie, which was yummy, but not quite as good as the meyer lemon chiffon cake at Quince.

It's sad when you can go to Boulevard & not be overwhelmed by the food.  Overall, we would say that it's solid food, solid service.  On par with Piperade, Scott Howard, & Kokkari, but we would visit Quince, Coi, Myth, & House first before we made a return trip to Boulevard!
author: Jenny M.

description: I had an enjoyable meal at this restaurant. The service was great. You will definitely need to make a reservation ahead of time to eat here. Good luck with parking as well!
author: Gina Y.

description:
This place is great!  I had come with my visiting mother-in-law, husband and 2 of his family friends so it was somewhat of a special occasion.  We got a window table facing the water right during sunset so that added to the ambiance.  I had heard amazing things about this place from my boss at work so it's been on my to-try list for awhile and definitely did not disappoint!

Sampled the softshell crab with red curry and noodle salad and the red abalone for an appetizer.  Both were amazing and the flavors were unexpectedly complementary.  For my entree I had the lobster with risotto and artichoke salad.  DIVINE!!!  Finally for dessert, I had some of the pecan turtle sundae (YUM), brown sugar whippersnapper (my least favorite), and flourless chocolate cake (good but a bit thick). 

For some reason even though we had just come from Hog Island and I had three courses, I was still hungry at the end.  I think because the food was just that great!

Overall the service was great.  Very down-to-earth and helpful people though at $20 per appetizer and $40 per entree, I would hope so.
author: Susan L.

description: Nice atmosphere and good food. I like their crab cake and tune tartare. Their steaks was memorable. We experienced good service and I would go back.
author: May B.

description:
For my last meal of 2007, I wanted something really, really good. Why? Well, 2007 was a tough year for me, and also for my dining companion, he whom I refer to as "the little boy" (although he's not really little, and ladies he's cute and single, too). So we wanted to close out 2007, and welcome 2008, with a phenomenal dining experience.  We chose you, Boulevard, and you delivered.

From the reservations staff to the valet parking attendants to the hostess to the sommelier and server, you dear Boulevard, executed our meal with culinary professionalism and style.  You treated us like royalty. Every plate that graced our table was exquisitely presented....a feast for the senses, gorgeous to look at and a pleasure to our palates.  And the wine list, how can we not mention that? The Billecart-Salmon Brut rose was the perfect way to begin our meal. And the ruby red Gigondas, with just the right amount of spice, splendidly complemented our main entrees.

Ohhh...but back to the food.  Seared day boat scallops? Perfectly caramelized exterior and melt in your mouth goodness. The oysters prepared four ways? So good, I barely shared. The filet mignon was amazing, the au gratin potatoes to die for. We finished the meal with an incredible cheese plate and a chocolate dessert so lovely we just wanted to look at it all night while sipping our respective Moscato and Grappa.  Thank you Boulevard, for helping to usher in 2008 with such panache. If the year ahead is anything like our meal, it will be great year indeed.
author: Suepattra M.

description:
LOVES. One of SF's most hyped, and it does not disappoint. While I am typically more a sucker for the trendy as opposed to the ornate, I have to admit Boulevard's old world charm is stunning. The interior is gorgeous, the ambiance is impeccable and the food is pretty damn good as well. I love the organic little gem to start and the black cod (which comes with white shrimp!). Others I have dined with rave about the calamari rockefeller, the heirloom tomatoes and the filet mignon. 

And do NOT skip dessert. Read carefully: There is a chocolate ice cream cake which includes a chocolate hazelnut cupcake (hello, already sold), salted caramel, chocolate glazed marshmallow AND caramel corn with peanuts. Ohhhhh yes. Yes. Yes. YES.
author: Carolyn C.

description: My husband and I have been here a few times and I have to say the place has never ever let us down.  The food is great, the atmosphere is romantic, great drinks and wine selection and it is not too loud.  There's not much I can say that hasn't been said already.  Oh and a favorite dish? The lobster ravioli with squid ink (oh dear!)
author: Sarah T.

description:
