I've just eaten there three times, and each time was wonderful! Yes, this is a "high-end" establishment, a fancy "foo-foo" place, where you go for a memorable meal.

Unless you are Bill Gates, yes, I'd try to expense this place!

The interior is wonderful, cosmopolitan, alive. It is a feast in itself.

I had a fantastic dinner there, and even though my date had too much to drink, our waiter put up with my date's "tipsy" state; odd questions; & odd offers (my date asked the waiter to join us for some wine, and the bottle was $150?!!!). The waiter handled it deftly. For you folks that sometimes whine here, how about what CUSTOMERS can put a business/waiter through?? (I forgave my date... she was a tall Canadian lass... wink)

The one lunch I enjoyed, a company that was pitching asked me where I wanted to dine. (I had already dialed in Boulevard as part of a payback for an ad buy I inked.) It was maybe a 2 1/2 hour lunch, and it was wonderful from top to bottom: food, atmosphere, service, vibe. And yes, I used to be friends with a woman who is a chef there, and had worked at the previous business (L'Avenue)... so I asked our waiter to say hello to her (Pam). At the end of the "lunch meeting", having dined well, my former friend sent over three amazing desserts (on the house) that were excellent to outstanding. Two knocked my colleagues socks off!!

As a side note, my understanding is that the aforementioned Pam runs the L'Avenue Private Party component of Boulevard: while I have never enjoyed this dining option myself, Pam has been with Nancy Oakes/Boulevard/L'Avenue for at least twelve years, and is quite talented in her own right.  Humm... Is a lover of dive's allowed to write this? hahha

Lastly, per the review that says Boulevard had someone pay for a meal that they never had because of a PG&E power outage & 3-hour wait ... that is a strange story, and a bit hard to believe the conclusion. It doesn't ring true. Does someone have a few axes to grind?
author: M Z.

description:
Two words: expense account.

That is the only way I could ever justify eating here again.  Luckily my first Boulevard experience was expensed, because $60 per person for lunch (two drinks, an appetizer and a lunch entree) is pretty painful, especially considering the modest portion sizes.  That said, the food was excellent, and beautifully prepared.  I just wished there was more of it.

Oh, and the service was kinda eh, but I think that's more the individual waiter and not the norm.
author: Eugene F.

description: Came here with some friends on a busy Friday night.  Service was attentive and food was superb, albeit a little pricy.  The lamb was perfectly cooked, as was the pork chop that my significant other ordered.  Dessert was delicious as well.  Would definitely return!
author: Ren C.

description:
If you think expensive=good, then Boulevard is for you. If you're on a corporate credit card and want to stick it to your partnership or whoever they are, then go for it!

The food is tasty although not the best bang for that kind of buck.
author: Mike G.

description: I think they were having issues in the kitchen the night we went.  We were a couple, but it took them about 30 min uses to bring out the starters.  Food was great though.  Also, we were seated side by side on a banch on a somewhat oval shaped table.We did not like this as we were craning our necks the whole night to look at each other.  Depending on what you like... ask to be seated across from each other!
author: Laura D.

description: 5 stars - Had dinner w/Art and my sister & her partner here last night to celebrate the installation of my sister's art show at Yield Wine Bar (check it out).  It was so amazingly good (except for the rambunctious children sitting next to us).  The service was excellent.  I had the ahi tartar starter, which was divine, and the lamb chops, which were out of this world.  Really.  Yum, yum, yum.  My martini was excellent as was the glass of petit syrah.  Total out the door was under $100 per person, which I think is quite good for the quality.
author: Kevin M.

description: Came back for my birthday a little more than a month ago, and this might just still be the BEST restaurant in SF!
author: Marcia L.

description:
Had a pretty good experience at dinner so this should really be 3 1/2 stars if that was possible. Trying to keep a good scale where there aren't any super low or super high scores, not everyplace is awesome because then there isn't "an ok" place anymore. 
Taste: food was excellent, the porcini mushroom carbonara was fantastic and would have eaten a larger portion for dinner if they had it! The ahi tuna and sea scallops got good reviews from my fellow diners. The lamb t-bone and pork rib chop were both excellent as well.
Service: quite good and attentive, quick with suggestions and background on the dishes. Dishes cleared promptly and wait staff was good about not pushing more wine and drinks as the night wore on.
Ambiance: was a super busy night so a little tough on table spacing and the place got super loud. Maybe on another night it would have been more bearable. There's definitely some charm there, but could have been poor combination of things that night
Value: sadly it's quite expensive for all that taste and quality service so rates pretty tough on the value. It's not super expensive, but other places nearby are also quite tasty and a bit cheaper. 
Overall: quite good food and service, would love to go back and could rate the place even higher based on ambiance. Seeing as the place is frequently packed, they have a solid following so book ahead if possible!
author: Aldo K.

description:
Took my wife here for her birthday yesterday and was very disappointed. Service was sub par. Even though I specifically informed them we were celebrating my wife's birthday, both when making my reservation and after confirming it over the phone, there was not a single acknowledgement about it from either the host or the waitress. When splurging for a special event at a fine dining restaurant, my expectation is to be treated likewise. 

Regarding the food, I ordered the lamb and my wife the king salmon. The lamb was very tasty, but the salmon not really special.  The only problem is, the portions are SUPER small! My shellfish salad had an index finger worth of lobster, 1 shrimp, 2 pieces of squid, a donut hole worth of crab and a few pieces of greens. $18.50 My entree had 3 small pieces of lamb, a few vegetables and a pinch of spinach for $36! I thought I mistakenly ordered from the kid's meal! My 5 yr old son could have finished 2 servings! Come on! I do not mind paying for a good meal, but at least put some food on the plate! Even if they doubled the portion, they would still turn a great profit.

We went at 6pm when it was still light and with the restaurant being quite dark, the mix did not make for great ambiance. While sitting, I was well lit, but my wife was in the shade. It is best to go when the sun has set to appreciate the soft orange glow from the shell shaped light fixtures.

If your going to spend this kind of money for a good meal, Gary Danko would be a better choice.
author: Monkeysign M.

description:
Boulevard is the place I would go to for my last meal. It is my favorite restaurant. The atmosphere, staff and food are simply the best. I have had some of the more memorable meals of my life at this restaurant, including: 

* One of the last dinners out with my grandfather and family before my grandfather passed.

* A meal with my 3 soon-to-be brothers-in-law who were taking me out to celebrate marrying their sister.

* A special dinner out with my wife (our first since having children)

Boulevard is as good as it gets.
author: Dylan S.

description:
I really liked this restaurant. i didnt  want to like it because of its popularty, and some of the people that go there, but I DID.
The food was creative and the taste was amazing. 
The staff was attentive and very nice, and made be fell comfortible.
The price was high, but everything else was great.
author: Steve M.

description:
Long ago I had a long distance relationship with this awful guy who lived in San Francisco and all I got from it was a dinner at Boulevard.

Luckily for me Boulevard is so awesome it made the whole tragedy of a relationship worth it.

I kid you not, it was that good.  I mean, I went to a number of restaurants when I would go visit him including that weird vietnamese italian place, some creperie, a tiny little cheese shop, this divey chinese restaurant, and whatever else I stuffed in my face at the Ferry Building.  Boulevard is really the only positive memory I have of the jackass.

I suppose he can thank Chef Nancy Oakes for that because what lingers in my mind now aside from a great location near the Wharf (but then again everything in SF is so close together) and the elegant decor is the heart melting food. In my mind, the food at Boulevard is so special that I'm actually sad that I didn't get to share this wonderful experience with my fiance instead.

The ex and I went to this restaurant with his charming friends that I lost in the breakup.  We started with the sweet breads and the foie gras.  I think Boulevard really stands out in my mind because it was the first time I ever had the elusive sweet breads.  There are so few places that carry it now and it was so well executed that it feels almost like a figment of my culinary imagination.  The foie gras was also outstanding. 

Now I do have to say that Boulevard carries what you would expect from a Nouveau French/American restaurant.  The statutory quail, rack of lamb, and filet make an appearance on the menu and subsequently in my mouth.  Chef Oakes specials change from time to time giving you a deeper look into her creative range.  But even with the standard staples she manages to make something classic new and fresh again with an elegant simplicity with a indescribable brightness that you'd think she was selling happiness one dish at a time. 

We rounded out the meal with some desserts.  As I'm sure you've noticed by the other reviews the portions are small.  This is not in a stingy way, but rather they are perfectly portioned so that you can enjoy each and every course leaving you feeling like a good joke should; wanting more.  Even after a scrumptious dessert trio sent out complementary from the Chef or the manger, I can't remember which one, I felt physically, mentally, and surprisingly emotionally satiated. 

Also of note, the cocktails even reflect this nouveau classic approach.  The blood orange martini was sublime incorporating beautiful color without a sacchariney tacky taste characteristic of most pretty on the outside drinks.  

So here Boulevard, here's another well deserved 5 stars for achieving what exquisite cuisine is meant to do: raise the spirits, tickle the palate and warm the soul.
author: Leah N.

description:
Would have given 4 stars for the food but knocking down 1 star for some inexplicable service issues for a place in this price range.  Food itself was very good.  Had a tomato and mozzarella starter (pretty good), then had the sea bass (decent) and halibut (excellent).  Ambiance was great for romantic dinner in the back half of the restaurant.  waitress was very attentive.

here's where we knock off a star.  very busy part of town with scarce parking so you have to valet or park in a garage.  we had made reservations but when we drove by there was no valet attendee in sight on a busy corner, then we drove down the block to the garage which was closed for some reason.  we ended up circling around for at least 20min and so we had to call the restaurant to let them know that we won't make our original time cuz we couldn't find their valet attendee (after at least 3 runs around the block).  they say "no problem, we'll hold your table for you. the valet should be right there".  we ended up finding random street parking by a stroke of luck, got to the restaurant (and FINALLY found the valet attendant too late) and then we are told by the girls at the reservation stand that we are too late and they let go of our table - this was not more than 5 minutes after they had JUST told us that they understood our parking issue and would hold it for us.  after giving us a little attitude their excuse was that someone "upstairs" handles those phone calls and no one had called to their front stand to notify them.  WTF?!?  so after complaining and getting a word in with a manager, they were finally able to seat us 45 min later for dinner.  look, for a classy place like this that charges quite a bit for their food, you would expect a little better communication between the workers to avoid this kind of confusion instead of just bull$hitting their way around customers.  that said, I'd say that the food quality was great but not for the price (starter, two entrees, 2 sodas with tax & SF city tax & tip came out to $120) so I give 3 stars
author: JL G.

description:
Elegant setting for great food with special people!

I liked this place. I am very picky when it comes to food and especially if we are paying top dollar for it. The service was excellent.

The Seasonal menu is highly recommended.

Gary Danko can learn a few things from this place.
author: A P.

description:
Went here after the ballet and it was nice they had late reservations.  Had very high expectations, anticipating a Chez Panisse type of night.

Despite having reservations, we had to wait for a table along with 3 or 4 parties ahead of us.  They did have a section near the bar with tables where you could sit and have a drink.  Once we were seated, service was nice and attentive.  Presentation impeccable.  But the pan roasted halibut and filet mignon, at best, were only good.  I'm not even going to mention the starters.  This was supposed to be incredible, not good!!  What happened?!?!  :(

Say it ain't so Boulevard.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Oh how Boulevard has slipped in the last few years, new chef?

The restaurant has gone from a place of solid French influenced California Cuisine - to a post-modern, smaller portioned, prettier on the plate than in the mouth, turn those tables atmosphere.

Don't let most of the Yelp photos deceive you, the better looking dishes are from quite awhile ago.

We just went for a holiday celebration with a friend on 12/18/2008. I started with the pear salad. (Good, but it included these mammoth candied walnuts. Unruly to eat in one bite, and impossible to cut.)

Followed that with the T-bone Lamb. Tasty, but it came with a side of GREEN mashed potatoes! What was that all about? They were cold and tasteless - and very unappealing. The green was just food coloring, it's not like they were wasabi potatoes, just green. What chef in their right mind does that?

Cut to dessert, which was deconstructed Rocky Road (again with the big-ass walnuts). Not as tasty as the calories would have you believe.

And I was a bit appalled to see our server pumping coffee from an air-pump thermos into a carafe before it was brought to our table. That is so tacky! For god's sake, if you must resort to a thermos pumper, at least do it out of sight. So much for fresh roasted coffee.
author: Bill E.

description: Some of the best food I have ever eaten in my entire life paired with the beauty of 1920's art deco.... wish i could eat here every day
author: Devan C.

description:
I haven't been to Boulevard since it opened, which has been well over a decade so it was nice to see that it has stood the test of time.  The interior is still gorgeous and feels intimate and buzzy at the same time.  We were given a table with a view of the water, a rare commodity in San Francisco.  Our waitress was like the decor, pleasantly understated.

I thought the appetizers were much more appealing than the limited entrees, which were heavy on the fish.  Not in the mood for fish, I asked our waitress for her recommendation.  She suggested the ribs, which to me was just weird that they even had them on such a fine menu.  In the end, my friend had crab cakes and halibut and I had fois gras and sturgeon.

The fois gras was out of this world ~ probably the best  I've ever had!  My friend loved his halibut.  I liked the sturgeon, but didn't care for how it was served with white beans.  

Nonetheless, overall it was a near perfect experience.  I would give this 4 1/2 stars if I could -- the 1/2 star demotion is for the trip to the bathroom -- out the restaurant and down some hotel's filthy backstairs.  The trip takes you out of the sublime into the ridiculous.
author: Lorraine F.

description:
Years ago I went to Boulevard for the first time.  And it was an amazing experience, from the food to the service, everything was fantastic.  I finally got a chance to go back just a few nights ago.  I had been trying to decide whether to go to Gary Danko's (read my review) or Boulevard.  Now I know from personal experience that there is a lot of 
debate on which is better.  But honestly they are both fantastic restaurants.  However, I was looking for a slightly more relaxed fancy restaurant so that is why I chose to return to Boulevard.  Plus, I knew that there would most likely be better people watching there.  Anyway, to make a short story short...it was just as good as I remembered it :)
author: Amanda P.

description: I just had my Christmas lunch at Boulevard, it is the 5th year that we have lunched here.  My lunch was a terrible disappointment.  I ordered the pork medalions and they were tough and over cooked.  Then they brought me the shrimp salad, boy never in an expensive restaurant have I been served flash frozen shrimp, but that is what is tasted like.  We foodies in the Bay Area know the difference.  What a terrible Christmas lunch...the whole thing was ruined by bad cooking and bad ingredients.
author: Virginia K.

description:
A date took me here for dinner. I'd heard of it from other "foodies" but I never got here. I never realized how darn expensive this place it. 

People talk about it was a "more casual" dining place... But geez, I could believe I was looking a the price of wine PER GLASS. The wine prices were easier 4X the Bev-Mo price, so I'd rather drink at home.

But enough about the prices--- my date paid the $120 bill for the two of us (which included 3 glasses of wine).

The food was just OK. I think I could grill a porkchop as good myself, but the salad was good and fresh, as was the salmon appetizer.

The service was stuffy but very "professional". These guys do this for a living, so I felt like I was being "lectured" on what wine I should have. (All I asked was "which is your favorite wine on the menu that I can get by the glass")

10 minutes later, my served decided on a French rhone wine that cost somewehre around $15 bucks a glass! YIKES!

Dessert was the best part, a chocolate combination thing my date ordered, and it's a good thing we were on a date, cuz it took forever and a day between each course!

I'm thinking that dinner bill includes a per minute occupancy rate at your table!
author: Anita R.

description:
Too many people are crowded into this stylish restaurant.  Possibly related is the decent but rushed and semi-impersonal wait staff.  The food is good but not wow and expensive wine (recommended by the sommelier) was only "nice".  The portions are too large, I'd much rather have many small tastes than a couple big ones.  

After eating here twice in search of the reasons for our friends' adoration, we can advise you to eat somewhere else to fulfill your fine dining cravings.
author: bethany h.

description:
I have eaten at Boulevard many times and never been disappointed.  The service and food are consistent and impressive.  I've never ordered the same thing twice and am thankful because they do everything perfectly.  

This is a great place to take almost anyone due to the variety on the menu.  It's pricey but . . . you get what you pay for honey.
author: Mariana B.

description:
3.5 Stars 

Decor is cozy, casual. 
We got a great table by the window w/view of the bay bridge.
Service was also great, our waiter went out of his way to call 2 cabs for our party.  Cabs were waiting for us outside by the time we were finished w/dinner.

However, disappointed with the food - I had the filet mignon (I asked for medium) along with someone else in our group. Mine was well well WELL done, his was medium (more like medium well). Mine was the chewiest, driest filet mignon I've ever had, not worth the $40+. Seared foie gras was good but nothing extraordinary, pork chops were also good w/juicy tenderness, but a bit bland.
author: Nana S.

description:
I took a client there today - He is still a client! Mission Accomplished!

Other than that, the food was great!  I had the fish (Abalore?) and the flavors jumped off the plate. Very happy with it. Yes the portions were small and yes the prices were high ($3.50 for a diet coke!) but it was the perfect place for the power lunch that i needed it to be.

If you are looking for romance, go somewhere else (unless you want ot be romantic with peole next to you). seats were close. If you are calling ahead, as for a window seat in the back - nice view and quieter.

I'll be back, but only when I need to 'buy'  a client.......
author: The Man M.

description:
Sit at the counter (not the bar) and watch the show in the open kitchen.
Best show in town and you get to eat the exquisite result. I order many appetizers, play with the wine steward, talk to people, stir up trouble and I learn lots. 

I love this place. I've enjoyed it over and over.  And I will again. Who's the lucky one who's coming with me?
author: maria m.

description:
It's nice being certain of things in life.  Like before I went to Boulevard recently, I was certain that my review was going to begin with these words:  Boulevard is my favorite restaurant in SF.

I have eaten here countless times, although over the last few years not with the frequency that I used to.  It's just so consistent.  A merely great meal would be a shock, the food is always ethereal and the service impeccable.  And of course the décor is architecturally interesting as well as being elegant and timeless.  The room actually has so much positive chi that the amazing view seems ancillary. 

On my most recent trip, the food and service were excellent, but perhaps a bit below the amazingly high standards that Boulevard has set for themselves in my eyes.

Started with the Foie Gras, first a terrine for the amuse bouche and then seared for the app.  Seared Foie Gras is like sex:  even when it's bad it's good.  But this was good, really good.  A generous portion seared to perfection, with interesting accompaniments.  Can't remember the last time I had foie gras this good.  Didn't hurt that the somewhat sweet Pinot Grigio that the sommelier picked out complimented it very well.

One person at my table got the lobster bisque, which I guess was a little too fancy to compare to other lobster bisques, but if I were to compare it I would say it was easily the best bisque I have ever tasted.  Phenomenal.

We also all shared the ravioli appetizer.  I ordered this because at one time a year or two ago they had a ravioli app that was to die for.  As they change the menu I knew that this one was different but based on the last I had to try it.  It was OK.  It was filled with a brie-like cheese that was good but completely overpowering.  The black truffle shavings were surprisingly low on flavor, both in this dish and the chicken entrée. 

Got the sole.  It was very good.  Came with fried artichokes that were the best thing on the plate.  Tried one way of the chicken four ways.  It was good, but the recipient of the dish said one of the ways was dry.

The service was great, but a few minor dings that are so subjective I hate to even mention them.  I didn't click with the sommelier.  He seemed a bit snooty, but perhaps I should have expected that.  My dinner companions had some problems with the server, but the service was excellent and she was very friendly so I am going to say she was great and leave it at that.

It's really the two entrees I tried that are keeping this from being a five star review.  But, as this is my favorite place, I will be back to let them earn that fifth star, which I know that they will.
author: craig F.

description:
I went to Boulevard recently with my husband and his parents.  My husband and I are vegetarians so we were a little concerned at first when we saw that the menu had no veg entrees and maybe only one appetizer.  However, I knew from earlier research that we could order the vegetarian side dish, which isn't on the menu, but can always be ordered.  When the food came out, our dishes were the envy of the table.  They were excellent.  

The food is superb, and the ambiance and decor are spot on.  Apparently there are pictures of naked women in the men's bathroom.  So, I'd say if you're a vegetarian, don't skip it just because there aren't any veg entrees.  Try the side platter, it's very good.
author: Farah A.

description:
Just returned from our first visit to Boulevard and thought it was great.  

Despite being 45 minutes late for our reservations due to the bay bridge closure and resulting massive backup on 101, the staff was understanding and we just had a drink at the bar for 10 minutes until they got our table together.  Whew.

Dinner was quite good.  A couple of us had the seared scallop appetizer with risotto.  The scallops were great, but the risotto was slightly undercooked.  Still good though. 

The main courses were really great though.  I had the filet mignon which was excellent.  My wife had the pork chops...I don't think I've ever had pork quite this moist before!

Boulevard seems to really pride itself on grandiose desserts and they didn't disappoint. 

Overall, a solid 4-star place.  WIll definitely return.
author: Brian S.

description:
This is my absolutely favorite restaurant.  I've only had dinner there once, but it was so special!  The food was spectacular, the service was fabulous and the decor is lovely.  
Can't wait to go back.
author: Theresa S.

description:
Before I ate here, I had a terrible eating habit.  All i ever ate were basic things like fast food, sandwiches and things like that.  But after eating here with my family for my birthday, it completely changed my life forever!

Now I eat literally EVERYTHING! Boulevard is the best restuarant I have ever been to.  I ordered the filet mignon which is cooked perfectly! It was juicy and tender, the plating of the dish was beautiful and service was great.  I can't wait to go back.  My friend who also went with his family on a different day, saw Baron Davis one time at this restaurant.  This place really lives up to the expectations and if you love food, this place is a must.
author: Darren W.

description:
I've been saving my 100th Yelp review for some place worthy of my centennial post.  Call me ridiculous or unnecessarily sentimental, but I didn't want this one to land on another yogurt shop or dive bar.  

And with that, I grant my 100th Yelp review to Boulevard.

Boulevard is by far the most classically romantic dining experiences in San Francisco.  And I say this with much bias, as it's the restaurant my boyfriend took me to on our first date, our 6 month anniversary date, and most recently our 1.5 year anniversary date.

The interior is beautiful, a large belle epoque space with intimate tables and dim lighting.  A fair warning: the menu is not suited for the herbivore.  All of the entrees spotlight a meat or fish, which are sure to please all pescetarians and meat-lovers.  My favorites are their shell-fish options: the tuna tartar, scallops, and crab salad are all phenomenal.  

The perfect combination of positive attributes- the views, the interior, the service-- make Boulevard one of the most unique destination restaurants on the west coast.  Well deserved of my 100th review.
author: Zuzzi E.

description: Quality cuisine! Highly recommend a visit to entertain your palate.
author: Gene A.

description:
I've eaten here twice now and decided to write up a review, because this place is worth the time and effort.  Boulevard's has everything.  From the revolving front door to the bathrooms the interior is beautiful, just classy enough to impress and just quirky enough to avoid being stuffy.  The hosts and waiters are extremely nice, and have gone the extra mile both times I've been there.  The drinks are superb, and the food even better.

Last night I went to Boulevard's with my fiancé.  We both had salads, she had the Alaskan Halibut and I had the Filet Mignon.  We drank some specialty drinks.  Everything was superb.  As a guy who orders steaks "medium" but is used to be ignored by chefs (who seem to be incapable of understanding the idea), I was surprised when my steak came out actually medium.  He listened!  If you prefer your steaks rare, you have no idea how unusual this is.  It was perfectly cooked, perfectly seasoned, everything I was hoping for.  The sides and presentation were also outstanding.   Our waiter - I wish I got his name - was the best waiter I've had in ages.  Attentive, interested, not over-bearing.  He neither rushed us nor left us waiting.  Plus, he brought us some tasters between our salads and meal, and who doesn't like tasters?  

The desert deserves special note.  Boulevard's has a pastry chef doing just the deserts, and it shows.  Instead of just slapping some raspberry on some chocolate like so many fancy restaurants do, the pastry chef is clearly going out of her way to try new things.  I'm not the type to use words like "daring" when it comes to food (I swear), but it's the best word here.  Our deserts both incorporated different flavors and textures wonderfully, and  both were great!  

To top it off, our bill was 50 bucks less than we guessed it would be!  To paraphrase the legendary food critic Anton Ego, I will be returning to Boulevard's soon, hungry for more.
author: William C.

description:
This is just an overall review of Boulevard for the handful of times I've being here. My husband loves this restaurant because its one of the few that he can leave feeling like he actually ate. So to start off portions are generous, great atmosphere, friendly & professional service and the food. OH! the food is just amazing! The pork chop is the best I've ever had . The desserts are just as amazing. Forgot what my husband had the last time but he loved it too.

Drinks here are not for the weak. You can actually taste the alcohol in here. I go to plenty of restaurants that charge you $11 for a Greygoose cran with no Greygoose in it. My one complaint are the ridiculously small tables they have. I feel like if I move the wrong way I will tip over everything on my table. I don't like feeling like a giant.
author: Taj P.

description:
I went here with 2 coworkers (actually 2 partners at my firm, hence the high-class selection) for dinner when I was in town for work. It's a favorite of one of the partners, who has been coming here for years. The service, wine, pace of the meal, and the meal itself were all flawless. 

I will leave it to other reviews to delve into details of the dishes I wouldn't have eaten (seems the French know their meats). But I will discuss one thing: beets. Yes, beets! My prior experience with beets: those gross staining red ones in greek salads, and Jitterbug Perfume (Tom Robbins). Yet imagine my surprise to see they're on the menu of one of the nicest restaurants in San Francisco. These little beets come out, yellow and red, with some kick-ass Humboldt's Fog. One of the BEST apps I've had in a really, really long time. I am no longer afraid of beets (well, maybe just a little due to that book) and for that, I thank thee, Boulevard.
author: Purvi R.

description:
Boulevard, we have finally met and held hands (and I don't wanna let go!!).  

I loved the appetizers.  I loved the foie gras, scallops, sweetbread...  Every dish tasted amazing.  The quality was definitely top notch, minus the stuffiness of a fine dining restaurant.  We talked loud and enjoyed one another's company.  No dirty looks from our waitstaff or neighboring customers.  The mood was lively.  

The main entree, for me (sea bass), was less amazing than the round of delicately prepared appetizers.  It fell a little short, tasting more like most bistro entrees. 

Then the chocolate cake finished the meal in a grand slam (bringing the entree experience safely home).  It was a warm chocolate cake with a scoop of ice cream, and coffee slushie.  Simple enough, yet it exploded in my mouth like fourth of July. 

Absolutely 5 stars.  No doubt.
author: Jiajia C.

description: Competent. Nothing exciting. It's a cold, calculated machine. No warmth at all from anyone. For $400 for two you should expect a lot more. Go elsewhere.
author: Michael F.

description:
First and foremost, loved the Holiday flair, it really gave a homey/approachable feel to the upscale restaurant! - Let Vueve and Dom pour galore!

The menu was good; I think we tried everything!

The Great:
FILET MIGNON! -Generous serving on top of creamy spinach and mashed potatoes.
The crab salad! -Three little balls of deliciousness.
The ahi-tartar! 
Cheese and wine selections are extensive. 

The could've been greater:
The Scallops: Just two of them, I want more.
The deserts... I don't know, nothing stood out. They were all pretty boring.
author: Rada I.

description: A San Francisco born yelper living in Oregon, I finally made it to the famous Boulevard.  Although the food is good, this place really is about the atmosphere and historic decor. The service is wonderful as you have time to enjoy your entire dinner and never feel rushed so that another group can have your table; at least five different staff persons attended to our need - my martini glass was never empty.  I recommend the delicious, meat dishes (with marinades and sauces) as an entree as the seafood portions are miniscule. The chocolate mint chip ice cream dessert is delicious paired with their amazing coffee.  Boulevard is a true  SF dining experience everyone must have at least once.
author: Marti B.

description: Really fresh seafood entrees such as the Alaskan halibut.  Reasonable prices. Delicious desserts.  Excellent service!
author: Cindy T.

description: Last night I went with 5 other people to Boulevard, and none of us were thrilled with our dinners.  Although the presentation was A+, the food itself was so-so.  It was quite expensive, and there are many better places in the city for the price.
author: Shaun M.

description:
Yeah!  I always eat good when I'm in the city.  This one's no exception. 

Décor's great.  I dig the revolving door and all the arches and baubles around. 

But yeah get to the food right?  We got our menus, and they said the menu is always changing.  The food was obviously autumnal, as it should be.  We got some appetizers for the table.  The foie gras with autumn fruits was wonderful.  I haven't had a grilled foie gras like this, and it's different than seared, and I found the flavor was more rich and pronounced this way.  The accoutrements were great too, and leaned more towards the sweet.  Beef carpaccio was superb...wish I had had more, it was refreshing and clean tasting.  The ahi tartare was nice as well.  All were overshadowed by the crab salad though...dungeness meat with a bunch of other stuff and dangit I could have eaten like two metric tons of the stuff.  Nothing, and I mean nothing did not fit with this dish, and it was so balanced and sweet and savory and perfect that I didn't want to stop eating it.  This is a must-have!!!

Entrée-wise we didn't share as much.  I had the duck done two ways.  It was a breast and a leg, both wonderfully meaty and savory, medium-rare.  It came with huckleberry relish (fruit and duck is so good together, and the tangy berries really cut the richness well)  shaved brussels sprouts with pecans (seasonal and reminiscent of thanksgiving.  Not enough brussels sprouts on menus and I loved them. Under-appreciated veggies they are)  and butterball potatoes.  Gone in seconds and a tasteful, seasonal way to present the duck.

Dessert was just as good.  We got some cheese---a wonderful crumbly blue and some brie-like stuff, and I got a rocky road sundae.  This sundae...adventuresome presentation.  Nearly like a deconstructive presentation here.  Chocolate ice cream, candied walnuts (aren't they almonds in the ice cream though?  oh well not complaining) meringues (!!! oh yeah!!!) and homemade marshmallows.  Everyone at the table said it looked like a little town.  Indeed it did.  I played the part of Godzilla faithfully then!! :)

San Francisco, you never fail me when it comes to food.  I always look forward to my returns.  Boulevard, thank you for a wonderful meal!
author: Sam M.

description: Does not live up to all the rave reviews I read in the papers and magazines.  Maybe I come to expect a lot of these highly rated restaurants, but really, when I pay prices like these I expect five-star all around.  From the service to the food, I found nothing awe inspiring.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
A llittle expensive for some, but the right price for that kind of establishment. They messed up on one of our drinks but still made us pay for it? The menu frequently changes so that's pretty cool. I went in with my girlfriend, and felt pretty out of place, it was dark, with alot of older poeple staring at us. A little crowded for my taste, I could hear the people on the side and behind us. (-1 star)

I had the halibut with some prawns and a scallop I think. The food was nicely cooked, but the shrimp was a little over salted. My green mashed potatoes were reaaaally yummy.. I wish my food was at least warm though, It came cold. (- another star)

My girlfriend had the .. pork chops I believe, and it was nicely cooked also, seared perfectly and pretty juicy, The endive was really sour though, and we took one bite, and pushed it aside. Other than that the lemonade we had tasted really good, Umm, service was good not great. I might come back to tr y thier desserts but only after I try Aqua first .
author: K N.

description:
We came for Mother's Day dinner and my parents had already been a few times and were excited to return. We were seated promptly at our reservation time, even though our entire party wasn't there yet....ahem....sister's ALWAYS late. And even though my sister didn't show up until 45 minutes later (not her fault, there was a lot of traffic crossing the bridge apparently), we were never hurried or rushed to order anything, which was very nice. 

We ordered the calamari stuffed with dungeness crab, some wine, and for our entrees - the filet mignon, quail, halibut, and pork. ALL were delicious, my mom said the halibut was the BEST she's ever had. The presentation is nice and everyone working there was very nice and accomodating. I like the decor too, esp the seats by the kitchen. My mom said those are her favorite seats b/c you can watch all the food being prepared and chat with the chefs. I like how one of them was wearing an A's hat too. Funny. You know....the inside of this place kind of reminds me of Casper's house - if you've seen Casper (yes...with bill pullman and christina ricci) you'll know what i'm talking about. 

Nice place to eat. Pricey, but worth the quality of service and food. I probably won't return any time soon b/c this seems like an "older crowd" place, but I"m glad my mom got to enjoy it for Mother's day.
author: Corrina S.

description: We drove 7 hours in a frenzied rush barely making the cut off for reservations at Boulevard on our last night in the Bay area.  The drive was well worth it....... the food was absolutely amazing and the service incomparable!  Even being the last couple dining, our server Ethan assured us there was no hurry and that we should take our time and enjoy the treasures he placed before us.  I will recommend this establishment especially for any special occasion.  What an incredible experience!  Just wish it weren't 2800 miles away, probably better that it is...... i'd go broke if this place were more accessible to me.  Cheers to Boulevard!
author: Steven H.

description:
This is more 3.5 stars.

I can see why this place is so popular. It has a gorgeous interior and they really make you feel special. There are all sorts of subtle nuances that add to the experience (like the blue water glasses, the interior theme continued in the open kitchen).

I also love the sea salt they use on the butter for the bread - makes it taste delicious.

I got the burger - tasted pretty much like a burger from Pearl's (and I don't mean this in a bad way - Pearl's had good burgers), but it didn't wow me. The fries were also a little over-salted. 

Good strawberry bon-bon for dessert.

I can't really imagine going back here though unless someone else is paying.

Everything seems to be a few dollars pricier than your typical restaurant, but then again, it is a prime piece of real estate.
author: Mark A.

description:
This restaurant came very highly recommended from a good friend, so we decided to try it for Valentine's Day and it did not disappoint.  (We tried to make reservations for 2/14 back in January and they were entirely booked so we instead reserved for 2/13).

I ordered the roasted mariquita farm golden beets and the organic free range chicken with truffles prepared 4 ways.  

I really love beet salad and this salad was delicious, generally beet salad is always served with mixed greens, candied walnuts, vinagrette and goat cheese, Boulevard instead paired the roasted beets with mixed herbs, truffles and this really delicious fresh buffalo mozarella.  It was a slightly different take on the way everyone else does it, I ate every bit of it.

In regards to the chicken dish, you can tell they spend a lot of care and preparations with the 4 different ways, my favorites were the confit chicken wing and crispy roulade.  It was served with israeli couscous which I didn't care for, I ate one bite and left the rest.  Only complaint is that this dish was slightly oversalted.  Note: The dish had so much meat that I was only able to eat about 40% of it.

***Now inserting random thought - while we were leisurely enjoying our meal we looked up at the ceilings at the slightly domed sections covered in brick.  It is a very interesting treatment which raised many questions in our minds...Are they real brick?  Are they faux foam brick?  How are the bricks attached to the ceiling?  Has a brick ever come loose and hit someone upside the head and killed them dead on the spot....?***

On to my husband's food...He ordered the ahi tuna tartare and the roasted pork chop.  The ahi tuna tartare was probably the best dish of the night, they served it with mushroom tempura which was sooo good - light, crispy, flavorful, perfect texture.  I wanted more of this dish for sure.  The pork chop was served with brussel sprouts, mashed potatoes, apple, and bacon.  Flavor wise, I'd say the pork was better than the chicken, although the chicken was more a interesting dish.

For dessert we had the sorbet - pineapple and raspberry lychee, very light, flavorful, and yummy!  Not too sweet.  It also came with a rosemary sugar cookie, of which we were both too full to finish.

All in all, I would eat here again on a special occasion, next time I would probably order a larger assortment of the starters and dessert and skip the main entrees.  Would also be good if they carried at least 1 vegetarian main entree.

Note:  I removed 1 star because my husband asked the waitress for a wine pairing recommendation for his pork chop, the waitress easily/quickly recommended the Scherrer Pinot Noir which my husband enjoyed thoroughly.  However, when we got the bill, 1 glass was $17.50, I found it surprising that she recommended one of the most expensive items out of the list of reds without any hint at the price!  A little nit picky on my part, I know...If she mentioned that it was pricey but delicious and worth it, we probably still would have picked it, but it would have made me feel better that she was looking out for us.
author: Burrito M.

description:
Big disappointment. Huge.  I had ridiculously high expectations for renown Boulevard.  I had wanted to try it since moving to the City six months ago. I enviously eyed diners entering the door from my apartment window. What a waste or money, expectation and time!

The dining room is beautiful.  Well-appointed, clean. The ambiance is boisterous, but not overly noisy.  I was encouraged when, upon being seated, I ordered and was presented with a beautiful Lemon Drop Martini.  Elegant large, clear sugar crystals decorated the rim and the Martini was delicious. Ditto for the massive mojito that my boyfriend was served.  It ends here.

There were four in our party so we began with two appetizers:  the ahi tar tar( $16) and the abalone ($20- the evening's special) . Ahi was BLAND!  I like my ahi with a little heat, and compared to the spicy ahi/salmon mix at Cosmopolitan, this really disappointed. The other problem was that they served this heaping mound of ahi with a pixie-sized serving of homemade potato chips. POTATO CHIPS. At Cosmo, the mix is served with delectable Nobi crackers baked with flecks of seaweed. Oh, and the superior Cosmo version is only $11. The Abalone was also bland.  So much batter that the flavor of the delicacy was lost.  Also, two very teeny pieces of abalone. Two members of our party had the goat cheese salad. Nothing special at all. 

Entrees
Two had the sea bass. It was obvious that the sea bass had been frozen (ludicrous when you're charging $35 for the dish), and one order was particularly veiny and tough.  It was also served with a really gummy risotto that had ham in it. 

I had the duck. Duck was good, with much of the fat trimmed, cooked medium-rare. I will say that the duck was a high-light, but again, at almost $40 for the entree, I had hoped for something awe-inspiring.  I'd say the quality was equivalent to the duck dish at One Market for almost twice the price. 

One diner had the scallops. Two. TWO SCALLOPS. FOR THIRTY FREAKING DOLLARS. TWO!!!!!!!

Dessert

EXCELLENT !!!! Creme brulet lemon cheesecake was to die for. Coffee was good too.  They should hand the kitchen over to the pastry chef!!!

Service

Not particularly friendly or attentive. Nothing to write home about.

Bottom Line

If entrees were about $10 or so less per person, I would have given Boulevard 3, maybe 3.5 stars. It's in a great location and some of the dishes are tasty.  But when a restaurant is going to charge extremely high prices, I expect nothing but the best. Either Blvd is resting on its laurels, or the majority of patrons haven't explored the vast expanse that is San Francisco cuisine.  Come in for cocktails and dessert, go elsewhere to splurge on a truly remarkable dining experience.
author: Jenni D.

description:
We had a great time at Boulevard!

The service was unpretentious yet thorough and helpful.

Setting: dark (which I like)  but perhaps a little dated.  Oh well, it's the food that counts, right?

The Food:  Delicious!  The seared scallops on a bed of risotto was well prepared and solid taste wise.

Seared Ahi starter- very good.

I do not have a big sweet tooth but the dessert was what solidified a positive impression- I ordered the cheese plate which was very good (like I said, I am not crazy about sweets)  but- my husband ordered the house made walnut gelato with figs and a dark, toasty caramel sauce drizzled on top!  Holy Crap!  My eyes rolled into the back of my head instantly!!!  Really good.
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
The restaurant itself is very comfortable and has a great atmosphere.  (Kuleto design, of course it was gorgeous.)  I love the history of the building and this part of town.

I had the the pheasant, which was very good, but I didn't love the sides.
author: Lindsey M.

description:
I have been dying to eat here for years, and brought my mom who was visiting from out of town.  We both had the same thing: the crab salad and sea bass recommend by the waiter.  The creme fresh sauce on the crab salad seemed a bit mayo-esque and was not pleasant to me, although the crab and avocado was good.  My mom liked the salad but I was skeptical. And the fish main was simply over-cooked for both of us.  The bass was a dry as a rock and we were surprised and disappointed.  After we ate, we informed our waiter and he was nice enough to give a free desert, but it didn't make up for over-cooked fish.  I'd be more tolerant, except at these prices, you expect that they wouldn't serve a dry piece of bass that a mid-westerner like my mother wouldn't eat.  

Also, we would have never gone for the bass in the first place if it wasn't highly recommended by the waiter.  

Go figure, my wife's lamb was fantastic.  So it was uneven, and if we had all ordered the lamb this would be an excellent review.  But I'd recommend that you complain on your first bite if you don't like what you get.  I felt ripped off but didn't want to make a fuss during a nice occasion with my mom and my wife.  But I also regret my mom had fish that, because it was improperly cooked, was no better than frozen Trader Joes.  I could have made a better meal at home, and that's just sad.
author: Michael M.

description:
First time here
Atmosphere is maybe 31/2 stars 
Service 3, sometimes 2 - they tried but it was like they were forced to or really stressed and overworked, no connection whatsoever
Food: AWFUL!!! Varied from nice to horrific
1. The abalone was great but the deep fried dont know what it was the served with it disgusting, popeye's chicken is better
2. My crab salad was inedible, im sure the crab was good if i could bare to taste it through GOBS of mayo or whatever, returned it
3. Duck Fois Gras , wrong! Overcooked and leathery outside, undercooked deep interior . Really too bad because if they had taken time it couldve been nice
4. Friend's lamb good
5. My pork chop completely undercooked with pink red bloody center ! ( this is pork! hello trichinosis) - returned it and had it recooked then it was delicious, kind of a bummer when you're trying to have a conversation and have to feel awkward to have something returned, shouldnt happen

It was nice of them to take the crab I didnt touch and the pork off the check, I didnt ask for it to be so at least they knew this was not acceptable for what we paid.
Maybe this was just a really busy Friday night they could not handle but thats a management issue and it made my time here unsatisfactory. I will try it again because there were some good things here but it was like being wary of the next dish and the inevitable next apology from the poor embarassed and annoyed waiter.
author: Elias M.

description: I've had a number of meals here and most have been quite good.  I think each time it was deserving of 4 stars but my latest dinner was disappointing.  I'm not often critical of portions and people fail to understand that high quality ingredients are more expensive and can't be served in grand portions like your Cheese Cake Factory.  But Boulevard has made noticeable reductions in entree size.  Perhaps meat costs are the culprit but increase prices if necessary.  My pork chop, a specialty for the restaurant, was way overcooked.  Ordered it as the restaurant recommended but it came out overdone.  Overall a disappointing experience.
author: John N.

description:
4 stars, not 5 stars because my expectations of this place were very high. Boulevard didn't quite meet them. Almost, but not quite. I enjoyed what I had very much so, but it didn't blow me away like I hoped for. 

My girlfriend and I had the calamari stuffed with lobster and crab. The first bite was a bit salty, but after that it was just perfect. Really good. We both had the filet mignon and it wasn't as tender as I had hoped, but it was still tender. Just a little overcooked, but yet surprisingly enough, the best steak I've had in years. 

Dessert was great, I forgot what my girlfriend ordered, something along the lines of a chocolate cake or something. I had a bleau cheese plate. A little rich for my taste, but adequate. The fruit pairing with the cheese could've been better though. 

Our waitress didn't do anything extraordinary in terms of customer service either. I didn't feel like wine or any alcohol that night because I got super wasted the night before, so I got a coke. But what I didn't like was the fact that after I was finished with my first one, our waitress asked if I wanted another, so of course I said yes. I guess restaurants like Boulevard don't give free refills. It was only $3, but it was the principle. I still had a $8 bottle of Pellegrino sparkling water and would've finished had I known, but not that big of a deal. 

In terms of expectations, Boulevard didn't meet them. 
But if they were a place that I had never heard of, it was very good. My girlfriend loved this place, I liked it a lot. 

Would I ever come back here again? Sure, but I think I'll explore other high end restaurants first.
author: Calvin L.

description:
Mmm, this restaurant hold a special in my heart, had my 'foie virginity' popped at this place, LMAO, it was so delicious served with chocolate sauce :p
This is a good 'ol reliable place for me. I've constantly had good experiences at Boulevard.
author: John L.

description:
A little pricey but the service was impeccable and the food was pretty decent.  We started with three appetizers Maine Lobster, Monterey Calamari and Short Rib Tortelloni.  Highlight was the Maine Lobster - fantastic fonduta ravioli serves as a beautiful complement to the cold-served lobster.  Short Ribs were tasty if not a bit grainy - like it was slow roasted but re-heated, very good flavor and a recommended order but don't expect it to be fresh off the rib.

I ordered the filet - very nice cut of meat (I finished it, after finishing three Rubio's fish tacos about 2 hours prior).  The two others I was with loved their meals - the bass and the pork prime rib.

The bathrooms were a bit of a hike (sadly, I had to take advantage - those damn fish tacos and Rubio's hot salsa) through the dining room, down an elevator and back in a corner.  But it was clean.

Enjoy.  Not sure what the "expensive" comments are about - the food was pricey but for the type of restaurant it strives to be and for the most part delivers, the prices seem in line with where they should be.
author: Jason K.

description: I have wanted to eat at this restaurant for a long time and finally got the opportunity this week for a work event.  The service and food were excellent.  The waiter was great, and had a vegetarian meal made for me.  Very fun evening.  Will go again.
author: Laura B.

description:
Good food;  painfully expensive. 

It was fun to go and the service was great. But in SF, there are better values to be had.
author: george s.

description:
To my surprise, I really didn't think this restaurant was what it was 'reviewed' and 'rated' to be.  The service was very good, non intrusive yet attentive. 

We came here for a birthday celebration so we got chocolate slab and candle on top of the dessert we ordered.  

There is an open kitchen where you'll see the line chefs preparing the foods.  

Maybe next time I come, I'll have to sit at the causal dining/kitchen area.  I was quite surprised that some patrons wore flip flops, jeans, shorts and sneakers.

Appetizers - Seared boat scallops 
Entree - Filet Migon with potatos & a butterfish dish
Dessert - chocolate cake (there was another name for it)
Drinks - Minty drink, Manhattan, coffee, and White pairing with the fish.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I've eaten here many times and it has always been outstanding...the food, the service, the atmosphere, everything. They have been so good so many times that my expectations have gotten very high. They have yet to disappoint. 

This is one of those restaurants where I really don't think you can go wrong. 

Heartily recommended.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
Love this place.  Any time I have a special event, or the family in town I take them here.  You can't go wrong with anything on the menu, and to save some dough, bring your own special bottle of wine.   Don't miss the desserts.

Reservations can be a bit of a pain. Here's a tip you don't need reservations (couples only) to sit at the cooks counter, and you get to watch them make all the dishes which is a blast.   You don't need a menu, you can just look at what they are making and ask for that.   You might even get lucky if one of the chefs messes up a plate, they will give it to you free.  Max time I've had to wait at the bar waiting for a seat is 15 mins, but you have to go before 7pm.
author: Dave L.

description:
holy moly in my mouth. gorgeous (and enormous!) restaurant with top-notch service, awesome food and a fab atmosphere.

walking through the door it feels almost like I stepped back in time a little, and there are very few bad tables in the house. service is attentive and punctual but i never felt rushed and oh my goodnes, the food.

portions are a little on the smaller side which means you can get away with 2-3 courses for lunch. gnocchi short rib bolognese was absolutely to die for. one of my favorite dining experiences in SF.
author: Amanda F.

description:
We ate here again recently and I remembered I didn't write a review yet. Well...here you go then!

We were in the area on business and decided to head in for a nice meal. The hostess....was not nice but wasn't able to secure a table at TSD in the ferry building...so we stayed. The bar tender was nice and came over to get our drink order. We arrived just before their dinner service and were the first ones but were seated after the 6th party. Why? I don't know. Hello hostess.

Our food came out in a timely manner and it was not good but not bad either. Honestly, it was expensive for what it was. I found the portions to be smaller than before and quality was ok. Here's what we had:
-bloody mary - tasted watered down, needed more vodka haha
-mango iced tea - it was SO sour, I asked for simple syrup to help it
-tuna tartar with chips (they gave me two chips for the whole appetizer) - this was ok
-filet mignon with fingerling potatoes, spinach and chanterelles - meat had no flavor, meh. potatoes and mushrooms were good though!
-sea bass with crab stuffed mussels - my fish was on the dry side, lacking in flavor. the crab stuffed mussels were tasty but tiny.

Would I return? No, probably not. Expensive for what the outcome was for us. Out total was about $150 with no tip, 2 people.
author: K H.

description:
I have to preface this review by saying that I'm reviewing food and experience from a long time ago....I was still living in the city, so that puts us back to around 2006....still, I'm thinking of doing some fine dining in the coming week, and Boulevard came to mind.

I can't even remember what I had....but I remember one price stuck out in my head...$17 for a ceasar salad. No way could it be worth that, I thought to myself. I would've paid $18. It was fantastic. The rest of the meal was very much the same, although it's true what they say about the small portions. Overall, definitely worth doing, but cost will keep you from doing it often.
author: Mike L.

description:
Just enjoyed a wonderful business lunch here with a few colleagues and a client.  Definitely a destination restaurant and a LOT of money has gone into just making this place look fantastic.  The interior is stunning, very Paris Metro-like in it's exposed brick arches, organically shaped lamps and stained glass bar.  The visual pop is stunning as it is.

Then you get the menu...

Wonderfully unique combinations of flavors and ingredients were featured including many items not commonly found on your typical menu, even at a nice place like this.  The calamari to start was delicious and cut with a fork soft.  The mountain char for the main course was also very tasty, presented on a bed of rice with wild broccoli on top.  The dessert I enjoyed was a rhubarb crisp topped with buttermilk ice cream, it was nothing short of amazing.  The food was all top notch, gorgeously presented and not too filling, worth the hefty cost of admission.  

The service was very good as well, with glasses being regularly refilled with water, well timed questioning of whether everything was to our liking, and good advice when we were choosing our meals.

At $60 a head (with tax and tip, but no wine) was not cheap, but definitely one of the best dining experiences I have had in SF.  The only real complaint I had was that the benches in our booth were so close together that the person sitting across from me kept accidentally kicking my feet, and I did the same.

Otherwise, if you're up for the tab, it's worth it.
author: Eric M.

description:
Scallops were tiny and rubbery, but tasty. I wouldn't order those again [actually my coworker ordered them]. The carpaccio was good and there was twice as much as I was expecting there to be. My coworker didn't like it (said it was too raw and not enough flavor), but I did, it was perfect for me. Maybe I just have a thing for carpaccio though. I do. The bavette was amazing. Juicy, tender, so dripping with good. I can almost taste it still. I would love to go back one day. This lunch was agency paid and we didn't have "time" for dessert. I can imagine it was pricey for the three of us with three appetizers, three main dishes, and two drinks. I'm sure lunch is much more pleasant than dinner here because of the atmosphere. I liked this place much better than Americano across the way.

Water was frequently refilled. Bread was provided. Smiles were given. Seats were quick. A large spacious booth for a party of three, awesome. Reservation made only an hour or two in advance. Matches on the host table. Restroom is one or two levels downstairs, hard to find, but the host or staff will walk you to the elevator entrance so you don't get lost. They use linen-like disposable napkins for hand towels.

Dish details:

SEARED MAINE DAY BOAT SEA SCALLOPS
Braised Lobster Mushrooms, French Beans
Lobster Sauce, Extra Virgin Olive Oil 15.

QUICK CURED WILD IVORY KING SALMON CARPACCIO
Lemon, Radish Extra Virgin Olive Oil
Focaccia Crostini, Farm Egg Salad, Aioli, Olives & Capers 13.50

WOOD OVEN ROASTED SNAKE RIVER FARM KOBE BAVETTE
Fondant Potatoes, Crispy Shallots, Tomato Relish, Sauteed Bloomsdale Spinach with Smoked Bacon, Red Wine Beef Jus 24.
author: Lorrie N.

description:
One word stands out to me.. overrated..

Wish I had gone here on a client/company-expensed dinner instead of my own dime, because I wasn't too impressed.    The appetizers were expensive and tiny.   

Food:
Ravioli - it was cold and the pasta tasted hard.. yuck... it looked beautiful but didn't have the taste to back up the dish

fish entree - I can't remember which entree I ordered but it had fish and it was okay.   The lamb that my gal pal ordered was pretty good though

Dessert -
We ordered the chocolate cake with ice cream - beautiful presentation but from a taste perspective the cake could have been more moist and I've had better ice cream.  

all in all i wasn't impressed and wouldn't go back to Boulevard unless it's for work :P
author: T M.

description:
Me: poor, hungry, student with no job and not a lot of time.  Eyes glazes over and tongue falls to the ground as I peruse the menu and try to come up with a good flavor combination.

Changing menu is a great idea, but it does force you to be experimental.  I loved what I ordered, but my friends did not care for theirs.  One of them was a fish-aterian (a vegetarian who eats fish), but found his dish sub-par.  I would normally discount that and give a place five stars, but at the end of the night, with a five hundred dollar restaurant bill for four people, everyone should have been please.
author: Tangerine L.

description:
All around fantastic meal, from beginning to end.

The Art Neuvo decor is absolutely gorgeous, the cocktails and wine list are excellent, the staff is friendly and knowledgeable, and the food is delicious, beautifully prepared and interesting. My dessert (a strawberry rhubarb ice box cake) was the best dessert I have had in years.

I do have a few criticisms, though:

1. Our table wasn't cleared in a timely manner after each course - when I go to a restaurant like Boulevard, I expect the service to be commiserate with the prices. Our empty plates hung around waaayyy too long on the table.

2. (This is just a personal pet peeve) My mojito was served in a big ol' clumsy, tall pilsner glass - I hate it when cocktails are served in undignified, awkward glasses.... just give it to me in a high ball, for crying out loud.
author: rachel m.

description:
How would you describe heaven? Kinda transcends words, eh?

In terms of dining experiences, I would look to comfort and ambiance, quality of service (attentiveness, friendliness, helpfulness), quality and creativity of food, and price.

With these criteria in mind, I'm going on record in saying that Boulevard is the best restaurant in San Francisco.

To be sure, on the last item (pricing), Boulevard is expensive. At first, I didn't even see the prices for the entres because they're printed so small and butted up against the descriptive prose. But, I know this going in, and so decided that price wasn't an issue (my good friend the credit card helped me out on that one).

But from the moment we walked in, we were treated like we were special (we are, dammit!). My lady started off with a daquiri, and I a champagne. The complimentary bread was ordinary, but somehow made extraordinary (surroundings, psyche).

We went with the special appetizer of the day, tempura garlic scapes with thinly sliced bits of summer squash, and oh my GOD. Yeah, whatever ... can't really write about how amazing they were.

She got Angus short ribs, I Angus filet mignon. When ordering our wine, I had a bottle picked out, and ran it by our server after placing the main course orders. She complimented me on the selection but offered one other from the same region of France, pointing out that the main difference might be the vintage. We went with my choice, but she wasn't offended. Not at all.

Okay, seriously, all I can say about the filet mignon is ... well, it was one of the top 5 things I've ever eaten. Covered in a Bearnaise sauce (according to Wikipedia: made of clarified butter and egg yolks flavored with tarragon and shallots, with chervil and tarragon simmered in vinegar), it practically melted in my mouth, and kept my taste buds entertained like never before. WOW.

I chose the Meyer lemon brioche pudding, a more firm bread pudding than most, and it was perfect. Yes, I'm serious.

Boulevard was part of our Special Dinners list. If you go, be prepared for an altogether mind-blowing experience.
author: Jeff H.

description:
This place is awesome.
Great food.
Great wine list.
What else can I add to the other 500 reviews.
The food is not off the chart innovative but it is simply tasty as heck.
You can't do it much better.
Bravo.
author: Matthew C.

description: This is my first review! And what better way than to start off with a good review for a great restaurant?  I came here with a friend and we had a great experience.  I had the filet mignon.  It was cooked perfectly medium rare, juicy, and hinted with just enough spices to give it a little extra taste.  For dessert, we had the donuts which ironically, were very exquisite for such a simple delicacy.  The merlot was great too, complimenting the steak very well.  The service was exceptional for the most part and the ambiance definitely had an old school feel to it.  Will come back in the future.
author: Alex G.

description: What could I add to this restaurant review that the 967 others before me probably said it even better that I ever could?? I'm just happy that I finally made it to Boulevard. What a great restaurant. Definitely a "must" in San Francisco. Oh I suppose next time, I'll dress up a little bit. My jeans and black t-shirt and hubby's casual Hawaiin shirt seemed a little out of place... The table next to ours had bunch of guys in suits and behind us was a family really dressed up to go ... somewhere nice!
author: Julianne C.

description:
Life has special occasions, Like takes VISA.
Birthdays, engagements, babies, getting laid, Tuesdays, all good reasons to drop some cash at Boulevard. And dropping ducats is what you will do, at Boulevard.

The service is amazing.Perhaps the only thing they could do to further pamper you would be to chew your food for you. But you wouldn't want that, They are super knowledgeable, as they should be. They will guide you through your ordering if you desire, or leave you to your own designs, if you desire. My advice? Take their advise! As a super knowledgeable server myself, sometimes you need to sit back and let the professionals take charge. 

When you have one of those special occasions, don't look at the price tag, just roll baby, just roll.
author: B.dot P.

description: My fiance and I had our first date here and it was beyond amazing. Fancy restaurant, perfect ambiance and delicious food.  We are planning on celebrating our engagement in this restaurant soon!!!
author: Flha H.

description: This is our special date night restaurant.  Although I'm a vegetarian, the salads are awesome and they make one of the best vegetable plates I've had.  The desserts are wonderful also.  The service is top.
author: Ann K.

description:
I have a bit of secret, please don't tell anyone, but I am in love with Boulevard.  I find myself thinking about Boulevard in my dreams and comparing all others to Boulevard and all others fall short.  I am currenlty counting the days until we make it back in June.  

When I experienced Boulevard before, it was stellar.  Our waitress and all other waitstaff were extremely attentive and nice.  The restaurant and the building it is housed in is beautiful.  We each had an appetizer, main and dessert and every single morsel I tasted that night was magic.  Simply amazing.  Everything about my experience was perfection. Hands down, the best meal I have eaten to date.
author: Christine F.

description:
Service is impeccable.

Food is fantastic.

Atmosphere is cozy and romantic. 

Great place for drinks at the bar, an anniversary dinner, business lunch, to entertain out-of-town guests or just because!!
author: Kittenheel S.

description:
This one is going to be short and sweet. One of the best meals I've had in the city. Skipping commentary on the starters and going straight to my entree. Angus Fliet Mignon was cooked to perfection and served up with a genius's permutation of local ingredients. 

Fell in love with the beautiful interior; classy and intimate. Can spend hours and hours here. Craving a next visit.
author: Annie Y.

description:
It's probably silly to even bother writing a review after 175 people have already done so.  I probably can't think of anything original to say.  Instead, I'll make a comment about expectations.

If you've read some stellar, 5-star review of a restaurant, and then go there with visions of having the same experience as the reviewer, you're screwed.  Places like Boulevard excel because they do so many things very well.  But they're not perfect and if you're honed in on all the details you will find things that aren't perfect.

Instead, I prefer to pull back and view the whole experience, did I really enjoy the restaurant, what about the people around me.  In the case of Boulevard, the answer to both of those was a resounding yes.
author: Shawn U.

description:
So the first time I went to Boulevard was an evening that was life changing. I ended up breaking up with my psycho ex after getting into a HUGE argument at dinner. I was really disappointed because it ruined a seemly wonderfully made meal.

I have been DYING to go back for nearly 5 years and when my mom and her new guy came into town and made reservations I was excited to go.

The service was top notch, vibe laid back, but the food was....

Dare I say so-so. Perhaps living in a town were you can get real great food for much cheaper has spoiled me. I found the menu, lacking, portions where tiny (I actually left hungry!) and the cost of it was just ridiculous. 

While my sweetbreads were tasty, I have had better at Isa's. My Sea bass was OK, nothing life changing. Our dessert was simply unimpressive. For the amount of the dinner I was really expecting an amazing dinner. Something to really write home about. Maybe this place has passed it's prime and I missed the boat.

Too bad everything else was great. But food is kinda of important.

1 star for the vibe, 1 star for great service, 1 star the gaggle of smoking hot ladies who walked in at the end of our meal for birthday party (especially the only brunette in the group! WOW!).
author: Brian M.

description:
So I'm only giving this place 3 stars for now cuz I made it as far as the bar area. I stopped in on New Year's Eve with my husband and a couple of our friends for a drink because we had a little while before the fireworks. We were lucky to snag a table. The place was bustling so waiters were zooming all over the place. Our waitress was friendly and they even gave us some party hats and streamers for the festivities. 

I looooove the old school interior of the place. They have brick ceilings, mosaic floors and wood paneling. I'm anxious to try the food cuz it looks delish!
author: Kimi M.

description:
Bring steve/sally-the-salesman here when he/she is trying to woo you and land you as the big account/fish, because let me tell ya...it aint cheap. It's a classy restaurant without the stuffy feeling and pretty hopp'n considering the menu. The decor is 1930s SF and the menu is very contemporary.  Possibly the best service I've ever received was here!



My sea bass was tender and salad was crispy and refreshing.  The shrimp on top of the fish were a little surprising to me.  I really didn't think it would work well, but I was wrong.  they were extremely tender, not tough or boring as shrimp can be and they were topped with a green herb.  This green herb, whose name I don't know, was the perfect topping.

The wine somonie (sp) knew his stuff and is well worth picking his brain for the perfect bottle for the night..down-right entertaining. You can't deny this place as it a SF culinary institution you gotta try at least once.
author: Lindonesia S.

description: My boyfriend took me here for Valentine's Day. I loved it--the best food I've ever had!
author: Beth Ann H.

description: Well I don't  know what all the hype is about. We went for my wife's and my mothers birthdays, and I have to say I was underwhelmed. The staff was very pretentious, and if the wine Sommelier had a smile, we never saw it, what a grump. We started off with appetizers, the ladies got salads which were not cheap, rather small and not exceptional. My dad god the scallops which were great and my brother and I each got the Ahi tartar. The tartar looked great but lacked and flavor and wasn't fresh at all. The ladies all got the house special pork chop which they all raved about. My dad got the swordfish which he said was good. My brother and I both got the filet mignon which for 50 bucks we were ready to be amazed. I have had better at Tahoe Joe's. We both gave it a C-, it had a really off flavor and was rather mediocre. I asked to see the manager about the Tartar, and I explained it was pretty tasteless and not fresh, he was rather nonchalant about the whole thing but we later found out he took them off our bill. We all had enough at that point but my dad insisted on the butterscotch pudding for desert. He loved it. They brought my wife and mother both vanilla ice cream for their birthdays, we thought was a nice gesture. Turns out you can make absolutely tasteless vanilla ice cream (both ladies said it was the worst ice cream they have ever had) and to add insult to injury, they charged us for them, even though we didn't order them. So all in all not impressed, save your money!!
author: Steve P.

description: Food was delicious, but not plentiful.  Older crowd then us 40 somethings.  Service was great -- the Bordeaux by the glass was expensive, but a generous pour that did the trick.  We tried 'foie gras' for the first time as others... followed the Fodor's recommendation on this one, and glad they could seat us at 9:30pm for a late evening meal...
author: OandG O.

description:
Gosh I really wanted to give this five stars. I lunched here with a friend last monday..and I thoroughly enjoyed my experience and food. 

I minused a star due to the lengthy trek to the biffy ... really... wow. Why oh why would anyone put a biffy to a spiffy place two stories below the dining area. With worn out carpeting no less... 

I was all in on the the service. Our waiter was AMAZINGLY agile. He anticipated our every need. Hence the 30% tip. His backup was great too - hope he tips out. I am sure he does. 

Then we had to wee...and wow-wee... we had a trek.... My friend had been there and knew the routine...I was like..... come ON... where the hell are we? 

Okay.... so I am done ranting about my biffy bad experience in a 5 star restaurant - that merits 4 for the aforementioned B.E. 

Oh ...by the way...our wine was delicious, my salad was exquisite, my friends app of dungeness crabcake was apparently delicious as I had expected to have a taste and was denied! (?!!) Our entree's memorable and dessert to die for! Coffees rounded out our 3 hour lunch that we will be back to enjoy again!
author: Ping P.

description:
minus points for slow service.  our weekday/work lunch took over an hour and a half! (we had to wait to sit down because they weren't ready yet when we got there at 11:30.  then the food took forever too.)

but the food was really good.  i had the roasted chicken salad - the chicken was moist, and the dressing on the salad was flavorful but light. 
the butterscotch sundae was also delicious and unique.
author: Maggie L.

description: It's good.  Stuffy waiters, but the food is very good and the meat is excellent.
author: Shinny L.

description: Not bad if you like expensive, old school restaurants.  I had a beet salad and an unusual fish dish (can't remember the specific type of fish) here and they were both quite tasty.
author: Chris B.

description:
Back in the ancient days, before I was Mrs. C. -- yea verily before the dot-com boom -- this was the place we always went for special occasions. We dined here Monday night to celebrate Mr. C's newfound employment, and it tickles me to no end that Boulevard is just as good as ever.

The service has gotten a little more sniffy, the clientele noticeably more swank, and the prices (never a bargain to begin with) have climbed proportionally. But the Beaux Arts decor is still gorgeous, the wine list is still deep without being impenetrable, and -- most importantly -- the food's still creative without being too far out in left field.

There were a couple of missteps in our recent dinner -- a desperately over-dressed salad, a server who left us sitting without water or drinks or so much as an "I'll be right with you" for nearly 15 minutes, an awkward gap between the appetizers and the mains -- but all was forgiven when our entrees arrived. 

My heirloom pork chop was easily the best pig I have eaten in the states, perfectly cooked and richly porky with a perfectly salty, herbal flavor.
