And the accompanying pyramid-shaped raviolo was like a minature meal in itself: mascarpone mashed potatoes on the bottom, with shredded wild boar ragu in the top. Yum!

It's nice when old standbys age well. I hope that Boulevard will still be around serving excellent food when we're celebrating our 20th anniversary.

-----Updated 3/24/05-----
In addition to the dinner above, I had lunch here yesterday, as well as another lunch a couple of months ago. Frankly, the food at lunch isn't as good as at dinner, and the service utterly stinks during the day. It's obvious they don't care as much about their local business as they do about the expense-account clients and celebrating couples who come at night. I'd rate 3 stars, maybe even 2, for lunchtime, and I certainly won't be going back during daylight hours.
author: anita c.

description:
Went here earlier in the week to finally use that gift card we received during Christmas! This was out second trip and the food was even better than we'd remembered. Last time we had the butterfish- which was so popular we ordered a whole other entree of it! 

This time around that butterfish wasn't on the meunu so I opted for the sturgeon over white beans with pancetta instead. The boyfriend had the suckling pig plate, which had pig cooked in about 4 or 5 different ways. Both dishes were incredibly tasty. Even before that, however, we had three(!) apps- a wild mushroom and truffle ravioli, avocado and grapefruit salad, and crab stuffed calamari. 

As if that wasn't enough, we also ordered dessert- english breakfast tea ice cream on biscottis and caramel pudding on top of a cake, and, just for kicks, a bon bon.

Our server was great. The only thing that lacks is atmosphere. It's a little outdated. But, all in all we had a great experience. However, if it weren't for that gift card I don't think it would've been necessary to come back.
author: Nina H.

description:
My favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  The food is great and the wine selection is extensive.  It is expensive, however, the price is appropriate for the quality of the food, drinks and the service. 

 A great place to bring friends and business associates.  I usually eat dinner at the bar or will stop by for drinks and appetizers.  The place is always crowded -  come very early or very late if you don't have a reservation.
author: Iris C.

description:
Absolutely amazing food.  Took my husband there for his bday and he STILL talks about it all the time! 

Great service.  Amazing food.  Delicious desserts!  Absolute A+
author: Pooja B.

description: Came here and had big expectations.  I had a great time with the company, but the food didn't give me a "wow" factor.  I tried the ahi tuna tartare and scallops for appetizers, it was decent.  The halibut I had was good, but I wish I got a little more adventurous and tried something a different.  I have a super sweet tooth so the highlight of the night was trying the dessert..we had a few to share but I really enjoyed the black forest cake and raspberry rhubarb galette.  Love the atmosphere...there is some history to the building the restaurant is located in, which is cool to know about.  I definitely recommend this place if you wanna impress your friends, family or that special someone!
author: Helen C.

description:
Thank you bosses of love for taking me here.  You don't pay me enough to afford it on my own, but thank you for charging this meal to your corporate account.  My taste buds will forever be at your mercy.

We had the dayboat sea scallops and fontina valle d'Aosta Ravioli and local sand dab for starters.  The sea scallops were good, but not jaw dropping.  The raviolis on the other hand were orgasmic.  I recommend trying them.  The local sand dab was off the hook as well.

For my main course, I had pork tenderloin with gorgonzola butter, polenta and pinenuts and grilled apricots.  This was absolutely mouth watering goodness.  My boss ordered it as well.  We were both completely and utterly satisfied with our decision.

For dessert, we had carmelized angel food cake with peaches, ginger marscapone cheese and fresh peach sorbet.  I had no room for dessert, but I pretty much inhaled this delectable treat.  5 stars!!!!

I would love to eat here again, and I will prob most likely wait for someone else to take care of the bill.  Sugar daddy, where are you when I need Boulevard?
author: Christina S.

description:
My overall impression of this restaurant wasn't great. I expected it to be mouth wateringly fabulous, but the dishes were mediocre - for the price you pay, you'd expect dishes that leave you wanting more.

The tuna tartare appetizer was so-so ... The taro chips over powered the tuna. Which was very bland. I've definitely had better, more flavorful tartare.

I ordered the California Seabass as my entree. Maybe I'm used to Chilean seabass so I wasn't prepared for the Californian. It was more meaty / dense than the Chilean - seemed more like swordfish. It was good, but IF I dine here again, I'd definitely order something else.

My date had the pork tenderloin entree. Which consisted three different cuts of pork - one of which was completely fat. He didn't even take a bite of it. Nor did I. The overall dish was good, but again, not great.

We finished our dinner off with the warm chocolate budino cake. Umm..  same deal - good, but I've definitely had better elsewhere.

Overall, better to spend your hard earned money at a better, more memorable, leaves you feeling like you've had the best meal ever, less expensive restaurant.
author: Jill T.

description:
You get what you pay for. So if I'm paying a high sum for dinner, I have high expectations. Boulevard is one of those restaurants that needed to blow me away in order to rank above average. It didn't. 

The appetizer was a promising start. We had a salad with arugula, pear, bleu cheese and hazelnuts. It was clean, refreshing, crisp and delicious. 

My entree took the meal in the wrong direction. I ordered the elk chop since I've never had elk before. I don't know that I'm a big fan of elk now that I've had it, but that's not Boulevard's fault. What I do fault them on is the use of sides. None of it did anything to enhance the flavor. I believe all items on a plate should work together and they didn't.

For dessert, our table shared the apple tartin and the ice cream sandwiches. Here the dinner again had an upswing since the ice cream sandwiches were absolutely delicious, especially the sandwich made with merengue that melts in your mouth. The apple tartin was just okay since its not what one would expect. (It was deconstructed so that the apple was separate from the crust.) 

Overall, there are plenty expensive restaurants in the city and if I am splurging on dinner again, I'll opt elsewhere.
author: eileen b.

description:
My foodie parents came into town and selected this restaurant and "allowed" me to treat them.  I was really looking forward to dining at this restaurant after reading some reviews.  Maybe my expectations were set too high before I arrived, but I can't say this was as great as I thought it would be.

For starters, my mom and I split the sweetbreads.  The portion was quite small, but very tasty.  The bacon was crisp and maybe a little overpowering.  My dad had the foie gras with quince bread which was very good.  An interesting combination that definitely worked.

For entrees my mom had the sea bass with risotto.  The risotto was delicious -- probably the best thing on the dish since in my mom's words, "The fish is just fish."  I guess nothing special.  My dad ordered the suckling pig three ways, of which one was very good and the other two were just okay.  I had the filet - nothing out of the ordinary.

For dessert, my mom had the apple terrine and my dad had this chocolate cake that they both enjoyed immensely.  I, on the other hand, had ordered the sticky toffee pudding.  It wasn't what I was expecting and I didn't really enjoy it.  I chalked it up to bad ordering.  My mom embarrisingly mentioned (not complained) to the waiter that I unfortunately did not like my dessert.  He said I could not leave the restaurant without enjoying dessert and brought me my second-choice of the huckleberry buckle.  Boy, that was good! I was sure happy to have been able to switch out desserts like that.  Pretty amazing service if you ask me!

Overall the food was good.  There were some very nice highlights to each meal, but the experience didn't leave me with an overwhelming desire to come back -- especially for th price.  3 stars for food, +1 for excellent service.
author: Katie M.

description: Boulevard was my best choice thereby best experience in San Francisco.  Food, Service and Ambiance were all great!  Don't miss this place!
author: Glenn H.

description: This is where I go for special occasions. Consistently top notch, and great ambiance. Love it!
author: Jc C.

description:
We were visiting some friends in The City and wanted to have a top notch dinner.  We entertained some of the more renowned restaurants but decided to go to Boulevard because our friend told us it was a great value (quality/price).  Boy was he right.  

Its a cozy place.  They took our coats as we were seated.  The service in General was great.  Our server was great.  

The menu was not a long list of random food.  They had 6-10 starters and about 6-10 main courses.  I like small menus which speak to specialization.  My food was fantastic.  Like any gourmet restaurant the portions were not huge.  I ordered a starter, THAI SCENTED LOBSTER SOUP , and a main course, BERKSHIRE PORK RIB EYE & DUROC PORK CHEEK (IOWA) WOOD OVEN ROASTED & SLOW BRAISED .  I don't like to stuff myself, but was able to eat all my food without feeling like I over ate.  It was perfect for me.  At the cost of repetition, my food was fantastic. 

Value!  For gourmet food, excellent service, and an overall fine dinning experience, this is place well priced.
author: Hugo G.

description:
This place never ceases to satisfy . . . as long as you are charging your meal to an expense account.  I just had the most amazing lunch - the scallop appetizer was really divine.  Everyone seems to serve scallops these days, but these are truly some of the best I have had.  I had the Escolar as my main - probably the best fish dish I have ever eaten in SF - and that says quite a bit.  Me love fish.  I had the bittersweet chocolate cake for dessert.  It was tasty - very rich, but hard to finish - and I absolutely love anything chocolate and decadent, so you might want to share that one.  

Only slight problem is that we got there at the rush, and it seemed that the entrees and desserts took an unusual amount of time to surface.  Though, I can't really complain because fine dining at Boulevard prices should not be rushed.

Go there and charge your employer!
author: Amy K.

description:
I had dinner at Boulevard with my bosses and a co-worker last week and I was thoroughly impressed with the food.  I ordered the crab salad appetizer as my entree and it was extremely tasty.  Portions are small considering the price ($17.50 for the appetizer), but it is located near the Embarcadero, so it was not such a shock to me.  Everyone else raved about their dishes.  And we all split a couple desserts, the chocolate sampler was delicious, and the peach dessert was good as well.

So I took off a star because of the hostess.  I did walk in the door with a backpack on, but I work at a software company so I lug a lap top to BART and around town. But besides that I was dressed appropriately. When I walked in, the hostess looked at me with a blank expression and the guy behind her asked me if he could help me. I told them the name the reservation was under, she looked at her list, said she didn't see the name and continued to look blankly at me.  My party was already there, and when I told her so, she raised an eyebrow at me. I swear I don't look totally weird, or at least not so horrible to deserve  the look she was giving me. So I decided it would be best not to wait around for her to think of something to say and I headed to the table.

To be fair, the rest of the staff was very attentive and non-awkward. It really deserves 4.5 stars.  They should allow half starts on yelp.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Their excellent dishes were accompanied by their excellent service.  We were extremely pleased with the experience overall.

Thanks for being a classic!
author: N. C.

description:
Another case of being a little disappointed by expecting too much. I wanted to take the mister out for a superb birthday dinner and I wanted to love, love, love Boulevard. It was very good, but not unbelievably excellent. Drat!

He started with the dungeness crab salad, and I had the beets. Both were good, with nice flavors and elegant presentation.

I had the opah as a main, and he had the lamb. Again, good combo of flavors. Both portions looked a little small at first, but both were rich enough that they were satisfying.

Dessert was perhaps the best course. I had the sticky toffee date cake, and he had the apple tart tatin. Mmm, why isn't cinnamon ice cream more widely available? 

Friendly service, easy parking on a Sunday evening, good people watching. 

Just not excellent.
author: Kendra A.

description: I was really excited to have my birthday dinner at Boulevard.  We made reservations four weeks in advance and got a 9:30 time.  We unfortunately had a horrible, negative server with no social skills.  First, she wanted to take the menus away while we were still looking.  My husband told her we are not in a hurry, and she was very short and said, "I'm just trying to make room on your table."  She wanted to get us in and out.  When we asked to order a dish after 10, she rudely commented "the kitchen is already closing and I thought you had ordered already." I will NEVER go back.  There are so many incredible restaurants in San Francisco and this is just not one of them.  If 9:30 is too late, then this restaurant should not offer that as a seating time.  Worst service I've ever experienced!
author: Jas P.

description: Came here a few years back with my cousin and will never forget the experience.  One of my dear friends was a chef there at the time who treated us to the best Boulevard had to offer.  I will say that this was one of the greatest fine dining experiences I have had.  The food was simply superb and at the highest level of gourmet cuisine.  A dinner here will take you on an exquisite and luxurious taste adventure.  You'll remember it for years (like me)
author: Navdeep B.

description:
This place definitely lives up to the expectations of incredible food, great service and a warm atmosphere.  For a quieter, more intimate dinner, I recommend reserving/requesting a table at the back of the restaurant (close to Embarcadero and the bridge/bay).  I haven't sat elsewhere in the restaurant so I haven't experienced any of the loudness people seem to complain about.  When I made reservations the first time I came here, we asked about the noise and they recommended where to sit for it to be quieter ... so they're definitely willing to shift things around to accommodate when possible.

Food was incredible.  I think I sampled off all 6 other people's plates, and devoured my own - appetizers, entrees and desserts were all incredibly delicious.  My personal favorites were the filet and the scallops.

Definitely pricey, but worth it for a very special occasion.  Our waiter was very professional, patient and accommodating but not remotely snobby or full of attitude, from what I can recall.

Anyway, I finish law school final exams in a week, so if anyone wants to take me here, please let me know!
author: Kristen H.

description:
This has been my favorite fall/winter restaurant for the last 10+ years.  That pretty much sums up how I feel about the place.

***** update (12/21) ******
we sat at the counter and noshed.  i ate pork blood.   also if you ever want to induct someone into the world of foie gras, this is the place to do it.  their foie has never failed me.  yum.  

it was also nice to see nancy oakes around, too.  i've actually seen her a few times on busy nights.  it's refreshing to see in this day and age of the celebrity chefs who really aren't in their kitchens/restaurants too often anymore.
author: ML ..

description:
So I totally saved my 100th review for this because it was my best friend's birthday party and i want him to feel special for popping my three-digit-cherry....

First, I must admit that I haven't been wowed by SF fine dining in a long time. Satisfied, but not floored. So given that slightly jaded outlook, take my review with a grain of salt.

I really, really liked it. Wonderful company, good service, a lovely space and view, good libations and food. Didn't love it though.

There are many good things to say about the food, but it wasn't perfect:
Squab appetizer: the squab was wonderful but the tortellini were too heavy, dense and cold.
Sweetbreads were great, but again, the side of lobster-stuffed onion was unbalanced in flavor. A couple of really outstanding items like the Seared Foie Gras with Breakfast Tea foam and the Abalone.

One of my friends had Halibut, which was delicious, but I had to send my Sea Bass back because it was overcooked. I received a replacement in less than two minutes (sorry for whoever lost his plate there....) and it was perfectly cooked, so no harm done. Aside from that, the dish was well made, but not really exciting: fish, butter, three kinds of peas and e voila! Although I can appreciate the philosophy of using fresh in season ingredients and letting them speak for themselves, so no big complaints there.

I'm not a big dessert person, unless you give me chocolate, but I went out on a limn and ordered brioche custard with sorbet. And here's a cheer to all them folks that say go out of your comfort zone: you're right. That was dessert heaven, totally orgasmic. I may never eat chocolate again. Well, maybe I won't go that far.

All in all: 6 stars for the occasion and the company, 4 happy stars for Boulevard.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
Their menu is pretty limited (and for some reason, most of it didn't sound very appetizing to me in writing), but perhaps this allows them to perfect their preparation of it because everything I tried  (scallop appetizers, Hawaiian swordfish, prime rib pork chop, bread pudding, black cherry iced tea) was delish! 

The service was what you'd expect from a place this expensive, but I'd gladly give up some of the hospitable friendliness for larger portions. =)
author: Yuffie G.

description:
Beers and Turley zin, 
Soft-shell crab, lamb and filet,
Coffee and key lime pie.
author: Brian J.

description: Trendy spot if that is your thing. The restaurant is incredibly noisy and they are not very accomodating about requests for seating. We had called ahead and were not at all happy with where we were seated and they couldn't offer anything better.  We'll try another top San Francisco restaurant for our next special occasion.
author: Martine M.

description: Everything here is amazing...so you really cant go wrong. I will say that if you are in the area and looking for a reasonably priced burger, this is one of my favorite spots in the city for it. Comes with fries too and for $15 you get an amazing Kobe beef burger. A total deal at an amazing place. I go here at least a few times a month for dinner too and am never disappointed.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Finally ate at this long time icon of good dining. I guess it lived up to our expectations, though I have to say we were just a little disappointed. There is really nothing wrong, the food is fresh and well prepared and the menu well chosen. 

Still, the experience seems to be a little bit mass-produced rather than a great, relaxing meal. The personal, "we actually care about you" touch was missing. While the food was clearly a notch better that places like Mustards and Tra Vigne, it still had that same almost rushed feeling.

So, in summary, you will probably not be disappointed with the food, but, do not expect a really special evening either.
author: R D P.

description:
There were many reviews suggesting that this place is good, as well as many reviews which suggested this place being overpriced.  This really is a great restaurant and deserves the attention it receives.  However, the hype and cost set the bar really high.

The foie gras comes on a pumpkin cake, which is a unique blend of flavors.  They seem to work together, but it left me itching for more.  Other times I have had foie gras, it has been extremely rich.  This time, it was not as heavily flavored as I would have liked.

For some reason, I decided to try the filet mignon as it seemed popular.  The filet was executed well and had great flavor.  Bad timing or poor kitchen work deducted from this whole plate as everything tasted as if it had been sitting for 10 minutes.  My food was literally luke warm.  

I did get a chance to sample some of the quail/beef plate and the cod.  The cod was probably the best with respect to blending of flavors and execution.  

A fellow diner had the pork prime rib and they were very satisfied.  It looked very appetizing and I have thoughts of returning just to sample.

If you find yourself limited with vegetarian options, they do make an all vegetarian side dish platter for $25 which is not on the menu.  


Finally, dessert ended up being a cheese plate for me.  This was probably the highlight of my meal.  A very fresh and balanced platter of items accompanied my cheese.  The ice cream sandwiches plate looked really appetizing and all of my fellow diners loved it.

As far as ambiance goes, this place is decorated well and lighting is friendly.

Bottom line:  The place does deserve the raves it gets, but expect to pay for it and don't set your bar too high.
author: Simon Y.

description:
Boulevard is like heaven on earth.  I had the best meal of my life there last night and wish I could afford to go once a week.  Sitting at the counter was so much fun, and the staff could not have been more friendly or professional.

We are lucky to have such great restaurants in SF, with Boulevard at the top of the list-

The ravioli with fontina and black truffles is seriously so amazing, and was the best dish I have ever eaten in my life.
author: James K.

description:
People.  Take it easy.  What's great about this place?  First, I did the precarious walk-around looking at other dishes, almost fainted at the size of the dishes and the small proportions of the food.  The dishes are enormous, 17" or larger... 

Our waiter has had at least 10-12 years of federal prison experience, no one just grows up that weird.  Now to the food:  1) don't order the bacon appetizer, 2) The salmon tasted nice but was easily 1/3 lb., I played it safe after my disappointing walk around with a filet mignon.  

Let's talk about this.  If I took the filet from the plastic at the store, placed it on the grill 7 minutes each side, it's impossible to mess up.  Impossible, can't be done, you cannot mess up a steak on a grill.  

Well it was about as average as possible.  Well there's a positive here, and the reason for the two stars - the wine list.  We ordered a 1999 Vino di Montepulciano.  After visiting there this summer, it's  a wonderful bargain at $66.  It was perfect.  I was so happy.  

But Californians!  Let's end the pressure on presentation, make a great meal  - no more huge plates, and decorative sauce drizzles.  It creeps me out, trying too hard.  Especially when the meal is average to below average the drizzling makes you a little pissed.  

So far, the best restaurants in SF have been ethnic small Chinese places - in the Sunset.  Yum!  

Also, if you are going on a date, tell make reservations for 3 to sidestep the aisle way tables.
author: Michael R.

description:
I love this place and always highly recommend it with much confidence.

The food is amazing, the ingredients are quality. Not sure if there are any other upscale restaurant in town that are daring enough to attempt the daily menu changes. A few people say the portions are small but I don't really understand that?? 

Lastly, this restaurant should be rated separately  at lunch and dinner. It "is" very great for lunch but lunch is LUNCH! and it's a completely different experience at dinner...Different service, different ambiance and WAY different food.

I will continue going back and I hope these guys keep changing that menu and pushing their limits.
author: Kara S.

description:
I know this place gets props and is chock-full of expense accounters and suit-clad lawyers, but it reminded me of a upscale, snobbish version of Houlihan's.  

There were very limited options for vegetarians, and my food was entirely too salty.  

I won't be returning.
author: mazzy r.

description:
See profile site for full review with formatted pics.


After an early breakfast at Tartine and plenty of time driving around viewing the city, the Golden Gate Bridge, and the Academy of Sciences the goal was a visit to California's oldest restaurant for some lunch around 2:00 - little did we know that President's day is actually a day off for those at Tadich Grill and most of downtown.  A little disappointed I fired up the GPS to figure out something close and low-and-behold was greeted by another Northern California landmark - Boulevard.  Having read glowing revies of Nancy Oakes both as a chef and a person, I'd actually considered dinner at Boulevard for that evening, but why wait, especially given the number of restaurants closed in SF on Mondays!

Arriving at Boulevard around 2:05 the restaurant was still approximately half full but our lack of reservations was not an issue at all.  A courteous valet took the car and led us through the doors into the marvelous stone-clad room with its beautifully wide open kitchen and prep area, long scenic bar, and smells that piqued both my interest and my appetite. 

After approximately 3 minutes we were seated and our wonderfully helpful (if not a bit pretentious) waiter, Joe W presented us with menus and suggestions for wine - an option we declined, instead opting for iced tea and water.  By the time Joe's assistant returned with water and tea our minds were made up, orders were placed, and I made a quick trip (down the stairs, where many old awards hang) to the restroom where, oddly, a picture of a nude lady hangs.  By the time I returned, a wonderful block of superb sourdough with wonderful salted butter was present and I proceeded to overindulge without regret.

For our meal options, my mother selected a main while my aunt chose an appetizer and a main and I selected two appetizers to serve as my main.  Course one of the meal consisted of my aunt's Dungeness Crab Cake with Bouillabaisse and Saffron Aioli and my eared Monterey Calamari with Pan Seared Artichoke Hearts and Puree, crispy tentacles, olive-red pepper relish.  Both dishes were presented nicely by Joe and described in great detail with the bouillabaisse actually added to the crabcake tableside - a nice touch.  Incredibly fresh and decent in portion, both dishes were true palate pleasers and on par with what one would expect in a place like Boulevard.  Though she was first hesitant about the crab because she worried the bouillabaisse would be too fishy, my aunt loved her dish and while I generally prefer a little less spice in my dish, the pepper with my calamari was actually quite subdued by the olive and the crispy tentacles provided and interesting contrast to the smooth cephalopods. 

For our mains, my mother selected the Organic Free Range Chicken Breast with Black Truffles, Baked Crespelle with Wild Mushroom Ragu, Ricotta, Sauteed Broccoli di Ciccio and Rich Chicken Jus while my aunt opted for the Kobe Beef Burger on Brioche Bun with White Cheddar, Crispy Fries, and Condiments.  As I do not eat beef I cannot comment on the burger, but my aunt claims it was the best burger she has ever tasted and stated she didn't even need to chew as the buttery brioche and beef melted on her tongue.  In reference to the fries, I can say that these were a stunning example of how to make a potato, though not on par with those of Michael Mina or Thomas Keller, quite better than Michael Symon's at Lola.  

With regard to the chicken, let's just say that if I had the money to purchase free-range local birds every day at home I'd be a much happier man and if all Broccoli tasted like this I wouldn't have so many patients telling me they did not like salad.  Without overstating I can say this was the best piece of foul I'd ever had (better than Trotters or Ducasse) until my subsequent meal at The French Laundry and I would strongly recommend the crispy coated yet perfectly moist bird to anyone who truly appreciates fine cooking technique and wonderful quality ingredients.  The truffles in this dish, like in the chicken at Le Cirque were mostly for show.

For my main, I allowed my love of eggs to be indulged and selected the Slow Cooked Organic Farm Egg with Soft Polenta and Roasted Garlic, Quercia Acorn Prosciutto and Shaved Himalayan Truffles.  Ham, eggs, garlic, and mushrooms simply never tasted so good - like the best savory breakfast you can imagine.  Perfectly poached, the egg's rich and smooth yolk contrasted sharply with the salty ham while the textured polenta and heavy hints of garlic were brought into focus by a surprisingly fresh and large portion (for the price) of Truffles.  While I'm not the sort who praises truffles simply because they are rare or pricey, their effect on eggs is something I truly love and this dish was no exception.

Somewhat full, yet well informed that dessert at Boulevard should not be missed each of us selected an option with each being a winner -
author: Michael U.

description:
Everything's perfect... the food, the wine, the service, the decor, the bar - and there's not a hint of snobbishness, at least not from the staff.  

Don't come here to save money, but if you're looking for an elegant, sophisticated and comfortable place to have a great meal, I can't think of  better place.

Absolutely awesome, my favorite restaurant!
author: Tim B.

description:
This place is a true jem! Absolutely one of the top Restaurants in SF. 
I have been here twice now, once for dinner, once for lunch, both time the service was out standing! The servers where attentive and with out delay, none for this sitting around for 10 minuets with out a drink crap! They where on top of their game! The food was wonderfully full of flavor. The restaurant it's self is really fun I think. The inside is very nice with lost of deep wood's and creative lighting fixtures. then entire experience is one to tip your hat to!
author: David P.

description:
Quite good. Yes, a little overrated seeing that they're often called one of the best restaurants in SF, but still, they're very good. 

The ambiance is very formal and east-coasty. Service is excellent and attentive. 

Portions may be on the smaller side but I'd rather pay for quality rather than quantity. This is definitely one of my favorite places in SF. I'd give them a 4.5/5  if iI could since I remember not being particularly impressed with the dessert. If this were Zagat i'd give it a 26/25/25 (they give the food a 27). 

Honestly though they will not disappoint you. Very classy atmosphere, service and top notch food.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
Dropped in Monday night with friends to eat at the bar, we had just gone to the Institute of Masters of Wine tasting at the Ferry Plaza and needed some good eats fast!
I ordered the Tuna tartar and the Goat Cheese stuffed Asparagus Ravioli, they where both to die for good!  The service was great and very friendly.

Basta!!!!
author: Ray P.

description:
Excellent location.  Right by the water, and right by the Bay Bridge.  Food is excellent, and so is ambiance, but would I come back?  Hmm..., possibly not.  I dined here only because of work related event.  

The servers are really attentive to your needs and you can tell that they are highly trained.
author: Kioko O.

description:
Fun to eat such a yummy tender steak, even if my slouching office mate with his dirty T-shirt hanging out of his "ring around the collar" shirt sitting across from me kind of dampened it. 

My point is that the food is great and the atmosphere nice.
author: Ricardo O.

description:
I'm sorry to say I'm not impressed with Boulevard! Ambiance-wise, it was like a GOP party. The decor, the people--waiters included, can be described as... older. The food had moments, but overall was borderline salty. Presentation was excellent.

Food I had:

Ahi Tuna Tartare: the various ingredients were laid out in a row, and went smoothly from mildly sweet to salty. Mix as you please.

Miso Black Cod & Lobster bisque: the cod and roll are brought out in a deep dish, and the waiter adds the bisque at your table. While the shrimp roll was good, the cod had lousy texture, and the entire dish was a touch too salty.

Monterey Red Abalone: there was more focus on the abalone MUSHROOM than the abalone itself. You get what I can only describe as two flakes of abalone. The herb soubise was reminiscent of simple pesto. Abalone is fantastic; the taste shouldn't be hidden!

As an entree, the Petrale Sole: presentation and flavor were all present, but the sole was not roasted enough. Some fish are fine seared, but not sole. We ended up leaving the inner "chunk."

I unwisely went against the waiter's recommendation for wine, and went for a glass of grenache. Bleh. Open too long before poured, and too heavy on licorice flavors for my taste.

The desserts were more redeeming:
The Butterscotch Cream Pie was light and delish save for a too-hard crust.

The Chocolate Fudge Cake was amazing. They don't give it enough credit on their menu. For those of you who like molten lava cakes, this is the sh*t. Have it. Since it's a heavy dessert, it came with mint ice cream which was so refreshing you could taste the mint leaves. 

I'd like to try again on a weekend... but I think this is more a place to bring the folks. Eh.
author: Esther L.

description:
We can talk about Creme Brulee all night here, but, please, have it at the Boulevard. It is described in the menu as something like Marin wild flower honey Creme Brulee, et cetera. Creme Brulee has got the sweet crust on top as opposed to Creme Caramel, which is cooked with the caramelized part usually on the bottom and is served top-down. Well, I basically grew up on Creme Caramel and since both cremes have the same custard base - i could tell right away that the creme served at the Bouleverd has had the egg yolks beaten by a machine - too smooth, too even - still excellent though. When you beat the egg yolks by hand - air bubbles form in the cream and it feels a bit more firm. It's the imperfections that sometimes make things unforgettable. 

French martini was okay, well, giving the fact that we were originally headed for Chaya and almost got there but, voila, they Did Not Know How To Make Me a French Martini, that French fusion place. A restaurant has got to have good bartenders, otherwise we immediately move next door. 

So, at Boulevard, we got bar seats and that was fine but for the large plates and food sharing that ensued. Ahi Tartare was okay, stuffed squid was good, salmon was okay, halibut seemed better, especially being dressed with zingy sour tomatoes and white beans. I am not sure about pairing risotto with Salmon - risotto seems to get a bit mushy under fish and. .. The Main thing that distinguishes first class cuisine from just a plain good'ol restaurant is the fact that in the good places you never think about salt. You never need to season anything on your plate because it has already been taken care of. On the other hand, Salmon at Boulevard needed rocks of salt to get it to a good place. Well, food up to creme brulee - 2 stars. creme brulee - 3, almost 4 if it had been with hand beaten yolks. Good night.
author: Dimmer L.

description:
I just don't get the hype of this place...

So here it is:

Visited Boulevard on a Monday night for our anniversary. We had reservations for 7, but were sat at 7.30. When you walk in, you notice right away how large the venue is, so noise was immediately a factor. Don't expect a quiet little dinner for two. Its like a large, super posh cafe, but doesn't feel like a "fine dining" experience.

It took a while for the waiter to notice that we were there, so water and menus came quite late. After that however, our server was spot on. His timing was impeccable (never interrupting our conversation) and his attention to detail was great. 

The crabcake salad was good, but it lacked the type of zest you'd expect from a supposed 5 star restaurant. My salmon was overcooked, as was the risotto that went with it. My wife's halibut was undercooked and also lacked any real flavor. The food didn't 
even look pretty. The Vanilla Brulee was good, but seemed a bit to thin for that type of dessert. 

All together it was quite a let down to eat here. This review may seem somewhat pretentious, but when you are shelling out over $200 for dinner for two, I feel like it should blow you away. To be truly 5 star, you need to have the right feel and mood setting, excellent inventive dishes, and top notch service. Once you have all of that, you need to also be able to do it consistently, every night. Boulevard misses the mark by not giving you the value that you'd expect for the premium price tag. 

This was my first and last visit.
author: D L.

description:
Another supplier lunch, this time at Boulevard. The 4 of us had a 12:30 reservation and were seated promptly. We had a fabulous table at the large back windows looking out onto the sunny Embarcadero.
Without fail, I have had crispy squash blossoms every time I've dined here, and this was no exception. In fact, this may have been the best preparation I've ever had - here or otherwise! We shared 2 orders, which they thoughtfully plated on one plate to save room (there was a lot of glassware on the table). 4 crispy squash blossoms, fried absolutely perfectly without a hint of grease, were stuffed with a creamy rock shrimp mixture. A saute of fresh corn and bacon was beneath the blossoms, and the whole thing was drizzled with a smoky tasso aioli. SO delicious!
I then ordered the tuna nicoise salad as my entree. A huge hunk of albacore tuna was perched atop a summer bean salad of yellow wax, cranberry, and green beans. The tuna and beans did need a little seasoning but fortunately the salt was left on the table. There were also some chopped heirloom tomatoes that were slathered in a yellow tomato aioli, which I immediately asked for more of because it was very tasty. I wish I'd had some fries to sop it all up! Half of a perfectly soft-boiled egg was also on the side. I spread the egg on my bread, yum! The sea bass and the filet entrees both looked very good, but the guys didn't feel like sharing :( I was able to try a bit of the chicken salad entree, which was also really tasty. Instead of a mayonnaise-drenched mush of chicken and apples, the presentation took an innovative approach: a roasted chicken leg and some grapes and apple slices were served with a wedge of iceberg and dressing on the side for you to basically make your own lettuce cups. I thought it was a very clever presentation and one that I might attempt to recreate. Somehow we'd left room for cheese (there's always room for cheese!) and picked 2 off the artisan selection. The St. Nectaire and Bayley Hazen blue were presented on a long platter as 2 crossed triangles, and accompanied by some honeycomb and roasted, salted almonds.
The service was mostly good throughout the meal (with a couple exceptions of waiting on plates to be cleared) but really fell apart at the end. Did we really need to wait 10 minutes *after* the cheese plate to be asked again if we were ready for the espresso? Just bring it! We need to get out of here - it's 3:15 pm!!! It also seemed exceptionally loud that day, not sure why. Other than that though, I was once again pleased with this classic, classy place.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Clearly the very best restaurant in San Francisco, quite a claim given that the city has many excellent restaurants in all price ranges.
author: Frank S.

description:
Boulevard is AWESOME!

I took my girlfriend here for her birthday. She absolutely loved it. It was awhile ago so I don't remember specific descriptions of what we ordered, but everything was cooked to perfection. 

From what my fuzzy memory can recall:
Appetizers:
Scallops- Cooked perfectly, but overall was not knock your socks of good.
Tuna Tartare- My GF was in a foodgasm. Enough said.

Entrees:
Steak- GREAAAATTT. I LOVE when a place makes good steak. When I say love I really mean it.
Fish?? the steak was so delicious I forgot what fish dish my girl ordered. I just remember she said it was delightful.

Dessert:
Key Lime pie- Lovely end to the meal

The place can get a little crowded and loud, but the service was top notch. Try to get the seat with the view of the bridge. Those looked nice. Also, I told them it was her birthday and the dessert came out with a nice candle on it. That was a nice touch that I actually didn't expect. 

This place won me major points from my GF so major props to Boulevard. Thank you!
author: Jack C.

description:
Phenomenal. My girlfriend and I came here for lunch awhile back on vacation and almost went back for dinner it was so good. We started with a dungeness  crab salad and calamari which were both super delicious. The calamari was almost whole and was stuffed with some chopped seasoning I believe. They were both delicious.  

For our main lunch course we had the fish of the day, whose name escapes me but was delicious.

Dessert was a chocolate tart and a bon bon ( amazing).

Our server was a middle aged gentleman with a beard, it's been a few months but I believe he may have had salt and pepper hair, not sure, but either way he was fantastic. Super friendly, coursed everything out for us  and was very helpful with any questions we had. 

Great food and great service from the hostess to the cooks to the bussers. 

I will be back next time I'm in town.
author: Chris W.

description:
ZOMFGS. 

Just thinking about this place makes me all warm and fuzzy inside. And full. And gluttonous. And super hungry. I'm so conflicted. I should have had lunch today. Sweet Jesus. Gaaaahhhhhh. Oh god, it is precious to me. 

I know it's not the *best* restaurant in the world, but I'll be god damned if it's not pretty high up there. Everything is perfection. It's true, the menu can get a little humdrum -- I'm sure if I check their current offerings, I'll find some sort of braised short rib, some sort of grilled filet, and some sort of Sonoma chicken. In this topsy turvy world, isn't it nice to have something you can always count on? 

The wine list is superb, from a Flowers Chardonnay to a Ridge Montebello. They have a great selection of Italian reds. I like a wine list with chapters, thanks. I like wine. 

It's not the edgiest place in town, but the decor is lovely -- and you can't beat the awesome view. Well, unless you're at the Slanted Door. If you go later in the night, you'll likely find a more jovial and less stuffy clientele. And me. Drunk. And full. And possibly singing a Barry White love song to the kitchen staff. Before I am escorted off the premises.
author: Sasha T.

description: It's not like Boulevard needs another great review, but this really was one of the most pleasant and delicious meals I have had.  The best part was that our server was so incredibly nice with just the perfect amount of interaction to be helpful and provide great service without being intrusive.  The lobster ravioli were certainly good enough on their own before taking a sip of Gewurztraminer between bites skyrocketed the flavor pairing to dreamy.  A lamb t-bone chop couldn't be more perfectly prepared.  Heavenly, just heavenly.  This is peaceful fine dining with elegance.
author: Dave T.

description: Can I write a review for a place I only had leftovers at? Of course. I had some of their steak and raviolli's and they were amazing! I will be sure to update my review when I go for real. Chalk this up as my funny review,
author: Michael C.

description:
An AMAZING Dining Experience...

I went with a party of four on a Thursday night at 7:30. It was quite busy but we were fortunate to get a table in the back. Everything we ordered was perfection...

It is a pretty expensive dinner. With four of us and a bottle of wine, with a few cocktails, coffees and appetizers and desserts, it was over $400.00. But with that being said, it was worth it, especially for a special occasion. The location of the restaurant is great too if you would like to take a walk after dinner or hop of the train to get home.

SERVICE:
Excellent. Our server was very nice and accommodating but didn't make us feel rushed at all. In fact we were there for almost two hours.

FOOD:
Excellent. We ordered the Suckling Pig, Duet of Angus Short Ribs and the Local Petrale Sole. All were equally delicious. They have a great variety.
Dessert was also excellent. We ordered the Tainori Valrhona Warm Fudge Cake and the Huckleberries and Meyer Lemon.
author: Christine S.

description:
2008; 1 Michelin star

If you're in the mood for a fancy-shhhmancy dinner, this is the place to go. My bf took me here for my b-day and it was a really nice, sit down place but I felt out of place since I think we were the only "young" ones dining. The clientele seemed older and affluent.

My bf got the Prime Rib Pork Chop which was dry and I got the Alaskan Halibut which was much better. Pricing is about $35 per plate and service was tip top. From outside you can get a view of the Bay Bridge.

A nice place to come back for a special occasion.
author: Janel Y.

description:
I had such an outstanding experience here!

Following a very traumatic (unrelated) experience, we arrived for our reservation over an hour early to ask if by chance they would be willing/able to seat us early (fully expecting they wouldn't be able to) and not only were they able to, but they were so friendly and accommodating. This was supposed to be a celebratory dinner and they went out of their way to help us smooth out our evening and enjoy ourselves.

As a self proclaimed foodie, my only wish is that I could have really been in the moment to enjoy their carefully crafted cuisine (yes! alliteration!) as it was intended to be enjoyed. All of the dishes on our table were designed with precision to stimulate all the senses. Everything was beautifully and thoughtfully prepared and delicious.

Despite my dismal mood, I really enjoyed this meal. The food was fabulous, the service was fabulous, and not only would I recommend Boulevard to others, but I would absolutely return.
author: kelly f.

description:
I discovered Boulevard while I was researching James Beard Nominated restaurants.  Not only was it nominated but I read many great reviews.  This place is quite popular, we weren't able to get a reservation before 10 pm.  Boulevard is dressy but not formal.  The kitchen is open concept, so you can watch the chefs make your meal right in front of you.  We had just gone on a wine tour so weren't really interested in alcohol.  I applaud them for having a non alcoholic drink menu.  We had their peach and strawberry lemonade and it was refreshing without being too tart.  For our mains, I had the CALIFORNIA SQUAB &TOLENAS FARMS QUAIL PAN ROASTED WITH GARLIC & THYME with Wild Rice & Farro with Seared Foie Gras & Caramelized Shallots Knoll Farm Brown Turkey Fig with a Salad of Red Walnuts, Dry Mission Fig & Pink Pearl Apples Roasted Squab Jus for $33.50.  It is hard when you have a duo because you are always going to like one better than the other.  I have never tried squab, and i liked it better than the quail.  It had a nice crust and was still slightly pink.  The figs were a nice accompaniment to the meat.  My sis had the LAMB T-BONE, WOOD OVEN ROASTED ON THE BONE WITH ROSEMARY, THYME, MINT & GARLIC SERVED OFF THE BONE with buttered greens, and potato stuffed zucchini flower for $34.  The lamb was juicy and cooked perfectly.  She loved the slight bitterness of the buttery greens which worked so well with the lamb.  It was a  well thought out dish.
If we just had our entrées, i would have given BLVD a 5.  However it took forever for our plates to get cleared off our table.  We also waited at least ten minutes to get a dessert menu.  Usually in a fine dining restaurant, everything is so well timed, it wasn't here.  
We had watched the pastry chef push out beautiful desserts all night but we opted for a cheese plate instead.  Each cheese you select is $7 and it is served with "SEASONAL FRUIT and OLIVE OIL ROASTED ALMONDS & BAGUETTE".  We chose a blue and a goats cheese.  Not joking it came with a rock hard baguette that was slightly scored into four slices,and a handful of almonds.  Now for the Seasonal Fruit, 1 cherry cut in half, 1 date cute in half, 1/2 teaspoon of honeycomb, and a little bit of lemon marmalade.  We went in the middle of summer when there was a bounty of fresh fruit and we were served this pittance.  It looked pretty, but the food costs was probably $2.  Overall the food was great but the service and the dessert totally brought the meal down.
author: Amy D.

description: My boyfriend and I frequent Boulevard daily for lunch in San Fran when visiting. It is hands down my favorite place for lunch in such a great culinary capital. If they have it, I recommend the ink squid pasta with rock shrimp stuffed calamari. To die for! Also, do not, I repeat DO NOT, forget desert at this restaurant!! It is worth the extra miles at the gym. Why is Boulevard my favorite? Because they are consistently exceptional!! Every single time they knock my taste buds out of the park. This restaurant is as near to perfect as it gets. I am  always in a good mood after I eat there!
author: Nina B.

description:
i must have went without ANY expectations because the 3 appetizers we ordered were all pretty darn good. this was our #2 stop in finding our company holiday party venue. we were on a time limit and had about 20 min to be in and out of there so only had time to order these appetizers:

-TUNA TARTARE was rather good - i never order this so i'm not sure what to compare it to but the tuna tasted fresh and the touch of homemade chips on top was fab! 

-LOBSTER BISQUE was okay, not the best i've had (was a bit too fishy).

-DUNGENESS CRAB CAKE was EXCELLENT! sorry for my lack of descriptive adjectives but man, this and the one i had at nero's in vegas were by far the best i've ever had. the 3 of us rated the crab cakes as the best appetizer yet.

-we washed this all down with our CHERRY-WHITE PEACH LEMONADE....DOUBLE YUM! their lemonade flavor changes daily.

this place had their own unique charm about it. somehow i could tell that their food is consistently good and i didn't feel stuffy as others mentioned. they have a downstairs private dining that can fit up to 40 i believe. dim and cozy, a great possibility for our party. our eat and run tactic got us out of there before our meter ran out! looking forward to trying dinner here.
author: Jane Y.

description:
This is my all-time fave SF restaurant.  They will always have a soft spot in my heart for the many birthdays I celebrated there with my fam...starting at age 12.  My pops chose the place this year for my bday.  I was totally stoked about the yummy treat to Boulevard on dad...and then...of course....I got sick!

I missed my own Boulevard bday dinner...but the great peeps went in my honor!  I wonder if the server sang to them.  I am in need of some Boulevard soon...hmmm.
author: debbie h.

description:
You really can't go wrong with Boulevard. I've been going there since the last 90's.

As long as you don't get all hyped up! 

Everything is solid. The food, the decor, the service. My fav though are the DESSERTS. 

Great place to take your folks, a date, or just celebrate. 

Thumbs up.
author: James M.

description:
I ate at here probably over 5 years ago and I'm so glad I had the opportunity to come back here on Monday night to enjoy another wonderful meal. I came here with a group of 8 and we dined in a private "wine cellar" room. The room was intimate with a brick wall filled with wine on one side and the other walls were mirrors. I really loved our room.

I started with a light blossom peach and goat cheese salad with champagne grapes and spicy pecans. The peaches were ripe and sweet and the thick slices of goat cheese were rich and smooth. I really enjoyed the spiced pecans, they were so crunchy and delicious. For my entree, I had the wild halibut with sauce prepared with dungeness crab meat, jalapeno corn and beans. The fish was wonderful and the sauce was just amazing. I loved the crab meat and the rich, creamy sauce. Although the prices here are definitely a splurge, the portions are quite large. 

The dessert selection looked fantastic, but we were so full from our two courses, we couldn't even bare to eat anymore. I would definitely recommend coming here for a special evening.
author: Denise L.

description:
We came here for Mother's Day, on Friday. Me, my two sisters and my Mom. 

We got there a few minutes before seating and decided on a few drinks, Mom & I each had a Lemon Drop and it was great. Little sister had a Roy Rogers and Mallory had a 7-Up that was a tad flat but that's ok. 

We get seated and our waiter is very friendly and personable, Ethan Allen! HAHA Just Ethan, but he was a great sport! 

We ordered 2 appetizers, the artichoke ravioli and the stuffed calamari! Both were to die for! Even the legs of the calamari were great!

We all ordered dinner, I had the halibut talk about melt in your mouth yummy! Mom had the Lula fish (I know thats not what its called, it was Hawaiian) Then we convinced my sister who just recently started eating chicken again, after like 8 years that the lamb was white meat! The little one ordered the crab salad. Everything was so good, like so good Mom suggested desert! 

We each ordered something different, I had the banana tiramisu, Mallory the chocolate cake, and the little one got Peanut Butter something cake! Mom, got a tasting and I am sure everything was equally as good! Mine was so good, I really didn't want to share!!!

Over all our experience was amazing, the service even better, and I swear I am coming back!!! Saving my penny's for a trip to BLVD!!!!
author: Angela B.

description:
I have been excited to try this since I drove by it last year on vacation. It was also referred to me by several wineries in the valley. 

I now have mixed feelings about it.

The atmosphere...spot on. Beautiful inside and out. Great menu, great hostess staff, great wine list. Scratch that. AMAZING wine list.

We sat down and waited a bit for for our server to come over. I asked for him to send the sommelier over to help with the wine list. 

It took 20 minutes for the sommelier to come over. I was appalled! When he FINALLY made it over he barely even cared it took so long. We were ordering a $150 bottle of wine and were treated as if we were ordering a 6 pack of beer. I asked about a few bottles and I didn't get more than oh its good, ya good, that is good too.

I was nearly to the point of saying forget it, I am not drinking. 

The problem is...this really set the dinner on a low note. My husband wasn't happy after and it was hard to turn the mood around. When the sommelier came with our $150 bottle of wine...we tried to lighten the mood a bit by joking around and he wouldn't have it. He was unfriendly and uninterested.

I will say our server was a nice guy. We had a great meal.....and good wine.

Just hard to get over trying to order $150 bottle of wine from the sommelier and being treated like riffraff.
author: Cameron S.

description: Hands down the best restaurant in San Francisco. Amazing food, impeccable service, wonderful ambiance. Anyone who post any less than 5 stars for restaurant has no idea what they are talking about, or is nit-picking some minor bullshit detail that happened to them one time.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Again, another place that doesn't need another review... I go to Boulevard's for work lunches when I want to treat someone without hurting the expense account.

Considering the quality and presentation of the meals I believe the prices are reasonable. Service and ambiance are accommodating... my only concern are their hard wood floors: they look beautiful but are you buffing those suckers every day?? Try walking on 3 inch heels along those slippery floors... frightening I tell you. But I keep coming back!
author: Nenette Y.

description:
I have been here twice now, both times for work. But, the restaurant is so enjoyable that it always ends up feeling less like work and more like pleasure! 

I highly recommend the lemonade, specifically the special one that changes pretty often. The last time I was there it was a red currant passion fruit lemonade- yum! The bread that they serve is nothing fancy, but it's nice to munch on while you sip the lemonade.

The pear gorgonzola salad has an oatmeal cookie-like thing crumbled on top of it, which definitely made the entire dish worthwhile. The ahi tuna tartare is prepared extremely well, and the accompanying chips and avocado are very tasty.

The pork tenderloin is very good, though it doesn't have as much of a "special" factor as some of the other dishes do. Next time I go I'd like to try the kobe bavette. 

I wasn't as impressed by the chocolate desserts as I was by the caramel ones. The caramel/pear dessert came with an amazing cake that would taste good off of a car bumper. 

Expect to spend a good amount of money (and time!) when you eat here, but it is definitely worth it!
author: lindsay w.

description:
I've eaten here several times, and I've never been particularly impressed.  The view of the bay bridge is of course exceptional, but for a restaurant known to be one of the best in San Francisco, the food is a big huge disappointment.

it's just nothing I couldn't get at just about any "good" restaurant in the city, at best.  I'd much rather explore great food in one of the many, many great little trendy restaurants in the Mission than keep going to Boulevard hoping they'd live up to their reputation, only to be disappointed, yet again.
author: Jenny S.

description:
I have been hearing about this place from some friends for quite some time and finally went for one of thier birthdays and the place was pretty good.  Rather pricy but the food does the talking here.

The service here at least this time around was decent but could have been better. My friends told me this probably the worst service they had to date but in no way was it bad. Which has to say that service here normally is top notch.

Some notable moments of the serivce were when we pulled out a bottle of wine we had brought with us a nice Cabernet I beleieve that deserves a fully bodied wine glass was provided without even asking.  The waiter remove the standard house wine glasses in favor for some the perfect glass to enjoy some fine vino. 

WE then looked through the menu and picked out soem appetizer before our meal We went with some scalops that were seared to perfection and melted in your mouth. Some crab cakes were also chosn that were equally as delicious although I am more partial to the scallops especially when they are cooked to perfection.

After appetizers and a few glasses of wine we move onto dinner and as i WAS TOLD BEFORE WE CAME. One if not the best Filet Mignon you will ever eat.  I am not sure If it is the best but right now it is the best that I can remember it was eveyrthing and more that my friends had described it. Utterly delicious. I will return to this Boulevard just to have that filet mmmmmm my mouth is wattering just remembering the perfectly cooked piece of meat as my mouth watering bites finished my meal before I knew it was done.  I tried to savor every bite but it was too good to let it sit and wait. I enjoyed it.

Dessert was really good I do not remember what we had as this was last month but it was good, we all chose different desserts and samples each others choices and every bite was as good as the meal. Top Notch pastry chefs at The Boulevard.

My only REAL gribe is after having a fine meal sometime you need to use the restroom. The Boulevard is an upscale eatery that has been in San Francisco for some time but to use the bathroom at The Boulevard you have to leave the restraunt go down the stairs or the elevator of the same building and then enter a note so nice bathroom that does not equal the tasty treats upstairs.  I am unsure if the restraunt takes care of the bathroom or if it is shared with other units as it was so so on the upscale feeel of the rest.  A restraunt can be great but the quality of the bathroom seals the deal, which is the only reason why this time around The Boulevard recieves only 4 Stars even with the okay service this place is a MUST!!!!
author: Robert S.

description: It's been a while since we dined here and now I can't remember why we have not returned sooner. Maybe it's because SF churns out great restaurants by the bushel.  We were staying at the Hotel Vitale across the street and that made it so much easier to have a great meal and just literally roll back to the room. Everything was wonderful with pork chop taking top billing. This has always been a house specialty and, if anything, has gotten better. The wine selection is excellent but the markup is steep-bring your own.
author: Alan B.

description:
This has been on my list for ages! So I was pretty excited when my boss and fellow co workers to me out for lunch! 

The lunch prices are very reasonable: which was very surprising $15-22 for entree. I've honestly spent more for lunch at Perry's down the street. 

1. Food-smaller portions, but the taste of the food was amazing. I would recommend the Crab BLT-it looked so small, but was a great portion size in the end and the bread was to die for, nice and fluffy. Crab meat with the avocado was just perfect! 

I would also recommend a side of fries, which may have been the perfect french fries I've ever had. Crunchy on the outside, and creamy smooth on the inside, not over salted. I would have to say these beat out MacDonald's :( (I apologize if its uncouth to compare Boulevards to MacDonald's :) 

2. Service was slow, maybe its the atmosphere of the restaurant, to enjoy your food, but I had to ask for water and the check. It even took awhile to get some items boxed up to go. 

Overall experience was great, I can imagine how nice this would be for a romantic dinner! So I'm hoping my next review will be for the dinner menu :)
author: Olivia W.

description: Lobster. Filet. Old Fashion's. Excellent service.  Fun Fun Times.  Every time.
author: C P.

description:
Pros: The filet was great, the whole meal came together nicely.  Huge wine list, which was nice.  My girlfriend had the lamb, she loved that as well.

Cons:Place was packed and they sat us 15-20 mins past our 9:15 res and we were on time.  Expensive.

All in all great restaurant.
author: Rich S.

description:
Impressed - yes, to say the least!  Everything and everyone, from the tuna tartar to the sommelier was excellent.  Boulevard came highly recommended, and I would be doing a disservice to the Yelping community by not passing on what an absolute privilege it was to dine at Boulevard.

I will be back soon Boulevard, until then, I will try not to miss you too much...
author: Munir S.

description: Amazing food, amazing service, amazing drinks. It is difficult to get reservations here. It is very expensive however you get what you pay for. One of the best restaurants I have been to. Everything was perfected. It is definitely worth a trip but expect to pay quite a bit.
author: Zachary J.

description: I wrote a review in February, but it has mysteriously been removed.  I write again to warn vegetarians that this is not the place for you.
author: Emily C.

description:
Good stuff.  Expensive as all hell, but good stuff.  I brought my gal over here last year for our 1-year and had ourselves quite the meal.  I recommend the lobster risotto.  One word of warning though, if you're looking to get dinner you ought to make reservations well in advance.  Especially for weekends.  I'm not talking days or weeks; I'm talking months.  I mean, yeah, sure you can just stroll right in and hope to get a table.  Hell, when we went, there was a couple with no reservation that got a table before us, but that was purely out of luck because the waiter for some reason thought they were us (the ones with the real reservation).  So don't count on it.

Once you're in though, expect to eat well and spend plenty.
author: Igor N.

description:
It's been about a year since I've eaten here, but this is by far one of my favorite SF restaurants (even better than Gary Danko). The ambiance is great- its pretty intimate and romantic. 

Honestly, I dont recall what I ate haha. BUT i do remember I had a crab salad and my bf had the Kobe beef appetizers. DE-LICIOUS! The waiters there are very polite and respectful. 

Def. highly recommend :)
author: lauren j.

description:
2008 Michelin Rating: One Star

Heard so much about this restaurant and finally I had the chance to try out their lunch menu.  We ordered the soup du jour lobster bisque and the Wood Oven Roasted Snakeriver Farms Kobe Bavette and the Seared Maine Day boat sea scallops as our main entrees.  The quality of food was absolutely fresh and delicious, no complain about that but for the price of the food, the dish portion were indeed very small.

The restaurant has a very nice art deco decor but it is certainly wearing out and showing of its age.  

3 stars for the food quality and decor but no stars for the tiny dish portion and run down appearance.  Will I go back for their dinner menu? probably not.  Surely there are better restaurants out there that's worth spending your money. 

I am glad I only went there for lunch.
author: Shirley H.

description:
For some time now I've suspected that I'm spoiled, and I finally became convinced last night.

I have wanted to try this place for over a year now and came here last night for a business dinner with 13 other men.  We were seated in the wine cellar cave.  Although the restaurant is a lot bigger and not as 'poshly decorated' as I expected, it is very nice and warm.

I had the seared day boat scallops which came with grits and bits of ham.  Needless to say, the scallops were cooked perfectly - brown on the outside and very tender on the inside.

For main entree, I had the Alaskan black sea bass.  It came with peas, green beans with "prawn salad" on the top.  The prawn salad is really prawns which have been sliced in half but it is slightly fishy.  the sea bass was nicely roasted and flaky.

I skipped dessert because I have been eating well lately and feeling lardy.

So why did I say last night convinced me I am truly spoiled?  Well, the food at Boulevard was cooked perfectly but didn't totally blow my mind.  There's been places that I have been to lately where the food was cooked perfectly but the chef either paired it with something very different or had an unexpected but interesting taste.  

So that's why I said I'm spoiled.  I now expect food at these places to be perfect and look for new presentations, new taste, new pairings to really impress me.
author: Yuan W.

description:
Maybe my expectations were too high, but Boulevard was not impressive.  Don't get me wrong, Boulevard is a really nice restaurant, but it just feels like something was missing.  Comparing it to other places in its category, the food was decent and the atmosphere more relaxed.  The wait staff were superb.  But nothing wowed me.  

The biggest disappointment was that we did not get any compliments from the chef *sniff*.  Space wise, it is one of the larger ones, but the tables were a bit too close together.  It was quite noisy.  I like the people at Boulevard because it's not the usual stuffy crowd.  My biggest disappointment were the crab cakes, I heard GREAT THINGS about it, but they were not serving it the night we went.   I recommend this place for the experience.  However, for the amount, there are other places that are much more worth it!
author: Carrie-C N.

description: My friend and I stumbled upon this restaurant as we were walking to the more touristy Embarcadaro restaurants.  Boy, were we excited we found Boulevard.  The place was full but we were seated at the chefs counter and were able to watch the chefs prepare the food - better than having a table as far as we were concerned!  We loved the ravioli and scallop appetizers - wanted seconds.  The swordfish was cooked to perfection and fingerling potatoes were so tasty.  We wished it wasn't our last night in San Francisco because we would have liked to have gone again and try the some of the other menu items.  Ahhmazing!!!
author: Heather R.

description:
how did this place get a michelin star? food was barely warm, quail was unevenly cooked (overcooked part tasted like chicken, correctly cooked part tasted like duck) and lamb, ordered medium rare, was overcooked.

we had abalone and black gnocchi with octopus as starters. portions were small and food was barely warm. the abalone tasted like it had been fried in butter (why??) and the deep fried thing (mushroom? sunchoke?) was greasy. the overall impression was greasy and this is the first time I didn't enjoy abalone (it tasted fishy).

my husband complained that the flavours in his black gnocchi/octopus/deep-fried calamari in tomato sauce didn't blend but i thought it was way better than my dish. the gnocchi and the octopus were good but the fried calamari was the culprit. it doesn't work with the dish. at. all. especially as, again, it was greasy and too salty.

i've never had quail before but my husband had enjoyed his at another 1-michelin star restaurant and had been dying for me to try it. i'd asked him if it was supposed to taste like chicken and he'd said no. after that, i let him try the overcooked ("chicken") and less cooked ("duck") portions and he said it wasn't supposed to taste like that. it had not been cooked well. the dish was also a mess: there was roasted hazelnuts, apriums (i think), dried apricots, prosciutto, cooked spinach, mashed potatoes and quail. sadly, the best part was the mashed potatoes. i don't know how this dish could ever have worked. the apriums were flavourful but too tart and didn't go with anything else on the plate. the hazelnuts were too strong tasting and again didn't go with the rest. the dried apricots were still dry and were tart as well. the prosciutto was over the top and unnecessary. btw, the waiter didn't ask me how i wanted the quail done so i guess the uneven overdoneness was their standard.

my husband ate his lamb and my quail and was scowling so hard the waiter came to see if everything was ok. my husband felt the lamb was overcooked even though he had ordered medium rare but he thought that maybe the edges were more overcooked so he decided to try the inner pieces before he made any comment. unfortunately, even though the meat looked pink, it was dry and tasteless. he then waited for the waiter to come back but it took some time and he had to ask another waiter/busboy for our server.

he asked if it was medium rare and the server said that was the order. he offered to bring another one or a substitution and my husband opted for another round of the same. luckily, this time it came perfectly medium rare and hot.

as the main dishes had been disastrous, we decided to skip dessert. my husband had wanted an espresso but i told him that if the food was not served hot, the espresso would be the same and cold espresso is a disaster. we then paid and left.

the saddest part is that it was our 9th anniversary and we had wanted to celebrate. my husband felt bad as he had chosen the restaurant but i told him the experience was so bad it was funny. i might have complained too loudly and if i spoiled our dining neighbours' meals, i'm sorry.

i asked a server and he said the chef was not in tonight. well, from what i understand, the chef cannot always be in the restaurant and even if she were not around, the sous chef should have kept things running smoothly. maybe the sous chef should be reeducated. serving overcooked, greasy, salty, cold food is not acceptable.

ps: the whole restaurant was a mess tonight from the hostess to the wait staff to the kitchen.
author: pj n.

description: We live nearby & have eaten here several times. I waited to review, to ensure consistancy vs responding to the JB award hype of last summer. I am hear to say, this place is rock solid dining! The best place to sit, if there are just 2 of you, is at the Chefs bar. I love watching them work & seeing all the tasty meals going out to the floor. The appetizers are fantastic & the entrees, although steep, are of great quality & presentation. The service was outstanding too. Always well-paced and aware of when our group of 6 needed anything. My only 'complaint' is the upcharging of the wine list prices. Its absurd here. Its very common very restaurants to upcharge a bottle you can buy on the shelf by $20-$30 but I saw bottles that were doubled! My recommendation? Bring a bottle or Magnum yourself & pay the corkage fee. Otherwise, great place to bring friends or family while visiting SF. Make sure to call 6 weeks ahead for parties of 6, as they only seat a few groups of that size per night.
author: Jen S.

description: Service was great, although it did take a bit long for us to get our food. For appetizer I had the soft shell crab and  my boyfriend had the scallops. The scallops came highly recommended, but they were a little on the salty side. The crab was great! I had the pork and it was sooo good, especially the side. My bf had the Fillet & he liked it! For dessert we had a chocolate mini cake with ice cream. Very dense, but soooo yummy!  Highly recommend trying it when in San Fran!!
author: Tania S.

description: We were recommended this restaurant and without too much thought we made a reservation for the 2nd day of our trip to SF. I discovered it was located right on the water with a view. I immediately became concerned that it would be just like all of the other restaurants "with a view" and have mostly tourists and overpriced-mediocre food. As it was a beautiful night and we wanted to see the Bay Bridge lights anyway, we decided to give it a shot - boy were we glad we did! The restaurant is  beautiful old world french decor. It is spacious with a stunning view in the back of the restaurant of the bay bridge. Mostly large groups back there, but there are a few tables for 2 further back in the restaurant that have a view. The space and feel is elegant without being stuffy - the perfect place for a date. We started out with a few cocktails which were good, but not mind blowing. For food I started with the dungeness crab. It was incredible. The crab melted in your mouth and the flavors worked so well together. For my entree I had the grilled swordfish. The portion is huge! It was grilled to perfection. The citrus flavors from the meyer lemon really came through. The risotto was also delicious, a nice balance to the rest of the dish. Service the entire time was friendly but unobtrusive. I really had a great experience here and was pleasantly surprised that a restaurant with this great of a view and atmosphere can deliver on all levels with their food. It is alittle pricey, but worth it- especially for a special occasion. Also, the building has a bit of history which is really interesting. If you are into that sort of thing, check it out for sure.
author: Joseph F.

description: Walked over for an after-dinner late night dessert paired with a delicious port. The chocolate macaron with roasted white chocolate is sinful. Finished the night with Weavers coffee. Luv Weavers. FYI: the crowd is, ahem, a more "mature" and conservative crowd. Most diners had a good 20-30 years on us.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Eating on the company dime is always a good thing. 2 lemon drops and a glass of wine later, we finally ordered. 

Thank god they had seared foie gras rather than your typical foie gras pate, but the mushroom bisque with GNOCCHI really caught my eye. Turns out there are 3 pan-fried gnocchi at the bottom of the bowl with creme fraiche, and the waiter pours the ever so smooth and fragrant bisque into the bowl so the gnocchi stays firm. OUT OF THIS WORLD.  Must order again!

I was apprehensive in ordering the pork chop even though the sides sound so good for it- stuffing and mushrooms. 

Waiter: "You know the owner is MRS. AIDELL.."
Me: "What? Like the sausage guy's wife??"
Waiter:" Yes! So you know anything pork-related will be really good.. just sayin."

He did not recommend wrong- the chop was so juicy and tender. And thick! How do they do it?! Another highlight of our dinner was the filet mignon which was ridiculously tender, something I can never achieve on my own. Also, if you're looking to order the halibut, make sure you know that it's served in paella form! Menu doesn't say this, and our waiter had to tell us.

Food and service were top-notch, but ambiance is.. loud. Really loud. I wouldn't call this a romantic restaurant, but a bunch of friends getting together.. definitely my recommendation.
author: Natalie Y.

description: Please don't waste your money. James Beard Award or no, this place isn't worth it. I give it one star for the atmosphere and the wine list. The salad with figs, prosciutto and candied pecans was the best offering of the evening, and the risotto appetizer was also quite good, though ridiculously small. Our dinners arrived lukewarm and were pretty awful, especially the accompaniments that came with each dish. The corn served alongside the salmon tasted freezer-burned! Desserts were fine. Service was slow, but professional. The tab was offensive, given the mediocrity of the meal. Would never go back.
author: Kelli K.

description: I've been here for dinner on three occasions and their consistency with providing a fabulous overall dining experience is refreshing! So many times I enjoy my first visit to a business enough to go back- only to be disappointed. The food, service and ambiance are all absolutely fabulous- every time! Boulevard is consistently getting it done and I will go back again and again!
author: Jen G.

description:
Outstanding.  I was afraid that this would be another long-standing SF restaurant just resting on its laurels (like Aqua--yeech!), but how wrong I was.  Great food, wine list, service and ambiance.  

Yes, the appetizers are expensive, upwards of $20 (think abalone), but when you're willing to pay 30 bucks for an entree, why the sudden pocket pinching?  

The portions sizes are perfect.  In this world of super-sized meals, I was so happy to actually finish a meal and not feel like I was about to explode (or have to take home a doggie bag consisting of some sad-assed 1/8th-sized plate portion which I'll just end up throwing out in a week).  I felt completely satisfied at the end of the meal.
