For appetizers we had the special abalone appetizer and the beet salad.  For entrees we ate the butterfish with stuffed, grilled calamari.  I'd never had butterfish before, and I'm regretting every moment I've lived not knowing about this fish.  Wonderful, sweet texture and taste.
For dessert we split the angel food cake served with sliced nectarines and diced peaches, accompanied by a wonderful ginger ice cream and I believe a nectarine sorbet.   A great finish to the meal.  

I would definitely come back.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
My office is within walking distance of Boulevard and I have been fortunate to enjoy numerous lunches and dinners there.  I think, in terms of decor, it is one of Pat Kuletos better efforts. There are three distinct areas within the restaurant, all of which I find appealing.

The food Nancy Oakes puts out is consistently good, if a bit conventional. In  this era of celebrity chefs,unlike her contemporaries, Ms. Oakes sticks to the cooking.  The kitchen benfits from not being subject to an absentee head chef.
author: Steve S.

description: Food was fine, service was good, but that was it - certainly not memorable. Everyone talked this place up, but maybe I missed something. Sadly I'm disappointed. In NYC this place would be lost in the noise. Again, nothing wrong with the food, just didn't have the flavors to be great. Unfortunately I won't return.
author: N. M.

description:
I'm a salmon junkie and I order salmon on almost every restaurant I've been to.

DO NOT ORDER SALMON HERE. 

I literally just threw up the salmon I had for dinner tonight.
author: CC P.

description: Have been here several times:  Service and food are outstanding - exceptional ingredients and preparation.  Not faddish.  Service has been really great, recommend very highy.  A bit pricey, butb still good value.
author: Glenn S.

description: Daaaaaa-yum!  Nancy, If I were 20 years older I'd marry you and be your man-servant. Dad and his O.G. crew, and me came for lunch. 5 bottles of wine, 5 courses.... Wow, my taste-buds were fucking break-dancing! It's quite the fantastic feeling.
author: Mark B.

description: Really good food but service was a bit off. 4 stars deserved for outstanding presentation.
author: David M.

description:
until returning for dinner last night my memories of boulevard were kinda stodgy - the sort of safe choice for taking the parents out to an upscale lunch or dinner but not a place to be wow'ed. Geez, i was wrong. From the inventive cocktail menu to the tasty eats, it served as a great venue to gather a group of friends.

Service was attentive without being cloying. We ended up waiting an add'l 30m for a table past our reservation time and the server apologized and brought us an extra dessert.
author: hunter w.

description: (Preliminary review because I haven't had the food yet). A glass of Riesling plus atmosphere... wow, this place is gorgeous!
author: Maximillian M.

description: We had dinner one evening on our trip. It was walkable from where we were staying and heard really good things. The atmosphere may be a little stuffy for my taste and it could have a little better beer selection but the food was amazing. Tuna tartare as an app, lamb chop, filet, beet salad all outstanding. The desserts were good, but not entree good.
author: Kurt D.

description:
I have been to Boulevard twice.  Once for a dinner in a group of nine (our bill was over $1000) and once just for dessert.  Generally, it is a bit pricey, but well worth it if you're going there for a special occasion or just to enjoy some excellent French-infludenced American cuisine.

Our meal was superb.  The service was not bad, but it wasn't incredible either.  It's been a while since I went there, but the one thing I can't seem to forget is how incredibly juicy the Foie Gras was.  I can't remember what I had for an entree, so either it wasn't that incredible or it just goes to show how amazing the Foie Gras was.  And the other unforgettable part of the meal was the smooth, creamy, unbelievably rich and tasty scharffen berger chocolate pudding, which to this day, still tickles me delightfully.
author: Natalie T.

description:
I had one very expensive piece of ravioli (out of three served on a gigantic plate). Strange why they would serve it in such a large plate considering it made the 3 pieces of ravioli appear even smaller. 

But if you are as desperate as we were for food, there is no better place to go. Just keep the wine flowing.....
author: Tu R.

description:
Due to my intense traveling for work (and the fact that my company was going to pay for it), I decided to take my girlfriend out to Boulevard for a nice dinner.  And it was such a nice dinner all around.  Had clam chowder soup for an appetizer and steak for dinner.  My girlfriend got the salad and fish.  Great food and service!

But let's talk about the important part...dessert.  I got the ice cream sandwiches and even though it was $10, they were the best ice cream sandwiches ever!  It was like heaven in an ice cream sando...who knew?  

Be prepared for a good 2 hour meal.  Get reservations way in advance, but if you do get it last minute, you will be eating at like 10 at night.

Can't wait to go back there again.
author: Dan D.

description:
Every dish was solid, perfectly cooked new American fare.  My two companions and I each had three courses, so I tried nine dishes in all, not a single one of which was the least bit original or inspired.  Everything was something that would have been really interesting and fresh on a 1998 menu, but it all seems pretty tired and standard now.  Aside from occasionally having access to some ingredients that home cooks are not likely to find (or to afford, at least not on the regular) it was mostly stuff that one could cook at home, if one had the time.  It was extremely loud and crowded, and our server was exactly the sort of old, white man that you'd have expected to find serving you at some upscale steak restaurant in the 1980's.

Nevertheless, as I said, every dish was perfectly cooked, and it was, overall, a great meal.  It just wasn't interesting enough to justify the prices, the accolades, or the (evident) pride and self-satisfaction they have.

We ate here one week after eating at Cyrus (an absolutely amazing new restaurant in Healdsburg), and Boulevard couldn't even compete.  It was practically like fast food compared to Cyrus.  Whereas we were constantly amazed at Cyrus before we even tasted the food (as well as after), Boulevard underwhelmed us from the moment we looked at the menu (which featured a mere handful of familiar, standard entrees).

This seems like the perfect place for a business lunch that's getting reimbursed, where you want to play it safe and make sure your clients and colleagues can all find something to eat that will be cooked perfectly, but it's certainly not the kind of place you want to go if you're looking to get excited about what you're going to eat.
author: David B.

description:
OK, granted, I got a veggie plate, but, it wasn't that great, really. For a city full of vegetarians (which I am not), you'd think they could get vegetables right.
Wasn't impressed and didn't feel the need to go back.
author: J. T.

description:
Rating is a reflection of price relative to serving size.

Definitely a place to go if you've got money to burn or if dining on an expense account.  Also, if you're hungry you will either leave hungry or broke trying to satisfy the hunger as portions aren't particularly generous.

I'm not saying the food or service was bad but the appetizers ranged in price from $11-20 ea and mains at least double that.  Booth seating was very cozy -- a bit uncomfortable for my petite frame of 5'2" since my feet dangled off the floor the whole meal. I had the soup of the day (lobster bisque with a dash of cream) and the crab BLT sandwich.  Both delicious and artfully presented.

Restaurant atmosphere was nice.  Place was busy but not too loud that you had to strain to hear conversation at the table. Service was very attentive.
author: M G.

description: A perennial favorite - been going here for over 15 years, very consistent quality of food, presentation and service.
author: Michael M.

description: Did a lunch business meeting here and was quite satisfied with the swordfish with maitaki mushrooms and sauteed spinach.  I'd go here for some more lunch meetings but will have to think twice about dinner since it'll run you $30-$35/entree easily.
author: Albie F.

description: This place is AMAZING! Every dish is perfectly cooked and beautiful. The lobster ravioli and the quail is delicious! They change their menu often.
author: Rosa D.

description:
Okay, have eaten here many times but truly have to award another all star status to them for saving me. I had mistakingly reserved the wrong date on opentable--by a full week--so I show ed up with business clients in tow without a table. They seated us without missing a beat.  It was Sunday, so surely that helped, but still they did not have to do it. They place was fully packed when we left so they certainly were not waiting for customers.

Food was, as typical, superb, service excellent, and atmosphere great. I can't thank them enough for their class in assisting  me when they did not have to. It says quite a bit.
author: M B.

description:
Dishes came to the table in much more inventive arrangements than the menu implied.   If you, or others in your group, aren't into that type of creativity the place is going to be a waste of money.  

If my mostly vegetarian girlfriend didn't happen to eat salmon, she wouldn't have had any entree to choose from.  For a place like San Francisco, this is not acceptable, and I think the restaurant would be served well to come up with at least one  vegetarian entree.

A lot of care went into making the dessert and starters very artistically presented.  I thought portions on the starters were quite small considering the price.   I might come back again, but only with other equally adventurous eaters.  Next time, I will leave the steak and potato set at home.
author: Aran J.

description:
Considered to be one of the best restaurants in San Francisco, this "French Brasserie" is a great taste of French cuisine  l'Americaine. The atmosphere is very Art Dco designed by Pat Kuleto...
 
+
View of the Bay Bridge (reserve a table with a view)
Great meat dishes
"Resto chic"
 
-
Disappointing fish dishes
Be ready to smell of food once done, the kitchen is open on the dining area
Service is almost too fast, you don't have time to enjoy your meal  la franaise
 
=
Good food but a bit too expensive. I totally agree "there is better for your money out there."
author: Kjell B.

description:
The quality of food here is by far the best. The food looks as good as it tastes (if not better). Going to fancy restaurants you expect tiny little portions, but the portions here are actually very decent. Remember to save room for dessert because they are very delicious.

This is probably my favorite restaurant in terms of taste alone.
author: Roger C.

description:
Boulevard is just the best overall restaurant in San Francisco. Period. The combination of food, the professional service, and the location and ambiance, make Boulevard the perfect special occasion restaurant.

Having eaten there several times now, I can't say enough about their menu. It's comfortable, formal (yet not quite as stuffy as a Aqua or Gary Danko), and always happening.

Boulevard has enough reviews by people who either love it (like me) or hate it and think it's overpriced, so i won't rant too long as i usually do. It's definitely not cheap, but if i have guests coming to SF and want the "best" San Francisco restaurant experience, I always take them to Boulevard and no one is ever disappointed.

If you want REALLY special occasion type of eating, then go to Gary Danko or Michael Minna or Fifth Floor, but for a guaranteed great experience that has the perfect amount of formal-ness, Boulevard is the place.
author: Don T.

description:
I hadn't been to Boulevard in years and I got the chance to go back for a small corporate function recently. We were in L'Avenue room downstairs for a party of about 30 people. The menu was set and it was the 

MIXED MARKET TOMATOES
Fregola & Parmesan-Feta & Olives-Burrata & Basil
Extra Virgin Olive Oil 14.75

Entree - Choice of:
WASHINGTON KING SALMON
WILD CAUGHT & GRILLED
Lobster Mushrooms, Parsley Garlic Sauce
Creamed Brentwood Corn, Maine Lobster 37

BERKSHIRE PORK TENDERLOIN (KUROBUTA)
WOOD OVEN ROASTED
Slow Roasted Rib, Braised Bacon
Sauteed Spinach, Brown Butter Figs & Almonds, Roasted Pork Jus 30

Dessert (none listed on Boulevard's site) - Choice of:
Brownie something

Rasbperry sorbet sundae-ish thing

The tomatoes starter was good but nothing particularly special for almost $15 bucks. A quarter of a green, red, and orange heirloom tomato with two slices of feta cheese--I wish the organizers had chosen something else.

The wild salmon was cooked well--meaning it was not overly done in the middle. However, someone oversalted parts of the exterior and took away from the dish. The fish was probably about the size of an a medium brownie. The base the fish was sitting on was okay as well. My coworker's fish was overdone and not pinkish inside unfortunately.

We both chose the raspberry thing. This is what the waiter recommended and it was absolutely disgusting. I wish Boulevard had it on their site so I could describe it. The raspberry sorbet was good but the rest was atrociously sweet and with horrible texture. I hope they take it off the menu. I almost considered asking for the other dessert.

Service was above average. I had to ask for my sparkling water to be refilled everytime. They were good about refilling wine and flat water though.

This restaurant seems to get stellar reviews or mediocre reviews and I happen to fall on the side of mediocre and its less acceptable due to the high price. There are so many other restaurants in the city that are better for the same or less money. When the cheapest entree starts at  $30 and goes up from there, the food should be exceptional and nothing should be disgusting and so it is held to a higher standard and thus two stars.

Although I have not been to Michael Mina or Gary Danko--I'll be certain to give either of those a try before I ever go back to Boulevard. 

Verdict: let someone else pay.
author: Zoom Z.

description:
Maybe I'm bucking the trend here...

but I found Boulevard overpriced and oversold.  Yes, the food was "fine", but the portions were pathetically small - if you want presentation, I guess that's what they do well here.

As comparison points, I think that Gary Danko and La Folie are far superior.  I'd also take Jeante at Jack's over it as well.

It does have great service and a great view of the bridge - but its not worth going to on your own dime, and I'd rather do my business lunches elsewhere.
author: Harper B.

description:
Went for the first time to celebrate our 25th wedding anniversary along with our two young adult children.  Hunter the waiter was SUPERB - friendly, attentive, helpful, all without being overbearing or obnoxious.
Food was excellent - wonderful salmon, filet mignon (umami) and lamb.  Truffle risotto appetizer was wonderful as well.  Great wine list too.
We'll be back.
author: Allan H.

description: The food was absolutely tantalizing to my pallet.  The amount of time it took to get my food is another story.  They are definitely an establishment that requires reservations for lunch as they pack up VERY quickly.  The service was very pleasant and accomodating.
author: Misstoo B.

description:
I really like the food at Boulevard, REALLY.  The table service is the best.  And up until my last visit I couldn't even think of anything negative to say about the place, at all.   It was, to me, the perfect dining experience
BUT, always the proverbial but, the last time I went instead of making reservations at 5 or 5:30 as I usually do, the other diners in my party wanted a later reservation and 9 was all that was available.  Ok, 5 or 9 that's fine.
I told the person taking the reservation that 2 in our party of 3 were disabled (I can't stand for more than 10 minutes without being in excruciating pain and my friend is in similar shape) so if we took the 9 could they please, please, PLEASE, note it so we could be seated "somewhat promptly".  "It shouldn't be a problem and I have made a note".  We arrived at 8:50 for our 9 pm reservation and weren't seated till 10pm.    
I wanted to die by 9:15 and thought I was going to pass out but the hostess kept insisting that it would only be a few more minutes.
They couldn't offer me a glass of water? or get chair so I could sit?   They were made aware of the situation both at booking and again upon arrival and could easily have said they would not be able to accommodate our request.   Does one have to have one leg or be in a wheelchair for them to "see" it?  or do you have to file an ADA suit for them to be accommodating?  We both have handicapped placards and the scars to prove that we are disabled, just because we don't "look" disabled doesn't mean we aren't.  It often means we've rested all day just to be there and won't be able to move the day after. 
I can't remember what I ate, I was in too much pain, and the thought of going back makes me shudder.  
No matter how good the food is, you shouldn't have to suffer to dine there.  They easily could have told me it would be impossible to make sure we were seated promptly with a 9pm reservation as I called Boulevard directly, during the day and spoke to a real person and made the situation VERY clear.  I was told it would be noted and wouldn't be a problem.
Bad form, Boulevard.  Very bad form.
author: Moxie H.

description: This is our favorite restaurant, not only because the food is excellent but because it is so consistent. The service and atmosphere are amazing and it is always a special experience. Because it is so wonderful and reliable it is our go to place for special occasions or with out of town guests so my positive experience has been proven repeatedly
author: cheri w.

description:
I have been to Boulevard many times, but this last visit was the worst.  The crab salad apatiezer was tiny, one or two bites and that was it. My steak  was a little tough, but it tasted fantastic. My date's lamb was the best lamb I ever tasted.  But it was the slow service  that  annoyed me the most.  If it was really crowded I wouid have understood, but it really wasn't. It's getting close to tax time, and for places like Boulevard, business goes down. 

I would still recommed Boulevard
author: Nick H.

description:
This place is classy, unique, with good service. Foie Gras here is wonderful.

The only complaint I have is I feel crowded here. Some may call it "intimate" (and it IS) but I prefer a little more space around my table than was offered.
author: Albany A.

description: Great menu and great service. You're gonna pay - but worth it!
author: Peter S.

description:
My favorite formal restaurant in San Francisco.  Whether your lunching or having dinner, Boulevard will delight you with a lovely experience.  A favorite is to start with a lovely Brut Rose, share a Foie Gras starter, and then order the fish special.  My husband always ordered a meat entree so I have the best of both worlds.

A beautiful, sophisticated atmosphere, top notch knowledgable staff, fine wine list and fabulous dishes makes Boulevard a treat for all.
author: M C G.

description: My overall favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Boulevard is always a special experience. The first time I visited this place was in 2005 & I try to make it there about once or twice a year since then. It's so good, I almost remember where I was sitting and at least one dish for each individual visit. The wine and Champagne list is outstanding and their staff is exceptional. The prices are high but not outrageous, quality has it's price. Can't wait to come back.
author: Patrick E.

description: Excellent Meal!  The vibe here is great even at 8;00 on a Wednesday night. Great wine list. Service was knowledgable and attentive
author: Mike E.

description:
I'm updating my review to 5 stars for the AMAZING dinner I had here recently: nom nom nom nom and all that. The lamb was sublime, creme brulee divine, the food was seasonal and for what it was, reasonable! 

I'm reduced to blubbering bad poetry, so great was my meal! Sorry for the flowery flutteriness, but I really LOVE Boulevard and Nancy Oakes. This place is so good that even the harried, unkempt stock broker sitting across from us in his sweat-suit was taken care of in the utmost style by the waitstaff; this place has the right amount of fine-dining class and San Francisco laid-back attitude, and because of this, it's one of my favorite places in the city.

****************************************************************************

Lunch is served!

The service was almost perfect, even though the place was extremely busy. The drinks were great, and everything, from the starters thru dessert, beat my expectations.

-1 star for the somewhat lukewarm pheasant ravioli. Still tasty, but should have been warmer!
author: Susan B.

description:
I'm not a fan of the crappy Yelp review because it does seem too easy, but I must say that my one and only visit to Boulevard was a disappointment from the moment we sat down.  Perhaps it was the waiter, who seemed to be phoning it in.  He wasn't rude, nor was he inattentive - he just seemed robotic and unenthusiastic.  We like to ask the waitstaff what they like, what's best and fresh that night - but our guy gave us the party line and moved on without a smile.  The food seemed 1999 - nothing extraordinary, and we were confused by the pork-with-side of pork ball and fish-with-side-of-fishball entrees.  The smaller items seemed out of place and, honestly, weren't very good.

But, as underwhelming as my experience might have been, it was *nothing* compared to the poor couple next to us.  They were probably in their early 70s, already seated when we sat down, and I  noticed them because I overheard our waiter say to them, loudly and slightly annoyed, "No Sir, a Pinot Gris is a WHITE wine."  As my husband and I were finishing our dessert (and we are slow eaters) I heard the gentleman yell, "Take them away!  We don't want them!"  We looked over to discover that they had been waiting over an *hour* for their entrees, which were just arriving.  We were eating dessert and they were STILL WAITING!  The junior waitress who brought over their entrees was confused, and he explained that he had been asking about his entrees repeatedly, and was at this point waiting for someone to bring his bill so he could leave.

At this point, I felt as if the hostess or manager, or perhaps even his & our original lackluster waiter, should have come over, apologized profusely, and comped whatever food and wine this couple managed to ingest.  But no - they sent that poor junior waitress back to the table to present the bill and that was that.  No formal apology.  

Maybe Boulevard cold be forgiven for not evolving its menu past its heyday, and on a busy Saturday night you might even forgive the meh waitstaff OR a forgotten table.  But to so egregiously screw up with a table and not even send a formal apology "from the house?"  Or comp the meal?  Unforgivable.
author: Catherine K.

description:
excellent food and service.
i felt like space was tight, tables were close - on that night at least.
author: Nedda S.

description:
Went here with my buddy for her birthday.  All of the food was very tasty, and prepared with precision...with a few caveats.  She got the quail, I got the filet mignon.  Both were delicious, but I think the quail was better. 

However, for a restaurant of this caliber, I can only award 3.5 stars, but I will bump it up to 4 because the service was fantastic and I liked the atmosphere inside.

Why?

When I cut through the foie gras, I definitely had to pick through some veins.

When I drank the blueberry lemonade, it was super intense.  Like sucking a lemon.

The desserts were nice and light, but something was off about the texture of the cakes.  Like eating 3-day old angel food cake from safeway.

And I definitely had an upset stomach that night.  I thought it was just me, but my friend confirmed this with me the next day.
author: Daniel P.

description: By coincidence, my cousin got married the same year as we did.  We all went to Boulevard to celebrate.  We ordered every appetizer on the menu, one filet mignon and four bottles of wine.  Fabulous!
author: Sondra H.

description:
After this many reviews who will ever read this one? 

Food good. Dessert better. Wine list wicked. 

We've been over 10 times and it is like an old friend. 

We ate ____ and drank ___ the waiter ____ was attentive and afterwards we did not have to get more food like tons of other places.

MM (for short) was one of such places. Ooooh, my first peripheral bash.
author: James T.

description:
One of my absolute favorite restaurants to dine at.  Most peeps would rate this as contemporary American cuisine, but I think it's more fusion, with French, Asian, and Mediterranean influences.  

This is a great place to go on a dinner date with your significant other.  The decor is classy, cozy, and upscale.  You can chat it up with your love at the bar and/or at the table while you wait for your gourmet meal.  Or if you're too nervous to speak, the two of you can admire and comment on the delectable food that is being plated from the kitchen.  (The kitchen is situated in the middle of the restaurant.)  

The food is divine!!!  Their seafood is so fresh, it melts in your mouth.  Their menu changes often, depending on what is fresh and in season.  If you see Monk-fish on the menu....order it.  It is soooo good.  Monk-fish, also known as, the poor man's lobster, is perfectly prepared at Boulevard.  I highly recommend the sea bass as well.  Oh, and if you're a big fan of brulee, you must have some for dessert.  

This meal is going to set you back quite a bit of $$$, but it's worth every penny.
author: Maj H.

description: My first time being here.  Very fancy place and food is good. The plating of food was very decorative and pretty! While you wait, they provide good fresh bread paired with salted butter! So goood!
author: Helen L.

description:
Boulevard food yum
architect orgasm, there
like hot waitress most
author: Mr. D.

description: This place is absolutely amazing.  Probably one of the best restaurants i've ever been to along with Rare 120 at the Hard Rock Hotel Las Vegas.  The best Gnocchi I've ever tasted.  The service was WOW....worth the $$$$
author: Lapriel S.

description:
i went through a torrential downpour for you Boulevard....why? because i expected GREATNESS...you...however...disapointed. *sad face*

ok so nothing was particularly bad about this place...but for the amount of money youre expected to shell out you kind of expect service better than i dunno...red lobster?

we had reservations and were seated quickly. i wouldnt consider this a first date place unless you enjoy screaming over all the ambient noise. its definitely lively in here. careful if youre wearing heels i almost died on the wet tile floor haha...

service: i dont know...i guess im just used to MORE. ive been to other fancy schmancy joints and they seemed a lot more attentive and friendly. maybe it was just my particular waitress but cups were continuously left empty and it was just silent and awkward every time she passed by. the other waiters that passed by to drop off food and such were a lot nicer haha.

food: we shared the bisque for an appetizer...creamy yummy soup accompanied by 2 prawns and 2 fried oysters...i usually HATE fried oysters because its a textural nightmare for me but they were DELICIOUS...

he had the filet mignon which was cooked perfectly however kind of salty. dont mean to toot my own horn but he said the steak i cooked was better HAH...in your face boulevard =) hahaha...but it was extremely tender.

i had the porkchop which was recommended by the waitress. it was good...im not usually a pork eater but the chop was very tender and juicy. also a little on the salty side and i couldve used a little more of the sauce to balance out the saltiness...but overall pretty good.

for dessert we had the macron and mint chocolate cake...both desserts were so incredibly rich i couldnt take more than a couple bites without drinking water...i mean it was GOOD but...DAMN it was sweet hahaha....

overall it was a good experience but mainly because of the company. i expected more out of a michelin star restaurant though. this isnt a place id frequent and for special occasions id probably go somewhere else. but if youre in the area and are hungry i say why the hell not? it looks like a good place for drinks as there is a quite an extensive alcoholic beverage collection =)....
author: Jaime W.

description:
If you walked by here, & looked in, you probably wouldn't think much.
However, once through the doors, the dining experience is always superb.

The layouts of the tables are appear pedestrian, but the lighting is nice & somehow conversations from other tables don't seem an issue.  

Pretty much anything you order will be great, but be sure to
order any cocktail with a cherry, as they're bourbon soaked and super delish.  Also, definitely have the carrot cake; it's AMAZING.
author: L. K.

description:
Voted "least likely to be found in the Mission," this is Rick Steves Paris guidebook style restaurant.  You either find the tulip lampshades frosted in pink and blue absolutely charming, or vaguely nauseating.  

I took my folks there, so it was perfect.  This is solid, traditional food, with plenty of meat offerings, nothing complicated, fussy or alienating, and made with fresh ingredients.  It will let your out-of-town, khaki-wearing uncle or dad or Nancy Reagan feel satisfied after the end of the meal.   I don't live or work around here, but the bar area looks comfy enough, and has some small tables for tossing back cockies.

The crab salad with citrus was the best dish and wonderfully done -- fresh, dense crab, without any disgusting mayo or cream sauce to kill the flavor of the sea,  blended with a bright, acid orange.   Excellent.  My brother's filet steak was a bit tough, which was surprising considering how carefully done everything else was,  but the flavor was grassy and deep.   As invertebrates are tasty, the stuffed squid was ordered, along with the abalone.   We thought we were going to get a chunk of whole abalone, pristine and firm.  What we got reduced abalone, but it was still flavorful.  Raw abalone would probably be too challenging.

The server was a very casual and helpful guy -- very good service -- and the folks were happy.  I don't personally go for the Belle Epoque-style but it doesn't get me writhing like some of the crochety reviewers.  I think adjusting  the bomb pop-colored lighting might deal with the 1-2 star people.  It is a well preserved building from the turn of the century and the downstairs private room has a wonderful small bar that makes one feel like you're in an excellent old tavern.
author: ed y.

description:
I remember going here with a friend once and he ordered there filet mignon which comes with a very delicious sauce. Not knowing that Boulevard is not a steak house, he asked for A1. The waiter looked at him as though he wanted to bitch slap him. 

I responded for the waiter with a simple "dude, it comes with its own sauce".

The courses are prepared meticulously, and of the many times I've been in they have yet to miss a beat. The aforementioned filet with potatos au gratin is my favorite dish. 

My only bugaboo is the atmosphere. Most of the patrons have gray hair and the room doesn't feel as alive and exciting as other establishments in the area. But, for the cuisine, by far one of my faves in the city.
author: Rodney P.

description:
exceptional.
I would have given it 5 stars except our night was marred by the fact that our plates sat long after we finished, getting refills was a chore and getting a new napkin was impossible.
Basically the waiter ignored us in between courses.
Ofcourse if you knew the whole story, like the fact that I slept with that hot muscle boy waiter and never called him again, a few months before you might understand his derelection towards our table but hey, 
business is business.
And Boulevard is in the business of being one of the finest restaurants in town.  
I hope to go back, and to have no personal knowledge of the waitstaff and their personal, um, shortcomings. ;)
author: Sean S.

description:
I was so disappointed.  I have heard all of the hype for all of these years, and ordered to my hearts desire....and the disappointment.

I read all of the reviews, and I wanted it to be delicious.

I am not a total foodie, but I know good food.

The flavors in all of the dishes were seriously lacking.

The Calamari and the Crab salad appetizers were both bland.

The Prime Rib chop was cooked perfectly, but the fish dish I had was very overcooked.

The service was perfect.

But all and all, for $250 for 2, I was not even a little bit wowed.

the Decour and noise level are not the greatest either.
author: Jackie M.

description:
I usually have strong opinions on restaurants.  But I am wishy-washy when it comes to this place.  Why?

For starters, decor is Cheesecake Factory gone pseudo-fancy (sadly reminds me of Grand Lux Cafe, Cheesecake's "upscale" partner).  This is not a good look for a place whose entrees can approach $40.  And then there is the bleach smell that hits your nose when you walk in - again, ok for a cheapie dive, but not for one of the so-called "best" restaurants in SF.  Gross.

Then there is the crowd.  Expense-accounters in abundance.  Boring. With a handful of poorly-dressed chubby out-of-towners.  Ugly.   Lots of old people.  Staid.

Then there is the food.  I have had the best lamb chops of my life here.  They are cooked in a wood-fired oven and are just delicious.  I would venture that any meat product from this oven would be stellar.  But I have also had the worst total business lunch of my life here.  One guy did not even touch is truffled risotto.  The heirloom tomatoes were mealy.  And everyone's steak was WAY overdone.  I even sent mine back.  To no avail.  However, I have also had some of the best wine of my life here.  It was a burgundy and way out of my league.  So if you have the $$ to drop on serious wine, you will be happy.  But then comes some of the worst dessert: way-too-rich and boring chocolate tart and mini stone fruit pies that tasted like canned pie filling, not alleged farmers market produce.  Sigh.  They both went unfinished, and I never do that.

Oh, Boulevard, why do you tempt me with perfect lamb and wine and then take it all away by the time dessert rolls around?  How can an experience be fabulous one night and awful another?  Your inconsistency is mind-boggling.
author: Melissa B.

description:
I was there to have a drink with a girl I just met so not sure about how their food is like but the atmosphere was not bad at all.  

Maybe it was because she was so cute, I had a great time in there so you know what that means.  Two thumbs up for this place.  Muahahhaha
author: Ernie K.

description:
You got folks in town? Boulevard.
Fancy clients you wanna win over? Boulevard.
Sure thing good dinner? Boulevard.
Excellent service? Boulevard.
Best place to spot a former 49er? Boulevard.
Wanna Not be surprised? Boulevard.

They do it well, just always stays the same. It's nice when you can always count on a place, but in a way it can be a bit creepy..like the truman show.
author: Rhubarb M.

description:
I have to say that I have grown tired of Pat Kuleto theme restaurants.  I have been Jardiniere, Farallon, Nick's Cove, and now Boulevard.  I feel like these restaurants are permanently stuck in 1990.  They are big and flashy, but belong to a different era.  I think Pat Kuleto's time has come and gone.  These restaurants may still thrill tourists, but locals are too smart to be blinded by his dated Belle Epoque obsession.

After living in the city for 10 years, I decided to try Boulevard.  I always assumed that this restaurant was overrated and avoided it.  I would walk by once in a while on the way to the Ferry Building and check out the menu or peak inside.  Finally, my curiosity got the best of me and I had dinner here on Saturday night.

We had an early reservation and after a painfully slow cab ride, we arrived at Boulevard.  I was instantly excited by the frenetic pace of the first dinner rush.  The restaurant was packed and bursting with energy.  The Audiffred Building is beautifull, even if the interior is a little dated.  I looked around and saw mostly tourists and business people.  There was a table of financial district workers sucking down cocktails and making jokes about the economy.  There was an old guy with a younger date, who had a bottle of Sine Qua Non Omega opened on his table.  It felt like 2005 and that was not a bad thing.

I looked at the menu and tried to keep an open mind.  Finally, I ordered the foie gras.  For $27 it was not a bad choice, but it could have been better.  Maybe it was the price, it just felt like something was missing.  There were all kinds of things on the plate, citrus, sweetness, and brioche.  I felt like I had seen this set up before with a different presentation.  I should mention that my wife had the ravioli with truffles and almost sent it back.  It was lukeroom and tasted like it had been sitting around under a heat lamp.

I had the lamb T-Bone for an entree and it was huge.  Too big really.  The meat was cooked perfectly and tasted fine, but I did not really want to eat the entire thing. 

At any rate, Boulevard is a landmark.  Great building, great location, big name owners, and all that.  I think the problem is that all of this has lead to some complacency.  The staff was professional and efficient, but they seemed more interested in controlling the crowd and turning tables, than pleasing their customers.  I will probably go back sometime in the future, but with a different set of expectations.
author: Ezra Y.

description: The food was good but the portions were on the smaller size for the price. Overall it was a good dining experience. The pork chop was good but it needed some type of sauce.  The dirty girl strawberries and cheesecake were great desserts but I would skip the caramel bar dessert.
author: T W.

description:
I went here recently for an expense account lunch.  Wonderful.  Really excellent food and fantastic, knowledgeable service.   I had an Ahi Tuna starter and a perfect steak. The dessert was outta this world -- a trio of ice cream sandwiches in delectable flavouring.  Really tasty cherry sparkling lemonade too.

I'd definitely come here again - as long as I can get someone else to pay!
author: green t.

description:
Boulevard is like heaven on earth.  I had the best meal of my life there last night and wish I could afford to go once a week.  Sitting at the counter was so much fun, and the staff could not have been more friendly or professional.

We are lucky to have such great restaurants in SF, with Boulevard at the top of the list-

The ravioli with fontina and black truffles is seriously so amazing, and was the best dish I have ever eaten in my life.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Not over-rated. Not over-hyped. This San Francisco institution is still one of the best.

Whether you're looking to wow clients at lunch, (reserve the private "vault"- its' walls are lined with wines and the room is darkly stunning), make the 'rents proud you're a working adult when they come into town, or gaze at your love over a romantic dinner, Boulevard doesn't disappoint. The food is, in a word: excellent. It's classic, not contrived; refined, not trendy; and elegant, not nouveau.

Bravo, Boulevard. And thank you for not being tempted by the beast of hipster trend ick.
author: Kiesha R.

description: Im a fan of the nightly changing menu and creative flair. After a last min decision between here and another great place, we drove by to see that it was crowded, but not packed to the gills. After valeting the car, we walked in and got seated right away... i guess it helpes to be dressed appropriately and have the right date with you. Appealing and tasty cuisine with great atmosphere. I will be back soon.
author: Meg O.

description:
I am really torn as to whether I should give Boulevard another chance. On one hand I feel it definitely deserves another chance. 
I am a pretty liberal star giver and I am really pretty fair in my reviews you would really have to do something to piss me off to get one star. I usually give four stars to places that I frequent usually they are moderately priced and the quality is good. 5 stars if a place really makes my taste buds scream and beg for more. Neither one of those scenarios happened for me when I dined at the Boulevard. 


I will say that their service is impeccable and that Boulevard does have what it takes to give you a "dining" experience. Most places I go to I want to eat and get out, but there is something about the ambiance and attention to detail at Boulevard that makes you want to linger and soak up what really is old aristocratic San Francisco of the Railroad Barron days. It is easy to kind of get transported back in time by low lit chandeliers, that could have held oil lamps at one time, the deep dark mahogany walls, the concave brick ceiling, and the sign that looks like it was something that was made back in the medieval times. For decor and service Boulevard rightly deserves 5+ stars. It was the food that disappointed me. 


Now I am not easily disappointed by food in fact I tend to eat a lot of it. I'm pretty fat. I got fat by eating. 


On to the food which was where I feel Blvd failed. 


The wife had 2 filets of patrale sole sandwiching a shrimp and lobster puree. I tasted the dish and I felt it was a tad bit fishy. Petrale Sole is one of my all time favorite fish in the sea. I eat a lot of it I have cooked a lot of it, I have cooked a lot of it for a lot of different people. I cook it very well. There is not too much to it, you buy fresh sole, fry it in a combination of olive oil and butter over medium high heat for 2-3 minutes and season. I feel like the sole that she was served was overcooked. It wasn't moist. And worst of all... it smelt a little fishy. Seafood should never smell fishy. Ironic I know but the truth nonetheless. This was very disappointing to me because although my sole doesn't have the fancy puree in it I know I'd rather eat mine than theirs again. The wife agreed. 


I had the Scottish Farm Raised Salmon, which was cooked to perfection. I feel like it was a little under seasoned but not by much, because the taste of Salmon is very unique and I enjoy it by itself. I do think that wild caught tastes better but I guess that wouldn't be too PC considering Salmon are at low numbers and such. The salmon wasn't why I ordered the dish though. It was supposed to be served on a Morel Mushroom risotto which was the real reason i ordered the dish. Mine came with an asparagus risotto which was flavorless, a shame because asparagus takes on the flavors you cook it with. It doesn't have a very distinct flavor like a leek or Fennel that can stand on their own. You have to season an asparagus dish. 


The winner of the night was definitely the lamb T-bone, which was cooked perfectly... bloody, and was seasoned well bathed in it's own au jus. When I go back I'll order that. The Veal Sweetbreads were absolutely phenomenal as well and I can't wait to try the foie gras. 

Will I be back? Definitely. Will I order seafood again? No. From my experience where the Blvd shines is with dishes where the main course had parents, suckled from them, and walked on land. 

5 stars service and ambiance 
1 stars for the seafood 
5 stars for the meat that was red 
5 stars for the veal shortbreads that were fantastic 

I look forward to going there again and hopefully giving more stars.
author: Anthony Y.

description:
I was treated to a nice meal at Boulevard on Saturday night on a fine December evening!  The evening was cold and wet as we walked towards the restaurant.  Once we entered, it felt very warm and comfy as we saw a very decorative dining room with christmas lights and items all around.  Very festive!

We had tried the Ahi Tuna Tartare and the Scallops for appetizers.  The Fish melts in your mouth and the Scallops were cooked 'oh' so perfect.  

For the Entrees, we ordered the Walu (Hawaiian fish) and the Filet Mignon.  The Walu's texture seemed dry once you bite into it, but, the flavor and the juices come forth and it's great!  Loved the white fish!
The filet mignon was cooked medium-rare and the meat was so tender.  Didn't disappoint!  

Had the Warm Chocolate Souffle Cake..... YUM!  The plate also included a side scoop of the Cilantro-flavored ice cream.... which was neat and original.....  

Overall, the evening was grand and the meal was perfect!  Definitely recommend Boulevard as a place for a special meal!  Recommend!!
author: Edward L.

description:
As soon as I walked through the revolving doors, I knew it was going to be a special night. To describe the holiday decor as "festive" would not be doing this restaurant justice - garlands, wreaths, and glistening ornaments decorating the ceilings, walls, and walkways make the already beautiful interior nothing short of breathtaking. The whole dining room sparkled like there was magic in the air. I know, I know that's totally cheesy but hey, I know magic when I see it.

If the atmosphere isn't enough to put you in the holiday spirit (i.e. the spirit of giving hundreds of dollars to this restaurant for dinner), then the food certainly will. While the selection of primary proteins in the starters and main courses may not vary significantly throughout the year, you're reminded that it's the holiday season through the supporting cast of ingredients - pistachios, beets, squash, pumpkin spice, cranberry, pomegranate seeds, chestnuts, parsnip, and quince add a huge helping of holiday charm to the menu. So much so that I was tempted to break out my bear skin rug and cozy up with some eggnog in front of the ovens - I don't think the chefs would've minded.

We started with the RED ABALONE paired with pancetta, potato mousseline, and abalone mushrooms - ingredients that didn't overpower the abalone's delicate flavor; and, the mushrooms mirrored the texture of the abalone perfectly. We also had the seared FOIE GRAS - a preparation saturated in holiday flavors with Pumpkin Brioche, Spiced Butternut Squash, Chili Candied Pecans, Cranberry Crackle & Burnt Caramel. I was ecstatic to try such a classic dish served in this way,  and it was exceptional. The PHEASANT LEG/RAVIOLI followed (apparently it tastes like chicken!), which was a bit on the dry side, but was saved by the delicious jus that accompanied it. Also of note, while I don't particularly like cod, the LOBSTER and COD was beautifully cooked, and the risotto was packed with flavor, giving the cod the boost it needed. Finally, the HUCKLEBERRY TART with fleur de sel ice cream, cinnamon, and pomegranate seeds was a perfectly sweet/tart/salty end to a perfectly seasonal menu. 

Service was...well, let's put it this way: it was good service at an exceptionally busy time. Certain grievances, like not bringing the bread soon enough, or the rushed demeanor of our waiter, were really symptoms of how slammed they were, not of how professional/attentive the service is. When it slowed down a bit, the waiter even catered to my annoying requests and helped me take pictures of the food by shining a light over the plates. Yep. I'm that girl. 

My conclusion? I couldn't have picked a better restaurant for my holiday celebration dinner. Boulevard put the magic of Christmas in my belly, and for that, I'm thankful.
author: Kelsey E.

description:
Put it this way - even if I was super rich and could eat $200 dinners any night I wanted, I would only come to Boulevard once in a blue moon. Why? Because my experience was so wonderful, so amazing, so romantic, that I could never imagine making that feeling commonplace.

I took my baby for her birthday and we dined and drank and spent all night in total bliss.

She had scallops that were cooked *perfectly*, sitting a top a very cool pureed potato thing (not to be confused with mashed potatoes), and topped off with foie gras.

I had the most succulent piece of french-cut pork I've ever eaten. I wanted to pick it up by the bone handle and suck it.  I didn't.  But I wanted to.  It was smoked, and cooked, and slathered in honey and truffle oil, then stuffed with applewood smoked bacon and chanterelles and fennel.  It was divine.  

The waiter was very pleasant. He wasn't overly gregarious, flamboyant, or cold - he was just professional and helpful.  We ordered a really great bottle of wine at his recommendation (Emily's Cuvee, Russian River Pinot Noir '02 $50) and it was so good we bought it from a store at a later date.

The dessert looked like the celebrity special.  It was very yummy and very cool.

Go on a special occasion and prepare to make the evening as special as the person you are sharing it with.  You will not be disappointed.
author: Jerkey J.

description: One of my last trips to SF we came here for dinner with a few friends.  The food was good but not some where I'd jump at the opportunity to dine again.
author: Jenny Q.

description: I don't know why there's so much hype around Boulevards.  Food was bland and unimpressive.  I even found a bug in my vegetables and when I told the waiter, he took it to the chef, brought it back and said "we use all organic vegetables so it happens sometimes." and put it back on my plate.  Just because they use organic produce doesn't mean you don't have to wash it.
author: Nadine T.

description: I don't know about everyone, but I didn't find this restaurant good at all. Maybe, I ordered the wrong thing? But the Quail that I order as my entry had soggy skin. It grossed me out. The Crab cake as an appetizer was not good at all. The dressing they put in the crab cake was over powering and couldn't taste the crab. Dessert was OK, I had better at the cafe by Bloomingdale and it was cheaper too. Drink was good which is all I go to say. Reason for rating this restaurant low. I will probably not go there again if I visit San Fran.
author: Angel S.

description: Lovely seared calamari on a fried green tomato, but the lamb was fair. Good wine, good service, but overall overrated at these prices.
author: S W.

description:
This is a much delayed review, but very important to add.

I've been here on several occasions and I thought the food was excellent.

...however, a few months ago, my fiance's family and I went to dinner here.  As we were being seated, the hostess spilled his mom's ENTIRE cocktail down her back!  She had to spend the whole dinner a cold, sticky mess.  She was completely embarrassed and miserable the whole time.  The only thing they provided to her was one complimentary dessert and a business card offering to pay for her dry cleaning.  It seems that a restaurant of this caliber could have done a lot more to ensure the comfort of this family after such a mishap.  I've been to less prestigious restaurants who responded better to a scenario such as this.  I don't think the situation was handled well and I would not return to this restaurant as a result
author: Colleen B.

description: I had the best meal of my life at Boulevard on August 21, 2013. I went here for a special birthday dinner while on vacation and it did not disappoint. I had the salmon and started with a mozzarella and tomato dish. The mozzarella was to die for! I have never had anything like it back on the east coast. The only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is because it took a long time for our food to come as well as to get our check.
author: Mandi R.

description: This place was good but overpriced. The ahi tuna tartare was to die for. The ambience is romantic. Although the food was delicious, I'm not sure I would go out of my way to eat here the next time I am in the bay area. I would, however, recommend this place to friends who have never dined there before. The service was okay. Our waiter seemed preoccupied with other customers and seemed rushed. Other than the service, I have no complaints about this place.
author: K R.

description:
SERRRIOUSLY OVERRATED. However I will say the filet mignon and chocolate cream pie were both pretty great. Just meh to the lobster (i know!), calamari, tuna tartare and squab, though. Also, I can't complain about the service, but can't really rave about it either. Blah-ness.

Came here with a group of six for din din. Not sure I'd go back...if i were paying.
author: Jen T.

description: Yum, yum, yum, that is all I have to say. The food here is really good.  Took my friend here for his birthday and he was so happy as he wanted to go here for such a long time.  Our server was excellent as she even figured out which person was celebrating the birthday, by putting a candle in the correct dessert. I forgot to tell her during the evening, but she was attentive to the reservation description and made the correct call.  Way to go Jay.
author: Marck N.

description:
the roasted squab and seared foie gras are to die for. the other entrees are a bit mediocre. desserts are excellent and presentation is on par.

service is good without being too stuffy and reservations are highly recommended. if you happen to get a window seat, the waterfront view is spectacular.
author: Charmaine L.

description: Noisy and crowded but I like the food and love the energy.  Don't go here for a quite business dinner or a romantic dinner for two.  Do go here if you want the city vibe and some great California-French type cuisine.
author: Dave K.

description: When I first moved here and didnt know the cheap and great places to eat, my friend from out of town and I went to Boulevard. It was good food but the vibe of the place wasn't for me. It seems like a place where rich non-colored people would eat. We been walking around the city all day and came in jeans and felt really out of place. They didnt treat us any different, the service was great. I had QUAIL for the first time in my life here and savored every bite.
author: Jane A.

description: Excellent food with no gimmicks. Waiter was superb and helpful. I recommend the filet medium rare, it was absolutely perfect. Scallops were very good as well. I would go back in a heartbeat.
author: George K.

description: Phenomenal food, service, ambiance, and location (on the Embarcadero overlooking the Bay Bridge).  I started with the sea scallops, served with pancetta and hazelnuts.  YUM.  I also tasted the Sonomo foie gras (had to try it before the foie gras ban next year, sorry PETA) and it was delicious. For my main course, I ordered the grilled swordfish, which was beautifully plated and really tasty.  Finally, the chocolate angel pie was as heavenly as the name implies.  This place is a bit pricey, but it's a great spot for a date or special occasion.
author: Kerry M.

description:
I ate here yesterday for a work lunch since its right across from my office and really enjoyed it, excellent service, I had the swordfish, very good. 
Again great service/staff and a nice place to take a client or other important person.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
loved the food here, amazing pork tenderloin, soft shell crab pasta, lobster bisque... and the desert, we got the chocolate cake, perfect with a scoop of icecream!

don't care about the classic decor though, a little too old for me.
author: Peter W.

description: Great service, wine and food. Other reviews state how good Boulevard is, I'll leave it with that.
author: Steve S.

description:
Treated to a lovely lunch with colleagues today. We got a reservation for 3 at a decent time with just a day's notice.  Was immediately impressed with the decor: classic old world, like something you would see in a 20's movie.  

I started getting nervous after waiting quite a while for our waiter to show his face. After asking for our water selection (not made to feel too inferior for selecting "tap"), he disappeared for another lengthy stretch. Fortunately, our "tap" did finally arrive and he returned to take our order shortly thereafter.

Today's soup, a lobster bisque, was a very satisfying selection.  A nice balance of fish stock and creaminess, not too salty as often happens. My colleague had the tuna tartare that looked just too fabu.  I resisted the urge to help myself.

I selected the paella as my entree. The word "paella" is in quotes on the menu, so I knew it would be untraditional.  2 shrimp, 2 pieces of dungeness crab clawmeat, a guinea hen thigh served on a bed of spanish style rice with peas, chorizo, and fava beans. The shrimp and crab were cooked perfectly; I was less impressed by the rest of the dish. How did they get those favas so small and shrivelled?

Dessert is clearly the star here. We eagerly sampled each others dessert selections (chocolate tart, toffee pear caramel, blackberry parfait) and declared each outstanding.

I resisted asking to see the check since I was a guest, but a lunch for 3 without any liquor easily went to $125.  I would gladly come again as a guest or on the expense account, but honestly, I dont get all the hype.  I've had far more impressive experiences here in SF at locales with a lower Zagat rating.
author: Tom C.

description:
We arrived early, 8:10 for an 8:30 reservation.  Even though they were packed, we were seated immediately in a crowded area between the kitchen and bar.  

First of all, let me say, Boulevard does one of the best Sapphire dirties I've ever encountered anywhere and was by far the coup d'grace of our visit.

A great place to people watch, while waiting between courses... the service was lagging, but to their end they were extremely busy.  By far the show stopper of the evening was the filet mignon.  Tender, juicy, and done perfectly at medium rare.  The lamb chops were good, but a little over cooked, which surprised me, as the filet was so well done.

Definitely worth checking out, but I think I'd be more happy going with a large group next time around.
author: Kate H.

description:
The Escolar (aka butterfish, and rightly so) I had for lunch today was insanely amazingly delicious. We got there right when they opened at 11:30AM, so we got the best seat in the place looking out the window on Embarcadero. The service was great and I could kiss the waiter for recommending the Escolar. The tuna tartare was good, but not as good as Foreign Cinema's. 

Did I mention that the Escolar was one of the best meals I've ever had? Cause it was. 

Update 11/15/06: I went back hoping to revisit the Escolar but, alas, it's gone. I opted for the Pork Tenderloin and it was just kind of "eh". The Fondant Potatoes were delicious though. I've been to Boulevard about 5 or 6 times over the past 3 years and it's been consistently hit or miss. One annoyance this time... we had an 11:30 reservation but they didn't open the doors until 11:45.
author: Bernadette D.

description:
OMG!  I have to say this is the best 1 star restaurant I've ever had.  I've been here 4 - 5 times.  Once for lunch and rest for dinner.  Their lunch is just almost as good as their dinner and the price is reasonable for the quality of the food that you get (maybe not the quantity).  

The best dishes were duck breast, calamari stuff risotto, and chocolate ganache cake.
author: Sarah H.

description:
My heart and appetite SWOONs FOR THE DESSERT!!! The crazy banana dessert is quite the spectacle when they pour the warm caramel on top of the geometric chocolate spirograph. I'm so sad that it's no longer offered. But if it ever makes a come back, it's a sweet tooth's heavenly dream come true!

I booked the reservation for my business group and everyone walked away satiated. Even my partner was very happy. High five to meeting high expectations!
author: Cathy H.

description:
I give this place 3.5 stars..
Although the ambience, the service and the beautiful Art Nouveau decor was great, the food actually was a bit of a letdown..  not that it was bad, but it was just OK and not very memorable surprisingly..
I would've given it 4 stars, but for the price of the dinner, we expected to be blown away..  D's had fish, which he thought was pretty dry and I had some kind of meat and to be honest, I don't even remember it and this was only a month ago..

Because of Boulevard's reputation we are willing to give it a 2nd chance some time to earn the 4 or 5 stars..
author: Rose C R.

description:
The service is excellent, the environment is very classy and beautiful, the appetizers were very delicious, main course I had was just OK.  I came with three other co-workers and we ordered 3 appetizers... the sea scallops, heirloom tomatoes, and the ahi tuna tartare.   All of which were very delicious.  . 

When we reached the main course, this is when I was slightly dissapointed.  I ordered the pan roasted sea bass.  I was expecting crispy on the outside, fluffy and juicy on the inside.  Instead, I got crunchy on the outside, dry on the inside.  For the price I'm paying, I was expecting excellent, but instead i got Good.    

Despite my dissapointment, I would definitely try the restaurant again.  Maybe I will get lucky the next time.
author: Sandy L.

description:
I have always loved Boulevard. It's an absolute class: elegant, consistent and just plain deee-lish.

Last night a group of 30 of us dined in the private room downstairs.  service was excellent and all dishes were yummy. We started with sea scallops, followed by a choice of halibut or pork chop, and a choice of chocolate pave or creme brulee.  i'd say the only dish i wouldn't order again is the chocolate pave (but it was still well prepared). the pork chop was a bit undercooked, but i forgive them for that since there were 30 of us. i'm sure if we had dine upstairs in the main dining, we would have had an impeccably executed performance by the kitchen.  lastly, the wine was top notch. 

all in all, a happy group and great times were had by all
author: joyce l.

description: Loved the decor and atmosphere! I really enjoyed this restaurant. Food was very good. The tuna tartare and the sea bass were both excellent. Service was just ok.  I cant wait to return to explore the menu more!
author: Lauren J.

description:
A great place to go to when wealthy relatives come to town. The food here is excellent, and the experience is magical.

I had the salmon, which was truly delicious. Perfectly cooked and adorned.

The deserts here are also pretty fabulous.

A note - this is definitely a restaurant for meat eaters. My friend ordered the vegetarian entree, which was just the vegetables from the main dishes. She enjoyed it, but wasn't satisfied to the same degree as the rest of us.
author: Dana L.

description:
Close but no cigar....The Boulevard continues to get top ratings for food, service, location, etc. But it misses its mark when the food doesn't live up to its reputation.

I agree that the location is fantastic (great views of the bay), the interior is beautiful (very french/art nouveau) and the service is excellent (everyone was quite friendly). But I wasn't too impressed by the menu (mind you, it was lunch when I went). I ended up having the chicken salad that was uninspiring. I had a taste of my companion's pork tenderloin which seemed very blah. Com'on --- if you're going to pay the costly prices for the food, then please have something to write about!

However, I have to admit the ice cream sandwich dessert ROCKS! I would come back again for just dessert.

The crowd was older and more sophisticate (I saw a cougar with bling bling pumps at lunchtime) and probably filled with business folks who have an expense account (I was part of the latter as I was being wined and dined by a vendor).

I'd give it another try to at least experience dinner menu. 'Til then...

Note: Valet parking is available. $12 for lunchtime. Not sure what the cost is during dinner time.
author: Vanessa J.

description:
I didn't know until recently that they have a lower level banquet room for groups! It was quite lovely to have our own room to ourselves (baout 20 of us) and the Lobster Bisque Soup was even better than the SF Soup Company's Organic Tomato Bisque Soup which is one of my favorites!

Their  service was excellent and the entire dining experience was delectible!
author: Mashimaro M.

description:
Fantastic restaurant! 

Ambiance is low key. Dim lighting and lots of browns and beiges. You can dress casually so don't worry about not fitting in if you are wearing jeans. 

The food is exceptional. I had the Ahi Tuna Tartare as a starter. Delicious! For my main entree, I had the Angus Short Ribs. Fantastic! For desert I had Mirror Glazed Double Chocolate Sachertorte. Rich and delicious. I also tried the Sticky Toffee Pudding with a Caramel Custard Top. Light. 

Expect to spend about $60 - $80 per person here (appetizer, main entree and dessert).

The service was top notch. Our waiter was very friendly and the staff here are very attentive. 

You will not be disappointed. Come here with family to celebrate a special occasion, business partners or a good friend.
author: Johanna C.

description:
I love my grandmother and grandparents/our elderly, in general.  Without them we wouldn't be who we are.

Having said that and in order to clear my name off the list of those 'going to hell', Boulevard is practically a geriatric facility.  I mean that in the nicest way possible.

The food is good and the ambiance is nice, nice in a more traditional or Hotel Restaurant way, and in some areas you get a decent view of the bay.

Can you tell I'm making an effort to be nice here?

Unfortunately, the crowd really makes this place more than stuffy, it's straight uptight.  I've been to my share of fine dining establishments and never noticed the feeling of evaluative eyes.  It was like everyone's Aunt Mary was there to judge me - strange, needless to say.

I can also say that everything on the menu has 'been done before', there definitely wasn't really anything inventive about Boulevard.  Is this because older people are less welcoming to change?

The Rack of Lamb I shared was good but I'm not going to go back until this place turns just a smidgen more relaxed, or I get constipated.
author: Lauren G.

description:
Lovelovelove!! The food - from the golden beet and goat cheese ravioli (which had an egg yolk inside each ravioli, shaved truffles on top and sat in a light nutty sauce), to the seared foie gras (which arrived on top of just-baked cornbread-like bread with blackberries), to the lamb T-bone (I usually don't like heavy meat dishes...but this one was amazing) to the sea bass (AWESOME potatoes) - was simply sumptuous, decadent and delicious. Since it was my bf's bday, we ordered the baked chocolate doughnut - OMG my arteries are still clogged...but it was so, so GOOD. 

One thing to note - the service was amazing. Our waitress was so nice, friendly and down-to-earth - she didn't even laugh at me when I asked if we could take a picture with Nancy Oakes. Maybe Nancy Oakes laughed at me, but at least my waitress didn't (at least not to my face). This place has amazing food and an even better ambience. They definitely deserve five stars!
author: Adrienne C.

description:
I seriously heart Boulevard. What a great dining experience. Great food, reasonable prices considering the quality of the food (pretty straightforward dishes for an upscale restaurant, but executed masterfully), fast and correct service, fantastic interior (and exterior, for that matter), and a top location right by the Embarcadero. What more can you ask for?

Yes, I know, an easy/cheap parking spot nearby.
author: Alexander G.

description:
Pretty much what you'd expect from a fancy restaurant in the heart of the financial district. I came here with the bf for our anniversary dinner and the appetizer we got was amazing. I don't remember what it is anymore, but it was spectacular. Also, credit to the waiter who recommended the Havens Merlot because it is now our special wine. 

Don't get the short ribs because it's nothing to write home about. DO get some type of seafood because it's what they are known for. 

Good place for a special occasion:)
author: Angela L.

description: What can I say, I love this place. Where does the beef come from....The waiter told me and said "this was a happy cow that had one bad day". The fillet mignon is excellent. Not cheap but you get what you pay for.
author: Seamus M.

description:
Took my boyfriend here for his 26th birthday - its a nice place to spoil someone but I have had better.

We were seated right away on our reservation, and I like that the menu is very seasonal.  We sat right next to the open kitchen which was awesome because I love seeing chefs in action.  We started with the Royal Sweet Sea Scallops -- definitely one of the best scallop dishes I've ever had, and I've had a lot!  Garnish with pancetta, thinly shaved radish, fresh hazelnuts and this green garlic spaetzle that was a revelation.  My main was the swordfish in a chorizo sauce with large white beans and small potatoes.  The fish was good but it came with prawns that turned out to be mushy, really surprising for the hype I've heard about this place.  My boyfriend had the sea bass, cooked really nicely with kind of a small portion size.

They serve half bottles of wine which was nice, and we shared a half of Sancerre.  Dessert selections weren't great to me but I don't typically like dessert so I guess I'm biased. 

Overall the decor was nice, food was good, but it wasn't an amazing experience.  And for the bill -- it should have been mind-blowing.
author: Kasia F.

description:
I have been eating at Boulevard since it opened, and as expected it was a wonderful dining experience.  The architecture transports you into another place, the service is professional and attentive, but never disruptive and I have never encountered any pretentiousness from the staff.  You will impress your guests, have an amazing meal, and feel special having dinner here.

The following are comments on my dining experience for dinner on Friday April 10.   The wine list is varied, but wow is it expensive, with very few bottles under $50.  We settled on a simple French table wine for $55 (Crozes Hermitage), which was an excellent choice as it was complex but light.   

 I had the crab stuffed calamari appetizer, which was quite good.  Although, the crab was very bland.  My partner had the scallops appetizer that was excellent.   For mains we had the Halibut and the Lamb.  The lamb was delicious and the halibut was perfectly cooked.  My halibut really did not stand out in any way.  The halibut was served with a bland sauce,  over some spinach and a side of potatoes.

The lamb was also served with a side of potatoes, that were quite basic.  I looked around and saw many people not eating their potatoes.  Potatoes just don't excite me, not that I don't enjoy eating them.  I noted a general lack of vegetables and greens with my meal.  I'm always surprised by San Francisco restaurants that tout Organic and Sustainable and the protein is the highlight of the dish!  Aren't we supposed to be eating more vegetables as part of our meals?

We shared the banana tiramisu for dessert, that was truly magnificient and was an updated version of the famous white chocolate banana cream pie.
author: Robert R.

description:
Great ambiance, great service, and wonderful food.  I walked in on Saturday night....it was crowded and appeared that all the tables were filled.  Now, that is a good sign in my opinion, it let's me know that this is the place that I want to dine at...there are tons of restaurants in the city- and if this place is packed-then is must be good.

We requested one of the cozy tables and the hostess let us know that it would probably be about 30-45 minutes.  No problem.  But in about 3 minutes, she came over to let us know that one of those tables were opening up and that we would be seated in a few minutes.  Score!!!  How nice was that??

The food was great....I had the crab salad and the lobster ravioli....delicious.  And our server was so polite and professional.  Now that is service!  The restaurant itself is huge....I think it used to be two different buildings at one point. but the decor is unique and quaint.  I LOVED the stone/brick ceiling.  They have a great selection of wines and a wonderful cheese platter that you create on your own by selecting the kinds of cheeses you want.  

It's a bit pricey.....but overal ambiance and the quality of food and service definitely makes it worth it.  I would definitely come back here again.
author: Toni L.

description: The Asparagus soup was absolutely delicious, the high point of our meal.  The scallop appetizer was interesting.  Our entrees were only fair, my pork chop was luke warm, soggy-no char- like it had been sitting there a while, covered in a strange sweet sticky sauce which I found entirely too sweet, oddly balanced.  It was our anniversary, we started with cocktails and ended with Butterscotch pudding for dessert.  They added a Happy Anniversary white chocolate piece onto the pudding but still charged us for the pudding.  Really? Butterscotch pudding was actually chocolate pudding drizzled with a butterscotch sauce that was barely visible, and hard to taste.   My partner's Filet was bland served with a fingerling potato, boring.  There are no sides unless you consider a smear of potato or other unrecognizable food stuff a side.  Drinks were so-so but overly priced.  The glass of Prelude Pinot Noir our server suggested was just ok-we had to ask what kind it was after the glass was served midway into our meal.  The staff clearing tables was excellent and we tipped them separately, they were that good.  Love the atmosphere, warm and cozy but be prepared to sit with people whisking by your table, it is tight.  $275 later  - over-priced for food not on par with top restaurants in the City.
author: Chris H.

description: We had a great experience here. Love the atmosphere and the food. Service was just ok. The ahi tuna tartare was a standout. Entrees were solid as well.  I will return when i'm back in SF.
author: Shaun A.

description: What can you say about this place that already hasn't been said.  Boulevard is one of best restaurants in town creating well-executed dishes day in and day out.  The San Francisco dining scene is as competitive as it gets and we certainly have our fair share of top restaurants but Boulevard has continued on as one of SF's go-to restaurant.  You can't get a bad meal here.  Great for business lunch, romantic dinner, group celebration.
author: Laurence H.

description: By far the best restaurant me and my boyfriend have been too. We are just gettting started on trying some of the top places in SF and we loved Boulevard. Yesterday was our anniversary and we wanted to go somewhere nice and special, we are not rich so going here was really special for us. We started out with the tortelloni which is so small 3 pieces but really delicious! For the entree i had the main lobster and scallop risotto, the bf had the lamb chops and both were amazing. For dessert we had the chocolate macaron with the roasted white chocolate, it was very chocolatey but good. With tip everything came to $140 and well worth it! Can't wait to go back but it probably wont be too soon!
author: Iliana B.

description:
Went for the first time last night.  I was floored by the food.  I haven't eaten in such decadence in a LONG LONG time.  This is easily the best meal that I have had since Chez Spencer.  I didn't think that the prices were too outrageous considering the portion size.  My starter could have been an entree.

All that being said, the room is sweet and the service is good without being over bearing.

I will be back.  I will be back all the time.
author: Thadd L.

description:
What a fantastic place. I came here for dinner in late 2003 and I had forgotten how awesome it is!

Went there last night for dessert and everything was divine. From the service (outstanding), to the delivery of the dishes (which is almost like a well-choreographed dance), to the food itself... it was a true pleasure to dine here. My favorite dessert was the Valhrona "black forest" mousse cake. I adore dark chocolate, and the mousse was redolent of rich, bittersweet goodness. It was layered with moist chocolate cake and a hazelnut dacquoise (meringue), and accompanied by a hazelnut brandied cherry ice cream. Worth every indulgent calorie!!!

We also enjoyed the "bananas foster passion" (a creative take on bananas foster), the sauternes ginger pear crisp, and the warm dutch apple pie (accompanied by carmel praline crunch ice cream) (hey -- it was a special occasion!! :))

Jessica Sullivan (pastry chef) does splendid work. Make sure to save room for dessert next time you're there!
author: Jill M.

description:
I will always have fond memories of a dessert I once had here.  It was the most luxurious White Chocolate Banana Cream Pie ever.  ..smooth creamy banana mellowness spiked with white chocolate shards, golden spun burnt sugar/caramel, buttery crust.  Oh how divine, dahling!  There has never been another quite like it.   
sniff sniff.  i miss you...
author: Rosieposie Y.

description:
Nice, not as nice as I thought it'd be (hence the 4 stars), but nice.  I was there for lunch so it was more of a "take your client out to lunch" type of feel.  My food was delicious though, and my favorite part was the dessert trio.  A small platter with three little, and YUMMY desserts!

P.S.  Love the revolving doors at the entrance.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
My sister treated me to this restaurant both times I was here - so I can't speak about the high prices..  The food was excellent, we had:

scallop appetizers - Oh my god..excellent.  I've been disappointed with so many other high-end restaurants on this dish but Blvd pulled through on this one.

Halibut - I can't help but ordered this both times I was here.  I love my fish and this dish melts me my mouth...I'm drowling just thinking about it now..  

Dessert - Choc mouse of course.  After all the excellent food before hands, I enjoyed this very much as well.  Not the best I've had but it rounded off the meal nicely.

5-stars for food & service. But yes, the prices definitely reflect this..but I haven't been disappointed yet...
author: Bessie T.

description:
Lets keep it simple

5 for the food, its great, has a great twist to everything. Its all performed to a higher level of cooking you can't find anywhere.

5 for the service, waitress was great attentive even suggested where to buy the wine.

5 for the atmosphere because it was great for fancy, probably the most fancy restraunt i've been to.

4 for the price, its expensive as hell. Well, I prolly shouldn't be complaining, if you go to Boulevard you should expect it. However, the amount of price you pay more for the higher level vs the price. I feel like its 4 times as expensive as it is good. 

4 quantity again, sorta like all the other fancy restraunts, quality not quantity.
author: Steven C.

description:
