I really liked my dining experience at Boulevard. My food was delicious, and I felt like royalty eating at Boulevard. I'm sure partly that had to do with the reputation of Boulevard and my excitement about eating at Boulevard, but still my experience there was really good. 

I had the filet mignon and a cocktail at the bar, wine with dinner, the whole meal to the nines. The staff were courteous, and I liked the decor of the place. It just felt rich. (And our bill for 2 came up to like 200 some- but its Boulevard.) 

My one only small issue is that my dinner guest is very allergic to nuts and seafood, and there was only a small selection he could choose from that didn't have either. Poor guy, this was his problem with the dessert  menu too (the nut issue). I'm sure the kitchen staff could have made a substitution, but we didn't want to bother, as it was our first time dining and we were in awe.

I'd go there for another anniversary or a special night out. Parking was easy too. Everything was just perfect.
author: Glansande J.

description:
After a day of walking in the sun on Saturday, we stopped off at Boulevards at 5pm sharp, and they were able to accommodate us at 5:30pm, without reservation...yeah!

While waiting to be seated, we ordered a bottle of the '05 Loire Pouilly Fume, by Blanchet. It's a great bright and crisp white with tons of fruit, a perfect start for the evening. Their wine list did have a good selection of wines for under $50.  Corkage policy allows you to bring in 2 bottles with a $20/each fee.

The menu had more enticing and exciting appetizers than main courses, so we opted to build a mini tasting menu of appetizers to feast on. 

First round:

The ARCTIC SNOW NECTARINES & FOURME d' AMBERT BLUE with mixed greens and the MONTEREY RED ABALONE with fried green tomatoes and watercress. The salad was nice, but it was the abalone that really set the tone for a perfect dinner.

Second round:

CRISPY MARYLAND SOFT SHELL CRAB paired with Crispy Green Beans, Shiitake Mushrooms, Pickled Armenian Cucumber, and ginger miso mayo. The crab was good, but a little heavy. I would have preferred a lighter, vinegar based sauce to accompany the fried crab. The CALAMARI STUFFED with CRAB & APPLEWOOD SMOKED HAM HOCK was absolutely delicious! The ham hock really sealed in the flavor for this appetizer.

Third round:

CRISPY VEAL SWEETBREADS with a roasted garlic aioli and the SEARED SONOMA FOIE GRAS with toasted cornbread. It was really this last round that grants this restaurant a 5 star rating. Creamy, velvety, and full of flavors that explode in the mouth, these two offered a perfect harmony of flavors and texture.

We concluded the meal with the cheese plate, complemented by fresh raspberries, grapes, toasted almonds, figs, and crusty bread. 

All in all, an excellent and memorable meal! Food was delicious. Service was exceptional, very professional, knowledgeable, and attentive.
author: K A.

description:
Another great SF restaurant.  Not too much to add to this list of reviews.  Watching the chef's do their thing was entertaining.  We were also sat at a window table and had some great views of outside and the restaurant.  I think we must have been the youngest people in the restaurant btw - and we're mid 30's.  Service was excellent.  The only drawback was the 15 minute wait for a table, even though we had reservations for 8pm.

The food.....
Appetizers:
Wrapped Calamari - excellent.
Scallops - better than the Calamari
Entree:
Alaska Black wild cod - probably the least favorite thing we had.  It was okay, but I've had better fish.
Filet Mignon - wowowowowow!  Medium rare, blackened, and tasty.
Dessert:
Creme Brulet - tasty as always
Apple thingamajig - very good too.

Talk about a descriptive review! :P  I think I write these just to remember what the hell I ate and not for others to read!  lol

She had a Pinot and I had Chimay.
author: shawn p.

description:
Although there are a lot of reasons to go to Boulevard besides the food, the design of the restaurant is certainly one of them.  I don't exactly how to describe it.  There is a little of everything in the room and yet somehow it all works together.

We arrived for our noon lunch at exactly noon and were seated immediately, even though one of our party had not arrived yet.  Our group of four was seated at a table that would easily accommodate six making for a very comfortable seating arrangement.

Over the years, I have tried many different items from the menu and have found all of them to be excellent in both presentation and flavor.  On our most recent visit, three of us selected the American Kobe Beef Burger and one selected the Grilled Local Albacore Tuna Nicoise which is a deconstructed Salad Nicoise without the salad.  All of the burgers were cooked perfectly and the fries that accompanied them were perfect.  The burgers were served with baby gems and heirloom tomatoes.

Since the entire group was going out for dinner later that evening, no one opted for dessert which was a shame since they have several chocolate desserts that are fantastic.

Boulevard remains a favorite location in San Francisco.
author: Scott M.

description:
I was disappointed here, which made me sad because I really wanted to love it.

I got a tanqueray tonic, but was pretty sure it was made with well gin.

The food was good, but not great. Not worth the money. Though I'm considering giving it another shot.
author: Sachin A.

description: Came here for a "work" type lunch with a very big group and I was not disappointed. My friends have mixed reviews (like on Yelp) but for me i really enjoyed the service and ALL of the food. I got a fish entree and it was superb. The starters were top notch as well (salad), everything was well seasoned.  I had a friend who is a vegetarian and her plate looked delic as well.  The wine that we had was also very good.
author: Ka C.

description:
The food here is not worth the prices.

The best thing was the seared foie gras appetizer. Didn't care too much for the pine nut almond cararot cake that came with it.  I also tried the wood fire grilled boneless quails.  Nothing spectacular or original about the flavor. It had a burnt taste I didn't like. I did enjoy the side of Italian farro in the style of risotto with purple potato and cauliflower. Tasty with a great texture.  Pan roasted halibut was okay also. Nothing that stood out. Liked the side of potato gratin though.

The crowd is older, dressed in business suits.
author: Starla L.

description:
You have to make reservations at this restaurant, otherwise you'd probably wont be seated for a while.  Came here for lunch and it was super busy, so busy that our lunch ended up lasting 3 hours -_-

Ordered:
Ahi tuna tartare - pretty good
calamari - tasted almost sort of raw, smelled fishy, almost sort of gross
the salad recommended by the waitress - didn't think it was that good, same goes for the rest of the guests since it was barely touched.  

Entree - baked pork ribs - heavenly, out of the world good.  too bad it came in such a small portion!!!!!! i think i need a good 2-3 orders to keep me full.  Other guests ordered the special burger, which wasn't all that special.  It came in generous portions, but why does it even matter when it's not all that great rights.  The fries that came with it was good though!  

Overall, very very expensive.  Thank god I didn't have to pay and had the chance to try this place.  This place is a must try, and definitely way more worthy of my money than house of prime ribs (which is total crap compared to this place).   

I'll be back!!
author: Emily L.

description:
I had dinner here recently for my birthday.  I'm a recent transplant from New York and Boulevard had been on my list of "must try" places.  

The cocktails were great and the wine list well priced for as upscale a restaurant as this is.

Now, the food.  It was great but not exceptional.  I had a better scallop and pork belly appetizer at a restaurant in Banff.  Not to mention you only get one scallop for your $15.  My duck and my husbands lamb were well cooked and flavorful, but again, not exceptional.  

Overall, Boulevard is a good place to come for a special occasion.  It has wonderful atmosphere and great food, but I don't believe it lives up to the hype, and therefore don't believe it justifies the price tag.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Some of the best food in town, yet a bit pricey. But compared to some of the other upscale places it's a steal. You will be well taken care of at boulevard!
author: David B.

description: I've eated here a few times, including recently. One of my friends thinks it's over rated. I disagree. The food, wine, service and ambiance have always been outstanding. But, I can't vouch for any meat dishes beyond the excellent seafood appetizers and entrees.
author: A H.

description:
AMBIENCE: 5

SERVICE: 4

FOOD:4

VALUE FOR MONEY: 3


Small yet diverse menu that's understandably heavy on fish and seafood given that you are right on the Embarcadero waterfront in downtown SF. 

The Dungeness Crab Salad was superb....5 stars for that appetizer! The salad of baby beets with darker arugula was also awesome. So was the sweet sea scallop that came paired with the lobster entrée. However, the lobster itself was not very flavorful.

Dinner portions are very small, which is not the same as saying "on the smaller side". They are actually very small....the meat/fish is only 4-6 ounces whereas you typically get 8-12 ounces elsewhere even at fine restaurants!
author: Marc P.

description: Boulevard used to be our go to "nice restaurant" for all the big occasions like birthdays and anniversaries.  Boulevard is really on the decline.  The food has gone from amazing to really good to just eh. The last straw was they severely overcooked my poor fish.  Another thing I don't care for is that the restaurant is so small.  You can't walk to your table without maneuvering around someone else's.  Also, Boulevard doesn't appear to have an enforceable dress code.  If i'm paying $200 for my meal, I like to dress nice, and I don't want to sit next to the schmuck wearing an "I love SF" sweatshirt and blue jeans.
author: liza m.

description: Good food and ambience, but not all it's hyped up to be.
author: Elena M.

description: Wonderful dinner. Terrific service. 25th anniversary dinner and it was a good choice
author: Fritz L.

description: Food was fantastic. The bartender was great. Service was wonderful. We will be back. Thank you
author: Nancy W.

description: Excellent service, beautiful interiors, but the food just wasn't quite there.  While it was tasty, there were several mistakes that I can't forgive at a restaurant that charges around $40 for entrees.  First, my starter, the buffalo mozzarella, came with several really large pieces of celery which were weird and overwhelming on the dish.  The mozzarella was bland; not nearly as salty/creamy as most buffalo mozz.  My entree was the lamb T-bone.  The lamb was tender and delicious but the grits on the bottom of the plate were oversalted and the artichoke heart on the side did not have all of the tough leaves trimmed away.  This is a rookie mistake that is unacceptable at a fine dining restaurant. Dessert (red velvet cake) was delicious.  Wouldn't return unless someone else was picking up the tab.
author: Amanda M.

description: The salad was good.  And that was all.  Everything else unmemorable and bland.  The service is fine but the not most attentive.  The decor is nice but it seems like like a banquet because I can hear my neighbors conversation.  I would not recommend this restaurant unless you have no other options nearby, which there are many.
author: Josh H.

description: Ambiance was superb with a great view of the waterfront.  However, the food was underwhelming.  I can't help but wonder how this place got a Michelin star.  I ordered the Yellowtail appetizer and Sea Bass entree.  My friends ordered the Salmon entree.  Presentation was okay.  Fish looked really plain, which not surprisingly also tasted very plain.  Nothing spectacular.  Certainly not enough to merit a Michelin star.  In all fairness, i've been told their meat dishes are their specialty.  So if you go, order their steak dishes instead of seafood.
author: Jasper J.

description:
Solid place. Just really, really good.

All is excellent apart from their pastry kitchen which needs to be improved upon.
author: Rich S.

description:
Now, we must warn readers that this restaurant may seem biased because this place has sentimental meaning to us.  However, we are very self-aware people =), so we'll try and make this as objective as possible.

Parking can be a bit difficult.  There are a lot of posh restaurants around this area, so the competition for a decent parking spot is fierce.  We opted for a parking garage and swallowed the bitter bill.

The restaurant itself is all about class and experience.  The decor is a bit muted for a French-inspired restaurant, but the dining room is expansive, yet intimate.  

We had heard that their menu had changed since our last visit, but if it helps, A had the quail and K had fish-- either halibut or swordfish.  The food is a bit pricey, but you really pay for what you get.  We ended up paying around $130 with no wine.  Not bad for a top-rated restaurant.

And like someone wrote earlier, their bread assortment is also super yummy.  

This would normally border at around 3.5 stars, but we'll play the sentimental card and bump it up .5 stars.
author: Kel S.

description:
All in all, I recommend Boulevard. Food is always fresh, well presented and the quality is consistant. 

The only reason I gave it four stars was because of the sevice. The waiter was just very curt in his responses and seemed annoyed at being asked about the menu or if he had a specific wine he'd recommend. I'd expect stuff like that if I were somehow crazy enough to find myself venturing to Olive Garden or something of the like, but not when Im paying this much. Service has just seemed to be hit or miss recently. It isn't enough to make me stay away, but it's something to take in to consideration when deciding whether or not you wish to dine here.
author: Anita B.

description:
Update:  I took my parents to Boulevard last night for an early 50th Anniversary celebration.  They were visiting from the East Coast and my father has wanted to go to Boulevard for years - ever since he saw Mark Bitman doing some kind of competition with Nancy Oakes on a NY television station.

Anyway, I digress... a few Yelpers have mentioned "attitude" issues at Boulevard and I MUST disagree.  Last night, the hostess originally led us to a table along the aisle near the open kitchen.  Because of the foot traffic from the wait staff, I asked her to move us somewhere a little less busy.  In less than a minute, we were seated at a lovely banquette corner table by the windows.  The folks at Boulevard have done this before when I wanted a different table, and they complied with a smile and no attitude whatsoever.

Later on, I walked over to the waitress and told her it was my parents' anniversary and asked if there was any way we could get an autographed menu for a keep sake.  The waitress smiled and said she would absolutely do her best, even though Nancy Oakes was VERY busy.  5 minutes later, Nancy Oakes came over to our table to congratulate my parents on their anniversary and we chatted for a few minutes.  You cannot pay for that kind of gesture... she did that out of good will.  Even better, when the bill came, a menu was tucked into the cover of the bill with a personal greeting from Nancy Oakes to my parents.  

This is an experience we will never forget and it only enamors me more to Boulevard.

For what it's worth, the truly yummy meal included:
Starters:
Calamari stuffed with Dungeness Crab
Guinea hen stuffed ravioli - decadent and rich
Seared Day Scallops - yes there are only two, but the flavor is remarkable.
Entrees:
Filet of Sole - a seared crust to die for and a rich buttery flavor
NY Pave Steadk & Short Rib - once of Nancy Oakes new dishes and a definite winnner
Suckling Pig trio - too good to describe...
______________________________________________________

I've had two great meals here, and loved the place both times.  I don't know why people think the portions are so small... they seemed perfect to me.  My friend had the Filet Mignon and I had the Veal last time and the flavor was impeccable.  

I agree it has the potential to be noisy near the bar area, especially since  I did go on a Friday the first time. You can easily get past that by getting a reservation on an "off-peak: day... that way you can escape the happy hour noise of Fridays and the crowds on Saturdays.
author: Audrey E.

description:
Hands down my favorite restaurant in the city.

So settle in with a Makers Manhattan and buckle up for a multi-hour floor flopping food-gasm that will mystify your senses of all time and place, stroke your palette into submission, and tickle your taste buds until you are crying with joy. This is THE place to bring your lover for an unforgettable dinner. There is nothing missionary about this joint. 

A word of warning, don't get too satiated before dessert because there are some scrumptious sweets to be had and more ohhing and ahhing to pass through your lips and annoy your sometimes stuffy ass neighbors. Mmmm mmmm did I say mmmmmmmmm?
author: Alison P.

description:
Boulevard is a San Francisco classic serving up delicious new Californian cuisine with some French fuss.  The foie gras is divine and the chocolate dessert trio is not recommended.  Rack of lamb was good but not worth a wait. The Filet Mignon was steak house quality that melts in your mouth.

Good beer and wine selection.  The starters seem to be better than the entrees overall.  Ingredients are fresh but not as good as Chez Panisse.

The ambiance takes you away from the financial district into a Parisian bistro.
author: Mo P.

description:
A little overrated.  

I took my boss here for lunch and she quite enjoyed it.  I thought the food was decent but nothing extraordinary compared to what i've read/heard.  I don't think I can find a reason to return-- not delicious enough to frequent and not special enough for special occasions.
author: J D.

description:
Finally made it here for a business lunch.  I don't know what's taken me so long!  Sure, it's pricy, but the food is outstanding, and it's gorgeous inside!  It made me think immediately of Paris, which I'm sure is the goal.  My boss jokes that it's like an upscale cheesecake factory, because the decor is so over the top and stylized, but I loved it.  Great views out over the bay, comfortable seating and bar area, and friendly but polished service.  

I tried the seared scallops, which we delicious (but let's be honest, they're usually delicious), the dungeness crab salad (divine!), and the butterfish.  Everything was beautifully plated, and the portions were just right.  Can't wait to go back!!
author: nicole l.

description:
I took my wife here just last Friday night.  We got there around 7 p.m. and were seated right away.  Place was crowded, but not in a meat-locker sort of way.  First - the service is just the best.  I tipped 25%, it was that good.  Second - food was the best.  My tuna tartare (sp?) was incredible.  I have had that in many places: I would've switched political parties to have seconds!!!  My wife's pork main dish - just out of this world.  The deserts were incredible.  

You pay for this excellent culinary and service experience.  The bill was $200.  She had two glasses of wine and I had a gin-and-tonic, so that added to the bill, but only a bit.  However, I didn't feel, given the level of food and service, that I was overcharged.  

A great experience.
author: Greg R.

description:
Crowded. Seemingly a bit too much so for the wait staff to handle. Unfortunate.

The Dungeness Crab Salad was great, minus the CRAB. The "little gem lettuce" was just that and more but the fishiness of the crab was in stark contrast to that freshness. The BBQ Angus Short Ribs were fine but the accompaniments really stood out to me, particularly the Yukon Potato Risotto and the Smoked Hen of the Woods Mushrooms. The Berkshire Prime Rib Pork Chop was perfectly seasoned and cooked - juicy and tender with a savory herb flavor.

The Warm Meyer Lemon and Huckleberry Brioche Pudding dessert was good. Not to die for but it was a nice finish.

One thing to note is that it's quite a trek from the dining area to the restroom facilities. Would not suggest taking anyone who cannot easily navigate stairs.
author: Kristi K.

description:
Good, solid, new American at prices that aren't over the top. The space has smart decor and is casual enough to be able to relax and enjoy yourself a bit. The staff are efficient, and service is friendly.

The dishes are very down to earth. Nothing to fancy or fusion-y for the most part.

The only disappointment I had there was during a visit last year. The rack of lamb was a bit under seasoned, and it came with just a smidgen of sauce -- it could have easily used another spoonful or two.
author: J K.

description: Great meal at Boulevard. I went there during the heirloom tomato celebration in San Francisco and they had a killer heirloom tomato and Buffalo mozzarella appetizer. Probably the best tomatoes I've ever had in my life. The pork chop is excellent also.
author: Steve T.

description:
Sat at the bar... great room and friendly bartender.  Split the fig salad, scallops, tuna tartare, abalone, and calamari.  My favorite was the calamari, it was stuffed and pretty good.  Wasn't wowed by anything else.
Interestingly, they do this panko breaded egg that was super clever and tasty.
I need new SF restaurant recommendations.
author: Lisa M.

description: really good food, decent service, great location, and AWESOME dessert menu.  only if parking was a bit easier.
author: Mike S.

description:
OMFG this is great.  From the moment we entered to the time we left, the service and food were exquisite.

Great:
Ahi tuna tartare 
Fomduta ravioli with shaved black truffles -- this appetizer was to die for,  the homemade pasta and cheese were amazing)
Organic free range chicken -- I never order chicken in a restaurant, but my companion did and it was so moist,flavorful,,, wow
Angus filet mignon -- cooked perfectly
24 month aged cheddar

Oops:
asked to take leftover chicken home, never was brought to the table and we left, forgetting to take it.
author: David S.

description: Yummy apple cheddar salad. Lighter fare than I expected  but then I had room for the fabulous dessert: a sampler of goodies. We sat at the prep counter which is not the same as the bar. Requesting the counter will put you ahead of the many diners who insist on table seating. And the counter is an interesting place from which to watch all the food preparation action by the pros.
author: Paula H.

description:
Absolute favorite restaurant in SF. Among the Top 5 of my favorite restaurants in the USA. Everything is perfect - service, ambiance/decor, the food, good lard, THE FOOD...

I come to SF rarely, so the menu is different every time I come, which always initially makes me sad that I can't get that special dish or dessert that I got last time. But then I order something else and it is always, always, just as wonderful as the last trip.

Price is 100% fair given that you're getting the total experience here. Excellent food, extremely attentive waiters. 

Personally I prefer dining at the prep counter. fun and educational to boot!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Still my favorite restaurant in San Francisco!  I have always wanted to come here by myself and sit at the bar and have dinner.  My chance finally arrived, and everything was better than I could have possibly imagined.  This is truly the best restaurant I have ever experienced.  The bartenders are so amazing and better than 95% of any waiter I have ever experienced.  Everything was beyond perfect.  I hope I get another chance to be here again soon!
author: David H.

description:
15 years of feasting fancy in SF and I had never before been to Boulevard. Well, turning 40 does bring some benefits (thanks sweetheart!), and my surprise 40th bday dinner at Boulevard was fantastic. The restaurant TOTALLY lives up to its reputation, and even exceeded my expectations. The ambiance, the service, the quality of the food. All spot on.

The food is very earthy -- sizeable portions and relatively simple preparations, but not at all boring. Each dish had wonderfully surprising elements, but nothing that got in the way of the main ingredient. We had quail and abalone for starters; pork and lamb for mains. Very accessible wine list, with great selection at all price points and nice choices by the glass and 1/2 bottle. The only thing that didn't totally impress was the desserts. They were delicious, just not memorable like the savory dishes. Still, no hesitation on giving Boulevard 5++++ stars. I would go back many times over.
author: Rob K.

description: Very good restaurant. My sister's introduced me to this restaurant when they lived in SF.  As good as it gets.  A must try, you won't regret it!
author: Arya M.

description: Service  was great. It's cool eating at a place where the address is 1 and the whole joint is filled with power suits even at 9:30 pm . The foie gras was excellent and the filet is something you could eat everyday. The stuffed muscles with lobster meat reminds you you're at the embarcadero. Great place and one you must try if in san fran.
author: Joshua B.

description:
I went here for a dinner lecture the other night. Walking through the restaurant towards the downstairs private room, I was surprised at how casual the atmosphere was compared to what I had imagined. It was upscale but not stuffy and pretentious. 

The meal started off with the avocado and heart of palm salad. Each plate came with 1/2 of an avocado and the center filled with hazelnut and pesto. It wasn't my favorite salad that I've ever had but that's just really based on preference. The others at my table really like it, especially the shaved truffles. 

The steak that I had was alright. It must have been average to the point where I don't remember much of the dish. 

For dessert, I had a big piece of brownie sundae. This would have been delicious if the brownie was warmed. 

I was disappointed with this meal based on reputation but I definitely want to try this place on another occasion, with a smaller group to see how it really is.
author: Jennifer C.

description: boulevard is an excellent place to have fine dining  . I luv this place , always very consistent with cooking skills and matching food and wine together . the hostess, waiters , captains . they are so nice and always try best to find tables available for u, of course its very busy so always make reservation ahead ! , I had my last foie gras there , haha~~
author: Heather Y.

description: Loved the food, service, and ambience.  Right across the street from the water - great views!
author: Shannon T.

description:
The food was good -- one dish was excellent -- but given the price and the hype, I left feeling disappointed.

The food: We began with cocktails that were excellent: well-executed, a not too intimidating list to choose from, and a good combination of classics and new things.  After we ordered, we were brought crusty, partially whole wheat sourdough bread, served cold and slightly stale; it came with ice-cold butter that was nearly impossible to spread.  Definitely not a highlight of the meal.  We had high hopes for the sea scallops appetizer but were disappointed: the plate was covered in various additions (e.g., a sweet potato-red pepper mash, and purple potato chips) that had more of a trying-too-hard than a perfect-combination-of-flavors effect.  The salmon entree was no better, and was served lukewarm from spending too long sitting in the kitchen.  The halibut was cooked perfectly but unfortunately nothing special. The one standout dish was the lamb tbone, which was cooked perfectly (so juicy!) and nicely presented.  We enjoyed the bittersweet chocolate brulee and dark chocolate mousse, but weren't blown away, and some of the fruity flavors lurking in the presentation were a turn off.  The tea we ordered for dessert came in the form of a mighty leaf tea bag; at this caliber of restaurant, I've come to expect loose leaf or more exciting tea selections.

The service: While our server provided an excellent wine recommendation, he was less than attentive: we struggled to get his attention to order drinks when we arrived, and to order a bottle of wine for dinner.

The ambiance: The open, fairly light dining room is better for groups than for romance.  While the water front location is nice, most tables in the long dining room are far from the view.

Overall, I wouldn't be embarrassed to take friends here, but certainly wasn't impressed!
author: Kay O.

description: Went with a colleague, looking for a fancy meal, in San Francisco. The Boulevarde was it. The pork chop was exceptional, really liked the cherry sauce they put over the chop. I hope to be able to being my wife back here in the future.
author: Eric S.

description:
Great restaurant! The food was awesome. I had Raviolini as a starter, "liberty farms duck" and as desert creme brûlée. It was nicely arrangend. And there was plenty of time between the different parts. However, it could have been a bit longer. For those three courses I took me 90min. 
Service was nice and good.
author: Florian K.

description: Having just received the James Beard award, Boulevard should have been beyond phenomenal.  Other than the Foie Gras and the Joseph Roth 2007 Burgundy, the food was mediocre and the service was fair. We felt rushed and therefore decided to order each course one at a time. 3 out of 3 entrees were brought to us lukewarm. When we advised our server, she promptly took them and told us that she would reheat them. A restaurant worthy of the recognition Boulevard has received should remake the entrees and bring them hot. Instead, several minutes later, our server returned with our rewarmed plates- the plate was warm, but the food remained lukewarm, as before. Nancy Oakes cooly cruised the restaurant twice, never stopping at anyone's table. We have eaten at both French Laundry and Per Se on multiple occasions, and each time has been a true dining experience with excellent food, wine, and service. Boulevard, on the other hand, was extremely disappointing.
author: Leland H.

description:
What makes Boulevard an exceptional culinary experience?    

1. Carpaccio with fried oysters, tasso aioli and spinach salad
2. Guinea hen (1/2 roasted and 1/2 stuffed in ravioli laced with foie gras sauce and sprinkled with Parmesan) on a bed of sauteed spinach
3. Goldeneye Pinot Noir from Alexander Valley, 2004 
4. Creme brulee with blackberries and scented with lavender oil

The fried oysters  was crunchy on the outside yet "oozing" and soft in the center.   The hen stuffed in ravioli with fois gras sauce worked well with the Pinot Noir (spicy with cinnamon, nutmeg, cherry and plum).   

Net: Highly recommended, 4.5 stars
author: TK W.

description:
I recently went here for an anniversary celebration.  I was slightly disappointed with the food. The dishes were good but I expected top-notch from this SF institution. However, the service was excellent. Our waiter was very attentive, really understood the menu and recommended great wines to complement our meal. 

I think this restaurant caters more to expense accounts than to private diners.  Overall, the restaurant was consistent and solid but not very inventive and intimate.
author: D. P.

description:
Service was, of course, superb.  Starters - I had scallops (yum...which is bog standard for scallops) and my sister had the soup (yum for soup).  My lamb was actually a chore to eat.  It was difficult to cut (my kingdom for a scalpel!) and was neither juicy nor flavorful.  I had better lamb at Firefly for goodness sake!

But then we had dessert.  I will forever have a place in my heart for the brioche pudding.  Because we are fiends, we decided to have second desserts.  My goat cheese cream "pie" wasn't as delicate as I'd hoped it would be.

Stars for great, friendly service and brioche pudding.
author: Christine C.

description:
Boulevard has always had a warm spot for me and thats probably why its still my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Chef Nancy Oaks has always been on the California cuisine scene and not because she is a woman, but because she is one of the first.

The decor is VERY romantic and very French inside. The food is Nancy's ever changing interpretation on fresh Californian. As you expect with upscale places like these, the menu is always changing, but with one difference. Nancy always keeps a different version of her pork chop and the soft shell crab on her menu. Which works for me since those are my 2 favorite things to order there and I don't deviate since its always a bit different everytime. Service is always impeccable and friendly. Excellent wine list.

Those 2 dishes with a bottle of 1985 Roederer Cristal and a 1994 Leoville Las Casas. I was so happy the first time I was there that I almost proposed to my ex-girlfriend.
author: Xavier P.

description:
Went there with a party of 4 for an early dinner before a show. The service was amazing. There was almost always someone at or near our table to respond to requests. They aren't pushy and intrusive though, just attentive and friendly. The waitstaff is also very  good about recommendations, and didn't steer us wrong. Although with the menu here I doubt there is anything you could order that would disappoint.

The menu at this place is not just about the featured items but all the thought and care that goes into creating the plates. Of the items that I ordered I was just as excited about the accouterments as I was about the features.

Examples: the Dayboat Sea Scallops could stand on their own but the delicious savory salty pork belly and peppers that come with this starter bring it to a whole other level.

The Halibut is the freshest and is prepared perfectly..but we all know what halibut should taste like. The brandade stuffed squash blossom is amazing....I still dream about it.
author: Tony P.

description:
Last night, I went to Boulevard for the first time with a few family members to celebrate my sister's 31st birthday. We were all excited - the hype and excitement over the restaurant is deafening - for some great food and wine.

Overall, the experience was pretty fantastic. The ambiance is amazing - even the christmas decorations were stunning - and you can tell right when you walk in the door that you're going to have an amazing culinary experience. I had the calamari for an appetizer and the filet for my entree. We all agreed that my filet was probably the best piece of meat any of us had had in a long time, and my sister's chicken was unbelievable too.

I would have to take off one star for the serving size. I understand this isn't a family-style portion restaurant, but the appetizers are just meant to be INDIVIDUAL appetizers (i.e. when you order the calamari, it's just three pieces, not a huge basket). Our waitress was wonderful, but the food was slow to come - we had to wait about 45 minutes for our appetizers and another 30 for our entrees. 

Everyone MUST try the desserts. The chocolate cake is still making my mouth water, and the rocky road sundae is ice cream perfection. As they knew it was my sister's birthday, the chef made a chocolate bar that said "Happy Birthday" in it and put it on the sundae for my sister. Perfection!

If you have some money to blow (and I mean at least $100/person), I'd definitely recommend trying Boulevard. I'd suggest setting aside at least 2 hours for this experience. You'd be amiss to dine-and-dash.

Also, if you are trying for a Friday or Saturday night reservation, don't be shocked when they tell you they are booked up for the next two months. Plan early!
author: David P.

description: I have been a Boulevard fan since they opened.  Last night I treated my son, his girlfriend and my boyfriend.  Again, they outdid themselves in customer service.  The waiter was wonderful, but not hovering.  The appetizers shine here, and suggest doing a few of them with a dessert.  The salad I had was so,so, mixed green a few dollops of (blue) with 2 really  unripened apricots.  The scallops however were excellent along with the foie gras.  Usually I find the desserts to be spectacular, but in the last few years they seem a bit tired and fussy.  I would definitely go back despite the "paying for parking" yuck factor.
author: Heather P.

description:
I went there last night with a friend who took me out for my birthday. Wow!
This has to b e one of the best places in the city.
Everything from appetizers to dessert was first class including the service.
Wonderful choices for appetizers incl.many crab dishes and foi gras.
Sea Bass with mushrooms and oven baked endive is a must try.
What a nice evening !
author: Maria C.

description:
Okay.  So the food was good.  I will give it that.  Solid ingredients.  Good flavors. 

I guess that I had just heard so much about this place beforehand and at no point in time was I surprised or impressed by the dishes in front of me.  

Also was not super happy with the decor...sort of felt like a very classy Cheesecake Factory.  Perhaps the progenitor of the Cheesecake Factory.  

3.5 stars for brilliant mediocrity.
author: Justin H.

description:
This has got to be one of the best restaurant in San Francisco if not the best. Yes, it is expensive, but this place is a dinning experience not just a dinner. Our son, my husband, & myself spent 3 hours having dinner here a week ago on a Sunday night. The building itself has been beautifully restored. Take note! The staff personnel are excellent, friendly and very accommodating. We were seated at a very good table that looked out to the Bay. 
To start with, we had three starters, Ahi Tuna Tar-tare, Scallops, and a Dungeness Crab salad with avocado. All every good. Then for the entrees we ordered the Northern Halibut, Pacific Walu, & Pork Prime Rib chop. They change the silverware after each course. We finished the meal with with fresh black berries in a yogurt crust with ice cream. All so good!!!  Thank you, Boulevard, for an evening that we will not forget .
author: Darla B.

description:
Boulevard is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco - every meal is wonderful. 
I've been here 4 times now and each meal has been memorable.  This time I had duck wrapped in pancetta with ravioli starter - great!  The suggested wine pairings are always good here too.  Service all around is attentive and friendly, never pretentious.   

I love the ambiance here as I am a huge fan of art nouveau.  It sort of combines an elegant art nouveau decor with warm brick.  We usually get a booth which is comfortable and intimate.

I was wavering between 4 and 5 stars but I couldn't come up with any flaws in the meals we've had there - so 5 stars then.
author: S L.

description:
I have eaten here many tmes over the past several years and I have never had a bad experience nor even the slightest hint of dissatisfaction by felow diners.  I was dining with a group of 8 and most of the party arrived before our reservation time.  I ordered a Grey Goose on the Rocks with olives "a little dirty".  As the bartender brought my drink he alerted me to the fact that the olives had pits and also provided a very small bowl for the pits.  I guess he knew I was the kind of person that would spit the pits onto the floor or toss them in a dinner that was passing by, so I gave him points for recognizing problem diners/drinkers.  The olives with pits surprised me since every other drink I have had with olives always came pitted.  Was I surprised when I tasted the olive, as it was the freshest and most flavorful olive I have ever had.  Remarkably delicious!


When we were seated at our dinner table we were promptly met by our professional server.  And I mean professional in every sense of the word.  This gentleman knew his stuff from the extensive wine list to each and every dish on the menu.  I started with a simple Mixed Geeens Salad with apple slices, sliced gorgonzola cheese, candied walnuts and a delicious light but distinctively flavored vinagrette dressing.  A quarter loaf of  sour dough bread was put at each end of the table with small tubs of butter that had sea salt sprinkled on the top.  I had a view of the bread station from my seat and do they ever go through bread.  Tons of it!  When I tasted it I discovered why.  The sour dough bread was delicious with a great crunchy crust.  We ordered two bottles of Pride 2006 Cabernet (remember it was a party of 8) which was recommended by a member of our group and no one was disappointed and at $160  a bottle it was well worth the price.  I had an incredible pan seared halibut dish that had a sauce that was even more delicious than the fish itself.  Other diners' selections at our table included Filet Mignon, Lobster Tail, Veal, etc. and everyone raved about the perfection of all dishes.  We asked for another bottle of Pride Cab, but were told we had the last two bottles.  We then ordered two more bottles of Nickel & Nickel Cab (which is a Far Niente "related" wine at a fraction of the cost) at $150 per bottle and as superb as the Pride Cab was this was even better!

Ordinarily I do not eat dessert after a late night meal, however, since I was catching a flight back to LAX at 10:43 pm, I figured the energy (or sugar high) would be good for me.  I had a chocolate dessert that was recommended by our server that had a multitude of textures and incredible rich chocolate flavor that was a delight to my already satisfied taste buds.

You have to try this great restaurant when you have the chance.  It is a dining pleasure.  Oh and I forgot to say the atmosphere is fabulous with great lighting and plenty of rich wood and colors all around.
author: John E.

description: really great place! great atmosphere, elegant, and great location. our table was right by the window and we could see all of the piers. I started off with the ravioli, which was okay, but then had the salmon with risotto which was amazing! dessert was the cherry ice cream sandwich, and it was a very elegant take on a fun dessert. I will definitely be back!!
author: Julia M.

description: My BFF & I had dinner tonite & the food was absoluitely delish.  The server as cute as can be, was perfection when it came to service.  He suggested the best wine without being pushy.  My BFF & I don't see each other so frequently but this dinner was close to perfection when it came to the excellence of the dishes we ordered, which was lamb & halibut.  Started with excellent choices of cocktail drinks, a great Cab by the glass which deserved an encore and ended with a lite but delish dessert of Irish creme balls icecream.  No contens why this restaurant is for keeps!!!
author: Evelyn B.

description: Great food and service!  We go to the Boulevard every summer when we visit my daughter in SF.  The service last time was exceptional. The waiter made very effort to accommodate our requests.  He brought special desserts, one to celebrate my daughter moving in with her boyfriend, and the other one to celebrate my boyfriend's nephew who had just moved to SF.
author: Vivian M.

description:
Now this is what I call having the whole package - Service, Decor, Style and Food!  This place is beautiful, all the staff, even the hostess were warm and not haughty at all.  The manager often walked the floor checking with his wait staff and the patrons.  Being able to view the cooking was actually an enjoyable experience for once, the kitchen flow was like a well synchronized dance - everyone knew their place, there was no shouting, banging or dirtiness.  

I was extremely impressed with our server.  We were here for my mom's birthday and one member of our party had a difficult time getting to the restaurant, actually took over 45 minutes to arrive after we were seated!  Our server was so accommodating, she never made us feel bad for the delay, she never rushed us, but rather made our time enjoyable and comforting.  She suggested we enjoy some beverages for a time and chat until our guest arrived, she answered our questions and guided us through the menu nicely.  When our guest still hadn't arrived, she took our appetizer orders and we ordered one for our missing guest.  By the time we got our appetizer and ate it, our guest still wasn't there.  The server came back and said she was going to have the chef remake the appetizer (it was scallops) so that they will be fresh and ready when our guest came.  Mind you we didn't even request that, because we didn't want to inconvenience them already..she took the initiative and she didn't just have the kitchen re-heat the meal, but they gave us a new one completely.  Our guest arrived and the meal went perfectly.

The desert course was wonderful and we were sitting at a table right by the desert chef, so it was fun to watch him plate and arrange the deserts throughout the night.  My mom by far had the best desert it was a strawberry key lime tart with margarita granita on top - just wonderful.  The whole experience was beautiful.
author: Erin A.

description:
This place was great and the service was outstanding. A little bit pricey for what they offer, but the employees make up that deficiency. Nice menu, great desserts, and overall a very nice San Francisco experience. 

well done
author: Kelly K.

description: It was ok. Nothing special.   The food was mediocre and the server acted like we were bothering her when we needed water refilled.  They do not do take out!
author: Chip H.

description: My first experience here was ok only because of the service. We did not get a waiter who paid attention to us. The food was great but for some reason I felt that we were rushed to order everything and get out to top it all off the waiter spent more time with the larger group than our group. For the price that we paid we should have been treated equally.
author: madi b.

description: Lovely place, wonderful ambiance and a client of mine actually supplies them with local honey!  Definitely a marvelous place to go for special occasions or just want an occasion to treat yourself.
author: Alacrity I.

description: I've been to a lot of the best eateries here in SF, and Boulevard ranks among the best of the best in my book. Lovely atmosphere, excellent service, and most importantly that "ahhhh" moment when you taste food that is truly to die for.
author: Kristen P.

description: We had a great time at the Boulevard just waiting for our food sitting at the bar watching all the different kinds of food coming from the kitchen look great. The bartender was nice and the people around us were pleasant. We will be back soon keep up the great smile it does make a different.
author: Yoen K.

description: Delicious food, lovely ambiance, and great selection of wines by the glass.... makes me happy. Not much of a view and sometimes the bar tenders were crabby, but over all a relaxed delight.
author: Kaethe S.

description: Prompt, professional service.  Well executed dishes.  Lovely atmosphere (I absolutely love the brick ceiling).
author: Lester B.

description: My last visit was okay, not a lot of veggie options but this did make an off the menu dish for me that was really nice, dessert was good but again not a lot of choices for vegi or vegan would be great if they could expand the menu to include these option, I have only been there for lunch so not sure about dinner menu
author: Chloe W.

description: Another great meal at Boulevard. This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. The food and service are both great and you cannot go wrong with any item on the menu. I highly recommend it for date nights or lunch with clients.
author: Courtney T.

description:
Really, I should write a much longer review, given the number of times I've had a truly wonderful experience at this SF institution.  This is only my second Yelp review, and Boulevard just comes to mind as my favorite place to dine, especially if someone is taking me there.

Yes, I am in the restaurant biz myself--I have been for over 20 years, and 15 of those years have been waiting tables at many of the City's other great restaurants.  Why I've never worked at Boulevard--I guess I'd like to save it for a purely fun place.  And because I've been around the block in this biz, perhaps I do get the insider treatment, but hey people--it's one of the few perks of a truly backbreaking burnout prone profession.

But let me recount with glory past meals of Crispy Quails, Veal Oscar, (modernised, soo delicious), Lamb Tenderloin, Corn and Scallop Soup...everything kind of recedes into a warm twinkly glow of gracious service and rich, honest, satisfying food.  

It's the kind of place where I dress up maybe as a favorite movie character ala Audrey Hepburn or Jane Birkin or Charlotte Rampling, and have a handsome fellow take me out for a 3 hour lunch.  This is NOT a place for a rushed pre-theatre dinner or 45-minute chicken caesar lunch.  This IS a place to order Champagne--before splurging on an elegant Burgundy to pair with the Duck or the Veal with Mushrooms.  

A place to ask your waiter to give you a rest between entree and dessert, so that you can build up the strength to order a cheese course as well, and linger over espressos and Eau de Vies.  (Or maybe Calvados)

Perhaps because I *do* know how to dine here, and I *am* able to cultivate relationships with the mgmt and staff, this review is so positive.  But you need not toil in the restaurant biz like I have to achieve this--if only more diners knew how absolutely thrilled restaurateurs are to pamper interested, engaging customers.  

If you love a restaurant, make yourself known to the staff and the managers with a warm thank you and flat out ask them to put a note by your reservation record of how much you liked your meal. Believe me, the next time you return, you'll be royalty.  (And you don't have to spend like a king to be treated like one.)
author: Andrea W.

description:
This used to be a solid five star sort of place for me.  I don't  know if it was an off night or if something has changed.
Nothing was terrible but nothing was great either.  Not exactly what we were looking for.
Very nice wine list and service was good.
author: jesse e.

description:
One of the best restaurants in the City.  If you are taking your top client out for lunch, this is the place to go.  Had a great steak!

They also have a great private room downstairs if you are entertaining a group.  Recently had a great business meeting in their basement setting.
author: Todd S.

description:
The food gets 4 stars, but the service only 2. 

This is the second time I've been--the first, I loved it, was so impressed and happy with my experience.

This time, the service was so slow that it really took away from the great food and beautiful atmosphere. I don't know if they were short-staffed or what, but the time between courses was very long. It took a while to get the order in, and then a while to get the starter (scallops, delicious and perfectly cooked despite the wait), and then the real waiting began. . . the entrees took forever to arrive (we finished the wine before they even got there). Then, we waited for a very long time for them to collect the plates once we were done. Once we ordered dessert, the coffee and port came out first, and the dessert almost 20 minutes later. I couldn't even enjoy my coffee with my dessert--come on, Boulevard! 

Bad or slow service really takes away from the guests' enjoyment of the meal. The best food is going to be tainted by having to wait for it too long, or stare at its leftovers on your table for 15 minutes. Maybe they need to increase staffing on their busy Friday nights or something.
author: Courtney M.

description:
Does anyone have anything bad to say about this place?  It does take a long time to be seated without a reservation...And the bathroom is a little far off.  But thats it!  

The location is great, the setup is nice, the wait staff is courteous, the bar is fully loaded and the food is the best part.

The great thing about Boulevard is that it is one of the few places I have been that ends up living up to the hype that it is given.  I think over the years, I have tried just about everything on their menu and have never felt even the slightest disappointment.   You can't really go wrong with anything there.  My personal favorite?  Dayboat Sea Scallops....
author: Gordon M.

description:
I came here for an organized, company sponsored thing, so I can't comment on the full menu. Although the food we received does appear to be straight off of the regular menu, so hopefully this is still helpful.

They were generous with the wine, and the Cabernet they were serving was quite good.

We started with the salad -- mixed greens with dressing, on top of poached pears, on top of a slice of procuitto. The procuitto was a nice surprise at the bottom, which is good cause the lettuce portion was only so-so.

I had the filet with potatoes. The steak was perfectly cooked, and the potatoes were good. This was the best dish of the meal.

I ended with some sort of apple-based dessert with brown sugar ice cream. It was okay, but not great. I wish I had chosen the chocolate one, instead. 

I'd love to come back as a "regular diner", because this place has nice potential as a special occasion dinner venue.
author: Kellie P.

description:
Organic, local, sustainable ingredients!
For such a late seating mid-week, the evening was lively and the 2,5 hours passed quickly.  Alisha took our drink order of Kir Royale and sparkling water.  She was friendly and knowledgeable.  Service was attentive and unobtrusive.  My wife and I like to play the folded napkin test where, if one of us leaves the table, and any of the wait staff fold the napkin before return to the table it passes the test.  It passed.  

Nancy Oakes' menu is diverse and is made of local and organic ingredients:  California squab (best I've ever had even compared to Le Louis XV's in Monaco), we pleaded with Alisha to make sure the chef's keep this on the menu as it melted in our mouth with each bite; Dixon rack of lamb (I chomped on the bones); Sonoma Foie gras (seared just right and not over done); Petrale sole (moist and crispy skin).  The temperature of the dishes were right on and the portions just right.

The warm bread was crusty and the inside light and airy, butter creamy.

The wines we chose were an 2004 Haven's Merlot Napa ($10,50/glass) and 2004 Scherrer Pinot Noir Russian River Valley ($17,50/glass).  Both stood up to the dishes and did not overpower any one of them.

To finish, the ice-cream sandwich and bon bon desserts were rich and chocolaty.  We ordered organic tea and coffee to accompany the dessert.

Boulevard shares the same building with the law office of former San Francisco Mayor's Willie Brown Jr.  The decorations were pleasing to the eyes.  The tables were spaced tightly to accommodate all the diners wanting in.  Now I know why there is a buzz about this restaurant.  The food and service was excellent.  It's one of San Francisco's finest restaurants.  I don't give out 5 stars easily.

My birthday (12/07) was night was well spent; and we'll be back.  One can't go wrong in choosing this place.
author: JOHN J.

description:
I felt very grownup dining here on Friday evening. My boyfriend and I got a last minute reservation and the table was waiting for us when we arrived. I love the architecture of this place (kudos to Kuleto) and the interior was very romantic. I am not sure I would want to be seated under the brick arc ceiling during an earthquake though. The one big contrast to the overall feel of the restaurant  would be the long walk to the restrooms downstairs in what appeared to be a different building.

I had read that the appetizers were exceptionally good, and I must agree that the crab stuffed calamari was delicious. In fact, that might have been my favorite dish. We ordered a bottle of pinot gris (Etude) and had entrees of local petrale sole and Atlantic black bass. The food arrangement was nice but a little misleading; my sole was folded in half making it taller and I had four fingerling potatoes lined up on the side, but my initial thought was that it was like that Citibank commercial where the man says the food is like elf food. However, when I began eating the dish, the meal easily filled me up. And both fish dishes were tres yummy.

For dessert we opted for a citrus plate with lemon sherbet. I think all of our selections complemented each other and really made the meal a memorable one.

We did the "guess the bill" game before opening the bill wallet. We both actually overguessed the amount, which turned out to still be the most expensive meal the two of us has eaten together (about $160 for a bottle of wine, app, 2 entrees, and a dessert).
author: Lori G.

description:
I really wanted to give Boulevard 5 stars, but I had to remove one for the service- it was quite average. 

Fois Gras with strawberries - to die for
Short Ribs - delicious, melt in your mouth (potato risotto was kinda odd with pockets of salt here and there, but I understand what they're going for with the texture)
Crepes with Blackberries - eh. crepes were ok, but the almond semifreddo- I could swim in it, I loved it so much. And that's coming from a lady who doesn't like frozen treats (i.e. ice cream)

Everyone should go at least once - it's DELICIOUS!
author: Samantha S.

description:
This is a good restaurant for business or a social lunch.  I was just here for a client lunch.  The atmosphere is quite nice and conversations are easy to carry at the well spaced tables.  The service was good, we never saw the bottom of our water and coffee.

I had the lobster bisque, dungeness crab salad, and the cherry and aprium crisp.  Everything was tasty, although I must admit the crab salad was not quite what I expected.  It consisted of slices of avocado topped with pieces of crab and surrounded by a few slices of baby cucumber and the lemon vinaigrette.  It was good, but I was imagining something a little more salad-like.

The portion sizes seemed small, however, I left feeling very full and couldn't even finish my dessert.  The meal was pricey, probably not a place I would come to on my own dime.  There are definitely many other restaurant choices with excellent food for this price range.
author: Angela O.

description:
A wonderful friend treated me and three friends to dinner here Monday night. Even on a Monday the dining room was packed and rightfully so. The ambiance at this Michelin rated restaurant is Art Nouveau and, with its flowery and sensual interior, reminded me instantly of the work of Alfonse Mucha. 

With a wonderful wine list, we started with a New Zealand white. Our waiter Dennis recommended the scallops, beet and goat cheese raviolle  and fig salad. All were wonderful but the standout was the thickly stuffed and uniquely flavored pasta.  For my main course, I chose the "reliable" filet mignon. It was the best steak I have ever eaten. Perfectly cooked, huge piece accompanied by bacon wrapped potatoes, fresh spinach and finely textured morel mushrooms.

Usually at upscale eateries, the desert course blows everything else out of memory. Here, it wasn't so. My "doughnut" was very tasty but that meat is the memory I take away from Boulevard.

Pricey but worth it if someone else is fronting the bill :)
author: Jessica M.

description:
This is not the sort of place to drop in, especially with a group of 7, but that's what we did the other night. They made room for us and gave us the usual excellent service. We had two superb bottles of wine and some fabulous main plates.

This was my 6th or 7th visit here; always a great experience, one of the absolute best restaurants in the City.
author: vinay d.

description:
Atmosphere 4-stars
Bar/Bartender 3-stars (no personality or sense of humor oh well)
Our table 5-stars (elevated at the rear of the rest. with a great view )
Server 5-stars
Food: Starter 2-Stars (Wild Boar Farm Heirloom Tomatoes etc. OK lacked that little extra bit of flavor - bland)
Wine: 4 Stars (good selection)
Food: Main Course 4 Stars (Berkshire Pork Chops from Ohio - Delicious)
Overall dining experience 4 Stars ( I will be back sometime soon)
author: Joe C.

description: Always a good time. Great food, solid service and a quality scene. If I had one recommendation for improvement it would be that the wine list is a bit overpriced for the selection. Overall I would highly recommend Boulevard for a high end dining experience.
author: David W.

description: As a Partner for a Big 4 firm, I used to love this place, I've even hosted large parties in their private room downstairs....until Friday night 8/28.  What a disaster.  The server didn't fill our water unless asked, we watched as the fresh bread was cut only to have it served long after the appetizers showed up, the food was bland and unimaginative, and worse, they are now charging a 4% special upcharge to provide healthcare coverage for their employees.  I have advised my firm and partners NEVER to take clients here again.  Huge let down.  And the server "Francesca", reminded me of the disingenuous and phony, and uber-uptight waitress in the movie "Waiting", if you've seen that cult classic.
author: Clammy M.

description:
The Set Up:  We went to Boulevard last night for my birthday.  The food was good.  However, two women were seated next to us shortly after we arrived.  One said nothing, ordered nothing and drank nothing.  The other woman was clearly intoxicated.  Upon arriving she spilled her martini on her friend so they got her another one.  She spoke very loudly and every other word was an expletive or crude statement. I am not exagerating.  Call the Manager, Adam Volpe, to confirm.  At first we found it amusing but she never stopped, and her friend never said a word.  She just continued a loud monologue of F this, MFing that, piece of S&*# that, talking about mens' penises, etc...  The bus boy, waiter and manager each came over to her on different occasions and she was asked to be quieter at least four times to no avail.  She then complained that she had ordered another drink but it never arrived (because they obviously cut her off).  Our waiter apologized many times and said we would be taken care of.  The manager also came over and apologized but did nothing else except finally offer to move us to a "quieter" table when we were almost through our entrees, but we were polite and declined.  When we left I let my wife go ahead and I told off the obnoxious woman about how foul mouthed, rude and inconsiderate she was.  Her response was "Who the F#*& are you!"  Other patrons waiting at the valet commented to us about the situation so they obviously heard her during their dinner.

The Question:  What should the restaurant have done?  If they asked her to leave she very likely would have made a scene.  Apparently they were unable to move us until we were almost done with dinner.  Should we have punished our waiter with the tip?  We chose not to.  While they said they would take care of us all they did was comp one dessert and our port, which amounted to 15% of a $300 bill.  I thought they would have at least comped us either the appatizers, the entrees or the wine.  At that point I just wanted to get out of there.  Now I am upset that I paid $300 to have a terrible time and the celebration ruined.
author: mildew w.

description: Great place to for business dinners and excellent wine list.
author: Jason H.

description:
we were in town visiting, and were able to get into Boulevard.  

In all of the years' of sporadically working in the bay area, I somehow never got to this gem, and after eating there -- my husband and I both wondered how we could totally miss the "target"?  Wow. 

Seriously, it was one of the best meals we've had this year.  We ordered the lobster bisque, foie gras to start = amazing,, and the rest of the dinner only got better....

Highly recommend and look forward to returning.
author: Zoie W.

description: This is my favorite place to have dinner in the city.  The food is amazing and the view is pretty sweet.  The service could have been a bit better but Ive been back and back so Im not complaining
author: Nadeem H.

description:
we had an OK/forget-able and very expensive meal here. frankly, i would never go out of my way to return. 

however, the most disturbing thing to us was what a dump the place was - it's filthy. the carpets are horribly stained and the bathroom was gross. the service here was good but it seem very overstaffed with wait staff awkwardly standing around.
author: Paul O.

description: One of the best place for seared Filet Mignon in the Bay Area.  Worth the money.  Not crazy about parking, but there is the $10 valet parking - given the amount of money I spend there they should validate this.
author: John L.

description: I have had amazing meals here for the past 2 decades. Each menu offering is a work of art. The portions seem small when you get served,but for me it is just the right amount. You need to save yourself room for dessert. They have wondeful cocktails and a huge wine list. The atmosphere is uplifting and happening. I love Boulevard.
author: Barry G.

description: Come here for business lunch all the time but we tend to have much better experience for dinner and after work drinks. Restroom  tucked all way downstairs with elevator access is a little inconvenient.. I remember being pregnant and had to go 3 times in one dinner seating...not all that fun. food is great and views are excellent of course. But be prepared that  there are typically 2 types of crowds there: business or old money!
author: Ada W.

description:
I am still thinking about last night's foie gras... The moment we stepped into Boulevard one of the staff greeted us as if we were long-time friends. We arrived 15 minutes earlier than our reservation, but they seated us right away. After looking over the extensive menu, I was torn between about 5 different appetizers, but I decided on the foie gras. I knew that I would have to hit the gym on a daily basis for the next few weeks to compensate for the amount of calories I was about to consume, but the foie gras was well worth it. I would become a regular at the gym, in fact, if it meant that I could enjoy the Boulevard's foie gras once again! It was of course extremely rich, the texture was wonderfully buttery, and absolutely delightful served atop a crisp mellow flavored biscotti. The dish was paired with a lovely tart sauce, and the tomatoes on the side were so sweet and juicy they tasted someone like plums. I've never had such fresh tomatoes in my life.
For my main, I ordered the lamb of course, and as the world's biggest lamb fanatic, I was not disappointed. It was perfectly cooked, with a slightly burnt (I love that smoky burnt flavor of crispness) on the outside, and the inside was a beautiful pink color. The fat fell right off the meat as I trimmed it off. Also, I was surprised at the generous portion of this dish as such high class restaurants tend to serve very small portions; I had 3 large chunks on lamb on my plate. As with the foie gras, the accompanying flavors of the dish just blew me away. In the sauce, there was a hint of olives, goat cheese, so many interesting textures. I could eat that dish all day and discover a new combination of flavors with every bite.
For dessert, I had a cinnamon brioche topped with apple sorbet, paired with vanilla ice cream, raspberry sauce, and blackberries. The sorbet was so crisp, flavorful, and perfectly icy that I could have had that alone as a dessert. While the brioche was cold (I was expecting a hot dessert) and a bit dryer than normal, the vanilla and raspberry sauce paired perfectly with the brioche as the brioche eventually absorbed the moistness of the ice cream and sauce. The composition of the dish was beautiful, I suppose my only complain is that I had to construct so much of the dessert myself. (I am so impatient when it comes to dessert - I wish I could immediately inhale the entire dish rather than carefully put it together myself)
The reason that I am not giving 5 stars after my incredibly lovely dinner is that my friend's salmon was overly salty and someone overcooked. While I did not try the dish complete with the sides, which I'm sure would have made up for the salmon, the salmon alone I definitely could not have eaten an entire plate of.
While the prices are certainly very high, I would definitely return for another night of elegance and extravagance. Also, the Boulevard is not one of those pretentious restaurants where normal people (like myself) would feel extremely uncomfortable among snobbish rich people. I noticed a very diverse crowd last night - businessmen, teenage couples, older couples... Take your girlfriend, boss, mom, ANYONE for a night out here and I guarantee they will appreciate you 1298301328 times more.
author: Shawna C.

description: I have been to SF several times, and I have not had a better meal than dinner at the Boulevard.  The pork chop was cooked perfectly.  The lobster/scallop dish was excellent as well.  Its not cheap(dinner for 2 with 2 drinks about $170.00) but if you are into fine-dining this place will not disappoint!!  Reservations for dinner a must!!
author: Tyrone H.

description: One of my favorite places to eat in SF!  If you are in town you have to stop by and eat, even if it's at the bar.  You might have the best seat in the house because you can watch the cooks in action.  Highly recommended!!
author: Mira M.

description:
culinary girl boner.

my boyfriend took me for my birthday dinner.....i had no idea where we were going.
we first discovered them at couchon 555 and they should have been the winner hands down.

so once i popped out of the cab and saw where i was going i think i squeeled. i knew right away no matter what i wanted pork. 

we were sat instantly. it was dark but enough light so i could see who was around and soak in all the color and texture on the walls and floor. 

everything i read on the menu i wanted. it was hard to narrow down things. if i was capable of eating like a 600 lb person i would have had one of everything.

everything blew me away. the cocktails dangerously delicious. the waiters wine choices spot on. 

i even had a candle in my desert and he gave us an extra pour of a scotch we had never tried. 

i guess if i had one complaint it would be the dress ...people. people. people. this isnt cheesecake factory. its not a sports bar. guys in popped collars with hats im talking to you. 

throw something nice on..a dress. a tie something besides baggy ass jeans and a hoody. 

cant wait to go back.
author: dawn a.

description: I feel that everyone is so overawed by the place that nobody dares to say a bad word about it. Two nights ago we had a pretty iffy dinner with an iffy waiter and a massive bill. 1 bottle of ok wine, no cocktails, 300 dollars. Sent a polite note to the general manager-not a peep. Mind you the Roman Empire didn't think it could ever start sliding on a slippery slope. Would be a great pity because until now they have been fine.
author: andrew f.

description: Oh my Lord, my mouth watered for 3 days after eating their chicken(?) squab plate.  Sooo delicious.  This is a special, upscale place in downtown SF.  I took some clients here to entertain, and the food was out of this world.  Service could have been more attentive at this stature of a restaurant, but the cuisine definitely compensates.  I would like to return here when I entertain in the Bay Area again.
author: Lynda A.

description: They have a really nice atmosphere here.  I think the food is just okay; it's nothing terribly inventive.
author: Julie S.

description: My wife and I went to Boulevard last night to celebrate our 30th Wedding Anniversary.  We don't often go to such expensive restaurants, but this was a very special occasion.  The food was all extremely good, and the service was impeccable.  I highly recommend Boulevard.
author: Bernard H.

description: Boulevard is only blocks away from my office which makes me a frequent visitor due to the convenient location. This restaurant has once again been awarded a Michelin star for 2011 and is definitely better than the One Market Restaurant. I love everything they serve at the restaurant. In particularly, I would like to recommend their Kurobuta Pork Short Rib and American Kobe Bavette.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Came here with my boss on a Tue night, and it blew us away!!!!

Food : 5 Stars
Service: 5 Stars
Wine: 4.5 Stars

Tuna Tartare - perfect !
Palm heart and avocado salad, roasted hazelnut, black truffle - best palm heart i have ever had. 

Lamb T-bone grilled on the bone, served off the bone- OMG!!!!!   Crispy skin, minimal fat, tender meat. Had it with a glass of Chateaunueff du Pape. YUM YUM YUM.

We will be back.
author: richard y.

description: just went there for my 50th- got the corner seat bay bridge views and rock star treatment- it's rare, at least in my experience, to get the big 3 all at once- great food, great service, and great ambiance- boulevard has all 3 and you can see why it's been a SF favorite and has stood the test of time...don't remember waiters name but he was a bald guy with a gruff voice- great personality, honesty, spot on recommendations and perfect timing...we had lamb, pork chops, steak and ravs- winter salad and crab -all were delicious and desserts were all fantastic...i've been to a lot of restaurants many that cost just a much or more and not been nearly as happy- forgot to mention portion size perfect - as i told them on the way out- i'll be back soon...
author: Robert H.

description:
I am not a food critic. But I do love good food and fine dining and Boulevard was both! This was my first visit to Boulevard based the recommendation of a SF foodie friend of mine. 
I wanted romantic and I got it. It is warm and inviting.
I wanted a fine dining experience and I got it.
We ordered the lamb off the bone and my date ordered the lobster.  Wonderful flavors ...NOT over seasoned nor over cooked which means it was wonderful! 
Portions are adequate but this is not the place you go to overload your belly. If you arrive hungry I suggest one appetizer per diner in your party. 
The service is fantastic. They have valet parking which was about $12 for evening and it can be added to your bill. 
Sadly we had to jet out before dessert to get to another engagement. 
Go for the relaxed atmosphere and fine dining experience. If you drink wine with your meal expect your tab to near $80-100 per person including the tip that is. 
We will be back!
author: Robin D.

description:
We had a lunch reception with just family and friends - maybe 12 of us. They gave us a private room which has an incredible atmosphere. They also keep a wide selection of wine in this room, so we were worried that we might be bothered by waiters walking in and out to get wine. Not at all. And food was just delicious. Crab cake and Squid with Thai curry sauce .. yummm. Fish was soooo fresh. They are not only good at seafood because  I remember having a piece of steak melting in my mouth. 

I'll take my date here for a romantic spot any time.
author: Uarporn N.

description:
I've lived in SF for almost 8 years and I finally made it to Boulevard with my boyfriend last weekend.  I am a foodie and I thought that the food was excellent, but that the experience was marred by the service.

We had to make our reservation 3 weeks in advance and could only get a 9:00pm res.  OK, we thought, because that will decrease the likelyhood of having annoying children in the restaurant.  However, when we got there (on time) we had to wait at the bar for 20 minutes before we were seated next to a table with a newborn. (Thankfully they were just lingering over coffee and we only had to deal with the baby for a few minutes.)

It took 10 minutes for the server to come and introduce herself and another 10 for bread and water.  We really felt neglected at times, not a good thing in a restaurant of this caliber.

Ok for the food.  I will admit that it was excellent.  We did skip appetizers and just focused on the entrees and dessert.  I had the wild seared salmon on a bed of cream corn with rock shrimp.  It was one of the best preparations of salmon I've had.  A nice crispy crust from the sear that was well seasoned and under that, a very velvety fillet. Everything from the texture to the seasoning was spot on.  For dessert I had the figs in balsamic with baklava ice cream.  I've never had anything llike it. Very light and refreshing, but bold at the same time.

Was it worth it?  The food was wonderful, but the service was so dissapointing, that I have a hard time justifying the cost of the meal.  I doubt that we ill go back anytime soon.  There are just so many more places with wonderful food and better service at a fraction of the cost.
author: Brett H.

description:
Boulevard was more lively and fun than I thought. At first glance, it seems like the kind of restaurant where diners talk quietly and talking to your server is awkward. But everyone was chatting casually without glancing around to see if they're being too loud! 

Ginger martini--not bad, not the best cocktail I've ever had. We had the tuna tartare appetizer--my first time eating raw fish so I'm not a very good judge but it had flavors of ginger on fried taro or something. I had the salmon--an absolutely gorgeous fillet, it was like velvet. He had the suckling pig prepared three ways--one was great, one was good, one was meh. Our cotes du rhone wine was awesome, their wine list is probably the reason I would go back. For dessert we each had a bon bon that was vanilla ice cream dipped in chocolate on top of a chocolate covered mini pretzel--SO good. We also had the sticky toffee pudding which was definitely the highlight of the meal. For 2 cocktails, 1 bottle of wine, 1 appetizer, 2 entrees, and 2 desserts, it was $150 which is not that bad! We were there for 3 hours.

Service was perfect--the hostess was totally down to earth, sweet, the bartenders were no nonsense, and our server was the perfect balance between polite and unpretentious or rude.
author: Abbie B.

description:
The service is very good but the food is very inconsistent.  Most people go this restaurant because of their reputation and location.  I guess some people can justify to themselves that this place is worth it.  

But I stopped patronizing this place because I never knew if I was going to get a good meal or a forgettable mea.
author: Rene M.

description:
This is one of my Top 5 restaurants in SF!!!  From the ambiance, service, to the food & wine a 10 out of 10 all the way around.
The only negative I would have is that we were seated right at the front of the Restaurant, so people who were waiting to be seated were basically standing right next to our table.

Their Caprese Salad was amazing, FRESH Buffalo Mozzarella, ripe thick juicy tomatoes and a nice balsamic vinaigrette.  

For my Entree I had the Halibut and it was one of the best cooked pieces of Halibut I've ever had.
