This place attracts a lot of the 'older crowd' My Fiancee and I are both in our 20s and we felt at least 20 years younger than almost everyone in the place.
author: Gurdeep J.

description:
If you're on company expense...this place is truly amazing.

We love everything they have to offer- from the crab to the abalone. Delicious...

We have had everything on the menu on various times here, and it is incredible- the only thing to differeniate at this point is the wine list.

And the wine list is incredible- you will love everything.

My recommonedation is that you come here if you have a company expense account or if you like to burn through cash!!
author: Chuck H.

description: This place was quite fancy and the food was wonderful.  Service was pretty good, too.  I started with a fried soft shell crab which was only ok but then had quail and squab as an entree.  Both were somewhat rare and exquisitely prepared.  The figs on the side were a nice touch.  For dessert, I had a chocolate cherry smore which was so decadent and rich.  I would definitely go back here!
author: Lisa C.

description:
my wife and i were excited to dine here for our first anniversary.  We have been to most of the top spots in SF but not Boulevard.  We started with the heirloom tomato salad which had some wonderful mozzarella and ricotta cheeses and also a ravioli dish- we started with a glass of Pinot and then a Lambert Bridge zinfandel (by the glass)- apps were very good,  We ordered filets, medium for dinner- the entire time we had a bottle of 2001 Silver Oak Alexander Valley Cab decanting- brought this from house a $25 corkage at fine establishments is cheap- so far, so tasty.....and then it comes to a crashing halt.  Our filets are served with a tasty looking corn dish, full of taste/peppery/savory and then a french version of potato skin- overcooked potato wedge with a stinky cheese somewhat melted over the top- somewhere bacon got brought in as an attempt to save the skin. no such luck- but wait....our filets are GRAY in color! are you kidding me- I have to send back a filet at Boulevard- ok, I will try and get over this- try number- but mediocre at best- Silver Oak was saving the meal )we are laughing at this point(we see the lighter side of life)- so we decide to order dessert- we ordered 3 desserts (just to sample) and not one of them was better than getting a pint of Cherry Garcia out  of my freezer at home!  Our server was more than embarrased by the entree disaster and removed the corkage fee/plus desserts from bill.

Not even in my Top 10 in SF- mediocre at best
author: Scott W.

description:
The food was only okay, which is not acceptable considering the price and hype surrounding this place. I had the $36 pork chop, which was fairly plain and flavorless. 

But what really struck me was the lack of effort to make the meal special. I regularly eat at restaurants ranked at this level, and there's usually an attempt to add something extra to the dining experience... since the price is substantially extra compared to other places.

Here there are no amuse bouches or little finishes like after-dinner chocolates or bites. I know this place is wildly popular and doesn't have to try very hard to fill its seats. It shows.
author: Dave B.

description: Service was 5 stars plus!  This was a night to remember due to Nathan our server. It started with recommendations for a cocktail, he suggested the Sidecar which was new to me, it was perfect.  I did not have my reading glasses so Nathan brought me a tray of four to choose from.  His way of recommending entrees was entertaining.  We choose the scallops and sweet bread. The scallops were my favorite.  I also had the salmon which was outstanding.  Nathan brought us a little after dinner treat which was perfect.  To end the evening we found him at the curb holding the door to our taxi!  Now that is service!
author: Tami B.

description: One of the finest restaurants in the Bay area. Great selection of items on the menu & wine list. Platings were nicely done & correctly sized encouraging patrons to order appetizers, main course & dessert.
author: J Z.

description:
If zero stars were available, that's what I would rate this kitchen because I prefer NOT to have shells in my Louisiana blue crab salad.  Imagine me, sitting in formal company and spitting into my napkin because shells bits were in each bite.  Yuck!

I'm not sure why I was so discreet.  Perhaps to be polite?  Instead, I decided to email the restaurant and tell them what happened.  No response.  Terrible customer service.  Will not return!
author: Don T.

description: Boulevard is, hands down, the best meal I have had in a long time. The space itself is beautifully arranged and lit -- the décor very belle époque-esque -- making for a lovely ambience and dining experience. Our server was so friendly and attentive; she could not have been nicer. We started with the Italian burrata and heirloom tomato salad, which was very fresh; my companions also shared the Maine lobster pyramid ravioli, which they really enjoyed. I do not typically eat seafood, pork or beef (adventurous, I know!), but I settled on the Alaskan Halibut -- and I have seen the light! It. was. delicious., not to mention beautifully presented. Tender, light, and so flavorful...the lemon sauce was the perfect complement. I also thoroughly enjoyed the fried green tomato and white corn. The portions are a good size, and adequately filling -- but they are probably small by American restaurant standards. Bottom line: So delicious, I was still thinking about it the next day. I will definitely be back!
author: Katie M.

description: Woohoo - This is as good as it gets! I have had some of the most amazing dinners and dining experiences at Boulevard. Important events have been celebrated here, including my graduation and 22nd birthday combination dinner. The word wow just comes to mind about the food, the service, the ambiance, the wine list, the design, the overall dining experience, everything. Not to oversell it, but honestly Nancy Oakes has made Boulevard one of the best restaurants in the Bay Area, if not the country. Nancy Oakes got her start in the City at Pat O'Sheas Mad Hatter and thank god she has kept her roots here!
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Boulevard...... I have thought of coming here for a really long time! I'm pretty sure my mom said she was going to take me here after I graduated from HS but that never happened. Anyhoo, nice restaurants for special occasions- I took L here for a nice Friday lunch since she got into 2 of the top 3 law schools! 
We started off with ridiculously expensive cocktails (TGIF starts at noon ;)). We got a sidecar and something fruity (I forgot), but the drinks were $13-16 as it normally is at upscale restaurants. For our appetizer, we got the infamous ahi tuna tartare. It was very fresh and unique due to nori chips that came with it. We quickly ran out of chips, but eating the tuna is just like eating sashimi.
L got the dayboat scallops with the saffron risotto. She really liked the dish, but complained how she had 3 dinky scallops for 21 dollars. Oh wells, she didn't have to pay for it. I tried the risotto and it was so smooth and flavorful. In my opinion, her dish was worth it. 
I got the American Kobe beef burger which came with roasted veggies, little gems lettuce, and fries. I really only liked the veggies and the fries, which were perfectly seasoned and came with a variety of sauces. However, I didn't think the meat was anything special, so I wouldn't order the burger again. I'm sure the burger at Wayfare would taste better.
The dessert was pretty awesome. We shared a chocolate candy bar cake, which was made with a rich flourless chocolate cake, nougat, ice milk, and ganache. What's not to like about this dessert? It was completely decadent. 
Overall, Boulevard was alright. I definitely wouldn't come back again. The food was eh and the service was also eh, considering the fact that I got carded when I paid the bill.... (It wasn't even like I was dressed casually anyways.)
author: Fiona N.

description: have not dined places with 2 bottle limit for corkage.  I forgot Boulevard is an old style restaurant.  food ya more traditional than contemporary.
author: Linda L.

description: I am sorry to say, I am not a fan.  I like the ambiance, but the food was pretty tasteless and uninspired.  I had the foie gras appetizer.  The foie gras itself was good, but the plate was covered with other things that did not add to the dish at all.  The bluenose seabass entree was completely bland.  For the price you pay, I feel I should have enjoyed my meal.  It was below average, in a lovely setting.  I will most likely not return.
author: Stephanie R.

description: This is my favorite place in San Francisco. I could eat here daily! It can be hard to get a reservation, crowded and loud at times, some of the hostesses can have attitude but the food makes it worth it.
author: Stephan J.

description: Went here for a past birthday and pretty much got what I expected. The food was exceptional, although the portions could have been bigger. I was expecting that with this type of restuarant though. The service was also great with friendly staff. If you don't mind the price, it's definitey worth checking out.
author: Ajay K.

description: Great service and great food. Wouldn't expect anything else from here. Love it and will be back every few months for special occasions.
author: Bradley H.

description: Not a memorable meal, but our experience at Boulevard was nice.  You have to try any one of their lemonade drinks= so good!  My salmon was okay, but I wouldn't consider it "the meal of the year".  With its cool and relaxing ambiance, Boulevard is a good place to go for an adequate meal.
author: Shannon W.

description: Boulevard lives up to its reputation as one of the best restaurants in SF.  Its a bit stuffy and the wait staff, while excellent, needs to loosen up.  For a better experience, eat at the bar and watch your food being made.  Also, don't go without a reservation...you could be in for a long wait.  The food is excellent; I've never had a bad meal here....and the desserts are absolute heaven. My only issue is the amount of food for the price, which is why I can't give the place five stars.
author: Josie O.

description: Very elegant American food. You can tell the chef spent time to fine tune everything on the menu. Did not try the famous pork chop because no one eat pork in my family. The lamp chop is good but Kokkari is still the best according to my husband.  The filet mignon was just ok. Can't compare to Mastro or Ruth's Chris. The appetizers are very nicely done. The squab is my favorite. One of my best compare to many high end places. The server is really really nice. I just think the portion is really small considered it is an American cuisine. I wonder how Mastro's steak house can manage to give such a huge portion with the comparable price.
author: Gladys W.

description:
The food was good but definitely overpriced and nothing to write home about.  The service was spotty since our waiter seemed somewhat uppity.  He must have thought acting snooty translated into "high-class."  Hardee har har...

The restaurant itself is cozy and beautiful.  The crowd tends to be older folk either there for business or socialites catching up w/ friends.

The only way I'd go back to Boulevard is if it's on company expense.
author: Jenny K.

description:
A cute place, with good but not great food, its not really a four star place, but its better than a three star

Friday night came and we arrived from work so were not out of place with fellow diners many of whom were men wearing jackets but they did not oust my hubby, who was not.

I ordered the Filet and it was reasonably sized (6 ounces) and cooked properly, but not particularly flavorful, and my husband had the veal, which was a tiny meat portion less than two ounces.  It was so small we actually asked if that was the normal portion size.

A nice tuna sashima with little crispy things appetizer and very good service, but all in all a rather unremarkable meal.

It was good, I just wouldn't plan an anniversary there.  Hubby stopped at  Inn-N-Out on the way home to fill himself up.
author: Victoria B.

description:
My first visit here was back in 2005. It was the always dreaded parents meeting dinner; my parents met his parents for the first time. The night went great and the food and wine were fantastic! Our server quickly caught on to the theme of our dinner and was accommodating and gave us plenty of talking time.

I have since been back a few times, normally eating at the counter pre-Giants night game. I'm always so happy with the food and the service.

I recommend this place for any occasion, the atmosphere is wonderful!
author: Morgan P.

description:
We tried this place a couple of time.  The decor/ambiance of the dining room is ok but IMO not up to the standard of a top restaurant.   The firsts and main had some excellent flavors but we definitely had some misses and I thought the consistancy was lacking.  
We had family from out of town and one of our dinners was in the private room.  It was quite nice and I would definitely consider this place for an event.  One distraction if I recall was waiters coming in to find wine since this was the wine room.
author: John P.

description:
Went to Boulevard based on recommendations from members of a Texas A&M website (Aggieyell). Excellent choice. This is a great place for a date night. My wife and I thoroughly enjoyed the atmosphere, the food, and the service. 

Appetizer - We had the red Abalone. It was our first experience with abalone and we really enjoyed it. The texture and flavor were fantastic.

Entrees - I had the pork chop and my wife had the Lobster and Sea Scallops. Both were very good.

Dessert- Donuts with pudding. Skip this one. Only an average dessert.
author: Allan H.

description:
I was very excited to go to Boulevard after running the SF Marathon on Sunday but was a bit disappointed.
Appetizers- foie gras was pretty good but not nearly as delicious as Gary Danko's, and was a little 'undercooked.'   Crispy soft shell crab was good but nothing to write home about.
Wine- we brought a bottle of our own Backus 2005 Cab since we looked at the wine list ahead of time and weren't really impressed.  Corkage is only $25, which is very reasonable.
Mains- only 7 to choose from and 3 are fish so not a whole lot of selection.  The pork chop (their 'signature item') was juicy and tender and probably the best part of the meal.  The filet is Angus, not USDA Prime, which is weird for a Michelin-starred restaurant.  It was just ok- again, nothing to write home about.
Service- a little more on the casual side compared to Danko's, but decent.  The waitress did let our wine glasses get empty a few times so we just poured our own wine- perhaps it was her passive-aggressive way of telling us she didn't like it that we didn't order one of their bottles?
All in all, everything was decent but I don't know that I'd go back or rant and rave about this place to a friend.
author: Maxine S.

description: My wife and stumbled across this place when we were staying at the boutique hotel across the street. Fantastic food and great atmosphere. We liked the food so much, my wife bought their cookbook!
author: Dave C.

description: Loved it! Service was friendly, welcoming and great. Food & cocktails were equally amazing. Best meal I had in San Francisco! Will definitely go back any chance I get.
author: Sean E.

description: One of the best restaurants in SF.  I've been here a few times.  The dinner and service is absolutely fantastic and has been consistently memorable each time.  A very romantic place for me and my wife on her birthday.
author: Jason N.

description: Asked for a glass with no ice and wow! Got a nasty look. Food is good. With good feel to the place. I might have got somebody on a bad hair day
author: Jon D.

description: Have been to Boulevard many times and it never disappoints. Food is top notch and the room is always packed. I always take large parties here, and you have to fax in your credit card info, which is a bit of a hassle but they are very professional here. Every group I've taken here has been very happy. Every course wins.
author: Suzy S.

description: My husband and I went here for our anniversary, the apps were great, but my way to expensive seabass tasted like canned tuna. We ordered a soft cheese as dessert and it came straight from the fridge, and the candied walnut were like glue on our teeth. We wont be here anytime soon.
author: Chelsea G.

description:
Considering the hype surrounding Boulevard, I have to say I was more impressed than I thought I would be.  Most dishes were cooked perfectly while service was also extremely professional and attentive.  Although the restaurant was completely packed on a (Sunday?) night, we were able to walk in and find seats  at the bar next to the kitchen without a reservation. It was great fun to watch the chefs in action.

I really enjoyed the red abalone which in itself is a treat I don't find on most menus, and this version was perfect. The sonoma fois gras and the king salmon were also BIG hits.  The pork chop: a great cut of meat but overcooked to the point where getting off the bone and even cutting it was near impossible.  Overall it was a very enjoyable meal and I'm glad that after years of passing this place up and thinking it was just a tourist joint, I finally tried it.
author: Brenna C.

description: Unbelievable dinner - hands down favorite restaurant.  Just in town for some holiday shopping, and our HIT was Boulevard for dinner Saturday night.  Thank you everyone who make our experience magic.
author: Ken N.

description:
Excellent restaurant for the price. You can pay a lot more at other restaurants like Gary Danko and stuff, so while this is expensive for me, I've had more expensive meals elsewhere. Actually I also hate how Yelp doesn't allow half stars but this would be a 4.5 in my book. i have to give it a 5 because of the value amongst fine dining places.

I tried One Market and it's honestly not as good. The atmosphere is excellent in Boulevard. I got seated close enough to the kitchen to watch the chefs do their thing, but far enough where I can still enjoy a night with my girlfriend.

Appetizer: Sea scallops + fried mushrooms. Wow this was just beyond delicious. Small portions, but I guess this meant we should've gotten our own. I forgot that fine dining gives perfectly sized portions! We shared this one, that's why.

Mains: I got the quail, and my girl got the sea bass w/ risotto. Both plates were delicious. I actually thought my dish was far better prepared and the meat was juicy, tender AND flavorful.

Dessert: Somehow I've already forgotten what we got as this was 4 months ago, but it was certainly wonderful.

I've paid this price for a full 3 course meal at other restaurants, but there's a reason WHY Boulevard stands out AND has a Michelin star.

I've tried other places like One Market, and they can't compare to Boulevard. This place just has a WOW to it. I'm going to recommend people who want to try out fine dining to first try out Boulevard. 

The only thing I wish they had was a prix fixe menu.
author: Dennis M.

description: Have been here numerous times, love the ambiance and the food.  Great, reliable place to take out-of-town guests or to treat yourself.  We've taken some of our pickiest friends here and they rave about it.
author: Kat W.

description: Do not order the Mexicali Rose drink unless you like the taste of smoke.  Aside from this odd tasting drink, our beet salad was refreshing and my filet mignon was alright.  Not so tender. I've had some better filets.  My chocolate dessert was okay.  I thought the chocolate was a bit hard. There are some things that I like soft, and I like my chocolate soft and moist.
author: Marzan W.

description: I had the pork belly for appetizer and the lamb for my main course. Both were awesome. The portions could be a little bigger though.
author: V M.

description: Wonderful design, delicious food, excellent service. A busy Saturday night and full bar but we were sat at our table right on time. I had the quail and squab entree-yummy! My partner had lamb that was just as it should be. Definitely recommend this place.
author: Carl S.

description: More American than French.  We have a private room so didn't experience the main dining area.  Service was terrific.
author: Platform Universe S.

description:
Came here to celebrate our anniversary.
We were nicely greeted and promptly seated . The restaurant was pretty busy already at 6 pm. We had a nice waiter, very friendly, who asked for our drinks right away. 
The seared scallops, the soft shell crab and the special appetizer of the day, beef wagyu with noodles were so good, we finished every bite! 
The lamb T bone and the pork chop were perfectly cooked. The last time I had a perfect pork chop was at Seastar in Bellevue. Juicy, tender, perfect medium, and with cherries! Yumm, I love cherries! The only slight disappointment was the filet mignon, it was not medium rare as ordered, and it was a bit dry. My son ate it anyway, the restaurant was too busy for us to send a plate back. 
For dessert, we ordered the nectarine and blueberries crisp. It was too sweet, do it made the fruits sour. But the homemade cherry chocolate chip ice cream and the peach sangria ice cream were excellent. 
In all, a great meal. The place was full, so the noise level was high, and that was a Wednesday night. Service was attentive, the food was paced nicely,no rush, no long wait. Everybody from the server, busser, food runner, etc.. was very friendly and professional. 
We will come again.
author: lovetoeat a.

description: I had a pleasant lunch here with excellent service. The special was a flat pasta with little taste and a small amount of rabbit cooked in tomato sauce. It was interesting but not something I would order again. The desert was angel food cake with peaches and ice cream. It was superb.
author: David M.

description:
I have been to Boulevard many, many times.  Without fail, I will order the Crab and Avocado salad, one or two of the $3 dessert bonbons, and another, more major, dessert.

The Crab and Avocado salad is always transporting.  Many crab dishes at other places are ruined when someone goes crazy with things like onions in the crabcakes, which overpower the crab.  The creamy, understated taste of avocado makes a perfectly harmonious Ginger Rogers to the crab's Fred Astaire.  They vary the other ingredients in it, using grapefruit slices, or plum tomatoes, or whatever else seems fresh.  It's always great.  For the mains, I've had a great, tender pyramid ravioli with mushroom, salmon, and steaks; all have been marvelous.  The desserts are always memorable, especially when chocolate cake or ice cream, or a combination of the two, are involved.

The surroundings are pleasant, warm, and always put me in a wonderful mood.  The interior is tastefully done, and the neighborhood, up by the Ferry Building and the Bay Bridge, can be a nice place to wander for ten or twenty minutes, after dinner.  The drink selection is very good.  But above all, it's that crab and avocado salad that I keep dreaming of.  Fantastic work!
author: Andrew H.

description:
Based on a local friend's recommendation, I booked dinner for our first wedding anniversary since we moved to San Francisco here and we were blown away by the whole experience.

To start with, when I called that day to check whether I'd booked for 7 or 7.30, it seemed that the booking had vanished from their system and they were fully booked.  I don't have a problem with this - things go wrong in even the best systems, and the key to good service is how you deal with them.  In this instance, the words "Please don't tell me that - it's our anniversary!" were barely out of my mouth when the lovely, lovely woman at their end said she'd fix it for us and that we could turn up at 7.  

We duly did, and were given a great table, where we received truly excellent service.  Brilliantly attentive when needed (while ordering cocktails, selecting food and wine and discussing the selection of desserts), and utterly unobtrusive at all other times.  The atmosphere is busy and though the surroundings might suggest Continental stuffiness the application totally takes off any edge of that.  The clientele was a very mixed bag, which I appreciated - places that make you feel uncomfortable if you're not in a tie will never get many starts from me.  My money's as good as theirs.

The food was outstanding - I had scallops to start and my OH had what he described as "The best salad I've ever had".  Mains were great and the dessert list is one of those that makes you want a sampling platter of everything.  Portions were sensible and enough to make us feel comfortably full without being stuffed.

We splurged slightly on a bottle of Bollinger, La Grande Annee 1999 and regretted not a cent of the cost.

We've eaten in some truly world class restaurants in many countries, and we'd have no hesitation in listing our experience at Boulevard right up there with the best of them.
author: Jon M.

description: Went here for business lunch.  The lobster bisque was delicious.  The slow roasted pork was pretty good but the portions are tiny.  For the price, I would expect a little more cut of meat and less potatoes.
author: Dan C.

description: My wife wanted to try this place for the longest time as she worked a block or so away. So today, I surprised her and we went there for lunch. The Blossom appetizers were beautiful - filled with ricotta, tastes like pizza. She had the Tuna and I had the soft shell crab BLT which was awesome. The service above par and staff friendly.
author: Johnson H.

description: I liked the portion size of the meal, which runs a little on the small side, but is perfect for me.  We ordred the lamb T-bone and the quail along with a mixed drink and a coffee.  I though the food was creative and tasted decent.  I guess I did not find anything exceptional (except for maybe the service), but I also did not find anything wrong with it.
author: H. L.

description:
Boulevard is like, one of THOSE places in SF.  So we went.  A party of four Koreans, for a birthday dinner one Sunday night.

It's fancy, it's expensive, the portions are small, the service is excellent, the decor is beautiful, the wine is good.  

My dad being the old-school Korean that he is, was worried about being hungry at the end of the meal so he kept munching on the bread.  Thank goodness because the appetizers, though beautiful and tasty, are teeny tiny.  We had the ahi tuna app and the dungeness crab salad.  Very tasty but really hard to do family style on such tastebud teasers- seriously, I felt like we were poor people sharing our last crust of bread.

My mom got the seabass, it was overcooked.  Which was sad because it was her birthday.  She also whispered to my sister and myself that it needed hot sauce.  My dad dug into his walu which was excellent- it was gone in minutes.  My sister tried the duck, which she normally doesn't love but it too, surpassed expectations.  I grudgingly ordered the seafood risotto (I really wanted the pork but mom doesn't eat it and I wanted her to try everything) which ended up being wonderful.  The scallop was perfectly cooked.  All it needed was a side of kimchee.

For dessert we ordered the quince pear walnut cake which was soooo good and the profiterole and banana cream pie thing (which though tasty was too sugary with those crunchy pieces.)   Coffee was fair.

The 1/2 bottle of anderson valley pinot that we got, though incredibly full and tasty and probably one of the better pinots I've had in a long minute, came with a hefty price tag.

I wouldn't say it's the most inventive, daring, or dynamic food or the most tasty- but for American fare it is quality food that is well prepared, well cooked, and well presented.  

All in all, it ended up being threefifty bones- otherwise known in working class people speak as an arm and a leg.  I think my parents had mini heart attacks but since it was one me, I think it made them feel worse.  

All in all we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves and it was so wonderful to open our family up to a different level of food experience.
author: erin k.

description: what i expected was a classy, snobbish, quiet, fancy restaurant. what i got was a comfy, intimate, casual setting that serves great food. this place is filled with patrons who work around the area and tourists who might have found this neighborhood gem on yelp. i especially love their cozy booth seats with plush cushions and a great view of the restaurant and open kitchen. here's the lowdown on the food: tomato and mozzarella salad was good, the pine nut and parmesan medley was excellent. together the dish was spectacular. tuna tartare was a bit predictable, but still on the good side. bf had the pork chop, which was perfectly seasoned. he adored the accompanied spaetzle. my california pacific sea bass was a treat. not as oily as the regular sea bass and extremely flavorful. this place is a must if you don't want haute cuisine without the fancy-schmancy bullsh**
author: Melissa Y.

description: I always like the food and wine at Boulevard.  Their service is very good.  Love the valet parking.
author: nina l.

description:
Boulevard is a marvelous place to dine among the elite of San Francisco. The restaurant offers seasonal cuisine with exquisitely fresh ingredients. I finally had the opportunity to try abalone. It was silky in texture and the decision to compliment the dish with guanciale was brilliant. I also had the rabbit and thought the loin was delicious but was not "wowed" by the addition of the breaded rabbit sirloin. My guest had the rack of lamb and he thought it was superb. The food is beautifully plated and it is obvious that the kitchen is at the top of their game. 

What I most enjoyed about Boulevard was the absence of attitude. Considering the reputation of the restaurant and the quality of the clientele, it was refreshing to dine in peace without being rushed by the server or intimidated by the sommelier. With regard to the wine selection, it is both reasonable and abundant. Although we brought our own bottle, we could not resist the half bottle selection. I tried the 2005 Ramey Chardonnay and I thought it was a winner (I recommend pairing it with the stuffed calamari and/or abalone).  

If you are looking to impress the one you love, or in my case celebrate a parent's birthday, Boulevard is the place to go. I would also like to thank the recommendation of a fellow reviewer who suggested requesting a seat in the back. The view of the Bay Bridge at night was gorgeous; it reminded me of that classic scene in the movie, "Manhattan."
author: Blake S.

description:
I've missed my Manhattan gourmet adventures since the first day my flight landed in SFO. I worried that I wouldn't be able to find something that I could dream about only to wake up to a puddle of my own drool on the pillow the very next morning. Then after many many recommendations I finally gave Boulevard a chance and my greatest compliment is simply that "why isn't it located in the heart of Manhattan with the big boys?"

The foie-gras, abalone, squab, lamb to name a few have been regulars in my dreams and I can only say "if you haven't been to Boulevard - you haven't discovered the true culinary potentials of San Francisco." Go! It's a must!
author: Catsu H.

description:
Had a fantastic business lunch here on a sunny SF day.  Paid for by the company, so who can complain?

A very nice restaurant inside with great views, wish I had a table more to the back.  The crowd seemed very rich-business-like.

Had some crab salad, kobe beef burger, and a half bottle of white wine, all delicious.  The check for the 3 of us came out to $200 something, which seemed like a lot to me.  Not sure if I would've paid that on my own.
author: K K.

description:
Very Posh setting, but most of the employees are very nice.  Don't expect to be full from your Dinner (even w/appetizer & dessert), portions are limited but very, very good.  Excellent place for an intimate dining experience.  

Needless to say (but I will anyway)...this place is expensive, and again, expect small portions!  If you have any change left, go to Jack 'n the Box down the street to get full!
author: D C.

description:
We sat in the counter by the kitchen...bread was cold, but good and butter was awesome...
.Had the foie gras...a little on the raw side and small..but my bf loved it....Abalone was fried...a little disappointing...and we shared squab/quail which was good...and the mocha and malt bon bon was a great ending...Service was great....and good value for the price
a plus that they're open sunday nts... :)
author: lani p.

description: Nancy Oakes is amazing!  The food is some of the best I've ever had, and the service is perfect.  We always dine here when we visit SF!
author: Tara J.

description: So comfy, feels like grandma's kitchen. Booths are great and yours for at least 2 plus hours. I've enjoyed the crudo a few times along with the foie. They are incredibly consistent and friendly. It's an experience and a pleasure to dine here. If anything maybe I'm looking for a bit more action at the end of the night but plenty of hotel bars in the area. Pork 3 ways was a let down a few years ago, mostly cant go wrong here. Nice but pricey wine list.
author: Tom W.

description: Secret vegi platter!! That was the coolest thing about this place. I have been before and had delicious seafood and meat but this time I asked if they had any veggies and the server told me they have a delicious veggie platter but had to take it off the menu because it was getting so popular and the chef did not want to be know just for his veggies. I ordered it and was amazed. Like a stroll down the farmers market. Might want to order two of them though. The view in the evening is pretty unreal too.
author: Scott D.

description: I think this place is very overrated. We had a dinner reservation for 9 pm, and were actually on time (which rarely happens) and we were seated at 9:40 pm! We did get a nice table by the window, with a view of the Bay Bridge, which was the best part of the evening. But the food here is average, so is the service.
author: Alina S.

description: One of my FAVORITE places to dine and always worth the price. The ambience is warm and wonderful and the food will knock your socks off. I wish I could come here every weekend - never been disappointed!
author: Ava S.

description:
Food - excellent, solid flavors and satisfying. Loved the scallops with lobster bisque.  It wasn't overly creative, but agian, very happy with everything.  I enjoyed the mingling of asian flavors with the tuna app. 

Service- PERFECT. I am not sure how this is attained, but Charles had it right. Friendly without trying to hang out and be our best friend. Attentive, knowledgable, unpretentious- the perfect waiter. 

fun,loud, swanky atomoshere

$550 for 4 but we all had starters, meals, and we had 2 bottles of wine-- very well priced interesting wine that we all loved, dessert, coffee, dessert wine.

A great evening.
author: Lynnie R.

description: This is what all restaurants should aspire to be.   Six of us enjoyed Boulevard last night to celebrate a birthday, and ordering food for us is always a challenge with two of us Vegan and two of us Gluten-free.   The wait staff and kitchen were very conscientious and accommodating to our table's needs.   With each course, the different servers confirmed "this is Vegan" or "this is Gluten-free" without prompting.   And the food was hand-slapping-on-the-table delicious, the presentation elegant and the portions just right.  The food is pricey, but the evening priceless.  Enjoy Boulevard with good friends, and you'll remember the meal for years to come.
author: Greg P.

description: Great service, the food was pretty good too. I got the calamari for an  appetizers which was way to salty and for my entree I got the filet mignon which was very delicious. The highlight of my night was definitely the dessert I got the strawberry  tart cake type of thing, it was to die for mmmm, yummy.
author: Nelli K.

description: Great atmosphere!   Overall, food was way slightly too salty but still above average.  Carrot soup was delicious and my pork tenderloin was cooked perfectly!  It was so tender, all I had to do was rest my butter knife on top and let gravity do the work.
author: Tron D.

description: I love lamb and goat. Lamb I will say it is one of best place for it. I was great. They can improve a service little. Cheers!
author: Cheng L.

description: Boulevard has been around for awhile, it's not the trendy new place, but I think Boulevard is the finest restaurant in the SF Bay Area.  When I want a great meal for a special occasion, this is it.  The service is excellent, the food is superb from start to finish, and the restaurant itself is stunningly beautiful.
author: Litta R.

description: We have been here a 1/2 dozen times now and this dining experience is, in my humble opinion, as good as it gets!  I almost always order what is on special or what the wait staff suggests for that evening.  The wine selection is exceptional with some nice selections that won't break the bank.  The foie gras or lobster bisque are spot on.  The most impressive thing in my opinion is the wait staff.  Every time I think I need something they seem to pick up on it and are right there.  This is what fine dining is supposed to be.
author: Aaron H.

description: Wow what a treat this restaurant is!! We got the swordfish and the lamb and we were in awe over the quality of ingredients! Yes it is pricey, but the ambiance and food make it worth it!! The chocolate de creme dessert was also great! Make reservations early as this place is busy!
author: Allan C.

description: We have always had an extremely great dinner there.  This last visit, the fish dishes were disappointing.  The fish was dry.  However, the filet and pork chops were great.  The service is beyond compare.  Made reservations 3 weeks in advance and could only get a 6:00 pm seating.  However, they gave us our favorite table.  Also, you get what you pay for -- be prepared to empty your wallet.
author: Deborah M.

description: Appetizers were tiny, but good.  Waiter was slow and uneducated.  Main dish was great.  Not a good place for a short lunch.
author: M. S.

description:
Love love love this place, although I have to admit, it's more for the atmosphere than for the food.  Very old school, wood panel, cozy bistro atmosphere.  When I come here, I feel at home.  Granted, there's a lot of oldness here - old people, old money, old building, old wood.  But it's the type of oldness that reminds me of my grandparents' place - old but cozy comfortable, like a well-worn big leather chair that I can just sink into with a book, in front of a warm fireplace.  This place reminds me of that.

Food is overall more french than american - meaning small portions, pretty presentation, intense flavors in small bites.  

You know what could make me give it 5 stars?  If it had a steak frites or burger and fries on the menu.  I'd love to sit at the bar with a yummy burger / steak and a glass of robust red wine.  That would make this place - PERFECT.
author: Hoola H.

description: REalllyyy goo service.. our waiter was the BOMB !! i wish i got his name..lol anyways i ordered a virgin strawberry drink. calamari, tartar and filet mignon and was absolute perfection! I would def recommend this place to anyone who wants fine dining, eclectic american/french cuisine and also be able to enjoy a nice loud environment! :)
author: Nessy N.

description:
purty good.

got seafood first time i went. wasn't great.

got land animals the second time. delicious.

there's a couple tables near the door next to the bar if you want to just do drinks.

service is excellent.
author: Andy P.

description:
UPDATE! I ate here again in January 2008. My boyfriend made reservations as part of my Christmas present.  As usual, it did not disappoint. The food was as amazing as I've always remembered it. Mmmm foie gras and rack of lamb and our waiter was extremely friendly and knowledgeable. This place has never ever let me down. I leave drunk, full and happy everytime.

Ok- the last time I've eaten here was October 2006 - but before that I've eaten there several times, and everytime, I've left completely happy, tastebuds a burstin, and FULL. The food is sensational, and for a pricey restaurant, the portions are large.  At Boulevard, the food, while creatively presented, is not meant to be art. The wait staff is also superb. They've always been able to recommend the perfect wine to accompany my meal and still keep it within my price range, which is rather modest. While Gary Danko may beat out this place in best restaurant, overall, Boulevard is  my favorite "special occasion" restaurant in SF when taking price into consideration.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Without a doubt this is my death row restaurant. 

I have never been disappointed by this place. Its not an every week or every month type of place. It takes me a bit to save up for, but it is always worth it.
author: Matt H.

description:
I have never been disappointed with the quality of the food and the service.  A fine menu and presentation.  My favorite entree is the 
fillet which is large enough to order as a split item for a $4 extra charge.  That way both parties enjoy our own plate and good helpings of the potatoes and vegetables.  The only problem I have encountered is that a few of  the booths against the side long window are too narrow and uncomfortable because of the architectual columms which limit the space.  Best seating's are the tables in the back section.  The bar is one of the best in the City.
author: irwin s.

description:
I must say, after all the hype over this place, I was not impressed.  I went with a group of people and out of all of us, the waiter singled me out as a problem maker.  Okay YES, I suppose it's "weird" to want the dressing of my salad on the side, but do you realllllly have to make a fuss about it??

The waiter hummed and hawed at my outrageous request, "Well, I guess we could put it on the side...but that's not how WE do it here..."  You jerk, just give me what I want!  Isn't the customer always right?

Aside from the pissy wait staff, the food left a lot to be desired.  I had the mushroom soup and a crab/avocado salad.  Both were "ehhh" and I was thankful that I wasn't paying.  NOT worth the price...

Dessert, however, was pretty darn good.  If you come here, get the peach/blackberry cobbler.  Sooo good!  The crust on top is really a sugar cookie, and the miniature vanilla bean ice cream scoop they give you is superb.  Granted, I am lactose intolerant - I had a few scrumptious bites anyway.

Another positive is the ambiance.  Nice place.  They definitely thought out the decor, but that's about it.  Bathroom down 3 flights of stairs?  Come on...

Bottom line: Go here if you're not paying and not expecting much.
author: Kristin S.

description: I really enjoyed the whole experience here last night. I tried the fois gras and it was delicious. I also had their scallops and beet salad. The service was perfection and they seemed genuinely nice. Eating at the counter where you can watch them cook is a real experience.
author: Sharon D.

description: Maybe its because this place sits across street from Americano that they just know its stiff competition. The food here is always consistently good. From fish to steak. Everything's prepared meticulously. It's such a cliche but this place was the only place so far where I've seen waiters holding up wine glasses and double check for stains before they bring them out to customers, I guess that kind of justifies the higher than average price they charge.
author: Bo D.

description:
Seriously, seriously, seriously good food!  It's been a long time since I've had a meal that left me wondering why anyone would eat anywhere else.  That's exactly what I was asking myself at the end of my meal at Boulevard.

We started off with the Tuna Tartare prepared two ways.  Both ways were exceptionally good and exceptionally complimentary of each other.  After much debate (ok, not that much debate) I couldn't tell which I liked more because I liked them both so much.

The main was a perfectly conceived and executed lamb dish.  Perfectly seasoned and perfectly cooked.  I could order that dish a million times over.  

Dessert was a perfect ending to a perfect meal.  I ordered the strawberry filo dessert and it was rich and flavorful.  

Love this place!!!  Will be back for sure!
author: L K.

description:
Nancy is still turning out stellar dishes after so many years.  I hadn't been back in almost a year so we decided a trip was long overdue...

First, you MUST try the "Pepo" cocktail.  Now in my 42 years, I've had thousands of cocktails and I can honestly say this was the absolute top of the list.  Who would have thought yellow watermelon and gin would go together so well?  add a little elderflower syrup and a sprig of opal basil and the combination is nothing less than Magic!  Truly refreshing.

We started with the abolone, which I hadn't had in years.  You literally can't tell which is the mushroom and which is the abalone steak.  The green salsa is an outstanding accompaniment -- a slight fresh zing with an accompanying mellow yogurt underling.

For my main dish, I opted for the Hawaiin Walu.  The fish was perfectly grilled and atop a lovely assortment of beans (favas, cranberry) along with an unctuous bean "mousseline" as they called it, reminiscent of umami.  Just lovely.  I actually asked the waiter if it had been poached in butter -- it was that moist and delicate yet rich but not overpoweringly so.

If you want an outstanding meal that is consummable (i.e., not over-the-top rich to the point that you can't eat more than one bite and here I think of Danko, Fleur de Lys {no offense to you chefs but I am easily put off by too much truffle oil and cloying rich sauces} definitely go to Boulevard.  It is top quality food served in top quality fashion without all the unnecessary fanfare.  Staff provide perfect service with a smile.  5 stars well worth it.
author: Brenda F.

description: This place was fantastic.  Sonoma Foie Gras was the best I've every had. The service was very good and the atmosphere was equally good. Highly recommend.
author: Bourdain, A.

description: Boulevard is a classy spot with great service.  The food was good but not great. I came here for dinner in January and I dont really remember what I had because the plates are not memorable to me.  I just know I had the filet and at the end I had the baked alaska.  I expected better food from all of the great reviews.
author: H. A.

description: Cafe for All Seasons in West Portal is better in every way except we had a nice view out the window.  I could not believe this was rated one of San Francisco's best restaurants.  Every dessert had ice cream.  Never again.
author: Joseph H.

description: Beautiful presentation, great service, great atmosphere, awesome food.  Perfect for any special occasion
author: David S.

description: Very Fancy and a good place to go if you want to impress.  Beautiful old building.  Where San Francisco's elite go to eat.
author: Kate J.

description:
Fantastic service and food.

Portion sizes are a little small, but otherwise you'll love Boulevard!
author: Scott M.

description:
What a great meal I had a this place not long ago. The service is very friendly from each and everyone working there, I enjoyed the nice historic decor and really love nice, relaxed ambiance. Our dinner reservations were delayed  for some reason and we had to waiting for about 10 minutes, but it was worth the wait since my dinning companion and I got one of the best tables on the house.

Now, lets talk about food. I found some of the appetizer portions a bit small such one of their signature dishes AHI TUNA: TARTARE & SASHIMI Tartare with Lime- Sansho Aioli, Wasabi Tobiko, Furikake Chip Sashimi Dressed with Soy & Sake, Shiitakes, Shiso, Crispy Rice 17.50 My dinning companion opted for the BRUIN FARM HEIRLOOM TOMATOES & ITALIAN BUFALA MOZZARELLA Toasted Spring Onions & Basil, Endive & Upland Cress, Olive Oil Vinaigrette 14.75, this was good too. For our main courses we had LAMB T-BONE (DIXON, CA)WOOD OVEN ROASTED ON THE BONE WITH ROSEMARY, THYME, MINT & GARLICSERVED OFF THE BONES quash Blossom Stuffed with Crushed Yukon Gold Potatoes, Mascarpone Cheese & Amaranth Greens Local Asparagus, Green Olive Salsa Verde & Roasted Lamb Jus 34.50 " Delicious!! and we also tried/shared another of their signature dishes: CALIFORNIA SQUAB &TOLENAS FARMS QUAIL PAN ROASTED WITH GARLIC & THYME Fig & Red Wine Risotto, Roasted Scarlet & Tokyo Turnips Fresh Figs, Red Walnuts & Pancetta with Barolo & Honey Vinaigrette Foie Gras Sauce & Quail Jus 29.75 quite tasty...  As you can see this could be a very pricey dinner event. 

I was disappointed about the dessert selection, we had the cheese platter and unfortunately I was disappointed as well. 

Will I go back ? the answer is yes!!  but, hopefully deserts may be better next time.
author: Ernesto C.

description: 5 star all the way!  We try to have dinner here anytime we are out in the San Fran area.  Very pricey but worth every bit you spend.  Atmosphere is amazing and the staff will treat you first class.  Highly recommend.
author: Wendy P.

description: walked out slanted door after 5 minutes of being seated came over here, got seated straight away at a bar table - amazing service and amazing food....  will come back again and again.. people mention pricey.. isn't this the norm for most restaurants of this quality. I was thinking it was quite inexpensive...
author: Tiffany S.

description: This is one of those classic SF resturants where your transported to an era long since past.  The interior design envelopes you and brings you to the 1930's.  The service is excellent and the menus is constently chaning with the seasons.  It seems like the dishs mirror to best meats, seafood, and produce California has to offer.  The abalone simply melts before it hits your tounge.  Everything I everhad is cooked to perfection.  It's definately a good special occasion place and the prices reflex the quality of experience.
author: Robin M.

description: I'd have to say one of the best foods I've had in my life.. I had great great great foods throughout my life.. but this was in another level.. the atmosphere.. the ambiance.. the service.. the FOOOD!!!.. and the price obviously.. i mean.. I probably wont eat here ever again unless I get a legitimate job but anyways.. I had the lamb steak.. and my brother had filet mignon.. and pork chop for my gf and filet mignon as well for my sister.. and the 30 dollar DUCK LIVER!!!!!!.. a bit pricey??? YOU THINK!!? i could have had about 12 in n out sanwiches.. and the duck liver was the size of my pinki.. wat!? it was my first time eating that.. it was a good experience.. the meats were all perfecftly tender and the lamb didnt stink like lamb.. if you get what I mean.. which was lovely and the pork chop.. my goodness was to die for as well... just crispy enough outside and juicy inside.. uhhhh.. mazing.. grace.. oh the check was 333.. 400 with tip.. so about 100 a person.. that was not the idea but it turned out that way.. lol.. good thing I didnt buy.. because had i did... that wouldve been 160 cheeseburgers from in n out down the toilet next morning..
author: Sean P.

description: I entertained Australian clients at the Boulevard for lunch. We were in a bit of a rush and didn't have time to sample appetizer or dessert. I had the kobe steak with mushrooms. Both were delicious and prepared very well. It feels historic, but I am not well read on the history. My clients and colleague equally enjoyed their meals.  One of the clients had mentioned that the Boulevard was on her list of things to do in SF, and I'm glad we were able to take them there. I highly recommend the restaurant for a business meal or a special night on the town.
author: William C.

description:
I have been wanting to go to Boulevard for as long as I can remember.  I tried to get a certain someone to take me for some sort of special occasion, and it seemed like this weekend just happened to be it.
We wandered over from Hotel Vitale (swoon), just to escape our claustrophobicly amazing suite with large patio and fantastic views. (this is sarcasm; but we did feel like getting out)
We didn't have reservations, and at 9:30 all the tables were still full.  Luckily we nabbed the last two seats at the dropped down section of the bar.  Sandwiched between two service wells, this is not prime real estate, but it worked for us.  Our bartender/server was great - a little aloof initially (we'll call it "cooly professional"), but fast, friendly, and kept a great beat with his Boston shaker.
We started with a couple of cocktails while we decided what we were going to sell our kidneys for.  We decided on three apps - the ahi tartare, the scallops, and the goat cheese and beet ravioli.  The ravioli were the first thing to catch my eye on the menu (I swear, I have goat cheese radar), but were my least favorite in practice.  The seafood was fab and beautifully plated.  A couple more drinks, some more yummy bread and we were stuffed.
Not a bargain meal by any means, but I'm so thrilled I finally made it in.  I will be honest that while I enjoyed the food, it was not the best meal I've had in SF and I probably won't be rushing back even though I absolutely adored the vibe and ambiance inside.  
Okay, maybe for dessert.  We didn't have enough room, but they all sounded amazing.
Or if I can figure out how to steal some of those cool, whimsical, Alice in Metroland light flxtures. . .
author: Jennifer D.

description: The Bouldevard gets a capital 'S' for Swank-ee! and a capital 'E' for expensive. If youre looking for a hot place to get your girl dressed up and drop a bill or two (or three, or four......) you've found the place! I recomend sitting at the Chef's Bar, this is where all the action is, and almost justifies the expense. You get to watch the cooks sweat, while they churn the wood fired oven and grill. What ever it is the Boulevard is paying them, they should double it, cuz they earn it!
author: Dr. L.

description: This is the place we always come for a special occasion and it has not failed to impress us once. The food and service are always A1 and the ambience is great - not stuffy but relaxed and comfortable.
author: Glen A.

description:
let me just say the sweet breads were f-ing amazing!

dessert is always good as hell too!

60 hour pork roast, are u kidding me.

just go:)
author: Kimberly R.

description: Boulevard is my favorite power lunch or power dinner restaurant in San Francisco.  French cuisine, fancy but not too pretentious.  The food is amazing in a way that only the Fench seem to be able to pull off.  The wait staff is attentive and friendly, the decor is warm and inviting with lots of wood, sculpted glass lights, even the floors have been carefully done for effect.  The clientele trend toward the somewhat older and powerful, but I felt comfortable there too and I am neither.
author: Bob H.

description: Again, one of the best dinners ever!  Who are these people giving Boulevard less than four stars?  And are you mad?
author: Jessica T.

description:
VERY DISAPPOINTING AND VERY OVERPRICED: I finally came to the famed BLVD after wanting to go for many, many years.  3 of us had lunch during the week, and I arrived early and had a glass of wine at the bar. The bar tender (tall, bald guy) was NOT very friendly at all, and was not exactly outgoing or fun, he had a crappy attitude and made me not want to be there (and I was the only one at the bar,  does he get it????) . I asked to see the selection for a GLASS OF WINE and He gave me a wine menu with only bottles on it and kept saying the selection was on the first page, however, after several more questions he realizes at my pointing out that in fact the page was MISSING from the book. DUH. So I ordered my $18.00 glass of wine and was not able to transfer it to the table, like I dont know a NORMAL GOOD restaurant does. So I thought to myself, not great so far but lets see...

We had lunch, I had a $14.00 boiled egg (63degrees for 45 minutes with polenta, very good but its an EGG - FOURTEEN DOLLARS ARE YOU KIDDING ME?) and the farm raised chicken. I actually thought our waiter was very good and very attentive, but he did mess up my friends order and lunch took about 45 minutes (THIS IS A BUSINESS LUNCH PEOPLE). My chicken was basically 1 piece of fried dark meat (thigh) and 1 piece of white meat which I thought was very weird. The fried piece was NOT GOOD, KFC is 10x better, and the other piece was okay. All told, I was disappointed, and would recommend against going to this restaurant. The asshole bartender stood out I must say, everyone else was SUPER nice and cordial like you would expect at BLVD.  My friend ordered the ravioli's which were just delicious, my other friend ordered just a salad. So I would say 3 out of 10 - but in this economy why anyone would come here is beyond me, another SF institution that eventually ends up with their heads up their asses.
author: John j.

description: Definitely one of San Francisco's best.  Boulevard has a warm decor, excellent food, top-notch service, and, for what you get, relatively reasonable prices. Great place for a business lunch or a special night.   There is not much more I can say about this excellent, no frills dining establishment.
author: Aimee G.

description: Fantastic service 5/5 stars. Delicious food. Lynn had the sea bass 4/5 stars. I had the file mignon 5/5 stars. Great dessert. Pricey but worth it.
author: Chris R.

description:
the beautiful curvilinear interior was so nouveau romantic.

sadly, the conservative and older crowd wasn't so much.  that stops it from making my "hote date" list.  

tip! do call for rezzies since they don't put up all of the available times on opentable. 

the bar area was long and narrow.  there were some fun cocktails on the menu to sip while waiting for a table or friends to arrive.

the food plating was impeccable.  

i devoured my perfectly seared foie gras while sipping my scherrer pinot noir '03.
my dinnermates ordered:
 the tuna tartare - he didn't share so it must have been tasty! 
the ravioli was on the small side of portions and it was par.

i was so sad that the short rib entree was so fatty.  not a good fatty because i don't shy away from eating pure fat.

thankfully, the evening ended well with a beautiful almond butter cake dessert.  it was outstanding
the cheese selction is also quite nice with a little chateauneuf-du-pape.

francesca, our server, was a sassy blond from hawaii.  she was friendly and knowledgeable about wine pairings and really added to a lovely evening with friends.
author: Anh V.

description: I never thought I would eat a cousin of pigeons but hell if it's cooked right I guess I'd try it.  I'm glad I did.  The squab was excellent.  The bird was prepared perfectly with a nice dark brown and crispy skin while the meat was a beautiful red color.  I also had their foie gras dish and it was indulgent with the fruit flavored sauce and pate.  It gave a nice sweet and savory flavor and it was a huge piece of foie.
author: Harry T.

description: This is hands-down my favorite restaurant anywhere.  Great ambience and decor.  Amazing service.  Wonderful food - so many unique flavors and little extra touches that show the chefs know what they're doing.  Worth it every time.
author: Lauren C.

description: The portions are tiny, the prices are too much for lunch, and the service was polite, but slow.  Bonus: only one vegetarian item on the menu (a lettuce salad).  I waited 40 minutes for a pricey boring salad.  The waiter couldn't even come with a suitable suggestion for a veggie alternative.  One guy in my group finished his meal in three bites, not large bites either.  The dressing was good and was clearly made in house, but it looked like a bag of mixed baby lettuce from trader joes with dressing and two cherry tomatoes (I counted).
author: Josh Z.

description: The best dinner I have had in San Francisco. Staff really puts this over the edge for me, as they are exceptional and I want to marry them all. Wine list runs the whole gamut and I feel like I could have spent a lot more money if I hadn't asked the wine dude on duty. Amazing.
author: senator t.

description: The absolute best gourmet food I've had in SF. Worth the wait and the price. I had the butterfish which amazingly melted in your mouth. The service was gracious and prompt. If I could afford it, I'd eat there all the time!
author: Shannon B.

description: My first visit to Boulevard. The food is good.  Started off with the sweetbread (I didn't know what it was) and it was quite tasty.  Service is good, the only thing about it was that the decibel level is pretty high.  So I remember it was hard to hear at times.  Good place to go on special occasions just wish it was a bit more quiet.
author: Victor W.

description: The service is excellent and the food was so good. We had the abalone appetizer and rack of lamb. That was the best lamb that I have ever had.
author: Elly G.

description: what can i say? this places lives up to its reputation. Food is very well plated, service is very professional, and the way eveything is set up in the place is just beautiful. I had a nice little view of the bay bridge and it was very nice. I've been here a couple times now and i have not yet been disappointed. Also had a birthday here and it was great. They even had a little candle for me heh heh. Great food, great service, cant wait to go back!
author: phillip w.

description: Nancy Oakes has left the house! First time there and spent a two hour ride to get to SF to eat here. The food was average to say the least, but someone HOLD THE SALT! Even the bread and butter was sallty. The service was great across the board. but the food fpr the price was not. This will be a one shot for my wife and I and the other couple who had eaten here before, noticed a decline in quality and uniqueness in the offerings. Time for this establishment to get back to basics.
author: John C.

description:
My family and I recently took a trip up to our favorite city for 4th of July and I can't tell you what a fabulous time we had up there. Our first dinner was here at Boulevard. Now, I have eaten here before for lunch and enjoyed it, but dinner I feel was a lot better.

We requested a table located in the back of the restaurant so we could enjoy the city view of the Bay Bridge.

We started off with some appetizers: 1) SONOMA FOIE GRAS
Dapple Dandy Pluot, Pistachio & Plum Biscotti, Plum Coulis
Fresh Santa Rosa Plums, 2) PANCETTA WRAPPED AMISH RABBIT
Rabbit Bolognese & Fava Ravioli, Golden Chanterelles 3) RED MONTEREY ABALONE Crispy Abalone Mushroom, Lemon Boy Tomatoes Tarragon-Chervil Aioli, Green Pico de Gallo (which was my least favorite). All good and ones I enjoyed, except for the Abalone.

For dinner we got: 1) ANGUS FILET MIGNON (CA)
WOOD OVEN ROASTED Fingerling Potatoes Roasted with Horseradish Cream, King Trumpet Mushrooms Spring Onion, Bloomsdale Spinach, Red Wine Butter Mushroom Jus with Caramelized Onion. Amazingly good!! 

This restaurant was great from the meal to the staff. I look forward to coming back here again for dinner
author: Kristen E.

description: I came here a few weeks ago to celebrate a coworkers 40th birthday. In the tough economy we are all dealing with it is hard to splurge on an expensive meal, but I do believe I was able to experience a preview of how great Boulevard's entrees must taste. We ordered a bowl of the cream of artichoke soup, the pear salad and a glass of sparkling wine. The soup was to die for. Full of flavor and zest. The salad had some blue cheese crumbles, slices of pear and tiny pieces of pomegranate. Delicious! The atmosphere will take your mind off work and for a few hours it almost feels like it's the weekend!
author: Jen B.

description: While Bobo's is right at the heels, I still think Boulevard has the best filet in the city. So. freaking. good. They also make a mean scallop. Service was a leeeettle under par the last time I was here but still very good.
author: Derek B.

description:
This is my forth time I have tried this restaurant. In the past, the soup was luke warm and I had to sent it back. Today for lunch which was comped because of a financial seminar the overall food experience was below par.

The salad dressing had no zeal  the cheese and bacon on the top of salad had no taste,   

The main course, American Kobe Bavatte(sliced beef), the meat was luke warm and all I taste was the pepper corn, the sauce did not
bring the dish together.  

The dessert, a trio of a sauced banana and chocolate cake with fresh whipped cream with coffee gelato ice cream was just average. 

The service was excellent and the red wine served was fine.
But for what I figured total to a $ 50 per person, the meal was sub par.

I will not be coming back.
author: Food Sage W.

description:
Food is above average...I liked the stuffed with crab meat squid but for crying out loud a steak ordered medium well should NOT be raw in the inside!
What my major gripe is, is the long wait (despite lunch reservations) for the table then an even longer wait for the food to arrive. This in spite of telling the waitstaff (friendly) that I was in a bit of a time crunch.

This restaurant I believe is typically overrated by at least one star by everyone. Note to owners of said restaurant....please buy new chairs they are very uncomfortable in the lower back, and please make sure that the table doesn't wobble up and down.
author: Craig M.

description: Well, what can I say, I think I came in here expecting so much more. I have owned their cook book for a while, but have never ate here until now. I would say the lamb I got was about as good as a Fleming's steak house. I really thought I would expect more from a place that have chefs/owners. The service was ok. I don't think I would come back here again because it's 6 star prices at 3.5 star food. If someone was going to buy be dinner, i would definitely come back and try it again though.
author: Nick C.

description:
thank you, boulevard!

my husband actually uttered "we should do fine dining more often" after he finished (ok, more like inhaled) his filet mignon.  he finally GETS it!!

he also mocked me while he sliced through his steak as if it were a stick of room temperature butter while i had to put some elbow grease into my pork chop.   i was all set to order fish, until i was deceived by the big juicy pork chop i saw being delivered to a table near us.  however, everything else we had (dungeness crab salad, arugula salad, dessertS) was fabulous.  

we dined here on my birthday and i noticed throughout the course of the night that it was somewhat akin to being in kauai on our honeymoon, where EVERYONE was on their honeymoon.  i saw at least four other desserts w/ candles being delivered while we were there and when it came time for mine, the message read "congratulations".  well, gee, thanks :p
author: Carol O.

description: I love this place- if you want I pork chop that taste like pork, this is the place. I always forget about this place until its been too late and I've already eaten somewhere else. We recently entered guests and I remembered Boulevard- we were not disappointed.  Excellent food and service. It was a little over $300 for the four of us and worth it.
author: Tracy B.

description: I've been here so many times that sometimes I take for granted how consistently good it is.  It's near my office so it's a very convenient place to have a work dinner function.  The menu is pretty good and there is always something interesting on the menu.  The wine list is fairly extensive so you'll be able to find a good bottle.  You will typically need to make reservations here as they seem to be constantly busy.  On the pricier side, but worth it.
author: V C.

description: I came here with a Silicon Valley CEO and a journalist for lunch at 1.30pm on a weekday. It was frankly an embarassing experience.The waiter was curt and didn't smile once (aside from when bringing the check), the food came at McDonald's speed, I think I told the bus boy *not* to clear our main course  about five times in 15 minutes. I was so annoyed I barely tasted the food and would never come back .. even on an expense account.
author: jane t.

description:
I went to Boulevard on business in San Francisco recently and it was a blast. The service is above par. We ordered drinks while waiting for our guests and they arrived in the middle of our drinking. The staff was nice enough to bring our drinks to the table for us and add them to the bill.

We all looked at the menu and saw many appetizers that we liked. The wait staff again was great and doubled the size of a couple of the plates so we could all have a sample. We got the Abalone, Stuffed Calamari, Scallops and Crispy Veal Sweetbreads. The seafood was cooked just right and the sweetbreads were definitely crispy. Some people don't like sweetbreads, but these were very good, a little earthy and a little sweet.

I had the Berkshire Pork Chop. Again this was cooked perfectly and the sides of mashed potatos and carmellixed onions and cooked figs were sweet and a good accompaniment to the pork chop.I finished up with their Strawberry, Strawberry Strawberry dessert; a small strawberry pie, strawberry ice cream and 'vanilla infused' strawberry. 

Everything at Boulevard was cooked perfectly and I can not say enough good things about the staff.  They were courteous and helpful, but with out going over the top. I had a fine time at Boulevard and would recommend it to anyone with the time in San Francisco.
author: Gregg T.

description:
meh. that was the feeling i left with and still have. meh. 
my fish was good, the 2nd time around, the 1st time it was overcooked. my friend's dishes were good. the salad was ok. the filet mignon was also good, the 2nd time around, same scenario as above. the desserts were very good! the service was meh. one of those that are professional and courteous, but obviously fake and couldn't care less about your experience there. defensive and awkward too. not good. i like good service, i respect people who take pride in their work and take care of their customers/guests, i mean, it's called the service industry for a reason, right?! you're supposed to take care of people and make them feel welcomed. that wasn't the case here. and it wasn't just him, the manager too, the service was definitely lacking, but they are professional. i won't be back, plenty of other friendlier AND better restaurants in the city, in my opinion. 
but when they cook the food properly, it is good, i have to say that. when it's done right it deserves 4 stars; however, w/ mess-ups and iffy service - 3 stars max!
author: Ilovelife Z.

description: Great setting and delicious food. Pork Chop is amazing. Best Cucumber Gimlet. A must eat.
author: Erin T.

description: excellent exection.  every time.  great food for lunch.  great food for dinner.  awesome service and cool building.  can't think of a reason not to go...still great after all these years
author: nick g.

description: I was way beyond discontent to even criticize the quality of their food....our waiter was the most discourteous one i've ever seen at a fine dining restaurant!!!  That's really too bad for this well known restaurant.
author: sharon q.

description: This place seemed popular by the out of town convention attendees, so  it was a hopping place.  On this night, it was definitely a little louder than usual.   It's a fancy restaurant with a full menu, so bring a big appetite.  I had the filet mignon and that was enough for me.  I didn't even have room for desserts.   Will try it again with an even bigger appetite.
author: Jeff H.

description:
one word, four syllables: over-rated.

disenchanted by the stuffy atmosphere (hello we're in san francisco!) and the long hike to go the ladies room. 

we had a business lunch here, and the service was incredibly slow, the food didn't light up any fireworks for me and parking in the area is insane! even flagging down a cab was difficult!

i hate to strike down such a renowned sf institution but i must. perhaps i will give it another shot, and i will experience what everyone else above & below is hollering about. 

boulevard, you still have a chance to gain two more stars from me.
author: Kat C.

description:
This place is really good. Definitely expensive, but worth it. 

The service is perfect. 

Try the calamari for an app and definitely try the chocolate tart for dessert. Wow, that's one of the best desserts I've had. 

The fish is good, but not great. The vegetables and mushrooms are what makes the dishes.
author: John W.

description: Oh man, the Filet Mignon! + a good Cab *muah* bellissimo!  I will be coming back just for that juicy, perfectly cooked and still-good-the-next-day-microwaved Filet Mignon. I wouldn't do the appetizers again but I barely remember what they were.
author: MT U.

description: Fantastic meal!  On a visit from Boston and really enjoyed it!  The restaurant is beautiful, the bartenders are top notch, server was great and the food was wonderful.  Can't wait to go again on my next trip to your wonderful city!
author: Heather B.

description: This is such a wonderful place for a special night out.  My husband and I had an excellent experience in every way.  The atmosphere is warm and cozy even through the restaurant is quite large.  The service was impeccable and the food absolutely delicious.  We have recommended Boulevard to out-of-state visitors, and have always had rave feed-back.  We look forward to many more visits.
author: Judith S.

description:
My boyfriend took me here for my birthday.

We had reservations but still had to wait a bit. The food wasn't the best, but there was a beautiful view (if you sat near the windows and if there was still a little sunlight left by the time you got there.

Food was good but not great. Haven't been back since.
author: Sally A.

description: Everything was wonderful except the burger...which was dry and ovrcooked..Go figure.   Soup.. fab..Scallops...beyond wonderful.  The room is beautiful. Great service.
author: Bleep S.

description:
This restaurant has a special place in my heart. Truly the best meal you can find in the city, and a romantic, beautiful setting to enjoy it in.

Boulevard is (and will probably always be) my favorite restaurant in San Francisco...
author: S.J. B.

description:
On my favorites for dinner. The place has a great decor, if you get at the back of the place you have an amazing view of the bay bridge. 

They have one of the best foie gras in town, you cant miss it!

I am a steak fan and since the menu is relatively short, the 3 entrees they have on beef are great! Amazing Rib Eye, but the best is their Lamb T-bone. They usually do them woven roasted which enhances flavor. 

Never asked for fish, although my wife order the salmon once and wasnt the best (on their deffense, it was alaska salmon which is white and my wife was looking for the regular nice pink salmon filet)

Their desserts are good, they used to have one of the best chocolate mousse I have ever had! However, they change the menu relatively often (Kind of every 6 months or something) and I havent find it again.

Carefull, is $$$$, not the every day place!!!!
author: Roger N.

description: Another one of the restaurant I like but prefer not to go back anytime soon.  Maybe perhaps when I'm older, much older.  It's like one of those place where you know exactly what you wanted than you would go there.  As for me, I'm still exploring, that's why I went.  Now I know.  The food is really good, absolutely love their desert.  It's definitely a bit on the pricey side.  The sad part about it, and this has nothing to do with the restaurant, all the food I ate there came right back where it went in, I had a little too much to drink.  Know your drinking limit before going, so your stomach could enjoy the food as much as your mouth does as it goes in and not the second time round as it comes out.  yeah...heheeeeee
author: Xiu L.

description: This restaurant has been around for ages, yet my first time going to eat here was this past Sunday.  My husband and I ventured out sans our three kids for an early Valentine's Day dinner.   I think the most romantic restaurants in SF are along the waterfront.   I'm a water-bearing Aquarius, can you tell?   After a wonderful dinner of foie gras, ahi tuna tartare, dover sole, shortribs and their chocolate ganache cake we left wondering why the heck we didn't come here sooner.  I can't wait to go back.   The cocktails there are pretty strong so be careful, ladies!  My husband thought he could get another kid out of me after a couple of those peach martinis :P
author: Christina L.

description: A great all around experience.  I had the pleasure of eating here on a business trip thanks to the reservation skills of my local host.  We had a great meal - with equally great wine.  The service was good and the restaurant is well put together.  Perhaps I credit my 5 star review to the fact that I live in Chicago and it is difficult to get fresh seafood here - but I thought Boulevard was one of the best dinners I've ever had.  I hope one day I'll get to go back.
author: adam k.

description: Boulevard is one of the amazing restaurants in San Francisco.  Everything on the menu from steaks, appetizers, drinks and desserts are just elegantly served in an atmosphere quite enthralling and very seductively appealing. It can be a great place to take a hot date on a cool breezy night or cold night in San Francisco. Though its cuisine is French inspired, the portions aren't and every bite is well worth splurging a pricey dinner with 'your family or your mainstay squeeze.  Bon a petit...You are worth it...:) RESERVATIONS are mandatory as it may take weeks to get in.
author: Richelle W.

description: Somewhat over-rated...food was mediocre and expected more for a number 1 restaurant on some of the review websites....
author: Yan M.

description: I've heard a lot of good things about Boulevard.  So I came in with high expectations.  We started with scallops, which were cooked perfectly.  My husband had the black cod, which he thought was good, but a bit undercooked, whereas I had the halibut, which I thought was slightly overcooked.  Nonetheless, we enjoyed our meal and the wine (they have a pretty extensive wine selection).  For dessert, I had the chocolate ganache and my husband had the red velvet cake trio (yummy).  Overall, the experience was good, but for the price and the hype, I expected more, which is why only 3 stars.
author: Cindy G.

description: I had a blast here the other night. Note: I was just at the bar, full menu service though. I walk by here all the time because it's near my gym. I had this preconception, based on going here a few years ago, that it was strictly fancy, business, chi-chi kind of restaurant.
