Well a buddy hangs out here and we went to the bar the other night for wine and appetizers. I ended up getting the white fish entree, with shrimp stuffed artichoke. I'm a total sucker for a well prepared artichoke. This place is great- not only is the food stellar, the sommelier is very nice, knowledgeable, and accommodating, but also the vibe here, the people and the entire "dinner as theater" phenomenon works to its favor. Great place- new favorite! Caution: very spendy, but definitely worth it.
author: Anna B.

description: Expensive and romantic.  Maybe even sexy.  I had the crab salad and it was good enough to be an small entree for me.  The dinner cost bucks but if you're on a date you want to impress you won't mind.  The service was spotless and the restaurant itself was really busy.  It was almost annoying.  My vegetarian companion complained about the menu, however, and did not think they offered enough options for the no meat eaters.  C'est la vie.
author: Angelina J.

description: Ok ... 3 luke-warm ravioli for $18?   Sorry, Pat, but unless you can figure out how to integrate more of the Jardinaire/ Martini House style/food [emphasis on MH] I ain't coming back.
author: Gavin M.

description: My husband and I ate there on a Fri night, no reservations so chose to sit at the "bar" area in front of the grill which was AWESOME. We got to see the cooks in action and stay warm at the same time. My Filet was fat, juicy, tender and gone in a matter of minutes. Salad was perfect, wine was great, server was very good. No room for dessert (unusual for me), maybe next time....
author: Jasmin F.

description: Scheduled the lunch for my *small* wedding here and it was lovely.  We booked their Wine Vault, a cozy, semi-private room (semi-private only because occassionally servers may have to come in to grab a bottle of wine, not because it is open to the main dining room in any way), and everyone was able to order from the menu.  The food was delicious, service was good, and they even cut and served our small wedding cake for us.
author: Bridget L.

description: I'm pretty skeptical of expensive restaurants since there's so much good cheap food in the city. But, I went for a date with my girlfriend on a Monday night. It was much better than I expected. Most memorable for me was the service. It was amazing. Neither rushed nor ignored. Really helpful with deciding what to order. Great atmosphere in there. And, the food was delicious, of course.  Highly recommended for a special night out.
author: Ethan B.

description: WOW!! What the hell took me so long to eat dinner here?! It was spectacular from start to finish. Amazing food--local/sustainable ingredients executed perfectly and memorably, outstanding service (waiter was very knowledgeable and helpful, yet nearly invisible), incredible ambience (beautiful and quite interior looking out at the bay bridge all lit up), and the feel of an elegant but casual meal (not the extra-fancy n-course ordeal often associated with food of this caliber). I plan to return as often as my time and wallet permit! :)
author: Joseph S.

description:
i don't hand out five stars readily, but this place is just... really good.  but pricey.  that's better than places that are pricey and have dishes that don't match up.  

this is a place where you won't be disappointed.  i don't like the tight seating arrangement and noise level, but in terms of food... it's top notch.
author: Erika C.

description: Good solid food, but nothing special. And for these prices, I expect something special. I'm glad I came here since this place is almost an SF institution, however, I would never come back. For the money, I could go to somewhere spectacular like Gary Danko or Myth... yummier!
author: Karen C.

description: A great restaurant with a good atmosphere and great food.  When I came here I had the filet mignon with mashed potatoes and mushrooms.  It was a good dish, though I enjoyed my friend's dish a little bit more.  She had pork cooked three ways and it was an excellent dish.  Overall I was very satisfied with the meal
author: Josh W.

description: Great Food! Great Atmosphere and Wonderful Service! No wonder why it's always packed!!  Last time, we were squeezed in, at the Bar, on a Saturday night with no reservation:) (I really appreciate it) It's always an enjoyable experience to dine there. Place is ideal for a Romantic dinner or a business event. Deserves the 5-stars and I highly recommend it!
author: Steph H.

description: I agree with Kimm W! Boulevard is definitely Phenomenal and consistent! The streak is melt in your mouth steak! Everything I had on the menu was very well made. It is pricey but you pay for quality and the food speaks for itself! I'm definitely a fan!
author: Christine L.

description: First time, phenomenal.  Second time, great.  Third time, eh.  Yet, I know I'd still go back for dinner here, no doubt.  Most times, you'll probably find creative entrees that simply please.  Enjoy an early dinner and you'll enjoy the work of a fresher staff as well.
author: Alfonso E.

description:
Nothing tastes better than a fabulous dinner on the company's dime! :0) 

We had the pleasure of dining in the semi-private room at the Boulevard- what a treat. Its warm, inviting and not terribly loud, with a mirror on one side, wine bottles lining the other wall and the ceiling with some sort of brick overlay... very cool... 

Their crab salad, tuna tartare and mixed green salad were amazingly tasty appetizers. Great way to start an excellent meal. Service was superb, as it should be. 

For dinner, I had the Walu- while the fish was cooked to perfection, I wasnt a fan of the dry mushrooms on my plate. I'm usually a mushroom fan but these tasted like they were picked out of the garden. No thanks. Next to me, I tried the SeaBass with the most delicious risotto. Though my Walu tasted better, I wish my side was equally satisfying. People at the table ordered the filet mignon, lamb and pork- all were pleased.

For dessert, I opted for a duo of ice cream- Guava and Coconut Mango... I'm a sucker for good icecream and this did not let me down.

Overall, I was very impressed with our meal at Boulevard. A few tweaks to the menu and I think they've got something here! :0)
author: Vic M.

description:
Dined here many times over the years. When I first started going in 2003, folks were saying that it was falling off, but I never saw it. 

Great menu and the service is excellent. If you want a great meal and to impress a date or work colleague, come here.  The food is American cuisine with a nod towards to the west coast. All meat and seafood dishes are delicious and even the desserts can't be passed up.

It is a casual place but I always feel better dressing up a little.
author: J R.

description: I am surprised that I do not eat here as much as I should given the proximity to my home.  Great selection of wines and spirits to start.  The appetizers and entrees are are exquisite.  The deserts are the bomb.  Share at your own risk.
author: Javier O.

description: Food=excellent, service=very good and the ambiance is perhaps the best in town.    They fixed the missing faucet in the mens room and as promised they've be upgraded to a four star.  If they want five... they should have someone cleaning the sink area in both bathrooms more frequently-after all, they pride themselves as being amoung the best so do what's right and give the people a place to primp before makin out with their date post foodgasm!!!
author: John C.

description:
This is where I've been sending my clients? So I had a 1st date with a young lady I recently met and she worked nearby, yada yada - Boulevard. So we have 5:30PM reservations that they called to confirm 2 days prior. We get there at 5:25PM and they're still setting tables. The hostess shuffles us off to the bar for drinks, which seems mildly like a ploy to juice us, but whatever.

The drink waitress seemed indifferent an like she was trying to rush us. I noticed after 20 minutes a lot of tables are starting fill up. So I ask the hostess what's up - we have 5:30PM party of 2, which we confirmed as soon as we walked in. She says I thought your party was incomplete. I said, "We're a party of 2. She was standing right next to me when we check ed in." She has someone take us to a table 1/2 way into the restaurant to a small table across from the kitchen. It reeks of gas and people kept getting seated across from us even closer to the kitchen then bailing out for another table (3 times). 

So the waiter, a bald guy also with no smile, gives us our menus. The portions were embarrassingly small. My date's rice bed under her tiny salmon portion wasn't even hot and was under cooked. I asked the waiter if he could take it back and have it re-bedded on hot, cooked rice. He offered to bring a side of the rice. It was steaming hot and had small nuts that the original one didn't. My lamb was fine, but also seemed like a tiny portion. The calamari appetizer was also not very generous. 2 bites each for 2 people for $17. Decent, but an organsm in my mouth, it wasn't. 

You'd think for $100 for 2 people without any alcohol at all, the staff could preform like they had been doing this for more than a week, act surprised to hear food was poorly prepared, muster a smile and pretend they wanted to be there 1 day before Thanksgiving. 

Also, to the asian guy who just popped in to scrape the crumbs off the table - if you've had no contact with the table prior to that moment, just popping in and aggressively scrapping crumbs without so much as an acknowledgement or a "pardon me sir" when both of us are leaning forward on the table chatting - it's a little intrusive and coarse.

I've also eaten at Hawthorne Lane, Aqua, Crustacean and back in the day - Sol y Luna & Arianna/Blue Fox and I'd take any of them over this place that's supposed to be in the top 2 or 3 restaurants in SF. When the decor and valet are the highlights of the experience, it's time to move on down the list and leave this one in the rear view mirror. I've seriously had more attentive service with a better atitude almost every time I've been to Denny's.
author: Joey N.

description: Ok, loved the food here.  I woudl recommend this place, had the softshell crab which was very nice.  Then had the lamb for the main which was also very tasty....but the best part was the chocolate doughtnut!!  Sounds strangely pornographic, but alas no, it was very very tasty.
author: Adam S.

description:
Excellent restaurant, but not worth the price...

The decor in Boulevard is very nice, classy but warm. The tables are a bit close to each other, but the noise level isnt terrible. Still, not the best for holding hands and gazing into each others eyes, when theres a table a few feet away. The service was excellent. Im youngish and the crowd is quite a bit older, so I normally expect to be condescended to and frowned upon (as I have at Hawthorne Lane). Not so here, everyone was polite and courteous and very helpful, since my girlfriend is very indecisive the waiter was more than happy to suggest both an entree and dessert, both which she was very happy with. The food was very good, but not astounding. Sauces tend to be a bit heavy or overdone. Good though, I think thats just my personal taste talking. The fish was a bit overdone, I like my salmon as rare as possible, and although many places can cook a nice rare steak, a nice rare fish is harder to come by. We had some fruit flavored iced teas (too much drinking during the night before!) which were very tasty. Dessert was presented nicely and was light and refreshing. There were definitely more entree and dessert items that I would have liked to try. I think we had crab cakes for an appetizer which were decent, not that great. My main problem with Boulevard is that its way overpriced, the food is comparable to Dine or many other places, nothing that really stood out. But if you dont mind paying for the nice decor and atmosphere, and want an upscale place, then I guess its OK. I probably wont be going back though, but it was good to try once. Just dont go because you want astounding food.

Pros
Very nice atmosphere, great service, good food

Cons
Overpriced and overhyped!

The Bottom Line
Very good food, but not astounding. Excellent service. Good for an upscale lunch. Nice atmosphere. But overall, overpriced and overhyped.

(p.s. i wrote this for another site a while ago but it still applies!)
author: Junglist S.

description:
Is there are moment when a great restaurant moves past prime and starts to descend, resting on its laurels, getting complacent in the idea that people will come no matter what? I wondered that last night about Boulevard.

THE FOOD
The scallop appetizer had three lovely scallops, perfectly cooked, and started us off on a good note. 

The four little gnocchi that followed were as flat as their flavor and the rabbit loin wrapped in pancetta tasted like the flavors had melded too long - an odd hammy taste overwhelmed. My companion commented that it was almost like a hot dog. 

My companion's filet mignon was ordered medium but came rare and with a heavy hand on the cheesy topping - the taste evoking of all things a blue cheese burger. She was unhappy not only with the rawness but the chewiness as well. 

My lamb was excellent but the waiter insisted that I order it medium instead of the medium rare I initially requested. I let him prevail but really, shouldn't I have it the way I want it? The greens that accompanied it were too bitter to complement the sweetness of the lamb.

The chocolate cake was oddly dry - hard to do with a flourless cake. It made me wonder about its age. The root beer part of the root beer float ice cream was almost a granita and seemed almost drained of its root beer color and flavor. The foam was tasteless. Only the little tuile of chocolate cookie and a cute little of spiral of spun sugar brought the whole dessert above absolutely pedestrian.

My companion and I both agreed - the whole meal tasted like a hotel dinner - in another city. 

THE SERVICE
Odd gaffes abounded. We were nicely greeted and the hostess gathered menus and napkins and then started to walk us to our table when she abruptly stopped, put down the menus etc. and greeted the people behind us. She then checked in two groups before she got back to us again, leading us to stand awkwardly wondering what was happening.

We did have a 5:45 reservation and I know restaurants like to flip tables but the person busing our table took away our wine glasses when they were empty without asking us whether we wanted a refill or saying anything at all. He just darted in his arm and sped off faster than a seagull nabbing a French fry. I eat quickly and surrendered my plate a bit before my companion was finished with her entrée. The bus person starting asking her if she was finished as soon as she was half done with the filet. Sigh. She finally let him have it when she was about three quarters done. Maybe there were orphan children in the kitchen.

The waiter was fine, attentive at first, but less so as time went on (not asking about more wine), an average experience. 

To be honest, I don't think we'll return.
author: Ann L.

description: Unequivocal 5 stars. I have been to many great restaurants in SF and all over the bay area, but this is definitely my favorite. I have never had a bad meal.
author: Lindsey S.

description: Boulevard was my Birthday pick last summer right after moving to the City. It was truly a fun and memorable night out... from martinis through dessert. However, I thought it was over-hyped and under-flavored. We enjoyed 2 or 3 apps that were all pretty outstanding and then when the entrees arrived... nothing. Perfectly prepared but nothing amazing that propelled Boulevard to the top of the Future Special Occasions list. I can deal with the high prices when it's one of those occasions but I was just not wowed. At all.
author: margot b.

description: My husband took me here for my birthday and from beginning to end, Boulevard delivered an amazing experience.    For starters ,I ordered the calamari stuffed with lobster and mushrooms - the calamari was tender, not rubbery and delightful.  He had the dungeness crab salad - which had wonderful flavors, light and delicious.  The entrees.  Now here is where the difference is.  If you go to Boulevard, you MUST, MUST have the Berkshire pork - it is out of this world.  Now, you may think, it's pork, how good can it be - but trust me it was unreal.  I kept taking bites off of his plate.  My  lamb was quite good, it was just that the pork was culinary bliss.  We had butterscotch pudding and rocky road brownie, both were a delightful sweet end to the evening.  Throughout it all, the wait staff was very attentive.  I don't think our water glasses ever went down more than 10% .  We sat side by side with a view of the kitchen which was fun.  Other tables had a view of the bridge which would be great too.  Great place to go, I would give it 5 stars, but the lamb was just not what I hoped for, especially after trying the pork.
author: Jen M.

description: Still a fine restaurant, well executed. Servers are kind of stuffy and pretentious, basking in the glow of the wealthy locals. Every dish was very good to excellent. Nothing we was incredibly innovative, but so what? Wines by the glass are surprisingly affordable as they include some well chosen but lower priced bottles. Our favorite dish this night was the quail.
author: t w.

description: Love this place for lunch or dinner! One of the best, gourmet lunches in town! Always great food! Great environment! Great location as I lived around the corner! Great wine list!
author: Jeanette S.

description: This place says "ol' reliable" when you walk in.  You pay some money, you get some great food.  Great service too.  Nice location.  Nice atmosphere.  Every town has at least one great steak place that does everything right.  Let's be clear that Boulevard isn't bold.  You get the reliably good food and the same experience every time.  Every town needs such a place, and Boulevard delivers the goods.
author: Brian D.

description: Another place that has been around for years and been good every year.  There isn't even much snobbery given the years of top ratings.  Really, a beautiful interior, great food, nice wine list.  If it was just a bit less expensive and not so hard to get in to, I would love to call it my cafeteria.
author: Zac A.

description:
beautiful room in a central downtown location.  caters to the expense account crowd, but really has something for everyone.  casual-ish bar area to grab a bite, loud and lively front area, quieter back dining room, and a private room that doubles as a wine cellar.  enough room where its easy enough to get a reservation, but doesn't feel like a vast cafeteria (e.g. ozumo's back room).

food is consistently excellent.  not really daring, but always some solid choices.  most recent trip, i had the lamb, which was a perfect medium rare.  the desserts are a cut above comparable locations.
author: Matt G.

description: I have to say, there are times I heart my job and eating free is definitely one of the perks.  So Boulevard is lovely.  I'm scared to know what the bill was but I figure my ignorance is a good thing.  I have a strong suspicion it was one of the more expensive dinners I've been on.  I had abalone followed by the rack of lamb.  It was succulent and wonderful.  Dessert was fabulous too.  Probably one of the best meals I've had ever.  My cosmo was perfect and the wine divine.  I know I'm using a lot of adjectives vs. descriptive passages re: the food but its been awhile since I ate there.  In short, my impression was: a truly a fantastic place.  The decor is also gorgeous, very french art deco.  I felt like I was in Paris in some tres chic restaurant.  This place is great for:  romantic dinner, place to impress anyone, business dinner/lunch.
author: Ann F.

description: We came for a rehearsal dinner and were seated in the private wine cellar room. Everything on the menu looked great so it was definitely difficult to decide. We had great service and everyone seemed blown away with their food. The steak especially was a big hit. An amazing dinner celebrating an amazing couple.
author: Adrienne G.

description:
I have the luxury of possessing work hours that are not of the norm. I generally leave  work around 12:00 noon. I may have a meeting with a client (or two) in the middle of the afternoon or the rest of the day is mine. Either way, I always have time to lunch and most times rather well. I do not have kids and my dogs' dietary requirements, do not decree an exorbitant amount of funding for her less then sophisticated palette. 
     That being said, I spend quite the sum on dining out and trust me, you are going to need a small fortune to dine well at this establishment. If you save your ducats, this experience is well worth it. Well prepared fare, a fully stocked bar, a more than sufficiently stocked wine selection and fantastic service will channel you into consumption comatose. That's not a bad thing. It's the cash coma you want to be leery of. I find one way of hurdling this obstacle, is to intake at these high-end restaurants during the lunch hours. The price-points on both appetizers and entrees are not as steep, the restaurant is not so "stuffy"and you have the rest of the day to enjoy. I feel you leave here more then satisfied, knowing that you have dined well and at (not quite) a fraction of the cost. 
     If you can't get out for lunch and supper time is your only option. Then may I suggest ordering a few of the appetizers. That way you know they are going to be small plates/portions but you get grazing options. Trust me, you leave on such a different level when you feel that you got what you paid for. Plus, you get to sample a cross section of what the restaurant has to offer, giving you more insight to the whole dining experience. I highly recommend Boulevard... you just have to know how to dine here.
author: Gabe T.

description: I have a confession to make. I have not been to Boulevard in many years. I don't remember what I ate. I don't remember what I drank.  I was far from being drunk-- that's something I just don't do. It's just that it was so long ago. All I remember is that is was excellent. I know that me and my whole family loved it. So why am I writing this review now? Yelp didn't exist back then.
author: Hunter G.

description: Boulevard is a restaurant I knew I would love from the second I walked in the door. The French Art Nouveau decor charmed me instantly, and the restaurant had a pleasant vibe. The crowd tends to be a bit older, probably due to the prices. My meal was fantastic, probably one of the best I had in 08. I would recommend Boulevard for a special occasion when money isn't a concern. It's not a place I'd want to try on a budget. Cocktails, wine and dessert are all in order.
author: Katherine S.

description:
3.5 stars

i don't understand why everyone keeps raving about this restaurant.  best restaurant in sf?  i dont think so.  sure the food is tasty but it lacks the wow factor.  the bf's fish entree was a bit dry, his beef carpaccio w/ oysters was decent - the batter on the oysters was too thick.  my filet mignon was a tad salty and the portion was small considering the $40 price tag.  my sweetbreads and mushroom bisque was also a tad salty.

service was quite attentive though.

i wont be heading back b/c i can enjoy better food at better prices elsewhere.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
This restaurant is awesome! My husband took me here for a belated birthday dinner. The decor is lovely, and somewhat dark. First, our server was probably the best server ever. I really wish I knew his name so I could put him on blast, the man even had a crumb cleaning tool....  He was GREAT. We ordered the calamari as a starter...um AMAZING. Meyer Lemon Drop: AMAZING. When I wasn't sure what beer to order, our server brought me a sample of what he thought I might like. He was so right. The filet mignon...god...there really is nothing quite like it. When I cut into it (which I didn't even need to do since it was just so tender) the aroma made me salivate. It was so delicious. We were full, but we still ordered some fruit and cheese as a dessert, and even that was tasty even though we were so full! And as a special surprise, my server brought a little bowl of ginger ice cream and cookie with a piece of chocolate that said Happy Birthday.
Everything about this meal from the service, to the ambiance, the drinks, the food (even the sauces and presentation).....perfect and worth every penny. I can't wait to come back :)
author: C M.

description: adding my $0.02 here... PHENOMENAL! I was also blessed with good company (this was my going away meal with my Fabulous Boss) but really, this was just a beautiful experience. Started with a Pimm's cup, I think I am going to start a list for where to get those in the Bay area. They supplied me with extra cucumber garnish! Love that! Then had the butter lettuce salad with something something tomatoes and avocado. Everything there was divine. I wish I could make simple salads taste so good at home! There was something about the avocado, it was chopped and laid on the tomato slices and it was kind of extra tasty and flavorful. I don't know, but it was GOOD. then, main was the sea bass with risotto and ham hocks and again... something something. This was beyond. Again, I only wish I could make fish that tender and flaky (Alton Brown swears this is a misnomer... nothing can be tender yet flaky. But this was!) and the risotto was just perfect, flavored with the ham. Yum. Then the dessert was the Caramel Chocolate ganache. So good, I did not even sweeten my coffee. We ended up splitting this because my boss wanted to take her dessert home to her son. Ok with me! It was so rich, I could have finished it but been sick afterwards. Attentive with the coffee refills too - that deserves extra credit in my book. It was a little loud towards the end of the meal (we had 5:45 reservations, so there was literally no one there when we sat down) but even still, food and service were excellent, so I could handle the loudness! Very recommended for the business meal, great for visitors (again for business!) and the decor is very comfortable without being too lazy or too over the top. I think I like it here...
author: Holly C.

description:
I wanted to like Boulevard better.  I've been wanting to try it for a while I took the opportunity to go last time my parents were in town.  It wasn't awful and my meal was fine (I had lamb), but it seemed as if they weren't making the best effort to provide a dining experience comparable with their reputation, not to mention their price.  First, they mixed up my and my dad's entrees.  Then, my mom's fish was bad.  Bad as in didn't taste fresh, not bad as in she didn't like it.  They replaced it, but still.  This place didn't get its reputation based on serving less than the freshest fish.  And they really rushed us.  We didn't order tons of expensive things, but they shouldn't have pressured us to leave so quickly (we were given our check a little less than an hour after we were seated, even after we had to wait for new fish.  

I was expecting so much more.  My lamb was good, and I'd be willing to give it another shot, providing someone else was paying!
author: M M.

description: My wife and I have had some outstanding meals at Boulevard over the course of the last several years.  Alas, this visit was a disappointment, largely because of mediocre food.  Our beet salad was unimpressive and rather miniscule.  And both the halibut and swordfish entrees were bland and uninteresting, more focused on appearance than on taste.  So based on this experience, the restaurant would appear to be riding on its past reputation.  It will be awhile before we return.  Too bad, another icon bites the dust.
author: Jay D.

description: Dining at Boulevard is an absolut must for anyone living in SF.  It's definitely a splurge restaurant, but well worth it.  Similar to Bacar, they have a great wine list (although I don't remember anything being priced exceptionally well -- no big surprise there.)  I went for my birthday dinner and the kitchen prepared a nice dessert that had "happy birthday heather" on it -- a nice touch.
author: Heather C.

description: Always completely satisfied with every visit at Boulevard!  I often come here for the tuna tartare & crab salad (or their crab cakes YUMM!)  for lunch.  Always very satisfying.  Especially the tuna tartare since the restaurant Tartare closed =(   For dinner I usually take my pick of their fresh fish entrees.  Always cooked perfect, and we all know how easily it is to screw up seafood.  Service is great and always friendly and inviting.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Classy restaurant near the Embarcadero.  I finally got to try this place on a business dinner after hearing so much about it.  I had a green salad with ripe figs and gorgonzola cheese...yum!  I love salads and this was a nice combo.  Some of my co-workers didn't care too much for it because of the figs.  And for my main entree, I had the filet mignon.  It came out medium as I had requested.  Juicy and tender...done very nicely.  Overall, a place I would only come on special occassions due to their pricey menu.  A bit too snotty for me.
author: Mick S.

description: Good eats, good atmosphere, great dessert.  Enough said.  But if you plan on going to dinner here, be sure to make reservations.  If you're looking for a place to have business lunches or reserve a private room for an event, go here.  It's great.  They have exceptional service and yummy food.  As long as it's the company that's paying for it and not you!  Your jaw will drop once you get the check.
author: Jin B.

description:
The food is incredibly good and always consistent here. I had my son's going away to college party here in the little wine room, and it was absolutely wonderful. I love the way the waitstaff are there, but not there. You are never wanting for anything. 
My favorite cocktaiil is a ginger martini. Favorite food is the lobster and anything that involves duck or squab. 
Only downside to me is the maze to get to the bathrooms and they are definitely due for an overhaul.
author: judith m.

description: Winner of several James Beard Foundation awards Pat Kuleto's French Brassiere is one of the best restaurants I've been to in San Francisco. The interior has beautiful Art Deco styling with mosaic pattern floors and beautiful ambient amber lighting. Pat Kuleto creates that special world with care and flair he is known for when designing a restaurant. The bar is so incredible (and word has it the oldest bar in San Francisco) you feel special just sitting there sipping your Kir Royal. I've even spotted celebrities on the occasions that I've dined there. Full bodied romantic atmosphere, impeccable food and knowledgeable staff.
author: JJ C.

description: Their filet mignon is perfection. Dessert was ginger creme brulee and chocolate cake with sprinkles of pomegranate. I normally dislike chocolate cake but theirs was fantastic-- moist, light, and flavorful. The service is good, although nowhere near the caliber of Fleur de lys or Picasso. Definitely worth visiting again for the food.  The portions are perfect for what fine dining is supposed to be about: the pleasure of tasting exquisite food. If one wants to fill up one's stomach like a  gas tank at the local Shell station, plenty of chain diners are available.
author: Faye S.

description: Boulevard is a crowd pleaser, hands down.  The menu has something for everyone.  Actually, on second thought, vegetarians might not be thrilled... but I was.  The appetizers and entrees cover the gamut of fish and meat and they are all well prepared and well complimented with great accoutrements.  While there are undoubtedly better restaurants in the city at this price point, Boulevard is still unique with a menu and atmosphere that sets it apart from the bulk of San Francisco dining.  Although it seems that most foodies don't choose it as their top choice, it should not be missed.  It's refreshing to have a no tapas, no Asian fusion, no avocado, no mod architecture place to go to in the city.
author: Dubs W.

description: Wow, this place is expensive, but what isn't down here? We were lucky and got a table in the back. That doesn't sound so lucky. The back? But the back is where the view of the bridge is. Yeah, you like views don't you? Views while eating super good food? Sure you do. Here's your place. We started out with foie gras and the dungeness crab salad. Awesome. The main dishes ordered were the lamb, filet mignon and no red meat for me, but pork, yes, thank you for being "the other white meat" because their suckling pig was so good I couldn't believe it. This is partly why I can't give up the pork. That and every type of cured Italian pork product. Yum. Anyway, save up some money, come here for a special occasion, enjoy.
author: Tan N.

description:
other than the hostess who said the walk was only 25 minutes from North Point to Mission(try 50 minutes, sister), the whole dining experience was lovely...

we were wearing jeans while everyone else was on the formal tip....
I was ok with that since my black t-shirt was new...

our waiter was cool and down to earth...
educating us on the menu and wines...

had the chorizo crusted halibut....
fresh...and delish...
everything else seemed to accentuate the taste of the halibut...
the creamed spinach, the fennel, the shallot,etc....
I hate onions....and that shallot was delicious...

my girl had the short-ribs and that was tasty too...

didn't seem like it would be filling but it was....
so dessert seemed like it would be out of the question....

but we did have bleu cheese w/ bread and other goodies, such as honey, almonds, cumquats(?), cherries, etc...

the half-bottle of pinot noir was perfect for the dinner....

they also have a perfect view of the bay bridge....
(being from down south, I guess that's kind of a big deal)

big ups to our waiter who navigated us through this fabulous dining experience....
author: Jared D.

description: I love this place! If you're craving fine dining, but not too stuffy place, come here.
author: April Rose D.

description: Boulevard holds a "sweet" spot in my heart as this was one of the first fine dining experiences that I had almost a decade ago (damn I'm old!). I remember trying to act all intelligent and sophistimacated, decked out in an oversized Hugo Boss suit that I bought at 75% off during one of those Macy's year-end clearance sales. Anyways, my date asks me if I like Sweetbread and instead of replying honestly with, "what's sweetbread???" I played it cool and said, "I LOVE sweetbread, let's get it". Needless to say, I was a little taken aback when the dish comes out and it looks like no Bread I've ever seen... and it sure as hell ain't sweet. Anyways, my cover was blown but I learned a lot that night. Just about anything tastes good fried!
author: James C.

description: What a great night! Terrific meal, menu, and service. Three of us shared a divine bottle of wine recommended by our server. My friends had filet and I had the sole. Per the suggestion of other yelpers we tried two desserts and they were sinful. Try to get Ethan's section. He knew the perfect wine to accompany a spectacular dinner.
author: Kate C.

description: I have been in Boulevard for 2 times.  For the food, I have nothing to complain.  But, with this price level, I would expect a better service.  First of all, even we have made reservation (10+ people each time), we still have to wait.  We waited for 45 minutes the 1st time and around 30 minutes the 2nd time.  For businessmen who have very tight schedule, I don't think that it's good place for lunch.  Secondly, the waiters there do not pay attention to our orders.  They messed up the orders, gave us the wrong food.  We asked for water 3 times and still had not get any.  For the first visit, we actually have pre-set our menu, the waiters just have to take the order from 2 choices of entrees.  The 2nd visit was at dinner time and it seemed to be better in services.
author: Roserrele W.

description: Great steak, beautiful presentation of all meals.  I can't give it 5 stars because (a) they made us wait 20 minutes for our table (even though we had reservations)  and (b) it was expensive and very rich.  Like I think I prefer my string beans with less butter.  But I think if you're a lover of true french cooking, then you'll think it's fine.  I think I'm a "california french" person :).
author: Annie F.

description:
everything on the menu looks like it would be delicious, i had a hard time choosing, but went for the kobe beef hamburger as my entree.
i started with the fried calamari which was AMAZING, not a huge portion but the perfect sized portion. we also had the ahi tuna tartare, also delicious.
i would say the hamburger was good, i ordered it med-well, which may account for its dryness, but the bun was delicious and tomatoes were divine the fries were to die for.
i also tried a bite of the dishes my dining partners were having, pork tenderloin- SOOOO YUMMY! and the seared scallops also very YUM!
we finished off our meal by sharing the apple blackberry cobbler w/ vanilla ice cream. i'm not a cobbler kinda girl but it was very tasty.


the service was excellent and the ambiance was very nice.
would definitely recommend this restaurant and will try going there for dinner some time.
author: jane k.

description: I'm giving it 4 stars since people only seem to be disappointed when they get hyped up about a place and inevitably are bummed out afterwards.  You shouldn't be if you're just looking for a good night out - it's unpretentious, you are filled up to the gills for the amount you pay and its finger licking good, the service is great (our waiter gave us some apertifs on the house), and the atmosphere can be loud but you know, I like it that way rather than feeling like the wait staff is hovering over you and watching your every move compared to other high-quality restaurants.
author: Rich C.

description: This is about as good as it gets. Friendly and attentive wait staff, a good bar, and excellent food. Great location too. It's definitely going to cost you some money but there's no question that it's worth it. I highly recommend it.
author: Carter F.

description: For weeks I've been hearing about the unprecedented splendor of Boulevard, so much so that I brought myself to actually make a reservation.  To my great disappointment, I found this place to be a bit frumpy, with an inexperienced wait staff and outrageous prices for mediocre food. The portions, however, were large, and the mini ice cream sandwich desserts were delicious.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Yeah!!! i am number 700 to write a review for The Boulevard. It was fantabulous! The food a 5, the service a 5, the decor a 5. Loved it. would definitley repeatt, everyday if i could. I was with a group of 4 and we were not the easiest people to serve. We had a few drinks, the ordering was all over the board. Nothing was like just sit down  shut up and order. Our waiter was very efficent and fast. Nice guy. Two of my companions had a view of a couple nearly getting it on unfortunatley my back was turned to the action. Damn.  After a huge San Francisco Weekend, this was a real treat on a Sunday evening. Make reservations. they are busy! We never felt rushed. Great time, great place, for a great city!
author: Donna S.

description: If you come here just for dinnner, I'd give this a 4-star recommendation, perhaps a 4.5 star, but add wine pairings and you get one hell of a great evening.  They will coordinate 1/4 pours, 1/2 pours or whatever your budget dictates.  Great wines, great meals; I will be BACK! Easily turn this into a 5 course by splitting entres and apps.
author: Nick S.

description:
3.5 Stars would be from my experience last week. Overall good, but not wow.
Bad:The bread was too cold and not tasty for some reason.  The plain butter didn't help.  The scallops for appetizer or starter plate was not tasty and not cooked well enough. The inside was a bit fleshy, though I wasn't quite sure if this was meant to be.  Leaving it cooked for least another minute would of been perfect.  In addition, the scallops had very few sand grains.   The pork dish was quite a disappointment.  None of the pork items were tasty. Either the wine numbed my taste buds, or  the pork was just bland lacking flavor.  I was expecting the taste to be better than a Roasted Crispy Pork you get at a Chinese Restaurant. Both the scallop and pork were not fufilling.  Another disappointment was the ghetto walk to their restrooms.  You leave the restaurant through a door and suddenly the bouvelard experience stops. It was like being in the movie Narnia - going through the closet and you are in another world.  In this case it was a dark door and you entered what I thought  was a deserted haunted hotel lobby.   I was like - oh my gosh.  Then you travel downstairs to the loo and again very plain and boring.

The good: See,  I do have a  lot of good things to say.  Service-- the best so far from my dining experience.  Not stuffy service you find at upper end restaurants, everyone I encountered were professional, geniune, polite, and happy.  They even listened to my concerns of my meal without attidude.  
The desserts (chocolate cake and the apple t) were top notch.  Those dishes were beautiful, tasty, and not too sweet at all.  I was surprised after my disappointing dinner that the desserts were top notch IMHO.  
The presentation of the scallops and pork dishes were done nicely and well laid out on the dish.  The decor in the restaurant andthe  men's restroom was nicely done --very frenchy.

Overall, despite my disappoinment with the food, the service and dessert made my decision to rank Boulevard 3.5.  Are there better restaurants in the city -- you bet there is.
author: Kevinwdw C.

description: Great atmosphere & dressy clientele, really feels like you've gone somewhere special.  The food was ok and the menu is broad, but you can certainly get better for considerably less money elsewhere in SF - everything we ordered at our table of 4 was ok but nothing was remarkable.  Our server was cheerful and attentive, but don't expect that from the sourpuss bartender or door staff.
author: Jeff P.

description:
The boy surprised me and took me here for my birthday last year; and let me tell you, if you're looking to go out for a special occasion, Boulevard is as good a place as any.  First of all, the service is phenomenal.  I don't know how they do it, but they manage to be attentive without making it seem like they're hovering or interrupting conversation.  The atmosphere is romantic and stylish, but somehow very relaxed all in one.  It's quiet enough to have a conversation easily, but not overly quiet so you feel like the tables around you are listening to every word you say.  But enough about atmosphere, the food, ahh the food...  I have to admit that I love a well-put together meal.  Boulevard is on the bandwagon of nouveau California cuisine, which I must say, isn't the most original concept these days, but I still enjoy.  We shared the crab-stuffed calamari as an appetizer (I'm sorry, you had me at crab-stuffed), basically perfection.  I had halibut, the boy had the pork chop.  Both were amazing.  Just lovely dishes of simple food cooked perfectly and well-seasoned.  We couldn't decide on just one dessert, so we settled for two.  I chalk this up to one of the better decisions in my life.  Both were exquisite.  

All in all, just a fabulous meal at a fabulous place.  Impressive without being uptight.  A wonderful way to spend a romantic evening.  And even if the food and atmosphere don't do it for you (though, I don't know why they wouldn't), the view alone is worth the trip.  Nothing like the view of the bay on a clear SF night to get you in the mood for love.
author: Chelsea D.

description: The food was good, not great. The best flavor pairing of the meal was the BLACK MISSION FIG & LATE SUMMER GRAPE SALAD. The goat was really smooth and creamy and went very well with the fig. I had an off-menu item for the main course, I had a pre-fix menu, the Kobe Beef Steak was a little more cooked than the medium-rare I asked for. Maybe because of that it wasn't as juicy and flavorful as I'd like. The Halibut looked delicious, but it was just  OK. I tried both the berry apple crisp and the flourless choco cake, the crisp was impressive looking and was very comforting. The choco cake was a bit heavy after a large meal. Otherwise, it was like eating smooth powdery fudge. I may give this place another go and try their filet mignon next time. Overall, for the price, the food could have been a lot better.
author: Olivia A.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in SF.  I wish I could afford to eat hear once a week, but unfortunately, that is not the case.  It is definately worth the price you pay and their menu is always amazing!  Can't wait for the next special occasion so I can eat here again.
author: Dana D.

description: Our reservations at Slanted Door got bumped two hours and fifteen minutes. We walked over to Boulevard. We needed a four top, so I walked in by myself and apologized for walking in without a reservation. The woman at the desk was very kind, while another staffer rolled her eyes jokingly. I can't blame her, I was taking a risk. I explained the situation and she looked through the book, but no luck. I thanked her for her time and I started to walk away. She called me back and said that a table in the bar was about to become free. The bar tables are first come, first served. We waited outside for fifteen minutes, then we were given a window table on the bar side. The staff was wonderful and the food was out of this world. There are somethings you can't put a price on. While the dining experience is expensive, you will be talking about this dinner for weeks to come.
author: John K.

description: The food and the service are both terrific.  We've been here twice and both times I've been really impressed with the quality of the food.  The atmosphere is classy and Parisian.  This is a great date or special occasion spot.  I think they have valet parking, but we were able to find street parking pretty easily.
author: Hayley B.

description: I took 3 friends to Boulevard and while the food is solid, there is nothing really special about the restaurant.  The ambiance is a bit blah, with traditional decor and the layout is not cozy.  A pretty loud restaurant and our waitress was not very friendly.  The price turns out to be as much as Gary Danko without the service and the atmosphere you'd expect for that much money.  It was approximately $100/person with one drink, appetizer, dinner, and dessert.  I won't go back; it's not worth the money.
author: Audra E.

description: This is a great lunch spot (if you made a reservation). Try the asparagus salad with Yukon Gold Potatoes and Lemon Vinagrette. If you are feeling really frisky, go for one of their FANTASTIC Appletinis.
author: Aimee G.

description: There is not better place to celebrate special occasions over a meal than BLVD. It's a destination and experience second to none.
author: Michelle S.

description: I went for lunch during dine about town a couple years ago.  I had kobe beef and it was so good!  I would definitely go back.
author: Seong P.

description: I haven't been to Boulevard in 2 years, so my review is a little outdated, but I've always enjoyed the quality of the food here.  We typically rent out the wine room for private dining, which is very cozy and blocks out much of the noise from the main dining area.  The service is quite good considering we typically have around 8 people in our party, and they are attentive but not obtrusive.  As others have mentioned, the dress code is a bit too casual for my taste, but we still enjoy dressing up for a nice dining experience.
author: Mai S.

description: Nancy Oaks is an SF legend and her restaurant Boulevard garnets it. It has  one of the best dining rooms in the city and the ambiance inside brings it. Her pork dish is still signature as well as her duck creations. Service is on pace and knowledgeable. The vibe is always cool in here as it hasn't missed a beat in all the time this place has been opened. 5 stars nope, but a classic SF institution.
author: Jim S.

description:
when you have mentally ill relatives, or people who are like really socially weird in your circle, i feel that establishments such as restaurants all start to fall into two categories.

1.  places where the staff shits on you and makes you feel bad because youre not some like perfect-appearing android with no soul, like they want because it looks better through the windows and because they're deeply insecure about themselves 

or 

2.  places where the staff is confident and secure and wants to make sure everyone, even the crazies, has a good time

boulevard is DEFINITELY in group 2.  they are awesome with certain people in my life, the food is amazing, and i love love love the lighting concept. 

my menu last night, and replicated whenever possible:
sidecar
little gem lettuce
filet mignon pinot noir
chocolate fudge cake

RIDICULOUS!
author: threeholepunch y.

description: The food here is solid, but I doubt much has changed since the 80's.  Who serves lamb chops with mint sauce anymore?  The service can be a bit obnoxious, as well: "Is everything absolutely delicious?"  There are much better restaurants in SF for the money- I'd leave this one to the tourists with their Zagat guides in hand.
author: C. W.

description: I have thoroughly enjoyed every meal at Boulevard.   I may have enjoyed it even more since Mama treated this last time.
author: Amme P.

description: Highly overrated. Food is good but is over priced. Service is great but the ambience is a bit stuffy because they have an older clientele. However, the portions are big in comparison to the miniscule ones we usually get in some of the fine dining establishments in SF.
author: Belle M.

description: Wow.  Had a great birthday dinner at Boulevard.  Everything was right on.  We showed up an hour early for our reservations and got seated right away.  We asked for a riesling off the wine list and the somelier made it appear.  The food was excellent.  We had the frois gras (not really pc) the gumbo, the sonoma spring duck and filet mignon...all excellent and delicious.  The service was impeccable.  Bravo!
author: Alex L.

description: I don't usually hyperventilate and get all intimated by food. But y'all this place got some serious reviews and is one of the best in this fair city of ours.  First of all the place was gorgeous and our seating was primo. I loved how everything was elegantly presented and not over frilly. The food was simple but mouth-gasmically good.
author: Sophia C.

description: The food is really good, specially their meats.  the service there can be a little phony... and i felt a little discrimnated against being young.  i made reservations a month ahead, and they still wouldnt get me a seat in the back of the resturant.... sat where everyone was walking by the whole night... wtf right? might as well just have walked in to get that type of seating...
author: Doug ..

description: Went here on a whim after work one day.  Good food, nothing to write home about, which for that price, you'd expect something somewhat memorable.  The sommelier was helpful- and picked a wine that both my coworkers (who preferred lighter body/fruitier) and i liked.  the food was good, but again, not superb.  finally had foie gras- which i'm told was not the best.  go if you're not paying.
author: Rohit G.

description: The new husband and I ventured to Boulevard for a romantic night out.  And I can understand the allure of the establishment: warm inviting decor, intimate setting, and enticing food.  However, as much as I like fancy expensive eats, I felt like I could have enjoyed better for the same amount somewhere else.  And it seemed like the place was just too loud with conversations.  Thank goodness we were given a gift card to the place.
author: Eidelyn G.

description: Very  special evening, but everything was quite good. The service was genuinely good.  I took off a star because it's so damned expensive. But I guess they gotta pay all them cooks that have debt to pay from chef school.
author: Cristian M.

description: Oh boy!!! This would be a regular stop if it were in LA.  Such a great place! The flavors were awesome, the dessert kick butt (my husband actually ate and finished it!) And the building itself is gorgeous! Loved the stuffed calamari and buffalo carpaccio.  My lamb was pretty right on! Nancy Oakes is one talented woman.
author: Maybeth F.

description: We hadn't been to Boulevard for several years; it was even better than we remembered. The beet salad and crab appetizer were wonderful and perfect to share. The duck entree was sublime: I wish I had been able to eat it all myself but had agreed to split it with my husband. Our waiter Danielle was perfect: funny, helpful, and attentive but not hovering. I will request her in the future. I like her no nonsense attitude and professionalism. Boulevard is still one of the finest restaurants in the city. I hope we can return more often! PS We were also lucky to get a seat at the bar in order to enjoy a cocktail while waiting for our table: we arrived an hour early exactly for that purpose.
author: Kris M.

description: Classic California cuisine. Small portions, large prices, impressive but noisy venue and very slow service.
author: Dan B.

description: I dined here for corporate luncheons twice. It was not impressive. I had a seafood cassoulet and the creme brulee. Which were all just mediocre. Cassoulet is not a fancy dish, I was surprised to see it. It was very bland and simple. The sugar on the creme brulee was so think I had to use a fork to puncture it. So won't be doing dinners here.
author: N G.

description:
The food is great.  The portions are decent-sized, as are the appetizers, in my opinion.  The atmosphere is enchanting, and the service was exceptional.  We sat far enough away from others to be able to have a conversation without needing to strain our ears to hear each other.  

The only undesirable part is with the restrooms across a hallway, through two doors and down the stairs.  That just doesn't seem very natural.  But places like this one are what San Francisco fine-dining is all about.  

The food here isn't cheap, but it is well made, and the overall experience is definitely worth it--most likely you will come away thinking that you will come here again sometime.
author: Stephen N.

description:
Everything in this restaurant is generally good. Food is very consistent, they never disappoint. I won't say that there is a particular dish that totally blows my mind though. Worth trying nonetheless.

Price is a bit expensive, but the place is good for business dinners. The ambiance is definitely more formal and a lil uptight. Gotta give them thumbs up for great service. 

Will I ever go back?? hmmmm maybe not but if you wanna try this place... Why not?? its not bad at all.
author: debora t.

description: I admit, I was a tad disappointed in Boulevard. I went for a work related lunch. We were seated fairly quickly and the service was all-around really great. Unfortunately, my coworker got a glass with lipstick on it (not cool), and I thought my meal- the seafood combo (scallops, prawns, mussels) was a tad bland. Boulevard is a classic SF restaurant- and its decor is unforgettable- its just a shame to be underwhelmed at lunch- I don't think I'll be going back for dinner on my own dime.
author: Kika S.

description: I was taken to Boulevard on a first date~  he scored big points for that!  Every course was orgasmic.  Each bite made my mouth water for more.  I can't leave out that the service was also phenomenal!!!  No wonder why it has been rated as San Francicso's best restaurant for the last 7 years.  Save room for dessert!!!
author: Paige C.

description:
Who should dine here:  People looking for a solid business meal (lunch or dinner) downtown; nice but serious atmosphere.  
 
1 Star - Lacking/Turn Off
2 Stars - Needs Work, But fixable
3 Stars - Adequate
4 Stars - Near perfect, rough edge here or there
5 Stars - Can't get much Better
 
Ambience/atmosphere: 4 stars.  I love the decor at Boulevard, it is very classy, but the employees and the clientele can make it feel a little stuffy or rather serious.  The restaurant itself is beautiful.  Not the best place for a romantic date though.  Attire is a little more dressy, given the large % of suits there on expense accounts.  
 
Service: 3.5 stars.  The service at Boulevard is generally very good, but not great.  I think it is often because it can get very crowded, and the staff are generally not able to give you the total attention you get at say a Quince or Gary Danko.  This was my experience last time, it felt like at certain times during the meal they forgot we were even there.  But in general it is pretty good, and the staff is knowledgeable on the menu, and their sommelier is great and can give you great advice on the wine list (see below).
 
Food: 4 stars. I would best describe the menu as French/Med. I used to think Boulevard had some of the best food in the city, not overall meal, just best food.  My last experience has caused me to change this a bit.  The food is really fantastic.  Just an example, last time I ordered the lamb done three ways.  Well my dish was cold, not warm, cold.  Like it had been sitting out for an hour.  But it was still so tasty I didn't bother to send it back, I can't imagine what it would have tasted like warm or hot.  The lamb was so perfectly cooked it melted in my mouth, and had very intense flavors that were nothing like the really earthy tastes sometimes found with lamb dishes.  The fish is generally a good choice here, I tried the butterfish last time and it was really fantastic.  Very rich, but extremely elegant.  For starters, tried the roasted butternut squash soup with Quail (a little disappointing) and the beef Carpaccio with fried oysters (great!).  The deserts here are very good, so save a little bit of room.
 
Wine: 4.5 stars.  Great wine list. Extensive, and fair pricing for a restaurant of this nature.  The by the glass list is great, however this part of the menu is a little overpriced, but at least they have good options.  I think Pinot goes best with the food here, especially the wines from Burgundy.  With the apps I would suggest a German Riesling.  But ask the sommelier after you choose your meal to make some suggestions in your price range.  
 
Overall: 4 stars.  Great place to go with a client on a business meal/meeting.  Would I go there on a date or with some friends, probably not.  Great food, great wine, but a little too serious for a fun/causal night out.  If you are visiting SF and staying downtown, consider it an option, but not a priority.
author: Scott P.

description: I tried Boulevard for the first time today and wasn't impressed. I give them 4 stars because the atmosphere, service, and food were all good. It had no soul, though, and the food was totally uninspired, tasted just like any other standard 5 star meal at any hotel or fancy restaurant anywhere in the world. I had the Kobe Beef roasted in wood oven. I just wasn't inspired by the experience ...
author: Eater S.

description: Big fan of this place.  Classy and intimate.  Wonderful food and service.  I hear a lot of celebrities come here while in SF.  I've never seen any, but that doesn't stop me!
author: Doctor G.

description: Great atmosphere, impeccable service and phenomenal food command no other than the five star Yelp rating.  As a sidenote, I saw a lot of amex platinum being pulled out on surrounding tables so that should hopefully give you an idea of the cost.  I would highly recommend as an appetizer the bay scallops with lemongrass noodles.  The noodles tasted straight out of a thai dish and complemented the scallops perfectly which had a little bit of hot sauce attached to it.  The abalone was also very delicious and something not found on many menus.  For the main course, both the seabass and halibut are great choices.  The seabass comes with risotto below it and the halibut is paired with different types of beans and a crab stuffed calamari body.  Bottom line is that I do not think you can go wrong at this restaurant except maybe the desserts.  Maybe it is the fact that my expectations just kept increasing as the meal progressed, but the  mudslide dessert was not on par with the appetizers and main courses.  Overall though, I was very pleased with my meal and I rolled out of the restaurant completely stuffed and satisfied.
author: Jason M.

description: Went for dinner over the long weekend. All food was great with the exception of steak, which was mediocre at best. Amazing lamb t-bone.
author: Boris B.

description: Honestly, I find this place is a touch over-rated.  Ambiance is nice, food is traditional and not very innovative.  Been for both lunch and dinner, and enjoy the bar before or after we go out, but the f= menu and food just don't do it for me, as I prefer light fare and more innovative cuisine.
author: Michele R.

description: Yes the food at this place is amazing but only 3 stars from me. We heard about Boulevard as soon as we moved to San Francisco so our expectations were very high. We went around holiday time so the atmosphere was great at the bar/restaurant. We had a great meal but when the bill came it was 240$ with tax and tip for 2 people. 2 apps, 2 entrees, and 1 dessert. We only had 2 glasses of wine and 2 beers so it's not like we drank much at all. Great meal but just not worth the price, with so many other options for restaurants in the city. Maybe this is to be expected anywhere close to the Embarcadero. A few other negatives, the restrooms are so far away from the restaurant, and the hostess was a little snooty. We were going to a show after dinner so we asked if she could help making sure a cab was there to pick us up in time and we were basically ignored. Yes the meal was great at this place but just not a great overall experience, don't think we'll be back.
author: Kate N.

description: After hearing all the good reviews, I thought I give this a try.  We had seared foie gras, that was ok.  scallops were recommended by our waiter n it was a bit salty, didn't taste any sweetness out of the "sweet scallops".  pork chops is suppose to be their signature dish, the meat tasted rough as if it wasn't brine, taste was blend.  filet mignon was cook to what was ordered but the meat wasn't top grade filet mignon.  we were reluctant to order dessert but after looking at the menu we decided to try one since we were there, we ordered the chocolate angel pie.  overall this is a historical bldg which made the restaurant look lovely, but we've had much better food than this.
author: Luxuriouskin L.

description: The first time we went here it was very good.  The filet mignon melted in your mouth the service was good and we were seated promptly despite a full dining room.  However, the second time fell short of the first visit.  Service was slow leaving an enormous gap between finishing our appetizer and getting the main course.  Furthermore, the filet mignon wasn't nearly as tasty as the first time which was a shame being that the first time it was delicious.  I went back the second time because I was impressed the first time, although now I can't say I'd be back as quickly.
author: Ikey S.

description: After more than thirteen years Nancy Oakes still has it. This is the heart of the resaurant city. While the staff has changed over the years, and not always for the better, the food is some of the best I have ever had the pleasure of consuming. The portions are still quite filling, the wines are perfect, keep on keepin' on!
author: Ian M.

description: Food is good but nothing exceptional. If you want a comparably priced meal, I suggest House of Prime Rib.
author: Alan K.

description:
Beautiful restaurant! beautiful views, attentive service, very good wine list (available on-line), but for me the food disappointing.

The hazelnut raviolis were greasy, heavy and tasted too much of blue cheese. I tasted the foie gras and it was overly seared and devoid of that wonderful rich/sweet that makes it worth ordering.  The fillet of beef was ordered medium, came rare and while the flavor was pleasant, the dish didn't really have much going for it, dull and uninspired sides.

The homemade ice cream was too sweet and otherwise unexceptional.

If you don't need the environment, don't go for the food.  I even resisted the buying the cookbook (I think that's a first).
author: T T.

description: Excellent food, service, atmosphere.  By far my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Jaki B.

description: I went in to dinner at Boulevard with big expectations and they delivered! Great place with amazing food, great service and a nice atmosphere. It is an expensive dinner but well worth it. Foie Gras and Lamb where GREAT! This restaurant is great for business or a romantic evening which is saying something. This is one of the best restaurants in the city.
author: Matt L.

description: Boulevard is my favorite right now when I want to treat myself out for some awesome food and ambiance. Its a bit pricey, but its worth it. The menu always changes so try anything..its usually tasty! Do not pass up the chance to order the duck, Kobe steak appetizers, or lobster macoroni if you see it.
author: Ho C.

description: For starters, we ordered lobster ravioli and scallop, both were delicious and tasty. I had filet mignon as the main course, it was really good, it went  well with the boulejais red that I ordered. The dessert menu had a pretty good selection, we ended up with chocolate flour cake and almond cake, they both were accompanied by ice cream. Four of us together, bill came out to be $360 including tips. It's not bad given we each ordered drinks too.
author: Milan L.

description:
I have dined here twice. The food is excellent (as is to be expected) and priced accordingly. The space is beautiful. However, I find the service to be quite sterile. The waiters are nice enough, but when dining at a restaurant that charges upwards of 30 dollars an entree, I want the service to be exceedingly warm and convivial, not merely 'professional'.

I guess I feel there are many other options in the city where you could eat just as well for less money, and not in the company of the FiDi crowd.
author: katie m.

description:
stars = quality/price i.e. this is a 3 or 4 star joint masquerading as a 5 star palace.

What does it mean to be a celebrity chef?  It means that you once cooked and might have been pretty good, but then later you took to running a restaurant, then later, to owning a restaurant that's open 7 days/week while you're  living in the country with the landed gentry.  Perhaps you'll inspire and let free new innovative young chefs to try their own, or just to rubber stamp your old favorites reduced to the mean.  So now we are cooking for the owner and not for the client.  q.e.d.
Boulevard is not bad, just too large for its britches.  Quality of staff is mixed, prices are high, lack of personal service, gorgeous surroundings.  You make your choice.  You won't get a bad meal, but you may be disappointed due to rediculously high expectations.  In France, this would be a lovely bistro, with few expectations, plenty of wine, familiar waitstaff, and seldom needing a reservation more than 8 hours in advance.
But then, perhaps you need to be an insider to get the quality we read about.

After all this is said, how is it that the same group that owns Boulevard are able to consistently creative and excellent chow as Martini House in St. Helena?  Perhaps because the clientele demands it.  Let's try that in S.F.

P.S., I had a perfectly lousy meal at Gary Danko, with no staff that had a clue about the overpriced wine list.  Only tried it once, but at those prices, and long lead time for reservations, can they afford to ever fail.

Apologies.  I have two more local restaurant pans to write, but I love practically all other restaurants in the Bay Area.  Seldom can go wrong with the ethnics.
author: amnnor n.

description: Came here with a party of six for my friend's birthday and after putting down $120.00 per person we were still hungry for more food because the portions are small plated. We ordered these appetizers to share: tuna ahi tartare, scallops, beets and blood orange salad. I ordered the seabass and it was kind of overcooked. My other friends ordered filet mignon and it was not bad but too small for that price. We ordered three desserts to share and everything was only okay because I do not remember what we ordered. Even after dessert we were still hungry considering that we had quite a bit of bread, appetizers, entree and dessert and wine. This is by far the most pricey shared meal I ever had to treat a friend and leaving with an unsatisfied stomach.
author: Allison H.

description:
i ve been to boulevard a few times and tought the food was very good..i took my family from over seas telling them that boulevard is one of the best restaurants in the city...
app...scallops,foie gras .abalone were exceptional..the tuna tartare was missing something just bland and greasy chip didnt make things better.
main...pheasant w/raviloi,,walu, filet M...very good,,the pork chop w/cheek was just ok on the bland side..
service..was excellent she was attentive and very professional .
overall boulevard is well worth it!!
author: kobe b.

description: I was really looking forward to this meal because I had heard such wonderful things. My husband and I went for our wedding anniversary last week. We had reservations but it still took them over half an hour to seat us which was quite annoying. This restaurant was packed and super duper loud. We got sat all the way in the back which was nice and a little quieter. Our server took quite sometime to even take our drink order. We sat at our table for over 15 minutes with just the menus. Our server took our order at 9:15 and our salad and scallops finally around at 9:45. Our server was pretty apologetic about our food taking so long and ended up giving me a glass of wine "on the house". That was nice and all but getting there at 8:30 and not eating anything till 9:45 at this so called "hi-end" place was disappointing. It was literally the best lamb and scallops I have ever eaten but I was not impressed with the sides the lamb came with. Our dessert was small but hit the spot - we had the ice cream bon bons. I think I will go again but I am hesitant.......
author: Jennifer S.

description: We have been to this restaurant twice for our company's Christmas luncheon and every one of us just loved our meals.  I've had the salmon twice and it was divine.  The Scallop appetizer is wonderful.  Very nice ambiance and the service is great.  We will keep going back!
author: Rebecca R.

description: This is one of San Francisco's best. A great place to celebrate a special occasion. Wonderful food and very good service. Great view in the room that faces the Bay Bridge. The atmosphere here is a winner as well. What makes this place a big winner is the FOOD. I have never had a bad meal here. I've paid more and have gotten less at other upscale San Francisco restaurants. This is one everyone should try. If you have friends visiting from out of town, send them here. If you are a local, go here. I don't think you can go wrong.
author: Arthur W.

description: Maybe I am just being tough on them, but Boulevard was really just So So. I am not a food snob or anything like that. I guess this place was built up to be some amazing dining experience and it was just ok... The tables were super small, the portions left something to be desired, and the taste was just ok. I did not, Not enjoy anything, I just wish it could have been a little more excited on my taste buds.
author: Miguel V.

description:
Surprised that this was not as pricey or snotty that I had somehow thought it would be. We had called ahead and got a table immediately. 

The service left nothing to complain about. We were told the specials. All questions were answered. And they had a vegetarian platter for the day which our waitress explained in good detail. We were asked about our food as soon as we had a chance to work on it. The lemonade that day was delish!

The vegetarian platter was good. It was very well plated. The kale (equivalent high sounding name) was made wonderfully. There was a spinach with roaster garlic and potatoes that was divine! (Yummmm!) The potato risotto was perfect, you could bite into the potatoes not all just mashed up. I loved that!

The other dishes at the table were the pork, which I was told was succulent.  The chicken in the chicken salad was cooked to perfection! 

We had the chocolate dessert platter and it was ...(sigh) very well put together. Cocoa of different degrees of sweet made it very tasty indeed!

The one thing we did not understand was that there were three of us at the table and there were 3 sets of white linens. As we were siting down, (only) my white linen was replaced with a black one. Neither of us knew why so! Explanations anyone?
author: Chandra I.

description:
This is a good business-dinner spot as well as a special-occassion place. The crowd (both times I've been there) has been a bit stuffy.
It's more of a place to take your parents than to mingle with some eligible bachelors, if you catch my drift. NOT that every meal should be about getting your flirt on rather than chowing down, but you must admit a good ambiance and crowd is in order!
author: Nicole R.

description:
My mother was in town, so I decided it  was finally time to check this place out.  The restaurant is beautiful.  We sat in the back, over looking the bay and the bridge.  Quite spectacular, especially for a visitor from out of town.

We ordered cocktails, and my martini was quite wonderful.  Then an appetizer of scallops was divine, though rather small.  I have to admit at this point I was a bit disgusted that they serve fois-gras and sweetbread.  That goes against my morals, and usually I won't frequent a restaurant that serves these dishes.  But anyway, moving on to entrees.  I had an *amazing* filet of escolar.  My mother had halibut that was equally delightful.  And my girlfriend, who is vegan, has nothing to choose from.  Luckily the chef prepared something special, which turned out to be couscous, green beans, and some other vegetable in little copper cups.  Cute, but really small and not that special.  After finishing, I was full, but could have eaten more.  The portions weren't quite big enough.  And I know what to expect from fancy restaurants...

So the bill came, and it was a whopper.  We all agreed that while the food was exceptional, and the view spectacular, it was overpriced.  If they had just given us a bit more food, or had things cost a bit less, I'd give this place 5 stars.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Been going here ten years.  Absolute tops. Favorite restaurant in SF.

Fun watching the prices go up.  This was the first place where I saw soup break $13 a bowl.  

One time, their manager was incredibly professional and nice when one of my friends got sick after eating here (I do not know if it was Boulevard's fault).  We were sent a written letter of apology and comped a complete replacement dinner including all drinks.  This was, needless to say, insanely good service.

Some of the best food I've ever had.
author: david m.

description:
the best power lunch in SF

expensive but oh so worth it

if dining alone or not for business,
make a reservation to sit at the pastry bar
and watch them make the fabulous desserts

i really have no complaints about this place

it is excellent every time
author: Eva S.

description: After fifteen-ish years of being in business, and always busy, it's fair to say this restaurant is a San Francisco institution. It has everything going for it: location, service, bustling ambiance, high-end table wares, an ever evolving menu, an extensive wine list, and a very dedicated staff. To be able to open something at this level and in essence "own" all the parts of what makes a great restaurant great would be a heady undertaking. And one thing is for sure, the dishes are created and cooked with access to some of the best ingredients in the United States. Reserve well ahead, and as with many restaurants in San Francisco, its a good thing to know if there is a large convention in town...
author: David S.

description: Its expen$ive, but well worth it on special occasains.  Great place!  I always leave satisfied and I keep thinking about the next visit!! The city has many great restaurants and its difficult to go to them on a regular basis.
author: Demanding T.

description:
I've been here a few times, and its gotten better...:)
The menu is always a surprise since they use whatever is in season and they must be doing something right because whenever I go, it's packed. The Foie Gras Appetizer, Lamb, and Arugula/Pomegranate/Cheese/Squash Salad is really good. get some chocolate cake for dessert as well! 
But always be sure to reserve a seat since they are always busy!
author: Kathleen T.

description: Went for a business dinner a few weeks ago.  After all the hype around this place I was quite disappointed.  Had the fish which was oddly prepared, slightly overdone and generally unmemorable.  I do remember that it was very overpriced, however, along with the rest of the meal.  My new colleague also seemed less than impressed with his dish, though this was supposedly one of his favorite places.  One thing we could agree on was that the service was atrocious.  To get a drink order we had to flag someone down after waiting for more than 10 minutes, and it didn't get any better throughout the meal.
author: Matt C.

description:
Since it's Good Friday, I got the day off from work and decided to treat myself to a nice lunch.  I walked downtown on a beautiful day and pulled up a seat at the bar at Boulevard.  Good choice.  

I started off with a Bloody Mary -- stellar -- one of the best I've ever had.  The bartender (I believe his name was Seth) was very attentive and delivered first class service.  For my meal, I had the salmon, which was served on a bed of risotto with a side of asparagus.  Everything was cooked perfectly and I loved every bite.  

I finished the meal off with an expresso and enjoyed my walk home on a sunny San Francisco afternoon.  I hope every Good Friday is as good as this Good Friday.  It was, indeed, a very good Friday.
author: Luke P.

description: My daughter and I had lunch at Boulevard in early November.  5 Stars +++ for ambience. The space and what was done with it is truly spectacular.  5 Stars for caring, attentive service.  1 Star for the food.  My Roasted Pork Flat Iron with Brussel Sprouts was oversalted, as was my daughter's Short Ribs.  The Spanish Goat Cheese and Arugula Salad was salty.  We should have held the dressing.
