i made reservations for 5:30 pm. we got to the restaurant at around 5:20 and sat at the bar where i ordered one cosmopolitan martini. when we walked in, there were several people ahead of us and i noticed that the hostess was less than friendly towards them. the people who came looked like they came from a convention and didn't really know what type of restaurant they were going into.  i think the hostess could have done a better job asking them if they had reservations or whatever it is that hostesses should say in a situation like that. there was not one smile on her face. i mean come on! the restaurant is expensive, but an average american can afford to eat at that place every once in a while. when it was my turn to let her know that we arrived for our reservation, she still had that semi-rude expression on her face. i wanted to say, 'dude, crack a smile! you're in the hospitality/restaurant business!' but of course, i didn't. my husband and i sat at the bar to wait until our table was ready. hubby's not  a real drinker so just had water. at 5:30 pm sharp, our waiter appeared next to us, took my drink and sat us at our table. 

for starters, my husband ordered the calamari stuffed crab and i had pheasant and wild mushroom ravioli. i was in a search to find a ravioli dish that will rival the ones i had at j.t.p.'s wedding at the four season's hotel. boulevard's ravioli didn't even come close! it was good, but it wasn't great. nothing to write home about. 

the calamari was fresh but it was just ok. it came with tempura of baby leeks and fennel which to me was the highlight of the dish even though it was just meant to be a garnish. the tempura batter was so light and crispy. it make the leeks and fennel oh so tasty. 
 
for our main dish, he had the duet of angus short ribs while i had the suckling pig which was prepared three ways. i didn't like my dish at all. maybe i made the mistake of ordering pork when i'm not really into pork. but i was curious as to what suckling pig tastes like and how it was going to be prepared. i was terribly dissapointed. the pig tasted funky to me. (mapanghi is what i told my husband). 


i tried his short ribs and wasn't thrilled about it either. the only part of my dish that i enjoyed was the 3 pieces of gnocchi on my plate and one lonely stuffed mushroom. neither of us finished our entree but i was very pleased with waiter's suggestion of riesling to go with my entree, and an italian red wine (a nebbiolo and barbera varietal) called bricco manzoni that paired so well with paul's dish. since paul doesn't really drink, i finished both glasses but was craving more of that red wine. i'm not really a fan of rieslings since i like my wines more dry. the riesling is too sweet for my taste but it was good nonetheless. but again, the bricco is just heaven! i will look for this wine and buy some to enjoy at home. 

like the wines we had, the dessert was also excellent. we shared the sticky toffee pudding with a caramel custard top.  this was a great finish to an otherwise mediocre dinner. the custard wasn't too sweet, the biscotti was great. the ice cream had a hint of lavander that made you go, 'hmmm, i feel like i'm eating flowers!' and the candied kumquats are like candied calamansi minus the tartness.

overall, i give boulevard a 2 out of 5 stars the excellent wine list, the great dessert, and the excellent wait staff (except for the hostess). it was good that we only had to pay an extra $30 for our dinner because of our gift card. i wouldn't come back to this restaurant if i had a choice. i would rather walk the extra 50 feet and dine at ozumo's (will post this review next time) where i am guaranteed to enjoy each bite of whatever i decide to get. 

parking is 10 bucks.

summary: 2 stars out of 5; bad hostess, excellent waiters; excellent wine and dessert.
author: Almira C.

description: I took my daughter here for her birthday.  We had an outstanding dinner with excellent service.  We had reservations and it wasn't terribly crowded.  We were seated immediately.  The goat cheese and beet ravioli were amazing.  Each of our  fish entrees was excellent.  The service was generally attentive and helpful.  We both remarked that we hadn't seen a menu recently that had as many appealing offerings.  I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Sarah J.

description: go on your company's dime- looking around the dining room, it seemed that the other patron's were all clued in on this (except for me).  dinner was good, but not spectacular.  the short ribs, lamb, and tuna tartare stood out. i was just expecting more!
author: Big e.

description: by far one of my favorites in the bay area. top notch service, food, and design.
author: Patrick D.

description: Seriously awesome food.  Actually , cuisine.  Never had anything less than stellar there in like a dozen years.  I personally like to sit in the bar cuz i find the dining room a bit stuffy...
author: eiming j.

description: Finally returned to Boulevard after a year or two... and it was as memorable as it was the first time.  Everything was delicious!! The foie gras was good, but not the best I've ever had.  But don't get me wrong, it was overall one of the better meals I've ever had.  The raviolis and tuna tartare were delicious... not to mention the filet mignon... Yum!!
author: Liz G.

description: We went to Boulevard last night for my daughters 26 th birthday. We arrived promptly at 7:30 and we told to wait in the bar area for 20 minutes for out table. There is no place to really stand there - very uncomfortalbe start to the evenning. By 8:30 we had for first food - a" bite", and a drink. Each course takes about 30 to 40 minutes. The place was packed.  The kitchen staff all seems to be overworked and busy. The waiter did apologize for not being able to honor our reservation. Each course was delivered by a new person.  The food was great and the ingredients first class. The restaurant management is a disaster and we would not go back for that reason..The frois grois  is really good and for dessert I had a bon bon that was sthe size of an averagel colcolate. The pork chop is rather ordinary, the ahi great. Too bad they can't get it all together. They would make more money if they could turn a table in less than 2 hours on a wed. night. I must say the architecture- brick ceiling, peacock design in th floor, the Christmas Decorations and wreaths were fabulous and made up for some of the wait time. Was it the parivate party downstairs that messed up the whole restaurant... who knows. They need help in the management part.  It is a real scene restaurant not  place to have a reasonably paced dinner.
author: alice c.

description: can somebody say OVERRATED....i have been hearing about this place forever, I thought it was gonna be awesome...i was soo disappointed.  we ordered a $96 NY steak for 2, with lobster stuffed baked potatoes and asparagus in a hollandais sauce...sounds awesome right...well the baked potato was...but the steak was rare, had a taste of ham to it, and was served COLD, who eats cold steak....i sent it back...but ate the potato lol. then! i told them to make me a filet...its was decent, definitely not remarkable...but when i got down to the last bite, i found a hair in my food. im thinking to myself that this experience couldn't have been any worse. the wait staff was so nice i felt bad complaining, so i didnt...i figure id just yelp it. for appetizer we had the scallops -which were good, the ravioli - i thought they were ok, but my girlfriend loved them, and the crab salad - which was a rip off, but still pretty good.  Wayfare tavern is a better place if your looking for the same kinda food
author: Michael C.

description: No wonder Michelin left out Boulevard's.  I was there for my birthday last weekend and was so excited to finally go to the place after living in the city for 13 years.  When I walked in it was so beautiful and warm.  I was so excited.  Much to my surprise I found the food to be mediocre if we're going to compare it to other high quality restaurants in the city.  I got the sole which was over cooked.  The calamari was tough and the desserts were also unbalanced.  Though others at my table raved over the tuna tartare, I found it to be tuna subpar.  The server was young and immature and actually made faces to other servers as she walked away.  I don't think we were high maintenance - just like any other foodie in the city.  The busboy dropped silverware all over my friend and just smiled.  In general, the service acted as if 'the food will cover us.'  'our reputation will cover us.'  'our decor will cover us.' 'our chef's name will cover us.'  well, unfortunately, it did not at all in my book.  thank you Michelin for not including Boulevards.  perhaps your choices were not just editorial mishaps.
author: Lori m.

description: This place is great.  The foie gras is amazing!!!  I wish I could afford to go to Boulevard on a weekly basis.  It's not pretentious and everyone is very friendly.
author: TV J.

description: Used to be one of my favorites.  However, the quality seems to have slipped half a notch in that last year or so.  Still a great place.  Only four stars because of the high price.
author: sfnewyorker Y.

description: Ok, so there are a bazillion reviews already....but WOW Boulevard is outstanding!!  worth every last penny!
author: Amy B.

description: Great food and service. Had the seared scallops on risotto and steak on my second visit. The place gets pretty loud but never too loud that you cannot carry a regular conversation. We also dined in their private room. It was a cozy, seats 6-8 comfortably-- great for a business dinner or celebration with friends.
author: Teresa H.

description: This restaurant is an incredible feast for the senses. The atmosphere and food is fantastic. Anything you order on the menu is likely to knock your socks off. Their dessert offerings are impressive as well, the creme brulee, sorbets & cakes are melt in your mouth. Since this place is on the pricey side, it's an excellent choice for a special celebration.
author: Stephanie B.

description: With every restaurant having the same organic produce and free range meat at their disposal few menus are as simultaneously inventive, classic, and accessible as the ones being printed and served down at Boulevard. Went here last night with my wonderful other for our 5th year anniversary and was totally blown away by the service, the wine, and the food. The fried farm egg with the buffalo carpaccio was impossibly exquisite. The softshell crab and ahi tuna tartare were outstanding and the calamari rockefeller was the best twist on two standards (oysters r. and fried calamari tenticles) that I've ever eaten. When each app arrived the server did an excellent job of describing all of the minute components, which made eating the food all the more memorable. We shared the filet mignon for an entree - superlative. Inside it was red, warm, and it cut like a cube of firm butter. It's accompaniments - trumpet mushrooms, spinach, and bacon wrapped potatoes (little ones) - fit like a tailored suit. I am lucky that my other eats small because I got her last two bites. For the finish they made our night extra special by sending out a little piece of chocolate with our desserts that read "happy anniversary." Yes, it is a bit cheeseball, but sometimes it is better to over (rather than down) play certain milestones in one's life. And for this reason I couldn't be happier with our choice of restaurants for such an occasion. It is also nice when the service doesn't stop after you have paid the check - the doorman hailed us a cab, showed us out, and thanked us for our business. On a last note: if you are a person who describes a place like Blue Plate or Incanto as "pricey" this will certainly be out of your league. Prepare to spend and you will be rewarded (here as well as there).
author: pax r.

description: We went to Boulevard for my daughter's birthday. This was her request, a repeat of her birthday there three years ago. The entire experience was superb. The holiday decor was lovely and understated. We had a drink at the bar, and were ushered to our table the moment we paid the bar tab. Our table was at the back of the restaurant, at the street with a beautiful view of the Bay Bridge lights. Our sever was friendly and professional, the water glasses were kept filled, the food was fantastic. We each had a different entree (a rule in our family) and every one was fantastic (Pheasant, filet, lobster with risotto, walu). We ordered two desserts, the family favorite chocolate, and fabulous ice cream sandwiches made with ginger snaps and pumpkin ice cream. The birthday candle and chocolate "Happy Birthday" plaque topped it off. This was a lovely evening, certainly would recommend it to anyone who is looking for a great special event dinner. It's a bit too pricey for a casual event.
author: Ellen S.

description: this place is probably the best resturant in SF. get the crab cake app. to die for. food is great. both dinner & lunch. lamb is great too. the third time i was there we sat right next to Willie Brown. he recognized me from the night before at an event. good times.
author: Miss O.

description: walked in at lunch and asked for a wine to be decanted ahead for dinner.  arrived at dinner and wine was the right temperature, perfectly decanted, waiting for us.  great service, great food, great location, could not ask for much more.  buffalo carpaccio with fried oysters and tasso aioli were a highlight.
author: Mark F.

description: ok, so like this place is cool.  the service is very attentive, without being pretentious.  and even though we were clearly out of our element, being the dressed up little hipsters that we are, the staff was friendly and welcoming for such a bougie place.  why it gets four stars and not five?  first off, this place is as expensive as all hell.  the only reason we were even here was because my work give me a $300 gift certificate as a x-mas bonus.  now we had talked about splitting it up into two dinners, but that sure didn't happen, haha!  our grand total for the two of us was $232 (and that's without tip).  and you certainly don't go here to get stuffed with food.  it's all about the presentation, and organic flavor and voodoo or whatever, which was undeniably great.  the only items that were underwhelming was the almond cake that was part of a dessert dish that was just so normal compared to everything else that it couldn't help but pale in comparison.  and the specialty cocktails weren't necessarily to my liking.  out of the ones that i had, the black briar and the classic daquiri didn't really do the trick for me, but their boulevard margarita was pretty damn good, and all the wines we tried were really good.
author: eric i.

description: Having enjoyed what I would term a spectacular dinner a year ago at Boulevard (to the tune of $250 for 2 people), my out-of-town friend and I returned only to be sorely disappointed.  Notably, the service by Tim is absolutely THE BEST.  Tim is a pro and you want him to be your best friend cause he's so personable.  However, our experiences with other staff members were surprisingly negative.  The bartender was actually rather rude, probably thinking he's funny.  He made sarcastic remarks that didn't end with a giggle but with a smirk.  We initially sat at the bar near cellar door and everytime it was opened a distinct smell of rubber (probably a fan) blew into the bar area.  Not good!  We finished our drinks and were nicely accommodated by the hostess for seats at the counter rather than our reserved table.  The place was actually pretty quiet but it was a Monday night.  We choose the counter because we love to watch the cooks AND that's where Tim the waiter-supreme works!   Tim showed up with menus and we reacquainted ourselves to him, talking about other restaurants and SF experiences he had suggested for my out-of-town friend's info.  We then faced the menus which listed the usual suspects.  Tim suggested the chicken and the pork.  I was primed for lobster because I don't cook it at home but was convinced to order the chicken.  My friend ordered the pork.  All of the first plates were the same as previously offered so we skipped that course, opting, we hoped, for a great dessert.  My friend ordered another glass of wine and I simply drank water as it was a school night (not a money issue).  Eventually the wonderful Acme bread and THE BEST butter in the world showed up and we chowed on that.  When our order came, the portions were fine but the SALT CONTENT WAS OVER THE TOP -- on BOTH plates!  The chicken looked skinny and was dry.  The chicken ravioli were way undercooked, a bit greasy, and the sauce was inedible.  And talk about inedible, the kale was like straw and dry and without even butter.  One bite was all I could possibly stand.  My friend liked the pork dish except for all the salt.  It was certainly beautifully cooked but spoiled by the "seasoning."  And his kale (what a cheap side) was also sicko.  Oh, and his mashed potatoes tasted like they came directly from a box and had the consistency of GLUE!  They laid on the plate, a pale brownish-yellow, flat as could be!  So we were prepared to have dessert but when the menu came it was completely uninteresting.  I was hoping for their chocolate mousse but it was not offered.  So we went without.  I had a cup of their delicious coffee and my friend had a grappa that Tim suggested and it was excellent.  Needless to say, we mentioned the problems with salt, etc., to Tim and he immediately cleared our plates and ran to the kitchen to, no doubt, inform them of the problem.  The chefs, who were quite stiff and didn't converse politely with consumers, asked how we liked our meals and we told them the truth.  One said he would advise the back kitchen.  Our bill (2 entrees, 1 coffee, 2 glasses of wine and a grappa) came to $96.  We left Tim $30 tip (!!) and hurried out.  Will I go back?  Maybe not ... sadly, so.
author: Ted F.

description: With over 400 reviews Boulevard doesn't need another good one but I enjoyed myself so much here I figured I'd add my 2 cents. The food here is amazing! I walked by the fillet on the way to the table and knew I had to have it. It was by far one of the better cuts of meat I have had since I dined at Harris'. Our waiter was top notch and very attentive to our needs. We were there for a birthday and the he brought us a complementary dessert which we didn't even have to ask for. He picked up on the gift exchange going on at the table. Boulevard is expensive. My future in-laws were in town, otherwise I couldn't afford to go there but it is definitely the type of place I would splurge on with a tax return or bonus. The only reason why I am not giving it 5 stars is because they seated us almost 30 minutes late and the host didn't seem overly concerned that there was that much of a delay but I guess when your food is as good as it is at Boulevard you don't have to worry.
author: Sierra d.

description: I went to BLVD because the menu seemed very light and fresh, I thought this was possibly due to the female influence on the menu, and I was excited to eat a meal prepared by a female chef. The meal was fantastic but was the richest and heaviest meal we had while in SanFran. We started with the Goat cheese and beet ravioli w/ shaved truffles. The dish was OK but i felt the cheese overpowered the sliced truffles. I also had my first experience with sweetbreads, Im still having trouble explaining them, but they were great, and I will always remeber BLVD for this aspect. We also had the lamb which was portioned perfectly (very small) with risotto. The richness of this dish was amazing and after three bites I was stuffed.  We ended with a strawberry consomme and fresh berries and greek yogurt. A perfect end to the richness of the meal.  The meal at BLVD was definietly not what I had predicted, but I was extremely satisfied.
author: Jason D.

description: great food, great service, great environment, and excellent wine collection.
author: reza f.

description: sat at the bar.  its the best place to sit for a quick seat and a great view of the cooking.  was like watching the food network live!  Food was fantastic and the smore icebox dessert is super
